Title: U.S. Economy Experiences Strongest Quarterly Growth Since 2003

Article:

The United States economy has shown significant growth, with the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) soaring 5% on an annual basis in the third quarter, as reported by the government on Tuesday. This marks the strongest quarter of growth since 2003. According to Dan Greenhaus, chief global strategist at BTIG, "there's no doubt the economy has been great this year."

The robust growth was observed across various sectors, including business investment, consumer spending, housing, exports, and government spending. Consumer spending, in particular, increased to a healthy pace of 3.2%, compared with previous estimates for 2.2%. With gas prices remaining low, many expect this trend to continue through the holiday season.

Defense spending was a significant contributor to the third quarter's growth, surging 16%. This growth represents an upgrade from the Commerce Department's initial estimate of 3.9% growth, making it the third and final reading on GDP for the year. The stellar third-quarter growth also marks an acceleration from the very strong growth of 4.6% during the second quarter and the rough first quarter when GDP was -2.1% due to harsh winter weather.

The strong growth has led to a significant increase in hiring, with employers adding 321,000 jobs in November. This makes 2014 the strongest year for job growth since 1999. The solid growth could clear the path for the Federal Reserve to increase interest rates in 2015.

The American public seems to be taking notice of the positive economic headlines, as more than half of Americans now think the economy is in good shape, according to a new CNN/ORC poll released on Tuesday. This marks a significant improvement from October when just 38% of Americans said economic conditions were somewhat or very good.

However, it is important to note that new data released on Tuesday showed that orders of big-ticket items unexpectedly declined in November, suggesting businesses are hitting the brakes on investment. As a result, another quarter of 5% growth may not be expected to wrap up 2014.

Title: Gun-Rights Activists File Federal Lawsuit to Block Maryland's New Assault Weapons Law

Article:

Gun-rights activists in Maryland have initiated a federal lawsuit to prevent the enforcement of the state's new gun law, which includes restrictions on assault weapons and large-capacity magazines, before it takes effect on October 1. The lawsuit was filed Thursday in the U.S. District Court in Maryland.

The plaintiffs argue that the Second Amendment and case law protect their right to own assault rifles and magazines that hold more than 10 rounds. The Baltimore Sun reported that the plaintiffs include the Maryland Licensed Firearms Dealers Association, the Maryland State Rifle and Pistol Association, the National Shooting Sports Foundation, Associated Gun Clubs of Baltimore, and several other organizations, individuals, and gun shops.

The new Maryland law, passed earlier this year, bans 45 types of assault weapons, but allows those who currently own them to keep them. The law also limits handgun magazines to 10 rounds and requires people to submit fingerprints to the state police to obtain a license to buy a handgun.

Lawyers for the plaintiffs plan to ask a judge Friday for an injunction to prevent the law from taking effect, according to a spokeswoman for the National Rifle Association. A spokeswoman for Governor Martin O'Malley, a Democrat, expects the law to withstand the group's legal challenge.

John Josselyn, Associated Gun Clubs of Baltimore's legislative vice president, said in a statement that the restrictions are "an unconstitutional violation" of the Second Amendment rights of "law-abiding, responsible citizens."

"Together we are drawing a line in the sand where Maryland's gun control agenda tramples the fundamental individual right to defend oneself and family in the home," Josselyn said.

A spokesman for the Associated Gun Clubs of Baltimore Inc., one of the plaintiffs, said the new laws would keep honest citizens from being able to "choose effective firearms for defense in the home."

The pending new law has led to a significant increase in applications for firearm purchases, resulting in a backlog. In the last two weeks, state troopers said applications are coming in at the rate of 1,000 per day.

Maryland State Police said Tuesday that residents who have submitted handgun purchase applications before new requirements go into effect next week will not have to obtain a handgun qualification license. The agency said that troopers will not enforce the new requirements, which also include background checks and fingerprinting, on applications submitted by September 30.

As of Friday, slightly more than half of the more than 100,000 purchase applications received had been processed, according to the agency. The agency began 24/7 operations in December to process the applications, but the backlog continued to grow.

Earlier this month, state police said 20 law enforcement officers from other agencies began helping with background investigations. State law requires that the investigations be conducted by police officers.

Troopers also said that beginning last week, 24 data entry employees from the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services have been inputting information from applications. State police said several security measures were being taken to limit the access of DPSCS employees to the State Police database.

Title: FBI Interrogates Las Vegas Shooting Suspect's Girlfriend, No New Information on Motive

 Article:

 The girlfriend of the Las Vegas gunman who carried out the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history was questioned by the FBI on Wednesday. Marilou Danley, who is regarded by investigators as a "person of interest," stated through her lawyer that she had no idea the shooter, Stephen Paddock, was planning violence.

 Danley, 62, said in a written statement read to reporters by her attorney in Los Angeles that Paddock never said anything to her or took any action that she understood to be a warning of the impending violence. Clark County Sheriff Joseph Lombardo told reporters he found it hard to believe that Paddock could have assembled the arsenal of weapons, ammunition, and explosives recovered by police completely on his own.

 Nearly 500 people were injured when Paddock, 64, opened fire on an outdoor concert from his 32nd-floor suite of the Mandalay Bay hotel on the Las Vegas Strip on Sunday night. He took his own life before police stormed his room, bringing the total death toll to 59. Police recovered nearly 50 firearms from three locations they searched, nearly half of them from the hotel suite. Twelve of the rifles there were fitted with so-called bump stocks, officials said, allowing the guns to be fired almost as though they were automatic weapons.

 In response to a question, Lombardo said investigators were examining the possibility Paddock's purchase of more than 30 guns in October 2016 may have been precipitated by some triggering event in his life. If Paddock did have any accomplice, there remained no evidence as yet "to indicate terrorism" in the shooting spree, said Aaron Rouse, FBI special agent in charge of the Las Vegas field office.

 Earlier in the day, U.S. President Donald Trump visited Las Vegas, marking the first time since taking office that he has had to confront a major mass shooting. In her statement after being questioned in Los Angeles, Paddock's girlfriend Danley insisted she knew Paddock as "a kind, caring, quiet man." Danley, an Australian citizen of Filipino heritage, said she flew back to the United States voluntarily "because I know that the FBI and Las Vegas Police Department wanted to talk to me, and I wanted to talk to them."

 Danley, who was twice married before her relationship with Paddock, became a focus of the investigation for having shared his retirement community condo in Mesquite, Nevada, northeast of Las Vegas, before leaving the United States for the Philippines in mid-September. FBI agents met her plane at Los Angeles International Airport before interviewing her, two U.S. officials briefed on the case told Reuters. As of midday Wednesday, there was no indication she was aware of Paddock's plans, they said.

 Investigators questioned her about Paddock's weapons purchases, a $100,000 wire transfer to a Philippine bank that appeared to be intended for her, and whether she saw any changes in his behavior before she left the United States. "Assuming she had no role in his actions, the most important thing is any light she can shed on Paddock's motive," said one official, who spoke about the investigation on condition of anonymity.

 Danley said Paddock had bought her an airline ticket to visit her family and wired her money to purchase property there, leading her to worry he might be planning to break up with her. Paddock's brother Eric told reporters the $100,000 transfer was evidence that "Steve took care of the people he loved," and that he likely wanted to protect Danley by sending her overseas before the attack.

 She arrived in Manila on Sept. 15, flew to Hong Kong on Sept. 22, returned to Manila on Sept. 25 and was there until she flew to Los Angeles on Tuesday night, according to a Philippine immigration official. Discerning Paddock's motive has proven especially baffling given the absence of the indicators typical in other mass shootings. He had no criminal record, no known history of mental illness, and no outward signs of social disaffection, political discontent, or extremist ideology, police said.

 Trump, touring a hospital in Las Vegas, told reporters Paddock was "very demented," and he asked Lombardo if investigators were any closer to establishing a motive. "We've had a couple good leads and we're working our way through it," Sheriff Joseph Lombardo told the president.

Title: Biden Campaign Outraises Trump's in Second Consecutive Month

Article:

In a significant development four months before the upcoming presidential election, the campaigns of President Donald Trump and his challenger, Joe Biden, have announced their fundraising totals. The Biden campaign has surpassed Trump's fundraising efforts, marking an unusual occurrence for a challenger to outraise an incumbent president.

Trump's reelection campaign and the Republican National Committee announced on Wednesday evening that they had raised $266 million for the three months ending June 30, including $131 million in June alone. In contrast, Biden's campaign and the Democratic National Committee announced they had raised $282 million during the last quarter and $141 million in June.

Jen O'Malley Dillon, Biden's campaign manager, wrote in an email to supporters, "It's clear that voters are looking for steady leadership, experience, empathy, compassion, and character—and they'll find all of these qualities in Vice President Joe Biden."

While Biden has conducted frequent fundraisers with high-dollar donors, his campaign emphasized its success in growing its list of small donors, with the average online donation last month being $34. The Trump campaign is boasting its substantial cash-on-hand war chest, now totaling $295 million, largely due to the early start Trump's campaign and fundraising efforts received upon his inauguration.

The Biden campaign has not disclosed its current funds, with full numbers to be available no later than July 20. The Trump campaign's focus on ad spending appears to be on holding onto states won in 2016, including some that were previously considered safe for the president. The Trump campaign has reserved nearly $100 million worth of ad time this fall in Arizona, Florida, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin, and is also buying ads in Georgia, Michigan, and Iowa, states Trump won in 2016.

The Biden campaign's fundraising surge coincides with national and state polls showing the president lagging behind Biden, partly due to the Trump administration's response to the pandemic and protests against racial injustice. The most recent Electoral College battleground analysis from NPR shows neither candidate currently has the 270 electoral votes needed to win the presidency, but Biden is closer with at least one state Trump previously won—Michigan—leaning his way, while the president has failed to make progress in states that Democrat Hillary Clinton won in 2016.

Title: House Speaker Pelosi Announces Delay of Impeachment Vote, Citing Constitutional Duty

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) announced Tuesday evening that the lower chamber would not be taking a formal vote on whether to initiate impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump at this time. In a meeting with the House Democratic caucus, Pelosi stated, "We're not here to call bluffs — we're here to find the truth, to uphold the Constitution of the United States. This is not a game for us. This is deadly serious."

According to Fox News, congressional aides privy to the closed-door discussions reported that Democrats do not wish to appear to be complying with the Trump administration's demands, following the White House's refusal last week to cooperate with the ongoing impeachment probe due to the lack of a floor vote authorizing the proceedings.

In an 8-page letter to Pelosi and other top Democrats, Counsel to the President Pat Cipollone wrote, "In the history of our nation, the House of Representatives has never attempted to launch an impeachment inquiry against the president without a majority of the House taking political accountability for that decision by voting to authorize such a dramatic constitutional step."

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) criticized House Democrats for abandoning due process in a speech from the Senate floor earlier in the day. McConnell stated, "House Democrats are finally indulging in their three-year-old impeachment obsession, full steam ahead." He went on to remind his colleagues that some Democrats had declared their plans to impeach President Trump before he was even inaugurated.

McConnell continued, "I don't think many of us were expecting to witness a clinic in terms of fairness or due process, but even by their own partisan standards, House Democrats have already found new ways to lower the bar." He added, "For all the public hyperventilating over institutional norms that we've heard from House Democrats, it appears they have no intention of letting norms, precedents or basic due process stand in the way as they seek to cancel out a presidency."

Title: China's November Exports and Imports Show Slower Global and Domestic Demand

Article:

China's November exports grew at a slower pace than expected, with a 5.4% increase year-on-year, according to Chinese customs data released on Saturday. This marks the weakest performance since a 3% contraction in March and is significantly below the 10% forecast in a Reuters poll. The slowdown in exports is attributed to the fading impact of firms rushing out shipments to beat planned U.S. tariff hikes and cooling global demand.

China's exports to major partners showed significant annual growth slowdowns. Exports to the United States rose 9.8% in November, compared with 13.2% in October, while exports to the European Union increased by 6.0%, down from 14.6% in October. Exports to South Korea fell year-on-year, contrasting with a 7.7% rise in October.

Import growth was 3%, the slowest since October 2016, and significantly below the 14.5% seen in the poll. Imports of iron ore fell for a second time, reflecting waning restocking demand at steel-mills as profit margins narrow.

Wang Jun, chief economist of Zhongyuan Bank in Beijing, commented, "The sluggishness in imports and exports is in full swing." He added that the soft imports "show a relatively significant pullback in domestic demand."

In recent months, Chinese exports had expanded robustly, which economists attributed to front-loading of cargoes before a now-postponed plan to hike U.S. tariffs of $200 billion of Chinese goods to 25% from 10% on Jan. 1. The November trade numbers came out less than a week after Presidents Donald Trump and Xi Jinping agreed to a 90-day truce, delaying that tariff hike as they negotiate a trade deal.

Stirring fears of a reignition of trade tension, the daughter of Huawei Technologies' founder, a top executive at the Chinese technology giant, was arrested in Canada on Dec. 1 and faces extradition to the United States, threatening to drive a wedge between the U.S. and China.

U.S. President Donald Trump, on Friday, sounded an optimistic note about trade negotiations with China as his top economic advisers downplayed friction from the arrest of Meng Wanzhou. "China talks are going very well," Trump said on Twitter, without providing any details.

Analysts at Haitong Securities in Shanghai noted, "Growth in shipments of Chinese goods on U.S. 200 billion tariff list has started to pull back, indicating that frontloading effects may be starting to recede." They added, "Now with U.S. and China agreeing not to escalate trade tensions any longer, China will start purchasing U.S. agricultural goods, which may narrow China-U.S. trade surplus in the future."

China's November trade surplus with the United States was a record $35.55 billion. The October surplus was $31.78 billion. But China's imports from the U.S. in November fell 25% from a year earlier, while the annual decline in October was only 1.8%. For trade with all countries, China's surplus was $44.74 billion for November, compared with forecasts of $34 billion and October's surplus of $34.02 billion.

On Thursday, the U.S. reported that its global trade deficit in October jumped to a 10-year high, and that the deficit with China surged 7.1% to a record $43.1 billion.

Economists say one factor helping keep up Chinese exports this year is that the yuan has weakened more than 5% against the dollar, helping to make Chinese products more competitive abroad. Jonas Short, head of the Beijing office of brokerage Everbright Sun Hung Kai, said the weaker yuan "should boost industrial exports over the coming months."

Economists in recent months have penciled in a deterioration in China's export outlook in 2019, factoring in higher U.S. tariffs on a wider range of Chinese goods. Chinese policymakers are expected to offer more policy support and deliver more support measures if domestic and external conditions continue to deteriorate.

China's central bank has cut the amount of cash that banks must hold as reserves four times this year, as policymakers seek to steady the slowing economy amid the trade war with the United States. The government aims for growth of around 6.5% this year, compared with 2017's 6.9% pace. Yang Yewei, an analyst at Southwest Securities in Beijing, said that as global demand cools, "domestic growth-boosting measures should be more effective."

Title: Constitutional Moment: Trump's Actions and the Erosion of the Rule of Law

Article:

In a series of lectures and publications, Yale Law School professor Bruce Ackerman has proposed a theory of constitutional change known as "constitutional moments." This theory suggests that constitutions can be altered not only through the formal amendment process but also when prominent political actors act contrary to the existing constitution, and their actions are accepted and validated by the people, thereby establishing a new constitutional norm.

The current political climate in the United States is characterized by some as a constitutional moment in Ackerman's sense. In an op-ed titled "Trump's firing of Comey is a crisis of American rule of law," Harvard Law School constitutional law professor Noah Feldman argues that President Donald Trump's firing of FBI Director James Comey represents a blow to the unwritten constitutional norm of political neutrality.

Feldman contends that while Trump's actions were technically within his constitutional rights, they violate an unwritten norm that has developed under the living constitution, which emphasizes the independence of law enforcement and political neutrality. This norm may be becoming more important than the traditional power of democratically elected politicians to supervise and fire officials in the executive branch.

The development of this norm has led to the emergence of a powerful "administrative state" in Washington, consisting of career bureaucrats who see themselves as above politics and believe they are running the country. Temporary political appointees who offend these careerists do so at their peril, as evidenced by the forced resignation of former EPA administrator Scott Pruitt due to a series of ethical lapses leaked by career staff who did not approve of his policies.

The current constitutional moment raises questions about who is truly running the country: the elected president or the career bureaucracy. This question was addressed by former FBI Director James Comey in his testimony to Congress following his firing, in which he stated that while the president may have the constitutional right to fire him for any reason, doing so for an inappropriate reason could be considered an impeachable offense.

The development of this new constitutional order, in which career bureaucrats wield significant power and influence, has been compared to systems such as the European Union and the United Kingdom, in which the career experts in the European Commission and the people's representatives in Parliament and the Council have gradually been consigned to rubber-stamping the laws they propose.

As the Trump administration continues, the power dynamics between the elected president and the career bureaucracy will likely remain a topic of debate and discussion. Early in this administration, former House Speaker Newt Gingrich predicted that President Trump would put up with the career bureaucracy telling him what he could and could not do for only about 60 days, after which he would "break this town." Whether Trump will "break" the system or be "broken" remains to be seen.

Title: San Bernardino Considering Legalization of Medical Marijuana for Revenue and Regulation

Article:

The bankrupt California city of San Bernardino, known for its historical significance as the site of the 2015 San Bernardino shooting, is exploring the possibility of legalizing medical marijuana and taxing its sale as a means of generating revenue and regulating the industry. The idea was spurred by concerns about the proliferation of illegal medical marijuana dealers in the city.

City Attorney Gary Saenz stated that a legislative review panel has been formed by the City Council to study the idea. This panel is collecting data, consulting with the city police department, and examining laws in other jurisdictions before bringing a proposal to the full committee. The panel plans on holding at least two more public meetings on the subject through August.

Police have reported as many as 20 illegal storefronts in the city at any given time, according to Saenz. Legalizing and regulating the now-unwieldy industry, he feels, is one of the tools available to the city to take control of the situation.

City Council member James Mulvihill expressed his support for the idea, citing the high cost of enforcing against illegal dealers. He stated that it costs the city $10,000 every time it goes after an illegal dealer. Any funds gleaned from the regulation and tax of marijuana dispensaries, according to Mulvihill and City Council member Michael McKinney, would be used exclusively for enforcement.

Mayor R. Carey Davis, according to McKinney, prefers not to see any marijuana dispensaries in the city, but is open to exploring all options to address the current problems. McKinney stated that his office has been receiving calls advocating both sides of the issue.

It is important to note that San Bernardino, with a population of 209,924, has maintained an outright ban on pot shops since medical marijuana was made legal through a ballot referendum in 1996. This was reaffirmed last year when the state Supreme Court in San Francisco unanimously ruled that local jurisdictions have authority to prohibit medical marijuana despite its legality at the state level.

San Bernardino declared bankruptcy in 2012, becoming the largest city in the U.S. to do so. Mulvihill emphasized that his support for the dispensaries is narrow, stating, "I’m doing this because of the trouble we’re in -- we can’t control it."

Title: Cuba in Mourning: Life Without Fidel Castro in 2016

Article:

Cuba is currently observing an official period of mourning following the death of longtime dictator Fidel Castro, who passed away last Friday. NPR's Carrie Kahn is in Havana and reports that the usually bustling city is unusually quiet, with few people out in the streets and many establishments closed.

"It's quite unusual here in Havana," Kahn said. "Usually on a Saturday or Sunday night, there's tons of people out in the street all along the iconic sea wall, the Malecon, listening to music, talking, drinking. There's none of that now. There's nobody out celebrating. Bars are closed. Discotheques are closed. There's no alcohol being sold in many restaurants. It's a very subdued scene here."

Fidel Castro, who officially stepped down as president in 2008, passing power to his brother Raul, remained a significant figure in Cuban life until his death. Raul Castro has been in power for at least 10 years, and while there is no expectation of significant changes in the immediate future, there is uncertainty about what the absence of Fidel means for Cuba.

"This is the first time in decades that there is Cuba without Fidel," Kahn said. "He was really out of the limelight a lot, but in 2016, we heard from Fidel two times."

The first time was in response to President Obama's historic visit to Cuba in March, during which Fidel criticized the United States. The second time was during the Cuban Communist Party's once-every-five-years Congress, where Fidel appeared on national television, looking frail and praising communism.

Kahn, who has been to Cuba several times since the opening in 2014, reported that opinions about Fidel Castro vary among Cubans. Some older people expressed sadness and pain, while others were glad he was gone and hoped for more change.

"We'll just have to see if that was the truth," Kahn said, referring to the possibility that Fidel was the one putting the brakes on economic reforms and the opening. "There have been few political openings, especially in the last two years. There have been more detentions and more repression of human rights activists and people fighting for open political expression here."

Kahn emphasized that the focus of the opening has been on economic, not political, changes. It remains to be seen what the future holds for Cuba without Fidel Castro.

Title: French President Macron Urges U.S. to Maintain Global Engagement in Address to Congress

Article:

French President Emmanuel Macron addressed the United States Congress on Wednesday, praising the country for its global leadership and urging it to maintain an open perspective on international threats. In his speech, Macron emphasized the importance of avoiding isolationism and nationalism, which he argued would only exacerbate fears and not provide lasting solutions.

During his three-day state visit, Macron, the first foreign leader to be granted an official state visit by the Trump administration, has enjoyed a series of pompous and cordial meetings with President Trump. However, on Wednesday, Macron showcased his independent centrist stance by addressing subjects of disagreement between the two leaders, such as isolationism and nationalism, which are key components of Trump's "America First" agenda.

Macron urged the U.S. not to "close the door to the world," stating that isolationism and nationalism are temporary answers that would only inflame, rather than alleviate, the fears of its citizens. His speech was met with a three-minute standing ovation and was described as an uplifting, emotional, and history-laden tribute to the "miracle relationship" shared between the U.S. and France.

Since Monday, Macron and his wife, Brigitte Macron, have been feted by the Trump administration with the first state dinner, a tour of monuments, and a review of U.S. troops. The visit has been marked by a growing chemistry between the two leaders as they consider pressing global threats, including Russian aggression, the Syrian civil war, climate change, North Korea, and the Iran nuclear deal.

On Tuesday, this chemistry seemed to produce a diplomatic breakthrough for the Iran deal, with Macron moving closer to Trump's harsh critique of the agreement. On Wednesday, Macron seemed to backtrack from Tuesday's harder line, stating that the deal should not be abandoned before "something more substantial" is developed.

Macron also prodded the Trump Administration on the Paris climate agreement, which Trump canceled U.S. involvement in at the start of his presidency. Macron expressed confidence that the U.S. will rejoin the accord.

In discussing climate change policy, Macron made a direct reference to Trump's 2016 campaign pledge "Make America Great Again" by stating, "Let us work together in order to make our planet great again and create new jobs and new opportunities while safeguarding our earth."

On terrorism, the French leader noted shared efforts to combat extremism and lamented the multiple attacks in the U.S. and Europe over the past five years, which he called a "horrific price to pay for freedom and democracy."

Macron also took direct aim at the scourge of "fake news," warning that lies disseminated online threaten freedoms worldwide. "Without reason, without truth, there is no real democracy," he said, adding that "the corruption of information is an attempt to erode the very spirit of our democracies."

An hour before the address, Trump tweeted, "Busy day planned. Looking forward to watching President Macron of France address a Joint Session of Congress today. This is a great honor and seldom allowed to be done...he will be GREAT!" The speech coincided with the 58th anniversary of a Washington address to Congress by then-French President Charles de Gaulle.

Title: U.S. Policy Shifts and Their Potential Implications for the Middle East

Article:

The recent comments of Omid Memarian, a human rights expert at the Center for Human Rights in Iran, suggest that Iranian leaders fear a resurgence of the Green Movement, a political movement that emerged following the disputed presidential election in 2009. Memarian's observation is that the Iranian authorities' harsh treatment of human rights lawyers is indicative of their fear of exposure and a desire to evade accountability.

However, the task of supporting the Green Movement, as was done for Solidarity in Poland during the Reagan administration, has become more challenging due to President Trump's indifference towards human rights issues and his policies towards migrants. The potential strategic repercussions of this shift in American values are being observed in the Middle East.

The article also suggests that the Trump administration's policies could mark the end of the American era in the Middle East. Trump's willingness to support Saudi Arabia, even in the face of human rights abuses, and his desire to withdraw from Syria and Afghanistan, could benefit Iran in both cases. The article also notes Trump's reluctance to re-establish deterrence with Tehran through a limited military response and his general skepticism regarding America's role in policing the global commons.

The article further discusses the potential consequences of these policies for traditional U.S. allies in the Middle East. It is noted that Saudi Arabia, despite its large military budget, is unable to defend itself and may be undefended if the U.S. does not provide protection. The article also points out the potential for Iran to take advantage of this situation, given the large and unhappy Shiite minority in eastern Saudi Arabia.

The article concludes by suggesting that the U.S.'s response to an unprovoked attack on a central pillar of the global economy is a test of American leadership. The consequences of failure will be felt for years, and this should be a concern for the new National Security Advisor, Robert O'Brien.

Title: Obama and Congressional Republicans Differ in Lessons from Fiscal Cliff Deal as Budget Deadlines Approach

Article:

President Obama and congressional Republicans have drawn contrasting lessons from the deal to avert the "fiscal cliff," as they prepare for negotiations on a series of budget deadlines that carry risks such as crippling defense cuts and a government default.

In a statement, Mr. Obama emphasized the deal set a precedent for agreements on deficit reduction and federal spending, requiring wealthier individuals or corporations to pay more taxes. He stated, "The deficit needs to be reduced in a way that’s balanced," and "Everyone pays their fair share."

However, many Republicans argued that the agreement this week gave Mr. Obama all the tax increases he would ever get, and future deals must focus on spending cuts. Some Republicans, such as Sen. Patrick J. Toomey of Pennsylvania, suggested they might force a government shutdown to make their point in negotiations over raising the nation's borrowing limit, a measure the president said he no longer debates.

Both sides will have the opportunity to test their principles soon. The bill approved by the House on Tuesday postpones steep, automatic spending cuts until March 1, giving the White House and Congress less than two months to agree on an alternative solution to reduce deficits. This fiscal deadline will be followed by another on March 31, when temporary legislation to keep the government running is set to expire.

Looming over both of these cutoff dates is the even more contentious question of raising the nation's debt ceiling of $16.4 trillion. The government technically has already reached its borrowing limit, but the Treasury Department is taking steps to postpone the day of reckoning until late February or early March. After that, the government would start defaulting on its debts, a scenario that Mr. Obama described as reckless.

"If Congress refuses to give the United States government the ability to pay these bills on time, the consequences for the entire global economy would be catastrophic—far worse than the impact of a fiscal cliff," the president said late Tuesday at the White House.

Mr. Obama stated his protracted feud with Republican leaders over raising the debt ceiling in the summer of 2011 hurt the economy. "The last time this course of action was threatened, our entire recovery was put at risk," Mr. Obama said. "Consumer confidence plunged. Business investment plunged. Growth dropped. We can’t go down that path again."

The president stated he "will not have another debate with this Congress" over raising the debt limit, but it's hard to see how he can avoid it if Republicans want to use the issue as leverage to achieve spending cuts.

As for the president's argument for more revenue, Republicans argued this week's agreement ended the question of taxes. Rep. Dave Camp of Michigan, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, stated, "We can and will pursue comprehensive tax reform this year, in 2013, and next steps. We need to address the fundamental driver of our deficits and debt, and that is out-of-control spending."

Both sides dispute just how much the fiscal cliff bill accomplishes. While the president is hailing it as a deficit-reduction measure, the agreement would boost the deficit by $4 trillion over the next 10 years, when compared with a scenario in which Congress did nothing. Democrats argued the legislation will lower deficits by about $600 billion over 10 years compared with current policy, because doing nothing was never a realistic option. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office stated the bill will increase spending over the next decade by about $330 billion.

Title: Florida Resident Wanda Kos Discusses Life, Politics, and the 2012 Presidential Election

Article:

In the suburban town of New Tampa, Florida, located in Hillsborough County, Wanda Kos, a mother of three and daughter of Costa Rican immigrants, shares her thoughts on life, politics, and the upcoming 2012 presidential election. Kos, who wears sneakers and a gray T-shirt, lives in a neighborhood with stone countertops, high ceilings, and lush Florida palm trees.

Kos discusses the economic struggles her neighborhood faced during the financial crisis, with many residents experiencing foreclosures. She mentions that her family has moved several times and is aware that they may have to move again due to the unstable real estate market.

On the political front, Kos voted for President Obama in the last election but is undecided for the 2012 race. She expresses reservations about the Republican candidate, Mitt Romney, and is still deciding on her choice. Kos's decision is influenced by her son's recent enlistment in the Army, which has added an emotional dimension to her voting process.

Kos also discusses her views on social issues, stating that she agrees with President Obama on certain matters but is uncertain about Obamacare's impact on her personally. She has faced challenges understanding the healthcare reform's implications for her.

In the past, Kos and her husband would carefully consider their political choices, weighing the pros and cons of each candidate. She acknowledges that she questions many aspects of President Obama's administration but is still undecided on the Republican alternative.

Kos's story highlights the intersection of politics and real life in the United States, as she grapples with personal, economic, and political challenges while making crucial decisions that will shape her family's future.

Title: USWNT Lawsuit: A Timeline of the Gender Discrimination Case Against U.S. Soccer Federation

Article:

The United States Women's National Soccer Team (USWNT) is currently engaged in a gender-discrimination lawsuit against the U.S. Soccer Federation, which was filed in March 2019. The lawsuit gained international attention following the team's dominant victory in the 2019 Women's World Cup, with the crowd chanting "Equal Pay!" as the U.S. team celebrated their fourth World Cup victory on July 7, 2019.

Here is a timeline of the current lawsuit, according to reporting by ESPN:

* March 2019: The lawsuit was filed in U.S. District Court for the Central District of California under the Equal Pay Act and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act.
* July 2019: USSF president Carlos Cordeiro released an open letter, citing what he described as extensive analysis of 10 years of financial data. He said the data showed that from 2010 to 2018, the women's players were paid $34.1 million in salary and game bonuses by U.S. Soccer, compared to $26.4 million given to the men during the same time period. The men's and women's teams operate with separate collective bargaining agreements and pay structures.
* Nov 2019: federal judge R. Gary Klausner of the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California granted the USWNT's motion to give its lawsuit class certification. The early win for the women meant the lawsuit could include players who appeared for the national team dating back to Feb. 4, 2015. U.S. Soccer had opposed the motion for certification.
* Feb 2020: In February, the two sides filed very different motions in district court. Lawyers for the USWNT filed for partial summary judgment seeking back pay of at least $66.7 million in addition to punitive damages. USSF asked the court to dismiss the lawsuit "based on the actual facts in the record and the governing law."
* March 2020: The federation reversed course on the most contentious of its arguments. Cordeiro resigned on March 12 amid backlash from fans and sponsors to language in court filings attempting to show women's players did not perform work of equal skill, effort, and responsibility. Both Cordeiro and new USSF president Cindy Parlow Cone apologized for the language widely viewed as demeaning women's players and women's sports generally.
* May 2020: The trial was originally slated to begin on May 5 but was pushed back to June 16 after both sides sought guidance from the court in light of the coronavirus outbreak. California Gov. Gavin Newsom has issued a stay-at-home order in his state because of the global pandemic. U.S. Soccer publicly apologized for and legally walked back its most hard-line arguments. Indeed, it earned a fairly resounding win on the motion for summary judgment by focusing not on the idea that the women's players did not perform equal work but that the differences in CBAs did not constitute discrimination but fair trade-offs willingly negotiated.

The USWNT alleges that the federation engages in "institutionalized gender discrimination." The trial is set to begin on June 16, 2020. The outcome of the trial will determine whether the USWNT has experienced gender-based pay discrimination.

Title: North Carolina's 9th Congressional District: State Board of Elections Orders New Election Due to Absentee Ballot Fraud

Article:

The North Carolina State Board of Elections unanimously voted on Thursday to order a new election for the 9th Congressional District, following months of investigation into an absentee ballot scheme linked to the campaign of Republican Mark Harris. The decision comes after the board found evidence of illegal activity that "tainted the results of the entire election."

The results of the November 6th election, which showed Harris leading Democrat Dan McCready by 905 votes, have been in limbo due to fraud allegations. The 9th Congressional District seat has remained vacant in the new Congress as a result. The district spans the area between Charlotte and Fayetteville.

The board was tasked with reviewing the evidence and deciding whether to certify the November 6th results or order a new election in the district. Before the vote, Chairman Bob Cordle stated that the "illegal activity" uncovered had "tainted the results of the entire election."

Republican Mark Harris initially fought to have his November 6th win certified, including mounting a court challenge. However, he abruptly reversed course at Thursday's hearing, stating that he struggled with recall and confusion during the hearing due to a severe infection and two strokes he suffered last month.

After spending three hours on the stand, Mr. Harris returned from an extended lunch break and announced his change of heart. He also revealed that he was hospitalized last month with a severe infection and suffered two strokes.

Mr. Harris maintained that neither he nor leaders of his campaign knew about the scheme to "harvest" absentee ballots, which is illegal in North Carolina. The scheme was allegedly orchestrated by political operative Leslie McCrae Dowless, who refused to testify at the hearings.

The North Carolina Republican Party Chairman, Robin Hayes, stated that he respected Mr. Harris' decision. North Carolina Democratic Party Chairman Wayne Goodwin, on the other hand, attributed the wrongdoing to Mr. Harris and the Republican Party.

Kristen Clarke, president and executive director of the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, cheered the decision for the new election. She stated that the evidence of rampant absentee ballot fraud made clear that the outcome of the election was completely illegitimate.

The board will set the date of the election at a future meeting. Earlier, Mr. Harris testified that Mr. Dowless had assured him they were not breaking the law. However, documents and testimony presented by election officials indicated otherwise, including cases of collecting absentee ballots and filling in ballots for some voters. It is illegal in North Carolina for anyone other than a voter or a close relative to mail in an absentee ballot.

Title: Defense Teams for Sen. Menendez and Salomon Melgen Accuse Justice Department of Mischaracterizing Evidence in Bribery and Fraud Case

Article:

In a recent court filing, lawyers for Sen. Robert Menendez (D-N.J.) and his wealthy donor, Salomon Melgen, have accused the Justice Department of having a "fixation on sex and salacious headlines" and have reiterated their call for a court to dismiss bribery and fraud charges against them. The defense teams took aim at a contention by prosecutors and FBI agents that they had uncovered some "corroboration" for claims the men may have consorted with prostitutes at luxury homes in the Dominican Republic.

The defense lawyers argued that no witness or document, throughout the entire investigation, has ever accused Senator Menendez of being in the presence of a prostitute, much less engaged in relations with one. They also disputed the FBI's characterization of a black notebook found at Melgen's office as a "prostitution ledger." Melgen's lawyers claim the notebook was filled with innocent material, and the FBI mistook jottings about "Dixi" to mean a prostitute, when it was instead the name of a sanitation company in the Dominican Republic.

The court filings by the defense team foreshadow what could be a heated argument next week in a federal courthouse in New Jersey. Lawyers for Menendez and Melgen have accused the government of "serious misconduct," including media leaks, a preoccupation with the defendants' sex lives, and misstating facts to the grand jury that indicted the men.

Last month, public integrity prosecutors at the Justice Department said it was the defendants who were twisting the facts. Lawyer Peter Koski said authorities had conducted "an exhaustive, focused, and disciplined investigation" that produced a 22-count criminal indictment against the long-serving senator from New Jersey and his wealthy friend of about two decades. The indictment said Melgen paid for travel and housing for Menendez in exchange for a series of favors from the lawmaker.

U.S. District Judge William Walls has already refused defense requests to move the trial out of New Jersey. On Sept. 17, he will hear both sides argue a series of incendiary motions about critical pieces of evidence and the way authorities gathered information and presented it to grand jurors. The case is scheduled for trial in November, but either side may seek to appeal, perhaps delaying the trial into an election year. Once Walls rules on a critical issue in the case—whether Menendez is charged with crimes, in part, for actions he took in the course of his public service, protected under the Constitution's "speech or debate clause"—the trial will proceed.

Randall Eliason, a former prosecutor who now teaches at George Washington Law School, said in a blog post this week the case is "shaping up as a clash that will have all the quiet gentility of a New Jersey mob war."

Title: President Trump Proposes $2 Trillion Infrastructure Bill as Fourth Phase of Coronavirus Response

Article:

President Donald Trump has called for a $2 trillion infrastructure bill as the fourth phase of the federal government's response to the coronavirus pandemic. The proposal was made via a tweet on Tuesday, just days after Congress approved a massive stimulus package worth over $2.2 trillion.

In his tweet, Trump stated, "With interest rates for the United States being at ZERO, this is the time to do our decades-long awaited Infrastructure Bill. It should be VERY BIG & BOLD, Two Trillion Dollars, and be focused solely on jobs and rebuilding the once great infrastructure of our Country! Phase 4."

Trump has long sought a major infrastructure bill, and this proposal appears to be a renewed pitch as an economic stimulus measure. The president's tweet comes as lawmakers in both the House and the Senate are already considering a fourth coronavirus response bill, although some have expressed caution about continuing to appropriate such large sums of money.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) recently stated, "I think the odds are we'll need more legislation. First, we don't know the extent of the crisis in terms of the magnitude, so that could rise. But there are going to be problems that we don't realize now that we'll have to grapple with." Schumer's comments were reported by The Hill.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) also expressed the need for further legislation, telling CNN that Democrats "had bigger direct payments in our bill, and we think we'll get more direct payments in another bill."

In a fourth stimulus package, Democrats are reportedly seeking additional funding for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), also known as food stamps, as well as emissions restrictions on airlines—a measure that was blocked from inclusion in the package passed last week. Pelosi also plans to push for pension protections, which did not make it into phase three of the stimulus package.

However, Republicans, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) and House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-CA), have expressed a desire to see the impact of the first three phases of coronavirus response legislation before considering another bill.

The 880-page coronavirus stimulus package, worth $2.2 trillion and passed and signed into law by Trump last Friday, is the largest economic relief bill in U.S. history. The bill provides massive aid to individuals, large corporations, and small businesses, with its unanimous passage in the Senate despite concerns on both sides about whether it involves too much spending or not enough.

The package includes provisions to help replace the salaries of furloughed workers for four months, rather than the three months initially proposed. Furloughed workers would receive whatever amount a state usually provides for unemployment, plus a $600-per-week add-on. The package also provides $1,200 per adult and $500 per child directly to the public.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has stated that he would be willing to ask Congress for more money for small businesses and those in the private workforce should it be necessary. A key piece of the latest relief bill is $350 billion in funding for small businesses, with businesses with fewer than 500 employees eligible for up to $10 million in loans, which can be used for payroll and other expenses, like insurance premiums, mortgages, rent, or utilities.

The latest unemployment numbers, released last Thursday, revealed that Americans filing for unemployment benefits surged to 3.28 million as the coronavirus pandemic forced businesses around the country to close. The Labor Department said Thursday that the new number eclipsed the previous record of 695,000, which was set in 1982, and is well above the levels seen during the 2008 financial crisis.

It is unclear, at this point, what provisions the White House would like to see as part of any proposed infrastructure legislation. As of Tuesday morning, the U.S. reported over 164,700 positive cases of COVID-19 and over 3,170 deaths.

Title: Trump Officially Announces 2020 Presidential Campaign, Faces Double-Digit Polling Deficit

Article:

WASHINGTON, DC – President Donald Trump has officially entered the 2020 presidential race with an event in Orlando, Florida. However, recent polling indicates that he has a significant lead to make up, as former Vice President Joe Biden currently holds a 10-point advantage over the president.

At an event in Washington, DC on Monday, Biden stated, "I believe we can win Texas and Florida if you look at the polling data now." According to a new CBS battleground poll of early contest states, Biden holds a double-digit lead against his many Democrat primary opponents, with Senators Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders, and Kamala Harris taking the other top spots.

Biden also expressed his plans to campaign in the South, stating, "I plan on campaigning in the South, and if I'm your nominee, winning Georgia, North Carolina, South Carolina, believe it or not."

CNN reports that the Trump campaign severed ties with several pollsters last week after information of unfavorable internal polls leaked to the press. President Trump denies the existence of the leaked polls, insisting they are "phony" and that "I'm actually a very honest guy."

The polls in question showed the president trailing Biden by double digits in Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, and by seven points in Florida, where Trump is officially announcing his re-election campaign on Tuesday. Trump's campaign manager Brad Parscale dismissed the polls as "ancient," adding that the campaign has seen "huge swings in the president's favor" since March.

However, even a Fox News poll Sunday showed Trump trailing behind five Democrat candidates in hypothetical matchups. Political reporter Julia Manchester from The Hill pointed out that "These are national polls, and I think one big lesson we've learned from 2016 is that national polls do not tell the whole story all the time."

President Trump maintained to ABC's George Stephanopoulos that he has a plan to win swing voters. "Safety, security, great economy," said Trump. "Frankly, I think we're going to do tremendously now with African Americans, with Asians, with Hispanics because they have the lowest unemployment numbers they've ever had in the history of the country."

Meanwhile, other 2020 Democrat contenders are also campaigning and making efforts to engage with voters. For instance, Mayor Pete Buttigieg claims, "We are working hard to engage people across the party but especially black voters. We have a moment on our hands where we can do the exact opposite of what the president has done. The president has used identity as a wedge, he's used race as a wedge to divide people who have common interests."

For now, the 2020 Democrat contenders appear united in going after President Trump instead of each other. This could quickly change, however, as they start facing off in debates next week.

Title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Allegedly Intentionally Crashed Plane, Says French Prosecutor

Article:

In a press conference today, Brice Robin, public prosecutor of Marseille, stated that the co-pilot of the Germanwings plane that crashed in the French Alps this week appeared to have intentionally destroyed the aircraft. Robin confirmed reports about the pilot being heard on the voice recorder asking co-pilot Andreas Lubitz, a German citizen, to take over the controls, with a chair heard moving and a door heard closing.

The co-pilot, 27, took control, Robin said, and the accelerated descent was made manually. The motivation behind Lubitz's actions remains unclear. Germanwings, which owns the aircraft, initially disputed the prosecutor's comments but later accepted the crash was intentional. Carsten Spohr, CEO of Lufthansa, stated, "We have to accept that the plane was crashed on purpose."

Spohr added that the co-pilot, who had 630 hours of flying time, had undergone extensive psychological and aviation review since beginning training in 2008 and joining the company as a first officer in 2013, though his training was interrupted six years ago for an unspecified reason.

The initial 20 minutes of the flight were reported to be normal, with the pilots communicating in a "jovial" manner. However, later, the captain can be heard on the voice recording knocking on the door and asking to re-enter the cockpit, but there was no response from the co-pilot. The co-pilot can be heard breathing until the moment of impact, leading officials to believe he was alive until the crash.

Air traffic control can also be heard calling, with no response from the cockpit. Lubitz, who lived in Montabaur, Germany, had no reason to lock the pilot out of the cabin, no reason not to respond to air traffic control, and no reason to disable the plane's ability to maintain contact with other planes in the area, Robin said.

Toward the end of the descent, investigators can hear "violent" banging on the door as the pilot tries to get in, Robin added. Lufthansa CEO Spohr stated that pilots are able to enter a code to re-enter the cockpit, but the pilot inside is able to disable the system electronically. So either the captain did not enter the code or Lubitz blocked his entry, he said.

Spohr added, however, "We have total confidence in our pilots and co-pilots." The German Interior Ministry stated there is no evidence that Lubitz had a connection to terror. The ministry is also working closely with the Dusseldorf prosecutor, who has launched an investigation into the matter. Real-time updates on this developing story are available through the ███ phone app.

Title: Supreme Court to Issue Rulings on Travel Ban, Union Fees, and California Abortion Clinic Regulations

Article:

The United States Supreme Court is set to issue rulings this week on several significant cases, including the legality of President Donald Trump's travel ban on people from five Muslim-majority nations entering the country. The nine justices are also due to decide on the legality of California regulations on clinics that steer women with unplanned pregnancies away from abortion and the issue of non-union workers paying fees to unions representing certain public-sector workers.

The travel ban case was argued on April 25, with the court's conservative majority signaling support for Trump's policy in a significant test of presidential powers. The justices began their term in October and aim to make all their rulings by the end of June, with more due on Monday. Six cases remain to be decided.

The current travel ban, announced in September, prohibits entry into the United States by most people from Iran, Libya, Somalia, Syria, and Yemen. The challengers, led by the state of Hawaii, have argued the policy was motivated by Trump's enmity toward Muslims. Lower courts have decided the ban violated federal immigration law and the U.S. Constitution's prohibition on the government favoring one religion over another.

In a significant case for organized labor, the court's conservatives indicated opposition during arguments on February 26 to so-called agency fees that some states require non-members to pay to public-sector unions. Workers who decide not to join unions representing certain state and local employees must pay the fees in two dozen states in lieu of union dues to help cover the cost of non-political activities such as collective bargaining. The fees provide millions of dollars annually to these unions.

The justices seemed sceptical during March 20 arguments toward California's law requiring Christian-based anti-abortion centers, known as crisis pregnancy centers, to post notices about the availability of state-subsidized abortions and birth control. The justices indicated that they would strike down at least part of the regulations.

Title: Romney Speaks at NAACP Amidst Controversial Voter ID Law and Election Context

Article:

Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, faced a challenging scenario on Wednesday as he delivered a speech at the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP). The speech's backdrop was heightened by the previous day's address by Attorney General Eric Holder, who criticized a proposed Texas voter ID law as harmful to minority voters and drew parallels to segregationist policies and practices.

Holder's speech in Houston framed the 2012 presidential election's political landscape for Republicans, emphasizing the sensitive and potentially explosive nature of attempting to unseat the nation's first African-American president. Romney, who has avoided in-depth discussions on race, was expected to present his economic case to the NAACP, an organization known for its historical role in civil rights advocacy.

Tara Wall, a senior communications adviser to Romney, acknowledged the challenges of reaching out to black voters and building coalitions. She emphasized the importance of addressing the jobs and unemployment situation, holding the administration accountable for the current economic state, and presenting an alternative choice for voters willing to listen.

However, the timing of Romney's speech could not have been more unfavorable, given that President Barack Obama is expected to win 9 out of 10 black votes in November. Wall acknowledged the need to manage expectations and to speak to voters where they are, while also offering an opportunity for those willing to listen to hear Romney's message.

Title: US Deploys Additional Troops to Iraq, Prepares for ISIS Strikes in Syria

Article:

The United States has announced plans to increase its military presence in Iraq, with approximately 500 additional troops set to be deployed in the coming week. This brings the total number of troops deployed this summer to over 1,500. Most of these troops will be stationed at operational command centers in Baghdad and Irbil, the capital of the Kurdish north.

The US military has conducted around 150 airstrikes in Iraq, but these were primarily defensive operations. President Obama has now called for a more aggressive approach, stating, "It's time to go on offense." This new strategy covers operations in Iraq, but a senior defense official notes that the president has the authority to strike ISIS targets in Syria as well.

The US plan to combat ISIS also involves ramping up assistance to the Syrian opposition. In the coming days, this will include a request to Congress for additional authorities and resources to train and equip these fighters. However, determining the "moderate opposition" in Syria has proven challenging, with the less-extreme center of the Syrian opposition being small and shrinking.

Another issue is that it is unclear if the Free Syrian Army, a group often considered a potential recipient of increased US backing, has a clear vision for what they would do with the Syrian state if they were to gain control. These questions about the "end state" in Iraq and Syria are important, as they help shape the Pentagon's strategy.

The deployment of additional troops and increased support for the Syrian opposition raises complex questions about the potential consequences for regional politics. If ISIS is pushed out of Iraq, for example, this could strengthen the standing of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and his regime. Similarly, if ISIS is defeated in Syria, it is unclear how the Sunni population in Iraq will respond to the Shiite-led government.

Former Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki has been replaced by Haider al-Abadi, but he may now become vice president, potentially perpetuating lingering resentments among the Sunni population. "The grievances that drive the Sunnis to fight against the [Iraqi] Army are still there," says Ben Connable, senior international policy analyst at the RAND Corp. and a former Marine intelligence officer in Iraq. "What happens next?"

Title: Michael Cohen's Shift in Allegiance: From Trump's Fixer to Confessed Liar

Michael Cohen, once known as President Donald Trump's "pit bull" and a loyal defender for over a decade, has undergone a significant transformation in his relationship with Trump. From declaring his unwavering loyalty to Trump, Cohen now refers to him as a "weak person."

Initially, Cohen's role was to protect Trump legally, stating, "If there’s an issue that relates to Mr. Trump that is of concern to him, it’s, of course, of concern to me. And I will use my legal skills within which to protect Mr. Trump to the best of my ability." However, the tides turned when the FBI raided Cohen's office in April as part of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation.

Trump initially came to Cohen's defense, but as the investigation zeroed in on Cohen, the lawyer began to change his tune. In July, Cohen released a recording of a conversation with Trump from two months before the 2016 election, which appeared to discuss payments to a former Playboy model who claimed to have had an affair with Trump. This marked a significant turning point in the relationship between Trump and Cohen.

In a tweet, Trump expressed his disapproval, stating, "What kind of a lawyer would tape a client? So sad!" Cohen responded, "I expected something like this from Cohen, he’s been lying all week. I mean, for two — he’s been lying for years. There’s nobody that I know that knows him that hasn’t warned me that if his back is up against the wall, he will lie like crazy, because he’s lied all his life."

On August 21, Cohen pleaded guilty to violating federal campaign finance laws. In a surprise court appearance on Nov. 29, Cohen confessed to lying to Congress about negotiations to build a tower in Moscow for Trump during the 2016 presidential campaign. Prosecutors in the special counsel investigation have interviewed Cohen repeatedly over the past several months.

Cohen has cooperated with the investigation, stating, "Mr. Cohen has cooperated. Mr. Cohen will continue to cooperate." Trump has attempted to minimize Cohen's admissions, stating, "What he’s trying to do is get a reduced sentence. So, he’s lying about a project that everybody knew about. I mean, we were very open with it."

Title: Romney Kicks Off "Every Town Counts" Tour in New Hampshire, Focuses on Rural America

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney embarked on a five-day bus tour on Friday, visiting the farm where he launched his presidential campaign last year. The tour, dubbed the "Every Town Counts" tour, will take Romney to small towns across several swing states.

During his speech at the farm, Romney emphasized the importance of rural America, stating, "In the days ahead, we'll be traveling on what are often called the backroads of America. But I think our tour is going to take us along what I'll call the backbone of America."

The former Massachusetts governor's campaign is focusing on rural communities, traditionally Republican strongholds, as both presidential candidates attempt to win over voters in these areas. Dee Davis, president of the Center for Rural Strategies, noted, "If it's Reagan on a horse or Clinton, the man from Hope, there's always been this kind of visual narrative or this story that to be president you had to be able to handle the wilderness, be comfortable outside of the city. It's just part of the lore."

The Obama administration has also taken notice of rural America, with Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack leading the Rural Council, a group of Cabinet members discussing policies aimed at rural America. The council recently released a report detailing improvements in the agricultural economy, including increased exports and record profits for farmers.

However, the Romney campaign argues that the Obama administration's success in these areas is due to external factors, such as a weak dollar, rather than administration policies. Jim Talent, a former senator from Missouri advising the Romney campaign, stated, "Exports are up. That's in part because of the weak dollar—and I guess the administration can claim some credit for that. I mean, the dollar's weak because the economy's weak."

During the tour, Romney will visit six swing states that went for Obama in 2008, focusing on small towns that voted Republican in the last election in an effort to tip the states in his favor this time. Romney's campaign platform includes proposals for more oil and natural gas drilling, lower taxes, and deficit reduction.

According to Dee Davis, in 2008, Obama lost rural counties by a smaller margin than past Democratic presidential candidates John Kerry or Al Gore did. However, rural districts in Congress shifted towards the Republicans in the 2010 elections, with two-thirds of the 60 House seats won by the Republicans coming from rural America. This trend, coupled with Romney's underperformance in small towns during the primary season, presents a challenge for the Republican candidate in winning over rural voters.

Title: California's Proposition 64: A Call for Legalizing and Regulating Marijuana

Article:

California's Proposition 64, also known as the Adult Use of Marijuana Act, aims to legalize, tax, and regulate marijuana for recreational adult use. The proposition is supported by the California Medical Association and is a response to the ongoing federal and state drug laws that ban adult recreational use.

The argument for Proposition 64 is based on the premise that marijuana is not a dangerous drug and has fewer ill effects compared to alcohol when used in moderation. There has been no known lethal human overdose of marijuana, and it is not in the same class as opioids, which can be fatal.

The proposition seeks to move marijuana cultivation and sale out of the criminal underground and into a regulated market. This would help end the black market, as stated by Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom, a proponent of the measure. The goal is to regulate and tax marijuana, similar to alcohol, to generate revenue for the state.

Currently, possession of less than an ounce of marijuana is not even a misdemeanor in California; it is an infraction, punishable by a $100 fine. If Proposition 64 passes, minors caught with an ounce or less would be required to attend drug education or counseling programs and perform community service.

Rep. Eric Swalwell, D-Dublin, has endorsed Proposition 64. As a former prosecutor, Swalwell need not fear being labeled soft on crime. In 2014, he stated that he does not believe legalization would drive up usage.

Critics of Proposition 64 argue that legalizing marijuana could increase squalor on the streets, particularly in cities like San Francisco. However, it is important to note that alcohol and heroin, not marijuana, are the primary contributors to downtown issues. Marijuana smoke, in fact, serves as a deodorant in a city known for its strong odors.

In conclusion, Proposition 64 aims to legalize and regulate marijuana for adult recreational use in California, with the goal of moving the trade out of the shadows and generating revenue for the state. The proposition is supported by Rep. Eric Swalwell and Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom, among others. The debate surrounding Proposition 64 continues as the election approaches.

Title: Eleven Democratic Candidates Qualify for Fourth Presidential Debate; Gabbard Falls Short Despite Claiming Third Qualifying Poll

Article:

Eleven Democratic presidential candidates have qualified for the fourth primary debate, scheduled for October 15 and potentially October 16, as per the Democratic National Committee (DNC). The qualification thresholds remain the same as those for the third debate: candidates must attract 2 percent support in four qualifying national or early-state polls released between June 28 and October 1, and collect contributions from 130,000 unique donors, including at least 400 individual donors in at least 20 states.

As of September 9, the candidates who have qualified for the fourth debate are:

* Joe Biden: 16 polls
* Pete Buttigieg: 16 polls
* Kamala Harris: 16 polls
* Bernie Sanders: 16 polls
* Elizabeth Warren: 16 polls
* Cory Booker: 13 polls
* Beto O'Rourke: 12 polls
* Andrew Yang: 7 polls
* Julián Castro: 6 polls
* Amy Klobuchar: 6 polls
* Tom Steyer: 4 polls

Tulsi Gabbard has announced that she has received a third qualifying poll, but the DNC is reviewing a different set of respondents, and the poll will not count for her qualification.

Billionaire activist Tom Steyer qualified for the fourth debate after receiving a qualifying poll from a CBS News/YouGov survey. However, Tulsi Gabbard remains two polls shy of qualification despite some controversy. In an ABC News/Washington Post poll released this weekend, Gabbard had 1 percent support among all adult respondents but 2 percent among registered voters. The DNC's policy is to use a poll's top-line number, which in this case was the support among all adults, as it appeared first in the survey.

Gabbard's campaign has expressed frustration with the DNC's polling standards in the past, and on Sunday afternoon, well after the poll's release, Gabbard tweeted that the survey was her third poll, despite the DNC's clarification. With less than a month to go until the deadline for qualification for the fourth debate, every poll really does count, and Gabbard is going to need all the help she can get.

Sources: Polls, Media Reports.

Title: Senate Reaches Bipartisan Agreement on Human Trafficking Bill, Clearing Path for Attorney General Nominee Loretta Lynch's Confirmation Vote

Article:

The United States Senate has reached a bipartisan agreement on a bill aimed at combating human trafficking, paving the way for a confirmation vote on Attorney General nominee Loretta Lynch. The agreement, struck on Tuesday, resolves a legislative logjam that has persisted for over a month.

The confirmation of Ms. Lynch, President Obama's pick to replace Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., has been pending since late last year. Republicans insisted on finishing the human trafficking bill first, with the trafficking bill being held up in a dispute over abortion funding.

On Tuesday, both parties agreed to shelve the abortion issue by rearranging funding for a victims' fund, drawing money from existing health care funds. The human trafficking bill could receive final approval in the Senate on Wednesday, after which Republicans may move on to Ms. Lynch's confirmation.

Sen. Patty Murray of Washington expressed her support for a swift confirmation for Ms. Lynch, who would be the first black woman to hold the nation's top law enforcement post. Ms. Lynch appears to have enough votes for confirmation, though just barely.

Many conservatives have stated they will vote against her, citing her defense of the legality of Mr. Obama's deportation amnesty as evidence that she will not be an independent constitutional referee. The White House has criticized Republican senators for insisting on completing the human trafficking bill first, stating that Ms. Lynch has waited longer than any other attorney general nominee in decades.

Some Senate Democrats have suggested racial motives behind the Republicans' strategy, but the inaction has kept in office Mr. Holder, who is also black and is disliked by Republicans. Republicans have defended their decision to insist on completing the human trafficking bill first, citing its importance in addressing human trafficking.

The agreement on the human trafficking bill resolves a dispute over the application of the Hyde Amendment, which prohibits federal funds from being used for abortions, to fines collected from convicted traffickers. Under the terms of the agreement, money collected from traffickers will not be used for health-related services but will be spent on services such as legal aid for victims. Health services for victims will be paid for by existing community health center funds with abortion restrictions, circumventing the need for another abortion fight.

The human trafficking bill still needs to pass the full Senate, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has promised lawmakers a chance to offer amendments. Some Republicans are itching to use the bill as a vehicle for fights over issues such as birthright citizenship for illegal immigrants. However, Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid has warned Republicans not to amend the bill, stating that it would upset the compromise.

Title: Turkey and Syrian Kurds Clash Despite Ceasefire; Erdogan Threatens Kurds

Article:

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has threatened the Syrian Kurds to withdraw from a safe zone along the Turkey-Syria border by Tuesday night or face further military action. The threat comes as both Turkey and the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) accuse each other of violating a five-day ceasefire brokered by Turkey and the U.S. on Thursday.

Violence has continued in northeast Syria despite the ceasefire, according to reports. Dave Eubank, a private military company employee with Free Burma Rangers, who is on the ground near the Syrian border town of Ras al-Ayn, stated that the fighting has not stopped, and movement in the area is severely limited. Thousands of Kurdish civilians live in the so-called buffer zone, a senior military source told Fox News.

Erdogan made the threat during a televised speech on Saturday, saying, "We will start where we left off and continue to crush the terrorists' heads." The Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army (FSA) was "still shooting all through the night," Eubank said. "So far since [the] ceasefire, no airstrikes here, but artillery and ground attacks."

A senior SDF official later said his forces will pull back from the border area and evacuate Ras al-Ayn, per the temporary peace agreement, as long as there are no delays. Redur Khalil said forces will move back 19 miles from the border, withdrawing from the 75-mile area between Ras al-Ayn and Tal-Aybad. Kurdish forces said they coordinated the withdrawal with the Americans. This is the first time the Kurds have publicly acknowledged they will pull back.

Khalil said a partial evacuation from Ras al-Ayn started Saturday after delays and coordinating with the U.S. Turkey claimed on Saturday it was living up to the terms of the ceasefire agreement and accused the Kurds of violating it. The Turkish Defense Ministry said Kurdish forces carried out 14 "provocative" attacks in Ras al-Ayn in 36 hours, according to the BBC.

In a statement, the SDF said there has been "no tangible progress" in solving the issues at the northeast border. As of Friday, 86 civilians had been killed since Turkey launched its military offensive into Syria on Oct. 9, according to a war monitor, the BBC reported. Erdogan claimed the move was to "neutralize terror threats" and establish a "safe zone." After carrying out airstrikes, Turkish ground troops later invaded northeastern Syria.

Nearly all U.S. troops there have been removed and will be redeployed in the region in the coming weeks. The U.S. had teamed up with the Kurds to fight ISIS in the region. Some analysts and politicians criticized President Trump for removing American forces, saying it was a "green light" for Ankara to invade Syria and fight the Kurds. Trump said the Turks have been "warring for many years," and that the U.S. does not need to protect war-torn Syria because it's "7,000 miles away." The president on Friday claimed "thousands and thousands" of lives were being saved in Syria and Turkey due to the ceasefire.

Title: Trump Campaign Manager Corey Lewandowski's Role Shrinks as Battery Charges Loom

Article:

In public, Donald Trump has continued to stand by his embattled campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, who faces battery charges for allegedly grabbing a reporter. However, behind the scenes, Lewandowski's role in the campaign is diminishing.

In early March, Lewandowski relinquished authority over many hiring decisions to a lower-ranking staffer. In recent days, the campaign's press office has been overriding his decisions about issuing credentials for campaign events. Going forward, Trump's just-named convention manager, Paul Manafort, is expected to take a leading role not just in the selection of delegates but also in the remaining primaries, according to three people close to the campaign.

The shift in Lewandowski's role is partly a natural outgrowth of the campaign's maturation.
