However, sources close to the campaign attribute at least part of the change to long-standing concerns among some members of Trump's inner circle about Lewandowski's lack of national experience, his perceived unwillingness to challenge Trump, and his brash temperament.

These concerns were renewed this week when Lewandowski was charged by police in Jupiter, Florida, with simple battery related to a March 8 encounter with a reporter then working for the conservative Breitbart News.

"I'm not saying Corey's going to be fired or anything because I don't think he's going to be, at least not at this juncture," said a person involved in Trump's campaign. "But Mr. Trump's listening to other people now. The crew's expanding. The inner circle is not what it used to be."

Neither Lewandowski nor the campaign spokeswoman, Hope Hicks, responded to requests for comment.

Lewandowski's once-outsized grip on the campaign began loosening soon after voting started this winter, when Michael Glassner's title was changed from national political director to deputy campaign manager, a change billed as a promotion.

"The move to deputy campaign manager was not something Corey wanted to happen, because it put someone in line as a successor in case he had to leave," said the person involved in Trump's campaign. "It was an odd move to go from national political director to deputy anything."

The move sparked enduring resentment toward Glassner among Lewandowski's loyalists on the campaign, including the many friends he hired from his home state of New Hampshire and a number of his fellow alums of the Koch brothers-backed Americans for Prosperity.

On March 2, the campaign promoted Stuart Jolly, who had served as Southeast political director, to national field director, giving him primary authority over the hiring and firing of field staff. Lewandowski had brought on the former AFP employee.

Trump's candidacy has consisted largely of high-octane rallies, and Lewandowski has been a near-constant presence at Trump's side as the businessman toured the country in his private jet, often making it difficult for other campaign staff and Trump allies to communicate directly with the candidate, who carries a cellphone but does not regularly communicate by email himself.

"It's hard to get things to Mr. Trump. It's hard to get things around Corey unless you know one of the kids," said the person involved in Trump's campaign.

Four people close to the Trump family and campaign say the concerns about Lewandowski's temperament and certain aspects of his performance extend deep into Trump's inner circle.

Lewandowski, a former New Hampshire state marine patrol officer, has a history as a confrontational anti-establishment figure stemming from his work running the failed 2002 reelection campaign of Sen. Bob Smith of New Hampshire, who was on the outs with the GOP after running for president as an independent two years earlier. Lewandowski cemented his anti-establishment bona fides during his time at Americans for Prosperity, where he antagonized some Republicans.

That reputation may compromise the campaign's fledgling effort to court the Republican National Committee, its officials, and members, one Trump friend suggested.

People close to Trump "have voiced concerns that Trump is not going to be able to win over the party apparatus if they have someone like Corey running the show," the friend said.

Between March 15 and Trump's reemergence on the campaign trail this week in Wisconsin, the businessman spent several days at his Florida estate Mar-a-Lago, one of the few places where Lewandowski remains far from his side.

During this period, Trump hired Manafort as convention manager, a move first reported by The New York Times on Monday. Manafort, a longtime associate of Roger Stone, Trump's friend and adviser, who left the campaign in August as Lewandowski consolidated control, but continued to serve as a surrogate for Trump and to consult with him.

Manafort has quickly taken charge of his own fiefdom in Washington. He is planning to hire a team of his own, which is likely to include several veterans of the 1976 Republican National Convention—the party's last convention at which the presidential nomination was contested—though he remains below Lewandowski on the organizational chart.

"He technically still reports to Corey, and Corey technically still has the title," according to a person familiar with Manafort's role.

On March 8, Breitbart reporter Michelle Fields alleged Lewandowski roughly grabbed her following a news conference at Trump's golf club in Jupiter. Lewandowski tweeted that Fields was "delusional" and that he had never touched her.

But on Tuesday, Jupiter police released security camera footage showing Lewandowski grabbing Fields and announced that Lewandowski had been arrested on a simple battery charge. Lewandowski and the campaign both maintain Lewandowski's innocence.

On Tuesday, Lewandowski was scheduled to appear on Fox News' "The O'Reilly Factor," but the campaign scrapped the appearance.

Trump has forcefully defended his campaign manager in the face of mounting criticism. Trump even blamed Fields for the incident, threatening to file charges against her, saying she grabbed him and that a pen she held in her hand could have been a dangerous weapon.

Following scrutiny of the campaign's habit of denying press credentials to reporters whose coverage displeases the candidate and his staff, the press office has overridden Lewandowski's decisions about issuing press credentials, according to the person involved in Trump's campaign.

Many news organizations, including [redacted], have had reporters excluded from Trump's rallies and events, often after publishing stories critical of the candidate or his aides.

Title: U.S. and Allied Nations Discuss Online Extremism and Encryption with Tech Companies

Article:

In the aftermath of racially-motivated attacks, such as the one that occurred at a Walmart store in El Paso, Texas, which resulted in the deaths of 22 people, there has been a growing concern over the role of online extremism in these incidents. The pattern is clear: hate-filled manifestos posted on websites populated by white supremacists, followed by gun attacks against various minority groups.

Following the El Paso attack, President Donald Trump stated his intention to work with law enforcement, as well as social media and technology companies, to develop tools that can detect potential mass shooters before they strike. However, identifying and stopping extremists who plan to launch an attack is a complex issue.

Law enforcement experts, such as Dave Gomez, a retired FBI agent who has worked on cases of both international and domestic terrorism, emphasize that the constitutional right of free speech means police cannot arrest someone solely based on extremist rants online, unless they make a specific threat.

"You couldn’t just open a case on the words," said Gomez. "Posting something like that on the internet doesn’t harm anybody. Police can only successfully investigate a white supremacist when you can 'connect his words to an overt act.'"

The White House will discuss violent extremism online with representatives from a number of internet and technology companies on Friday, according to a White House spokesman. Social media companies are reluctant to spy on or censor their users, though they are increasingly responding to demands that they take down obvious incitements to violence.

In an effort to detect national security threats, the FBI, in early July, requested bids for a contractor to help it trawl through social media sites. Top law enforcement and domestic security officials from the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand met with leading social media and internet companies in London last week, pushing them to help authorities track suspicious users.

The government officials noted in an agenda paper for the meeting that some companies "deliberately design their systems in a way that precludes any form of access to content, even in cases of the most serious crimes." The final statement from the meeting said little about encryption, and neither company nor government officials talked about what was discussed.

The use of broad surveillance powers enacted by Congress in the wake of the September 11, 2001 attacks has helped law enforcement track international terrorist groups and stop people with links to foreign groups like al Qaeda and Islamic State before they could carry out crimes. However, the key law criminalizing "material support" for terrorism does not apply to investigations or prosecutions of domestic terrorists, such as violent white supremacists, who commit hate crimes.

This week, the FBI Agents Association called on Congress to make domestic terrorism a federal crime in order to give agents more tools. The Electronic Frontier Foundation, which promotes internet civil liberties, stated that the sheer amount of users posting aggressive content online makes it almost impossible to identify and track the people who pose an actual threat.

"Even though it seems like there is another mass shooting every week, if you are looking at the number of mass shooters versus the total population, it’s still a tiny, tiny number which means this is still a very rare event," said Jeremy Gillula, the group’s tech products director. "It’s like trying to predict where lightning is going to strike."

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Rules Out Conference on Senate Immigration Bill

Article:

In a move that seemingly confirms the demise of comprehensive immigration reform efforts this year, House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) has declared that the House will not hold a conference on the Senate-passed immigration bill. Boehner reiterated his long-standing opposition to the bill and stated that the House will never vote on it.

Last week, the third-ranking House Republican, GOP Whip Kevin McCarthy (R-California), indicated that there isn't enough time left this year for the House to take up immigration reform, as the House is in session for only 15 days between now and the end of the year.

Following the 2012 presidential election, in which Hispanic voters overwhelmingly voted for President Obama, Boehner expressed the need for Congress to pass major immigration reforms. He stated, "I think a comprehensive approach is long overdue. And I’m confident that the president, myself, others can find the common ground to take care of this issue once and for all."

Facing internal divisions within his conference on the issue, Boehner insists he still wants action but any legislation has to be addressed in pieces. He stated, "I want us to deal with this issue, but I want to deal with it in a common-sense step-by-step way."

A series of targeted immigration bills have passed the House Judiciary Committee, focusing on border security and enforcement, but GOP leaders have not scheduled any floor votes on any of them. A significant bloc of House conservatives is opposed to any measure that provides a path to citizenship or legal status for the 11 million undocumented workers in the United States. So far, none of the House GOP proposals address that issue, but opponents worry that any negotiation with the Senate would increase pressure on House Republicans to deal with questions of citizenship.

Boehner's statement Wednesday, declaring no talks with the Senate on its bill, was designed to put those concerns to rest. The Speaker brushed aside a question of whether House GOP leaders were avoiding the divisive debate on immigration reform to focus on problems with the implementation of Obamacare.

"This is about trying to do this in a way that the American people and our members can absorb," Boehner said, adding that immigration reform is too complicated to rush. "There are hundreds of issues involved in dealing with immigration reform, and we’ve got to deal with these in a common-sense way where our members understand what we’re doing and their constituents understand."

Title: President Obama's Immigration Address Highlights DREAMer's Story, Offers Relief to Millions

Article:

In his national address on immigration Thursday night, President Barack Obama highlighted the story of Astrid Silva, a DREAMer who felt "complete relief" as Obama laid out his plan to shield up to 5 million undocumented immigrants from deportation. Silva, an undocumented immigrant who came to the U.S. with her parents when she was four, was surprised to hear her story told by the President.

During his speech, Obama said, "Astrid was brought to America when she was 4 years old. Her only possessions were a cross, her doll, and the frilly dress she had on." Silva was motivated to begin advocating for herself and other undocumented immigrants when her grandmother died, and she could not travel to Mexico for her funeral.

Obama's orders will give papers and work authorization to up to 4 million undocumented parents of U.S. citizens. Silva, who was standing next to her father facing deportation orders during the speech, could benefit from Obama's action as her brother, Silva's brother, is a U.S. citizen, according to the Washington Post.

Silva will meet Obama on Friday when he heads to Las Vegas to continue making his case at a high school. Despite feeling relieved by Obama's actions, Silva stated that what's missing is still "a law by Congress, since they refused to act on it." She added, "A lot of parents of students who are undocumented are not included. We are going to continue fighting for them, and this is not the end."

Title: Social Media and Death Wishes: A Look at Controversial Tweets from Charlie Sheen and Carl Paladino

Article:

In the realm of social media, while it offers numerous positive aspects, it also serves as a platform for controversial and offensive content. A recent example of this can be seen in the tweets of actor Charlie Sheen and former New York co-chairman of the Trump campaign, Carl Paladino.

Sheen, a well-known liberal figure with a history of alcohol and drug problems, tweeted "Dear God; Trump next, please! Trump next, please!" following the deaths of Carrie Fisher and her mother, Debbie Reynolds. This wish for the death of the President-elect sparked backlash, but some social media users defended Sheen, stating that his tweet was not about political differences, but something "so much worse."

In a similar vein, Paladino, a former gubernatorial candidate and member of the Buffalo school board, made controversial remarks about President Obama and Michelle Obama. He had stated, "I'd like [Michelle Obama] to return to being a male and let loose in the outback of Zimbabwe where she lives comfortably in a cave with Maxie, the gorilla." These racist remarks were followed by an apology from Paladino and a denouncement from the Trump campaign.

It is important to note that while free speech and political views are protected, calls for violence or the use of racist, misogynist, or anti-Semitic language are generally considered unacceptable by decent folks. The response to Sheen's tweet, compared to the reaction that would have likely occurred had a celebrity of his stature called for Obama's death, suggests a possible desensitization to such content on social media platforms.

In this case, the comparison to Paladino's remarks was made, highlighting the double standard that can exist in the interpretation and response to controversial statements on social media, with some individuals justifying offensive words by those on their political side.

In conclusion, while social media offers a platform for free speech and political discourse, it is crucial to maintain a level of respect and decency in the content shared. Calls for violence or the use of hate speech should not be tolerated, regardless of political affiliation.

Title: President Trump Cancels Summit with North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced the cancellation of the scheduled summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, which was set to take place in Singapore on June 12. In a letter released by the White House on Thursday, President Trump expressed his disappointment in recent behavior by the North Korean regime.

"We greatly appreciate your time, patience, and effort with respect to our recent negotiations and discussions relative to a summit long sought by both parties, which was scheduled to take place on June 12 in Singapore," President Trump wrote. "We were informed that the meeting was requested by North Korea, but that to us is totally irrelevant."

The President went on to express his anticipation for the meeting, stating, "I was very much looking forward to being there with you." However, he felt it inappropriate to proceed with the meeting due to the "tremendous anger and open hostility" displayed by North Korea in a recent statement.

"Therefore, please let this letter serve to represent that the Singapore summit, for the good of both parties, but to the detriment of the world, will not take place," President Trump wrote. He also warned, "I felt a wonderful dialogue was building up between you and me, and ultimately, it is only that dialogue that matters."

The letter comes after repeated threats from North Korea, including nuclear war, and after the regime called Vice President Mike Pence a "dummy." This is a developing story, and updates will be provided as more information becomes available.

Title: Hagel Resigns as Defense Secretary Amidst Ongoing Foreign Policy Challenges

Article:

Former Senator Chuck Hagel resigned as Defense Secretary on Monday, following nearly two years of service, during which he oversaw the winding down of wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and steered the military through sweeping changes involving gays and women in the military. Hagel's resignation came amidst multiple foreign policy crises, including the rise of the Islamic State group.

In a radio interview with KFYI, Sen. John McCain, who is expected to take control of the Senate Armed Services Committee in January, expressed his gratitude towards Hagel and criticized the White House for a whispering campaign that accompanied Hagel's abrupt ouster. McCain, who served in the Senate with Hagel from 1996-2008, opposed Hagel's appointment to defense secretary but praised Hagel as an honorable man.

President Obama, in a Rose Garden press conference, announced Hagel's decision to step down, stating that it was an "appropriate time" for him to complete his service. Obama praised Hagel as "an exemplary defense secretary" and a steady hand for strategy and budget. Obama also expressed gratitude for Hagel's honesty, stating that he always "gave it to me straight."

Hagel's tenure was marked by a rocky relationship with the White House's insular foreign policy team, and he stepped down under pressure amidst multiple foreign policy crises. Sources told FoxNews.com that Obama's dissatisfaction with Hagel, as well as a desire to shake up the cabinet following the devastating midterm elections, played a role in the president seeking Hagel's ouster.

Hagel, a Vietnam veteran and former Republican senator, took office in February 2013, five years after retiring from the Senate. Prior to his political career, Hagel co-founded Vanguard Cellular, worked for an investment banking firm, and ran American Information Systems, a company that makes computerized voting machines. He also taught at Georgetown University after stepping down from the Senate.

A senior defense official said that Hagel submitted his resignation letter to Obama on Monday morning, and the president accepted it. Hagel agreed to remain in office until his successor is confirmed by the Senate. The president is not expected to nominate a new Pentagon chief on Monday.

Hagel, the only Republican on Obama's cabinet, served as senator from Nebraska for two terms, beginning in 1996, and became a critic of U.S. involvement in Iraq. Obama nominated him to succeed Leon Panetta as Defense Secretary in his second term.

Recent questions about Hagel's future at the Pentagon were prompted in part by his decision to postpone a long-planned trip this month to Vietnam. At the time, officials said he needed to remain in Washington for congressional consultations, but that did not stop speculation that the White House might be looking for a replacement for the final two years of Obama's term.

Just last week, Hagel was asked about the speculation during an interview on the Charlie Rose show. He was asked whether he's concerned by the speculation. "No. First of all, I serve at the pleasure of the president," Hagel said. "I'm immensely grateful for the opportunity I've had the last two years to work every day for the country and for the men and women who serve this country. I do not get up in the morning and worry about my job. It's not unusual by the way, to change teams at different times."

Title: Whistleblower Alleges Secret Appointment Lists at Chicago's Hines VA Medical Center

Article:

A whistleblower has come forward claiming that Chicago's Hines VA Medical Center is maintaining secret appointment lists to falsify wait times for veterans' appointments. The allegations were made to CBS News by VA social worker Germaine Clarno.

When asked about the extent of the alleged fraud, Ms. Clarno stated, "We're talking about surgery, radiology, women's clinic, all those different areas, all the specialties, all the clinics." She further added, "It's hospitalwide."

The alleged manipulation of appointment wait times is not only to game the required appointment wait time but also to collect bonuses for doing so, according to Ms. Clarno. This issue has raised concerns about the treatment of veterans in the VA system, with some questioning the priority given to veterans' health care over budgetary concerns.

Meanwhile, the Pentagon has approved the transfer of convicted traitor Bradley Manning from prison at Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, to a civilian prison to receive "gender treatment." Manning, who was convicted of sending classified documents to WikiLeaks, has changed his name to "Chelsea" and wants hormone therapy and other medical treatment to align with his gender identity.

The cost of hormone replacement therapy alone could be upwards of $200 per month, for life. The Manning situation has sparked debate over the provision of healthcare to prisoners, with some arguing that denying treatment could amount to cruel and unusual punishment.

The allegations of secret appointment lists and the transfer of Manning have raised questions about the prioritization of healthcare in the federal system and the treatment of individuals within it. The VA has yet to comment on the allegations made by Ms. Clarno.

Title: Study Finds Reducing Zero Sum Perceptions Most Effective in Reducing Partisan Hostility in the United States

Article:

A recent study, led by researchers Matt Motyl, Brian Nosek, Jon Haidt, and their collaborators, aimed to determine the most effective strategy for reducing partisan hostility between liberals and conservatives in the United States. The study, which tested five interventions, found that the intervention focused on reducing zero sum perceptions was the most effective at reducing hostility, closely followed by the superordinate threat intervention.

The five interventions tested in the study were:

1. Self Affirmation: Participants wrote about a valued personal characteristic and a time they embodied that trait.
2. Learning Political Membership Last: Participants read about a very positive group of individuals, only to later learn that they had volunteered for the opposing political party.
3. Observing Civility: Participants watched a video describing the relationship between Republican Ronald Reagan and Democrat Tip O'Neill, highlighting their friendly and respectful relationship.
4. Superordinate Threat: Participants read an article describing the threat of cyber warfare attacks on the United States, concluding that bipartisan efforts could eliminate this threat.
5. Reducing Zero Sum Perceptions: Participants read an article describing the consequences of a zero-sum mentality and the ways it is inhibiting progress, concluding that shedding this mindset in favor of increased compromise could help both sides achieve their goals.

After the intervention phase, participants completed a measure of partisan hostility, indicated their explicit liking of Republicans and Democrats, and completed an implicit measure of political attitudes (the Implicit Association Test). The results showed that each intervention produced the desired effect, that being lower hostility, but the degree to which they were effective varied. Reducing Zero Sum Perceptions was the most effective intervention at reducing hostility, closely followed by Superordinate Threat (although Reducing Zero Sum Perceptions was the only intervention to approach statistical significance, p =.052).

Notably, none of the interventions reduced implicit or explicit liking for one's own party relative to the other party. In fact, most interventions increased partisan preferences relative to the control condition. This demonstrates that promoting civility need not reduce an individual's liking for his or her own group. Rather, hostility can be specifically targeted and reduced without changing these attitudes.

The results of the intervention contest suggest that there are multiple paths to reducing partisan hostility. However, not all strategies are equally effective. Interestingly, the intervention that produced the best results (Reducing Zero Sum Perceptions) was the least based on past psychological research. As such, when trying to reduce the hostility in the current political environment, I advise paying attention to the nuances of the current sources of hostility. As time goes by, the issues that divide us change. Our attempts to bridge those gaps should adapt with them.

For more information about the interventions used, see this document: Civil Politics Contest Study-Materials. For more information about the study in general, see this project's page on the Open Science Framework.

Title: Federal Judge Halts Obama's Executive Actions on Immigration

Article:

A federal judge in Texas has put a halt to President Obama's executive actions on immigration, two days before they were set to take effect. U.S. District Judge Andrew Hanen ruled that the president overstepped his authority, halting both the new Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA) and the expansions to the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.

In a 120-page court document issued Monday, Hanen wrote that if the executive actions providing legal status to millions of people were to take effect, "The genie would be impossible to put back into the bottle." President Obama, speaking to reporters at the White House, said the Justice Department will appeal this decision, and he is confident that the executive action he took is "well within my authority."

Homeland Security Secretary Jeh C. Johnson stated that because of the injunction, his agency "will not begin accepting requests for the expansion of DACA tomorrow, February 18, as originally planned." Until further notice, they will also suspend the plan to accept requests for DAPA. Johnson added that the court's order "does not affect the existing DACA," and that it will not change the enforcement priorities he outlined when President Obama set his plan in motion last November.

Obama called on Congress to act and said he had taken this action because he would not "stand by and do nothing." He said while he disagreed with Hanen's opinion, "I respect the ruling." The Justice Department will appeal the judge's temporary injunction, the White House says.

The injunction gives 26 states more time to form legal arguments against the actions, which were expected to protect as many as 4 million people who are in the U.S. illegally from being deported. The plan also includes an option to apply for work permits. The states had argued that the changes would cause "dramatic and irreparable injuries."

On the other side of the issue, there are 12 states, the District of Columbia, and 33 mayors across the country who are supporting the Obama administration. They say the executive action would benefit them, as workers who are here illegally would come out of the shadows and work and pay taxes.

Obama announced his plan weeks after last November's midterm elections, saying that he was taking action because Congress had not sent him a bill addressing the problems in America's immigration system. Before the ruling came out late Monday, the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services agency had been preparing to begin accepting applications under the new rules on Wednesday.

The Texas lawsuit against the president's executive orders was initially filed in December by Gov. Greg Abbott, who was then the state's attorney general. Abbott accused the president of violating several provisions of the U.S. Constitution, including one that gives Congress jurisdiction over immigration laws. Abbott also argued that Texas would be irreparably harmed by the action. He cited as proof last summer's surge of undocumented immigrants from Central America who entered Texas illegally through the Rio Grande Valley.

Welcoming the injunction, the current attorney general in Texas, Ken Paxton, called it "a victory for the rule of law in America and a crucial first step in reining in President Obama's lawlessness." In his decision, Judge Hanen, an appointee of President George W. Bush who has been in his post since 2002, also noted that there has been a political and national debate over how to handle both legal and illegal immigration. He added, "To date, however, neither the President nor any member of Congress has proposed legislation capable of resolving these issues in a manner that could garner the necessary support to be passed into law."

Title: Dutch Attorney Indicted for False Statements to FBI in Connection with Russia Investigation

Article:

On Tuesday, special counsel Robert Mueller's office indicted Dutch attorney Alex van der Zwaan for making false statements to the FBI. The indictment alleges that van der Zwaan, who is based in London, lied about his communications with Rick Gates, former Trump campaign chair Paul Manafort's deputy, and an unidentified individual (Person A) during the investigation into Manafort and Gates' ties to the Kremlin.

Van der Zwaan's connection to the Russia case stems from his work at Skadden Arps, a large corporate law firm, in the early 2010s. During this time, Manafort and Gates were working for Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych, a Kremlin-backed leader. Yanukovych was embroiled in a power struggle with another prominent Ukrainian politician, and Manafort and Gates were tasked with covering up Yanukovych's undemocratic prosecution of the politician by commissioning a report from van der Zwaan and his team at Skadden Arps, which concluded that there was no political motive for the imprisonment.

The Skadden Arps report, while significant in Ukraine, was a relatively obscure issue for most of the world. Manafort and Gates continued their work for Yanukovych after the report's completion, and van der Zwaan moved on to other assignments. However, the Mueller investigation would soon bring van der Zwaan's work back into focus.

In November 2017, FBI agents questioned van der Zwaan about his communications with Gates and Person A in relation to the Skadden Arps report. According to the indictment, van der Zwaan lied about his last communication with Gates, stating it was an "innocuous text message" in August 2016, and that he had not spoken to Person A since 2014. The indictment alleges that van der Zwaan was, in fact, secretly communicating with Gates and Person A about the Skadden report in September 2016 and had surreptitiously recorded the call. The indictment also alleges that van der Zwaan deleted an email between himself and Person A sent around the same time as those conversations and told the FBI that he "did not know" where the email was.

Van der Zwaan is scheduled to appear in court on Tuesday at 2:30 pm EST to answer the indictment. He is expected to plead guilty, according to reports.

The key piece of information in this case is the timing: Manafort resigned as Trump's campaign manager on August 19, 2016, weeks before the alleged conversations between Gates, Person A, and van der Zwaan. If Gates and van der Zwaan were discussing the Skadden report in September 2016, and van der Zwaan felt the need to lie to the FBI about it, it suggests that there may have been something criminal about the report's production or something whose release would be politically damaging.

Interestingly, both CBS News and the Los Angeles Times reported on Monday that Gates had struck a plea deal with Mueller and would testify against Manafort, his former boss. It is not a stretch to think that evidence provided by van der Zwaan, such as his "surreptitious" recording of his call with Gates and Person A, helped Mueller build a case strong enough that Gates had no choice but to flip.

Gates, as Manafort's longtime assistant, might have valuable information about Manafort, who is one of the most pivotal players in the Trump-Russia scandal. It is conceivable that van der Zwaan might be the first domino in a chain of events that leads to a major breakthrough—a Manafort conviction or plea deal.

Right now, that is speculation: We don't know how the Manafort case is actually going to play out. But that is almost certainly Mueller's strategy—get van der Zwaan to get to Gates to get to Manafort, and from there, get vital information about Trump's real ties to Russia.

What this shows, more than anything else, is how methodical and wide-ranging the Mueller investigation is—that it's willing to look all the way back to an obscure report from the winter of 2012 in order to get to the truth about the Trump-Russia scandal. Mueller is starting at the lowest level, with seemingly unrelated people like van der Zwaan, to get to the big fish.

Title: Senate Approves Online Sales Tax Legislation; House Passage Uncertain

Article:

The United States Senate has approved legislation that would require e-commerce businesses with over $1 million in annual sales to collect state and local sales taxes on goods delivered to states that would normally impose such taxes. The Marketplace Fairness Act (MFA), which passed with a vote of 69 to 27, now moves to the House of Representatives.

However, the MFA's passage through the House is uncertain due to the reservations of key Republican lawmaker Rep. Bob Goodlatte (R-VA), chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. Despite bipartisan support, the legislation will need to pass through Goodlatte's committee before it can be voted on by the full House.

Conservative groups argue that it is unconstitutional to force e-retailers to collect sales tax when they have no physical presence in a state. They also contend that the legislation will diminish tax competition among the states and be difficult for online retailers to enforce, given the numerous jurisdictions that collect a sales tax.

Proponents of the MFA, including conventional retailers and state governments, argue that it will "level the playing field" between brick-and-mortar businesses and Internet-only companies that have not charged sales tax in the past. They claim that the software now available makes it possible for retailers to calculate sales taxes just as easily as they calculate shipping charges. The law mandates that each state make sales tax software available free of charge to e-commerce businesses.

Most states are in favor of the law, as they see a large pot of uncollected sales taxes. A 2009 University of Tennessee study projected unpaid sales taxes from Internet sales would amount to $23 billion in 2012.

The dispute over collecting sales tax dates back to a 1992 US Supreme Court decision that barred states from requiring a retailer to collect sales taxes on its behalf unless the retailer had a physical presence in the taxing state. The MFA is an attempt to change the law.

Immediately after the MFA cleared the Senate, Representative Goodlatte expressed disappointment that the latest version did not follow "regular order" in the Senate, but instead bypassed the Senate committee with subject-matter expertise. Goodlatte has already indicated that he has deep reservations about the MFA. He is concerned that the legislation does not make tax collection simpler and that aggressive state tax bureaus could try to pry money from e-retailers in other states that the bureaus did not think complied with the legislation.

The dispute over the MFA's future remains uncertain, with some independent analysts questioning if the legislation has a future due to Goodlatte's reservations. However, not all conservatives oppose the legislation. On May 6, Colin Hanna of Let Freedom Ring and Al Cardenas of the American Conservative Union endorsed the bill. MFA proponents hope that this argument ultimately sways the House to approve the legislation.

Title: U.S. Cancels Long-Range Missile Interceptors in Europe, Shifts Focus to North Korea Threat

Article:

The United States has announced the cancellation of 14 interceptors intended for a missile defense system in Europe, a move that abandons a part of a European system strongly opposed by Russia. This decision could potentially open the door for new arms control talks.

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel revealed the cancellation on Friday, citing development problems and a lack of funding. The interceptors, initially planned for deployment in Poland and possibly Romania in the early 2020s, were part of an overall restructuring of missile defense plans aimed at countering missiles from North Korea and Iran.

The shift in U.S. missile defense plans in Europe is the second major change to the program since President Barack Obama took office. This change could cause unease among some U.S. allies, including Poland and Romania, who view the system as a sign of U.S. engagement in the region and a counterweight to Russia.

The restructuring includes spending $1 billion to add the 14 new interceptors to the 26 that are in underground silos in Alaska. The European-based interceptors would not have protected the United States from North Korea.

The U.S. commitment to missile defense in the region "remains ironclad," Hagel said, without making any reference to Russia's objections to the European plans. Other parts of the program in Europe will move forward.

Missile defense has been a contentious issue since President George W. Bush sought to base long-range interceptors in Central Europe to stop Iranian missiles from reaching the U.S. Russia believed the program was aimed at countering its own missiles and undermining its nuclear deterrent.

Obama reworked the Bush administration's plan soon after taking office in 2009. He canceled an earlier interceptor planned for Poland and radar in the Czech Republic, replacing high-speed interceptors with slower ones that could stop Iran's medium-range missiles.

Under Obama's plan, the interceptors were to be upgraded gradually over four phases, culminating early next decade with those intended to protect both Europe and the United States. Russia initially welcomed the changes to the Bush plan, and relations between the two powers improved. That, in turn, paved the way for the New START treaty setting new limits on both countries' nuclear arsenals.

However, Moscow has ramped up its criticism of Obama's revisions, which are backed by NATO, and claims the fourth and last planned upgrade of the interceptors would be able to stop its intercontinental missiles launched at the U.S. and undermine Russia's nuclear deterrent.

The decision to cancel plans for the long-range interceptors will help the president's arms control goals, according to Tom Collina, research director at the Arms Control Association. "We give up nothing since Phase 4 was not panning out anyway. This is a win-win for the United States," Collina said.

The U.S. informed Poland and Romania of the decision ahead of the announcement, but Russia was not. The cancellation was criticized by Republicans in Congress, who have charged that Obama has undermined allies while pursuing his goals to drastically cut nuclear weapons.

The U.S. remains committed to all the other parts of the plan, including the first three phases. The decision was prompted by the need to address faster-than-anticipated progress by North Korea on nuclear weapons and missiles. The changes free up the money to do so, Hagel said.

Hagel cited North Korea's December rocket launch that put a satellite into space and showed mastery of some of the technologies needed to produce a long-range nuclear missile. He noted that last April, the North Koreans publicly displayed a road-mobile intercontinental ballistic missile, the KN-08. Navy Adm. James Winnefeld Jr., vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said that missile is believed to be capable of reaching the U.S.

The missile defense system was first fielded by the Bush administration in late 2004. It has a spotty test record and has never been used in actual combat. In addition to the 26 interceptors in Alaska, the system includes four interceptors in California. The 14 additional interceptors should be in place in Alaska by September 2017, but not before they have been tested adequately.

Title: Christopher Wood's COVID-19 Outlook and Market Insights

Article:

Christopher Wood, global head of equity strategy at Jefferies, has expressed optimism regarding the recent trends in COVID-19 data, particularly the decline in median age of new cases and deaths, despite an increase in new cases. He suggests that the coronavirus could potentially burn itself out as it mutates into a less virulent form over time, similar to severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

In terms of investment strategy, Wood recommends a barbell approach, suggesting ownership of both growth and value stocks. He anticipates growth stocks to outperform due to second-wave concerns, while value stocks should rally during discussions of a V-shaped recovery. He also expects renewed outperformance by Europe and Japan, given their indexes' greater cyclical gearing.

Regarding the economy, personal income decreased by 4.2% in May, while consumption increased by 8.2%. The personal savings rate fell to 23.2% from 32.2%. Friday is the annual reconstitution day for the Russell stock-market indexes, typically one of the highest volume days for the year.

The Federal Reserve conducted stress tests on big banks and is requiring large lenders to preserve capital by suspending share repurchases and capping dividend payments. Bank stocks had rallied on Thursday on a loosening of restrictions.

Amazon is reportedly set to announce the purchase of self-driving car developer Zoox for $1.2 billion. Cannae Holdings and Senator Investment Group are offering $65 per share in cash for the 85% they don't already own in CoreLogic, a real estate data and analytics company.

Nike reported a fiscal fourth-quarter loss on a 38% revenue decline, while Big Lots saw sales well ahead of expectations. The Trump administration has urged the Supreme Court to overturn the Affordable Care Act.

U.S. stock futures, oil futures, and gold edged lower as the open approached. Bank of America has projected that the S&P 500 could land between 3300 and 3600 based on previous bear-market rallies. They are tactically bullish on expectations for second-quarter earnings to surprise to the upside but strategically bearish. They advise diversification into a 25/25/25/25 asset allocation of stocks/bonds/cash/gold or factor allocation of growth/yield/quality/inflation before 2021.

NASA is offering a $20,000 prize for a space toilet that can work on the Moon.

Title: Koch Network Launches Campaign to Oppose Donor Disclosure Measure in South Dakota

Article:

WASHINGTON — A group tied to billionaire Charles Koch has launched an aggressive campaign to oppose a ballot measure in South Dakota that would require Koch-affiliated groups and others like them to reveal their donors' identities. The measure, known as Initiated Measure 22, calls for public disclosure of donors who fund advocacy efforts, the creation of a state ethics commission, and public financing of political campaigns.

Americans for Prosperity (AFP), the largest activist group in the policy and political empire founded by industrialist Koch and his brother, David, has formed a coalition called Defeat 22 to fight the measure. The coalition has already run commercials on talk radio and country-music stations, contacted 50,000 voters through phone calls and door-knocking, and distributed mailers denouncing the initiative as a money-grab by politicians.

Ben Lee, the state director of Americans for Prosperity and chairman of Defeat 22, stated that the South Dakota fight is a battle to protect donors' free-speech rights. Luke Hilgemann, AFP's national CEO, argued that revealing donors' identities could subject them to threats and intimidation and drive them away from funding advocacy groups.

The Koch network is one of the most influential groups in conservative politics. Some 700 like-minded donors each pledge to give at least $100,000 annually to a mix of educational, policy, and political organizations affiliated with the Kochs that push a small-government agenda. The network is on track to spend about $750 million during the 2016 election cycle, about a third of which will be directed to politics. A large share of the network's money flows through nonprofits whose donors are anonymous.

Koch officials say preserving "free speech" is among their top priorities in the coming years. "Wherever there are threats against the First Amendment, we will be there to weigh in," Hilgemann said.

The South Dakota measure would not bar donations to nonprofit groups active in politics, but it would require the groups running independent ads and distributing mailers to disclose the identities of anyone who gives more than $100 in a calendar year. The early spending against the measure caught organizers by surprise, with former GOP state senator Don Frankenfeld stating, "We're scrambling now to mount an appropriate response to the misleading charge that it's a raid on the treasury for politicians."

On the other side, Massachusetts-based Represent.Us is waging bipartisan campaigns around the country to end anonymous contributions in politics and pass laws it says will curb public corruption. Represent.Us and other advocacy groups helped successfully pass similar measures in Seattle and Maine last year. In addition to South Dakota, two more initiatives that deal with either campaign finance or lobbying issues are headed to voters this fall, in San Francisco and Washington state.

Both sides view South Dakota as an important test in a year when voter anger about the role of moneyed interests in politics helped buoy the White House candidacies of Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and the Republican nominee Donald Trump. Republicans control the governors' mansion in South Dakota and both houses of the state legislature. A former GOP state senator, Don Frankenfeld, is helping run the "Yes 22" campaign in the state.

"If it can happen in South Dakota, it can happen in 10 or 20 other states," Hilgemann said. The early spending against the measure caught organizers by surprise, with Frankenfeld stating, "We're scrambling now to mount an appropriate response to the misleading charge that it's a raid on the treasury for politicians."

Title: Western Powers Join Search for Kidnapped Nigerian Schoolgirls as Frustration Grows Over Government Response

Article:

Western powers, including the United States, United Kingdom, and France, have announced they will join the search for hundreds of Nigerian schoolgirls kidnapped by Islamic terrorists, as parents' frustration grows over the Nigerian government's response. A small team of U.S. military personnel is expected to arrive in Abuja, Nigeria, in the coming days to assist in the search. The team will consist of approximately 10 uniformed soldiers from AFRICOM headquarters in Stuttgart, Germany. They will be logistics and communications experts who will assess the situation and advise Nigerian officials, according to Pentagon spokesman Col. Steve Warren. The U.S. military has no plans to carry out a rescue mission.

The team is part of a larger U.S. contingent that includes officials from the FBI and the departments of Defense, Justice, and State. The total number of U.S. personnel is not expected to exceed 20 members. France has also announced it will send security service agents to help track down the Boko Haram terror group and its hostages.

China has offered to send satellite intelligence to help Nigeria's army locate the girls, and the U.K. plans to send in a team of experts, according to reports. The pledges of support come amid mounting frustration among parents of the kidnapped girls who are worried about what Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau and his army of jihadist fighters might do to their daughters in the days to come. The group has vowed to sell into slavery the roughly 275 kidnapped teenage girls.

"We do not know where they are and we do not know what is happening to them," one parent, who declined to be identified, told Deutsche Welle. He said some parents are so afraid to lose their daughters that they have stopped eating. The Nigerian government is offering a $300,000 reward for information leading to Shekau's capture, and the United States is offering a reward of up to $7 million for information leading to his location.

Local residents have reportedly pooled money for motorcycles to head into the forest in search of the girls missing since last month's abduction and those who have since been abducted. Nigeria's government has come under fire over its response to the kidnapping. Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, a potential 2016 Democratic presidential candidate, said Wednesday that the Nigerian government has been "somewhat derelict in its responsibility toward protecting boys and girls, men and women, in northern Nigeria in the last years."

However, a senior adviser to Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan told The Washington Post that it was "not helpful" to fault the government. He called for greater international assistance in the country's fight against terrorism. "The Nigerian government is doing all it can in collaboration with its allies to ensure that our daughters, the girls, are brought back home—everything in its power," Douglas told the paper during a visit to Washington on Wednesday.

At least two girls have reportedly died of snakebites, and roughly 20 others are thought to be ill. Shekau made his plans clear in a video released Monday in which he gloated about the kidnappings. "I abducted your girls," he said in the hour-long video that opens with fighters shooting guns into the air and shouting "Allahu akbar" and "By Allah, I will sell them in the marketplace."

Shekau's army is estimated to number from a few hundred to a few thousand fighters. In recent days, Boko Haram also has raided villages in and around the forest, including a raid Monday night on a village near the border with Chad in which eight more girls were kidnapped. A source said the hostages are being transported from one base to another, typically during the cover of nightfall, to avoid detection.

Shekau was reportedly Boko Haram's deputy leader until its founder, Mohammed Yusuf, was killed by local authorities in 2009. In 2012, Shekau was declared a "specially designated global terrorist" for numerous bombings, including the August 2011 attack on the United Nations office complex in Nigeria's capital, Abuja, that killed 23 people and injured dozens more.

On Wednesday, as many as 300 people were killed when extremists attacked the town of Gamboru Ngala on Nigeria's border with Cameroon, according to local reports. The attack and hundreds of casualties were confirmed by Borno state information commissioner Mohammed Bulama who spoke to The Associated Press by telephone. Shops and homes were set ablaze and razed in the attack, he said.

Title: Lawmakers Extend Tax Breaks and Confirm Judicial Nominees, Fail to Pass Terrorism Risk Insurance Act

Article:

In a final flurry of activity on Tuesday, lawmakers managed to pass a bill that extends a package of expired tax breaks and confirmed 12 judicial nominees. This development, as reported by NPR's Ailsa Chang, marked a significant achievement for the Obama administration, with the President confirming 88 judges this year, nearly double the number from the previous year.

The extension of the tax breaks, however, will last only slightly over two weeks, expiring at the end of 2014. The bill, according to Forbes, was "quite literally the best we could do," as stated by Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-UT). Politico described the bill as "that nobody really wanted," referencing an earlier effort by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid to build legislation that would have lasted two years.

The White House, in a pre-emptive veto threat, expressed dissatisfaction with the tax breaks extension, complaining that it failed to make permanent an expansion of its favored tax credits for working families. This move effectively killed any remaining attempts to pass a two-year extension that had been approved by the Senate Finance Committee.

Senate Democrats were further disappointed by the failure to pass a bill authorizing the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act (TRIA). Senator Tom Coburn (R-Okla.) blocked a vote on the bill, effectively killing the legislation, as reported by The Hill. Coburn, who had threatened to take this action, refused to agree to a unanimous consent request that would have set up a final vote on the measure, requiring a 60-vote majority for passage.

In a positive note, President Obama, according to a White House statement, signed the government funding bill that will last through September of next year. The only exception is the Department of Homeland Security, which is funded through February. The Senate also confirmed several other of the President's nominations, including Anthony Blinken as Deputy Secretary of State and Vivek Murthy as the country's new Surgeon General, a position that had been vacant for 17 months.

Title: FBI Identifies and Arrests Suspect in Partisan Bombing Campaign

Article:

WASHINGTON — FBI Director Christopher Wray, known for his restrained rhetoric, described the swift resolution of a series of partisan bombing attacks as a Hollywood-like operation during a Justice Department briefing on Friday. The lone suspect in the bombing campaign, 56-year-old Cesar Sayoc, was identified and apprehended following a nationwide manhunt.

The breakthrough in the investigation came on Wednesday when two of the 13 un-exploded devices, one addressed to President Barack Obama and another to Representative Maxine Waters (D-Calif.), were delivered to the FBI Laboratory in Quantico, Virginia, for analysis.

Investigators discovered a fingerprint on the envelope containing the device intended for Waters. By Thursday, they had matched the single print to Sayoc, who has a criminal record in Florida. Further examination of both the Waters and Obama devices revealed DNA among the components of the pipe-bombs, which were crudely constructed using six-inch PVC cylinders, small timers, batteries, wiring, and "energetic material."

Late Thursday night, federal investigators enlisted the help of the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to compare the recovered DNA with existing samples taken from Sayoc in previous criminal cases. By Friday morning, federal authorities, who had been investigating the case for just four days, were ready to move in.

"This is phenomenal work, with the greatest pressure, under an incredibly tight time frame," Wray said during the briefing. "We see unbelievable work like this on TV shows and in Hollywood, but to see it up close, in reality, is something to behold."

Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Wray, who have faced criticism from President Donald Trump, acknowledged the significance of the quick resolution of such a disturbing case. "This is a demonstration of the skill, the capability, and determination of our American law enforcement," Sessions said on Friday.

"We've caught the right guy... It's exactly what the doctor ordered," Wray concluded.

Title: Michigan Becomes 24th Right-to-Work State as Governor Signs Controversial Legislation

Article:

Michigan has become the 24th state to adopt right-to-work legislation, with Governor Rick Snyder, a Republican, signing the bills into law on Tuesday. The House approved two bills, which were also passed by the Senate last week. Both chambers are dominated by Republicans.

The new legislation allows workers at union-represented employers to opt out of paying union dues. Thousands of people, many of them union workers, gathered outside the statehouse, chanting and holding signs as snow fell. At least three school districts were closed as teachers traveled to Lansing to protest.

Michigan, with 17.5% of employees represented by unions, would be the most heavily unionized state to pass such legislation. It would join neighboring Indiana in converting to right-to-work this year.

Union leaders, such as UAW President Bob King, have expressed concerns about the impact of the legislation. "It would devastate the workers," King told CNN Tuesday morning. "We're worried about all workers in the state of Michigan."

Supporters of the bill argue it will help attract businesses to the state, but critics say it will weaken labor's bargaining strength by cutting union financial resources without bringing in more jobs.

According to Richard Hurd, professor of labor studies at the ILR School at Cornell University, employees in right-to-work states have lower wages, on average, than their counterparts elsewhere. This is because unions are weaker in those states and are less effective in bargaining for higher wages. Only two-thirds of workers join unions in right-to-work states, on average.

The Economic Policy Institute, a left-leaning organization, reports that the average full-time, full-year worker in a right-to-work state makes about $1,500 less annually. The rate of workers covered by employer-sponsored health insurance is 2.6 percentage points lower, while pension coverage is 4.8 percentage points lower.

Right-to-work states have seen employment expand by 8.2% between 2001 and 2010, according to State Budget Solutions, an advocacy group that supported the measure. In contrast, those without the law experienced a 0.5% decrease, according to the group's analysis of Bureau of Labor Statistics figures.

The passage of the measure symbolizes the declining fortunes of the nation's once powerful union movement. Only four states have passed right-to-work laws since the 1960s.

"If right-to-work passes in Michigan, it demonstrates the weakness of the labor movement," Hurd said. "If it can happen in Michigan, there's a feeling it can happen anywhere."

Title: President Obama's Visit to Israel Amidst Arab-Israeli Conflict

Article:

As President Barack Obama lands in Israel on Wednesday, he will not be entering a morally neutral landscape, but rather a region fraught with the complexities of the Arab-Israeli conflict. To navigate successfully, Obama should adhere to a moral compass emphasizing inalienable rights, starting with equality and freedom from racial and religious intolerance.

The Palestinian appeals Obama may encounter will be framed in emotive language, focusing on issues such as Jewish settlements on Arab land and "apartheid walls" surrounding them. Settlements are widely perceived as a significant point of contention between the United States and Israel.

In May 2009, Obama became the first U.S. president to demand a total settlement freeze from Israel, stating this during a press briefing alongside Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Israel responded with a unilateral moratorium on new settlement construction, but it expired in September 2010 without reciprocal action from the Palestinian Authority. Since then, the Palestinian Authority has refused to resume negotiations.

The Palestinian political machine has leveraged every international forum to make settlements the central sticking point. A recent example is a new UN report from a "fact-finding mission" that investigated rights violations allegedly caused by Israeli settlements.

However, at the heart of the opposition to settlements lies the endorsement of another Arab country without Jews, with the creation of what is best described as 'apartheid Palestine' being the ultimate goal.

The Middle East Road Map, endorsed by the Security Council in 2003, labeled settlements a "final status" issue to be "negotiated between the parties" because the ownership of the land and the longevity of settlements had not, and has not, been determined. If negotiators decide that a particular territory will become part of a future Palestinian state, why should an exodus of current Jewish inhabitants be automatic?

Israel has a history of uprooting Jewish settlements under difficult circumstances. Israeli governments have included settlements in negotiations and stand ready to negotiate without preconditions. The claim that settlements are an obstacle to peace, therefore, resonates for the wrong reasons, as the UN demonstrates: anti-Semitism and the objection to any Jewish state are at the root of it all.

The Human Rights Council's settlement report, currently being applauded in Geneva, has one annex. It begins: "Timeline – Israeli settlements in the Occupied Palestine Territory 1948." Not 1967. The report's pseudo-legal analysis objects to "Settlement Master Plans." The lingo – invented by the report's authors – is an unmistakable allusion to the deportation "master plan" of Nazi SS chief Heinrich Himmler.

The "selected sources" upon which the UN "fact-finders" relied (and which are posted on the UN's website) include tales that Israel is deliberately dumping "waste" in the territories to increase cancer and miscarriages among Palestinians and declarations that Israelis harbor "racist beliefs of Jewish supremacy."

The link between the anti-settlement battle cry and the racist challenge to the Jewish state's legitimacy is also apparent from the General Assembly's most recent fall session. Last November, 120 countries, represented by the Arab League, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, and the Non-Aligned Movement, and its spokesperson Iran, denounced: "the racism of Israel and its settlers"; "Israel's racist, inhumane policies...feverish settler campaigns and systemic killing of civilians"; "the terror, violence, and provocations by extremist Israeli settlers"; "The era of Zionism is over."

In short, the demonization and delegitimization of settlements are inextricably connected to the demonization and delegitimization of Israel itself. In March 2011, Palestinian terrorists brutally murdered 3-month-old "extremist settler" Hadas Fogel, and her 11-year-old brother Yoav, 4-year-old brother Elad, and her parents Ehud and Ruth. In January 2012, Palestinian Authority official television broadcast and re-broadcast a program in which family members of the convicted murderers – egged on by the PA TV host – praised the "operation."

Facilitating the creation of apartheid Palestine is not a confidence-building measure. It will not produce a peace partner or spawn a law-abiding future neighbor. Enabling apartheid Palestine should be an anathema to every post-segregationist fiber in the American body politic, starting with President Obama.

Title: Obama Reiterates Islam Does Not Represent Terrorism at Countering Violent Extremism Summit

Article:

President Barack Obama emphasized on Thursday that Islamist terrorist groups, such as al Qaeda, ISIS, and Boko Haram, do not represent Islam, referring to the idea that the West is at war with Islam as an "ugly lie." The president made these remarks during the closing session of a summit on "Countering Violent Extremism," hosted by the U.S. State Department in Washington.

Obama urged the nations gathered to remain steadfast in their fight against terrorist organizations. In his address, the president seemed to address administration critics who have noted the White House's reluctance to use the term "Islamic" when referring to such terrorist groups.

"Obviously, there is a complicated history between the Middle East and the West, and none of us, I think, should be immune from criticism in terms of specific policies," Obama cautioned. "But the notion that the West is at war with Islam is an ugly lie -- and all of us, regardless of our faith, have a responsibility to reject it."

On Wednesday, the president explained that he avoids mentioning Islam when discussing terrorism to prevent Islamic radicals from using such references for recruitment purposes. "We must acknowledge that groups like al Qaeda and ISIS are deliberately targeting their propaganda to Muslim communities, particularly Muslim youth," he said.

The president's refusal to acknowledge any connection between Islamic State terrorists and Islam has been met with criticism. Cliff May, president of the Foundation for the Defense of Democracies, suggested that the president and his administration should acknowledge that radical Islam is the root cause of terrorism and groups like ISIS.

"We're kind of avoiding making decisions now and we're saying things that really nobody that's informed about these matters can actually believe," May told ███ News. "He thinks he's doing it because he wants to avoid the impression that this is in any way a religious war – it was 21 Coptic Christians who had their heads taken off by the Islamic State."

This week's White House summit followed the State Department's recent, quiet meeting with members of the Muslim Brotherhood, which has sparked outrage from the governments of Egypt and Saudi Arabia. Zvi Mazel, former Israeli ambassador to Egypt, questioned the reasoning behind the meeting.

"So how come, the United States, the administration, in that case the president himself and the State Department, receive delegation of the Muslim Brothers?" Mazel asked.

Title: Military's Mavni Program Faces Tightened Vetting and Backlash

Article:

The Military Accessions Vital to the National Interest (Mavni) program, established in 2008, has seen a significant shift in recruitment and vetting processes in recent years. The program primarily targets individuals with language skills in strategically important languages such as Chinese, Korean, or Russian, as well as those with medical training and college degrees. Over 10,000 troops have joined the military through this program since its inception, with the majority serving in the Army.

In response to potential security concerns, the Defense Department has implemented stricter vetting procedures for immigrant recruits. These enhanced background checks now extend to recruits seeking roles as clerks, mechanics, and surgeons, mirroring the level of scrutiny previously reserved for troops requiring top-secret clearance. The additional layers of scrutiny include reviews by the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), a decade-long financial history examination, an extensive questionnaire, and numerous lengthy interviews.

The increased vetting process has led to significant delays, with thousands of recruit reviews accumulating in a backlog. Recruits have reportedly waited years for the clearances necessary to advance in their military careers, and in some cases, initial screenings have expired and must be repeated. As a result, the Army has reportedly begun discharging recruits, even in the absence of security concerns.

"They were being discharged even if there was not a security concern," said Ms. Cutler, a representative for the Mavni program. "These are often highly skilled individuals, many have master's degrees."

In July, government lawyers labeled the Mavni program an "elevated security risk" and claimed that some recruits had provided false information to obtain student visas and that others had friends associated with foreign intelligence organizations.

However, a 2017 report by the RAND Corporation found no evidence that the Mavni program had caused any security problems. The report, which has not been officially released, found that the program's recruits were generally better educated and performed better than the average enlisted soldier, and had not been involved in terrorism or espionage.

Margaret D. Stock, a retired lieutenant colonel in the Army Reserve who helped create the program and is now an immigration lawyer representing some Mavni soldiers, suggests that the military may be seeking to curtail the Mavni program due to administrative burdens and excessive regulations.

Title: House to Vote on Resolution to Block President Trump's Border Emergency Declaration

Article:

The United States House of Representatives plans to vote on a resolution Tuesday aimed at blocking President Donald Trump's declaration of a national emergency along the southern border. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced the move on Friday.

Pelosi described the president's declaration as an attempt to honor an applause line in a rally, and criticized the move as disrespectful to the legislative branch and the Constitution. "Not only is he disrespecting the legislative branch and the Constitution of the United States, he is dishonoring the office in which he serves," said Pelosi, who spoke from the border city of Laredo, Texas.

Trump announced the declaration last week as a means of freeing up billions to pay for his proposed wall along the U.S.-Mexico border after Congress failed to provide the money he demanded. Democrats have called the declaration an overreach of Trump's power and have vowed to fight it. Their resolution, if passed by both chambers of Congress, would terminate the emergency declaration. However, if Congress approves it, the president could veto it.

Speaking to reporters on Friday, Trump vowed to veto the resolution "100 percent." "And I don't think it survives a veto," the president predicted.

The resolution is expected to pass the Democratic-controlled House, but its future is uncertain in the Republican-held Senate. Unlike most legislation, the resolution is rooted in a provision from the National Emergencies Act that would require it to be voted upon within 18 calendar days after it is introduced and then be sent to the Senate.

Many Republicans have expressed discomfort with the president declaring a national emergency to secure funding for a wall along the southern border, but it's unclear whether they would vote for such an effort.

The bill is expected to pass the House, but its future is uncertain in the Republican-held Senate. However, unlike most legislation, the resolution is rooted in a provision from the National Emergencies Act that would require it to be voted upon within 18 calendar days after it is introduced and then be sent to the Senate.

Normally, if Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell does not want to bring legislation from the House to the floor, he can block it from getting a vote. But once this bill passes the House – which is expected to do so – the Senate will have to take it up within 18 days of receiving it.

In addition to the resolution, Pelosi on Friday did not rule out committee chairmen filing lawsuits over the wall. Sixteen states have already filed a lawsuit over Trump's emergency declaration, arguing it exceeds the power of the president and unconstitutionally redirects federal money that Congress had set aside for other purposes.

The White House officials have said the emergency declaration and other budget maneuvers would free up an additional $6.6 billion, which would build at least 234 miles of border wall. The fight over wall funding led to a 35-day government shutdown – the longest on record.

Title: Notable Political Moments of 2015: A Recap in GIFs

Article:

In the year 2015, a series of significant political moments unfolded, some memorable for their oratory, others for their unconventional gestures. Here is a compilation of some of the most notable moments from the year, presented in the form of GIFs.

1. Hillary Clinton's Persistence in a Marathon Hearing:

During an 11-hour congressional hearing, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton displayed unwavering resilience. The hearing produced a collection of unforgettable quotes, including this viral "dirt-off-your-shoulder" moment:

2. Joe Biden's Unsolicited Back Rub:

Vice President Joe Biden shared an unusual bonding moment with Ashton Carter's wife, Stephanie, during the swearing-in ceremony of Secretary of Defense Ashton Carter:

3. Ben Carson's High-Grabshake:

A rare display of camaraderie between Donald Trump and Ben Carson resulted in what appears to be Carson's first attempt at a high five:

4. John Boehner's Emotional Display:

Former Speaker of the House John Boehner made a rare public display of emotion during an event that is likely to be remembered for generations:

5. Bernie Sanders' Vice Presidential Bid:

Before their more recent computer-themed debate, Bernie Sanders extended an olive branch to Hillary Clinton in defense of her role in Servergate:

6. Larry David as Bernie Sanders:

Sanders later commented that "He does me better than I do," referring to the comedian portraying him:

7. Marco Rubio and the Political Football:

During a campaign event, Marco Rubio demonstrated, through his great form and muscular physique, how children can be harmed when he fails to practice gun control:

8. RBG's Somnolent State of the Union:

During the State of the Union address, Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg was observed dozing off, inadvertently revealing the hundred-year-old secret of why cameras are banned in the courtroom:

9. Donald Trump's "Crazy Eyes":

Donald Trump displayed a powerful intimidation tactic, often referred to as "Crazy Eyes":

10. Jeb Bush's Chest Bump:

A campaign aide presumably taught Jeb Bush how to chest bump:

11. Hillary Clinton's Dancing:

Hillary Clinton moved her extremities in coordination to a vaguely discernible tempo, but after 2015, she remains in the lead. She can dance however she wants, OK?

Title: Trump Administration Increases Military Involvement in Ongoing War on Terror

Article:

The Trump administration's approach to the war on terror, as outlined fifty days into the new administration, is showing a renewed focus on counterterrorism efforts, particularly in Yemen and Afghanistan.

In Yemen, the U.S. has reportedly increased its bombing campaign against Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) following a late January raid. According to Foreign Policy, the Obama administration had handed over plans for a stepped-up campaign to the incoming Trump team in January, and there has been an immediate change in the tempo of operations. The U.S. has now reportedly dropped more bombs on Yemen than in any previous year.

In Afghanistan, the Trump administration is considering an increase in troop levels in the 15-and-a-half-year war, where the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) has recently established a presence. General Joseph Votel, the head of the U.S. Central Command, which oversees military operations in Egypt, the Middle East, and Southwest Asia, suggested a few thousand more troops above the 8,500 currently deployed in Afghanistan are needed to break a "stalemate" with the Taliban.

The U.S. is also reportedly deploying additional troops to Syria, with The New York Times reporting the deployment of 400 troops ahead of the campaign to take Raqqa, ISIS' self-proclaimed capital. The U.S. is also deploying 2,500 additional troops to a staging base in Kuwait in support of the campaign against ISIS, although military leaders would not speak to the media about the plans for these troops.

The Iraqi government took no formal diplomatic action after it was included in President Trump's first executive order travel ban, instead lobbying members of the administration to be removed from the next version. Iraq's removal from the ban was also recognized as being motivated by its assistance in the campaign against ISIS.

Finally, the Trump administration has signaled its willingness to expand the use of the prison camp at Guantanamo Bay. Attorney General Jeff Sessions called it a "very fine place" to hold unlawful enemy combatants, and suggested the military would decide whether to hold suspects there and whether and how to prosecute them. This shift is in line with the Trump administration's privileging of military decision-making priorities in the conduct of the war on terror.

The Trump administration inherited battlegrounds in the war on terror all over the world and, thanks to years of Congressional inaction, few limits to how to interpret the post-9/11 authorization of the use of military force (AUMF) which has been used since its passage as legal justification for military actions in places like Pakistan, Yemen, Syria, and Iraq after the Iraq war-related withdrawal, against not just Al-Qaeda and "associated forces" but offshoots like ISIS which have become rivals. During the campaign, Trump suggested he would be open to some kind of Congressional vote on an AUMF specifically for ISIS, but despite a bipartisan push no such votes have yet materialized.

Title: PolitiFact's Assessment of Hillary Clinton's Truthfulness in 2016 Election Sparks Controversy

Article:

In 2009, the fact-checking organization PolitiFact, run by the Tampa Bay Times, won a Pulitzer Prize for its coverage of the 2008 election. However, the organization's credibility has come under scrutiny in the 2016 election due to its assessment of Hillary Clinton's truthfulness.

According to a recent NBC News poll, only 11 percent of voters described Clinton as "honest and trustworthy." In contrast, PolitiFact's rating for Clinton finds that half of her statements are true or mostly true, 22 percent are half-true, and 26 percent are false or mostly false, with only 2 percent being labeled "pants-on-fire" false. Donald Trump, on the other hand, was given a "pants-on-fire" rating for 19 percent of his statements.

One of the areas of contention is Clinton's use of a home-brew server for State Department emails. Clinton has stated that the decision was made for convenience and that it was allowed. However, FBI Director James Comey testified before Congress that thousands of Clinton's work-related emails were not returned, and that no other secretary of state exclusively used a private server. PolitiFact rated Clinton's "allowed" assertion as "false," but not "pants on fire."

Another point of contention is Clinton's linking of an "awful internet video" with the Benghazi terrorist attack, which PolitiFact did not rate. In October 2012, on CNN, Clinton blamed the "fog of war" for her video remarks. CNN's Jake Tapper, however, determined for FactCheck.org that Clinton contributed to a false impression of the attack despite the State Department and Clinton seeming to know from the beginning that it was a terrorist attack.

PolitiFact editor Angie Drobnic Holan explained that the organization "purposefully didn't rate statements that we couldn't verify."
