Once the facts became clearer, PolitiFact revised its ratings accordingly. Holan stated that the organization's main goal is to tell its readers what it knows and what it doesn't know.

PolitiFact's assessment of Clinton's truthfulness has also been criticized by other fact-checking organizations. The Washington Post fact-checker gave Bill Clinton three "Pinocchios" for his attack on FBI Director James Comey, stating that he made a "pathetic and misleading attempt to normalize Hillary Clinton's use of her personal email account and play down the fact that she was the only secretary of state to use a private server." PolitiFact did not comment on Bill Clinton's attack on Comey.

The discrepancy between public perception and PolitiFact's assessment of Clinton's truthfulness has led some to question the organization's credibility and impartiality.

Title: U.S. Reaffirms Support for Iraqi Government in Battle Against Islamic State as Tensions Mount

Article:

Tensions between the Obama administration and the Iraqi government have escalated over the quality of Iraqi security forces, with Vice President Joseph R. Biden reassuring Iraqi Prime Minister Haider Al-Abadi on Monday that the U.S. stands behind the Iraqi government in its fight against the Islamic State.

The White House stated that Mr. Biden's phone conversation with Mr. Al-Abadi aimed to "reaffirm U.S. support for the Iraqi government’s fight against" the Islamic State. The conversation followed Defense Secretary Ashton Carter's criticism of the weak state of Iraq's military, which he cited as a major reason for the fall of Ramadi last week.

Defense Secretary Carter stated, "The Iraqi forces just showed no will to fight. They were not outnumbered. In fact, they vastly outnumbered the opposing force, and yet they failed to fight, they withdrew from the site, and that says to me, and I think to most of us, that we have an issue with the will of the Iraqis to fight [the Islamic State] and defend themselves."

A spokesman for Mr. Al-Abadi, Saad al-Hadithi, said on Monday that his government was surprised by Mr. Carter's comments. "Carter was likely given incorrect information because the situation on the ground is different," Mr. al-Hadithi told The Associated Press. "We should not judge the whole army based on one incident."

Mr. al-Hadithi attributed the fall of Ramadi to mismanagement and poor planning by some senior military commanders. However, no action has been taken against those commanders, and he did not elaborate.

General Qassim Soleimani, the head of the elite Quds forces in Iran's Revolutionary Guard, offered his own assessment of American forces. In Iran, the daily newspaper Javan, which is seen as close to the Revolutionary Guard, quoted Gen. Soleimani as saying the U.S. did not do "a damn thing" to stop the extremists' advance on Ramadi.

Gen. Soleimani questioned the U.S.'s commitment, asking, "Does it mean anything else than being an accomplice in the plot?" He also stated that Iran and its allies are the only forces that can deal with the threat.

The war of words over the loss of Ramadi, amid other gains by the Islamic State group in recent days, highlights the fissures among countries that have become allies of convenience against the militants. As Iraqi troops continue to flee their advance, governments across the world are questioning whether relying on Iraqi troops and militiamen on the ground alone will be enough to stop them.

The White House stated that Mr. Biden "welcomed" a decision by Iraq's Council of Ministers last week to mobilize additional troops and prepare for counter-attack operations against the Islamic State. The vice president pledged full U.S. support in these and other Iraqi efforts to liberate territory from ISIL.

U.S. officials, including Mr. Carter, have said Iraqi forces fled the Islamic State advance on Ramadi without fighting back, leaving behind weapons and vehicles for the extremists. President Obama was also critical of Iraq's effort last week, stating that the loss of Ramadi was "indicative that the training of Iraqi Security Forces, the fortifications, the command-and-control systems are not happening fast enough in Anbar, in the Sunni parts of the country."

So far, the American approach to the conflict has been to launch airstrikes as part of an international coalition it leads, as well as equipping and training Iraqi forces. Iran has offered advisers, including Gen. Soleimani, to direct Shiite militias fighting against the extremists. Iran has said it does not have combat troops fighting in Iraq, though some Revolutionary Guard members have been killed there.

Baghdad has said military preparations are underway to launch a large-scale counteroffensive in Anbar province, home to Ramadi, involving Iranian-backed Shiite militias. However, that possibility has sparked fears of potential sectarian violence in the Sunni province, long the scene of protests and criticism against the Shiite-led government in Baghdad.

Title: House of Representatives Yet to Vote on Impeachment Inquiry Resolution for President Trump

Article:

The House of Representatives has yet to vote on a resolution authorizing an impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, a procedural move that has sparked debate among political analysts and lawmakers. In a recent podcast, Matt Glassman, an expert on legislative procedure at Georgetown University, stated, "The Constitution is very clear about impeachment, but it is also not specific."

In the two presidential impeachments of the modern era, the House did have an official vote on a resolution authorizing the impeachment process. This precedent, established during the impeachments of Richard Nixon in 1973 and Bill Clinton in 1998, could make the process appear more serious to voters and Republican officials. However, House rules do not appear to require such a step, and it is not a common practice in impeachments of other officials.

The impeachment process may be initiated through various actions and events, including the receipt and referral of information from an outside source, investigations by congressional committees under their general authority, or the introduction of articles of impeachment in the form of a House resolution, according to a Congressional Research Service overview of current House impeachment rules.

Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who has shown little inclination to hold an impeachment-opening vote, told the Atlanta Journal-Constitution last week, "If we want to do it, we'll do it. If we don't, we don't." Many Republicans argue that without such a vote, the current impeachment process is just a typical House oversight action and does not require extra White House deference in regards to the provision of documents, witness testimony, and other information.

On Tuesday, the White House sent a letter to House Democratic leaders stating it would refuse to participate in the inquiry, charging that it lacks "any legitimate constitutional foundation, any pretense of fairness, or even the most elementary due process protections." Earlier on Tuesday, the White House blocked the U.S. ambassador to the European Union, Gordon D. Sondland, from speaking with investigators from three House committees. President Trump tweeted that he would "love" to have Mr. Sondland testify, but that the process was a "totally compromised kangaroo court."

There are both political and procedural reasons why Speaker Pelosi might not want to hold an impeachment-opening vote or see it as necessary. Drawing up such a resolution would be difficult and politically risky, as Democrats might find themselves divided over what to include. In addition, House rules have changed, and today the House majority has unilateral subpoena power, removing a big incentive for such a vote. Speaker Pelosi may also be holding an impeachment-inquiry vote in reserve, in case she needs it to convince the courts to force the White House to turn over documents or testimony.

The White House has its own procedural and political reasons for demanding a vote – which mirror those of House Democrats. Republicans may want an impeachment vote to provide subpoena power to the House minority, allowing them to carry out a parallel investigation of the actions of former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter Biden in Ukraine, or to call witnesses they feel could debunk charges made against President Trump. In the Nixon and Clinton cases, the kickoff vote did provide such authority to minority members. However, in practice, its impact could be limited, as the actual issuance of subpoenas would likely still be subject to full committee votes in which Democrats would triumph.

The GOP may also believe it can use this issue to raise doubts about the process in the eyes of voters. Last week, House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy of California sent Speaker Pelosi a letter calling for impeachment to be put on hold "until transparent and equitable rules and procedures are established." William Howell, a professor of American politics at the University of Chicago, told the Los Angeles Times, "This is almost entirely about framing the narrative."

Title: House Intelligence Committee Hears Closed-Door Testimony from Intelligence Inspector General

Article:

On Thursday, Michael Atkinson, the Inspector General of the Intelligence Community, appeared before a closed-door meeting of the House Intelligence Committee. The Committee is set to hold an open hearing next week with Acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire, who is also scheduled to brief the Senate Intelligence Committee the following week.

The nature of the complaint that led to Atkinson's testimony remains unclear, but it is known that the incident involves a principle of Congressional oversight. The complaint, which Maguire has not invoked executive privilege to withhold, is seen by some as a disregard for the plain language of the law.

Two observations can be made from this situation. First, the intelligence community's watchdog, not a disgruntled deep state actor, found the complaint significant enough to inform Congress. Second, the administration is taking steps to keep the complaint from becoming public, even in confidential hearings.

President Trump, in a tweet, questioned the validity of the complaint, stating, "Is anybody dumb enough to believe that I would say something inappropriate with a foreign leader while on such a potentially 'heavily populated' call. I would only do what is right anyway, and only do good for the USA!"

However, the President's tweet contradicts his history of concealing details of his conversations with foreign leaders, such as President Vladimir Putin of Russia, and his casual disclosure of Israeli classified intelligence to the Russian foreign minister and ambassador in the Oval Office. The Defense Secretary also resigned after learning that President Trump had discussed withdrawing American troops from Syria with the Turkish president over the phone.

Three House committees are currently investigating whether President Trump attempted to persuade the Ukrainian government to investigate business dealings of the son of the former vice president and current presidential candidate, Joseph Biden. They have requested a transcript of a July 25 phone call between President Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.

Title: Senate Democrats Urged to Highlight Conservative Influence on Supreme Court Nomination Process

Article:

The confirmation hearings for President Trump's Supreme Court nominee have sparked a debate over the nominee's judicial philosophy, constitutional interpretation, and alignment with landmark Supreme Court cases such as Brown v. Board of Education and Griswold v. Connecticut. The article argues that Senate Democrats should use the hearings as an opportunity to educate the public about the influence of conservative legal activists, particularly the Federalist Society, on the federal judiciary and constitutional law.

The Federalist Society, a conservative legal organization, has been instrumental in shaping President Trump's Supreme Court nominees, as evidenced by the preapproved list of potential nominees during the 2016 campaign. The article suggests that the Federalist Society's supposedly neutral interpretation of the Constitution aligns with Republican policy preferences, potentially leading to changes in laws protecting voting rights, reproductive freedom, and labor unions, among others.

The article also highlights the global movement against liberal democracy and independent judiciaries, citing examples in Hungary and Poland. It warns that the confirmation of the nominee could lead to a loss of rights and the invalidation of several laws over the next several decades.

The article concludes by urging Americans who care about the court's future and its role in the American system of government to engage in the political process to restore protections and create an environment where radical judges cannot be nominated or confirmed. The article suggests that long-term organizing is crucial, even in challenging times.

Title: Davos Elites Face Criticism for Climate Change and Economic Inequality Commitments

Article:

The World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, is under scrutiny as business leaders and politicians gather to discuss climate change and economic inequality. While the attendees express a commitment to addressing these issues, critics question whether their actions will match their words.

According to reports, the International Monetary Fund (I.M.F.) has recently revised global growth estimates, which could potentially undermine corporate commitments to climate-change initiatives. The WEF, in its support of both President Trump and climate activist Greta Thunberg, is being criticized for attempting to maintain a lower-tax environment while pursuing a climate-friendly agenda.

Critics argue that without a clear distinction between genuine change and empty rhetoric, the WEF will continue to be perceived as a hypocritical exercise. The remaking of capitalism is a delicate process, as it requires companies to prioritize stakeholders beyond shareholders to avoid being outperformed by competitors adhering to traditional rules.

Some argue that the current pace of earnings growth may not be sustainable if companies prioritize stakeholders over shareholders. While efforts to broaden the base of stakeholders may contribute to future growth, the scale of the problems addressed at Davos this week may require more drastic intervention.

The harsher critics posit that the tension between President Trump and the Davos crowd is not a clash between nationalism and globalism, but rather a disagreement between intellectual fads. Both Trump and the Davos set share the assumption that business leaders and wealthy investors are the most important participants in economic life.

Regarding Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's comments about Greta Thunberg, critics question why Republican Party policymakers do not heed the advice of economists on climate change. A January 2019 letter signed by thousands of economists, including Nobel laureates and former Federal Reserve chairs, advocated for taxing carbon dioxide emissions as the gold standard of climate policy.

Critics suggest that it would be constructive for Mnuchin and other GOP leaders to listen to economists and advocate for moderately aggressive, market-oriented solutions to the climate problem. However, the current government is doing less than nothing to reduce emissions, despite its public lectures on the need to listen to experts.

Lastly, the article discusses the potential for increased conflict in the Middle East following the assassination of Iranian military leader Qasem Soleimani. President Trump's declaration of a red line regarding American targets or assets may not deter Iran's proxy forces, and influential Republican senators are urged to remind Trump of his promise to keep America out of foreign quagmires and prevent further escalation with Iran.

Title: Political Media's History of Biased Debate Analysis

Article:

As the autumn season marks the start of election year, the political media and partisans are gearing up for their quadrennial fall classic: the presidential debates. However, the media's history of assessing the first presidential debate has often been marked by a confusion between style and substance.

In 2008, for instance, Mark Halperin criticized John McCain's performance in the first debate as "Cluttered, jumpy, and often muddled," while giving him a surprisingly high grade of "B-." In contrast, Halperin characterized Senator Obama as "Polished, confident, focused," while being "immersed in the past, present, and future details of policy." Despite this, Obama only received an "A-" grade from Halperin.

The 2012 debate saw more of the same kind of misjudgment. President Obama was deemed detailed, patient, and reserved, while Mitt Romney was described as petulant, aggressive, and a liar. Eleanor Clift noted that Romney won on style and debating points, but Obama "stuck more closely to the facts." However, this truthful assessment didn't score the ratings and clicks the national media needed, leading them to drive the narrative of Romney's win into the history books.

As the upcoming Clinton-Trump debate approaches, many pundits and political zealots are already planning to grade Donald Trump's performance on a severe curve, while setting the bar for Hillary Clinton's victory much higher. Trump and his surrogates have already been "working the refs," warning debate moderator Lester Holt and the nation that Trump won't be held to real-time fact checks.

It is essential for the media to apply the same set of rules to both candidates, regardless of their previous experience. Both Clinton and Trump are selling their life experiences as equal reasons to think they're qualified to be president. Any member of the media who tries to grade either on a curve is exposing themselves as a biased referee, who should simply be ignored.

In politics, as in sports, there are rules for competing fairly. Each candidate must follow those rules honestly, avoid provable lies (sorry spin doctors), obey the clock, make their points with style, but more importantly, with substance. Being president isn't just about playing to a crowd or a camera. Finally, no matter who wins the debate, being the President of the United States is not a game.

Title: Vice President Pence Signals Interest in 2020 Presidential Run, According to Sources

Article:

In a private meeting with Al Hubbard, a top economic advisor from the Bush administration, an aide to Vice President Mike Pence reportedly expressed interest in being prepared for a potential presidential run in 2020, according to two sources briefed on the conversation. However, Vice President Pence himself has not made any overt efforts to separate himself from President Trump, maintaining public praise and private allegiance.

Marty Obst, an aide to Vice President Pence, denied any private insinuations of positioning himself for a 2020 run and called such suggestions "beyond ridiculous." Meanwhile, Mr. Ayers, who has signaled to multiple major Republican donors that Mr. Pence wants to be ready, declined to comment when reached on the phone.

Vice President Pence is reportedly taking steps to establish his own identity and build relationships that could benefit him in the future. In June, he spoke at Senator Joni Ernst's annual pig roast, a significant event for Iowa Republicans, and held a separate, more intimate gathering for donors afterward. Upon arriving in Des Moines on Air Force Two, Mr. Pence was greeted by an Iowan who had expressed dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act, who also happened to be a member of the state Republican central committee.

Furthermore, the vice president has used his residence at the Naval Observatory as a hub for relationship building. In June, he opened the mansion to social conservative activists like Tony Perkins of the Family Research Council and representatives of the billionaire brothers Charles G. and David H. Koch. The vice president's actions suggest a calculated effort to position himself for potential future political endeavors, although he has not made any official announcements regarding his plans for 2020.

Title: White House and Congress Remain at Impasse on Student Loan Issue as Obama Visits University of Nevada, Las Vegas

Article:

President Barack Obama visited the University of Nevada, Las Vegas on Thursday to call on Congress to act on the issue of student loans, as the deadline for interest rates on federally subsidized Stafford loans to double on July 1 approaches. The President has been advocating for a solution to this issue for over a month.

During his speech, Obama urged students to pressure Congress to prevent the interest rate increase, stating, "The clock is running out. Some of these folks in Congress are a little stubborn. You've got to tell Congress, 'Don't double my rate.' I need you to stand up."

However, Republican leaders in Congress have reportedly sent several proposals to the White House on May 31 to pay for the $6 billion cost of subsidizing student loans. Since then, administration officials have been largely ignoring these offers.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, commented on the situation, stating, "The president has yet to respond. One can only surmise that he's delaying a solution so that he can fit in a few more campaign rallies with college students while pretending someone other than himself is delaying action."

White House press secretary Jay Carney stated that the administration is working with Congress, but he noted that Republican leaders have resisted solutions prior to sending the letter last week.

In addition to the student-loan issue, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, offered GOP leaders a "bipartisan" proposal to resolve the student-loan issue. The proposal includes changing the formula by which employers calculate their pension liabilities and increasing employers' premiums for insurance provided by the Pension Benefit Guarantee Corp.

The speech on student loans at UNLV was the only "official business" on Obama's two-day trip aboard Air Force One, along with five campaign fundraisers in California that netted him well over $5 million. Mixing business with campaigning allows the president to split the cost of the trip between his campaign and the taxpayers, rather than having his campaign fund pay for the entire trip.

Republicans have criticized Obama for using the student-loan deadline to curry favor with young voters, whom he needs to energize for the November election.

"Unfortunately, the president is more interested in campaigning for the students at UNLV then actually working with Congress to find a solution," McConnell said. "Mr. President, open your mail. The solution's right in front of you. The only people dragging their feet on this issue are over at the White House—dragging their feet to fit in yet another college visit."

Obama held his fifth fundraiser of this trip Thursday morning at the Los Angeles-area home of Chuck Quarles, a real-estate developer. Air Force One costs about $180,000 per flight hour to operate, meaning the cost of the two-day trip is nearly $2 million just to fly the plane. Campaign-finance experts say a president's campaign is expected to reimburse the government for the cost of a first-class commercial airline seat for each person flying on Air Force One to or from a political event.

Title: Bipartisan Governing Trend Emerges in U.S. Politics: Analysis of Virginia and New Jersey Election Results

Article:

Tuesday's election results in Virginia and New Jersey have highlighted a shift in American politics, as traditional voting patterns seem to have little relevance in the marquee battles. Columnist Ramesh Ponnuru, writing in the New York Post, noted that it would be logical for more conservative Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli to outperform Republican Governor Chris Christie in New Jersey during their reelection bids. However, the results of Tuesday's election did not follow this logic.

The reasons for Cuccinelli's loss are multifaceted. First and foremost, personality played a significant role. Cuccinelli was portrayed as a right-wing Republican, with his positions on issues such as gay marriage, abortion, and social issues used extensively against him in ads throughout the growing North Virginia suburbs.

Second, Cuccinelli was running against the legacy of the Republican Governor Bob McDonnell's administration, which was marred by allegations of corruption and a growing ethics scandal. McDonnell's silence throughout the campaign benefited Cuccinelli initially, but it also left room for Democrats and spending groups to link them with little rebuttal.

Third, Terry McAuliffe benefited from over $35 million in expenditures and substantial fundraising efforts by high-profile Democrats like Bill and Hillary Clinton, as well as President Obama himself.

In contrast, the victors in both races, Governor Chris Christie and Terry McAuliffe, emphasized bipartisan governing. Christie, known for his work with Democrats in the legislature and his collaboration with President Obama on Hurricane Sandy relief, won significant levels of support from Democratic leaning groups.

Christie also navigated the issue of gay marriage effectively. He maintained a principled stand against gay marriage but allowed same-sex marriages to proceed in New Jersey at the 11th hour, limiting the fallout.

McAuliffe, despite his liabilities, ran as a mainstream centrist Democrat. He used economic issues to present himself as an alternative to the status quo in a state that has experienced increased unemployment and slower than average economic growth.

The wins for Christie and McAuliffe suggest that Americans are seeking politicians who govern in a bipartisan manner. This is not to say that these politicians are not traditional; they certainly are. However, they have recognized the importance of working across the aisle and the ideological divide in the current political climate. The two candidates who have managed to do this, Chris Christie and Terry McAuliffe, have been successful, and their bipartisan efforts may have been as influential in their wins as any other factors.

This development, with two bipartisan governors winning their elections, is a positive sign in an overly partisan and polarized America.

Title: Hackers Compromise North Korea's Uriminzokkiri Twitter and Flickr Accounts Amid Rising Tensions

Article:

Seoul, South Korea - Hackers reportedly breached at least two government-run North Korean online platforms on Thursday, as tensions escalate on the Korean Peninsula. The affected sites include the North's Uriminzokkiri Twitter and Flickr accounts, which ceased posting content typical of the regime in Pyongyang, such as photos of North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un with military officials.

An unusual image posted on the North's Flickr site depicts Kim's face with a pig-like snout and a drawing of Mickey Mouse on his chest. Beneath the image, the text reads, "Threatening world peace with ICBMs and Nuclear weapons/Wasting money while his people starve to death." Another posting reads, "We are Anonymous," a name associated with a hacker activist group. A widely circulated statement, attributed to the attackers, claims the compromise of 15,000 user records hosted on Uriminzokkiri.com and other websites. The authenticity of the statement could not be confirmed, as the North's official website did not open on Thursday.

Tweets on the North's Twitter account indicated "Hacked" followed by links to North Korea-related websites. One tweet read "Tango Down" followed by a link to the North's Flickr page.

North Korea established its Twitter account in 2010 and has over 13,000 followers. The North uses social media to praise its system and leaders and to repeat commentaries sent out by the North's official Korean Central News Agency.

Tensions have been high in recent days between North and South Korea, and the North's military warned on Thursday that it had been authorized to attack the U.S. North Korea is reportedly upset about sanctions against its nuclear program and joint military drills between the U.S. and South Korea.

Title: House to Vote on $1.1 Trillion Spending Bill, Ending Government Funding Impasse

Article:

The United States House of Representatives is expected to vote on a $1.1 trillion spending bill on Wednesday, aiming to fund the federal government through October and potentially ending the ongoing partisan disputes that led to a government shutdown and the threat of default.

According to The Associated Press, the GOP-led House is scheduled to pass the 1,582-page bill on Wednesday, although many Tea Party conservatives are expected to oppose it. A Senate vote is anticipated by the end of the week, with the Democratic-led chamber also expected to pass the plan.

As reported by NPR's Ailsa Chang to the Newscast Desk, the bill details the broad outlines agreed upon in last month's budget agreement on Capitol Hill. The budget authorizes spending for nearly every aspect of government within the parameters of last month's budget agreement.

One significant difference between this bill and the December deal involves cuts to military pensions. The budget agreement announced last month reduced the annual cost-of-living increases for military retirees under 62 by one percent. This spending plan reverses that cut, but only for disabled veterans and relatives of deceased military members.

The measure eases across-the-board spending cuts by providing an extra $45 billion for military and domestic discretionary programs for fiscal 2014, totaling $1.012 trillion. It also provides an additional $85.2 billion for Afghanistan war funding, which is typically handled off-budget.

Bloomberg News reports that the funding will run through January 15, and lawmakers plan to pass a separate three-day stopgap bill at current funding levels to extend the deadline to January 18. This would give lawmakers enough time to enact the comprehensive legislation without risking a government shutdown. The House plans to vote on the three-day measure on the same day.

Regarding the political implications, The Hill states that:

1. The bill includes a provision that would allow the Senate to bypass the filibuster for certain nominations, a move that could make it easier for President Biden to fill vacancies in his administration.
2. The bill includes a provision that would allow the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to implement net neutrality rules, a move that could face legal challenges.
3. The bill includes a provision that would prevent the Federal Reserve from issuing new regulations on banks with assets under $10 billion, a move that could face pushback from Democrats.
4. The bill includes a provision that would prevent the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) from issuing new regulations on workplace safety, a move that could face pushback from labor unions.
5. The bill includes a provision that would prevent the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) from issuing new regulations on greenhouse gas emissions, a move that could face pushback from environmental groups.

Title: Portugal's Decriminalization of Drugs Reduces Overdose Deaths, Study Shows

Article:

A neuroscientist, Carl Hart, former chair of Columbia University's Psychology department, has advocated for the end of the war on drugs, citing its negative impact on society and the ineffectiveness of the policy in reducing drug use. In his new video and upcoming book, Hart argues that the war on drugs has led to increased conflict between law enforcement and citizens, higher incarceration rates, and the formation of violent drug gangs.

Hart, who grew up in a tough Miami neighborhood, initially believed that drug use caused significant harm. However, after 20 years of research, he concluded that the evidence did not support this hypothesis. He argues that the illegal status of drugs leads to increased profits, which in turn leads to violence and the formation of gangs.

One of Hart's concerns is the opioid epidemic. He suggests that the tight restrictions on opioid sales contribute to the high number of overdose deaths. If drugs were over-the-counter, he argues, there would be fewer deaths due to tainted drugs.

Hart also points to Portugal as an example of a country that has decriminalized all drug use and offers medical help instead of punishment. In 2001, Portugal decriminalized drug use, and deaths from overdoses dropped sharply. In 2017, Portugal had only 4 deaths per million people, while the United States had 217 per million.

Hart argues that the war on drugs disproportionately affects black citizens and that a more permissive drug regime would lead to better outcomes in all areas. He believes that the war on drugs funds a prison-industrial complex and that research not in support of the "tough-on-drugs" ideology is routinely dismissed to maintain funding and public outrage.

In conclusion, Hart's research suggests that the war on drugs does more harm than drugs themselves and that decriminalization, as demonstrated in Portugal, can lead to a reduction in overdose deaths. He argues that society should not punish all citizens because of the actions of a few who cannot handle drug use.

Title: The Cost-Effectiveness of Cracking Down on Visa Overstays and Employer Compliance

Article:

The federal government has significantly increased border security measures since 2005, including the addition of hundreds of miles of walls and fencing along the U.S.-Mexico border, a doubling of the Border Patrol, and rapid spending increases that have led to duplicative programs. President Trump's proposed border wall has been met with skepticism, as it is seen as a potential multibillion-dollar boondoggle.

The surge in spending on border enforcement has already reached a point of diminishing return, with the federal government spending more on immigration policing than on all other law enforcement activities combined. Most of California, Arizona, and New Mexico already have some kind of barrier, while Texas faces challenges due to the difficulties of building along the Rio Grande River and private land ownership.

Since 2007, the estimated number of undocumented immigrants has dropped from 12.2 million to slightly over 11 million. While illegal immigration has not ceased entirely, it is being offset by people returning to their home countries. An estimated 35% to 50% of the inflow is people who come in legally and overstay their visas, individuals not impacted by walls or other border control efforts.

Given these factors, the proposed border wall is considered a colossal waste of money. The idea of forcing Mexico to pay for the wall has led to the cancellation of a scheduled meeting between President Trump and Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto. A proposed 20% tax on imports from Mexico to recoup construction costs would potentially ignite a mutually destructive trade war, effectively making U.S. consumers bear the costs.

Cracking down on visa overstays and on employers who hire illegal workers is seen as a more effective means of improving immigration enforcement than spending an additional $12 billion or more on a border wall.

Title: Minneapolis City Council Pledges to Replace Police Department with "Public Safety" System

Article:

The Minneapolis city council has announced its intention to disband the city's police force and replace it with an alternative system of "public safety." This decision comes in response to the death of George Floyd, a Black man who was killed by a Minneapolis police officer in late May.

The city council's decision follows a series of largely peaceful protests across the United States and around the world, sparked by Floyd's death. Over 10,000 protesters have been arrested during the weeks of unrest, many for non-violent offenses.

The Obama administration introduced measures to hold police forces accountable after the shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, in 2014. However, the Trump administration's Department of Justice has allowed these incremental efforts to wither, which may explain the growing support for a more radical solution: "defund the police."

The city council's decision to disband the police force and replace it with a public safety system is a dramatic step towards reform. The specifics of the new system have not yet been announced.

In addition to the Minneapolis city council's decision, protests have spread to cities as far afield as Nigeria and Australia. The novelist Ben Okri suggests Floyd's case has caused worldwide reverberations because his words "I can't breathe" speak eloquently both to our fears of the coronavirus pandemic and to the implacable nature of institutional racism.

The unrest in the United States has also sparked a debate about the role of police forces and the need for reform. Some argue that the police are acting like occupying armies, while others argue that they are necessary for public safety. The debate is ongoing, and the future of policing in the United States remains uncertain.

Title: Violence Erupts During Peaceful Ukrainian Unity March in Donetsk

Article:

A peaceful march advocating for Ukrainian unity in the eastern city of Donetsk was disrupted by pro-Russian separatists, resulting in explosive fireworks, chaos, and physical altercations on the city's main boulevard. The demonstrators, who were waving the sky blue and gold flags of Ukraine and singing patriotic songs, had only walked about half a mile before they were attacked by a mob of masked men carrying clubs.

The violence began as a large group of these men, who appeared to be pro-Russian separatists, ran out of side streets and attempted to block the road ahead of the marchers. Fireworks and homemade bombs were thrown from the crowd, with separatists responding by throwing stones and beating people with their weapons. Riot police, who had been trailing along beside the marchers, swiftly moved in, clashing with the attackers and trying to separate both sides.

One member of the mob was seen getting hit in the head with an exploding homemade bomb, and a loud bang was heard at the feet of a police officer. Marchers scattered in all directions, with members of the pro-Russian mob chasing them down the street. One man, with a head gash and visible blood, flashed a simple peace sign as he walked off to find help.

In the midst of the confusion, an ambulance crew was treating the wounded, where a Ukrainian journalist with a bloody bandage on his head was found. He told reporters he was trying to flee when he was hit by a brick. The demonstration had begun peacefully, but pro-Russian separatists had been calling for their supporters to oppose the march on social media for several days.

Three weeks ago, separatist gunmen occupied the main administration building in Donetsk and have since turned it into a heavily fortified command center in their bid to carve out an independent republic with strong ties to neighboring Russia. Donetsk lies at the center of one of Ukraine's volatile breakaway eastern provinces, and, as witnessed today, it is simmering on the verge of all-out civil war.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Officials Face Challenges in Tracking Extremists Amid Differences with European Counterparts

Article:

U.S. intelligence officials are encountering difficulties in monitoring the movements of American and European-born fighters who travel to the Middle East to join Islamic extremist groups like ISIS, due to varying approaches to information sharing and homeland security from their European counterparts, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal.

The report states that U.S. officials are finding it challenging to trace the movements of suspected extremists once they enter certain European countries. This issue arises despite close intelligence links between U.S. and European security services, with intelligence from both sides of the Atlantic bolstering terror watch lists maintained by U.S. officials, such as the no-fly list.

A point of concern among U.S. intelligence officials is a series of anti-terror proposals made last week by British Prime Minister David Cameron, particularly his proposal to revoke the passports of British nationals who have traveled to fight for ISIS. U.S. counter-terrorism officials reportedly view this move with apprehension, as confiscating passports could prevent individuals who have traveled to Syria and Iraq from communicating with authorities and providing intelligence about the situation there.

A report in The Times of London last week suggested that up to 30 British-born ISIS fighters have grown disillusioned with the militants' brutal tactics and wish to return home, but are hesitant due to the punitive measures advocated by Cameron.

President Obama is set to meet with congressional leaders Tuesday afternoon to discuss his plan to combat the ISIS threat. Few details of Obama's plan have been disclosed ahead of a scheduled Wednesday address to the nation, though the New York Times reported Monday that the White House is planning a three-phase campaign that some Pentagon officials believe would take at least three years to fully execute.

The U.S. has already carried out nearly 150 airstrikes against ISIS in Iraq, and The Times reported that the final phase of the campaign would involve the extension of airstrikes into Syria, where ISIS has its base.

The Obama administration is also applying pressure on allies to firmly align behind action against ISIS. Secretary of State John Kerry is scheduled to travel to Saudi Arabia and Jordan to meet with Mideast leaders and assess their level of commitment to a growing worldwide coalition. The Associated Press reported that Kerry pressed a core group of 10 countries to form a loose coalition to target last week's NATO summit. Along with the United States, the coalition includes the United Kingdom, France, Australia, Germany, Canada, Turkey, Italy, Poland, and Denmark.

As he deliberates his next move, Obama is seeking advice from prominent foreign policy experts across the political spectrum over dinner at the White House. Among the guests invited to join Obama and Vice President Joe Biden were former national security advisers from the Obama, George W. Bush, Clinton, and Carter administrations, as well as Council on Foreign Relations President Richard Haass and former Acting CIA Director Michael Morrell.

In a call Monday evening, Obama congratulated new Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi for the approval of a new government. The White House said al-Abadi "expressed his commitment to work with all communities in Iraq as well as regional and international partners to strengthen Iraq's capabilities" to fight the Islamic State militants.

Obama also spoke with Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott on the need to continue addressing the ongoing threat from the Islamic State and to thank Australia for its contributions to humanitarian air drops in northern Iraq, according to the White House.

Title: White House Shifts Focus to Economic Recovery as CDC Releases Guidelines for Reopening Businesses

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has released new guidelines for the safe reopening of businesses, schools, churches, and other organizations as states gradually lift their coronavirus restrictions. The recommendations, which are still subject to revision, offer advice on how to reopen various types of entities, including schools, religious facilities, workplaces, and restaurants.

The CDC has put together "decision trees" for at least seven types of organizations: schools, camps, childcare centers, religious facilities, mass transit systems, workplaces, and bars/restaurants. The recommendations were obtained from a federal official who was not authorized to release them publicly.

In the initial reopening phases, schools should space desks six feet apart, nix any field trips and school assemblies, and have students eat lunch in their classrooms instead of the cafeteria. Churches should hold services through video streaming or at drive-in or outdoor venues as much as possible. They should also encourage everyone to wear cloth face masks, use a stationary collection box, and schedule extra services if necessary to make sure church pews are not packed and congregants stay at least six feet from each other.

Restaurants should consider using throwaway menus, single-service condiments, and disposable forks, knives, spoons, and dishes. They should install sneeze guards at cash registers, limit the number of employees on a shift, and avoid having buffets, salad bars, and drink stations.

The guidance for religious groups includes providing congregants spiritual and emotional care "on a flexible or virtual basis or refer them to other available resources."

Allen Fagin, executive vice president of the Orthodox Union, said that as much as worship in synagogues is "one of the most fundamental aspects of Jewish life," his faith also believes that "the sanctity of life is more important than any other aspect of observance."

The application of any guidelines is likely to have significant regional and demographic variation, Fagin added. "There's going to have to be a great deal of both training and soul-searching in particular communities to make certain the guidelines are understood and will in fact be adhered to, to the letter," he said.

Various trade groups have also started coming out with their own recommendations. For example, the National Restaurant Association last week put out guidance to restaurants considering reopening. The association said restaurants should clean and sanitize reusable menus, while the CDC suggests using disposable menus. And the CDC recommends that employees use cloth masks when interacting with customers, but the association doesn't. But some guidance is similar. The association and the CDC both recommend seating dining parties at least 6 feet apart.

Larry Lynch, a senior vice president at the trade group, said the restaurant industry is already heavily regulated in order to prevent foodborne illnesses. So he doesn't think additional guidelines from the CDC are onerous.

"The fact is we're probably already 80% of the way there with the mandates coming out of the food code," he said.

Lynch said the biggest concern for restaurant owners isn't federal guidelines, but convincing people that it's safe to return to restaurants.

Many companies, especially those with strong remote work capabilities, are already drawing up plans that go beyond the CDC's guidelines, said Bhushan Sethi, global people and organization leader at PwC, a consulting firm. He said many companies are considering keeping their employees working from home well after authorities lift stay-at-home orders.

"It's a bare minimum compared to the playbook that many firms are putting in place," Sethi said of the CDC guidelines on workplaces. "Firms are acknowledging that people are going to be fearful."

About 65% of companies recently surveyed by PwC are planning to reconfigure work sites to allow physical distancing. Some 52% are planning staggered shifts or alternating crews, according to the April 18-22 survey of chief financial officers at 305 U.S. companies.

Title: David Brock Assumes Control of Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington

Article:

David Brock, a self-proclaimed former right-wing hitman turned Clinton enforcer, has taken over as chairman of Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW), a leading watchdog group. The move, confirmed by Brock in an interview, marks a significant expansion of his political influence.

Under Brock's leadership, CREW is set to undergo a transformation, becoming a more politically oriented attack dog organization. The reconfigured CREW will establish a more politically focused arm, expand its focus into state politics, and engage in closer coordination with Brock's fleet of Democrat-backing nonprofits and super PACs, including Media Matters, American Bridge, and the American Independent Institute.

Brock, who founded Media Matters in 2004, described the changes as providing "potentially powerful tools in the tool box." He stated, "We have been in the accountability for 10 years very successfully. It is kind of a one-stop-shop now."

In addition to the restructured CREW, Brock is also forming a new, overtly partisan watchdog group called The American Democracy Legal Fund. This group, to be run by Brad Woodhouse, president of American Bridge, will operate under section 527 of the Tax Code, allowing it to engage in more political activity than CREW's traditional portfolio.

CREW was founded in 2003 by former federal prosecutor Melanie Sloan and white-collar lawyer Norm Eisen. The group gained a reputation for relentlessly pursuing litigation and ethics complaints against primarily Republican public officials, playing a significant role in the Jack Abramoff scandal and the downfalls of powerful GOP Reps. Tom DeLay and Bob Ney during the Bush administration.

Under the stewardship of Sloan, who serves as CREW's executive director, the group has maintained a non-partisan approach, pursuing corruption allegations regardless of political affiliation. CREW's annual "Most Corrupt Members of Congress" report, which started in 2005, has included 25 Democrats among its 88 featured members. The group has also called for the resignations of embattled New York Democratic Reps. Anthony Weiner and Charlie Rangel, and has pending requests for investigations into the Obama administration.

The exact details of the new structure and operations of CREW under Brock's leadership are still unfolding. Further information regarding the new executive director and the specifics of the group's expanded focus are yet to be announced.

Title: Trump Threatens Protesters Ahead of Tulsa Rally, Cites Increased Security Measures

Article:

President Donald Trump, in preparation for his first campaign rally in months in Tulsa, Oklahoma, on Saturday, has threatened any protesters who may attempt to disrupt the event, stating that the situation will be "a much different scene" compared to how protesters have been handled in cities like New York, Seattle, or Minneapolis.

In a tweet on Friday morning, Trump wrote, "Any protesters, anarchists, agitators, looters or lowlifes who are going to Oklahoma please understand, you will not be treated like you have been in New York, Seattle, or Minneapolis. It will be a much different scene!"

The specifics of Trump's threat and the actions he could take to enforce it remain unclear. However, the president has taken a more hostile stance towards protesters in recent weeks, categorizing "protesters" alongside "anarchists," "looters," and "lowlifes."

Trump has previously blamed the antifa movement for violence at protests without providing evidence and has boasted about the National Guard's handling of protesters in Minneapolis, comparing it to a "knife cutting butter."

A curfew was imposed in Tulsa beginning Thursday night and continuing into the weekend, according to Tulsa's mayor, due to concerns about organized groups coming to the city. Mayor G.T. Bynum stated, "Last night, I enacted a curfew at the request of Tulsa Police Chief Wendell Franklin, following consultation with the United States Secret Service based on intelligence they had received. Today, we were told the curfew is no longer necessary so I am rescinding it."

Trump later tweeted, "I just spoke to the highly respected Mayor of Tulsa, G.T. Bynum, who informed me there will be no curfew tonight or tomorrow for our many supporters attending the #MAGA Rally. Enjoy yourselves - thank you to Mayor Bynum!"

The rally was initially scheduled for June 19, known as Juneteenth, the holiday marking when the last enslaved people were informed of their freedom, more than two years after President Abraham Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation. In a rare move, the president, after consulting with two black Secret Service agents, announced last week that he would reschedule the rally for the following day.

Tensions in the city are not limited to race, as Oklahoma is still grappling with the coronavirus and has seen a recent increase in cases. The city is also the site of a race massacre in 1921, in which as many as 300 black residents were killed by whites.

Concerns about the rally extend beyond race, as the state is still battling the coronavirus. Trump, in another tweet on Friday, referred to the Tulsa rally as the re-launch of his reelection campaign, stating, "Big crowds and lines already forming in Tulsa. My campaign hasn’t started yet. It starts on Saturday night in Oklahoma!"

The rally is expected to draw as many as 100,000 Trump supporters, with some having lined up outside the 19,000-seat Bank of Oklahoma Center in Tulsa days before the rally. Trump claimed this week that over a million people had requested tickets for the event, and his campaign has been exploring possible venues for an overflow crowd.

Oklahoma's Republican Gov. Kevin Stitt supported the rally during a meeting with Trump at the White House on Thursday for an unrelated event focused on government assistance for small businesses. Stitt assured the rally would be safe, despite a city health official labeling an event like the rally a "huge risk factor" for spreading the coronavirus.

Trump boasted about the demand for tickets to his first rally during the ongoing pandemic and cited the state's handling of the pandemic as one reason his campaign chose Oklahoma. "We're so excited to have you," Stitt told Trump. "And like you said, I don't know if people caught that but over a million people have requested tickets to come to come to this event so it's just gon na be amazing."

Trump campaign spokesperson Erin Perrine told ABC News the campaign "takes the health and safety of rally-goers seriously and is taking precautions to make the rally safe," including temperature checks for attendees and providing them with face masks and hand sanitizer.

Title: Criticism of WHO's Response to China's Handling of COVID-19 Pandemic Raises Questions About Organization's Structure and Funding

Article:

The World Health Organization (WHO) has faced criticism from the left for its response to China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, but calls for drastic measures such as cutting its funding during a global health crisis are being met with skepticism.

The WHO's constant praise for China's response has left many exasperated, with some arguing that the organization has been too lenient towards China due to its status as a major donor and an important backer of its current leader, Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus.

President Donald Trump has been a vocal critic of the WHO, raising concerns about its handling of the pandemic, but some argue that his approach is misguided. Amanda Glassman, the executive vice-president and senior fellow at the Center for Global Development, stated that a deeper problem is the WHO's low budget and relatively toothless structure.

Unlike the International Atomic Energy Agency, the WHO has no redress against governments that do not cooperate. Glassman said, "It operates in countries at the pleasure and permission of the host country governments. So in the case of China, to be allowed to enter China, it was a negotiation to get there."

Disagreements with the WHO should not lead to the US slamming the group or withdrawing support. The global community still needs an authoritative body that sets standards, collates, and studies all of the pieces of the Covid-19 puzzle coming in from affected countries.

Early on, when the WHO wasn't as harsh on China as it perhaps should have been, it was not getting support from the United States to do anything differently. Global public health expert Stephen Morrison stated that it's important to remember that the WHO is an organization made up of its member states. To forcefully take on one of those members (in this case, China), it needs the backing of the others.

Trump's criticism of the WHO has been inconsistent, as he has repeatedly vouched for China's efforts and transparency in handling the pandemic. Early on, when the WHO wasn't as harsh on China as it perhaps should have been, it was not getting support from the United States to do anything differently.

In conclusion, the WHO is in need of reform, but at a time when humankind is literally fighting for its life, now is not the wrong time to decapitate the agency leading the global response. If not the WHO, then who?

Title: Potential Pitfalls in Upcoming Republican Immigration Bills: Enforcement, Citizenship, and Visa Reforms

Article:

As the United States awaits a Republican-proposed immigration bill, several key issues have emerged that warrant close attention. The potential legislation must address the possibility of immigrants gaining citizenship, enforcement measures, and visa availability.

One of the primary concerns is the citizenship issue. Any legalization plan should allow for the potential of immigrants becoming American citizens. While the principles rule out a "special" path to citizenship, they do not exclude the possibility of eventual naturalization for the estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants. The specifics of this process, however, remain unclear at this time.

Republicans are reportedly demanding "significant fines" and other penalties for undocumented immigrants, and the meeting of enforcement benchmarks as a condition for legalization. They also propose mandatory national expansion of the E-Verify hiring database and a new entry-exit visa system. However, new layers of enforcement should not be so onerous as to prevent immigrants from leaving the shadows, and reforms to legal immigration must be expansive enough to ease crushing backlogs that discourage potential immigrants.

Increased powers for states and localities to enforce immigration laws, potentially leading to racial profiling and other abuses, have no place in any bill.

As we wait for a bill, deportations continue. The Obama administration has expelled nearly two million people, breaking up thousands of families that President Obama has repeatedly promised to protect. If Congress fails to pass comprehensive immigration reform, will the President protect these individuals through his own administrative action, as he already has by deferring deportations for a relative handful of unauthorized youths?

The road to comprehensive immigration reform has been long and fraught with obstacles. The hopeful days of bipartisan Senate legislation in 2013, eventually killed by a Republican filibuster, are a distant memory. Now, as Republicans, traditionally advocates of self-deportation and Arizona-style laws, may be edging closer to saying yes to legal status for millions of the undocumented, the question remains: Are they serious, and will any bills get past the party's "hell no" caucus? It will soon become clear whether this is the first step back toward the rational, humane reform that should have passed years ago.

Title: House Approves One-Week Extension for DHS Funding, Long-Term Bill Remains Unresolved

Article:

The U.S. House of Representatives approved a one-week extension of funding for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) on Friday, following a day of intense negotiations. President Obama signed the bill later that day. The passage of the one-week extension came after a longer three-week stopgap was rejected in the House.

The contentious issue that has delayed a longer-term funding bill, the inclusion of a push-back on President Obama's executive action on immigration, remains unresolved. The fresh deadline to resolve the impasse is approaching.

According to NPR's Ailsa Chang, speaking on Weekend Edition Saturday, the lack of coordination between Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker John Boehner created tension between the two chambers. Many House Republicans resented being pressured by the Senate to pass a long-term funding bill, which is one reason they pushed back with a shorter-term bill.

Republicans anticipate that next week, the House will likely align with the Senate's bill, funding DHS through September without immigration changes. "I don't think there's any alternative," said Rep. Charlie Dent (R-PA). "When we're at the end of next week, what do we do?"

An aide to House Speaker John Boehner (R-OH) stated that the Republican leader had made no commitment, but House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) expressed expectation that the one-week measure would provide the necessary time to pass a funding measure covering the remainder of the fiscal year.

Boehner's allies are concerned that his critics within the Republican Conference may attempt to oust him as speaker if, as expected, he puts a long-term DHS funding bill on the House floor next week. While Boehner dismisses such speculation, close friends believe such a move is a real possibility.

Twenty-five Republicans voted against Boehner for speaker on the floor in early January, signaling his continued problems with his conservative hardliners. Boehner's allies believe that the DHS debacle on Friday, when 52 Republicans voted against the three-week plan, was in part aimed at toppling the speaker.

Chang notes that Boehner has a vocal and determined contingent of conservatives in his caucus who are not afraid to challenge him, and this group is larger now than before the election. More than 50 Republicans voted against Boehner's first plan on Friday.

Title: Democrats Express Concern Over Hillary Clinton's Public Remarks on 2016 Election

Article:

Democrats, including staunch supporters and former aides of Hillary Clinton, have expressed concern over the former Secretary of State's public remarks regarding her loss in the 2016 presidential election. Many Democrats believe that her continued criticism of the Democratic National Committee and her handling of the election are hurting the party and making her appear bitter.

In interviews with over a dozen Democrats, they acknowledged the need for Clinton to explain her election loss and empathized with her anger over the FBI's investigation into her private email server. However, they unanimously agreed that Clinton needs to rethink her public blaming tour.

One longtime aide questioned Clinton's strategy, stating, "Good God, what is she doing? She's apparently still really, really angry. The election was stolen from her, and that's how she feels. But to go out there publicly again and again and talk about it? And then blame the DNC?"

Former Obama aides are also puzzled by Clinton's strategy. At the Recode conference, Clinton stated that she had inherited nothing from a "bankrupt" Democratic Party led by Obama for eight years. A former senior aide to Obama commented, "If she is trying to come across as the leader of the angry movement of what happened in 2016, then she's achieving it. But part of the problem she had was she didn't have a vision for the Democratic Party, and she needs to now take a break and let others come to the forefront."

The Democratic Party is currently feeling somewhat leaderless after the eight years of Obama and the surprise Clinton defeat. President Obama has largely gone out of public view, though he reappeared this week with a statement criticizing President Trump for pulling the United States from the Paris climate deal. Advisers to Obama have said he wants to give a new generation of leaders room to grow.

Sen. Bernie Sanders is perhaps the leading figure on the left after he gave Clinton a run for her money in the 2016 primary. However, he is not even a member of the Democratic Party. Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez is still adjusting to his leadership position after winning his post in a contest with Rep. Keith Ellison. The two have worked hard to forge a united front since the election.

The former Obama aide stated that Clinton's criticisms of the DNC can make it tougher for new leaders to come forward. "It's hard to do that when you have the former nominee out there in a newsy, aggressive manner," the aide said.

While Obama has made public appearances since leaving office, he has generally refrained from talking about Trump. Instead, he has held events focused on getting young adults active in civic engagement. This puts Obama in the tradition of other past presidents who have generally sought to avoid public criticisms of their immediate successors. Whether Obama will continue to avoid public criticisms of Trump is unclear.

Longtime aides and advisers say Clinton will not run for public office again and that she feels liberated to finally speak her mind. They anticipate that Clinton will keep discussing the election, particularly to promote her upcoming book, which is expected to be published this fall.

"She's saying the same stuff she would say on a phone call with me," said one former aide who worked on the 2016 campaign. "And I think she'll continue to have a national dialogue on what needs to be fixed."

Democratic strategist Brad Bannon stated, "I'm not sure there is a political strategy here. It sounds to me like more of a personal strategy." Bannon added, "Complaining about an outcome and blaming everyone else is not a good political strategy."

Jamal Simmons, a Democratic strategist, acknowledged some frustration among Democrats over Clinton's remarks. "Some people I know are just frustrated that it's happening," he said. "She is a national hero and a great public servant and has the right to be upset."

Simmons added that if she's going to discuss the loss, "it would be nice to hear a little more about the things she did wrong, which I believe mattered more than what she has discussed." Simmons, who worked for Al Gore, stated, "When Al Gore lost the election, he went to Europe, gained weight, and grew a beard. He walked away. And there's something to that."

Title: President Trump Urges West Virginia Voters to Oppose Don Blankenship in Senate Primary

Article:

In a tweet on Monday, President Donald Trump urged Republican primary voters in West Virginia to oppose former coal baron Don Blankenship in the upcoming Senate primary. Trump instead endorsed two of his rivals, Attorney General Patrick Morrisey and Representative Evan Jenkins.

"To the great people of West Virginia, we have, together, a really great chance to keep making a big difference. Problem is, Don Blankenship, currently running for Senate, can’t win the General Election in your State... No way! Remember Alabama. Vote Rep. Jenkins or A.G. Morrisey!" Trump tweeted.

The president's tweet comes ahead of Tuesday's primary in West Virginia, aiming to prevent a loss in the general election against Senator Joe Manchin, D-W.Va., in November.

Attorney General Patrick Morrisey and Representative Evan Jenkins have intensified their attacks on Blankenship, who is a former coal industry executive serving a year in prison for conspiring to violate mine safety laws in connection with the Upper Big Branch Mine explosion in West Virginia in 2010 that killed 29 workers. Blankenship's parole is set to end on Wednesday, the day after West Virginians cast their ballots.

Over the weekend, Morrisey announced plans to have Blankenship disqualified from the race for failing to submit a financial disclosure, a violation of election law. "My campaign will be informing his probation officer in Nevada about this issue right away, to determine if this refusal to comply with federal law violates the terms of his supervised release," Morrisey said.

Blankenship's campaign stated that if he wins the primary, it will release paperwork detailing his finances the following week. Blankenship also responded to Trump's tweet, expressing confidence that "we’re still going to win" and stating that the president must not understand West Virginia politics.

"Neither of my opponents can beat Joe Manchin without my support, but I will beat Joe Manchin even without the support of the establishment," Blankenship vowed. "... Tomorrow, West Virginia will send the swamp a message—no one, and I mean no one, will tell us how to vote. As some have said, I am Trumpier than Trump, and this morning proves it."

Meanwhile, Morrisey has started using "robo-calls" to potential voters, stating, "Convicted criminal Don Blankenship didn’t vote for President Trump and is a resident of Nevada, where he must report to his parole officer."

Blankenship has campaigned as an outsider against the Washington establishment. However, top Republicans see similarities to GOP candidate Roy Moore, who lost the Alabama special election race amid allegations of sexual misconduct, ultimately flipping the seat blue for the first time in decades.

Blankenship has also been accused of running racially charged ads in recent weeks. Trump's eldest son, Donald Trump Jr., came out against Blankenship just days ago, citing the Moore example.

"I hate to lose. So I’m gon na go out on a limb here and ask the people of West Virginia to make a wise decision and reject Blankenship! No more fumbles like Alabama. We need to win in November. # wv # wvpol," Trump Jr. tweeted.

Blankenship has also taken direct aim at Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., another move from Moore's playbook. The candidate has called McConnell "Cocaine Mitch" and attempted to link the leader to a 2014 report about drugs purportedly found on a ship owned by his in-laws.

Blankenship has accused McConnell of creating jobs for "Chinapeople" and said his "China family" has given him millions of dollars. McConnell's wife, Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao, was born in Taiwan. Her father, entrepreneur and philanthropist James S.C. Chao, was born in China.

In addition to West Virginia, North Carolina, Ohio, and Indiana will hold primary elections on Tuesday ahead of the midterms. Trump won each of the four states in the 2016 presidential race.

Title: Supreme Court Establishes Right to Unanimous Jury Verdicts in State and Federal Trials

Article:

In a landmark decision on Monday, the Supreme Court, by a vote of 6-3, overturned a previous ruling that the Sixth Amendment does not guarantee a right to a unanimous jury in state trials. The ruling, which was a reversal of a 1972 decision, will now apply to both federal and state courts.

The ruling overturned the conviction of Evangelisto Ramos, who is serving a life sentence in Louisiana for a 2016 murder conviction following a jury vote of 10-2. The court's decision is significant as it continues a trend in which the court has held that protections in the Bill of Rights that originally applied only to the federal government also apply to actions by state governments.

The court's ruling is important because it establishes that most of the significant protections of the Bill of Rights—the ones dealing with personal liberty—do apply to the states. This is not just a legal nicety. At a time when the relationship between the states and the federal government is being newly debated, it's important that there is no daylight between the two when it comes to fundamental rights. Where basic rights are concerned, this must be one country.

Louisiana and Oregon, which have long since renounced the racist underpinnings of their non-unanimity rule, nonetheless retained it on less noxious but still ill-conceived reasoning. The theory that non-unanimity discourages hung juries, which waste resources, since cases then have to be retried, has been criticized for ignoring that a unanimous jury is a fundamental right and for proceeding on two faulty assumptions: (1) Hung juries are worse than wrongful convictions or acquittals, and (2) permitting non-unanimous verdicts makes hung juries less likely—to the contrary; it undermines the spirit of open-minded deliberation that encourages juries to arrive at a consensus.

A 2018 report from the New Orleans Advocate validated what many had long suspected: that split-decision verdicts were particularly harmful in cases where the defendant was black, or when black people served on majority white juries. According to the paper's research, black defendants in Louisiana were 30 percent more likely to be convicted by a split jury decision. When jurors don't have to agree on a decision, jury members with strong dissenting opinions are effectively silenced. The Advocate found that in some parishes, this happened more frequently to black jurors.

Justice Alito pointed out in Monday's dissenting opinion that Louisiana and Oregon now face 'a potential tsunami of litigation' as defendants seek new trials for convictions that weren't decided unanimously. However, this crush of appeals signifies something valuable—it's proof of the necessity of today's ruling. The sheer fact there could be so many people denied a fair and just trial is exactly what made today's majority opinion so important, and for too many, so overdue.

Title: President Obama to Discuss Counterterrorism Strategies Amidst Increased Fears of Terrorism

Article:

In an attempt to alleviate concerns regarding terrorism, President Obama will spend a significant portion of the coming week discussing his strategies for combatting the Islamic State (IS) militant group both domestically and internationally. The president has adopted a more reassuring tone in response to terrorist attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, California, urging Americans not to succumb to distrust and fear.

"Terrorists like ISIL are trying to divide us along lines of religion and background," Obama stated in his weekly address on Sunday, using an acronym for the extremist group. "That's how they stoke fear. That's how they recruit."

However, for an increasing number of Americans, these fears are becoming increasingly real, following terrorist attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, California. A recent poll found that 5 in 10 Americans believed the risk of a terrorist attack in the United States was high. A new survey reveals that this number has increased to 7 in 10, despite attempts by the government to assure citizens that there are no credible threats to the US.

In an effort to publicize the government's counterterrorism efforts, the president has scheduled a series of high-profile visits to the Pentagon and the National Counterterrorism Center this week, before leaving Washington for his annual two-week family holiday in Hawaii.

The Dec. 2 mass shooting in San Bernardino has raised concerns about the US government's ability to identify lone-wolf radicals who may have been inspired by Islamic State. The US government has been successful in intercepting would-be terrorists who have been in contact with terrorist recruiters online, but the fact that the shooters in the San Bernardino attacks managed to remain under the government's radar until they killed 14 people at a health department holiday party has fueled fears that the government may not be doing enough.

The recruitment strategies employed by IS, including an online approach that focuses on inspiring lone attacks, have forced US intelligence officials to engage in a war on multiple fronts, from the Middle East to social media.

Obama will begin the week with a National Security Council meeting at the Pentagon, followed by a public update about the US strategy against Islamic State. On Thursday, Obama will visit the National Counterterrorism Center, which analyzes intelligence to stay abreast of recruiting methods and other information on terrorist groups. Obama is scheduled to address reporters after a briefing at the suburban Virginia facility.

The visits are seen as counterweights to the increased fear over terror attacks in the public and in the widely-viewed presidential election campaigns. Previously, Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump proposed banning Muslims from entering the US, a suggestion that the president has alluded to in public comments urging Americans to remain united.

"We cannot turn against one another by letting this fight be defined as a war between America and Islam," Obama said on Sunday.

Title: Clinton Accuses Sanders of Seeking to Abolish Obamacare Through Single-Payer Healthcare Proposal

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton has accused her primary rival, Bernie Sanders, of aiming to abolish the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) through his proposal for a single-payer healthcare system. The attack stems from a bill Sanders introduced in the Senate in 2013, which would have established national single-payer healthcare with state-run programs overseen by a federal board.

Sanders' bill, in some ways, mirrors Obamacare, allowing each state the option to set up a marketplace exchange for insurance plans, with the federal government operating a large exchange for states that opt out. The bill would have folded federal programs like Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP into these state-run programs.

However, Clinton's specific accusation that Sanders' single-payer plan would allow states to opt out entirely is questionable, as it contradicts the progressive nature of the proposal. The Clinton campaign has aggressively pursued this attack throughout the week, with Chelsea Clinton, who is not typically an attack dog, criticizing Sanders' plan for potentially stripping millions of people of their health insurance.

The debate between Clinton and Sanders over healthcare proposals is a contentious issue within the Democratic party, with some suggesting that it could lead to a sharpening of the general Democratic healthcare platform before the general election. Some have also proposed the possibility of Sanders and Clinton uniting to push for a public option, a proposal that was taken off the table during the drafting of the ACA in 2009, damaging the progressive credibility of the law in some circles.

Regardless of the specific healthcare proposals, it is unlikely that any will pass through the Congress that the next president will be saddled with. The major barrier to enacting single-payer or adding a public option to the ACA remains Congress and the army of industry lobbyists who will descend on it when the insurance companies perceive their bottom lines to be in jeopardy. Additionally, the House of Representatives is likely to remain under Republican control after November, and these Republicans are expected to continue their obstructionist tactics.

Even if the House flips to the Democrats, a president would still have to contend with the Senate, where the Democratic majority is not guaranteed. The Senate, like the House, is a complex and often unpredictable body, with a history of bipartisan cooperation and obstruction.

In conclusion, the debate between Clinton and Sanders over healthcare proposals is a valuable discussion for the Democratic party, as it sharpens the party's platform and highlights the challenges of enacting progressive healthcare reform. However, it is essential to remember that the major barrier to enacting single-payer or adding a public option to the ACA remains Congress and the powerful lobbying forces that oppose such reforms.

Title: Texas Authorities to Seek Adult Court for Ethan Couch, Missing Teen Involved in Fatal Drunk-Driving Accident

Article:
