Texas authorities have announced their intention to seek adult prison for Ethan Couch, the teenager who used the "affluenza" defense in a juvenile court case for a drunk-driving accident that resulted in the deaths of four people in 2013. Couch was taken into custody in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, on Monday, nearly two weeks after he failed to appear for a probation appointment.

During a press conference on Tuesday, authorities outlined potential legal options for the state to pursue. Couch is scheduled for a court hearing on January 19, where the district attorney will motion to move the juvenile case to adult court. The juvenile judge will make the final decision on the case's location.

Couch and his mother, Tonya Couch, were located and arrested by Mexican authorities on a road in Puerto Vallarta. Couch, who was previously known for his blond hair, had brown hair during the arrest, but authorities were able to make a positive identification.

Authorities believe the two planned their escape, with Tarrant County Sheriff Dee Anderson stating, "They even had something that was almost akin to a going-away party before leaving town."

An arrest warrant will be issued for Tonya Couch on charges of hindering an apprehension. Prosecutors plan to ask a judge to transfer Ethan Couch's case to adult court during a hearing next month.

Couch's attorneys, Scott Brown and Reagan Wynn, have stated they will not comment on the case until they speak with their client, which is unlikely to happen before Couch returns to the United States. The two are currently being held at immigration offices in the state capital, Guadalajara, and are expected to return to the United States aboard a commercial flight to Houston on Tuesday.

Mexico's Jalisco state prosecutors' office stated its agents had been working with American authorities since December 26 to track down and capture Couch and his mother. They were found in a less affluent section of Puerto Vallarta's old town, far from the city's glitzy resorts, golf courses, and high-rise hotels.

Couch was apparently trying to lie low; a photo distributed by the Jalisco state prosecutor's office shows him in detention with his blond hair dyed black and his normally blondish beard a light brown.

Tarrant County Sheriff Dee Anderson believes the two fled in late November after a video surfaced that appears to show Couch at a party where people were drinking. If found to be drinking, Couch's probation could be revoked, and he could be sentenced to up to 10 years in prison.

Couch was driving drunk and speeding on a dark two-lane road south of Fort Worth in June 2013 when he crashed into a disabled SUV off to the side, killing four people and injuring several others, including passengers in Couch's pickup truck.

He pleaded guilty to four counts of intoxication manslaughter and two counts of intoxication assault causing serious bodily injury. Because of his age, he was not certified as an adult for trial, and a judge sentenced him in juvenile court to 10 years' probation and a stint in a rehabilitation center.

The U.S. Marshals Service had issued a wanted poster promising a reward of up to $5,000 for information leading to Ethan Couch's whereabouts and capture.

Title: McAuliffe's Campaign Focused on Virginia, Not the Clintons, Despite Clinton Associates' Involvement

Article:

Terry McAuliffe's 2013 gubernatorial campaign in Virginia is attracting attention as a potential testing ground for Hillary Clinton's political influence, according to several donors and operatives. McAuliffe, a close associate of the Clintons, has stocked his campaign with top-tier talent likely to be involved in any potential Hillary Clinton presidential effort.

Notably, McAuliffe's campaign has raised nearly $2 million in March alone at a half-dozen out-of-state fundraisers featuring former President Bill Clinton or other Clinton insiders. Robby Mook, Patrick Hallahan, Jonathan Mantz, and Jackson Dunn are among the key figures in McAuliffe's campaign team.

The success or failure of McAuliffe's campaign serves as a measure of Clinton's strength and organization in a critical swing state, as Virginia now rivals Ohio in its significance for winning a presidential election. However, McAuliffe's campaign and its surrogates have officially discouraged the perception that it is a Clinton farm team.

It remains unclear whether Clinton has endorsed McAuliffe's fundraising pitches, with Clinton herself leaving campaigning and fundraising to her husband. Discussions of 2016 could potentially complicate McAuliffe's message in his tight race against Republican state Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli.

McAuliffe has sought to portray himself as a moderate Virginia businessman rather than a Washington insider, despite his close ties to the Clintons. James Carville, a longtime political strategist and Clinton loyalist, stated that McAuliffe and his team have not pitched his campaign as a Clinton effort-in-waiting. Carville, who hosted a fundraiser for McAuliffe last month, emphasized that McAuliffe has his own political base.

Another McAuliffe fundraiser in Georgetown last month raised $170,000 from a group of longtime allies and protégés that resembled a Clinton kitchen cabinet-in-waiting. The event, held at Harold Ickes' Washington home, was co-hosted by Ickes, Dick Gephardt, and their lobbying partners, as well as Jonathan Mantz and other Clinton loyalists. The invitation described McAuliffe as "a mentor to all of us...now it is time to elect him governor."

Title: BD Medical Technology Company Shifts Manufacturing to Mexico Due to U.S. Tariffs

Article:

BD, a medical technology company, announced last month that it was relocating some of its manufacturing from China to Mexico, in part due to the Trump administration's tariffs. Troy Kirkpatrick, a spokesman for BD, stated on Friday that the company was still in the process of making the shift, involving diagnostic devices and other products, and was assessing the latest tariff announcement.

On Thursday evening, President Trump announced via Twitter that he would impose a 5% tariff on Mexican imports starting June 10, with the potential to increase to 25% by October if immigration issues were not resolved. The immediate impact of these tariffs could be felt by consumers, particularly in the fresh fruits and vegetables market, where distributors may have little choice but to pass on costs.

Emily Blanchard, an economist at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College, expressed concern, stating, "As a consumer, that was my first thought. Those are my avocados and strawberries. What are you doing?"

For other products, the effects could be more gradual. Companies may initially absorb some of the costs to avoid losing business or on higher-margin items where they face competition from domestic producers. However, economic research shows that consumers eventually bear the brunt of tariffs. The impact could be greater in the case of trade with Mexico because many imports from there contain parts or materials from American factories.

Katheryn Russ, an economist at the University of California, Davis, commented, "We're taxing ourselves on our own goods."

Economists suggest that the direct effects of a 5% or even 10% tariff would likely be small, especially with a strong economy and low inflation. The larger threat, they say, is the disruption these tariffs could cause for automakers and others who have come to rely on supply chains that seamlessly cross international boundaries. Over time, these supply chains could break down, particularly if companies decide they cannot trust trade rules to be consistent from one year to the next.

Brian Dunch, a trade expert at PricewaterhouseCoopers, stated, "It's the cumulative effect of all this uncertainty. You'll see supply chains Balkanize."

Title: Sanders Loses in States with Higher Income Inequality

Article:

Bernie Sanders, the Democratic presidential candidate who has built his campaign on addressing income inequality, has been losing in states where income inequality is worse. Conversely, Hillary Clinton, his main rival, has been winning in states with higher income inequality.

This counterintuitive trend is evident in a chart of all 50 states showing their distance from the median of the Gini index, a widely used statistic that measures income inequality on a scale from 0 (total inequality) to 1 (total equality). The states are lined up from left to right, from the most equal (Alaska, at 0.4146, or 0.455 from the median) to the most unequal (New York, at 0.5048, or 0.447 from the median).

The pattern is striking: Clinton clearly wins in the most unequal states. And even in the one fairly equal state she won—Iowa (that lonely, farthest-left green bar)—she barely won, and even then only among "state delegate equivalents," not voters.

This trend does not necessarily mean that Clinton is beating Sanders at appealing to voters on the basis of inequality. Instead, it may suggest that primary turnout is far more about party organization and campaign mobilization.

There are several factors that may be contributing to this trend. Race may play a role, as the South is both heavily unequal and heavily black. American blacks in general are more economically disadvantaged than whites nationwide, due in part to what they call "deep-rooted, systemic problems." Sanders also appeals explicitly to rural voters in particular with his gun control stances, which may have helped fuel his performance in states with larger rural populations.

The simple geography of where candidates are from also played a small role here. Sanders happens to be from Vermont, the 11th most equal state. Clinton, meanwhile, claims New York (most unequal) as her home state, and just won there.

It's also true that inequality in New York is not the same as inequality in Louisiana, despite the fact that their Gini measures are pretty close. High poverty levels help drive Southern inequality, while in states like New York, Wall Street executives help push inequality higher.

The Gini index covers the full spectrum of income inequality, but the results are a bit more mixed when you look at another measure, like how much of the income the one-percenters earn. True, Clinton is still leading in the most-unequal state (New York) and Sanders still wins some of those most-equal states (Alaska, Hawaii, Vermont). But those Southern states are more mixed into the middle.

Still, given Sanders' focus on the issue, he and his campaign might have thought he would be able to break through in places where inequality was worst. It just hasn't happened.

Title: Schumer Criticizes Trump's Nominees, Cites Lack of Transparency and Paperwork Issues

Article:

Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer (D-NY) criticized President-elect Donald Trump's nominees during a press conference on Wednesday, labeling the cabinet picks as a "swamp cabinet" due to their backgrounds as bankers and billionaires. Schumer expressed disapproval over the scheduling of hearings for some nominees who had not yet submitted their paperwork to the Office of Government Ethics.

Specifically, Schumer pointed to Betsy DeVos, Trump's pick to lead the Department of Education, as her paperwork was not completed before Tuesday's hearing. "The last two weeks have not been good for open and transparent government," Schumer stated.

Democrats have called for another hearing for DeVos, and Schumer warned that if Democrats feel Republicans are rushing nominees, they will force "extensive debate" on the Senate floor. This could potentially slow down the Republicans' efforts to get nominees confirmed.

Senate leadership is currently negotiating over how many nominees will receive a vote before the full Senate on Friday.

In addition, Schumer suggested that Republicans should block Rep. Mick Mulvaney from leading the Office of Management and Budget due to his failure to pay taxes on a household employee. Schumer compared this to a scandal that derailed President Obama's initial Health and Human Services pick, Tom Daschle, who withdrew his 2009 nomination amid reports of unpaid taxes.

Mulvaney has since paid the $15,000 in taxes, as well as penalties, and the Trump team has dismissed the criticism, stating that Mulvaney has already taken "appropriate follow-up measures."

Title: Jack Lew's Confirmation Hearings: Questions on Fiscal Policy, Offshore Tax Havens, and Balanced Budget Claims

Article:

Jack Lew, President Obama's nominee for Treasury Secretary, faces a series of questions during his confirmation hearings today, primarily focusing on his role in the private sector, offshore tax havens, and his past claims about the federal debt and budget.

Lew, who served as the director of the Office of Management and Budget under President Obama, is expected to answer questions about his lucrative layover at Citigroup, including a $940,000 bonus he received before the bank received a government bailout. Senators will also inquire about his role in the accumulation of bad mortgage debt that led to the 2008 financial crisis.

The hearings will delve into Lew's understanding of finance, as he is an expert on fiscal issues but may lack knowledge about the private sector beyond the fact that large, highly regulated banks often hire powerful government officials. Senators will also question Lew about his decision to shelter his wealth in the Cayman Islands, and whether this action is consistent with the character he is expected to uphold as the head of the Treasury Department.

In addition to these personal questions, senators will ask about the president's disregard for budget and fiscal laws, such as the lack of a budget proposal this year and the president's failure to offer a solution when the Medicare trust fund is running low.

The hearings will also address the mounting federal debt, with Lew expected to finance an estimated $4 trillion in additional borrowing during President Obama's second term. With negotiations ongoing over the next fiscal crisis, Lew's answers will provide insight into the president's fiscal policy and his thoughts on the ongoing spending cuts agreed upon in the 2011 debt-limit deal.

One of the most contentious issues for Lew is his past claims that Obama's fiscal plan would lead to an end of borrowing and eventual debt reduction. Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-AL), the ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, has accused Lew of "deliberate artifice" for claiming that Obama's plan would lead to balanced budgets.

Sessions argues that Lew's claims were misleading, and he is counting on his colleagues to build a case against Lew, question by question. Democrats argue that Lew's claims were based on the expectation that Obama's plan would stimulate the economy, leading to increased revenues that could be plotted on a budget graph.

The hearings are unlikely to change many minds about the controversial nominee, but they will set the stage for a potential filibuster of Lew's nomination. If a powerful, high-ranking Republican accuses someone of lying under oath, his fellow Republicans will have to render their own judgment on the matter.

Lew is hoping to transition from a career focused on budget management into a role focused on policy and power. He will find that the stakes and consequences are much higher for the ones borrowing and spending the money rather than just counting it. With much eye-rolling about Obama's claims in his State of the Union speech that his new spending proposals wouldn't add "one dime" to the debt, it's a difficult moment for Lew to face Sessions' trap.

Title: US Government's Intervention in Sugar Market Leads to Artificial Price Hikes and Taxpayer Losses

Article:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has been running a series of farm-and-rural programs and subsidies that, in practice, function as corporate welfare for agribusiness. One of the most significant consequences of the government's persistent interference is the creation of an artificially high sugar market, which benefits a limited number of farmers at the expense of the economy at large.

The federal government has implemented complex loan programs, import barriers, and production quotas to maintain artificially high domestic sugar prices. This results in American taxpayers supporting domestic sugar producers against free-market competition, and consumers across the country paying higher prices as a result.

The USDA is expected to buy sugar in the domestic market this year to drive prices up and prevent defaults on loans made to sugar processors. According to Barbara Fecso, an economist at the USDA, the department may need to buy 400,000 tons of sugar to boost prices to an "acceptable level." A purchase of this amount would represent approximately 4.4% of projected U.S. sugar production in the marketing year ending on September 30.

To encourage ethanol producers to buy the sugar, the USDA's Commodity Credit Corporation is expected to sell it at a loss of about 10 cents per pound, totaling $80 million. According to Ms. Fecso, the USDA would incur losses if it acquires sugar in a down market, as it would need to dispose of the sugar to avoid owning it. The USDA is expected to lose money regardless of how it disposes of the sugar, but selling it to ethanol producers at least provides some return on the investment.

It is important to note that the information provided does not offer a clear explanation of the "acceptable level" of sugar prices or the specific economic ripple effects of the government's sugar market intervention. Additionally, the article does not provide a comparison of the cost of the sugar subsidies to the potential benefits for the economy at large.

Title: Study Highlights Concerns Over Declining Role of Facts in Public Life

Article:

A new study, "Truth Decay: An Initial Exploration of the Diminishing Role of Facts and Analysis in American Public Life," published by the Rand Corporation, examines the declining role of facts and analysis in public discourse. The study suggests that the increasing volume and velocity of information from the internet, social media, cable television, and talk radio are contributing factors to this trend.

The study identifies four trends that are detrimental to fact-based discourse and policymaking:

1. Increasing disagreement about facts and their interpretations.
2. The blurring of the line between fact and opinion.
3. The increasing quantity of opinion relative to facts.
4. Declining trust in formerly respected sources of factual information.

The authors, Michael D. Rich, the president of Rand, and his colleague Jennifer Kavanagh, argue that the information deluge, combined with the ability to curate personalized information, erodes society's assumption of a shared set of facts. This situation deepens the human proclivity for confirmation bias and motivated reasoning, leading to the formation of information silos.

The study also highlights the impact of gerrymandering, assortative mating, and geographic segregation of like-minded individuals, which contribute to the creation of echo chambers and polarization. Furthermore, the authors note that when filters and gatekeepers are removed, barriers to entry into public discourse become negligible, allowing for the proliferation of toxic digital subcultures.

The authors propose several suggestions to combat truth decay, ranging from teaching critical reasoning in schools to supporting long-form and investigative journalism with public funds. However, their primary purpose is to suggest research projects that will yield facts about the consequences of the new media and intellectual landscape.

The study also mentions the issue of simple mendacity, citing examples such as social-justice warriors at Google claiming that Lincoln was a member of the National Union Party instead of the Republican party. The authors caution that a default position of skepticism is defensible, given the historical context of deception in public life, such as Watergate, the Pentagon Papers, Iraq's missing weapons of mass destruction, and the "if you like your health care plan, you can keep it" controversy.

The study concludes by expressing concern over the spread of truth decay due to the proliferation of dime-store Nietzscheans on college campuses, who argue that there are no facts, only interpretations. The authors warn that what happens on campuses does not stay on campuses, and this ideology can have far-reaching consequences for public discourse and policymaking.

Title: Romney and Ryan Accuse Obama Administration of Inconsistency in Libya Attack Explanation

Article:

In a joint interview with running mate Paul Ryan, Mitt Romney accused the Obama administration of not being truthful about the circumstances surrounding the attack on the U.S. Consulate in Libya, which resulted in the death of U.S. Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans. Romney stated, "We expect candor from the president and transparency, and he continues to refuse what is said by the other members of his administration: This was a terrorist attack. We were attacked apparently by Al Qaeda and it is a very troubling development."

Romney's comments echoed complaints made by Republican lawmakers who question the administration's shifting explanation of the September 11 attack, initially described as "spontaneous" violence tied to protests over an anti-Islam film produced in the U.S. Obama officials have gradually walked back that description, and Obama acknowledged on Monday that it "was not just a mob action."

National Counterterrorism Center Director Matt Olsen was more direct last week, testifying to Congress that the four Americans "were killed in the course of a terrorist attack." Romney's running mate, Paul Ryan, questioned the president's consistency with his own administration officials, stating, "When the director of the Counterterrorism Center comes to Congress and testifies and says that this is a terrorist attack... I think you would want to ask that question of the president, why he is not on the same page with his own administration officials?"

Obama devoted much of his address to the United Nations General Assembly to the attack in Libya and unrest in the Mideast. He paid tribute to Ambassador Chris Stevens, recalling Stevens' time serving in the Peace Corps as an English instructor in Morocco. The president went on to restate his administration's support for the Arab Spring, calling it a "season of progress." However, he did not mention terrorism in his U.N. speech and has yet to elaborate on how extremists were able to launch what now appears to have been a coordinated attack on the consulate.

Obama, in an interview taped Monday on ABC's "The View," condemned extremist elements in the Muslim world and vowed the U.S. is "not going to shrink back from the world because of this." He also stated, "We are going to hunt down those who did this, we will bring them to justice." In the interview, which aired Tuesday, Obama said there was "no doubt" that the assault "was not just a mob action" but a sign of extremism in nations lacking stability.

In interviews and at campaign events Monday, Romney criticized Obama's leadership abroad, leading a chorus of Republicans in criticizing the president for what they said was minimizing the death of Ambassador Stevens. Obama, in an interview with CBS' "60 Minutes," said recent violence in the Mideast was due to "bumps in the road" on the way to democracy. Romney on Monday also suggested Obama was leaving American foreign policy at the mercy of events instead of working to shape global politics in America's interest.

Title: Congress Considers Gun Control Bills as Trump Outlines Policy Preferences Remain Unclear

Article:

The House Judiciary Committee will take up legislation on Tuesday aimed at preventing mass shootings, as lawmakers and the White House respond to a recent series of attacks across the country. The bills under consideration include measures to limit access to high-capacity gun magazines, block individuals convicted of hate crimes from obtaining firearms, and incentivize states to adopt extreme risk protection orders, also known as "red flag" laws.

However, the Republican-controlled Senate's stance on these bills remains unclear, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell stating that he will not hold any votes on the issue until President Trump outlines his preferred policies. To date, Trump has called for action but has not publicly identified specific policies he supports, causing frustration among some of his Senate allies.

Sen. Roy Blunt (R-Mo.) expressed this sentiment on NBC's Meet The Press, stating, "The president needs to step up here and set some guidelines for what he would do."

The White House has been meeting with members of Congress and those affected by mass shootings to gather feedback on potential next steps. Tony Montalto, president of Stand with Parkland, which advocates for measures to prevent such tragedies, said, "We hope the president can take the lead." Montalto's 14-year-old daughter, Gina, was killed in the 2018 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida.

After back-to-back shootings in El Paso, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, killed 31 people, Trump called for strong action on expanding background checks. However, in recent weeks, Trump has expressed more concern about addressing mental health issues and the effectiveness of universal background checks.

"We have to protect our Second Amendment very strongly," Trump told reporters on Monday when asked about gun control.

The White House has stated that various measures are being weighed at this point. "It's a deliberative process," said White House spokesman Hogan Gidley. "We want to do something that will actually help...not just something that will make people feel good."

Max Schachter, who attended the August White House meeting, lost his son, Alex, in the Parkland shooting. Schachter supports closing loopholes in background checks for gun buyers and expediting the death penalty for mass murderers.

Democrats in Congress have stated that they do not plan to abandon their push for gun control measures. "We are not taking no for an answer. We are not going away," House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) vowed at a news conference on Monday. She cited recent public opinion polls indicating widespread support for proposals like the House-passed bill requiring background checks for almost all gun sales.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) has reportedly spoken to the president several times in the past month, stating that Trump is "all over the lot" on the gun issue. Schumer argued that the public support for new gun control measures indicates "it's a different era" from previous times when Congress failed to advance any legislation.

Title: Presidential Candidates' Plans to Address Iran Nuclear Deal and U.S.-Cuba Relations

Article:

Two significant events are currently unfolding on August 14, 20XX. The first involves the visit of Secretary of State John Kerry to Cuba, and the second pertains to President Obama's ongoing efforts to secure Congressional approval for his nuclear deal with Iran. This article will outline the key points of each event and the proposed plans of a potential future president to address these issues.

Iran Nuclear Deal:
The Iran nuclear deal, a contentious topic, is centered around radical Shia clerics in Iran who seek to unite the world under their version of Islam and are responsible for the deaths of hundreds of Americans. They finance terrorists that seek to kill Americans and wipe Israel off the map. The deal, as proposed by President Obama, allows Iran to retain its existing nuclear infrastructure and endorses the construction of a full-scale, industrial-size nuclear program within 15 years.

The proposed plan by the unnamed presidential candidate aims to roll back the deal through a three-part strategy. First, the candidate plans to reimpose sanctions on Iran, limiting its nuclear program and economy. Second, the candidate will ask Congress to pass new measures targeting human rights abuses and the sponsorship of terrorism. Third, the candidate intends to link any future talks with Iran to its broader conduct, including human rights abuses, support for terrorism, and threats against Israel.

U.S.-Cuba Relations:
The normalization of relations with Cuba, another point of contention, involves the Castro regime's repressive tactics and opposition to American interests. The candidate's plan to address this issue includes a three-part strategy. First, the candidate will give the Castro regime a choice: either continue repressing its people and lose the diplomatic relations established by President Obama, or carry out meaningful political and human rights reforms and receive increased U.S. trade, investment, and support. Second, the candidate will restore Cuba to the state sponsor of terror list until it stops supporting designated Foreign Terrorist Organizations, helps North Korea evade international sanctions, or harbors fugitives from American justice. Third, the candidate will support Cuba's pro-democracy movement and promote greater access to uncensored information for the Cuban people.

In conclusion, the unnamed presidential candidate has outlined plans to address the Iran nuclear deal and U.S.-Cuba relations through a three-part strategy for each issue. The candidate aims to prevent Iran from gaining a nuclear weapon and to ensure the United States stands with the Cuban people, not their oppressors. However, the candidate acknowledges that these tasks will not be easy and will require strong, principled leadership.

Title: Science Education Activist Challenges Wall Street Journal's Stephen Moore on Myths About Science Funding

Article:

In a recent episode of Real Time with Bill Maher, science education activist Zack Kopplin confronted The Wall Street Journal's Stephen Moore over misconceptions about science funding. Moore, who questioned the necessity of funding research on "snail mating habits," was criticized for his lack of scientific background.

The purpose of such research, as Kopplin explained, is due to the fact that snails carry parasitic worms that cause schistosomiasis, a disease that is the second most socioeconomically devastating after malaria. These parasitic worms are transmitted to humans through infected snails, particularly in developing countries where access to clean water and sanitation facilities is limited. The worms' infectious larvae emerge from the snails, travel in shallow water, and easily penetrate human skin, maturing in internal organs. The result is schistosomiasis. As of 2009, 74 developing nations had reported significant rates of schistosomiasis in human populations.

Moore is not a fringe right-wing figure; he is a senior economics writer and an editorial board member for The Wall Street Journal. During a nationally televised show, he advocated for ending a government-funded scientific study while boasting about his lack of understanding of the research behind it.

This incident echoes similar sentiments expressed by Rush Limbaugh on his radio show the same day, suggesting that science today is an extension of the Democratic Party.

For conservative media figures like Moore and Limbaugh, scientific ignorance appears to be a deliberate choice rather than an oversight. From climate science and polar bears to economics to condoms to social sciences to duck penises, conservative media perpetuate the same anti-science behavior repeatedly. The argument is that scientists are inherently biased because they are passionate about science. This is a third-rate sophism combined with fourth-rate Luddism.

It is essential to note that this article does not imply that all scientists are correct by default. Instead, it advocates for respecting the scientific method, where scientists present arguments with data and rigorously test ideas until a consensus emerges. This is essentially a free market for scientific ideas. Is this approach something conservatives should be interested in?

For more information on the scientific method and research projects, readers are encouraged to visit Zack Kopplin's petition.

Title: Virginia's Off-Year Elections: A Test for the GOP in a Swing State

Article:

The Republican Party in Washington is facing a significant challenge in the form of Virginia's off-year elections, which they view as an opportunity to recover from the losses of 2012 and reset the political debate in a crucial swing state. The elections could also serve as a platform to send outgoing Governor Bob McDonnell on a high note and deliver a national message about the direction of the Republican Party.

However, the Republican state Legislature, local conservative leadership, and the de facto gubernatorial nominee have caused concerns among party strategists. The GOP-held state Senate has stirred national attention with controversial proposals, such as a plan to redraw the legislative map and a suggestion to divide Virginia's Electoral College votes by congressional district.

These actions followed the 2012 uproar over a Virginia measure, championed by conservative state Del. Bob Marshall, mandating ultrasound procedures for women seeking abortions. This issue was used by Democrats as a national cause, driving Virginia women away from the Republican ticket and undercutting McDonnell's vice presidential contender and Senate candidate George Allen, who ultimately lost to former governor Tim Kaine.

The same legislative body that steered the 2012 GOP message off course has struggled to refocus on a winning agenda for 2013. The unresolved redistricting controversy has been a distraction from McDonnell's ambitious proposals to overhaul education and transportation. The Virginia House of Delegates is expected to decide soon whether or not to take up the Senate's provocative new legislative map, with McDonnell's legacy and national profile once again at stake.

Republican Lt. Gov. Bill Bolling, who has criticized the state GOP since withdrawing from the governor's race late last year, lamented the partisan atmosphere in the Virginia capital. "I've been very disappointed that this session has taken on such a partisan tone," Bolling, who has toyed with an independent run for governor, told a news outlet. "We have some very big issues on the table this year like transportation funding and education reform, and we don't want to see those issues compromised because of partisan spats over redistricting or anything else."

The stakes are high, as Virginia has become one of the most important swing states in the country, a traditional GOP stronghold that now has two Democratic U.S. senators and voted twice for President Barack Obama. A triumphant last year for McDonnell, capped by a victory for Republicans in the 2013 governor's race, could at least start the process of turning back that tide.

At the moment, it's an open question whether the GOP will have the discipline to pull that off. While polls show the 2013 governor's race is highly competitive, Republicans have felt distinctly anxious in recent weeks over a series of hard-right comments by state Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli, a hero of national conservatives who has continued to speak out on issues such as contraception and the Affordable Care Act despite outside pressure to pivot toward the middle.

Title: Investigation Launched into Alleged Hoax of Fake Sexual Assault Allegations Against Robert Mueller

Article:

In a recent development, Gateway Pundit writer Jacob Wohl and Republican lobbyist Jack Burkman have been exposed for attempting to promote false sexual assault allegations against FBI special counsel Robert Mueller, according to a report by NBC News.

Approximately two weeks ago, prominent reporters received an email from a woman claiming that someone associated with Burkman was offering money to make false sexual assault allegations. After reporters contacted Mueller's office to inquire about the claims, Mueller requested that the FBI investigate the apparent hoax.

Peter Carr, a spokesman for Mueller, told NBC News, "When we learned last week of allegations that women were offered money to make false claims about the special counsel, we immediately referred the matter to the FBI for investigation."

Reporters began investigating the source of the claims, which were being promoted by Wohl and Burkman online. Wohl tweeted on Oct. 19 that a "prominent DC insider" told him that women were "prepared to make credible allegations" against Mueller.

On Tuesday, Burkman announced that he would reveal the first of Mueller's accusers at a Nov. 1 press conference. One of the women was supposed to claim that she worked at the law firm Pillsbury, Madison and Sutro in 1974, and that was when the alleged assault would have taken place. However, the law firm told NBC News that there was no record of that woman ever having worked there.

Burkman claimed he was investigating sexual misconduct and alcohol allegations. When media inquiries were made, Burkman responded by telling The Hill Reporter that Jacob Wohl ran Surefire Intelligence, a firm that was supposedly involved in the investigation. Wohl, however, denied any connection to the sexual assault investigation and to Surefire Intelligence.

However, evidence suggested otherwise. Wohl's email was listed in the domain records for Surefire Intelligence's website, the phone number for the company redirected to Wohl's mother's voicemail, and alleged Surefire employees had fake LinkedIn profiles using headshots of random people pulled from the internet. One alleged employee even looked suspiciously like Wohl himself, under the name "Matthew Cohen."

There were other tells that Surefire was a fraudulent company. The company's LLC was just incorporated a few weeks ago, and the address Surefire listed is occupied by a law firm that said it had no connection to Surefire. Wohl stopped responding to NBC News when they called him out about the phone numbers.

Gateway Pundit published alleged "exclusive documents" about the fake sexual assault allegation, but later took them down and is reportedly looking into the allegations that Pundit writer Jacob Wohl was involved in the scheme. The documents posted on Gateway Pundit indicated that one woman would accuse Mueller of sexual misconduct at a New York City hotel on Aug. 2, 2010. However, Mueller was serving jury duty in Washington, D.C. on that day.

UPDATE: Gateway Pundit founder Jim Hoft tweeted that the site has taken down documents it posted related to the fabricated allegations against Mueller, and that it is also looking into the allegations that Pundit writer Jacob Wohl was involved in the scheme.

Title: Amtrak Train Collides with Freight Train in South Carolina, Killing Two Crew Members and Injuring 116

An Amtrak passenger train, traveling from New York to Miami, collided with a parked CSX Corp freight train in Cayce, South Carolina, on Sunday, resulting in the deaths of two crew members and injuries to at least 116 others. This is the fourth fatal crash involving an Amtrak train since December.

The incident occurred at approximately 2:35 a.m. local time (0735 GMT) when Amtrak Train 91, carrying nine crew members and 136 passengers, hit a CSX freight train that was stopped on a side track, or siding. The section of track was operated by CSX, and the Amtrak train was diverted onto the siding at a switch where a padlock had been attached, according to Robert Sumwalt, chairman of the U.S. National Transportation Board (NTSB).

The NTSB is investigating the cause of the collision, with a particular focus on understanding why the switch was lined in the direction that led to the collision. The damage to the locomotives has been described as "catastrophic." An NTSB investigation team is at the site.

Amtrak engineer Michael Kempf, 54, of Savannah, Georgia, and conductor Michael Cella, 36, of Orange Park, Florida, were killed in the crash. Autopsies are currently being conducted.

Two of the 116 injured individuals are in critical condition. The collision occurred approximately 5 miles (8 km) southwest of the state capital, Columbia.

South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster described the scene as "horrible" and stated that the first engine of the freight train was "torn up," and the single engine of the passenger train is "barely recognizable."

Amtrak expressed its condolences for the deaths and stated that CSX owns and controls the dispatching of all trains, including the signal systems that control access to sidings and yards. Amtrak President and CEO Richard Anderson stated that the passenger train hit the tail end of the CSX train, which had two locomotives and 34 empty auto racks.

Images from the scene show the passenger train's locomotive lying on its side, and the first car bent and derailed, although it remained upright. At least four of the freight train's cars were crumpled but remained on the tracks.

U.S. President Donald Trump received regular updates on the crash while at his resort in Palm Beach, Florida. He tweeted, "My thoughts and prayers are with all of the victims involved in this morning's train collision in South Carolina."

In December, three people were killed when an Amtrak passenger train derailed in Washington state. In late January, an Amtrak train carrying Republican members of the U.S. Congress killed one person in a garbage truck with which it collided in Virginia.

A Federal Railroad Administration Investigative team is also on the scene in South Carolina to help establish what happened. The U.S. Department of Transportation stated, "It is important to understand the factors that contributed to this tragic accident and how all stakeholders can ensure a safe and reliable rail system going forward."

Title: Facebook's Removal of Protest Information Sparks Free Speech Debate

Article:

In a recent development, Facebook has faced criticism for removing information related to anti-lockdown protests, citing potential violations of large public gathering restrictions during the COVID-19 pandemic. The move has sparked a debate over free speech, with some accusing Facebook of colluding with state governments to suppress free speech, while others praise the company for combating harmful misinformation.

Senator Donald Trump Jr. accused Facebook of colluding with state governments to quash free speech, calling the actions "chilling and disturbing." Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) questioned the company's decision, asking, "Because free speech is now illegal America?" Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) expressed concern that Facebook and government officials are partnering to shut down views with which they disagree.

On the other hand, Connecticut Democratic Sen. Richard Blumenthal praised Facebook's move, stating that the company is right to take a stand against harmful misinformation. Protesters have demonstrated against stay-at-home orders, and Facebook initially indicated that it had removed the protest information at the request of states whose authorities said they violated restrictions on large public gatherings. However, the company later clarified that it sought guidance from states but ultimately made its own decision to take the posts down.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg offered a slightly different explanation in an interview with ABC News, suggesting that the company removes content that disputes social distancing practices and therefore poses a "risk of imminent physical harm."

This is not the first time Facebook has faced criticism for its policies on removing content. The company has faced blowback for its handling of misleading political ads and vaccine misinformation. Vera Eidelman, a staff attorney at the American Civil Liberties Union's Speech, Privacy and Technology Project, stated that Facebook, which controls a platform for the speech of billions, should not be censoring political speech online.

David Greene, civil liberties director of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, argued that Facebook seemingly deciding to remove protests based on whether they violate state law provides an objective yardstick. However, he noted that without further clarity, it can be difficult to judge the fairness of the company's decisions and ensure that they do not disadvantage certain groups or types of protests.

Matthew Feeney, the director of the libertarian Cato Institute's project on emerging technologies, contends that preventing deaths during a pandemic offers Facebook a defensible rationale for removing content. However, he noted that Facebook and other social networks are not bound by the First Amendment and often "punt" by looking to state laws or non-government groups for rules they can enforce.

Facebook, Google, Twitter, and other social media companies have long denied that politics is a factor in their decisions about what content they will and will not allow. The companies have sought to make their process more transparent, with Facebook in particular announcing the creation of an independent board to review content moderation judgments. However, when it comes to content or advertising that is explicitly political, Facebook has at times concluded that inaction is the best action. For example, when Twitter and Google imposed new restrictions on political advertising last year, Facebook stuck to its policy of not fact-checking political ads or limiting their reach.

In a speech at Georgetown University last fall, Zuckerberg laid out an aggressive approach to "freedom of expression," acknowledging that "free expression has never been absolute." Zuckerberg cited social and civil rights activists over the centuries as examples that inspired his stance, saying free speech and protests have enabled progress no matter how disquieting they felt at the time. However, in recent years, Zuckerberg said, people have expanded what they consider to be dangerous speech.

Title: U.S. Congress and President Obama Negotiate "Fiscal Cliff" Deal, but No Agreement Reached as New Year's Day Approaches

Article:

With New Year's Day fast approaching, the U.S. Congress and President Obama are engaged in last-minute negotiations to avoid the "fiscal cliff," a combination of across-the-board tax increases and automatic spending cuts set to take effect. As of Sunday evening, no deal has been reached, but negotiations are ongoing.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, announced Sunday that there is still a significant distance between the two sides, but there is still time to reach an agreement by Monday's midnight deadline. He stated that negotiations would continue.

Talks stalled at one point on Sunday, prompting the top Republican negotiator, Sen. Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, to bypass Mr. Reid and speak directly with Vice President Joseph R. Biden.

The impasse seemed to lift somewhat when Republicans dropped their demand to change Social Security's cost-of-living adjustment formula, and both sides traded offers on the income level at which taxpayers will see an income-tax rate increase and debated what other incentives would be included.

Sen. John McCain, an Arizona Republican, explained why the party decided to forgo demands for entitlement reform, stating, "You can't win an argument that has Social Security for seniors versus taxes for the rich. So we need to take it off the table."

A deal would need to clear not only the Senate but also the House, where conservative Republicans hold sway. In the absence of an agreement, Senate Democrats are preparing to force a vote on Monday on their own fallback solution, which would raise taxes on families making more than $250,000, extend unemployment benefits, and could include other party priorities.

However, this legislation is unlikely to reach President Obama's desk, leaving a small window for a deal that could prevent millions of taxpayers from facing rate increases.

The fiscal cliff encompasses the combination of across-the-board tax increases set to take effect on Tuesday, followed by $110 billion in automatic spending cuts imposed as a result of last year's deal to raise the debt ceiling. Analysts predict that the combination will plunge the economy into a short, sharp recession, though in the long run, the deficit would drop, government debt would return to manageable levels, and the economy would be stronger over the next decade.

Earlier on Sunday, President Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner traded blame for the situation. Mr. Obama stated on NBC's "Meet the Press" program that Republicans prioritize protecting tax breaks for the wealthiest Americans, while Mr. Boehner countered that the House has passed bills to cancel the tax cuts and the automatic spending "sequesters," and that Mr. Obama could have prevented the situation by pressuring Senate Democrats to send the House a bill.

Both sides have moved substantially. The Republicans have conceded one of their major principles in agreeing to higher tax rates, while Mr. Obama has stated he could accept tax increases beginning at income levels higher than the ones on which he campaigned: $200,000 for individuals and $250,000 for families. The latest offer from Republicans is to let rates rise on individuals making more than $450,000 and families making more than $550,000, according to Democrats, who countered with rates above the $360,000 and $450,000 levels.

Regardless of what happens with marginal rates, all taxpayers are likely to see at least some tax increases with the expiration of the 2 percentage-point payroll-tax holiday, which was worth about $1,000 to the average taxpayer last year. It is also unclear whether any final deal will cancel the other part of the cliff: the $110 billion in automatic spending cuts set to take effect on Wednesday.

As leaders continue to negotiate, some senators are preparing their own workarounds in case the negotiations break down at the leaders' level. Sen. Susan M. Collins, a Maine Republican, stated, "I've talked with numerous Democrats and Republicans on the floor, and there are a lot of subgroups who are eager to tackle this issue and try to come up with a solution if the negotiations break down at the leaders' level."

Title: No Charges Filed in NASCAR Noose Incident, FBI Determines Rope Was Present Since October 2019

Article:

NASCAR went to Talladega Superspeedway on heightened alert after Bubba Wallace, its only Black driver, took an active role in a push for racial equality. The noose found hanging in Wallace's garage stall at Talladega had been there since at least last October, federal authorities announced Tuesday, stating there will be no charges filed in the incident that rocked NASCAR.

U.S. Attorney Jay Town and FBI Special Agent in Charge Johnnie Sharp Jr. stated that the investigation determined "nobody could have known Mr. Wallace would be assigned" to the stall in question. NASCAR said it was the lone garage stall with a pull-down rope that resembled a noose.

NASCAR has defended its reaction and insisted it would call the FBI again if a similar situation arises. Wallace, who never saw the rope, said it had been fashioned into a noose.

"I wanted to make sure this wasn't just a knot," Wallace said on CNN. "It was a noose."

Wallace, who instantly began to fear for the safety of his family, remained angry at what he perceives as constant tests of his character. He holds no ill-will toward NASCAR.

"I stand behind Steve and I stand behind NASCAR," he said. "NASCAR was worried about Talladega. We had that one circled on the radar with everything going on."

NASCAR opened the Talladega gates to 5,000 fans, its highest number so far during the coronavirus pandemic. Since finding his voice over the last month, the 26-year-old Mobile, Alabama native has embraced an international role in NASCAR's attempt to push past its rocky racial history.

The FBI sent 15 agents to Talladega for Monday's rescheduled race at the same time the industry rallied around Wallace. In an unprecedented show of solidarity, every team member on pit road lined up behind him during the national anthem.

NASCAR President Steve Phelps has taken nine questions about the finding in Wallace's garage and none provided any details of the incident. Roughly 48 hours after the discovery, federal authorities said video confirmed the rope "was in that garage as early as October 2019" hanging from a garage door. The rope was referred to as a noose, but can be used as a handle when closing the door.

Phelps continued to call it a noose after authorities said no charges would be filed, and held firm in that NASCAR is investigating why the rope was tied that way. He was pleased it wasn't a hate crime directed at Wallace, but insisted NASCAR would have conducted its investigation the same way even now knowing it was just a coincidence.

"We would have done the same investigation," he said. "The evidence was very clear that the noose that was in the garage was in there previously. The last race we had in October, that noose was present. The evidence we had, it was clear we needed to look into this."

Meanwhile, Wood Brothers Racing team said it cooperated with the investigation and an employee recalled "seeing a tied handle in the garage pull-down rope from last fall," when the team had the stall. NASCAR, which first tried to ban the Confederate flag five years ago but did nothing to enforce the order, has yet to detail how it will answer Wallace's call to stop the display of the flag.

Title: Hundreds of Yazidi Volunteers Trained by Kurdish Forces in Syria to Combat Islamic State

Article:

Hundreds of Yazidi volunteers have been trained by Kurdish forces in Syria, according to Reuters, with these civilians now reportedly returning to the battlefield in Iraq. The training is a response to the atrocities committed by the Islamic State (ISIS) against the Yazidi community.

On Sunday, a Reuters photographer visited a training camp at the Serimli military base in Qamishli, northeastern Syria, on the border with Iraqi Kurdistan. The photographer observed 55 Yazidis being trained to fight ISIS. The trainees, both young and old men, were taught how to use assault rifles and rocket-propelled grenades by Syrian Kurds, sweating in the 40-degree Celsius heat.

The Yazidi civilians wish to remain in Syria due to safety concerns, but the volunteers are eager to return to Iraq to fight. The training period for these newly armed civilians is relatively short, with several days of training before they risk their lives fighting ISIS.

In Syria, the Yazidi volunteers undergo training in weapon use and fighting tactics for several days before being sent back to Mount Sinjar to fight, according to Anas Hani, a member from the media office of the Kurdish YPG. Hani stated that there are several training camps for Yazidi men who have volunteered, and hundreds have graduated in the past ten days, with more training ongoing.

ISIS is a highly sophisticated fighting force, but the brave, all-women battalion already fighting these murderous jihadists in Iraq may find support from these Yazidi volunteers. The exact number of Yazidis massacred by ISIS remains unknown, but reports of the atrocities committed against this peaceful group have been disturbing. Kidnapped Yazidi girls continue to be forced into slavery and unwanted compulsory marriages.

Title: Trump Signs Executive Order on Climate Change, Announces New White House Office of American Innovation

Article:

President Donald Trump has taken swift action to restore momentum following his unsuccessful attempt to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. On Tuesday, Trump signed an executive order that rolls back some of President Obama's key policies on climate change and carbon emissions. The previous day, Attorney General Jeff Sessions made a surprise appearance at the White House daily media briefing to discuss the administration's opposition to so-called sanctuary cities.

On Monday, the president announced the new White House Office of American Innovation, led by his son-in-law and senior adviser, Jared Kushner. The group aims to develop fresh solutions to persistent problems afflicting American society.

However, it remains unclear whether this burst of activity can help Trump find his footing or settle jangled nerves on the right. The failed push to repeal ObamaCare, which reached its denouement last Friday, was a significant setback even for the president's natural allies. While some Republicans, such as Speaker Paul Ryan, are vowing to revisit ObamaCare, there is no clear path forward.

Investigations into alleged connections between Russia and people in Trump's orbit, as well as the related controversy over the conduct of Rep. Devin Nunes, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, are also pestering the administration. The next big-ticket item on Trump's agenda is tax reform, but any push toward that goal will be subject to the same treacherous cross-currents on Capitol Hill that sank the healthcare push.

Executive orders repealing Obama-era regulations and hard-edged rhetoric on illegal immigration at least give supporters heart. "I don't think his agenda has changed," said Barry Bennett, who served as a senior adviser for Trump's presidential bid. "But, Bennett added, items that did not require congressional approval 'are going to happen, so [the White House] can shift the narrative when they desire, which is what they are doing.'"

Trump has not focused only on policy since the healthcare push went awry. He has taken to Twitter to blame the conservative House Freedom Caucus for his defeat and has insisted that ObamaCare will "explode." Fueling the kind of palace intrigue that has surrounded his White House, Trump tweeted a recommendation that his followers should watch Jeanine Pirro's Fox News show over the weekend. Pirro used that platform to call for the resignation of Speaker Paul Ryan. The White House pushed back at suggestions that Trump knew what Pirro was going to say.

To some critics, Trump's feverish level of activity has a negative flip side: an unwillingness to do the honest self-reflection that might help him avoid repeating mistakes. "He lives in a sort of reality-distortion field where he doesn't want to acknowledge that he makes any mistakes," said Timothy O'Brien, the author of a biography of Trump. "He very rarely acknowledges making mistakes, and I think that is largely because he has been insulated from the consequences of his mistakes his whole life."

During his presidential campaign, Trump often displayed a propensity to create the kind of big news that drowned out his rivals. His initial announcement that he wanted to ban all Muslims from entering the United States came with the Iowa caucuses looming. It was made within hours of a poll showing his then-rival Sen. Ted Cruz leading Trump in the state.

Two months later, Trump again threw out the political rulebook and hit back at criticism from Pope Francis. Another Trump biographer, Michael D'Antonio, noted at the time on CNN's website that "even those of us who know him and his fighting mentality have to marvel at his ability to find new battles."

"If he did not bounce back from adversity, he would be hosting 'The Apprentice' at the current time," said Tobe Berkovitz, a Boston University professor who specializes in political communication. "He's the maestro of agenda-setting, both for good and bad. All it takes is 140 characters [on Twitter] and at least one or two news cycles get converted to focusing on a new aspect of Trump and his presidency."

Critical voices like O'Brien's believe Trump is in a different world now, however—subject to the intense scrutiny that faces any president and with the Russian controversy lapping at his feet. "The most dangerous thing, staring him right in the face, is the Russia investigation," O'Brien said. "And all of his diversionary tactics haven't actually taken that away as the central thing that the media and Capitol Hill are looking at. He hasn't changed the narrative on that and, in fact, the response has been very ham-handed. Exhibit A on that is Devin Nunes."

But Trump loyalists remain convinced that he can bounce back once again, even when the stakes are at their highest. "I am still very optimistic," said Bennett. "We had bad days in the campaign. Next day, we're on to the next fight." The Memo is a reported column by Niall Stanage, primarily focused on Donald Trump's presidency.

Title: "Rove Criticizes Defunding Obamacare Efforts as Unrealistic, Predicting Government Shutdown

Article:

Karl Rove, a prominent Republican strategist, has expressed skepticism towards the efforts of the Defund-Obamacare Caucus to defund the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. Rove, who was a key advisor to former President George W. Bush, has stated that the defunding strategy is unrealistic due to the lack of support from Democrats in the Senate.

According to Rove, the defunders would first need to convince some Democrats or a significant number of them to join their quest. However, he believes this is highly unlikely. If, hypothetically, the defunders were able to garner enough support, the president would simply veto the measure. Overturning the veto would require a majority in both the House and Senate, which Rove states is not feasible.

Despite these challenges, the defunders continue their efforts, even after Senator Ted Cruz admitted the votes were not available and after the principal cheerleader for defunding, Jim DeMint, admitted that the effort is primarily a public relations stunt. Last week, the defunders staged a power move against House Speaker John Boehner and House Majority Leader Eric Cantor of Virginia, who had been trying to negotiate a more tactical approach.

The standoff between the defunders and the House leadership could lead to a government shutdown, potentially affecting nearly all federal activities. In the event of a shutdown, public outrage would likely fall upon the Republican Party, as it did during the 1995 shutdown.

While the Democrats are not without fault in this situation, the article notes that they have the necessary votes to maintain their position. As Oscar Wilde said, "It would take a heart of stone not to laugh out loud" at Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's complaint that "bipartisanship is a thing of the past." Reid's history of intransigence is also central to the current standoff.

The article also touches on the upcoming debate over the debt ceiling, another fiscal issue that will follow the appropriations fight. President Obama and the Democrats have stated that they will not negotiate on the debt ceiling, while some argue that congressional conservatives are holding the debt ceiling and the country's credit rating hostage.

The article concludes by comparing the situation to a Hollywood action movie scenario, where the hero is faced with a villain threatening an innocent hostage. In this case, the hero, President Obama, is not backing down, instead willing to let the conservative Republicans shoot the innocent bystander in the head, so he can shoot them in the foot. The article suggests that this is not a noble approach.

Finally, the article highlights the long-term fiscal challenges facing the country, with the Congressional Budget Office reporting that the nation's long-term fiscal trajectory is unsustainable without real and deep cuts to entitlements. The article argues that the defunding of Obamacare is a denial of mathematical reality, but the question of the national debt is a far graver issue that the whole country is facing."

Title: Kushner's "Shadow Task Force" on Coronavirus and the Role of Health Insurance Company Oscar

Article:

For several weeks, Jared Kushner, the son-in-law of President Donald Trump, has reportedly led a "shadow task force" on the coronavirus, separate from Vice President Mike Pence's official committee. This task force, which includes federal officials allied with Kushner and outside corporate executives, has been meeting at the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).

According to The Washington Post, an HHS senior official contacted Oscar, a health insurance company, on March 13, the day of Trump's press conference, to seek its help. Kushner's group has focused on expanding and publicizing coronavirus testing, particularly at drive-through locations.

Oscar was developing a coronavirus-testing website prior to the HHS call, and the company offered its work freely to the government. The website, which resembled a tool Oscar had already built for its customers, was designed to look like a government-developed product provided freely by the Department of Health and Human Services to the American public. The site listed a limited number of testing locations nationwide, including some drive-through sites that Trump had promised.

However, the website was never launched. Jackie Kahn, an Oscar spokesperson, stated that the company's involvement was a coincidence and had nothing to do with Kushner. She declined to discuss whether Oscar had discussed its site with Joshua Kushner or any board members or investors before Trump's March 13 press conference.

The ad hoc nature of Kushner's task force has already raised federal law concerns. The involvement of Oscar in the task force deepens Kushner's ethics and conflict-of-interest problems, according to experts.

Jessica Tillipman, an assistant dean at the George Washington University School of Law and an expert on anti-corruption law, stated that Oscar's relationship with the Trump administration could breach federal law in two ways. First, companies are generally not supposed to work for the federal government for free, though some exceptions can be made in a national emergency. "The concern, when you have some free services, is that it makes the government beholden to the company," Tillipman said.

The second potential breach of federal law involves the use of private resources for government work. Tillipman and other experts noted that if Oscar's work was not compensated, it could be considered an in-kind contribution, which is prohibited under the Federal Election Campaign Act.

The exact nature of Oscar's relationship with the Trump administration remains unclear, as does the extent of Kushner's role in the "shadow task force." The ad hoc nature of the task force and the potential legal issues it raises continue to be a topic of discussion and concern.

Title: Intra-Party Disagreements: Gillibrand Criticizes Obama on Military Sex Crimes, Pelosi Opposes Trade Bills

Article:

Senator Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY) has criticized President Barack Obama for his handling of the fight against military sex crimes, stating that he has not fulfilled his December 2013 promise to overhaul the Defense Department's judicial system if progress was not made within a year. Gillibrand's remarks come after the Senate voted down an amendment she sponsored that aimed to change the way sexual assault is prosecuted in the military, removing it from the military justice chain of command.

Gillibrand's public rebuke of a fellow Democrat follows House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi's (D-CA) decision to vote against two related trade bills last week. Pelosi, who had been seen as a silent ally to Obama and the Republican-led House in promoting Obama's trade agenda, kept her position secret until the end of Friday's debate, when she announced her opposition.

Pelosi stated that her opposition was to win a broader fight, arguing that "our people would rather have a job than trade assistance." She added that while she supported a bill to help workers who lost their job due to foreign trade, she opposed fast-track legislation, which would allow the president to negotiate trade deals with limited Congressional interference.

Hillary Clinton, the Democratic front-runner in the 2016 presidential election, appeared to back Pelosi, mentioning Pelosi's efforts to challenge Obama's free trade deal negotiations twice. Clinton stated, "The president should listen to and work with his allies in Congress, starting with Nancy Pelosi, who have expressed their concerns about the impact a weak agreement would have on our workers, to make sure we get the best, strongest deal possible."

Today, Gillibrand's amendment failed in the Senate, but Democratic opposition to President Obama on trade, military sexual assault, and other issues is likely to continue.

Title: Boy's Distress Call Preceded Sewol Ferry's Distress Call, South Korean Coast Guard Confirms

Article:

The South Korean coast guard has confirmed that a distress call from the sinking ferry Sewol was not made by the crew, but by a boy who used a cell phone to contact emergency services from aboard the ship. The boy's fate remains unclear.

The boy dialed South Korea's emergency number, telling dispatchers for a local fire service, "Help us. The boat is sinking." This revelation is likely to add to questions about the conduct of the crew, nine of whom are facing charges in last week's sinking.

The first distress call from the ferry Sewol came three minutes after the initial call from the boy. The ship's crew made a distress call to maritime officials three minutes later.

At least 146 people are confirmed dead, according to the joint task force leading the search. Earlier, when the death toll was reported to be 128, authorities had said that 174 people were still missing. The death toll had been expected to climb as divers were able to reach the ship's cafeteria, where many passengers were thought to be when the ship began to have troubles last week. However, early Wednesday, the coast guard said no bodies had been found in the cafeteria.

Rescuers will continue to focus on the third and fourth decks of the five-level ship, said Koh Myung-seok, a spokesman for the joint task force. Above the ship, two buoys marked its location in the water, surrounded by dozens of vessels, ranging from dinghies to warships. Inflatable powerboats zipped across the sea, ferrying divers to the area.

Searchers used guide ropes to lead them into the submerged ferry. Bard Yoon, one of the divers, said conditions are so bad "my heart aches."

"We're going in thinking there may be survivors," he said. "When we have to come back with nothing, we can't even face the families."

On shore, relatives of missing passengers waited anxiously, many of them parents of high school students who were on a field trip. As bodies come in, they are called into white domed tents to identify the remains of their loved ones.

Authorities said the efforts are still a search and rescue operation, but no survivors have been found since 174 people were rescued soon after the ferry went down.

As the search continues, investigators are trying to figure out what happened to make the ship list before finally capsizing and sinking into the ocean. Initial criticism has focused on the captain and some crew members. South Korean President Park Geun-hye said Monday that their actions were "akin to murder."

The captain, Lee Joon-seok, has defended his decision to tell passengers to stay put as the ferry began sinking, saying he was concerned about the sea's strong currents and cold water as well as the lack of rescue ships. Questions have been raised about why the third mate was steering the ship when it ran into trouble on its way to a popular vacation island. The captain was in his cabin at the time.

Chonghaejin Marine, which operated the ferry, has posted an apology on its website. "We pray for the Sewol victims who lost their precious lives due to the accident," it said. "We prostrate ourselves before the victims' families and beg for forgiveness."

Title: U.S. Intelligence Agencies Conclude COVID-19 Not Manmade, Investigating Possible Lab Leak

Article:

U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that the novel coronavirus was not manmade or genetically modified but are still examining whether the origins of the pandemic may be traced to contact with infected animals or an accident at a Chinese laboratory in Wuhan. The statement from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, the clearinghouse for the web of U.S. spy agencies, comes as President Donald Trump and his allies have promoted the unproven theory that an infectious disease lab in Wuhan, the epicenter of the Chinese outbreak, was the source of the global pandemic that has killed over 220,000 worldwide.

The statement reads, "The Intelligence Community also concurs with the wide scientific consensus that the COVID-19 virus was not manmade or genetically modified. The IC will continue to rigorously examine emerging information and intelligence to determine whether the outbreak began through contact with infected animals or if it was the result of an accident at a laboratory in Wuhan."

Trump and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo have made public statements speculating about the lab, with Trump stating, "More and more, we’re hearing the story." Pompeo added, "The mere fact that we don’t know the answers—that China hasn’t shared the answers—I think is very, very telling." Pompeo also pressed China to allow outside experts into the lab "so that we can determine precisely where this virus began."

While Trump and Pompeo have made public statements speculating about the lab, a U.S. intelligence official disputed the notion that there was any pressure on agencies to bolster a particular theory. The intelligence official was not authorized to publicly discuss the issue and spoke only on condition of anonymity.

Scientists say the virus arose naturally in bats. However, Pompeo and others have pointed fingers at an institute that is run by the Chinese Academy of Sciences. It has done groundbreaking research tracing the likely origins of the SARS virus, finding new bat viruses, and discovering how they could jump to people.

U.S. officials say the American Embassy in Beijing flagged concerns about potential safety issues at the lab in Wuhan in 2018, but they have yet to find any evidence the virus originated there nearly two years later. The Chinese government said Thursday that any claims that the coronavirus was released from a laboratory are "unfounded and purely fabricated out of nothing."

Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang cited the institute's director, Yuan Zhiming, as saying the lab strictly implements bio-security procedures that would prevent the release of any pathogen. Geng also criticized U.S. politicians who have suggested China should be held accountable for the global pandemic, saying they should spend their time on "better controlling the epidemic situation at home."

However, a Chinese government spokesman, Zhao Lijian, demonstrated that China was not above sowing confusion in the face of the pandemic. He tweeted in March the falsehood that the virus might have come from the U.S. Army.

Title: Democratic Representative Ilhan Omar Praises President Trump's Handling of Coronavirus Crisis

Article:

Democratic Minnesota Representative Ilhan Omar has joined a growing list of Trump opponents praising the President's response to the coronavirus pandemic. In a series of tweets on March 19, Omar commended Trump's recent efforts to combat the COVID-19 outbreak, describing them as "incredible" and the "right response in this critical time."

Omar retweeted comments from Democratic Massachusetts Representative Ayanna Pressley, who praised "unprecedented leadership" in the country during these unprecedented times. Omar agreed, stating, "we should never let politics get in the way of good policy."

In another tweet, Omar expressed hope that other politicians would join a "united front" to push for policies that would help the nation navigate the economic anxiety caused by the coronavirus outbreak.

Omar's praise for the president comes as other notable Trump critics have also voiced favorable opinions of the president's response to the coronavirus crisis. MSNBC's Joe Scarborough, a frequent Trump critic, urged his viewers to rally around the president and his efforts on March 17. New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and CNN's Dana Bash have also praised Trump's reaction to the coronavirus crisis.

Trump declared a national emergency on March 13, promoted a $1 trillion stimulus bill, and has ordered military hospital ships to the Atlantic and Pacific shores of the U.S. to treat coronavirus victims.

Title: Nick Sandmann Discusses Lincoln Memorial Encounter, Claims Lack of Disrespect Toward Nathan Phillips

Article:

Nick Sandmann, one of the Covington Catholic High School students involved in the controversial encounter with Native American activist Nathan Phillips at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington D.C., has stated that he was not disrespectful towards Phillips during the incident. In an interview with Savannah Guthrie airing Wednesday on TODAY, Sandmann expressed regret for the encounter but maintained his innocence regarding any disrespectful behavior.

In a preview clip released Tuesday evening, Savannah asked Sandmann if he felt he owed anyone an apology for his role in the incident, which went viral. Sandmann replied, "As far as standing there, I had every right to do so. My position is that I was not disrespectful to Mr. Phillips. I respect him. I'd like to talk to him. 'In hindsight, I wish we could have walked away and avoided the whole thing.'"

The incident occurred after a widely circulated video showed Sandmann, wearing a "Make America Great Again" hat, appearing to grin close to Phillips' face as the activist sang and played a drum during an Indigenous Peoples March. Sandmann's family released a statement over the weekend through a public relations firm, in which Sandmann claimed that the encounter followed an incident in which four African-American protestors directed "derogatory insults" at his school group. He stated that, with permission from a chaperone, he led students in school spirit chants to counter the hateful things being shouted at their group.

In the statement, Sandmann said he "never interacted" with Phillips and was "startled and confused as to why he had approached me." Phillips has stated that he approached the students, hoping to defuse the tension from a heated exchange he said he saw the group have with Black Hebrew Israelites.

Phillips has criticized the school chaperones, telling MSNBC's Joy Reid, "Where were they? How did they allow these students to come to this point after an hour of this happening? Were they with them? Were they encouraging them?" Phillips told NBC News in an interview, "Instead of being expelled, the students should go through some kind of sensitivity training. That they should...cultural education of some kind. And if they don't, then don't graduate."

Covington Catholic High School has stated that the students were in Washington, D.C., to attend the March for Life rally. Savannah's full interview with Sandmann will air Wednesday on TODAY.

Title: Trump's Tax Reform Plan and Its Potential Impact on National Debt

Article:

President Trump's long-awaited tax reform plan, recently unveiled in a one-page outline, appears to cater to conservative ideals, with proposed reductions in corporate and top income tax rates, the repeal of the Obamacare tax on investments, and a doubling of the standard income tax deduction. The plan aims to help both the working class and the wealthy, but it has been met with concerns regarding the potential increase in the national debt.
