The Tax Foundation, in analyzing Trump's campaign tax plan last year, estimated that the plan could add around $6 trillion to the national debt over the next 10 years. However, approximately one-third of this deficit impact could be offset by economic growth, leaving about $400 billion per year in additional debt.

To address this issue, potential spending cuts have been suggested. The Government Accountability Office's 2017 study of duplication and fragmentation identified at least $20 billion in potential savings per year. Past estimates by former Oklahoma Senator Tom Coburn have been as high as $95 billion per year. Assuming a conservative total of $25 billion year or $250 billion over a decade in savings, this would help offset a portion of the tax reform's impact on the national debt.

Further savings could be found in the Pentagon, where an internal report, initially buried, found administrative waste that could be reduced by $125 billion over a 5-year period without requiring layoffs or personnel reductions. Additionally, there is an estimated $25 billion per year in savings from the country's biggest discretionary department.

Improper government payments, totaling $144 billion for fiscal year 2016, also present an opportunity for savings. Most of this is overpayments by Medicare and Medicaid, along with other programs like federal education grants and the EITC.

While spending cuts are not without controversy, focusing on eliminating duplicative programs, self-identified waste, and improper payments could help offset a significant portion of the tax reform's impact on the national debt. The potential savings identified so far total just under $200 billion, assuming no increases since 2016.

It is important to note that no spending cut is easy, as every dollar in waste has its own interest group advocating for its preservation. However, the fact that a few items can account for as much as half of the shortfall from a massive tax cut suggests that focusing on spending cuts is a viable option for policymakers.

If Republicans believe that cutting duplicative programs, self-identified waste, and improper payments is not politically possible or not worth fighting for, they may want to question their purpose in Washington.

Title: Midterm Election Results Show Democratic Gains, Challenges for Republicans

Article:

The midterm elections of 2018 have resulted in a significant shift in power, with Democrats making substantial gains in the House of Representatives and Senate, as well as in various state-level positions. As of the latest count, the Democratic Party has gained at least 35 seats in the House, with the possibility of this number reaching 40 as the remaining close races are settled.

In the Senate, the Democratic Party has flipped a second seat from red to blue with Kyrsten Sinema's victory in the Arizona race, following the earlier win of Jacky Rosen in Nevada. This shift solidifies the Democratic takeover of the House and keeps the Republican Senate majority thin.

Democrats have also taken over at least seven governors' mansions, won back majorities in eight state legislative chambers, and flipped at least 329 state legislative seats.

Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat, commented on the results, stating, "The more time that passes since Election Day, the better things keep looking for Democrats." He boasted about his party's "Women of the West" – Sens.-elect Sinema and Rosen.

In Florida, the results of the Senate and Governor's races are still uncertain due to ongoing recounts. As of Tuesday, Republican Governor Rick Scott led Democrat Sen. Bill Nelson by more than 12,500 votes, or 0.15 percent of the roughly 8.2 million votes cast. In the Governor's race, Republican Ron DeSantis had a 33,000-vote advantage over Democrat Tallahassee Mayor Andrew Gillum.

President Trump initially declared the midterms a Republican success, stating that they "defied history" with Senate gains. However, the current Senate pickups are likely to be one or two, rather than the four or more initially suggested.

Democratic strategist Brad Bannon commented, "If the GOP has many more'victories' like this, it will go the way of the Whigs." The White House did not respond to questions about the growing Democratic wins.

The Republican losses in the midterms are less severe than the 63 Democratic House seats and seven Democratic Senate seats lost by President Obama in his first midterm, which he called a "shellacking." However, the setbacks this year still sting for the president and congressional Republicans.

Chris Grant, founder of the Republican consulting firm Big Dog Strategies in Buffalo, described the election as "a tough night all around" for the party. He attributed the Democratic success partly to candidates raising more money through ActBlue, a fundraising platform that allowed small-dollar donors to give to a variety of Democratic candidates across the nation.

Grant suggested that the Trump presidential campaign's focus on small-dollar donors in 2016 could benefit Republicans in 2020 as President Trump seeks re-election. He also noted that the lessons learned from the 2018 midterms could help Republicans in the 2020 presidential race.

Title: Senate Fails to Advance Chuck Hagel's Defense Secretary Nomination Due to Filibuster

Article:

Thursday marked a significant development in the ongoing saga of Chuck Hagel's nomination as President Obama's second-term defense secretary. The nomination fell two votes short of the required 60 in the Senate, which would have allowed it to proceed to a final vote. The vote, largely along party lines, was 58 to 40 with one senator voting present.

Four Republicans joined Democrats in voting to end debate and proceed to a final vote. They were Mike Johanns of Nebraska, Thad Cochran of Mississippi, Susan Collins of Maine, and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) expressed disappointment, stating, "Just when you thought things couldn't get worse, it gets worse." Reid plans to schedule another procedural vote for the week after next to try to advance Hagel's nomination to a final vote.

The debate over Hagel's nomination has been labeled as the first time a defense secretary has had their nomination stalled in such a manner. Republicans, however, insist they have not filibustered the nomination. Instead, they argue that they are seeking more time to have additional questions answered.

Initially, it appeared that while many Republicans would vote against Hagel's confirmation, no one would actively try to block it. However, the situation has since escalated, with Senate Republicans requesting answers to questions about speeches Hagel has given since leaving the Senate in 2009, as well as inquiries about his financial dealings. Senate Democrats argue these questions are unwarranted.

In the aftermath of the filibuster, Senate Republicans have expanded the questions they want answered before allowing a vote on Hagel's nomination. Some of these questions concern an issue unrelated to Hagel: the September 11, 2012, Benghazi attack on the U.S. Consulate and its aftermath, which led to the deaths of Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans.

The Democrats who control the Senate have 55 votes they can count on, a number that includes the Senate's two independents. Two Republicans have also stated they will vote for Hagel, Mike Johanns of Nebraska and Thad Cochran of Mississippi. However, this still leaves Reid three votes short of the 60 needed to end a filibuster. The source of the remaining three votes remains unclear.

Even Sen. Susan Collins of Maine, the closest thing to a moderate in the Senate Republican caucus, stated on Wednesday that she would be voting against Hagel. If the Hagel nomination is not confirmed, the president would be left with two options: finding a nominee more acceptable to Senate Republicans or adopting a John Paul Jones approach, telling Senate Republicans he has not yet begun to fight and sending them another nominee who would provoke their opposition.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Officials Testify on Russian Hacking of DNC Emails

Article:

In a hearing held by the Senate Armed Services Committee on Thursday, top U.S. intelligence officials testified that Russians hacked into the Democratic National Committee (DNC) emails on orders from the highest levels, with the intention of undermining the U.S. presidential election. However, the officials did not provide details on how they arrived at this conclusion.

The hearings have been criticized for potentially being used to undermine the election, as per the Russians' intentions. The hearings followed the release of emails containing sensitive information from the DNC, which exposed various issues within the Democratic Party.

The hearings also addressed the long-term cyberattacks on the United States by not only Russia but also China, Iran, and other adversaries. The ineffectiveness of the efforts taken by President Obama and his national security team to thwart these damaging intrusions was highlighted.

Senator Tim Kaine, a failed vice-presidential candidate, was criticized for his attempts to make light of the situation during the hearing, with his comments falling flat. Kaine took aim at President-elect Donald Trump and his new security team, as well as complaining about "fake news."

James Clapper, the Director of National Intelligence, was a key figure in the hearings. Clapper has been criticized for his past dishonesty, including lying about the National Security Agency (NSA) collecting data on millions of Americans during a 2013 hearing. During the hearing, Clapper attempted to differentiate between hacking into American email systems and the use of that information to supposedly influence the election, a political question outside of his area of expertise.

The hearings also touched on the Obama administration's failure to punish foreign entities for their cyber espionage against the United States. Clapper defended this failure, stating, "I was a bit reticent... You know, people that live in glass houses shouldn't publicly throw too many rocks." This comment was seen as a reflection of the Obama administration's approach to international relations, known as the "Glass House Doctrine." This doctrine suggests that the United States is just another country in a world of struggling nations, with nothing unique or exceptional to offer.

Title: Trump Administration Aids Oil Industry Facing Economic Impact of Coronavirus

Article:

President Trump announced on Friday that the Department of Energy would purchase crude oil for the nation's strategic petroleum reserve, aiming to support the oil industry that has been struggling amid the coronavirus pandemic. The move is expected to save taxpayers "billions and billions of dollars" while helping an industry in crisis.

Oil prices increased nearly 5% following the announcement, but this was only a fraction of the amount lost earlier in the week. In South Texas, Rudy Martinez, who rents rooms to out-of-town oilfield workers, has experienced the effects of the recent collapse in crude oil prices.

"I actually have a little man camp, and these guys are on the way out because they lost contracts," Martinez said. He added that the workers' per-diem payments and his weekly rental fees have decreased significantly due to the current economic situation.

Before the oil business downturn, Martinez could charge up to $2000 a week per person. This is just one example of the impact declining oil prices have on rural communities that rely on the oil industry. The United States, the world's largest producer of crude oil, stands to lose a lot if oil prices remain low.

Oil prices had been falling due to fears that the coronavirus epidemic could threaten global economic growth and decreased demand as large gatherings were canceled and people stayed home to avoid getting sick. The situation worsened last Sunday when Saudi Arabia and Russia failed to agree on production cuts, leading to a price war. In a surprising turn of events, Saudi Arabia announced it would increase oil production and offer substantial discounts to its customers.

U.S. oil companies, particularly smaller ones, are now considering significant cuts. Industry analysts warn of potential bankruptcies, especially if oil remains in the $30 per barrel range. Companies operating in Texas's Eagle Ford Shale need prices between $40 to $60 a barrel to remain profitable.

Karnes City, Texas, was transformed by the oil drilling boom that began about a decade ago. Karnes County National Bank President Trip Ruckman recalls local farmers and ranchers who were barely getting by, only to suddenly receive large oil royalty checks. Although the town still appears busy with trucks on the roads and a few local hotels still full, Ruckman anticipates a slowdown in activity within a few weeks to a month or two.

There have been reports that the Trump administration may offer additional aid to the oil industry, such as reducing federal royalties for oil pumped on government land or offshore, or providing low-interest government-backed loans. However, environmental groups, like Greenpeace, have expressed opposition to such measures.

One potential positive outcome of the current situation is lower gasoline prices for motorists in the coming months. However, with many limiting travel due to coronavirus concerns, increased consumption, as typically occurs when gas prices decrease, may not occur this time.

Title: Senate Intelligence Committee Releases Bipartisan Report on Benghazi Attacks, Blames Obama Administration for Security Failures

Article:

A bipartisan report from the Senate Intelligence Committee, released on Wednesday, has attributed the 2012 terrorist attacks in Benghazi, Libya, which resulted in the death of four Americans, including U.S. Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, to a series of failures by the Obama administration. The report, which is the result of a long-delayed investigation, lays out more than a dozen findings regarding the assaults on Sept. 11 and 12, 2012, on the diplomatic compound and a CIA annex in Benghazi.

The report states that the State Department failed to increase security at the sites despite warnings, and faults intelligence agencies for not sharing information about the existence of the CIA outpost with the U.S. military. The committee determined that the U.S. military command in Africa didn't know about the CIA annex and didn't have the resources to defend the diplomatic compound in an emergency.

The report specifies that four Al-Qaeda-linked groups participated in the attacks: Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM), Ansar al-Sharia, Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP), and the Mohammad Jamal Network.

The Senate Intelligence Committee's assessment comes on the heels of a Fox News report re-confirming that U.S. officials knew that the Benghazi attacks were acts of terrorism within minutes. The report also notes that the State Department ignored or rejected requests for more security from its own ambassador, failed to heed security warnings, and lacked intelligence analysis post-attack, showing an "unsettling" lack of concern.

The report also alleges that the Obama administration unnecessarily hampered the committee's review, and Republican committee members' notes go further, accusing the administration of still withholding relevant documentation. The Senate Intelligence Committee's assessment comes amidst a series of developments, including the State Department knowingly renewing its lease on the Benghazi compound without sufficient security in July 2012 and declining to renew a Defense Department security team that departed the country one month before Amb. Stevens was assassinated, and rejecting an offer of a Marine detachment. These are an awful lot of developments for a "phony scandal," the report suggests.

Title: Global Stocks Plummet to Three-Year Low as Coronavirus Cases Surpass 200,000

Article:

In a volatile trading session on Wednesday, global stocks plunged to a three-year low as the worldwide cases of the coronavirus surpassed 200,000. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped over 1,300 points, settling below the psychologically-important level of 20,000, marking its lowest close since February 2017 and entering bear market territory. The S&P 500 also plummeted, triggering a market-wide temporary halt to trading before closing down by over 5% on the day.

The ongoing COVID-19 crisis has prompted governments worldwide to consider stimulus measures and stringent restrictions to curb the virus's spread. However, the economic fallout is already being felt, with several indicators deteriorating sharply. Wall Street predicts a recession this year, with JPMorgan Chase economist Bruce Kasman stating, "There is no longer doubt that the longest global expansion on record will end this quarter. The key outlook issue now is gauging the depth and the duration of the 2020 recession."

The coronavirus pandemic continues to keep investors on edge, as one major economy after another shuts its borders to stem the outbreak and considers measures to combat the financial and economic disaster that COVID-19 is leaving in its wake. The Trump administration is working on a fiscal stimulus package to counter the effects of the COVID-19 outbreak, with the stimulus likely to exceed $1 trillion. The Senate approved a bill on Wednesday that would provide for sick leave, expanded job benefits, and coronavirus testing.

Monetary policymakers also stepped in with further stimulus on Tuesday. In a move anticipated by many market participants, the Federal Reserve announced the relaunching of its financial crisis-era Commercial Paper Funding Facility, a program designed to help U.S. companies gain increased access to financing amid the pandemic-related disruptions.

Volatility stemming from the outbreak has seen the Dow move up or down by 1,000 points or more for 8 straight days, and 11 times in the last month, according to Yahoo Finance data.

Title: Bill Clinton Advocates for Honoring Health Insurance Promises, but Obama's Promise is Unfulfillable

Article:

Former President Bill Clinton has suggested that President Barack Obama should honor his commitment to allow Americans to keep their health insurance plans, despite the latter's infamous promise that has been proven false. In an interview with Ozy.com, Clinton stated, "I personally believe, even if it takes a change in the law, the president should honor the commitment the federal government made to these people and let them keep what they got."

Clinton's statement carries weight, given his reputation for verbal dexterity and his history of dissembling under oath, which led to the suspension of his law license. However, the problem with Clinton's advice is that Obama's promise on insurance was not only an injudicious statement, but one that was impossible to fulfill.

The promise ran counter to the central premise of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). People losing their current insurance is not an unintended consequence of the law; it is an intended consequence without which much of the law doesn't work. In essence, Obama's lie runs so deep that even Clinton, who had his law license suspended for dissembling under oath, may not fully comprehend its implications.

The Obama administration's posture is that the president is sorry for misleading people and wants them to keep their coverage, but it just can't be done without unraveling a key element of Obamacare. The White House's strategy is based on spin and muddling through, hoping to brazen it out and come up with administrative "fixes" to the problem of cancellations. The politics of Obamacare are becoming increasingly toxic due to the immediate and concrete costs, such as canceled policies and higher premiums, which are more politically significant than the promise of a direct benefit.

Title: New York's Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Criticizes Amazon's Decision to Establish HQ2 in Long Island City

Article:

Incoming freshman Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a Democrat from New York, has criticized Amazon's decision to establish half of its second headquarters in Long Island City, Queens. In a series of tweets, she expressed concern over the reported tax breaks the company will receive and described the local community's reaction to the news as "outrage."

Ocasio-Cortez's position on Amazon may distance her from some of the state's top Democrats, including Governor Andrew Cuomo and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, who have been involved in negotiations over the deal. The Democrat's stance may further cement her status as an outsider among New York's establishment Democrats, many of whom endorsed Joe Crowley, the longtime incumbent House member she unseated in the Democratic primary.

Ocasio-Cortez criticized the tax breaks reportedly offered by the state's economic development arm, Empire State Development. She suggested they may come at the expense of critical pieces of the city's infrastructure, such as its mass transit and public housing, which face billions of dollars in repair needs.

"Amazon is a billion-dollar company," Ocasio-Cortez tweeted late Monday night. "The idea that it will receive hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks at a time when our subway is crumbling and our communities need MORE investment, not less, is extremely concerning to residents here."

Amazon's split decision means the selected locations can expect to share as many as 50,000 jobs and roughly $5 billion in investment. New York and Arlington, Virginia's Crystal City neighborhood won the Amazon competition, beating out places including Newark, New Jersey, Boston, and Austin, Texas. Ocasio-Cortez's district includes parts of Queens adjacent to Long Island City, including Sunnyside and parts of Astoria.

State and local officials are expected to make an official announcement on Tuesday, a source with knowledge of the plans told ███ late Monday.

Ocasio-Cortez stated that the deal must include substantial benefits for the surrounding community, which is home to the Queensbridge Houses, the largest public housing project in the country.

"We need to focus on good healthcare, living wages, affordable rent. Corporations that offer none of those things should be met with skepticism," Ocasio-Cortez tweeted. "It's possible to establish economic partnerships with real opportunities for working families, instead of a race-to-the-bottom competition."

"Lastly, this isn't just about one company or one headquarters," she said in a tweet sent Tuesday shortly after midnight. "It's about cost of living, corps paying their fair share, etc. It's not about picking a fight, either. I was elected to advocate for our community's interests—& they've requested, clearly, to voice their concerns."

Ocasio-Cortez, 29, is set to become the youngest member of Congress when she's inaugurated next year following her upset victory over Crowley.

Title: Frustration Mounts as Jeb Bush Struggles in New Hampshire Primary

Article:

In the days leading up to the New Hampshire primary, frustration within the Bush family's political circle has become increasingly apparent, with some supporters acknowledging that it may soon be time for Jeb Bush to exit the race. The former Florida governor trails Marco Rubio in polls, and there is a growing sense that he is running out of time to demonstrate strength.

Many donors and influential supporters, bound by a deep and longstanding connection to the Bush family, say they will remain with Bush as long as he is in the race. However, others, distressed by the rise of Donald Trump and Ted Cruz and eager for the Republican Party to rally around a mainstream candidate with viability, say they have come to terms with Bush's long odds and the possibility they will eventually support someone else.

Vin Weber, a Jeb Bush adviser who also worked on George W. Bush's presidential campaigns, said, "I acknowledge reality. There's going to be three or four candidates remaining after New Hampshire." He added, "We'll see what happens in South Carolina, and from there you can see the dynamic starting to winnow the field pretty quickly."

Barring a strong showing in New Hampshire, some top Bush fundraisers and supporters say Wednesday could be a day of deep reflection for them. One top Bush fundraiser who played a key role in his brother's administration said, "If he doesn't do well in New Hampshire, I think he needs to think long and hard about what he wants to do."

While Bush's top aides are still struggling to keep restless supporters in line, there is still some reason for optimism. If recent polls are to be believed, Bush has climbed to within striking distance of second place, putting him in a head-to-head competition with his chief rival, Rubio. Bush might have more upside after Saturday night, when he emerged relatively unscathed from the GOP debate while Rubio stumbled under a barrage of attacks, largely from Chris Christie.

However, Bush's top aides are still struggling to keep restless supporters in line. On Thursday, three days after the former governor barely registered in the Iowa caucuses, the pro-Bush super PAC Right to Rise held a conference call with top donors to outline the path forward. At one point, Mike Murphy, a longtime top Bush adviser who oversees Right to Rise, was pressed by a donor on why the super PAC's substantial spending had yet to improve the former governor's poll numbers.

For Bush's supporters, the question of whether to desert him is a complicated one. Bush's network of loyal donors and political supporters is far more extensive than that of any of his rivals. The ties between them and the Bush family, to which many remain deeply indebted, are strong and long-lasting. This weekend, dozens of longtime Bush family friends and supporters from across the country descended on New Hampshire to trudge through the snow and knock on doors.

If some backers do begin to walk away, it could alter the trajectory of the campaign. The former governor, who has raised well over $120 million, has a deep well of donors who could go on to fill another contender's coffers. To date, Bush has lost relatively few high-profile contributors. One exception came in November when Brian Ballard, a top Florida-based fundraiser, announced he was ditching the campaign over disagreements over strategy.

Some say they are hesitant to leave Bush because there is a growing sense that he has no intention of departing the race soon. He has said publicly to supporters and privately to senior aides that he will fight on to South Carolina and his team has begun planning a campaign event there with George W. Bush. His campaign is getting ready to send a bus of Bush loyalists from Washington, D.C. to South Carolina.

To many of Bush's closest followers, the thought of him dropping out is almost unthinkable, particularly if Rubio emerges as the leading establishment candidate. Among Bush's top advisers, the dislike of Rubio, who for years was a junior figure to Bush in Florida politics and is seen as deeply disloyal, is intense. One top Bush fundraiser said that on conference calls with the campaign, Rubio has been called "Judas," a reference to the biblical figure who had betrayed Jesus.

However, with the governor struggling, some, for all their feelings of closeness to the family, hint that they are beginning to think about the possibility of a 2016 campaign without him. Francis Rooney, who served as an ambassador under George W. Bush and has been a major donor to Jeb Bush's campaign, said, "Sooner or later the process is going to unfold, and we'll see who gains traction."

At times in recent weeks, the gloomy outlook in the campaign has been interrupted by moments of humor. Shortly after kicking off the Right to Rise conference call last week, Mike Murphy introduced himself to listeners and began his initial remarks. Then, he was suddenly interrupted. "Ah, f--- you," one person on the line blurted out. There was silence. Those on the call wondered: Was a frustrated donor, unhappy about Bush's lagging poll numbers and his crushing defeat in Iowa, directing venom toward Murphy? (As it turned out, the expletive-using caller was none other than Charlie Spies, the veteran Republican election attorney who represents Right to Rise. Spies had been cut off by a driver and had forgotten to turn on his mute button, though at the time the listeners on the call – and Murphy – didn't know that.)

Title: GOP Candidates Vow to Reverse Obama's Foreign Policy Achievements in 2016 Election

Article:

In the 2016 U.S. presidential election, foreign policy has emerged as a significant issue, with several Republican candidates vowing to reverse key foreign policy achievements of President Barack Obama. This has led to comparisons with the Affordable Care Act, which Republicans have consistently pledged to repeal.

During Obama's second term, the administration has been working to restore diplomatic relations with Cuba for the first time in over half a century and negotiating a deal to limit Iran's nuclear program. Several GOP presidential contenders, including Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), have vowed to reverse these policies if elected.

Sen. Rubio, who announced his presidential campaign on Monday at Miami's Freedom Tower, a symbolic location for Cuban exiles, is a fierce critic of Cuba's government and U.S. relations with it. When asked if he would re-break diplomatic relations with Cuba if elected, Rubio responded, "Absolutely." He expressed a desire for "free and fair elections" in Cuba and stated that U.S. policy can provide "major leverage."

Regarding Iran, Rubio contends that any agreements made by one president can be undone by the next. He suggested that if elected, he would re-impose sanctions, even if other world powers and the United Nations failed to follow suit. Such a move could lead to a new confrontation with Iran.

The possibility of such dramatic foreign policy reversals raises questions about the feasibility of these actions. A president can break diplomatic relations with Cuba, even if they've just been restored. However, supporters of Obama's Cuba policy expect a different dynamic, with the U.S. opening to Cuba potentially bringing economic opportunities.

In theory, a president could also tear up an agreement made by their predecessor. However, the legality of such actions is contested, with Iran's foreign minister insisting that an agreement would be binding and withdrawal would be a "blatant violation of international law."

Obama has been critical of the Republican candidates' foreign policy proposals, describing them as "foolish" ideas that would undermine the presidency. The election's outcome may not hinge on foreign policy, but the issue is generating significant discussion among candidates and the public. Republicans are running against the retiring president's foreign policy legacy, providing one last opportunity to critique Obama's policies.

Title: A Neutral Analysis of the Debate on Gun Control in Light of Recent Mass Shootings

Article:

The recent mass shooting in Las Vegas, the deadliest in modern U.S. history, has sparked renewed discussions on gun control. This article aims to present a neutral analysis of the arguments for and against stricter gun laws in the context of this tragedy.

To resist calls for more or tougher gun laws or enforcement in the wake of tragedies like Las Vegas, one must first accept that existing laws and regulations may not reliably prevent such crimes as long as guns exist. The new or expanded national gun control laws advocated as sensible and necessary would have had no effect on the Las Vegas shooting, even if perfectly enforced, as Jacob Sullum explained at Reason earlier today.

One argument for stricter gun laws is the prevalence of gun-related crimes. In Nevada, over the course of three years prior to 2017, rifles were used in murders four known times, according to the FBI's Uniform Crime Report. However, Nevada's figures show an unusually large number of gun murders where the type of gun used is unknown. If we assume the ratio of handgun to rifle murders is similar for known and unknown gun types, we should add 20 more rifle murders, for a total of 24 in the three-year period. This larger number represents 4% of total murders in Nevada over that three-year period. Killers used hands or fists to murder 25 times during that same period.

With its "lax" gun laws, Nevada saw 67% of its murders committed with a gun last year. This is one percentage point lower than the 68% for the country as a whole in 2016.

Another argument against stricter gun laws is the belief that some individuals are bizarre and horrific outliers who can and do horrible things. However, noticing how rare are such events, despite the millions of rifles out there, might give one pause when imagining a national legal solution to such bizarre individual crimes.

Guns are not the only tools that allow an evil maniac to cause so much harm. The driver of the truck that produced 84 casualties in 2016 in Nice, France, shows this. Legal solutions short of bans are largely irrelevant to these sorts of crimes.

The unwillingness to leap to a legal solution to mass gun murders requires recognizing that guns are tools, with genuine uses for personal safety, personal fulfillment, and convenience, just as are cars. A tiny number of people who own or have access to these specific tools ever use them to harm another human.

Some people do not see getting rid of guns as a proportionate response to the actual demonstrated threat of rifles, even post-Las Vegas America. One reason is the threat of severe civic unrest if the U.S. government attempted a mass confiscation, even with the promise of an absurdly expensive buyback, of that many almost universally legally and peacefully owned weapons.

Vast harm can come to individuals and communities from ultimately futile attempts to extirpate such things. One might consider how police, who would be the confiscators, behave, especially in America's poorest and least-respected communities. What might it be like unleashing them on a contraband potentially lethal to them?

You might disagree with these value judgments and assessments of proportionality, but a failure to fall back on a legal solution to mass gun murder events is a plausibly reasonable understanding of the extent and proportion of the problem weapons cause versus the costs in civic peace and innocent lives damaged.

For the vast majority of their owners, guns are no more worthy of banning than any other element of their peacefully enjoyed liberty, one tool among many to shape their chosen life and leisure. Banning something that tens of millions of people innocently value and imposing onerous costs on American citizens, generally downward in socioeconomic terms, is a recipe for disaster. There is intellectual room to understand and internalize the pain and damage that weapons can cause in the hands of an evil maniac, yet still sincerely believe that any effective legal solution is either impossible or requires an unacceptable level of police interference into innocent lives.

Title: US-China Emissions Agreement: A Significant Political Step, But Falls Short of 2-Degree Target

Article:

In 2009, the United States pledged to reduce its emissions by 30% compared to 2005 levels by 2025, following the Copenhagen Accord. The agreement was met with criticism and was labeled a failure by many. Fast forward to today, the US, in an "historic" agreement with China, has committed to cutting emissions by less than that, with a target of 26-28% by the same date. This new agreement, however, has been met with cheers rather than boos.

The agreement marks a significant moment as China, for the first time, has named a date when their emissions will peak. The Chinese government has promised not just to peak their emissions by 2030 but to increase the share of non-fossil fuels in their energy mix to 20% by the same date. Interestingly, a report from analysts GlobalData suggested that China is already on course to get 20% of its energy from greener sources by 2020.

The agreement, while significant in terms of China's commitment to cap its emissions, is not seen as a game-changer in terms of global warming. "This does not put us on a pathway to 2 degrees," said Samantha Smith from the World Wildlife Fund (WWF). "This announcement is a political signal from these two countries. If we understand it as a signal, it is a good thing and it is a first for China to stand up and say it will cap its emissions."

The China-US step has received a muted welcome from the Alliance of Small Island States (Aosis), a group of countries facing threats from rising sea levels. "We look forward to more detailed information about how the commitments match up against what is needed to ensure a safe global climate," the Aosis ministers said in a statement. "We recognize the importance of bilateral cooperation between these two countries, but the numbers must add up."

The real significance of the US-China deal lies in the changes it signals in the United Nations political process. Every nation has committed to agreeing a new deal by the time the parties gather in Paris next year. Next month, the negotiators will meet in Peru to draft the text of that agreement.

The Beijing deal is significant because it underlines the fact that China is changing its position. "It signals a shift," according to Liz Gallagher from environmental think-tank E3G. "At the highest level, there is a recognition that China is not a deeply poor society and that they are distinct from other developing countries."

The deal should also put pressure on some developed countries who have been moving away from tackling emissions. "The ball is in play, so now others, not just developing countries but the likes of Japan, Canada, and Australia, there is now pressure on them to come forward with something themselves," said Samantha Smith.

Taken together with the EU's recent announcement of new climate targets for 2030, one could be forgiven for thinking that a deal in Paris is in the bag. However, cutting emissions is just one part of the negotiations, and for many countries, the least important bit. For many, the bigger questions are about cash to cope with the impact of climate change. Many nations want a financial mechanism that would put a legal responsibility on those who have done most to cause climate change to compensate those who suffer most from it. This is a potential iceberg for the whole process.

Title: One-Third of U.S. Voters Unaware of Their Congressional Candidates, Poll Finds

Article:

A recent poll by ███/Ipsos has revealed that approximately one-third of registered voters in the United States are unaware of the names of their party's candidates for Congress in their respective districts. This finding, published less than five weeks before the midterm elections, highlights the importance of name recognition in motivating voters.

The poll, conducted between September 24-30, surveyed 2,597 registered voters and had a credibility interval of 3 percentage points. According to the poll, 34% of Republican registered voters and 32.5% of Democratic registered voters did not know the names of their party's congressional candidates.

Professor Robert Erikson of Columbia University in New York City suggests that the current level of party polarization in the U.S. may lead voters to base their decisions on their feelings towards President Donald Trump rather than the local candidates.

In terms of party affiliation, 54% of U.S. adults surveyed disapprove of the way Trump is handling the presidency, and Democrats currently hold a 9 percentage point lead in a generic question on which party they expect to vote for in Congress. Democrats need to win 23 seats in the House to secure a majority, which they could use to more effectively oppose Trump's agenda.

Beyond party and name recognition, gender may also play a role in voters' decisions this year, according to Michael Cornfield, an associate professor of political management at George Washington University. The #MeToo movement and protests surrounding Trump's Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh have contributed to this trend.

"In these cases, it's not just the name," Cornfield said in an email. "Gender relations may be the top issue."

The poll's findings suggest that name recognition may be a critical factor in motivating voters, but the current political climate and the role of gender in voters' decisions could also significantly impact the midterm elections.

Title: Trump Endorses Cruz in Texas Senate Race, Praises Relationship

Article:

In a rally in Houston on Monday, President Donald Trump endorsed Sen. Ted Cruz for re-election in the upcoming midterm elections. Trump described Cruz as "a really good friend of mine" and emphasized the importance of maintaining the Republican majority in the Senate to pass key legislation, such as the proposed border wall.

The event, which was moved to a larger arena due to high demand, attracted a boisterous crowd. According to Trump's campaign, over 100,000 people expressed interest in the free tickets for the event, although the Toyota Arena, which holds 18,000, was not at capacity during the rally.

While polls show Cruz with a comfortable lead over his Democratic opponent, Rep. Beto O'Rourke, many attendees expressed that they had come to see Trump rather than Cruz. One attendee, Rick LaBlanc, a retired oil industry executive, stated, "I do like Ted Cruz a lot but I'm here to see Donald Trump. I'm a Trump man."

The last Democrat to win a statewide race in Texas was in 1994. The Democratic Party has long hoped to capitalize on shifting demographics in urban areas, while Republicans have relied on Texas as a solid block across the south and southwest.

Cruz's opponent, Beto O'Rourke, has made a notable impression on voters with his campaign, raising $38.1 million in the three-month Federal Election Commission reporting period that ended on September 30, a record for a Senate candidate.

Trump described O'Rourke as "a radical, open borders left-winger," while Cruz labeled O'Rourke as a "gun-grabbing liberal." O'Rourke has expressed support for impeaching Trump and has advocated for relaxed immigration policies and gun control.

Cruz and Trump exchanged bitter insults during the 2016 presidential campaign, but their relationship has improved since Trump took office. Cruz has been an outspoken advocate for Trump's efforts to crackdown on immigration, repeal the Affordable Care Act, and nominate conservative judges to the Supreme Court.

Trump praised Cruz for his role in the recent Supreme Court battle, stating, "We had our little difficulties, but actually if you remember in the beginning it was a lovefest...then it got nasty. And then it ended, and I'll tell you what nobody has helped me more."

Title: Alabama Rejects Federal Plan to House Coronavirus-Positive Cruise Ship Passengers

Article:

The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) proposed a plan to house some American passengers evacuated from the Diamond Princess cruise ship, which was stuck in Japan due to the coronavirus outbreak, at the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Center for Domestic Preparedness in Anniston, Alabama. However, state officials have rejected the plan, potentially causing authorities to shelve the idea.

As of Sunday night, the global death toll from the virus surpassed 2,600, with over 79,000 confirmed cases. The U.S. has 35 confirmed cases. The HHS plan called for the FEMA Center in Anniston to serve as a quarantine center for passengers with minor or no symptoms. Those who become seriously ill would be taken to pre-identified hospitals, according to HHS.

The plan received a swift and negative response from Alabama's mayor, governor, and multiple congressmen. Representative Bradley Byrne stated on Twitter, "The people of Alabama DO NOT want the coronavirus brought here." He added, "I’m fighting to bring this to a full stop. Leave these people in the place they came from, don’t spread them around the US, and keep them OUT of Alabama. The risk is much too high."

Representative Mike Rogers claimed he had spoken with President Donald Trump, who Rogers said agreed that the HHS plan was the "wrong decision." Governor Kay Ivey stated that the HHS announcement was "inadvertently, and perhaps prematurely, sent." She clarified that Anniston was being considered only as a backup plan and no decision had been made to send anyone to Anniston.

Worldwide, South Korea reported its sixth and seventh coronavirus deaths and announced that cases have surpassed 760. President Moon Jae-in raised the virus alert level to red, the highest in its four-tier system, for the first time in more than a decade. Schools that were supposed to open in a week will be delayed until March 9.

In China, President Xi Jinping pledged unrelenting efforts to control the outbreak that has killed over 2,400 of his countrymen. "The epidemic situation remains grim and complex," Xi told state media. More than 77,000 of the infection cases are in mainland China. The silver lining is that over 24,000 of those patients have been confirmed as "totally recovered."

President Hassan Rouhani of Iran issued a decree setting up a national committee for managing the epidemic, which has killed eight people in the country – the highest death toll outside China. Another 43 cases have been confirmed. Cultural centers, schools, and universities in 14 provinces were ordered closed, and Turkey closed its border with Iran. Sylvie Briand, director of global infectious hazard preparedness at the World Health Organization, expressed concern over the "very rapid increase in a matter of a few days" in Iran.

Title: Glenn Greenwald Clarifies Concerns Over Executive Power and Civil Liberties

Article:

In a recent statement, journalist Glenn Greenwald emphasized the importance of opposing the acquisition of abusive powers and the erosion of civil liberties, stating that such powers, once granted, tend to become permanent and are not limited to the current administration. Greenwald expressed his surprise at the apparent short-sightedness of Obama supporters, who, despite their reservations about a potential future president, do not urge the current administration to limit executive power.

Greenwald pointed out an apparent contradiction in the stance of some Obama supporters, who express concern about the president's policies but remain silent on the issue of executive power. He cited examples of Obama's policies, such as the secret kill list, which have raised concerns among some, yet are met with acceptance by others.

Greenwald also criticized the lack of concern from some Republicans regarding Obama's policies, despite their vocal opposition to other aspects of his administration. He cited examples such as Sarah Palin's criticism of Obama's Medicare treatment review board, while remaining silent on the president's literal death panel that has resulted in the deaths of American citizens.

Greenwald urged voters to focus on the issue of executive power and the potential dangers of granting such powers to any administration, regardless of political affiliation. He emphasized the need to defeat Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan, due to their perceived bellicose and malign nature, but also acknowledged that the current administration has set precedents that could be inherited by a future administration.

Finally, Greenwald addressed the issue of privilege and the ability to write about certain issues. He did not elaborate on this point in the provided text.

Title: Hurricane Sandy Overshadows Presidential Campaign in Final Days

Article:

The aftermath of Hurricane Sandy has dominated the news cycle in recent days, overshadowing the presidential race between Mitt Romney and President Barack Obama. With just a few days left before the election, the Romney campaign is facing challenges in gaining media attention.

Tom Rath, a senior adviser to the Romney campaign, stated, "It interrupted the news cycle at a time when there were favorable horse race stories for Mitt. In a campaign, you do not get to design the racetrack; you play the cards you're dealt."

Romney has responded to the storm by collecting donated food in Ohio, calling for donations to the American Red Cross, and sending out messages of sympathy. However, his efforts have not received the same level of attention as President Obama, who has been touring New Jersey with Republican Governor Chris Christie, who has praised Obama's handling of the disaster.

William Schneider, a senior fellow at Third Way, a centrist think tank, commented, "It's going to be a little harder for [Romney] to argue that this is a failed presidency, because the president appears to have performed well in this crisis."

David Yepsen, director of the Paul Simon Public Policy Institute at Southern Illinois University, stated, "I don't see a rallying-around-the-president effect." He also noted that the storm is unlikely to reshape the electoral map, as the worst of the destruction occurred in northeastern states that were considered certain to vote for Obama.

Speaking strictly in terms of media attention, the storm is a dominant event that may take several days to play out before the focus returns to the presidential election. David Carney, a Republican consultant, suggested that voters have already made up their minds and that a strong closing argument from a candidate or increased media coverage may not change the eventual outcome.

Rath, the Romney adviser, suggested that voters are invested in the presidential race and will make their choices known, regardless of the shape and coverage of any final campaign sprint. "Everybody is overwhelmed and moved by the pictures, which are compelling beyond measure, but at the end of the day, they'll think, 'We've got to vote,'" Rath said. "The American people are going to say, after putting up with this race for 18 months, 'It's time for me to make my decision.'"

Title: Delay in GOP Lawsuit Against President Obama Over Obamacare

Article:

House Republicans' announced lawsuit against President Barack Obama over the implementation of the Obamacare law has yet to be filed four months after the initial announcement, despite being expected to take place in September. The suit, which alleges that the president exceeded his constitutional authority by failing to implement certain provisions of the law, was intended as a rallying point for aggrieved Republicans during the election season.

Lawyers close to the process initially expected the legal challenge to be filed in September, but now they do not expect any action before the elections. Some attribute the delay to electoral politics, suggesting that Republicans were concerned that filing the suit could rile up the Democratic base. However, the GOP has remained silent on the reasons for the delay.

The delay means the core of the suit could be moot before the Obama administration even responds to it in court. The case was expected to center on an employer mandate provision that Obama twice delayed but is now set to kick in for many employers on Jan. 1.

Former House Counsel Stan Brand, a Democrat, questioned the seriousness of the lawsuit, stating, "I thought this was a constitutional crisis and the republic was in jeopardy because Obama overstepped his bounds. Now, they can’t even get around to filing it?"

A spokesman for House Speaker John Boehner said the date for filing the litigation remains up in the air. "No decisions on timing at this point," spokesman Kevin Smith said Friday. He declined to comment on speculation about the reasons for the delay.

Some Democrats suspect the filing has been delayed because Boehner's announcement of the suit over the summer backfired to some extent, spurring fundraising by Democratic committees. Raising the issue again so close to the election could agitate those in the president's base who view such a lawsuit as disrespectful and part of an effort to delegitimize Obama.

Democratic consultant David DiMartino argued that the delay could push an even wider swath of the country away from the GOP. "I think it goes beyond the Democratic base in terms of the Americans who thought this was beyond the pale," he said. "Republican leaders are really good at finding really efficient ways to alienate huge swaths of the American public, and this is one of those issues."

Some conservatives, however, see the suit's postponement until after the election as important to rebutting charges that it's only about politics. Todd Gaziano of the Pacific Legal Foundation stated, "After the election, it ought to garner more serious commentary, evaluation, and judicial review. It can have some very helpful consequences for a principle that I think liberals and conservatives should both be concerned about, and that is the president's unilateral authority to rewrite a statute in dozens of ways."

Title: Pentagon to Allow Transgender Recruits as Court Orders Military to Accept Them

Article:

The United States Department of Defense has confirmed that it will allow transgender individuals to enlist in the military starting January 1, 2023, following a federal court order. This decision comes despite opposition from President Trump, who announced a ban on transgender servicemembers via Twitter in the summer of 2017.

Last year, then-Defense Secretary Ash Carter ended the ban on transgender service members, allowing them to serve openly in the military. He stated that within 12 months, transgender people would also be able to enlist. However, President Trump's tweet in July 2017 stated that the federal government "will not accept or allow" transgender troops to serve "in any capacity" in the military.

The new policy sets a strict set of physical, medical, and mental conditions that potential transgender recruits must meet to join the armed services. The Pentagon can disqualify potential recruits with gender dysphoria, a history of medical treatments associated with gender transition, and those who have undergone reconstruction. However, such recruits are allowed if a medical provider certifies they have been clinically stable in their preferred gender for 18 months and are free of significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas.

Transgender individuals receiving hormone therapy also must be stable on their medication for 18 months. Maj. David Eastburn, a Pentagon spokesman, stated that the enlistment of transgender recruits will start on January 1 and will proceed amid the legal battles. The Defense Department is also studying the issue.

The government's decision was quickly challenged in court, and two U.S. district court judges have already ruled against the ban. Part of one ruling required the government to allow transgender individuals to enlist beginning January 1.

The Justice Department spokeswoman, Lauren Ehrsam, told Fox News, "We disagree with the Court's ruling and are seeking to stay the Defense Department's obligations under that ruling as we evaluate next steps. Plaintiffs’ lawsuit challenging military service requirements is premature for many reasons, including that the Defense Department is actively reviewing such service requirements, as the President ordered, and because none of the Plaintiffs have established that they will be impacted by current policies on military service."

The government had asked that the January 1 requirement be put on hold while the appeal proceeds. The Pentagon's move on Monday signals the growing sense within the government that authorities are likely to lose the legal fight.

Title: Snowden's Asylum in Russia and Ongoing Investigation into NSA Leaks

Article:

Edward Snowden, the former National Security Agency (NSA) contractor, is currently living and working in Russia under a one-year asylum. The Russian government has refused to extradite Snowden, who was indicted by the U.S. Justice Department in June on charges of espionage and theft of government property.

Snowden has expressed a willingness to return to the United States if offered amnesty, but it remains unclear whether President Obama, who would likely have to make such a decision, would extend such an offer. The damage that Snowden's leaks have allegedly caused to national security is a point of contention.

The NSA is still uncertain about the extent of the data Snowden took. In some cases, government officials first learn about specific documents from reporters preparing their articles for publication, leaving the State Department with little time to notify foreign leaders about incoming disclosures.

The Justice Department continues its investigation into Snowden, with Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) agents from the Washington field office leading the probe. According to senior government officials, Snowden methodically downloaded the files over several months while working as a government contractor at the Hawaii facility. The officials also believe that he worked alone.

Despite Snowden's technical expertise, some American officials also place blame on the NSA for being slow to install software that can detect unusual computer activity carried out by the agency's workforce, which, at approximately 35,000 employees, is the largest of any intelligence agency.

Title: Tahrir al-Sham's Technologically Advanced Recruitment Tactics Alarm Western Intelligence Agencies

Article:

A recently deleted YouTube video showcases a young man, dressed in the attire of a modern jihadist, promoting the Levant Liberation Committee (Tahrir al-Sham), an umbrella group created through a merger between the Qaeda-affiliated al-Nusra Front and other militant groups in Syria. The group, often referred to as ISIS 3.0, is known for its younger and less religious fighters, lack of interest in governance, and nimble operations.

Tahrir al-Sham's recruitment efforts have reportedly alarmed Western intelligence agencies due to the group's sophisticated use of technology. The group has employed a crowdfunding approach on the anonymous Telegram app to recruit new fighters, bypassing traditional recruitment video methods.

The group's potential capabilities pose significant threats to critical infrastructure. With a limited number of dedicated actors, Tahrir could potentially disrupt power grids, cellphone, GPS, and satellite communications, or hack into government computers and publish classified military and intelligence information, endangering Western agents and assets.

Tahrir's digital networks, operating on the principle of "The narrower the audience, the bigger the impact," are difficult to detect and censor. Their use of encrypted communication channels and social networks on the Dark Web are not visible to satellites or vulnerable to bombing.

The still-emerging digital battlefield is a lesser-understood component of the 16-year war on terror. Tahrir militants have learned from ISIS's successes and failures on the battlefield, using multiple platforms to amplify their impact. While ISIS sent messages using a broadcast model, Tahrir has experimented with platforms like Sarahah, an app that allows users to send anonymous messages to one person, providing a honeypot approach for Tahrir to A/B test different messages.

Governments are still trying to censor ISIS on Twitter, while Tahrir is reportedly experimenting with an app that reaches over 16 million young people and is the top download in over 25 countries, including Egypt, Jordan, and Lebanon. Tahrir can fail, quickly measure what resonates, and retool their pitch before the activity is detected by officials, leveraging their speed for an advantage.

Title: Report Estimates 25 Million Americans Exempt from ObamaCare Penalty in 2016

Article:

A new congressional report suggests that more than 25 million Americans without health insurance will not be subject to the penalty in 2016 due to an increasing number of ObamaCare exemptions. The Wall Street Journal, citing an analysis by the Congressional Budget Office and the Joint Committee on Taxation, reported that the number of people expected to pay the fine in 2016 has decreased from the previous projection of six million to four million.

The report is likely to raise fresh concerns among insurers, who have expressed concerns that the number of exemptions to the law's individual mandate are leading to fewer young, healthy people signing up for health insurance. An insurance pool skewed toward older, comparatively unhealthy people is likely to result in premiums rising.

Under the Affordable Care Act, the penalty for not purchasing health insurance is either $95 per adult or 1 percent of family income, whichever is greater. This amount is set to increase to $695 per adult or 2.5 percent of family income in 2016, with a total family penalty capped at $2,085.

The Act provides exemptions to the penalty for certain groups, such as illegal immigrants and members of certain Native American tribes or religious sects. The Obama administration has since added exemptions for hardships like domestic violence, property damage suffered in a fire or flood, or having a health plan canceled when ObamaCare came into effect this past October 1. One exemption, written as being for people who "experienced another hardship acquiring health insurance," does not require documentation.

Residents of 21 states who have opted not to expand their Medicaid program under the health law may also be exempt from the penalty. The Journal reports that more than 4 million Americans who receive subsidies through the federal ObamaCare exchange could qualify for hardship waivers if the subsidies are struck down in court.

The Affordable Care Act was narrowly upheld by the Supreme Court in June 2012 in a ruling based in part on acceptance of the administration's argument that the law's individual mandate was not a tax. Republicans have argued that the Obama administration has undermined its own argument by issuing so many exemptions and should scrap the mandate completely.

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services told the Journal that approximately 77,000 individuals and families have requested an exemption as of this past April. However, that number is expected to rise because many exemption requests can only be claimed on tax returns filed in 2015. The Obama administration has given people whose insurance plans were canceled because they did not meet ObamaCare's minimum coverage requirements an exemption that runs until October 2016. They are also allowed to buy a minimum amount of coverage originally available to people under 30.

Title: Supreme Court Takes on Same-Sex Marriage Cases, Potentially Resolving Constitutional Right to Marry

Article:

The Supreme Court has taken on two same-sex marriage cases, a move that could lead to a final resolution on the constitutional right to marry for same-sex couples in the remaining states that prohibit it. The court's decision to hear both cases, one from California and another seeking to establish a constitutional right to same-sex marriage, has some gay rights advocates bracing for a split decision.

The court's move comes eight years after Massachusetts became the first state to allow gay and lesbian couples to marry, and four years after California voters rejected a ruling of their Supreme Court allowing same-sex marriages. The speed at which the court is moving has some advocates anticipating a resolution within months.

The court could strike down the federal Defense of Marriage Act, which defines marriage as a union between one man and one woman for federal purposes, or it could reject the idea that the Constitution requires states to allow same-sex marriage. This dual approach could lead to a split decision, with the court allowing same-sex marriages in some states but not others.

Supporters of traditional marriage have expressed optimism, with Brian S. Brown, the president of the National Organization for Marriage, stating, "Taking both cases at the same time exposes the hypocrisy on the other side."

The court could also limit the trial court decision requiring California to allow same-sex marriage to just two counties or even to the couples who brought the case. The justices could also affirm a California-only rationale, which would mean Proposition 8, the voter initiative that banned same-sex marriage in the state, would fall, but its impact would be limited.

The court could also pursue what Kenji Yoshino, a law professor at New York University, calls the "eight-state solution," affecting California, Delaware, Hawaii, Illinois, Nevada, New Jersey, Oregon, and Rhode Island. These states give gay and lesbian couples all the benefits and burdens of marriage but withhold the name "marriage." A ruling in favor of this solution could violate equal protection principles, but it could also have "perverse effects," according to Professor Yoshino.

The eight-state solution could discourage states from enacting laws allowing gay and lesbian couples to join in civil unions, fearing they would be forced to adopt same-sex marriage if they do. However, it is unlikely to provoke the same level of reaction as imposing same-sex marriage on states that currently prohibit it.

The Supreme Court's decision to consider the California case marks a change from the caution of an earlier era, when the court avoided cases that would require a decision on the constitutionality of anti-miscegenation laws. The court did not strike down laws banning interracial marriage until 1967, in Loving v. Virginia, when 16 states still had them on the books. It has been just four years since the California Supreme Court struck down two state laws limiting marriage to a man and a woman.

"We are in the midst of a major social change," wrote Justice Carol A. Corrigan in dissent. "For some the process is frustratingly slow. For others it is jarringly fast."

Title: Iranian Police Deny Using Live Ammunition Against Protesters Following Downing of Ukrainian Plane

Article:

Police in Tehran, the Iranian capital, have denied using live ammunition against protesters who took to the streets in outrage over the shooting down of a Ukrainian airliner. Officers were reportedly given orders to "show restraint," according to the chief of police. Videos posted online on Sunday appeared to record gunfire and showed an injured woman being carried away. Protests erupted on Saturday, after Iran admitted to mistakenly firing missiles at the Ukraine International Airlines jet that crashed near Tehran, killing all 176 people on board, mostly Iranians and Canadians.

For the first three days after the crash, Iran denied that its armed forces had shot down the plane and suggested there had been a technical failure. The admission of responsibility, which came after video emerged of a missile appearing to hit the plane, provoked widespread anger in Iran against the establishment.

Days earlier, Iranians had been united in grief over the killing of Gen Qasem Soleimani, their country's second most powerful man, in a US drone strike in Iraq. The latest reports of a possible crackdown echo the protests in Iran in November over rising fuel prices, during which human rights groups say hundreds of people were killed.

Sunday's demonstrations went on late into the night, as people vented their fury against the Iranian government and the powerful Revolutionary Guards, who shot down the Ukrainian plane. A video posted to social media shows a protester kicking and then ripping down a large poster of Soleimani. There were reports that a number of people were injured when security forces broke up a protest in Tehran's Azadi Square, during which people chanted "death to the dictator" - a reference to Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

One video posted on social media allegedly showed members of the paramilitary Basij Resistance Force, which is often used to suppress domestic dissent, attacking protesters in the area. What appears to be gunfire can be heard. Another video shows an injured woman being carried away by people who shout that she has been shot in the leg. A pool of blood is seen on the ground.

A protester who saw the injured woman told the BBC: "They started to come with sticks, they started to beat us. When we started to shout slogans, they started to bombard us with fire, they started to shoot." Despite such reports, Tehran police chief Brig-Gen Hossein Rahimi insisted that his officers did not fire live ammunition at protesters.

"The police treated the people who had gathered with patience and tolerance," he said, before warning that "those who intend to manipulate the situation" would face consequences. Iranian government spokesman Ali Rabiei meanwhile dismissed as "crocodile tears" US President Donald Trump's expressions of support for the protesters.

Fresh protests reportedly took place on Monday afternoon outside universities in Tehran and the city of Isfahan. Footage showed students at the capital's Sharif University of Technology chanting "They killed our elites and replaced them with clerics" - a reference to Iranian students who were on flight PS752.

The captain of the national men's volleyball team, Said Marouf, wrote on Instagram that he hoped Iran had seen its "last show" of "deceit and stupidity." And one of Iran's most famous actresses, Taraneh Alidoosti, posted that Iranians were being treated not as citizens but as "hostages."

Ukraine's Foreign Minister, Vadym Prystaiko, told the BBC that Iranian President Hassan Rouhani had assured the Ukrainian government in a telephone call that "no-one who is to [blame] will escape punishment." Mr Prystaiko added that five of the countries that had citizens on board the airliner - Canada, Ukraine, Afghanistan, Sweden, and an unnamed country - would meet in London on Thursday to discuss possible legal action.

He said the "grieving nations" would work out what steps to take individually and collectively to "bring the perpetrators to justice and how we can repay those families who have suffered." Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau also told a memorial service for the 57 Canadian victims that their country would "not rest until we get the accountability, justice, and closure that the families deserve."

Later, the head of Canada's Transportation Safety Board (TSB), Kathy Fox, said Iran still had the black boxes from the aircraft, and that they were damaged. But Ms Fox said there were early signs that Iran was "allowing the TSB to play a more active role than normally permitted" - such as by inviting its investigators to take part in downloading and analyzing data.

The Iranian government meanwhile denied there had been a cover-up. "On these sad days, numerous criticisms were raised against the country's officials; some of us have been accused of lying and secrecy," spokesman Ali Rabiei told reporters on Monday. "But honestly, it was not like that."

"The reality is that we did not lie," he added, blaming "a lack of valid information" and also "the US's psychological warfare" for his own and other officials' denials that the plane was shot down. Mr Rabiei insisted that senior officials, including President Rouhani, did not know that missiles had been launched at the airliner until Friday evening. However, the Revolutionary Guards' Aerospace Force Commander, Brig-Gen Amir Ali Hajizadeh, had said when admitting its role in the "unintentional" strike that he had informed officials about it on Wednesday.

Gen Hajizadeh said on Saturday that Iran's air defenses had been on the highest state of alert because the Revolutionary Guards had just fired ballistic missiles at US bases in Iraq in retaliation for the killing of Soleimani. The operator of a missile defense system near Tehran's airport mistook flight PS752 for a US missile and due to problems with a communication system was unable to contact the command center, according to the general. "He had 10 seconds to decide," he added. "He could have decided to strike or not to strike, and under such circumstances he took the wrong decision."

In a separate development on Monday, the UK Foreign Office summoned Iran's ambassador in London following the detention of his British counterpart in Tehran after he attended a vigil for victims of the Ukrainian plane crash. The CEO of Canadian company Maple Leaf Foods, Michael McCain, meanwhile criticized the US government for escalating tensions in the Middle East in the days before the crash, in which he said a colleague lost his family.

Title: NSA's Middle East and North Africa Group Updates Sigint Collection Capabilities

Article:

In 2008, the National Security Agency (NSA) made changes to its Signals Intelligence (Sigint) collection capabilities within its Middle East and North Africa group. The changes resulted in a significant reduction in the number of search terms, or selectors, and the daily messages added to the agency's Pinwale database.

The reduction in volume was considered a major achievement, allowing for new collection on Iranian leadership and Saudi and Syrian diplomats, according to a report. The NSA's Middle East analysts discovered major glitches in their search software, with one target missing over 500 messages in a week due to the software's inability to search for email addresses.

Joel F. Brenner, the agency's former inspector general, believes much of the criticism directed at the NSA is unfair, reflecting a naïveté about the realpolitik of spying. However, he also stated that technology has outpaced policy at the NSA, and that routine targeting of close allies may be bad politics and is foolish in an era where spying may be exposed.

William E. Binney, a former senior NSA official who has become an outspoken critic, is less concerned about foreign leaders' sensitivities and more about the potential danger the NSA poses at home. He believes without new leadership, new laws, and top-to-bottom reform, the agency will represent a threat of "turnkey totalitarianism" - the capability to turn its immense power, now directed mainly against other countries, on the American public.

Bobby R. Inman, who served as NSA director from 1977 to 1981, offers a radical suggestion for the agency: to release everything they believe Edward Snowden has and make it public. Inman suggests this would be a shock to the agency but could help them move past the controversy and begin rebuilding.

Title: Trump's Campaign and Policy Shifts Raise Concerns Among Experts

Article:

During his presidential campaign, Donald Trump has been known for his shifting policy positions and controversial statements, particularly regarding immigration, international affairs, and economic policies.

Trump's campaign strategy has been marked by the use of divisive and controversial rhetoric, such as the "birther" campaign against former President Barack Obama's legitimacy and repeated denunciations of trade deals and relations with China. NBC News has reported that Trump has made 117 distinct policy shifts on 20 major issues, including three contradictory views on abortion in one eight-hour stretch.

Trump's tax-cut plan has been a source of concern, with initial estimates suggesting it could cost $10 trillion in tax revenue, later revised to $3 trillion by one adviser. However, there is no credible indication of how this would be paid for, with assurances that those in the upper brackets will be favored.

Trump's plan for cutting the national debt has also raised eyebrows, with his suggestion that he might try to persuade creditors to accept less than the government owed. This idea, imported from Trump's debt-steeped real estate world, would undermine faith in the government and the stability of global financial markets.

Trump's open doubts about the value of NATO and his repeated denunciations of trade deals present a major diplomatic and security challenge. His plan to renegotiate the Iran nuclear control agreement and his admiration for Russian President Vladimir Putin have also raised concerns among experts.

Trump's admiration for Putin and his urging Russia to meddle in the presidential campaign by hacking Hillary Clinton's emails have been particularly contentious issues. Experts warn that if Trump were to become president, Putin might obtain favorable deals if Trump, his admirer, wins the White House.

Voters should consider the potential consequences of Trump's policies, such as the potential for trade wars leading to recession, the impact of a large deficit on the economy, and the potential loss of the new national health insurance system that millions now depend on. Trump has yet to provide a clear plan for replacing the health insurance system.

In conclusion, Trump's campaign and policy shifts have raised concerns among experts, with many warning of the potential negative consequences of his proposed policies on the economy, diplomatic relations, and national security. Voters should carefully consider the kind of change they want and whether Trump's policies align with their values and goals.

Title: Biden and Bloomberg Push for Tougher Gun Control Legislation, Citing Reduction in Gun Violence

Article:

The push for stricter federal gun control laws has encountered a political impasse, but this has not deterred Vice President Joe Biden and former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg. On Thursday, they advocated for the "importance of passing common sense legislation to reduce gun violence," including the implementation of a comprehensive background check system for all gun sales.

The duo spoke at New York City Hall, with prospects for a ban on semi-automatic weapons resembling military assault weapons seemingly stalled. Bloomberg cited public opinion polls showing widespread support for background checks, stating, "there's no real debate among Americans about this issue." He argued that nationwide background checks on all gun sales would save lives, and that the only question "is if Congress has the courage to do the right thing."

Bloomberg emphasized that guns purchased in states with "weak gun laws" often end up in states with stricter requirements. Biden, who praised Bloomberg's "immense" and "committed" gun control work, criticized those who argue that the proposals would infringe upon rights.

"Tell me how it violates anyone's constitutional rights to limit (ammunition clips) to 10 rounds," Biden said. "Think about Newtown... Think about how many children and teachers may be alive today had (the shooter) had to reload (more often than) he did."

Biden expressed optimism that Congress will take action this spring, stating, "There is no question that if this becomes law, it will keep guns out of the hands of people who should not have them. It will reduce violent crime. It will save lives. We know that's true, because in states that already require background checks on private sales, the rate of women murdered by an intimate partner armed with a gun is 38% lower than in states that do not have such background checks."

The ban proposal, vehemently opposed by the National Rifle Association, is expected to receive fewer than 40 votes, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid said Tuesday, falling short of the threshold needed to defeat a filibuster or pass the Senate. Instead, the ban could be offered as an amendment to the gun legislation on the Senate floor to secure a vote on it, Reid said.
