Biden, who lauded Bloomberg's "immense" and "committed" gun control work, criticized those who say the proposals would violate rights. "Tell me how it violates anyone's constitutional rights to limit (ammunition clips) to 10 rounds," Biden said. "Think about Newtown... Think about how many children and teachers may be alive today had (the shooter) had to reload (more often than) he did."

He worked to raise the spirits of people discouraged by the power of the gun lobby. "I was told in 1992, when I introduced many of these reforms, that there was no way, you never beat the gun lobby, it's not possible. Well, in 1994, we did. In 1994, reason prevailed, and we passed the assault weapons ban, a limitation on the size of magazines, and a number of other measures, including expanding the so-called Brady Bill and background checks."

Many reforms have since expired. But, he said, "One thing I want to lay to rest at the outset: They worked. They all had a positive impact on public safety."

Biden said that the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting in Newtown was carried out with "a weapon of war, and that weapon of war has no place on American streets." The shooter, Adam Lanza, used a Bushmaster AR-15 rifle to kill 20 children and six adult staff members.

"Taking it off American streets has no impact on one's constitutional right to own a weapon," Biden said. He also noted that conservative Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia "acknowledged that government has a right to limit certain weapons from being able to be possessed by American citizens."

Biden expressed his admiration for the Newtown families and said their presence has helped move legislation through the Senate Judiciary Committee and gives such gun control reform a "fighting chance."

"It takes an enormous amount of courage to be here," Biden said to the families. "And you say, well, what's the courage? Having lost a child, I understand that every time you show up at something that ranges from a memorial service, or to talk about the circumstances in which your child was lost, it comes back to you in a flash, as if they got that phone call yesterday. And I told you before, I do not know how you do it, but you do it. You do it."

(Biden's first wife and the couple's 1-year-old daughter were killed in a car accident in 1972.)

Biden argued against those who say assault weapons and high-capacity magazines cannot be banned. He said gun-trafficking legislation will give police "the power 'to be able to deal more rationally with straw sales, those sales where people go in, buy multiple guns, and then sell them to the bad guys." He said the more police are on the streets, the better.

The proposed reforms, Biden said, "will not solve every problem. It will not end every gun death. But it will substantially reduce it. And it matters."

Title: The Broken Process of Supreme Court Justice Appointments: A Look at the Current State of SCOTUS Nominations

Article:

The retirement of Justice Anthony Kennedy, following the contentious political climate that ensued after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, has highlighted the broken process for selecting Supreme Court justices in the United States. In 2016, Senate Republicans, in response to Scalia's death, established the principle that open seats on the Supreme Court should not be filled during an election year. This principle, if applied consistently, would mean that Supreme Court seats would be unfilled 50 percent of the time, given America's biannual national elections.

The ensuing political tension led to Democrats filibustering Neil Gorsuch, a broadly qualified nominee who would have likely passed easily in previous eras. In response, Senate Republicans eliminated the filibuster on Supreme Court nominations. This tit-for-tat escalation, as political scientist Steven Smith terms it, is known as "Senate syndrome."

Currently, the minority party holds no power over Supreme Court picks. The majority party can and will appoint their preferred candidate, who will serve for life. However, when the Senate and the White House are controlled by different parties, there is almost no chance that any seat on the Court will be filled.

For instance, if Democrats win the Senate in 2018 and Ruth Bader Ginsburg retires in 2019, the chances of Trump replacing Ginsburg and giving conservatives a 6-3 majority on the Supreme Court are slim. This situation, where the stakes are too high and the process is unpredictable, has led to Supreme Court nominations becoming a contest of power, with real consequences for American life.

The Supreme Court decides how elections are funded, whether abortions are legal, and whether millions of people will continue to have health insurance. Given the life-altering impact of these decisions, it is no surprise that elected politicians and activist groups view the composition of the Court as a matter of life and death.

While Merrick Garland was relatively moderate, his appointment would have shifted the Court to a 5-4 liberal majority, leading to a series of transformative rulings that Republicans might find abhorrent. Neil Gorsuch, though qualified, has ruled in ways that Democrats find awful, and the clarity of his opinions will not soften their effects.

The core problem lies in the high stakes of Supreme Court nominations. Candidates serve for life, and the timing of open seats is unpredictable. President Jimmy Carter served four years and saw no open seats, while President George H.W. Bush served four years and filled two. Barack Obama served eight years and named two justices, and Donald Trump has already been given two vacancies in less than two years.

To deescalate Supreme Court fights, a possible solution is to limit terms. Holding justices to a 10-year, nonrenewable term would lower the stakes of any individual Supreme Court nomination and make the timing of fights more predictable. This reform could have bipartisan support, as it would ensure that every President would have the opportunity to replace two Justices per term, and that no court could stretch its ideology over multiple generations.

Implementing a reform like this would be a step toward repairing and normalizing a process that is now dangerously broken, infuriatingly random, and distorting both our politics and the judges we choose to interpret our laws.

Title: Cory Booker Drops Out of Presidential Race After Failing to Qualify for December Primary Debate

Article:

Democrat Cory Booker, a U.S. senator from New Jersey, has ended his presidential campaign following his failure to qualify for the December primary debate. His departure leaves a field that was once the most diverse in history with only one remaining African American candidate, former Massachusetts Governor Deval Patrick.

Since launching his campaign in February 2019, Booker struggled to raise the necessary funds for a White House bid. He was at the back of the pack in most surveys and failed to meet the polling requirements needed to participate in Tuesday's debate. Booker also missed last month's debate and exits the race polling in low single digits in the early primary states and nationwide.

In an email to supporters, Booker stated that his failure to make the debates prevented him from raising the money required for victory. He also mentioned that the impeachment trial of President Donald Trump would deal a significant blow to his campaign by pulling him away from Iowa in the final weeks before the Feb. 3 Iowa caucuses.

Booker had hinted at the challenges facing his campaign last week in an interview on The ███' "Ground Game" podcast. He stated that if they couldn't raise more money in the final stretch, they wouldn't be able to do the things that other campaigns with more money could do to show presence.

In his email to supporters, Booker pledged to do "everything in my power to elect the eventual Democratic nominee for president," though his campaign states he has no immediate plans to endorse a candidate in the primary.

Cory Booker was once lauded for his role in the renewal of Newark, New Jersey, as the "rock star mayor" who helped lead the city's revitalization. During his seven years in City Hall, Booker was known for his headline-grabbing feats of local do-goodery, including running into a burning building to save a woman, and his early fluency with social media, which brought him 1.4 million followers on Twitter when the platform was little used in politics.

Booker's rhetorical skills and Ivy League background often brought comparisons to President Barack Obama, and he had been discussed as a potential presidential contender since his arrival in the Senate in 2013. Now, Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren has mastered the art of the selfie on social media. Another former mayor, Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Indiana, is seen as the freshest face in the field. Former Vice President Joe Biden has built a strong base of support with black voters.

Booker's message of hope and love seemed to fall flat during an era characterized perhaps most strongly by Democratic fury over the actions of the Trump administration. An early focus on building out a strong and seasoned campaign operation in Iowa and South Carolina may have hampered his campaign in the long run, as the resources he spent early on staff there left him working with a tight budget in the later stages of the primary, when many of his opponents were going on air with television ads.

On the stump, Booker emphasized his Midwestern connections and delivered an exhortation to voters to use "radical love" to overcome what he considered Trump's hate. However, he rarely drew a contrast with his opponents on the trail, even when asked directly. Even some of Booker's supporters worried his message on Trump wasn't sharp enough to go up against a Republican president known for dragging his opponents into the mud.

Booker struggled to land on a message that would resonate with voters. He's long been seen as a progressive Democrat in the Senate, pushing for criminal justice reform and marijuana legalization. And on the campaign trail, he proposed establishing a $1,000 savings account for every child born in the U.S. to help close the racial wealth gap.

He was among the first candidates to release a gun control plan, and at the time it was the most ambitious in the field, as it included a gun licensing program that would have been seen as political suicide just a decade before. He also released an early criminal justice reform plan that focused heavily on addressing sentencing disparities for drug crimes.

However, he also sought to frame himself as an uplifting, unifying figure who emphasized his bipartisan work record. That didn't land in a Democratic primary that has often rewarded candidates who promised voters they were tough-minded fighters who could take on Trump.

Booker's seat is up for a vote this year, and he will run for reelection to the Senate. A handful of candidates has launched campaigns for the seat, but Booker is expected to have an easy path to reelection. Booker's exit from the presidential race further narrows the once two dozen-strong field, which now stands at 12 candidates.

Title: Rolling Thunder Ride for Freedom Faces Potential Decline as Vietnam Veterans Age

Article:

The annual Rolling Thunder Ride for Freedom, America's largest single-day motorcycle rally, took place in Washington on Sunday, with concerns about a potential decline in participation as Vietnam veterans, who form the event's core, age. Artie Muller, executive director of Rolling Thunder Inc., the nonprofit foundation that sponsors the freedom ride, expressed concerns about the future of the organization.

The Ride for Freedom, which began in 1988 with approximately 2,500 motorcycles and riders, has grown steadily over the years, with 1 million riders and spectators attending the rally on Sunday. However, the growth is primarily due to supporters and family members of younger veterans, as veterans from Iraq and Afghanistan have gravitated toward other organizations.

One such organization is Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of America (IAVA). IAVA riders, on Victory motorcycles, rode alongside Rolling Thunder for the Memorial Day weekend event. IAVA has started its own parades, with Victory providing bikes to escort the veterans.

Harley-Davidson has a significant market share in the U.S., with approximately 52% of the market, and Rolling Thunder bikers predominantly ride Harley-Davidson motorcycles. However, younger riders and those who ride for IAVA have increasingly been choosing Victory motorcycles. Victory motorcycles were introduced in 1998 and were designed to compete directly with Harley-Davidson.

Victory has pursued a partnership with IAVA. On Veterans Day last year, Victory announced it would donate $500 for each bike sold in November and December to IAVA. This year, IAVA riders rode alongside Rolling Thunder for the Memorial Day weekend event.

IAVA's deputy director of strategic corporate and foundation partnerships, Matt Colvin, sees the group as the next generation of riders. He expressed hope that the younger veterans would eventually integrate with Rolling Thunder. Rolling Thunder's executive director, Artie Muller, echoed this sentiment and expressed hope that more Iraq and Afghanistan veterans would participate in the event.

Despite the potential decline in numbers, the sentiment behind the Ride for Freedom remains strong. IAVA and Rolling Thunder will continue to work together, but it is not yet time for the younger veterans to take over, according to Mr. Colvin. He believes that there is a next generation that will step up and take over in the future.

Title: New Electronic Voting Machines Deployed in U.S. Elections Amid Concerns Over Foreign Interference

Article:

Last week's national elections marked the first use of new electronic voting machines in two states, as well as a shift in governorships and legislative control in Virginia to the Democrats. The elections also served as a test for the new voting systems, which were implemented to protect the 2020 election from foreign interference.

The deployment of these new machines follows the 2000 Bush v. Gore election, which was marred by disputes over hanging chads and confusing butterfly ballots. In response, Congress approved over $3 billion to replace older voting methods with easy-to-use electronic voting machines. However, cybersecurity was an afterthought at the time, leading to the current systems that rely on voting machines vulnerable to hacking.

Russia targeted election systems in all 50 states during its effort to influence the 2016 election, and is expected to launch a similar campaign in 2020. Intelligence officials also fear that foreign powers like China and Iran may engage in similar activities.

To address these concerns, more than 130,000 new machines have been purchased to replace older paperless ones, many of which carry known security vulnerabilities. These old machines do not create a paper backup, making it impossible to verify whether their results have been compromised. Despite the push from Congress to replace them, it is estimated that 16 million voters will use paperless machines in 2020.

Some security experts worry that the new machines, which provide a paper backup that can be checked by voters and election officials, are also insecure. Most are not connected to the internet, but they can be compromised within minutes by a savvy hacker in person. These new machines were used for the first time last week in a number of districts across the country, with some locations reporting major glitches.

The issues with the new machines have led some election security experts to call for a return to old-fashioned pen and paper ballots. However, some experts worry that a return to paper voting could bring back old issues such as voter error, confusing ballots, slow counts, and suppressed turnout.

There is bipartisan consensus in Congress that more needs to be done to secure the country's voting machines. A bill providing extra funding for election systems recently passed both houses, and more money could be apportioned before 2020. However, legislation passed by House Democrats that would require all voting systems to have a paper record has stalled in the Republican-led Senate.

The next big debate in election integrity may involve the use of smartphones for voting, a method that was used for the first time by a small number of voters last Tuesday. While this method is seen as potentially increasing access to voting, it raises troubling security concerns.

John Brandon, writing for Fox News, stated, "The main issue is that criminals and foreign operatives intent on disrupting the midterms have worked harder, faster, and with more intent than those trying to fend off the attacks. Hackers rely on automated processes — apps, development tools, and online databases on services like GitHub or Pastebin — that make it easy to hack the machines used for tallying votes."

In contrast, Jim Geraghty, writing for National Review, argued, "No hacker in Moscow can reach across the World Wide Web and alter what your ballot says. Even if they somehow managed to alter the data being tabulated in some local or state government system that is connected to the Internet, a recount would reveal the discrepancy."

The potential erosion of public confidence in the election process due to perceived insecurity is a concern. As Lee C. Bollinger and Michael A. McRobbie wrote in The Hill, "It is sobering to consider the effect that a deep erosion of public confidence in the election process could have. It would be devastating to Americans' faith in our democracy and the legitimacy of our elected government."

Title: Caroline Kennedy Nominated as U.S. Ambassador to Japan

Article:

CNN reported on Wednesday that Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of former President John F. Kennedy and a prominent Democratic supporter, has been nominated by President Barack Obama to serve as the U.S. Ambassador to Japan. If confirmed by the U.S. Senate, Kennedy would become the first woman to hold the post.

Kennedy, a top supporter of Obama, served as the co-chair of his vice presidential search committee in 2008. She has largely shunned the limelight and scrutiny associated with her famous last name, but has made speeches at the 2008 and 2012 Democratic National Conventions.

After publicly expressing interest in running for the U.S. Senate seat in New York vacated when Hillary Clinton became secretary of state in 2009, Kennedy ultimately decided against making a bid, citing "personal reasons."

Kennedy has a background in education, having received degrees at Harvard and Columbia. She has served in a variety of roles at New York non-profits, including the John F. Kennedy Library and the American Ballet Theatre.

The current U.S. ambassador to Japan is John Roos, who assumed the role in 2009. He was the first American ambassador to attend commemoration ceremonies for the American atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. He also led America's embassy through the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, and the ensuing nuclear aftermath.

The United States is Japan's largest economic partner and a military ally. The U.S. military presence on Japan's Okinawa Island has remained a point of diplomatic tension between the two nations. Some of the island's residents have complained about noise from the base, located in an urban area. Many others were incensed by the misconduct of U.S. troops stationed there, including the 1995 rape of a 12-year-old Japanese girl by three U.S. military personnel.

Opposition to the presence of U.S. troops in Okinawa runs so deep that it contributed to the resignation of former Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama in 2010. He had promised to move the base but later announced that the base would stay, a decision he called "heartbreaking."

Title: President Trump Discusses Coronavirus, Travel Restrictions, and Irish Prime Minister's Visit

Article:

President Donald Trump reassured reporters on Thursday that the markets would recover as he welcomed Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar to the White House for a meeting to celebrate the ties between the U.S. and Ireland. However, stocks plunged 7% after the opening bell that morning due to fears and fallout from the coronavirus.

The visit comes after President Trump's Wednesday night announcement of travel restrictions on Europe due to the global spread of the deadly coronavirus. The new travel restrictions do not apply to Ireland or the United Kingdom.

During a press conference in the Oval Office, Mr. Trump addressed criticism that he decided to restrict travel from Europe without consulting European leaders. Mr. Trump explained that it takes a long time to make individual calls to world leaders, and claimed Europe does not alert the U.S. when it raises taxes on the U.S. Mr. Trump insisted his announcement was "clear," even though his own White House had to clarify the announcement.

"Well, we get along very well with the European leaders, but we had to make a decision, and I didn't want to take time and -- you know, it takes a long time to make the individual calls," Mr. Trump told reporters. "And we are calling, and we have spoken to some of them prior to -- some of the majors, prior to. But we had to move quickly."

President Trump stated that his team has not discussed travel restrictions within the United States, but he did not rule it out, as the National Guard moves into a New York suburb to establish the country's first containment zone. The president insisted that he has more authority than most people know, and hinted that he's been reading up on the Stafford Act, the federal law outlining the means of deploying federal natural disaster assistance to state and local governments.

"We need a little separation until such time as this goes away. It's going to go away, it's going to go away," Mr. Trump said, seemingly referring to former Food and Drug Administration head Scott Gottlieb. "But in the meantime, we want to lose as few people as possible, so important."

The president's meeting with the Irish prime minister is one of the few events that is proceeding as the U.S. grapples with the spread of the coronavirus. As of Thursday, there were more than 1,300 confirmed cases of the illness in the country, according to Johns Hopkins University. There are 43 confirmed cases in Ireland.

Varadkar is set to attend the annual "Friends of Ireland" luncheon hosted by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Capitol Hill on Thursday. President Trump attended the luncheon in the first three years of his presidency but is skipping this year's event, citing the impeachment inquiry launched by House Democrats last year. President Trump told reporters on Thursday that he is too busy.

"Since the speaker has chosen to tear this nation apart with her actions and her rhetoric, the president will not participate in moments where she so often chooses to drive discord and disunity," White House spokesman Judd Deere said earlier this week.

Officials in Washington, D.C., and around the nation have begun to cancel large events due to the coronavirus, which has spread to more than 100 countries. At the White House, public tours have been halted, and in the U.S. Capitol, congressional leaders are nearing a pause on tours.

President Trump also canceled upcoming events in Nevada, Colorado, and Wisconsin "out of an abundance of caution from the coronavirus outbreak," White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham said late Wednesday.

The White House and Congress are weighing a legislative package to provide economic relief to businesses and people impacted by the virus. President Trump said he wants paid sick leave to be a part of that.

Title: Obama's Fourth Defense Chief Selection: Ash Carter's Appointment and the White House's Influence on Defense Policy

Article:

President Barack Obama's selection of Ash Carter as his fourth defense secretary marks a critical moment in the president's relationship with the military and national security, as the choice signals a continuation of the White House's active role in setting defense policy.

Carter, a well-regarded policy expert and former deputy defense secretary, is expected to carry out the strategy set by the West Wing and the National Security Council, rather than shift the balance of power back to the Pentagon. This is in line with the Obama administration's approach to defense policy, which has been marked by a greater White House role in setting defense policy compared to previous administrations.

Two of Obama's previous defense chiefs, Robert Gates and Leon Panetta, have criticized the White House for policy failures and interference. The third, Chuck Hagel, was reportedly unable to navigate the White House currents and was let go without an obvious replacement.

The White House's control over defense policy has been a source of criticism, with some arguing that it undermines the traditional role of the Pentagon and the military. Former State Department official Aaron David Miller described Obama as "one of the most controlling foreign policy presidents, if not the most controlling, since Richard Nixon."

The White House's sensitivity to criticism of undue interference was evident this week, with White House press secretary Josh Earnest reminding reporters that previous administrations had also experienced White House-Pentagon divisions.

The choice of Carter, who lacks a strong political profile but is widely touted for his policy expertise, has been met with mixed reactions. Kori Schake, an NSC defense official and State Department official under George W. Bush, described the choice as "better management of the department than Chuck Hagel offered but no change in the sweeping arrogance of the president's closest policy advisers on national security."

Many former officials are waiting to see how Carter adjusts to his new position and whether he develops the political skills to handle the White House better than his predecessors. Lawrence Korb, a Reagan administration assistant defense secretary, noted that Carter lacks the leverage over the White House that Gates and even Panetta had.

Nonetheless, Carter is expected to face challenges in building a strong team at the Pentagon and navigating the White House's influence on defense policy. The success of his tenure will depend on his ability to balance the demands of the White House with the needs of the military and the Pentagon.

Title: High Approval Rate of President Obama's Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) Program Affects Supreme Court Case

Article:

President Obama's Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which offers temporary protection from deportation and work permits to certain undocumented immigrants who were brought to the U.S. as children, has approved 93 percent of all applications decided through December 2016. This high approval rate is likely to influence the Supreme Court's decision next month on a legal challenge to a broader amnesty program.

The DACA program, announced in late 2014, is considered a test run for a broader amnesty program that Obama proposed, which has been halted by lower courts as they determine the administration's authority to grant temporary stays of deportation, issue work permits, and make illegal immigrants eligible for some taxpayer benefits.

Critics argue that the high approval rate undercuts the administration's claim that it is not rewriting the law but offering guidance on how to prioritize enforcement. They contend that the 93 percent approval rate suggests that the program does not have stringent eligibility criteria.

Supporters of the program argue that the high approval rate is due to the immigrants' diligence in ensuring their eligibility before applying, resulting in fewer borderline cases and fewer denials. They also point out that the nearly $500 application fee makes immigrants think carefully before applying.

The Supreme Court is set to hear oral arguments on April 18 and could issue a ruling by the end of June. The case, led by Texas and 25 other states, challenges the Deferred Action for Parental Accountability (DAPA) program, which would extend amnesty to the parents of DACA recipients.

The DACA approval rate has become an issue in the DAPA case, as lower court judges have used the performance of the Dreamer amnesty to inform their rulings on the broader program for parents. At the end of last year, nearly 715,000 people had been approved, and fewer than 55,000 had been rejected.

Immigrant rights groups have countered the argument that the administration lacks discretion in granting or denying DACA applications by citing cases where officers have used discretion to reject applications. For example, they point to the case of an immigrant named Christian, who was denied despite meeting all the criteria and being a hardship case, and the case of Francisco, a Virginia man who was denied despite being married to a U.S. citizen and having a U.S.-citizen child.

The Supreme Court will now decide whether the administration has the authority to grant temporary stays of deportation, issue work permits, and make illegal immigrants eligible for some taxpayer benefits. The decision could have significant implications for the millions of undocumented immigrants in the U.S. who are eligible for the DACA and DAPA programs.

Title: Oregon Bureau of Labor and Industries Orders $135,000 in Damages for Discrimination Against Same-Sex Couple

Article:

The owners of Sweet Cakes by Melissa, Aaron and Melissa Klein, have been ordered to pay $135,000 in damages for emotional suffering to a lesbian couple based on a final order from the Oregon Bureau of Labor and Industries. The order, issued on Thursday, upholds an initial ruling in January that found the Kleins had violated Oregon civil-rights law by refusing to bake a wedding cake for a same-sex ceremony in 2013.

Oregon labor commissioner Brad Avakian, in his 122-page order, stated, "This case is not about a wedding cake or a marriage. It is about a business's refusal to serve someone because of their sexual orientation." He added, "Under Oregon law, that is illegal."

The Kleins had argued that participating in the wedding by baking the cake would have violated their religious beliefs, but Mr. Avakian rejected the distinction between discriminating against a same-sex couple and refusing to participate in a same-sex ceremony. "The forum has already found there to be no distinction between the two," he said.

The Kleins' attorney, Anna Harmon, called the final order a "shocking result which shows the state's relentless campaign to punish Oregonians who live and work according to their faith," according to KATU-TV in Portland. The Kleins, who closed their shop and now sell baked goods from their home, indicated in a Facebook post that they "will NOT give up this fight," suggesting they may appeal the order to the Oregon Court of Appeals.

In a Facebook post, the Kleins stated, "According to the state of Oregon we neither have freedom of religion or freedom of speech. We stand for God's truth, God's word and freedom for ALL Americans. We are here to obey God not man, and we will not conform to this world."

The Sweet Cakes case is one of at least a half-dozen involving complaints by same-sex couples against Christian small business owners who declined to provide products for gay weddings. The specifics of these other cases were not provided in the source text.

Title: Sanders' Resolute Attitude Towards Democratic Party and Presidential Race

Article:

Bernie Sanders, the Vermont senator and Democratic presidential candidate, has displayed a newfound determination in his campaign, a development that stems from months of frustration with the national Democratic Party. This frustration is attributed to a perceived bias in the debate schedule, fund-raising arrangements, and the appointment of Clinton partisans as leaders of important convention committees.

The Democratic National Committee (DNC) also rebuked Sanders on Tuesday for not explicitly condemning a violent incident at the Nevada Democratic convention over the weekend.

Despite Sanders' expressed desire for Donald Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, not to win in November, his advisers and allies suggest that he is prepared to cause some damage to Hillary Clinton in the short term if it means securing a majority of the 475 pledged delegates in California and arriving at the Philadelphia convention with significant political influence.

Tad Devine, a senior adviser to Sanders, stated that the campaign does not believe their attacks will benefit Trump in the long run, but added that the senator's team is "not thinking about" the possibility of their actions potentially derailing Clinton from becoming the first woman elected president.

Devine emphasized, "The only thing that matters is what happens between now and June 14," referring to the final Democratic primary in the District of Columbia. "We have to put the blinders on and focus on the best case to make in the upcoming states. If we do that, we can be in a strong position to make the best closing argument before the convention. If not, everyone will know in mid-June, and we'll have to take a hard look at where things stand."

The prospect of a prolonged Democratic primary battle is causing concern among party leaders who are eager for Clinton and House and Senate candidates to focus on attacking Trump without being distracted by internal Democratic strife. Sanders has garnered nearly 10 million votes compared to Clinton's 13 million, and Democratic leaders argue that Clinton needs time to court young voters, liberals, and Sanders supporters who view her as aligned with corporate and big-money interests.

Title: Millennial Political Alliances: A Shift in the 2016 Presidential Election Landscape

Article:

The 2016 presidential election is approaching, and an unusual silence pervades social media regarding potential candidates, particularly among the millennial generation. This demographic, known for their vocal opinions, appears to be in a state of political indecision as the political alliances of millennials are up for grabs.

For the past seven years, millennials have been steadfast in their support of marriage equality, aligning with the Democrat Party's platform. However, with the legalization of gay marriage in every state, many millennials find themselves apathetic towards the political landscape without a direct loyalty to the Democrat Party.

Millennials' political views are diverse, as evidenced by the results of a recent Reason Foundation poll. They desire small government, provided budget cuts do not directly affect them. They have higher approval ratings for Congress than any other generation, yet they oppose Obamacare, despite supporting the promise of universal health care.

The millennial generation's political leanings are complex, and their desire for limited government is a common thread. This desire for minimal government intervention is surprising, given the past eight years' focus on taxing the wealthy and redistributing wealth. However, millennials are more inclined to support movements that raise money for those in need, without government control over how and where to do so.

The political affiliations of millennials are in flux, and the Republican Party, when stripped to its bare bones, may have what millennials want to rally behind. The millennial generation desires freedom to pursue their passions, start their own companies, and enjoy life without government intervention. They value their wealth and want to use it as they see fit.

If the Republican Party can learn how to create a conversation centered around limited government, 2016's political landscape may become more red than anticipated. The political affiliations of the millennial generation are officially up for grabs.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Performance in Democratic Race Draws Mixed Reviews from Commentators

Article:

The Democratic primary race has seen Hillary Clinton securing victories in multiple states, yet she is receiving negative reviews from some political commentators. Despite President Obama's endorsement and Clinton's expected victory, some commentators express concerns about her performance and her ability to withstand a potential challenge from Donald Trump in the general election.

Joe Klein, a longtime observer of the Clinton family, offers a critical assessment of Clinton's political style and her potential matchup against Trump. He suggests that Clinton, often perceived as the embodiment of the political establishment, may struggle to connect with voters in the current political climate.

Klein argues that Clinton's speaking style, which he describes as "nutritious but bland," may not resonate with voters, particularly in comparison to Trump's more direct and divisive approach. He also criticizes Clinton's perceived tendency to avoid taking firm positions on certain issues, which he sees as a liability in the current political climate.

Another concern raised by commentators is Clinton's low polling marks on honesty, a result of the email scandal and decades of accumulated accusations. Veteran journalist Jeff Greenfield identifies three reasons why Clinton could prove to be a weak candidate: mistrust among the electorate, her association with the political establishment, and her perceived embodiment of the past rather than the future.

Despite these concerns, Clinton enjoys broad support within the Democratic Party, and most Bernie Sanders supporters are expected to shift their allegiance to her. However, the same cannot be said for Trump, who is facing a Republican revolt against his potential nomination.

The article concludes by noting that Clinton's ability to generate enthusiasm among voters, particularly younger voters, will be a key factor in her ability to win the general election. The success of her campaign will be measured by improved reviews from journalists on the left, indicating a more authentic and engaging political style.

Title: U.S. Secretary of State Tillerson Meets with Russian Counterpart Amid Syria Tensions; White House Press Secretary Spicer's Controversial Remarks

Article:

U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is currently in Moscow for meetings with his Russian counterpart, Sergey Lavrov, amid escalating tensions between the U.S. and Russia over the war in Syria. On Tuesday, White House officials accused Russia of attempting to conceal the Syrian government's alleged role in a chemical attack that killed 86 civilians, including dozens of children, last week. The U.S. asserts the Syrian government carried out the attack, while Russia has blamed the anti-government rebels.

During the trip, Russian President Vladimir Putin has signaled he may meet with Tillerson. This is a departure from Putin's earlier position.

Meanwhile, lawmakers and Jewish organizations, including the Anne Frank Center, are calling for White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer's resignation following his controversial comments regarding the Syrian conflict. Spicer compared the Syrian regime to Hitler and falsely claimed Hitler never used chemical weapons.

In response to these allegations, Spicer stated, "You look, we didn't use chemical weapons in World War II. You know, you had a—you know, someone as despicable as Hitler, who didn't even sink to the—to using chemical weapons."

In fact, the Nazis systematically used poison gas as part of their genocide of 6 million Jews and others. The Nazis began experimenting with gas with the specific purpose of carrying out mass murder in the late 1930s. After the Nazis invaded the Soviet Union, they deployed gas vans to kill hundreds of thousands of people. By 1942, the Nazis had set up a series of concentration camps where gas chambers were the main method of killing people. At its peak, as many as 6,000 people, mostly Jews, were gassed to death every day at Auschwitz concentration camp alone.

During his comments, Spicer also referred to Nazi concentration camps as "holocaust centers."

Hours later, Spicer apologized, although he made a number of mistakes during his apology, including mispronouncing Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's name. Spicer stated, "I mistakenly used an inappropriate and insensitive reference to the Holocaust, for which, frankly, there is no—there is no comparison. And for that, I apologize. It was a mistake to do that."

In his apology, Spicer also mispronounced Assad's name, with CNN's Wolf Blitzer correcting him, stating, "Bashar al-Assad. I know you've mispronounced his name a few times, but it's Bashar al-Assad."

Spicer later clarified that he meant to say President Trump was seeking to stabilize the region, not to destabilize it.

Title: Unexpected Success Predicted for Affordable Care Act in 2023

Article:

The Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, is set to fully take effect at the beginning of next year, and predictions of potential issues are circulating widely. The act is anticipated to face administrative challenges, and consumers may experience a significant adjustment. Some Republicans are reportedly counting on the law's difficulties to provide them with a substantial electoral advantage.

However, new evidence, particularly from California, the law's most significant test case, suggests that the real Obamacare shock may be one of unexpected success.

Before delving into the implications of this news, it is essential to clarify a crucial point: the Affordable Care Act is a conservative reform in terms of its impact on most people's healthcare. Americans who receive health insurance from their employers, Medicare, or Medicaid—which is to say, the vast majority of those with any form of health insurance—will see minimal changes when the law takes effect.

There are, however, millions of Americans who do not receive insurance from their employers or government programs. They can only obtain insurance by purchasing it individually, and many of these individuals are effectively excluded from this market. In some states, like California, insurers reject applicants with past medical problems. In others, like New York, insurers cannot reject applicants based on their personal medical history (community rating), leading to high premiums due to the enrollment of individuals with current health problems while healthy individuals often choose to remain uninsured.

Title: President Trump Removes State Department Inspector General, Allegations of Retaliation Arise

Article:

President Donald Trump fired the State Department's Inspector General, Steve Linick, on Friday, citing a loss of confidence in the Obama administration appointee. The president's letter, which did not mention Linick by name, stated that his removal would take effect in 30 days, according to The Associated Press.

Linick, a former assistant U.S. attorney in California and Virginia who has held the Inspector General (IG) position since 2013, had overseen reports that were critical of the State Department's management policies since Trump took office. His office had also criticized several Trump appointees for their treatment of career staff for allegedly being insufficiently supportive of Trump and his policies, the AP reported.

Last October, Fox News reported that Linick had hosted a closed-door briefing on Ukraine for aides from several congressional committees. The briefing examined communications between Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani and fired Ukrainian prosecutor Viktor Shokin and current Prosecutor General Yuriy Lutsenko. Linick also shared news clips and information regarding Ukrainian energy company Burisma, Fox reported.

The conversations between Giuliani and the Ukrainians were in reference to reports that former Vice President Joe Biden had sought to have Shokin fired amid an investigation into Burisma, whose board members included Hunter Biden, son of the former vice president. President Trump's July 2019 request that Ukraine's president investigate the Biden matter led to the House impeaching the president last December on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. The Senate acquitted Trump in February.

Democrats in Congress immediately cried foul, with the chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee suggesting that Linick was fired in part in retaliation for opening an investigation into Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.

"This firing is the outrageous act of a president trying to protect one of his most loyal supporters, the secretary of state, from accountability," said Eliot Engel, D-N.Y., in a statement. "I have learned that the Office of the Inspector General had opened an investigation into Secretary Pompeo. Mr. Linick's firing amid such a probe strongly suggests that this is an unlawful act of retaliation."

Engel offered no details of the alleged investigation into Pompeo, although two congressional aides told the Associated Press the investigation involved allegations that Pompeo may have improperly treated staff.

Linick's removal continues a series of changes among the government's inspectors general. In April, Trump fired Michael Atkinson, the inspector general for the intelligence community, for his role in the whistleblower complaint that led to Trump's impeachment. Then Trump removed Glenn Fine as acting inspector general at the Defense Department, a move that stripped him of his post as chairman of the Pandemic Response Accountability Committee. That panel is charged with overseeing the allocation of more than $2 trillion in coronavirus relief funding.

During a White House briefing on the coronavirus, Trump questioned the independence of an inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services over a report that said there was a shortage of supplies and testing at hospitals.

When Linick departs, he will be replaced by Stephen Akard, a former career foreign service officer with close ties to Vice President Mike Pence, a Trump administration official told the AP. Akard currently runs the department's Office of Foreign Missions. He had been nominated to be the director general of the Foreign Service but withdrew after objections he was not experienced enough.

"The president must cease his pattern of reprisal and retaliation against the public servants who are working to keep Americans safe, particularly during this time of global emergency," said House Speaker Nancy Pelosi in a statement. Pelosi claimed Linick was being "punished for honorably performing his duty to protect the Constitution and our national security."

Rep. Eliot Engel, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, suggested Linick was fired in part in retaliation for opening an unspecified investigation into Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. "This firing is the outrageous act of a president trying to protect one of his most loyal supporters, the secretary of state, from accountability," Engel said in a statement. "I have learned that the Office of the Inspector General had opened an investigation into Secretary Pompeo. Mr. Linick's firing amid such a probe strongly suggests that this is an unlawful act of retaliation."

Engel offered no details of the alleged investigation into Pompeo, but Linick's office had issued several reports critical of the department's handling of personnel matters, including accusing some of Trump's appointees of retaliating against career officials.

Title: California Attorney General Considering Action Against Officials Defying Sanctuary City Laws

Article:

California Attorney General Xavier Becerra has stated that he is considering taking action against officials who are defying the state's sanctuary city laws. During a news conference, Becerra emphasized his duty to enforce state law, stating, "State law is state law. It's my job to enforce state law, and I will do so."

When asked if this stance meant potential legal action against a sheriff who announced her department would cooperate with Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) by publishing inmate release dates through an online database, Becerra did not provide a direct response.

Orange County Sheriff Sandra Hutchins, in a statement on Tuesday, defended her department's decision, stating that it "will enhance communication between the Sheriff's Department and our law enforcement partners to remove dangerous offenders from our community."

Fox News host Tucker Carlson interviewed Sheriff Hutchins, expressing concern over the attorney general's statement, stating, "You are chief law enforcement officer of the county. The attorney general is threatening to arrest you." Hutchins responded, "I don't think he understands what the law says. What I'm doing is entirely within the confines of the law, and I'm doing what I think is important for my constituents. It's a public safety issue to me. It's not about immigration at all. It's about individuals who have committed violent crimes."

Following the Sheriff Department's statement, the Orange County Board of Supervisors voted 3-0 to join the Department of Justice's lawsuit against California over three of the state's recent immigration laws. Supervisor Shawn Nelson stated before the vote, "This legislation prevents law enforcement from removing criminals from our community and is a threat to public safety."

Title: FBI Obtains FISA Warrant to Monitor Carter Page, Trump Campaign Advisor

Article:

The FBI obtained a secret court order last summer to monitor the communications of Carter Page, an adviser to presidential candidate Donald Trump, as part of an investigation into possible links between Russia and the campaign. The FBI and the Justice Department obtained the warrant targeting Page's communications after convincing a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court judge that there was probable cause to believe Page was acting as an agent of a foreign power, in this case Russia, according to U.S. officials.

This development marks the clearest evidence so far that the FBI had reason to believe during the 2016 presidential campaign that a Trump campaign adviser was in touch with Russian agents. Such contacts are now at the center of an investigation into whether the campaign coordinated with the Russian government to swing the election in Trump's favor.

Page has not been accused of any crimes, and it is unclear whether the Justice Department might later seek charges against him or others in connection with Russia's meddling in the 2016 presidential election. The counterintelligence investigation into Russian efforts to influence U.S. elections began in July, officials have said. Most such investigations don't result in criminal charges.

The officials spoke about the court order on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss details of a counterintelligence probe. It is also unclear whether the FBI's surveillance of Page captured any evidence of wrongdoing or collusion with the Russian government.

In a separate development, Rep. Devin Nunes (R-CA), the chair of the House Intelligence Committee, first unveiled the news of the unmasking in a short press conference last month, where he later briefed the White House on the find. The move was seen as controversial, with members of the committee crying foul that they were not shown the documents that Nunes said revealed this information.

Nunes also viewed these documents on White House grounds, where two staffers aided in a navigational capacity since intelligence services were reportedly stonewalling Nunes. While the two White House staffers did not turn out to be his direct sources, the optics were bad, and the damage was done.

It is also reported that the person who requested the unmasking was high up the food chain in the intelligence community, not a member of the FBI, and well known. That person was Susan Rice, who said last month on PBS that she had no clue about the leaks. Now, she says that unmasking was part of the job; she changed her story. Rice isn't exactly an arbiter of truth either. She lied about the nature of the 2012 Benghazi attack, which she said was due to a spontaneous reaction to a YouTube video when in fact—the administration knew that this was a coordinated terrorist attack by a group affiliated with al-Qaeda.

Both GOP and Democratic House Intelligence committee members have looked at the documents that Nunes and ranking member Rep. Adam Schiff (D-CA) looked at and concluded that there doesn't appear to be anything out of the ordinary (or illegal) even with Rice's unmasking request. However, both the House and Senate probes seem to be set on calling Ms. Rice in for further questioning.

As of right now, there is no definitive proof that the Trump campaign colluded with Russia, according to Rep. Adam Schiff himself last week. FISA warrants are almost never turned down, so it's apparent that the threshold is rather low. What is absolutely true as of right now is that there is no definitive proof that the Trump campaign colluded with Russia.

Title: Islamic Militant Group Gains Control of U.S. Embassy Compound in Tripoli, Libya

Article:

An Islamic militant group, the Dawn of Libya, has reportedly taken control of the U.S. Embassy compound in Tripoli, Libya's capital city. American personnel evacuated the area approximately a month ago due to ongoing fighting in the country. An Associated Press journalist was granted access to the compound on Sunday, following an invitation from the Dawn of Libya.

Upon inspection, the compound showed signs of vandalism, with broken windows, but most of the equipment appeared untouched. The breach of the diplomatic post may reignite debate in the U.S. regarding its role in Libya, more than three years after supporting rebels who overthrew dictator Moammar Gadhafi.

A commander for the Dawn of Libya group claimed that their forces had been in control of the compound since last week. In response, a senior State Department official stated, "We've seen the reports and videos and are seeking additional details. At this point, we believe the Embassy compound itself remains secure, but we continue to monitor the situation on the ground, which remains very fluid."

The official also noted that the U.S. Ambassador and other officials remain engaged, both in Washington and from the U.S. Embassy in Valletta, Malta, where embassy staff from Tripoli were recently relocated. No U.S. military or assets were guarding the property after the State Department's withdrawal.

On September 11, 2012, U.S. Ambassador Christopher Stevens, former Navy SEALs Tyrone Woods and Glen Doherty, and State Department information management officer Sean Smith were killed in a terror attack on a U.S. outpost in Benghazi, Libya. A video posted online showed men playing in a pool at the compound. U.S. Ambassador to Libya Deborah Jones stated that the video appeared to have been shot in the embassy's residential annex.

However, two sources with first-hand knowledge of the embassy and other U.S. facilities in Libya claim that the YouTube video in which the militia members are diving from a roof into the pool was taken at the CIA annex in Tripoli, which was abandoned when U.S. Embassy personnel and the ambassador evacuated on July 26. It is approximately a mile away from the U.S. Embassy in Libya.

When the CIA abandoned the annex in July, it would no longer be considered sovereign U.S. territory. Jones also stated that the compound appears to be "safeguarded," not "ransacked." The fighting prompted diplomats and thousands of Tripoli residents to flee. Dozens were killed in the fighting. On July 26, U.S. diplomats evacuated to neighboring Tunisia under a U.S. military escort. The State Department announced that embassy operations would be suspended until the security situation improved. The Dawn of Libya militia has called on foreign diplomats to return now that the fighting has subsided.

Title: High School Student Speaks Out, Denies Allegations of Racial Taunting at Rally

Article:

Nick Sandmann, a junior at Covington Catholic High School, has broken his silence regarding the viral video showing a confrontation between Native American protesters and his classmates at a Washington rally. In a statement released Sunday evening, Sandmann claimed that his classmates were taunted by a group of African-American protesters before the viral clip was recorded. He also stated that he and his family have received death threats.

Sandmann, who was one of the students seen in the viral video, said, "I am mortified that so many people have come to believe something that did not happen -- that students from my school were chanting or acting in a racist fashion toward African Americans or Native Americans. I did not do that, do not have hateful feelings in my heart, and did not witness any of my classmates doing that."

The initial accusations were made against the students, who were wearing "Make America Great Again" apparel, for allegedly mocking a Native American participant in the Indigenous Peoples March. A brief clip of the apparent confrontation quickly spread on social media, with many condemning the students and some calling for their identification and harassment. The Roman Catholic Diocese of Covington and the high school issued a joint statement apologizing to the activist, identified as Nathan Phillips, on Saturday.

However, the emergence of longer video that appears to show some students being harassed by a group of protesters has led some conservatives to retract their earlier criticisms of the students.

According to Sandmann, his classmates had taken part in the March for Life and had arrived at the Lincoln Memorial to wait for the buses that would take them back to Kentucky. However, Sandmann said, the students were confronted by four members of the Black Hebrew Israelite movement, who allegedly called them "racists," "bigots," "white crackers," "f-- -ts," and "incest kids." They also reportedly taunted an African-American student from his school by saying they would "harvest his organs."

Sandmann said one of the students asked a teacher chaperoning the trip for permission to "begin our school spirit chants" to drown out the hecklers. In one chant, the group appeared to perform the haka, a traditional Maori dance. Marcus Frejo, a member of the Pawnee and Seminole tribes who witnessed the chant, said he considered it mockery.

"At no time did I hear any student chant anything other than the school spirit chants," Sandmann said. "I did not witness or hear any other students chant 'build that wall' or anything hateful or racist at any time. Assertions to the contrary are simply false."

At that point, Phillips approached the group with his drum and, according to Sandmann, "locked eyes with me and approached me, coming within inches of my face" and "played his drum the entire time he was in my face." Sandmann said he remained "motionless and calm" to de-escalate the tense situation. He also denied taunting Phillips by making faces at him, but said he smiled at the protester "because I wanted him to know I was not going to become angry, intimidated, or be provoked into a larger confrontation."

For his part, Phillips told The Associated Press Sunday that he was trying to keep the peace between the students and members of the group who were heckling them. He also insisted that the students were making disparaging remarks about Native Americans.

"They were making remarks to each other... (such as) 'In my state those Indians are nothing but a bunch of drunks.' How do I report that?" he said. "These young people were just roughshodding through our space, like what's been going on for 500 years here -- just walking through our territories, feeling like 'this is ours.'"

Frejo said he joined Phillips to de-escalate the tense situation, singing the anthem from the American Indian Movement with both men beating out the tempo on hand drums.

"I am being called every name in the book, including a racist, and I will not stand for this mob-like character assassination of my family's name," Sandmann said. "... One person threatened to harm me at school and one person claims to live in my neighborhood. My parents are receiving death and professional threats because of the social media mob that has formed over this issue."

Title: American Health Care Act Fails: An Analysis of the Failed Legislation and Its Implications

Article:

The American Health Care Act (AHCA) has failed to pass in the U.S. House of Representatives, marking a significant setback for the Republican Party and President Donald Trump. The bill, which aimed to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), faced opposition from both Democrats and a significant number of Republicans.

The AHCA was criticized for its potential to leave 24 million people without insurance and increase deductibles for millions more, while providing tax cuts for millionaires. Michael Needham, head of the conservative Heritage Action, described the bill as "an awful bill that will impact millions of Americans' lives and is opposed by nearly every serious conservative health care analyst."

Representative Mo Brooks, a conservative Republican from Alabama, stated, "I will vote against the American Health Care Act because it has more bad policy than any bill I have ever faced." David Brooks, in his Friday column, wrote, "This bill takes the most vicious progressive stereotypes about conservatives and validates them."

The failure of the AHCA is seen as a significant legislative and tactical failure for Speaker Paul Ryan, who took charge of the process and failed to create legislation that could pass. Some bills fail even though the party faithful love them, but the AHCA was not one of those. Republicans were glad to see it die.

Beyond the legislative and tactical deficiencies, the AHCA reflected a deeper failure of moral and policy imagination. Ryan, who had promised to repair the Republican Party's relationship with the poor, presented a plan that was widely criticized as inadequate.

The limits of Donald Trump's attention span were on display throughout the AHCA's short life. He never bothered to learn enough about the AHCA to make a persuasive case for it, which is part of the reason it failed. Trump's strategy of blaming Democrats for the bill's failure is unlikely to be effective, as he never attempted to gain Democratic support.

Republicans would be wise to reflect deeply on what happened and reconsider their approach to policy-making and governing. As Jonathan Chait writes, "Republicans have spent eight years fooling themselves about Obamacare... Their attacks on Obamacare have been opportunistic and cynical in ways that made its replacement nearly impossible." Big policy change is hard, and the modern Republican Party has built itself in opposition, often ignoring the successes of the policies they criticize.

Title: 39 Bodies Found in Truck in England; Driver Arrested on Suspicion of Murder

GRAYS, England (AP) — Authorities found 39 people dead in a truck in an industrial park in England on Wednesday, in one of Britain's worst human-smuggling tragedies. The truck and the trailer with the people inside apparently took separate circuitous journeys before ending up on the grounds of the Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays, 25 miles (40 kilometers) east of London on the River Thames.

Police were reconstructing the final journey of the victims as they tried to piece together where they were from and how they came to be in England. The truck and its driver, a 25-year-old man from Northern Ireland, were arrested on suspicion of murder. The truck was registered in Bulgaria to a company owned by an Irish citizen, according to Bulgaria's Foreign Ministry. The Belgian federal prosecutor's office has opened an investigation.

Ambulance workers discovered the bodies after being called at 1:40 a.m. It was unclear who called the ambulance service. No cause of death has been made public, and police have not released further details about the victims. The number of victims was shocking, although it has become sadly common in recent years for small numbers of migrants to occasionally be found dead in sealed vehicles after having been abandoned by traffickers.

The tragedy recalls the death of 58 migrants in 2000 in a truck in Dover, England, and the deaths in 2015 of 71 migrants from Syria, Iraq, and Afghanistan who were found suffocated in the back of a refrigerated truck that was abandoned on an Austrian highway close to the Hungarian border. Groups of migrants have repeatedly landed on English shores using small boats for the risky Channel crossing, and migrants are sometimes found in the trunks of cars that disembark from the massive ferries that link France and England.

The National Crime Agency said its specialists were working to "urgently identify and take action against any organized crime groups who have played a role in causing these deaths." It said in May that the number of people being smuggled into Britain via cargo trucks was on the rise.

The investigation is ongoing, and further details about the victims and the truck's journey are still being pieced together.

Title: Jersey City Shooting Highlights Challenges in Controlling Gun Trafficking Across State Borders

Article:

TRENTON, N.J. (AP) — The fatal attack on a Jewish market in New Jersey has highlighted the challenges in controlling gun trafficking across state borders, as officials from states with strong gun restrictions call for stricter firearm control in places with weaker laws.

Three civilians and a police officer were gunned down Tuesday by two killers with anti-Semitic and anti-law enforcement beliefs, according to the state's attorney general. The attackers carried five firearms and a pipe bomb in the U-Haul van they drove to the Jersey City Jewish market before opening fire, officials said. Two of the weapons used by David Anderson, 47, and Francine Graham, 50, were bought by Graham in Ohio last year, police said. It's unknown where they got the three other guns.

New Jersey is among the states with the toughest gun restrictions in the country, and in the past two years, Democratic Gov. Phil Murphy has signed over a half-dozen new restrictions into law, including a lower bullet limit for gun magazines and a red flag law. He's also made a priority of highlighting the so-called iron pipeline of firearms from other states, particularly along the Interstate 95 corridor. Murphy, for example, is requiring state police to publish data monthly on guns recovered from crimes. The data shows nearly 80% of so-called crime guns are from out of state.

Murphy says it's important to "name and shame" states with weaker gun laws that effectively import weapons into New Jersey. And in California, its Democratic governor and attorney general this year both criticized the continued ability to bring in illegal firearms from other states despite California's strict gun laws.

For years, Chicago officials have complained that street violence often comes from the muzzles of guns sold in states with less-stringent laws. Officials there and elsewhere have renewed demands for gun control at the federal level.

"It keeps happening, over and over and over again, on their damn watch," California Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom said of federal politicians. "I can't put borders up in a neighboring state where you can buy this damn stuff legally."

Federal legislation is the missing factor, agreed Murphy's top gun adviser.

"If we're being honest, New Jersey is not an oasis and that's why it's extraordinarily frustrating," said Bill Castner. "We will continue to push and identify the most aggressive actions, but without a federal solution, it's extraordinarily challenging."

Shannon Watts, the founder of Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America, said her group is pressing ahead with state-level gun control because of the political headwinds in Washington.

"What we have to do until we have the right president and Congress is go state by state," Watts said in an interview. "That's what we have to do now because of the political makeup. Every state is only as safe as the closest state with the weakest gun laws."

Second Amendment advocates, though, push back on the need for tougher state and national laws. Scott Bach, the executive director of the New Jersey Association of Rifle and Pistol Clubs, an affiliate of the NRA, invoked a common criticism of tougher restrictions: criminals break laws, they don't follow them.

"Criminals laugh at gun regulations — the only thing they understand is severe punishment for actual gun crime," Bach said.

Officials are still investigating the Jersey City attack and have yet to release details about how the deceased attackers obtained their weapons.

Title: U.S. Successfully Tests Medium-Range Ballistic Missile Defense System; North Korea Vows More Missile Tests

Article:

The U.S. Missile Defense Agency (MDA) announced on Wednesday that a U.S. warship successfully intercepted a medium-range ballistic missile off the coast of Hawaii. The test took place after North Korean leader Kim Jong Un vowed to continue conducting missile tests in the Pacific.

The USS John Paul Jones detected and tracked a missile launched from the Pacific Missile Range Facility on Kauai with its onboard radar before intercepting it with SM-6 missiles, according to the MDA. This marks the second successful interception of a medium-range ballistic missile by an SM-6 missile in a test.

MDA Director Lt. Gen. Sam Greaves described the test as a "key milestone." He stated, "We will continue developing ballistic missile defense technologies to stay ahead of the threat as it evolves."

Defense Secretary Jim Mattis is scheduled to meet with South Korea's Defense Minister Song Young-moo at the Pentagon on Wednesday. The two will discuss possible responses to North Korea's provocative actions, according to South Korea's Yonhap news agency.

North Korea released images of its intermediate-range ballistic missile launch over Japan on Wednesday, a day before the test. The official Korean Central News Agency reported that the Hwasong-12, the first missile the nation has fired over Japan, was "guided" by leader Kim Jong Un and observed by senior officials.

The launch of the intermediate-range rocket traveled nearly 1,700 miles and reached a maximum height of 341 miles as it flew over the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido early Tuesday, according to South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff. Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary, Yoshihide Suga, described the test as an "unprecedented, grave threat."

Kim Jong Un stated that "more ballistic missile rocket launching drills" are "necessary" to modernize his military's strategic capabilities and that his country will continue to observe "U.S. demeanors" before deciding on future actions. Kim expressed "great satisfaction" with what he called a "meaningful prelude" to containing the U.S. territory of Guam, which he has threatened to fire four missiles toward.

President Trump warned Tuesday that "all options are on the table" in response to North Korea's latest missile launch. A military response seems unlikely, according to security analysts.

The U.N. Security Council "strongly condemned" the missile test and North Korea's launching of three ballistic missiles into the sea on Aug. 25. It demanded that Pyongyang "immediately cease all such actions" in a statement following an emergency meeting Tuesday. It did not announce new sanctions.

Choo Mi-ae, the head of South Korea's ruling Democratic Party, urged Pyongyang to accept its offer of dialogue and stated, "Such an act that threatens neighboring nations is unpardonable." Choo added, "If North Korea trusts South Korea's government and holds its hands, the door will open for its survival. Otherwise, it will face more serious isolation."

Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi stated that China will "fully and completely" abide by U.N. Security Council sanctions and will work with other council members on how best to react to North Korea's latest action. "We will make a necessary response," Wang said. China, North Korea's most important ally, accounts for about 90% of the North's foreign trade.

British Prime Minister Theresa May called on China to put more pressure on North Korea, as she arrived in Japan for a three-day visit Wednesday. "We think that China has a role to play and we'd encourage China to do everything it can to bring pressure on North Korea to stop this," she said.

Earlier this month, the Trump administration imposed sanctions on 10 companies and six individuals from mostly China and Russia who it says helped North Korea develop its nuclear and ballistic missile programs. They were the latest in a raft of blacklists issued in recent months to punish Chinese and Russian companies that try to evade international efforts to isolate North Korea.

Title: Three Killed, 11 Wounded in Explosion in Afghanistan's Khost Province

A motorcycle rigged with a bomb exploded during a football match in Afghanistan's eastern Khost province, according to Sayed Ahmad Babazai, a police chief in the area. The bomb detonated near a football pitch in Nadir Shah Kot district on Monday afternoon, as reported by the provincial governor's spokesman, Talib Khan Mangal, to Afghan media.

The bombing occurred after the Taliban announced the resumption of offensive operations against Afghan security forces, ending the "reduction in violence" agreement that preceded the signing of a deal between the armed group and the United States. Under the deal signed on Saturday, foreign forces will withdraw from Afghanistan within 14 months, subject to Taliban security guarantees and a pledge by the group to hold talks with the Kabul government.

The four-part agreement sets March 10 as the date for an intra-Afghan dialogue, as well as a prisoner swap, which would see the government release 5,000 Taliban prisoners and the Taliban release 1,000 captives. However, Afghan President Ashraf Ghani stated on Sunday that "the government of Afghanistan has made no commitment to free 5,000 Taliban prisoners."

In response, the Taliban stated on Monday that it would not take part in intra-Afghan talks until the prisoners were released. Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid told Reuters news agency, "We are fully ready for the intra-Afghan talks, but we are waiting for the release of our 5,000 prisoners." Mujahid added, "If our 5,000 prisoners - 100 or 200 more or less does not matter - do not get released, there will be no intra-Afghan talks."

Commander of NATO forces in Afghanistan, US General Scott Miller, stated that the United States expected the Taliban to "be very serious" about its obligations. Miller said in a tweet, "The reduction in violence was a confidence builder... The United States has been very clear about our expectations - the violence must remain low."

Title: U.S. Special Forces Member Criticizes Turkey's Invasion of Northeastern Syria, Citing Atrocities and Potential ISIS Release

Article:

A U.S. special forces member serving with the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) in Syria has criticized Turkey's ongoing invasion of northeastern Syria, stating that Turkey is inflicting atrocities. The unidentified soldier, who has been involved in the training of indigenous forces on multiple continents, told Fox News that Turkey is not adhering to the agreed-upon security arrangements and that the SDF has met every single agreement with no threat to Turkey from their side of the border.

President Trump announced on October 6 that U.S. troops would withdraw from the area in anticipation of Turkey's offensive, removing the chief deterrent to Ankara's operation. The decision has sparked controversy in Washington, with some lawmakers expressing concern about the potential for an ISIS comeback and a stain on America's honor for abandoning the Kurds.

Turkey has long viewed Kurdish groups in northern Syria, which have worked with the U.S. in the fight against ISIS, as linked with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), a terrorist organization labeled as such by both Washington and Ankara. Reports have emerged of several civilian casualties since Turkey's military operation began, with the U.S. soldier telling Fox News that the U.S. president "doesn't understand the problem" and the repercussions of the withdrawal.

Defense officials have expressed concerns that the offensive against the SDF could lead to the inadvertent release of several ISIS members that the SDF is detaining. Trump confirmed on October 10 that the U.S. had taken custody of two ISIS militants believed to be part of an execution unit in case the Kurds or Turkey "lose control." The U.S. has already taken the two ISIS militants, known as the Beetles, out of Syria and into a secure location controlled by the U.S.

The U.S. service member stated that the current situation is not helping the ISIS fight and that many of the ISIS prisoners "will be free in the coming days and weeks."

Title: Sen. Rand Paul Tweets About "Festivus" and Washington Grievances

Article:

Senator Rand Paul, a self-proclaimed fan of the sitcom "Seinfeld," participated in the unconventional holiday-like tradition of "Festivus" on Monday, a concept popularized in a 1997 episode of the show that is celebrated on December 23. The tradition involves airing grievances.

Paul, a Kentucky Republican, expressed his discontent with politics in Washington, D.C., through a series of tweets. His grievances ranged from criticisms of the Federal Reserve and the recently passed bipartisan budget, to more lighthearted complaints such as the food in the Senate cafeteria and the D.C. street cleaning schedule.

In one tweet, Paul criticized the concept of bipartisan deals in Washington, stating, "In Washington, 'bipartisan deal' is a synonym for 'increasing our debt.'" He also expressed dissatisfaction with his fellow Senator Cory Booker for not retweeting him enough.

In response, Booker tweeted, "U, me & 'feats of strength': Senate floor, name the time," referencing a "Seinfeld" episode where the characters engage in a "feats of strength" contest.

Paul also called for more debate and amendments in the Senate, and criticized changes to the rules that he perceived as an "iron fist" approach. He lamented the absence of burgoo, a traditional Kentucky dish, in the Senate cafeteria, and expressed frustration over his staff altering his wardrobe, particularly a turtleneck sweater.

Additionally, Paul voiced minor grievances about remembering the D.C. street cleaning schedule and the impact of Federal Reserve policies on the economy, particularly on the poor and middle class. "Fed policies make you poorer," he tweeted, "and hurt the poor and middle class the most." He also attributed high grocery and gas bills to Federal Reserve policies.

"Seinfeld" writer Dan O'Keefe weighed in on Paul's reference to the show the following day.

Title: House Ways and Means Chairman Issues Subpoenas for President Trump's Tax Returns

Article:

House Ways and Means Chairman Richard Neal has escalated the dispute over President Donald Trump's tax returns by issuing subpoenas to Department of Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Internal Revenue Service (IRS) Commissioner Charles Rettig. The Treasury Department had previously rejected Neal's request for six years of the president's tax returns.

In a statement, Neal said, "While I do not take this step lightly, I believe this action gives us the best opportunity to succeed and obtain the requested material."
