He added, "I sincerely hope that the Treasury Department will furnish the requested material in the next week so the committee can quickly begin its work."

On Monday, Mnuchin rejected Neal's request for the president's tax returns in a letter. Mnuchin stated, "In reliance on the advice of the Department of Justice, I have determined that the Committee's request lacks a legitimate legislative purpose, and pursuant to section 6103, the Department is therefore not authorized to disclose the requested returns and return information."

Neal initially requested Trump's 2013-2018 tax returns from the IRS, which is part of the Treasury Department. He invoked a law allowing a select few members of Congress to review individual tax returns for legislative purposes and cited legislative proposals and oversight related to federal tax laws as his basis for the request.

This is the first such demand for a sitting president's tax information in 45 years. Neal also demanded copies of tax returns for Trump's trust and for his golf club in Bedminster, New Jersey.

The subpoena is part of a broader effort from Congress to obtain documents and bring administration officials and allies in for questioning. On Wednesday, the GOP-led Senate Intelligence Committee subpoenaed Donald Trump Jr. to answer more questions. Earlier that day, Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee voted to hold Attorney General William Barr in contempt of Congress over his refusal to hand over an unredacted copy of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on the Russian interference in the 2016 election.

Title: Secretary Clinton Takes Responsibility for Benghazi Consulate Attack, Denies Cover-up

Article:

Secretary of State Hillary Clinton took responsibility on Monday for any security failures leading up to the consulate attack last month in Libya that resulted in the death of the American ambassador, Chris Stevens, and three other Americans. However, she pushed back against claims of a cover-up, attributing the Obama administration's shifting explanations for the attack to the "fog of war."

The attack on the consulate in Benghazi occurred on September 11, 2012. Initially, administration officials suggested that the attack was "spontaneous" violence that grew out of protests over an anti-Islam film, rather than a premeditated attack. However, it later became clear that intelligence officials suspected terrorism almost immediately, and investigators now believe extremists tied to Al Qaeda carried out a coordinated attack, with no evidence that the attack was preceded by a protest outside the consulate.

Clinton attributed the administration's shifting story to "the confusion you get in any type of combat situation." She stated, "Remember, this was an attack that went on for hours. There had to be a lot of sorting out... Everyone said, here's what we know, subject to change."

The Obama administration, particularly the State Department, has faced intense scrutiny on Capitol Hill over the level of security at the consulate, with allegations that requests for increased protection were denied or ignored. This question was a prominent topic during the vice presidential debate on Thursday, when Vice President Biden denied getting any requests for increased security. The White House later clarified that Biden was speaking for himself and the president, not for the State Department.

Clinton seemed to back up Biden's claims, stating, "I'm responsible for the State Department, for the more than 60,000 people around the world." She continued, "The decisions about security are made by security professionals. But we're going to review everything to be sure we're doing what needs to be done in an increasingly risky environment."

Clinton also addressed the question of a June explosion at the consulate in Benghazi that some have argued should have raised a red flag about security. She stated, "I can't speak to who knew what." She added, "We knew there were security breaches and problems throughout Libya. That's something that came about as the aftermath of the revolution to topple Qaddafi, with so many militias formed, so many weapons loose... It was taken into account by security professionals as they made their assessments."

Three Republican senators, John McCain of Arizona, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, and Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire, stated that Clinton's claim was "a laudable gesture." However, they put the responsibility for the Benghazi attack and what they called "an escalating pattern of attacks this year in Benghazi" squarely on President Obama and his national security team. They stated, "If the president was truly not aware of this rising threat level in Benghazi, then we have lost confidence in his national security team, whose responsibility it is to keep the president informed. But if the president was aware of these earlier attacks in Benghazi prior to the events of Sept. 11, 2012, then he bears full responsibility for any security failures that occurred."

Title: Potential Discussions on ACA: Delay of Individual Mandate, Medical Device Tax, and Other Changes

Article:

In the event of discussions between President Barack Obama and Republican and Democratic leaders regarding the Affordable Care Act (ACA), there are limited areas of agreement due to the significant differences in their perspectives.

One of the main points of contention is the individual mandate, a requirement for individuals to obtain health insurance or face a penalty. The Republican argument, which has garnered support from some Democrats, is that if the Obama administration can delay the requirement for large employers, individuals should also receive a one-year break from the individual mandate. However, the White House is concerned that delaying the individual mandate could disrupt the balance of healthy and sick individuals in the new insurance system, potentially leading to higher insurance prices and fewer people covered.

Another potential point of discussion is the repeal of the medical device tax, a 2.3% tax on the sales price of medical devices by manufacturers and importers. This idea has won some Democratic support in the past, but it would result in a loss of $30 billion in revenue needed to fund the ACA.

Other potential changes include delaying the entire law for one year, including pre-existing condition coverage, and repealing the Prevention and Public Health Fund, a part of the health law that is not central to its operation. However, these changes would not satisfy the tea party Republicans, who seek a more comprehensive overhaul of the ACA.

Additionally, Republicans could renew their push for the repeal of the Congressional subsidies for health coverage through the Obamacare exchanges. This issue has been a point of contention, with Republicans arguing that it provides a "special break" for lawmakers and their staffs, while Democrats maintain that it is similar to the employer contributions lawmakers and their staffs have always received to get federal employees' health coverage.

In summary, while discussions between President Obama and Republican and Democratic leaders regarding the ACA may occur, there are significant barriers to reaching agreement on piecemeal changes that would not cripple the law, while larger changes proposed by Republicans would be nonstarters for the White House.

Title: Suspect in Charleston Church Shooting Arrested in North Carolina

Article:

Dylann Roof, the alleged perpetrator of a shooting incident at a Charleston, South Carolina church that resulted in the deaths of nine individuals, has been apprehended, authorities confirmed. The arrest took place at a traffic stop in Shelby, North Carolina, approximately 250 miles north of Charleston.

According to police, Roof, 21, was expected to be charged Thursday night with murder, allowing for his extradition. More charges were anticipated, as per the local prosecutor's office in communication with a local affiliate WCIV.

A citizen reported Roof's car to the police, who subsequently made the arrest. Roof cooperated with the officer who stopped him, according to police.

Charleston Police Chief Gregory Mullen expressed satisfaction at the swift resolution of the case during a news conference, stating, "I am so pleased we were able to resolve this case quickly."

The FBI and Charleston police had earlier identified Roof, of Lexington, South Carolina, as the suspect. The shooting occurred at the historic predominantly black Emanuel AME Church on Calhoun Street, where the suspect opened fire on a bible study group, killing eight people and injuring one, who later died. Police initially reported two people hospitalized, but later clarified that only one person survived the shooting initially.

The alleged gunman, whom the mayor called a "horrible scoundrel," was inside the church attending the prayer meeting with worshipers for almost an hour. The victims included three males and six females, and the Rev. Clementa Pinckney, church pastor and a South Carolina state senator, was among the dead. The other victims were identified as Rev. Sharonda Singleton, retired pastor Dr. Daniel L. Simmons, Ethel Lee Lance, Cynthia Hurd, Myra Thompson, and recent college graduate Tywanza Sanders.

Three people survived the shooting, but details about them were not immediately available.

"This is a situation that is unacceptable in any society and especially in our society and our city," Mullen said.

Early this morning, police released pictures from surveillance footage showing the suspect, a white man, approximately 21 to 25 years old, as well as the car he was driving. The suspect was described as approximately 5-foot-9, wearing a sweatshirt with distinctive markings and Timberland boots.

For real-time updates on this developing story, users can "star" this story in the ███ phone app. Download ███ for iPhone or ███ for Android.

Title: Germanwings Flight 9525: Autopilot Reprogrammed, Co-Pilot's Apartment Searched

Article:

Germanwings Flight 9525, a plane traveling from Barcelona, Spain, to Dusseldorf, Germany, crashed Tuesday, killing all 150 people on board. New details suggest that the co-pilot, Andreas Lubitz, intentionally crashed the plane.

According to Flightradar24, a website that tracks aviation data, the autopilot on Germanwings Flight 9525 was reprogrammed during the flight by someone inside the cockpit to change the plane's altitude from 38,000 feet to 100 feet. The plane's cockpit audio recorder captured horrific sounds, including the captain banging on the door and screaming for several minutes before the crash.

Police searched Lubitz's apartment in Dusseldorf, Germany, on Thursday, looking for clues about his possible motive. The French government has also asked the FBI to help investigate the crash. Investigators are still baffled about why Lubitz would have crashed the plane.

Lubitz was a German national and had been with Germanwings since September 2013. He had completed 630 hours of flight time and had all the necessary certifications and qualifications to pilot the aircraft alone. He had passed medical tests, and the audio recording showed his breathing to be steady, with no sign that he had a heart attack or other medical issue.

Lufthansa, the parent company of Germanwings, does not have standard psychological testing for pilots once they are hired. The company considers an applicant's psychological state when hiring, but Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr stated that the co-pilot was "fully qualified to pilot the aircraft on his own."

The bodies of the crash victims will not be released to family members until all DNA identification work has been done, a process likely to last several weeks. While some human remains have been recovered, many have not. The task is treacherous for search crews working on steep slopes in icy weather.

The disaster is not being described as a "terrorist attack," and the killing of 150 people would not typically be described as a "suicide." Lufthansa is providing "financial support" to relatives of the victims, and many relatives and friends of the victims have traveled to an area near the site where their loved ones perished.

Title: Libertarian Party's Gary Johnson Gains Momentum Ahead of National Convention

Article:

In the unpredictable 2016 presidential election, the Libertarian Party is seizing an opportunity to make a significant impact, as voters express reservations about the likely Republican and Democratic nominees. The Libertarian Party's national convention, starting this Friday, will determine their nominee.

Former New Mexico Governor Gary Johnson, heavily favored to win the Libertarian nomination, has been garnering attention recently, with at least two polls placing him in double digits against Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Donald Trump. One poll showed Johnson pulling 10 percent against the two major party candidates, a notable achievement for a party that has never garnered more than 1 percent of the vote in a presidential election.

Johnson acknowledged that his poll numbers reflect a combination of growth among libertarians and a "none-of-the-above" choice for disillusioned voters. If he secures the nomination at the Memorial Day weekend convention, Johnson indicated he would aim to fill the role of Trump/Clinton alternative.

"The nominee for the Libertarian Party is going to be the only third-party candidate on the ballot in all 50 states," Johnson said. "I jokingly say that if Mickey Mouse were [the] third name in any polls, the recognizable figure that he is, [he] would be at 30 percent. But Mickey is not on the ballot in all 50 states."

State ballot access will be a challenge, but Johnson, who is already on 32 state ballots, expects the party to be on all 50 state ballots by November. To appeal to #NeverTrump Republicans, Johnson has tapped another former GOP governor, William Weld of Massachusetts, as his running mate.

Johnson is still short of the 15 percent needed to qualify for the presidential debates. However, he believes that if he participates in the debates, the ticket could collect electoral votes. Johnson's optimism about actually winning is tempered by reality and history, as the party has a poor track record in general elections, and Johnson's poll numbers have not always held up.

In the 2012 general election, Johnson polled at about 4 percent during the campaign but ended up with less than 1 percent of the popular vote. Still, the 1.2 million votes represented a record for a Libertarian, and if the party can build on that this year, it could be enough to influence the outcome in November – though whether the candidate draws votes away from the GOP or Democratic nominee remains to be seen.

About 1,000 delegates are expected to gather in Orlando for the convention. Johnson, anti-virus software developer John McAfee, libertarian media publisher Austin Petersen, and 15 other candidates are among the top contenders. Johnson is not guaranteed a first-ballot victory, but if he does not win on the first round, McAfee stated, "If Johnson does not win on the first round, it will be mine."

William Irwin, the chairman of the philosophy department at King's College, who has written books on libertarianism, most recently "Free Dakota," said, "Some predicted the libertarian moment has passed. I think the libertarian moment is now." However, Johnson, if nominated, could run into trouble with some conservatives while attracting liberals due to his support for abortion rights, marijuana legalization, military cuts, and a reserved foreign policy, as well as his backing for sweeping entitlement reforms, changes to the tax code, and term limits for members of Congress.

Johnson and Weld, both two-term governors in the 1990s, were given A's in the libertarian Cato Institute's Fiscal Policy Report Card for cutting spending and taxes. "Two governors running against a candidate that has never held office and another who has not held executive office – the Libertarians would be the most experienced ticket," Cato Institute Executive Vice President David Boaz said. "But this year, experience isn't what people are looking for."

Title: U.S. Army Soldier Charged with Sharing Deployment Information with Extremist Groups

Article:

A U.S. Army private, Ethan Phelan Melzer, has been charged with multiple counts of attempted murder for allegedly planning to provide information about his unit's deployment to extremist groups, with the intention of inciting an attack. The charges were brought forth by a federal grand jury on Monday and carry a maximum sentence of life in prison.

According to John Demers, assistant attorney general in charge of the Justice Department's national security division, Melzer, a 22-year-old from Louisville, Kentucky, "planned a deadly ambush on his fellow soldiers in the service of a diabolical cocktail of ideologies laced with hate and violence."

Court documents reveal that Melzer began communicating with followers of a violent, satanic neo-Nazi fringe group known as the Order of the Nine Angles in April. In May, he reportedly started sharing information about his Army unit, stationed in Italy, and its planned redeployment to a U.S. military base in Turkey, with the intention of inspiring a jihadist attack.

The FBI stated that Melzer unknowingly communicated with a confidential source assisting in an FBI and Army investigation while in a restricted chat room. He allegedly shared the location of a U.S. military installation, the nature of the weaponry his unit would be armed with, its vulnerabilities, the number of soldiers stationed at the base, and other details.

Federal officials claim the Army thwarted the plot in late May, and the FBI arrested Melzer on June 10. He reportedly confessed to providing the information to the messaging application users to facilitate a mass casualty attack on his unit.

The Order of the Nine Angles is based in the U.K., but has gained notoriety as a source of inspiration for violent American white supremacists. Brian Levin, a terrorism expert at California State University in San Bernardino, described it as "a decades-old extreme satanic Nazi cult whose glorification of violence and mysticism has found a renewed international audience, including some young violent American neo-Nazis."

The Southern Poverty Law Center describes the Order of Nine Angles as "an enigmatic Satanic occult group." Its most extreme adherents "promote human sacrifice, Nazism and Fascism, and Aryan myths, and have been reported to praise Adolf Hitler and Osama bin Laden."

Melzer joined the Army in 2018 and became a follower of the group in 2019, according to the Justice Department. He was deployed overseas in 2019 and was reportedly following propaganda from several extremist groups by then.

Audrey Strauss, the acting US attorney in Manhattan, where the formal charges were filed, stated, "Melzer was motivated by racism and hatred as he attempted to carry out this ultimate act of betrayal." No information about his defense lawyer was available at the time of publication.

Title: Mitt Romney Campaigns in Michigan as Likely Republican Presidential Nominee

Article:

Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts and the likely Republican presidential nominee, has returned to his home state of Michigan, marking the final stop on a five-day, six-state Midwestern tour. Romney, who was born in Michigan and raised in the suburbs outside Detroit, expressed optimism about his chances of winning the state in November.

"I think Michigan's a state I can win," Romney told reporters on his campaign plane as he left Iowa. When asked if carrying the state in November would hold special significance, Romney replied, "If I win in Michigan, then I become the president, and that would mean a lot to me personally."

Romney's father, George Romney, ran a car company - American Motors Corp. - and served as the governor of Michigan. George Romney unsuccessfully sought the Republican presidential nomination in 1968, a prize his son is set to be officially awarded at the Republican National Convention in August. Mitt Romney launched his unsuccessful bid for the 2008 GOP nomination nearly six years ago.

Michigan is one of several states that could determine the outcome in November. It is not on Romney's campaign's list of top targets, which includes traditionally Republican states like Virginia and North Carolina and swing states like Ohio and Florida. However, it is one of a number of Rust Belt states President Barack Obama won in 2008 where Romney's campaign team sees an opportunity.

"There's another level of states that are all states that Obama won last time," said deputy campaign manager Katie Packer Gage, a Michigan native. "And he won't win if he doesn't win them again."

Romney faces an uphill battle in Michigan, as there is a strong Democratic base in Detroit, and he has struggled to explain his opposition to the federal bailout that saved General Motors and Chrysler. Romney's 2012 campaign has been marked by frequent reminders of his Michigan roots, with George Romney's photo displayed on the campaign bus during the primary and supporters bringing Romney '68 memorabilia to campaign rallies.

Romney has talked about his love for Vernors, a distinctive ginger ale popular in Michigan, and has affectionately referred to Michigan's trees as being the "right height." During the primary campaign, Romney was criticized for his comment that his wife, Ann, drives "a couple of Cadillacs," which was perceived as out of touch with Americans struggling in a bad economy.

Romney's opposition to federal support for General Motors and Chrysler has been a contentious issue, and he has struggled to clarify his position. Romney has stated that he supported the managed bankruptcy that eventually structured GM, but he was opposed to facilitating it with the federal money that the Obama administration provided, and he criticized the bailouts during the primary campaign. There are already signs that he plans to soften his tone on the issue.

"He's going to acknowledge, as he has, that President Obama and he ultimately shared the same goal, which was to see the auto industry survive and thrive," said Gage, the deputy campaign manager. "They just had different ways of going about it. He's pleased to see that he does seem to be getting stronger."

Title: Five Key Points to Watch in President Obama's Second-Term State of the Union Address

Article:

President Barack Obama will deliver his first State of the Union address of his second term on Tuesday, outlining his second-term agenda. Here are five key points to watch for:

1. Bipartisan Progress and GOP Criticism: According to sources, the president is expected to highlight bipartisan progress on immigration reform, but he will also take the Republican Party to task on debt and tax reform. Already, Republicans are bracing for criticism.

2. Balance of Jabs and Olive Branches: The number of jabs directed at the GOP and mentions of common ground will be closely monitored as a measure of the president's approach to bipartisanship.

3. Forgettable Rhetoric: State of the Union addresses are often forgotten, with their focus on policy laundry lists rather than great oratory.

4. Policy Priorities: The president may address a range of issues, including U.S. policy in Syria, Iran's nuclear program, and the security of U.S. diplomatic posts. Domestically, he may address poverty in the United States and issues such as U.S. use of unmanned drones, the legal rationale for targeting Americans, gay rights, women's rights, climate change, and education.

5. First Lady's Fashion: Michelle Obama's outfit has become a surprise highlight of the night, with her 2009 gun-themed dress causing a stir. This year, speculation is high about whether she will bare her arms again.

Given the importance of the State of the Union address as a platform for the president to outline his priorities, it is expected that he will use the opportunity to address his critics and respond to his base on the issues mentioned above. The speech is also expected to focus heavily on economic themes.

Title: Obama Administration's Healthcare Reform: Grandfather Clause and Policy Cancellations

Article:

In a significant turn of events, the Obama Administration's health reform plan, known as Obamacare, has faced criticism over a promise made by President Obama during the health reform's promotion. The promise, "If you like your health care plan, you can keep your health care plan. Period," has been called into question as critics argue that it was unlikely to be true at the time and is now being proven false.

The controversy stems from a "grandfathering" provision in the Obamacare regulations. Initially, the provision allowed most Americans to keep their insurance as long as their policies were in effect as of March 23, 2010. However, the Department of Health and Human Services later narrowed this provision by stating that if any part of a policy was significantly changed since that date, the policy would not be grandfathered.

Buried in Obamacare regulations from July 2010 is an estimate that because of normal turnover in the individual insurance market, "40 to 67 percent" of customers would not be able to keep their policy. The regulations further state that because many policies will have been changed since the key date, "the percentage of individual market policies losing grandfather status in a given year exceeds the 40 to 67 percent range."

The Obama Administration's assurance that Americans could keep their health insurance plans under Obamacare now appears to have been misleading, as the Administration's own regulations led to the cancellation of many policies and the implementation of more expensive ones. The reason for these changes is the Obama Administration's new minimum guidelines for what insurance must cover.

One individual affected by these changes is Jacqueline Proctor, a 60-year-old Californian. Her new insurance plan must cover childcare and maternity care, services she will never use. Proctor's new insurance will cost "more than twice as much" as her old insurance.

The Obama Administration's rhetoric that the new insurance is better may not resonate with individuals like Proctor, who are facing increased costs for services they do not require. The Administration's repeated assurance that Americans could keep their health insurance plans under Obamacare, even in recent debates with Mitt Romney, now appears to have been misleading.

Title: Judges' Skepticism Toward Flynn Case Dismissal Raises Questions for Justice Department

Article:

In a three-judge panel hearing on Friday, the skepticism of Judges Henderson and Rao towards the dismissal of charges against former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn was evident. Both judges have previously shown a tendency to interpret the law in a manner favorable to the Trump administration in other politically charged cases.

The assignment of Judges Henderson and Rao to the panel had raised the possibility that Mr. Flynn might prevail, despite many legal experts questioning the timing and validity of Ms. Powell's request for immediate intervention by the appeals court at this stage. However, all three judges seemed to agree that Judge Sullivan had the power to hold a hearing.

The Justice Department, represented by the deputy solicitor general, Jeffrey Wall, argued that this development would be detrimental to the executive branch. He described a brief submitted by former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, George B. H. Fisher, as a "polemic," and expressed concern about having to defend against it. The department may be required to disclose internal deliberations, including the reason why no career prosecutor signed the motion to dismiss the charge against Mr. Flynn, in a potentially politicized atmosphere, according to Mr. Wall.

"There are real harms here, and if we know what has to happen at the end of the day, with all respect, district court should be directed to do it now rather than have some unnecessary and very harmful proceedings," he stated.

The arguments on Friday did not provide a clear answer regarding the consequences if Judge Sullivan were to reject the Justice Department's motion to dismiss the case. Judge Wilkinson did not take a position on whether a judge could sentence a defendant who had pleaded guilty, even if the executive branch no longer wanted to pursue the case.

Judge Henderson, however, seemed to express a skeptical view of Mr. Gleeson's brief, suggesting that Judge Sullivan may have chosen an "intemperate" person to critique the Justice Department's move. She added that the judge may declare Mr. Gleeson's brief "over the top" and grant the dismissal motion in the future. The outcome of the case remains uncertain.

Title: Senate Republicans' Healthcare Bill Fails as Three Senators Vote Against Repeal

Article:

The Republican-backed healthcare bill, also known as the "Plan B," has failed in the Senate after three Republican Senators, including Lisa Murkowski, voted against the repeal of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). This development was announced by journalist Laura Litvan on July 18, 2017.

The failure of the bill marks the third "no" vote, with more expected to follow. The aftermath of this failure is expected to lead to a circular firing squad within the Republican party, as conservatives criticize Senators who are distancing themselves from their 2015 vote, moderates blame conservatives for sinking the previous bill, and various factions express their discontent with the leadership.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is reportedly planning to hold a "motion to proceed" vote on the 2015 repeal bill, despite the expected political backlash. This move could result in a significant number of GOP members refusing to allow a piece of legislation they previously voted to pass onto the floor.

The purpose of McConnell's decision to hold the vote is unclear. Some speculate that he may be using this as leverage to revive the compromise bill, while others suggest he is frustrated with his recalcitrant conference and wants to subject his members to tough votes. Alternatively, the vote could be intended to demonstrate the inability of Republican-only solutions to pass, thereby necessitating bipartisan cooperation.

In a related development, West Virginia Democrat Joe Manchin has initiated bipartisan healthcare talks with former governors turned senators, as reported by Sam Stein. However, the anti-conservative demands from even the most moderate of Democrats could pose challenges in these negotiations.

The breadth of this failure is impressive, even by GOP standards, and the assignment of blame is not expected to go the way President Trump desires. The Republicans' inability to pass a pressing policy concern and a perennial campaign promise will not go unnoticed by voters. Washing their hands of the situation is not likely to be an acceptable course of action for the Republicans.

Title: President Trump and Vice President Pence Celebrate Christmas with U.S. Troops Overseas

Article:

On Christmas Day, President Donald Trump held a video teleconference with U.S. troops stationed around the world, including in Kuwait, Qatar, Guantanamo Bay, and on the USS Sampson. The call also included troops from various bases. Vice President Mike Pence made a surprise visit to Afghanistan last week.

During the call, President Trump expressed his gratitude to the troops for their service and wished them a Merry Christmas. He said, "I just want to wish everybody a very, very merry Christmas. We say Merry Christmas, again, very, very proudly. Very, very merry Christmas. We’re going to have a great year, an incredible year. I’m thrilled to bring season's greetings on behalf of the first lady and our entire family, and most importantly, on behalf of the American people."

He continued, "As we celebrate this most precious holiday, we’re grateful for each of you who spend this Christmas away from our families and defend all of our families, our freedom, and our flag. Every American heart is thankful, and we’re asking God to watch over you and to watch over your families."

The media covering his initial remarks was ushered out of the room so the President could have a personal conversation with the individuals on the call.

Vice President Mike Pence tweeted on Christmas Eve, "For all who, in the coming days, will look to a manger & claim the promise announced on a Holy Night of peace on Earth & good will toward men-from the First Family, my family & families across America: Merry Christmas."

On December 23, Vice President Pence made a surprise visit to Afghanistan.

Title: Polls Show Negative Perception of Hillary Clinton in Key Swing States

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the Democratic front-runner for the 2016 presidential election, is facing a negative perception in key swing states, according to recent polls. In Colorado, Iowa, and Virginia, a majority of voters have an unfavorable view of Clinton, with 56 percent of Colorado voters, 56 percent of Iowa voters, and 50 percent of Virginia voters holding an unfavorable opinion of her. This negative sentiment is comparable to that of Donald Trump, the most polarizing Republican candidate in the poll.

In Colorado and Iowa, Clinton's unfavorable scores are close to those of Donald Trump, perhaps the most polarizing candidate on the trail and the Republican with the worst favorability numbers in the poll. By comparison, more voters rated Scott Walker and Marco Rubio favorably than unfavorably in all three states. Jeb Bush, meanwhile, was viewed more unfavorably in Colorado and Iowa, but did not have any gaps the size of Clinton's.

These negative perceptions extend beyond swing states, as well. In a June nationwide CNN poll, 57 percent of voters said they did not find Clinton trustworthy. In several swing states, voters do not think she is honest or trustworthy. In a Quinnipiac poll from June, voters in three other states—Florida, Ohio, and Pennsylvania—were also more likely to find her untrustworthy than trustworthy.

The negative sentiment towards Clinton is not only due to her unfavorable ratings but also to a barrage of news stories generated since the start of the campaign. Her use of a private email server during her time at State, questions about whether Clinton Foundation donors were seeking political clout, and her evasion of the press have all contributed to a narrative of a candidate who is being less than transparent.

For her part, Clinton has said she believes voters can see through these narratives and still lend her their support. "At the end of the day, I think voters sort it all out," she told CNN in June. "I have great confidence. I trust the American voter. So I trust the American voter 100 percent, because I think the American voter will weigh these kinds of accusations."

However, Clinton's campaign is not only facing a trustworthiness problem. Quinnipiac has found that in six swing states, voters are either split or negative on whether they believe Clinton cares about their needs and problems.

One pollster suggested that Clinton should have realistic expectations about changing people's minds and focus on her strengths. "At this point, for somebody like Hillary Clinton, who's been in the public eye for so long, you're just not going to change some of these perceptions," said G. Evans Witt, principal and CEO at Princeton Survey Research Associates. "You're not going to move the Republican numbers on Hillary Clinton as trustworthy. That means there's only a limited range for improvement, no matter what she does."

One bright spot for Clinton is her leadership skills, which pop up in state after state in these polls. Even when voters view her unfavorably, think she does not understand their problems, or say she is untrustworthy, they also view her as a strong leader. Focusing on her leadership strength could be a way for Clinton to clear a likability (or trustworthiness) hurdle.

Democratic strategist Craig Varoga suggested that Clinton should emphasize her leadership credentials and skills to make people feel that she is more trustworthy and authentic. "The campaign should use that leadership as an opportunity to speak bluntly and authentically about the issues that actually matter to people in the country," Varoga said. "If she speaks—not demagogically, but speaks bluntly—I think there will be a very positive reaction to that."

Varoga added that there is one other important thing to remember when looking at any poll about how voters feel about 2016 candidates. "This is in many ways a completely lousy time to run for president," he said. "Frustration with politicians is off the charts, and that means well-established candidates like Clinton and Republican Jeb Bush are facing a testier electorate than candidates in previous races have faced."

Overall, the polls suggest that Hillary Clinton faces a negative perception in key swing states, with voters questioning her trustworthiness and her ability to understand their needs and problems. However, her leadership skills are a bright spot, and focusing on these strengths could help her clear a likability (or trustworthiness) hurdle.

Title: Conservative Political Action Conference Kicks Off with a Dozen Potential Republican Presidential Candidates

Article:

The annual Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) commenced this week, a three-day event hosted by the American Conservative Union. The event will feature a dozen or so potential Republican presidential candidates, including Jeb Bush, Scott Walker, Rand Paul, Chris Christie, and Ted Cruz.

According to a series of reports on political polarization published last year, 9% of the public overall identifies as consistently conservative, with 20% of Republicans and Republican leaners falling into this category. Most of the remaining Republicans and leaners were either "mostly conservative" (33%) or had a mixture of liberal and conservative views (37%).

Here are five facts drawn from a package of reports about consistent conservatives:

1. Consistent conservatives participate in politics at higher rates than most other ideological groups. Half of consistent conservatives said they had contacted an elected official within the past two years, the highest level among the five groups. This figure was 28% for all Americans. Consistent conservatives also ranked high on other measurements of political engagement, such as donating money (26%), attending campaign events (24%), and volunteering on a campaign (12%).

2. Conservatives had outsize influence in the November midterm elections. Although consistent conservatives make up only about 9% of the total adult population, they vote at higher rates than people elsewhere on the ideological spectrum. Consequently, a report published a few weeks before the 2014 midterms estimated that consistent conservatives would make up 17% of the November 2014 electorate.

3. Conservatives prefer nonurban lifestyles. The research found an overwhelming preference among the most conservative Americans for nonurban lifestyles. 41% of consistent conservatives said they would live in a rural area if they could live anywhere in the U.S., and 35% picked a small town.

4. When it comes to raising children, conservatives prioritize responsibility, faith, and hard work. When asked about the three most important traits to teach children, 61% of consistent conservatives cited "being responsible," and about as many (59%) identified religious faith as particularly important; hard work was chosen by 44%.

5. Conservatives gravitate toward Fox News. A separate Pew Research report on polarization and media habits found that 47% of consistent conservatives (and 31% of people with mostly conservative views) cited Fox News as their main source for news about government and politics; no other news source came close. Additionally, 88% of consistent conservatives said they trusted Fox News – by far the highest level of trust by any ideological group of any single news source among the 36 they asked about.

Title: Obama Announces Federal Intervention to Lower College Costs and Rate Schools Based on Educational Value

Article:

In a two-day bus tour through New York and Pennsylvania, President Obama announced on Thursday a broader role for the federal government in lowering college costs. The plan involves rating schools based on their educational value and tying taxpayer money to school performance.

Speaking at the State University of New York at Buffalo, the president proposed capping student loan repayments at 10 percent of future paychecks and implementing measures to ensure students attending school on federal grants remain in school by doling out the money in installments.

The president's announcements are part of an effort to revitalize his domestic agenda, which has been stalled due to budget and partisan battles on Capitol Hill. The plan aims to make higher education more affordable and accessible, with the federal government and colleges currently engaged in a financial arms race, according to the president.

Beginning in 2015, the Education Department will compile and release a scorecard of colleges that provide the best value. The formula will consider affordability, productivity, and access. Affordability will be measured by tuition costs versus the number of students taking loans or on scholarship. Productivity will be measured by graduation rates and the earnings of graduates. Access will be measured by the percentage of students who receive federal aid.

By 2018, after the scorecard has been refined, federal funding will be tailored to reward schools that accept low-income students and perform well according to the rest of the formula. The plan also encourages colleges and universities to explore new avenues of education, such as lower-cost online courses or awarding degrees based on learning outcomes rather than the number of classes taken.

Congress will need to approve the president's plan to dock schools' federal funds for poor performance on the Education Department scorecard, and lawmakers will also need to pass legislation to cap student loan repayments at 10 percent of postgraduate incomes. The Higher Education Act, which is due to expire at the end of this year, will need to be debated and reauthorized.

Republican lawmakers have expressed mixed reactions to the president's plan. Rep. John Kline, Minnesota Republican and chairman of the House Committee on Education and the Workforce, agrees with the idea of promoting innovation among colleges but finds the proposed ranking system "arbitrary" and potentially stifling. Sen. Chuck Grassley, Iowa Republican, sees areas where his party can work with the president to control costs but urges the president to call on colleges to limit executive salaries. Grassley also emphasizes the importance of helping the consumer side of the equation, stating that students and parents becoming savvy shoppers would force colleges to rein in rising costs to compete for students.

Title: CNN Announces Seven-Hour Climate Change Town Hall

Article:

CNN has announced a seven-hour climate change town hall, scheduled for September 4th. The extended duration aims to provide each of the 10 participating Democratic presidential candidates with 40 minutes to discuss their plans to address climate change.

The town hall will be moderated by CNN hosts Wolf Blitzer, Erin Burnett, Anderson Cooper, Chris Cuomo, and Don Lemon. The candidates' appearance times are as follows:

- Former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro will be interviewed by CNN's Wolf Blitzer at 5 p.m. ET.
- Businessman Andrew Yang, who will also be interviewed by Blitzer, will come on at 5:40 p.m.
- California Sen. Kamala Harris will be interviewed by CNN's Erin Burnett at 6:20 p.m.
- Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar, who will also be interviewed by Burnett, will appear at 7 p.m.
- Former Vice President Joe Biden will be interviewed by CNN's Anderson Cooper at 8 p.m.
- Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, who will also be interviewed by Cooper, will be on at 8:40 p.m.
- Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren will be interviewed by CNN's Chris Cuomo at 9:20 p.m.
- South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg, who will also be interviewed by Cuomo at 10 p.m.
- Former Rep. Beto O'Rourke will appear with CNN's Don Lemon at 10:40 p.m.
- New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker will also be interviewed by Lemon and will come on at 11:20 p.m.

According to previous CNN polls, 96 percent of Democratic voters want "aggressive" action taken to address climate change. The town hall was announced after the Democratic National Committee voted last week not to host a debate focused on the issue.

It is worth noting that CNN's decision to host a seven-hour town hall has been met with skepticism, as many viewers may find such a lengthy event challenging to engage with, given that three-hour-long debates are already considered long. However, the network's ratings have reportedly been declining, and this event may serve as an attempt to revive their viewership.

Title: Sen. Tom Coburn Criticizes 2013 as One of the Worst Years for the U.S. Republic

Article:

Sen. Tom Coburn (R-OK) has criticized 2013 as potentially one of the least productive years in Washington's history and "one of the worst for the republic." In a piece published in The Wall Street Journal, Coburn argued that the rule of law gave way to the rule of rulers during the year.

Coburn cited the disastrous rollout of President Obama's health care law and the president's broken promise, "if you like your health care plan, you can keep it," which was labeled as the "Lie of the Year" by the Tampa Bay Times' PolitiFact.

The senator wrote that President Obama's actions revealed a conformity to the political culture he vowed to reform as a presidential candidate. Coburn also pointed to the administration's unilateral, extralegal actions, such as delaying the employer mandate for a year and ignoring immigration and border-security laws.

Coburn also noted Congress's 6 percent approval rating and wrote that its most significant action this year was Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's move to change the chamber's filibuster rules. Coburn also criticized the Senate for ignoring the Constitution and appointing people without confirmation.

The senator also pointed to his annual Wastebook report, which showed the federal government funding the study of romance novels, providing military benefits to the Fort Hood shooter, and helping the State Department buy Facebook fans.

Coburn concluded that the coming year presents an opportunity for Americans who hope for better governance, stating, "Despite Washington's dysfunction, 'We the People' still call the shots and can demand a course correction." He ended with a call to action, saying, "If you don't like the rulers you have, you don't have to keep them."

Title: Deadly Easter Sunday Bombings in Sri Lanka Kill Nearly 300, Trigger Nationwide Curfew and Social Media Block

Article:

Nine coordinated bombings in churches, luxury hotels, and other sites across Sri Lanka on Easter Sunday resulted in the deaths of nearly 300 people and left hundreds more injured. The deadliest violence since the end of the country's civil war a decade ago, the attacks occurred primarily in and around Colombo, the capital.

Defense Minister Ruwan Wijewardena described the blasts as a terrorist attack by religious extremists, and police reported the arrest of 13 suspects, though no immediate claim of responsibility has been made. Wijewardena stated that most of the bombings were believed to have been suicide attacks.

The explosions caused ceilings to collapse and windows to shatter, resulting in the deaths of worshippers and hotel guests in a series of scenes filled with smoke, soot, blood, broken glass, screams, and wailing alarms. Many victims were carried out of blood-spattered pews.

Bhanuka Harischandra, a 24-year-old founder of a tech marketing company from Colombo, was en route to the Shangri-La Hotel for a meeting when it was bombed. "People were being dragged out," he said. "People didn't know what was going on. It was panic mode."

Most of those killed were Sri Lankan nationals. However, the three bombed hotels and one of the churches, St. Anthony's Shrine, are frequented by foreign tourists. Sri Lanka's Foreign Ministry reported that at least 27 foreigners from various countries were among the deceased.

In response to the attacks, the Sri Lankan government imposed a nationwide curfew from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. and blocked most social media platforms, including Facebook and YouTube, to curtail the spread of false information and ease tension in the country of approximately 21 million people.

Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe expressed concern that the massacre could lead to instability in Sri Lanka and vowed to "vest all necessary powers with the defense forces" to take action against those responsible.

Cardinal Malcolm Ranjith, the Archbishop of Colombo, called on the Sri Lankan government to "mercilessly" punish those responsible "because only animals can behave like that."

According to police spokesman Ruwan Gunasekara, at least 290 people were killed, and at least 500 were wounded. Gunasekara also reported that police found a safe house and a van used by the attackers.

The scale of the bloodshed recalls the worst days of Sri Lanka's 26-year civil war, during which the Tamil Tigers, a rebel group from the ethnic Tamil minority, sought independence from the Buddhist-majority country. The Tamils are Hindu, Muslim, and Christian.

Sri Lanka, located off the southern tip of India, is about 70% Buddhist. Scattered incidents of anti-Christian harassment have occurred in recent years, but nothing on the scale of what happened on Sunday. There is no history of violent Muslim militants in Sri Lanka, but tensions have been running high more recently between hard-line Buddhist monks and Muslims.

Two Muslim groups in Sri Lanka condemned the church attacks, as did countries around the world, and Pope Francis expressed condolences at the end of his traditional Easter Sunday blessing in Rome.

Six nearly simultaneous blasts took place in the morning at the shrine and the Cinnamon Grand, Shangri-La, and Kingsbury hotels in Colombo, as well as at two churches outside Colombo. A few hours later, two more blasts occurred just outside Colombo, one of them at a guesthouse, where two people were killed, and the other near an overpass.

Three police officers were killed during a search at a suspected safe house on the outskirts of Colombo when its occupants apparently detonated explosives to prevent arrest, authorities said.

The Shangri-La's second-floor restaurant was gutted, with the ceiling and windows blown out. Loose wires hung down, and tables were overturned in the blackened space. From outside the police cordon, three bodies could be seen covered in white sheets.

Foreign tourists hurriedly used their cellphones to text family and loved ones that they were okay. Visitors from around the world come to Sri Lanka to see elephants, tea plantations, ancient Buddhist monuments, and other sights.

"I had a sense that the country was turning the corner, and in particular, those in the tourism industry were hopeful for the future," said tourist Peter Kelson, a technology manager from Sydney. "Apart from the tragedy of the immediate victims of the bombings, I worry that these terrible events will set the country back significantly."

Locals who work in Sri Lanka's vital tourism industry were shocked and upset by the bloodshed.

"After so many years, we've started again," said Gamini Francis, 56, a long-time hotel worker. "A lot of people are going to lose their jobs. 100% sure. It's tragic. Crazy people killing innocent people."

Sri Lankan forces defeated the Tamil Tiger rebels in 2009, ending a civil war that took over 100,000 lives, with both sides accused of grave human rights violations.

Harischandra, who witnessed the attack at the Shangri-La Hotel, said there was "a lot of tension" after the bombings, but added, "We've been through these kinds of situations before." He noted that his social media feed was flooded with photos of people standing in long lines to give blood.

Title: Shake Shack Executives Call for Improvements to Paycheck Protection Program Amid Confusion

Article:

Shake Shack Inc.'s top executives, including CEO Randy Garutti and founder Danny Meyer, have called for improvements to the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) following the return of a $10 million loan the burger chain received. The PPP is part of the $2.2 trillion CARES Act, aimed at providing financial assistance to small businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

In a joint letter posted to LinkedIn, Garutti and Meyer expressed concerns about the application process, stating, "The onus was placed on each business to figure out how, when, or even if to apply. The 'PPP' came with no user manual and it was extremely confusing."

According to a Treasury Department information sheet, the PPP is open to any business with 500 or fewer employees. Shake Shack, with an average of about 45 workers per location, has 189 restaurants in the U.S. and nearly 8,000 workers.

The coronavirus pandemic has reportedly caused $1.5 million in weekly operating losses for Shake Shack, as stated in the letter. According to SunTrust Robinson Humphrey analysts, 84% of Shake Shack's company-owned restaurants are in counties with at least 1,000 confirmed COVID-19 cases, with none of the company's locations in a county with fewer than 50 cases.

Danny Meyer, founder of Shake Shack, is also the CEO of Union Square Hospitality Group, which operates high-end restaurants such as Gramercy Tavern, Union Square Café, and Maialino. The business had more than 2,000 employees who were laid off when restaurants closed on March 13.

The executives suggest more funding and "some necessary tweaks" to the program, such as assigning a local bank to each applicant to avoid issues that arise if a restaurant doesn't have a pre-existing loan or banking relationship. The Small Business Administration announced that the program ran out of money last Thursday.

The National Restaurant Association has asked Congress for $240 billion in relief, stating that 40% of restaurants have closed, some permanently, and eight million workers have been furloughed. Before the pandemic, restaurants employed more than 12.2 million workers in the U.S.

The NRA estimates $240 billion in restaurant losses by the end of the year.

Title: The Evolution of John McCain's Political Career and the Dissolution of His Fan Club

Article:

The dissolution of John McCain's old fan club, once known as McCainiacs, has led to the scattering of his supporters among various political groups, including neocons, deplorables, Clintonites, and Bernie Bros. This shift is not as unusual as it may seem, as the rebellion McCain represented in 1999 and 2000 was a reflection of the desires of the American public during that time.

In the late 1990s, Americans generally supported the policies of Bill Clinton, if not the man himself. Republicans, in their rhetoric, were careful to appeal to the center. Issues such as immigration, war, and trade were divisive, but not to the extent they would become. The jobs were not yet gone, and the events of 9/11 and the bank collapse had not occurred.

Rebelling against the G.O.P. establishment in 1999 meant defying the donor class on taxes and the religious right on social issues. However, by 2016, rebelling against the establishment meant defying the donor class on trade and immigration and siding with the religious right on social issues. McCain, who had become part of the establishment, saw his earlier fans sort themselves accordingly.

If McCain, at times, seemed bitter, these immense shifts may have contributed to his bitterness. Politicians, more than most people, learn to cope with swings in the public mood, but those who have enjoyed a period of marked resonance, when everything they say triggers sympathetic reverberations with the masses, have it hard when that stretch runs out. McCain was going fairly strong in 2004, but the formula of 2000 could no longer work. What remained instead were unpalatable choices. He could give up on a presidential run, or he could make nice with the Republican Party. McCain chose the latter, and from 2004 on, he became a loyal party member, lining up behind his party and president.

Unfortunately, this was like chaining oneself to Three Mile Island. Both Bush and his party were becoming ballot-box poison. By the time McCain finally secured a presidential nomination in 2008, it was at exactly the wrong time. What everybody wanted—peace, a break from Bush-era policies, and a fair and sensible way out of a financial crash—McCain couldn't offer. What he could offer, resolute leadership in war, nobody wanted.

The campaign that year showed McCain at his best and worst. To the consternation of many Republicans, he eschewed all advice to hit Barack Obama for his association with radical preacher Jeremiah Wright. He made a proposal to the Obama campaign that the two candidates do 10 town halls together, and the idea, while self-serving, was still wonderful. McCain also stuck to his pledge, one that was broken by Obama, to use public financing for his campaign. At the same time, McCain shocked many of his admirers by picking as his running mate Alaska Governor Sarah Palin, someone exceptionally unsuited to the role. Palin's virtues (sense of humor, love of country, informality) were entirely inadequate in the face of her vices (insecurity, ignorance, self-deception), all of which were brought out under the glare of a national campaign. It made McCain look reckless and cynical.

After 2008, McCain managed to frustrate nearly everyone. Democrats became enraged when McCain joined his fellow Republicans in partisan politics to weaken Obama. Republicans became enraged when McCain voted to confirm nominees or pass immigration amnesties. Because he broke ranks, because he was independent at one moment yet partisan the next, people tried to impose defamatory theories on him to make the pieces line up. Some Democrats found it easiest just to call McCain a phony and a hack. Some Republicans found it easiest to say McCain was actuated by sanctimony and spite. In the far-rightish world, you could even read lengthy arguments that McCain had been a stooge of the Viet Cong. Each theory had very little predictive power, however. A simpler explanation is that McCain, while at times expedient or partisan, preserved more independence of mind than is customary in his trade.

Title: New York Primary Results Widen Leads for Trump and Clinton in 2016 Presidential Race

Article:

In a significant turn of events, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton have secured victories in the New York primary, marking a comeback for both candidates after their losses in Wisconsin two weeks prior. The primary, held in their home state, saw each candidate garner approximately three-fifths of the vote, significantly widening their leads among pledged delegates.

The victories in New York have opened a pathway for both Trump and Clinton to potentially secure their nominations before the conventions in July. In recent weeks, doubts had arisen as both front-runners seemed to lose momentum, with rivals promoting the prospect of open conventions in both Cleveland and Philadelphia.

However, after New York, the pressure is on the challengers, who will find fewer opportunities to narrow the delegate gap with each passing week. The next significant opportunity to halt either Trump or Clinton may be next week, when Pennsylvania, Maryland, Connecticut, Rhode Island, and Delaware hold the next-to-last round of multistate primaries. A total of 144 delegates will be available for Republicans and 392 for Democrats.

A sweep for either front-runner next week would make stopping Trump or Clinton not only daunting but mathematically infeasible. Even the chances of a second ballot at either convention would go from forbidding to remote.

Donald Trump was declared the winner shortly after polls closed, tallying 60 percent of the statewide vote. When counting ended, Trump was poised to claim all 14 at-large delegates and about 75 of the 81 delegates awarded by congressional district.

Hillary Clinton did almost as well as Trump in percentage terms, with 58 percent, while she outpolled Trump in the raw vote by nearly half a million. She did not dominate the delegate count quite as much as Trump, but only because the Democrats divide their delegates proportionally—both statewide and district by district. She took home an estimated 135 new delegates to Sanders' 104. She already had 39 of the state's 44 superdelegates (who are free to change their minds).

The outcomes may have been equally discouraging for challengers in both parties. Ted Cruz and Bernie Sanders, winners in Wisconsin and in a handful of caucus states that lent them momentum in the weeks since mid-March, stumbled badly in the Empire State. Both had hoped to at least limit the damage they would suffer on Trump's and Clinton's turf, while looking to friendlier venues ahead.

However, the front-runners ran roughshod across the landscape. Cruz finished a weak third with scarcely 1 vote in 7, earning zero delegates. New York Republicans preferred Ohio governor John Kasich, who got 1 vote in 4 statewide and gained perhaps three or more delegates (his first since he won his home state a month earlier).

Bruising as the loss was for Cruz, it may have been just as bitter for Sanders on the Democratic side. Clinton only increased her delegate lead by about 30 in the crucial category of pledged delegates. But the real pain for her rival was the opportunity cost. Sanders' team had given it their all in New York, outspending Clinton on TV and hoping visibly for an upset—or at least a narrow loss that could be spun as a moral victory.

Looking ahead, Trump, with his delegate lead growing again, can look to another stretch of promising ground next week. Polls give him an edge in all five contests, with 144 delegates at stake. A sweep would greatly enhance his chances of reaching the majority of delegates needed for a first-ballot nomination (1,237).

There is an active "stop Trump" movement, both in social media and in the higher circles of the GOP establishment. Senators seeking re-election in swing states have been advised to stay away from Trump and even to skip the convention.

Cruz has been successful in certain states in placing sympathizers in delegate slots that are committed to Trump on the first ballot. The individuals who occupy those slots would be expected to defect from Trump on later ballots.

However, all that will be moot if Trump can get close enough to the magic number that a few pre-convention deals might well put him over the top. After a win like he scored in New York, such a "last mile" strategy looks increasingly plausible.

For her part, Clinton was sounding equally sanguine just blocks away, telling a throng of her supporters that the race was "in the homestretch and victory is in sight." She did not say it, but Sanders now needs to win 60 percent of the delegates in every contest remaining—just to overtake Clinton in pledged delegates. He has no discernible path to turning around her advantage in superdelegates.

Neither candidate's race is over yet. Weeks and months of pre-convention politicking remain. But after next week, it is possible that—for one or both of the front-runners—it will no longer be far from over.

Title: Media Reaction to State of the Union Addresses: Obama and Rubio Compared

Article:

In a comparison of the media's reactions to the State of the Union addresses delivered by President Barack Obama and Senator Marco Rubio, the coverage of the two speeches revealed stark differences. If President Obama's speech could be described as a Christmas list of government investments, Senator Rubio's response was met with criticism, particularly regarding a water bottle incident.

President Obama's State of the Union address on Tuesday night outlined a series of government spending initiatives, using the term "invest" 11 times. The media generally praised Obama's speech, with MSNBC's Ed Schultz calling it "a stunning speech tonight," CNN's Jessica Yellin describing it as "relaxed and confident," and Politico summarizing the media's response as "State of the Union reaction: Media gives Obama thumbs up."

Senator Rubio's response, however, was met with a different response. During his speech, Rubio reached off-screen to grab a bottle of water and take a drink. This action was the focus of much media attention, with MSNBC and CNN discussing the incident, as did numerous left-wing pundits. The Daily Kos founder, Markos Moulitas, described the incident as "The sip of water laughed at world wide."

The media's reaction to Rubio's water bottle incident was harsh, with MSNBC host Rachel Maddow commenting on his "big reach for the water glass," and Chris Matthews describing the speech as "tinker toys" and "primitive." Former RNC head and MSNBC analyst Michael Steele also criticized the water bottle, stating, "I did not like the water bottle."

CNN was not much better, with anchor Chris Cuomo making a reaching joke and even mimicking Rubio grabbing for the bottle. The incident was also replayed multiple times, like a Super Bowl touchdown.

In contrast, President Obama's speech received far nicer treatment. Anchor Wolf Blitzer described the most powerful and emotional moment of the president's speech as coming near the end, when victims of gun violence stood and cheered and shed tears in the House gallery.

On Twitter, CNN media critic Howard Kurtz wrote, "Twitter going off on Marco Rubio water bottle. Really dousing him," while E.J. Dionne, a Washington Post liberal columnist, Tweeted, "Poor Marco Rubio: It was the gulp that roared. TV can be a cruel medium #sotu." The Nation's Greg Mitchell described it as the "Return of the Swig Party."

The media's focus on the water bottle incident overshadowed the twin realities of the Obama speech - taxes and spending. Former GOP presidential candidate Newt Gingrich told CNN that it was "the most pro-government speech since Lyndon Johnson." Johnson, for those who lack Gingrich's grasp of history, made his mark expanding government with his "Great Society" programs.

For Rubio's part, he reminded viewers to blame Obama for the sequester and the cuts "were his idea in the first place." The senator also highlighted Obama's call for a sudden huge hike in the minimum wage to $9 an hour, which would mean a 24 percent hike from the current $7.25.

The media's reaction to the two speeches highlights the differing perspectives and biases that can influence coverage of political events. While President Obama's speech was generally praised, Senator Rubio's response, particularly the water bottle incident, was met with harsh criticism. The focus on the water bottle incident overshadowed the substance of Rubio's speech and the twin realities of Obama's speech - taxes and spending.

Title: Romney Accuses Media of Bias at Al Smith Dinner, Scholar Claims Media Protects Obama

Article:

In a joking manner at the Al Smith dinner, Mitt Romney took on the press, stating that some in the media have a certain bias in their reporting. "Now I never suggest that the press is biased," he said, "I recognize that they have their job to do, and I have my job to do. My job is to lay out a positive vision for the future of the country, and their job is to make sure no one else finds out about it."

Romney went on to comment on the media's portrayal of events, citing examples of headlines that he found to be biased. "Let's just say that some in the media have a certain way of looking at things," he said. "When suddenly I pulled ahead in some of the major polls, what was the headline? 'Polls Show Obama Leading from Behind.' And I've already seen early reports from tonight's dinner. Headline: 'Obama Embraced by Catholics. Romney Dines with Rich People.'"

Meanwhile, Professor Paul Kengor, author of the book "The Communist," told Breitbart News that the media's job is to protect President Obama, not to expose him. Kengor's book exposes Obama's relationship with Communist Party operative Frank Marshall Davis.

Frank Marshall Davis was revealed to be the subject of Kengor's book in July 2007, when a Communist Party writer named Gerald Horne made the disclosure. Blogger Trevor Loudon wrote about the connection the same year, and AIM confirmed the identification of "Frank" as Frank Marshall Davis on February 18, 2008, in a column titled "Obama's Communist Mentor." Davis's 600-page FBI file was released in August of that year, before the election.

When asked by Breitbart News if any mainstream media journalists have contacted him about his definitive and exhaustive analysis of Davis and his relationship to Obama, Kengor replied, "Are you kidding? No way. Not a chance." He added, "They aren't real journalists. They're political partisans first and journalists second. They're not honest, or they delude themselves on a grand scale. They've sacrificed their noble profession to an ignoble political ideology."

The Romney campaign has decided not to attack media bias, even though liberal media strategies of distortion and omission can cost a Republican candidate critical voter support and in Romney's case guarantee an Obama re-election victory on November 6.

Tim Groseclose, author of "Left Turn: How Liberal Media Bias Distorts the American Mind," told AIM in an interview with Roger Aronoff that the leftward bias of the media has shifted the political quotient of the average American by about 20 points on a scale of 100, in terms of conditioning the public to accept the Democratic Party, its candidates, and policies. This translates potentially into millions of votes.

At the AIM "ObamaNation" conference on September 21, pollster Pat Caddell urged Romney to openly run against "two organizations" - the Democratic Party and the "mainstream media." He said the media have "made themselves a fundamental threat to the democracy, and, in my opinion, made themselves the enemy of the American people," because they hide information that is critical to making informed decisions in a democracy.

However, Romney told CBS News that he had no plans to challenge media bias. This approach reflects the influence of Romney adviser Ed Gillespie, who has said the campaign has a "no whining rule" about media coverage. "We just deal with the facts," he said.

GOP strategist and SuperPAC sponsor Karl Rove told a gathering of Republican donors that he has advised Romney and other Republicans not to attack Obama as a socialist or a left-winger because the charges would be met with denials. He urged a "respectful tone" toward the President.

Although the media and the Republican Party establishment do not want to deal with Kengor's book, Frank Marshall Davis is the subject of the Joel Gilbert DVD, "Dreams from My Real Father," being mailed to millions of households in the various swing states. The media are starting to take note of this. "Radical Anti-Obama DVD floods Florida mailboxes" is the headline over one story carried by a Florida television station.

While Gilbert's theory about Davis being Obama's real father is subject to discussion and debate, his film does cite factual data about Davis's relationship with Obama and notes the existence of the 600-page FBI file on Davis. If there is nothing to hide in this relationship, Paul Kengor told Breitbart News, then why did Obama himself delete the references to "Frank" in the audio version of his book, "Dreams from My Father"? "Obama narrates the audio version," Kengor notes. "The liberals feted him with a Grammy for his sterling narration. And the back cover of the audio states, 'This abridgment has been approved by the author.'"

Kengor said, "Frank appears in every section of the memoir, all three parts, starting in Hawaii and then when Obama thinks of him later in Africa, Europe, Chicago. It's not like Frank appears only on pages, say, 15-22. He appears throughout the text. It's eerie to be reading the book in hard cover, and listening simultaneously to the audio, and see and hear everything the same, line to line, sentence to sentence, paragraph after paragraph, page upon page, and then suddenly, on a dime, out of the blue, come upon a printed sentence or paragraph that mentions 'Frank' and—bam—the audio suddenly skips ahead. It's chilling. It's clearly deliberate. No question about it. It's clear concealment."

Cliff Kincaid is the Director of the AIM Center for Investigative Journalism, and can be contacted at [email protected] org.

Title: Italy Extends Nationwide Emergency Measures to Combat Coronavirus Outbreak

Article:

Italy has extended its emergency measures, which include travel restrictions and a ban on public gatherings, to the entire country. Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte announced the measures on Monday, urging citizens to stay home and seek permission for essential travel. The measures are aimed at protecting the most vulnerable, as Italy's coronavirus death toll jumped from 366 to 463 on Monday, making it the worst-hit country after China.

The number of confirmed infections also increased by 24% from Sunday, according to official figures. Cases of the virus have been confirmed in all 20 Italian regions. Mr. Conte emphasized the importance of staying at home, stating, "We're having an important growth in infections... and of deaths."

The prime minister described the measures as "I stay home," with people forbidden to gather in public. All sporting events, including football matches, are suspended nationwide. Schools and universities will remain closed until 3 April.

Only those with a valid work or family reason that cannot be postponed will be allowed to travel. Passengers departing on flights will have to justify themselves, as will all those who arrive by plane. There are controls at train stations to check the temperatures of passengers. Cruise ships are also forbidden to dock at various ports.

Earlier on Monday, seven inmates died amid riots at prisons across the country after authorities suspended all visits as part of attempts to control the spread of the disease. The trouble began in the northern city of Modena at the Sant'Anna prison, where at least two of the dead are believed to have lost their lives to drug overdoses after they raided a prison hospital for the heroin substitute methadone.

In other incidents, detainees set fire to a cell block, then climbed onto the roof through windows and started waving banners at San Vittore prison in Milan, while dozens of inmates broke out of a prison in the southern city of Foggia during protests. Nine are still missing. There were also riots at other prisons in northern Italy and at facilities in Naples and Rome.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that the threat of a pandemic is "very real." As of now, the number of infections worldwide is over 111,000, with about 3,890 deaths. In other developments, everyone arriving in Israel will be required to self-quarantine for 14 days, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced. Iran has reported 43 new deaths related to the disease in the past 24 hours. At least 237 people have died and 7,161 have been infected across the country since mid-February, although the real figures are believed to be far higher.

In Canada, the first death related to the virus has been confirmed, an elderly male patient in a care home in Vancouver, British Columbia. In France, Culture Minister Franck Riester has become the first member of the government to be infected with the virus. In the US, the number of confirmed cases now exceeds 500. A cruise ship carrying thousands of people who were stranded for days due to a coronavirus outbreak has docked at the port of Oakland, near San Francisco. Shares around the world had their worst day since the financial crisis amid concerns about the economic cost of the outbreak.

For further information or to speak to a BBC journalist, please contact us via the following methods: [contact information].

Title: Trump Administration Proposes Modest Shift Toward Merit-Based Immigration Policy

Article:

Last week, the Trump administration unveiled an immigration plan aimed at reshaping the United States' immigration policy, prioritizing merit-based immigration and high-skilled labor over family-based immigration. The plan, while a modest improvement over the administration's previous restrictive immigration policies, is far from comprehensive or sufficient.

The plan's central focus is a shift toward a "merit" system similar to those in place in Australia and Canada. The reform would increase skill-based immigration from 12 percent to 57 percent, while decreasing family-based and lottery-based immigration by 50 percent. This shift is expected to benefit employers seeking high-skilled workers, as the cap for H-1B visas (for temporary, skilled workers) and employment-based green cards has not increased for many years, while the U.S. workforce has grown by 38 million since these programs' inception.

During his testimony before the House Committee on Small Business, my colleague Daniel Griswold advised members of Congress that increasing the number of high-skilled workers is crucial for serving the booming economy, particularly the tech and healthcare industries, as well as future American businesses, large and small. Griswold suggests tripling the number of H-1B visas to 195,000 and doubling the 1990 cap of 140,000 employment-based green cards.

Griswold also recommends exempting spouses and minor children of the primary green card worker from the cap to preserve family units without taking away from the ability to attract more workers. Additionally, he suggests repealing the per-country quotas on green cards, which he argues counterproductively discriminate against immigrants based on their country of origin.

The Trump administration's plan maintains current immigration levels, which may seem counterintuitive given the need for more immigrants. However, this approach is better than the administration's previous proposals to cut legal immigration in half. The plan faces criticism for failing to enhance legal immigration of low-skilled workers, despite the benefits of importing labor, and for not addressing the issue of "Dreamers" and the current illegal population.

With the Democrats unwilling to give any proposals coming from the administration a chance on the House floor, including this one, the proposal is better understood as a political document than a serious legislative proposal. As such, it fails to be aspirational and implement a comprehensive and needed immigration plan. Yet, it should be commended for putting an end to the narrative about scaling back legal immigration.

Title: Comey Suggests Trump May Have Committed Indictable Offenses, Potential for Post-Presidency Indictment

Article:

In a CNN town-hall-style meeting on Thursday, former FBI Director James B. Comey suggested that President Donald Trump may have committed crimes that could lead to indictment once he leaves office. He stated that, were Trump not the president, he likely would already have been indicted.
