When asked by host Anderson Cooper whether Trump acted with corrupt intent to interfere with an ongoing investigation, Comey replied, "It sure looks that way." He based this judgment on his reading of special counsel Robert Mueller's report, particularly Trump's order to White House Counsel Don McGahn to fire Mueller.

When asked whether he agreed with an open letter from numerous federal prosecutors that Trump would already have been indicted on obstruction of justice charges if he were not the president, Comey was emphatic. He noted that it has been a longstanding Justice Department policy that a sitting president cannot be indicted.

Attorney General William P. Barr has stated that Mueller's decision not to charge Trump was not solely based on this policy. When the question of indicting a president arises, it poses an awkward question, according to Comey. He suggested that Mueller, in writing his report, seemed to be balancing Justice Department policy with building a factual record that could be used in other circumstances, such as Congress's power to impeach a president.

Contrary to his statements on Thursday that corrupt intent could be inferred about Trump for his actions, Comey declined to bring charges against Hillary Clinton because, he said, such intent could not be proven.

When asked whether Trump could be indicted in 2021 or 2025 when he is no longer president, Comey said that was a possibility. "The Justice Department will have to take a serious look at that," he said.

Comey also dismissed another defense of Trump—that the president, by definition, cannot obstruct justice by exercising his legitimate constitutional powers to run the executive branch. "The president is not above the law," he said, calling the theory pushed by, among others, Harvard law professor Alan Dershowitz "crazy and a recipe for lawlessness."

Title: Trump Claims Unbriefed on Alleged Russian Bounty Intelligence

Article:

President Donald Trump has claimed that he was not briefed on intelligence about a Russian unit offering bounties on American service members in Afghanistan because the U.S. intelligence community deemed the information not credible. Trump's statement came in a late-night tweet on Sunday, where he also suggested that the details of the intelligence, first reported by The New York Times on Friday, may have been fabricated by the media to make Republicans look bad.

Neither the White House nor the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) have directly addressed the credibility of the intelligence as described, but have disputed the Times' account that Trump was briefed on the information. Representatives for the ODNI and CIA did not immediately return requests for comment on Monday about the president's claim that intelligence officials informed him the information was deemed not credible.

White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany said on "Fox & Friends" on Monday that Congress would be briefed on the matter, without offering further details on who would participate in the briefing. McEnany did not comment on the details of the intelligence but suggested that it had not been deemed "verifiable and credible" in denying that Trump had been briefed on the information.

Trump's tweet on Sunday came shortly after The Washington Post reported that intelligence assessments concluded that the Russian payments offered to Taliban-linked militants led to the deaths of U.S. service members in Afghanistan.

The Times reported on Friday that the intelligence community concluded months ago that the Russian intelligence unit known as the GRU secretly offered payments to Taliban-linked militants for successful attacks on coalition forces in Afghanistan last year. The newspaper reported that Trump had been briefed on the intelligence and that officials had deliberated potential response options but that the White House had not authorized any further action.

The revelations have prompted criticism of Trump, who has been consistently scrutinized for his friendliness towards Russian President Vladimir Putin and resistance to taking firm action against Moscow over its interference in the 2016 presidential election.

"His entire presidency has been a gift to Putin, but this is beyond the pale," presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden said during a virtual town hall on Saturday. "It's betrayal of the most sacred duty we bear as a nation to protect and equip our troops when we send them into harm's way. It's a betrayal of every single American family with a loved one serving in Afghanistan or anywhere overseas."

The White House on Saturday denied that Trump or Vice President Pence was briefed on the intelligence but did not refute the accuracy of the intelligence as described by the Times and other news outlets.

"The United States receives thousands of intelligence reports a day and they are subject to strict scrutiny. While the White House does not routinely comment on alleged intelligence or internal deliberations, the CIA Director, National Security Advisor, and the Chief of Staff can all confirm that neither the President nor the Vice President were briefed on the alleged Russian bounty intelligence," McEnany said in a statement.

"This does not speak to the merit of the alleged intelligence but to the inaccuracy of the New York Times story erroneously suggesting that President Trump was briefed on this matter," McEnany continued.

Director of National Intelligence John Ratcliffe, who was recently installed in the top intelligence post by Trump, issued a statement backing the White House but did not comment on the substance of the intelligence reported by the Times.

Title: President Trump Criticizes Washington State Judge Overturning Travel Ban; Judge's Ruling Blocks Enforcement of Executive Order

Article:

President Donald Trump on Sunday criticized the Washington state judge who overturned his travel ban, as the Justice Department's attempt to reinstate the order was rejected by an appeals court on the same day. The executive order, issued on January 27, restricts entry into the U.S. for at least 90 days for people from seven Muslim-majority countries, halts Syrian refugees indefinitely, and all refugees for 120 days.

In a series of tweets, Trump expressed his disapproval of the ruling, stating, "I have instructed Homeland Security to check people coming into our country VERY CAREFULLY. The courts are making the job very difficult!" and "Bad!".

U.S. District Court Judge James Robart ruled on Friday that the states of Washington and Minnesota, which filed the lawsuit, had "met their burden of demonstrating that they face immediate and irreparable injury as a result of the signing and implementation of the executive order." Washington Attorney General Bob Ferguson sued this week, challenging key parts of the order as illegal and unconstitutional. Robart granted Ferguson's request for a temporary restraining order "on a nationwide basis" forbidding federal employees from enforcing Trump's order.

The Justice Department issued a strongly-worded response to Robart's decision, stating that halting the travel ban "harms the public" and "second-guesses the President's national security judgment." The Department of Homeland Security announced Saturday that it would not continue to implement Trump's order, meaning business as usual at all airports. The State Department also said it would not cancel or revoke any more visas. Last week, up to 60,000 foreigners had their visas revoked.

"Those individuals with visas that were not physically cancelled may now travel if the visa is otherwise valid," the State Department said. Robart stated that Trump's order is harmful to "residents in areas of employment, education, business, family relations, and freedom to travel."

Title: Gun Control and the Role of Education in School Shootings: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

The recent surge in discussions about gun control, particularly in the aftermath of mass shootings at schools, has sparked a heated debate. Media personalities, such as Chris Cuomo on CNN and MSNBC, have been vocal in their criticism of politicians for allegedly being influenced by gun lobby groups. However, this article will not delve into political affiliations or speculate on the motivations of individuals.

The discourse surrounding gun control has been a contentious one, with some arguing for stricter regulations and others advocating for the preservation of Second Amendment rights. In this context, it is important to consider the role of education and its impact on school shootings.

The rise in school shootings is not solely attributable to the absence of gun laws but rather the absence of a civilized culture that values and adheres to rules. The liberal elite's cherished lobby, the teachers' unions, has been a significant contributor to this crisis. Critics argue that these unions, filled with self-interested individuals, have seen their pensions grow as schools have deteriorated.

Before the rise of the teachers' unions, public schools did not require "gun-free zones" or large security forces. Teachers were responsible for shaping minds and souls, and discipline and rigor were the norm. However, under the ridicule of a ruling class that now treats the debased condition of schools solemnly, this discipline and rigor have vanished.

The liberal vision of gun control without self-control results in a multiplicity of laws that an increasingly depraved citizenry will not obey. The Florida shooter, for instance, violated numerous laws. Adding a few more would not have prevented the tragedy.

The multiplication of laws can only lead to the destruction of a free society, where the final solution to crime is treating everyone, both the virtuous and the vicious, as criminals. This article does not advocate for or against gun control but aims to highlight the importance of self-control and the role of civilizing institutions, particularly schools and families, in shaping society.

The conversation about gun control should focus on the capacity of citizens to respect existing laws rather than the multiplication of restrictions. In other words, the conversation should turn to the repair of civilizing institutions, starting with the most fundamental school of virtue, the family. However, this is a conversation that gun-control advocates may be reluctant to engage in, given their role in the corruption of these institutions.

This article does not take a political stance but aims to provide a neutral analysis of the role of education in school shootings and the need for self-control in the context of gun control discussions.

Title: China and U.S. Agree in Principle to Roll Back Tariffs in Phase One Trade Deal

Article:

China's Commerce Ministry announced on Thursday that Beijing and Washington have agreed in principle to roll back existing tariffs in phases if trade talks between the two countries progress. Ministry spokesman Gao Feng stated that both sides have agreed to simultaneously cancel some tariffs on each other's goods, according to CNBC, citing the Chinese state broadcaster.

Gao added that the two sides are closer to a so-called "phase one" trade agreement after constructive negotiations over the past two weeks. If a "phase one" agreement is reached, tariffs already increased would be canceled at the same time and by the same rate, according to Gao. The size of the reductions would depend on the agreement's content.

Gao emphasized that a limited trade agreement requires the U.S. and China to remove the same amount of charges at the same time, as a key condition. The news of a "phase one" trade agreement prompted US stock index futures to rally Thursday morning, with Dow futures poised to open more than 120 points.

The two governments have imposed tariffs on billions of dollars of each other's goods in a dispute over China's trade surplus and technology ambitions. These tariffs have weighed on trade and threaten to depress global economic growth, which already shows signs of slowing.

President Trump agreed to postpone a planned tariff hike while lower-level officials worked out the details. According to the Oct. 12 agreement, China has agreed to purchase up to $50 billion of American farm goods. However, the two sides have yet to announce progress on major disagreements over technology and other issues following 13 rounds of talks.

President Trump and President Xi Jinping were due to meet at this month's gathering of Asia-Pacific leaders in Chile, but that event was canceled due to protests. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross stated this week that any "phase one" agreement would be general and cover trade in specific areas such as soybeans and liquefied natural gas. More complex issues would be addressed in later negotiations, he said.

Title: Facebook Removes Marine Corps Page Denigrating Women After Congressional Intervention

Article:

Facebook has removed a page that allegedly denigrated women in the Marine Corps following a complaint from a House member to the Pentagon, which was seen as another example of the military's lax attitude toward sexual harassment.

Rep. Jackie Speier, in a letter to Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and top military brass released Wednesday, cited the page and asked officials to outline their response. The Marine Corps, in a statement released Wednesday by Capt. Eric Flanagan, stated that Marines are responsible for all content they publish on social networking sites, blogs, or other websites, and there is no tolerance for discriminatory comments.

Speier, who has pushed the Pentagon to treat sexual abuse cases with more urgency, said in an interview, "I almost expect to see this trash. The military is not policing itself." It is unclear who created or updates the page. In later online posts, Speier was called a vulgar four-letter word, incorrectly called a senator, and threatened for causing the page to be taken down. Speier's office said the posts were referred to U.S. Capitol Police, which declined to comment Wednesday night.

The Marines' statement said that based on complaints received, both active-duty and reserve Marines have been involved, and all instances are referred to commands for appropriate action. Facebook removed the page Wednesday after determining the administrators were fake, said a company official speaking on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak publicly. Facebook routinely removes pages that bully or harass people in general, the official said.

Speier wrote that the Marine Corps inspector general is aware of the site and has been monitoring it for three years. The Marine Corps statement said the inspector general has "been dealing with complaints about social media over the past 10 years," but did not specifically answer questions about the site removed Wednesday.

Speier wrote that the page and others like it "contribute to a culture that permits and seems to encourage sexual assault and abuse." The Marines' statement said officials have "notified social media sites on several occasions" of offensive content, but "there are difficulties in identifying the individuals responsible for the offensive material due to fake accounts and pseudonyms. Social media sites are not obligated to divulge personal information to the Marine Corps."

On Tuesday, the Pentagon released a report that estimated 26,000 troops had been sexually abused in 2012, up 35% since the last survey in 2010. Later Wednesday afternoon, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, D-Nev., sent letters to the chairman and ranking member of the Senate Armed Services Committee asking them to add anti-sexual assault provisions to the 2014 defense authorization bill, which is being developed now.

"As you prepare the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2014, I strongly urge you to include additional legislation to ensure justice for victims of sexual assault in the military and to prevent these horrific acts against service members in the future," Reid wrote Sens. Carl Levin, D-Mich., and Jim Inhofe, R-Okla. "Specifically, I urge you to eliminate the ability of military commanders to arbitrarily reverse convictions under the Uniform Code for Military Justice for sexual assault," Reid wrote.

On Thursday, key White House aides are scheduled to meet with a bipartisan group of about 12 members of the House and Senate to discuss potential legislation to address the issue.

Title: Trump and Khan Family Controversy: A Closer Look at the Interviews and Responses

Article:

In the latest media controversy, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has faced criticism for his response to the emotional speech delivered by the bereaved parents of Captain Humayun Khan, an immigrant soldier who died in Iraq in 2004. The speech, given at the Democratic National Convention, was a powerful rebuke, though factually incorrect in some aspects, such as the claim that the Constitution bars religious tests for immigrants.

During interviews with Maureen Dowd of the New York Times and George Stephanopoulos of ABC News, Trump was asked to respond to the speech. In both interviews, Trump expressed a desire to hear more from Khan's wife and made comments perceived as insensitive, referring to the subordinate status of women in Islam. Trump also suggested that the Clinton campaign had scripted Khan's remarks, a claim the family later denied.

The media has been critical of Trump's response, with some outlets labeling it as an attack on the Khan family. For example, Ezra Klein of Vox.com wrote an article titled "Donald Trump's slander of Captain Humayun Khan's family is horrifying, even for Trump." However, it is worth noting that similar criticisms were not leveled against Hillary Clinton when she questioned the credibility of Patricia Smith, a mother of a victim of the 2012 Benghazi attack, during the Republican National Convention.

Trump has since issued statements on Twitter and his campaign website, defending his stance on radical Islamic terrorism and criticizing Clinton's role in foreign policy. He has also accused Clinton of destabilizing the Middle East, contributing to the rise of ISIS, and being responsible for the deaths of American lives in Benghazi and Libya.

In response to the controversy, Khizr Khan, Humayun Khan's father, has made the rounds of the Sunday morning shows, stating that terror has "nothing to do with Islam." Meanwhile, Trump has continued to defend his immigration policies and criticize Clinton's foreign policy record.

Joel B. Pollak, Senior Editor-at-Large at ███, has written a new book titled "See No Evil: 19 Hard Truths the Left Can't Handle." The book is available on Amazon.

Title: Sen. Rand Paul Criticizes President Obama's Border Policies During Guatemalan Visit

Article:

Sen. Rand Paul (R-KY), currently in Guatemala to perform pro-bono eye surgeries, criticized President Obama's border policies during a closed-door meeting with Guatemalan President Otto Perez Molina on Wednesday. Paul stated that the main cause of the ongoing border crisis lies with the White House, not Guatemala City.

In an interview with Breitbart.com, Paul said, "I told him, frankly, that I didn't think the problem was in Guatemala City, but that the problem was in the White House in our country, and that the mess we've got at the border is frankly because of the White House's policies."

Paul expressed support for the House bill to end Obama's deportation relief program for Dreamers and stated that the legislation would "go a long way to fixing the problem." However, he criticized Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid for not allowing votes on any bills this year, which, according to Paul, is to protect vulnerable senators from elections.

Paul, a potential contender for the 2016 GOP presidential nomination, condemned Obama for not doing enough to secure the border and stated that without a real solution at the border, there can be no reform. He also criticized Obama for offering unilateral policies without congressional approval and for not securing the border before implementing any immigration reforms.

Democrats responded to Paul's comments, calling his trip to Guatemala a campaign farce. Michael Czin, national press secretary for the Democratic National Committee, wrote in a memo, "While everyone should commend Paul for his aid work, it's unfortunate he turned a trip organized by a well-respected eye center into a crass campaign photo op."

Czin also criticized Paul for condemning the president in the presence of a foreign leader and for voting against Democratic immigration reform legislation and opposing an emergency supplemental package to address the border crisis. Czin concluded, "America deserves better from our elected officials—especially those who want to seek the highest office in the land."

Title: Saudi Arabia Grants Turkey Access to Consulate Amid Khashoggi Investigation

Article:

President Donald Trump suggested on Monday that "rogue killers" could be behind the disappearance of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, following a phone call with Saudi Arabia's King Salman about the case. Trump stated that Salman offered him a "flat denial" in relation to Khashoggi's disappearance, a columnist for The Washington Post who was last seen in public when he entered the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey on October 2.

Later on Monday, the Saudis were reportedly preparing to admit that Khashoggi died during an interrogation that went wrong, intended to lead to his abduction from Turkey, according to two sources. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo left Washington for Riyadh at midday to meet with the Saudi King on Trump's orders.

Previously, Saudi authorities had maintained that Khashoggi left the consulate the same afternoon of his visit, but have provided no evidence to support the claim. Khashoggi's fiancée, Hatice Cengiz, who was waiting outside the consulate, says she did not see him re-emerge.

Trump described King Salman's denial as "very strong" and said, "It wasn't like there was a question in his mind. The denial was very strong." Trump continued, "With that being said, the king firmly denied any knowledge of it. He did not really know -- maybe -- I do not want to get into his mind but it sounded to me like maybe these could have been rogue killers, who knows?" Trump added, "We are going to try to get to the bottom of it very soon."

CNN reporters saw Turkish investigators, including forensics officers, entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul Monday evening. Saudi officials had granted permission for the premises to be searched, a Turkish diplomatic source told CNN, and police were seen cordoning off the area before investigators arrived. Turkish officials also want to search the nearby consul general's residence.

Turkish authorities believe 15 Saudi men who arrived in Istanbul on October 2 were connected to Khashoggi's disappearance and possible murder. At least some of them appear to have high-level connections in the Saudi government. A source familiar with the ongoing investigation told CNN on Friday that Turkish authorities have audio and visual evidence that shows journalist Khashoggi was killed inside the consulate.

International pressure is mounting on Riyadh to explain Khashoggi's disappearance, in a case that has created a diplomatic rift between Saudi Arabia and the West. The UK, France, and Germany have demanded a "credible investigation" into the events, and Trump on Sunday warned of serious retribution if the Saudis were found to be behind his possible death.

Saudi officials threatened to retaliate if the US imposed sanctions, but Riyadh later softened its tone. The case has also caused friction between Saudi Arabia and Turkey, which has repeatedly accused the Saudis of failing to cooperate with their investigation.

CCTV footage shows Khashoggi entering the Saudi consulate on October 2. The agreement to allow a search of the consulate comes a day after King Salman called Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan to discuss the case. The two leaders agreed on a joint working group to look into the journalist's disappearance.

The Saudi official said that a royal decree was issued Friday directing the public prosecutor to conduct an internal investigation into the Khashoggi case, based on intelligence shared by Turkey with Saudi Arabia. The official said that although a joint investigation team was cooperating on the ground, the Saudi "leadership had felt that an internal investigation was needed to make sure no stone is left unturned to unfold the truth."

Amid the diplomatic fallout over Khashoggi's disappearance, international firms are pulling out of a high-profile investment summit. The Future Investment Initiative conference, dubbed "Davos in the Desert," was due to take place later this month in Riyadh, hosted by Saudi Arabia's de facto ruler, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

The latest high-profile invitee to pull out of the conference is World Bank President Jim Yong Kim, according to a person familiar with the decision. JP Morgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon has also withdrawn, a spokesperson confirmed Sunday. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin was still due to attend the conference. Trump said on Monday that Mnuchin has until Friday to decide whether to attend. "He's going to make that decision," Trump said.

The BBC reported that the attendance of British Trade Secretary Liam Fox was in doubt. The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia considered delaying the Saudi investment conference until after the investigation, according to a source with direct knowledge of the situation. It is unclear if that is still under consideration, according to the source. CNN received no response when reaching out to the CEO, managing director, and organizers of the conference.

Saudi Arabia has found support in a number of Arab allies, including Oman, Bahrain, Jordan, Lebanon, the United Arab Emirates, and Egypt, which all put out statements Sunday saying they expressed solidarity with Saudi Arabia. The Palestinian Authority also put out a statement of support.

Title: President Trump Faces Pressure to Remain Cautious Amidst Russia Investigation Developments

Article:

In the wake of special counsel Robert Mueller's unveiling of indictments and plea deals in the Russia investigation, President Donald Trump faces a critical decision: to remain silent or react. The indictment of former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort and his associate Rick Gates, along with the plea agreement with former Trump foreign-policy adviser George Papadopoulos, has generated negative press coverage that could potentially provoke Trump's notorious impulsive responses.

The indictment of Manafort, who allegedly engaged in shady lobbying activities, is not directly linked to the Trump campaign. The charges against Manafort, dating back to 2006, involve failure to register as a foreign lobbyist and alleged money laundering. If Manafort has information about a potential collusion scheme, there is currently no evidence to suggest this.

George Papadopoulos' plea for lying to the FBI, however, does involve his work for the campaign. He misled investigators about the timing and nature of his contacts with Russians who proposed a meeting between Vladimir Putin and Trump, and discussed dirt on Hillary Clinton. However, Papadopoulos' role was minor, and it remains unclear if the discussions led to any significant actions.

If Trump were to fire Mueller or issue pre-emptive pardons, he would escalate a peripheral issue into a full-blown crisis. Removing Mueller would lead to the handover of all special counsel materials to Congress and potentially make Trump a lead witness in impeachment hearings. A Trump pardon of Manafort would associate the president with the lobbyist's alleged malfeasance, suggesting that Trump has something to hide.

The decision to oust James Comey, the former FBI director, appears to have been driven by Trump's frustration over Comey's refusal to publicly state that Trump was not under investigation. If Trump repeats this impulsive action by firing Mueller or issuing a barrage of pardons, he risks making the situation much worse for himself. Conversely, if Trump is innocent, firing Mueller would be a catastrophic error.

In this critical moment, the calculus is simple: if Trump is innocent, he should avoid actions that could jeopardize his presidency. If he is guilty, there is little he can do to prevent the truth from coming to light. The choice lies with Trump: remain silent or risk making a bad situation worse.

Title: Brexit Transition and Its Implications for the U.K. and EU

Article:

The transition agreement associated with Brexit, effective from January 31, 2020, will treat the U.K. as if it were still part of the EU for the next 11 months. This arrangement, however, is not expected to last long, as both the U.K. and the EU are striving to establish their positions on a global stage dominated by the U.S. and China.

The Brexiteers advocate for 'Global Britain' as a free-market counterweight to a protectionist EU, but the division on trade and geopolitics has yet to materialize. The complexities of disentangling the relationship from the EU have proven more challenging than many anticipated, as evidenced by the end of the careers of two prime ministers, eight cabinet ministers, and over 80 MPs since the 2016 referendum.

Britain must negotiate a trade deal governing future commercial relations with Europe by the end of the year or risk expensive disruption with its largest trading partner. If no agreement is reached, the possibility of a no-deal exit looms, which could lead to backlogs at ports, shortages in food and other goods, and significant economic disruption.

Experts suggest that a no-deal exit could take seven years to negotiate, as demonstrated by Europe's recent trade deals with Canada and Japan. However, Prime Minister Johnson has repeatedly ruled out extending the transition date.

If no agreement is reached, two potential outcomes emerge: a narrow trade deal that governs some manufactured goods while leaving out services, the bulk of the British economy, or a no-deal exit. The latter scenario would entail costly mayhem, as companies on both sides of the English Channel stockpile goods in anticipation of customs snafus and choked ports.

Brexit is not expected to mark the end of Britain's zero-sum politics. The liberal status quo, long before Britain voted to leave the EU, has entrenched asymmetries of power and inequalities of wealth. The imperative to patiently listen to the other side is not just unrealistic; it is insulting to those who persistently lose out.

In a separate matter, President Trump's declaration of airstrikes in response to attacks on American targets or assets has drawn a red line that Iran cannot cross. However, Iran relies on a network of proxy actors from Yemen, Syria, Iraq, and Lebanon. The question remains whether these proxy forces will respect Trump's red line, and the potential for violent conflict remains high. It is crucial that influential Republican senators remind President Trump of his promise to keep America out of foreign quagmires and prevent further escalation.

Title: Obamacare Premiums to Increase by an Average of 22% in 2017

Article:

Obamacare premiums are set to increase by an average of 22% in 2017, according to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). The most popular benchmark plans will see a significant price hike, with the number of insurers offering plans on the federally run exchange also expected to decrease.

Roughly one in five customers will have only a single insurer as an option next year, following the withdrawal of major players such as UnitedHealth Group and Aetna from most states and the failure of nearly all of Obamacare's co-op plans. This situation is particularly challenging for President Obama, who is trying to boost his legacy in his final months in office, and for Hillary Clinton, his would-be Democratic successor, who has defended the law.

Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's spokesman, Jason Miller, stated, "This shows why the entire program must be repealed and replaced." Congressional Republicans, who are struggling to maintain their majorities in both chambers, also seized on the news, warning voters that electing Democrats would cement the Affordable Care Act into law.

Obamacare customers can get a first look at their own rates when they log onto the federal HealthCare.gov website during the open enrollment period, which begins on November 1. According to HHS, 80% of customers won't feel the full impact of the increases because they qualify for taxpayer-funded subsidies. Nearly three-quarters of customers in 2017 will be able to find a plan for $75 or less per month after tax credits kick in.

However, several million customers do not qualify for government subsidies or purchase insurance off the exchanges, so they will feel the full brunt of the increases. Taxpayers will also have to shell out more money to cover the subsidies for those who do qualify, meaning Obamacare's costs will continue to rise.

On Monday, the House Energy and Commerce Committee asked the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services to detail the burden that taxpayers are shouldering. "While the administration continues to focus on premium'affordability,' it ignores the undeniable fact that federal taxpayers are subsidizing these premium increases through tax credits," wrote Rep. Fred Upton, Michigan Republican and the panel's chairman, along with other leading members.

Analysts for months had warned of massive premium increases, stating that the Obamacare program is still struggling to entice healthy customers who are needed to make the economics work. Increases will vary widely from place to place, though some of the figures are eye-popping: In Arizona, a 27-year-old's average monthly premium for the second-lowest silver, or "benchmark," plan jumps $196 to $422, a 116% increase, before subsidies.

In Oklahoma, that same customer would get a 69% increase. Customers in Indiana and Massachusetts, which runs its own exchange, would be the only ones to see a decrease, of 3%, according to the HHS report. The administration stated that things could get worse if the federal courts do not overturn a judge's decision in May that sided with House Republicans, who say the Treasury is unlawfully reimbursing insurers for losses under the 2010 health care overhaul.

Despite the headwinds, HHS Secretary Sylvia Mathews Burwell is predicting that the marketplace will expand by roughly 1 million customers in 2017 as insurers bring their prices in line with actual costs. She estimated that 13.8 million people will buy plans during open enrollment on the exchanges, compared with 12.7 million who initially signed up for 2016. That is still short of the 15 million that congressional scorekeepers predicted just a few months ago.

Even President Obama has said his law will need changes after he is out of office, including a government-run plan, or "public option," to bolster competition in the exchanges. As it stands, the number of insurers participating on HealthCare.gov has dwindled from 232 this year to 167 in 2017. HHS stated that customers on HealthCare.gov, which serves 39 states, will still be able to choose, on average, from 30 plans with different combinations of premiums, out-of-pocket costs, networks of hospitals and physicians, and prescription drug coverage options.

Title: House Judiciary Committee's Request for Attorney General Barr's Testimony Met with Resistance, Threatening Contempt Proceedings

Article:

The refusal of Attorney General William Barr to appear before the House Judiciary Committee has led to a heightened sense among Democrats that the executive branch is in defiance of the Constitution and the rule of law, according to Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-Md). Raskin, a former constitutional law professor who sits on both the House Judiciary and Oversight committees, stated, "They have succeeded in building a near unanimous sense in the Democratic Caucus that the executive branch of government is in defiance of the Constitution and the rule of law."

Barr, already under scrutiny from Democrats in both the House and Senate, declined to appear Thursday before the House Judiciary Committee because he did not want to be questioned by committee lawyers, only members. Democrats refused to accommodate Barr, citing a larger constitutional principle at stake. "He does not dictate to us how we conduct hearings in Congress," Raskin said.

The Trump administration has made it clear they are not willing to cooperate with Democrats' demands. White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders described Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler's request for staff lawyers to question the attorney general as a "pathetic" moment for the committee. "Look, we lost confidence in Jerry Nadler a long time ago, but it's surprising to find out he's lost confidence in himself," Sanders said.

Democrats are now deciding on their next course of action. Nadler has stated they will make one more attempt to negotiate and obtain the unredacted Mueller report. If they do not receive it, they will hold Barr in contempt and take further legal action. On Friday, Nadler sent a letter to Barr requesting the unredacted Mueller report by May 6. If Barr does not comply, he will face contempt proceedings and further legal action.

In his letter, Nadler wrote, "Lastly, it can not go unremarked that, in refusing to comply with congressional oversight requests, the department has repeatedly asserted that Congress's requests do not serve 'legitimate' purposes." He continued, "This is not the department's judgment to make. Congress's constitutional, oversight and legislative interest in investigating misconduct by the president and his associates can not be disputed."

Some Democrats are already calling for Barr's impeachment, including Rep. Eric Swalwell (D-Calif.), who is running for president. Others, including many of the 2020 Democratic presidential hopefuls, have called on him to resign. There is talk of censure, a type of public reprimand with little practical effect. Lawmakers are also researching Congress's long-dormant "inherent contempt" powers, which have not been triggered in nearly a century.

Speaker Pelosi (D-Calif.) reminded reporters on Thursday that ignoring Congress had consequences for another president. "As you probably know, in the Articles of Impeachment for President Nixon, Article 3 was that he ignored the subpoenas of Congress, that he did not honor the subpoenas of Congress. This is very, very serious," she said.

Pelosi also criticized Barr for what she described as conflicting testimony to Congress about his communications with Mueller, over Barr's handling of the initial summary of the report. A March 27 letter from Mueller revealed this week called into question Barr's account. "But what is deadly serious about it is the Attorney General of the United States of America was not telling the truth to the Congress of the United States. That's a crime," she said.

A spokesman for Barr called Pelosi's comments "reckless, irresponsible, and false."

Not every reaction has been as serious. Rep. Steve Cohen (D-Tenn.) brought a bucket of KFC to the empty hearing room on Thursday to make a theatrical point. "Chicken Barr should have shown up today and answered questions," Cohen said, perhaps sending a message to the administration about what happens when you ignore Congress. Cohen proceeded to eat the chicken in front of the cameras.

Increasingly, Democrats like Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.), who sits on the Judiciary panel, say they are not interested in hearing from Barr anymore. "At this point, I do not believe anything Barr says. So I'd rather have Mueller," she told NPR.

Nadler has invited Mueller to testify on May 15. It is not yet confirmed, but Barr has said publicly that he has no objection to this. Another anticipated clash still to come involves Democrats' desire to hear from former White House Counsel Don McGahn, but President Trump is indicating that he will invoke executive privilege to block any request. "Congress should not be looking anymore. This is all. It's done," Trump told Fox News on Thursday.

Title: Yahoo News Confirms Katie Couric's Continued Employment Amidst Documentary Editing Controversy

Article:

Yahoo News has confirmed that Katie Couric will continue in her role as global anchor, despite allegations of deceptive editing in documentaries she executive produced and narrated. The documentaries, "Under the Gun" and "Fed Up," have been under scrutiny for manipulated content since their release.

In the 2016 documentary "Under the Gun," Couric and director Stephanie Soechtig edited out gun rights activists' answers to a question about background checks, replacing them with several seconds of silence. This led to calls for Couric's dismissal from Yahoo News following a report by The Free Beacon that revealed the raw audio of the interview.

Additional accusations of deceptive editing were made in the 2014 documentary film "Fed Up," also executive produced by Couric and directed by Soechtig. Dr. David Allison, director of the Nutrition Obesity Research Center, stated that his portrayal in the film was "antithetical to the spirit of science and democratic dialogue." Industry sources told The Free Beacon that the documentary inserted audio at a moment it did not occur during a separate interview with Lisa Gable, a spokesperson for the Healthy Weight Commitment Foundation.

The Weinstein Company, which distributes "Fed Up," manually requested the removal of YouTube videos from the film following the Free Beacon report. Soechtig, who did not respond to repeated requests for comment from The Free Beacon, defended the film in a statement to Variety, stating that it has had a significant impact on American eating habits and has inspired conversations about the issues.

A spokesperson for Couric did not issue a statement to Variety but directed the publication to Soechtig's statement. Yahoo News, which was not involved in the creation and production of the independent documentaries, maintains confidence in the work of its news team, adhering to the highest standards of journalism.

Title: Egypt Declares State of Emergency Following Deadly Church Bombings Claimed by ISIS

Article:

Egypt's President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi declared a three-month state of emergency on Sunday, following two suicide bombings at Coptic Christian churches that left at least 44 people dead and over 100 injured. The attacks, claimed by the Islamic State (ISIS) terror group, occurred at St. George Church in Tanta and St. Mark's Cathedral in Alexandria during Palm Sunday services.

The first explosion took place at St. George Church in the Nile Delta town of Tanta, where at least 27 people were killed and 78 others wounded, according to officials. Television footage showed the inside of the church, where a large number of people gathered around what appeared to be lifeless, bloody bodies covered with papers.

A second explosion, which Egypt's Interior Ministry says was caused by a suicide bomber, occurred at St. Mark's Cathedral in the coastal city of Alexandria, leaving at least 17 dead and 48 injured. The attack came just after Pope Tawadros II, leader of the Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria, finished services, but his aides told local media that he was unharmed. At least three police officers were killed in the St. Mark's attack, the ministry told The Associated Press.

ISIS claimed responsibility for the attacks via its Aamaq media agency, following the group's recent video vowing to step up attacks against Christians, who the group describes as "infidels" empowering the West against Muslims.

The blasts occurred at the start of Holy Week leading up to Easter and just weeks before Pope Francis is due to visit Egypt, the Arab world's most populous country. Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi accused unnamed countries of fueling instability in the country, adding "Egyptians have foiled plots and efforts by countries and fascist, terrorist organizations that tried to control Egypt." El-Sisi ordered the immediate deployment of troops to assist police in protecting vital facilities across the country.

El-Sisi did not immediately detail the legal measures needed to declare the state of emergency, but according to the Egyptian constitution, the parliament majority must vote in favor of the state of emergency.

President Donald Trump tweeted that he is "so sad to hear of the terrorist attack" against the U.S. ally but added that he has "great confidence" that el-Sissi, "will handle the situation properly." The two leaders met at the White House on April 3.

The State Department issued its own statement condemning the attacks, which it called "barbaric." "The United States will continue to support Egypt's security and stability in its efforts to defeat terrorism," the statement said.

The attack in Tanta was the latest in a series of assaults on Egypt's Christian minority, which makes up around 10 percent of the population and has been repeatedly targeted by Islamic extremists.

Grand Sheikh Ahmed el-Tayeb, head of Egypt's Al-Azhar—the leading center of learning in Sunni Islam—condemned the attacks, calling them a "despicable terrorist bombing that targeted the lives of innocents."

Across the street from St. George, neighbor Susan Mikhail, whose apartment has a clear balcony view of the church and its front yard, said the explosion violently shook her building midmorning, at a time when the church was packed. "Deacons were the first to run out of the church. Many of them had blood on their white robes," she told The Associated Press. Later, the more seriously wounded started to come out, carried in the arms of survivors and ferried to hospitals in private cars, she said.

Pope Francis decried the bombings, expressing "deep condolences to my brother, Pope Tawadros II, the Coptic church and all of the dear Egyptian nation." Word of the attacks came as Francis was holding Palm Sunday services in St. Peter's Square.

Both Israel and the Islamic Hamas movement ruling neighboring Gaza also condemned the bombings. Presidential spokesman Ibrahim Kalin tweeted his condolences and said, "We strongly condemn the heinous terror attacks on churches in Egypt on Palm Sunday today."

Mehmet Gormez, the head of religious affairs in Turkey, "cursed" the attacks and said they are the shared problem of all humanity. "The immunity of a place of worship, no matter the religion it belongs to, can not be violated and the bloodthirsty killing of innocent worshippers can not ever be forgiven," Gormez said in an official statement.

Turkey's Ministry of Foreign Affairs also published a statement denouncing the attack on St. George Church. "We convey our condolences to the bereaved families and the whole people of Egypt," the statement said before a second attack hit an Alexandria church.

The bombings add to fears that Islamic extremists who have long been battling security forces in the Sinai Peninsula are shifting their focus to civilians. A local Islamic State affiliate claimed a suicide bombing at a church in Cairo in December that killed around 30 people, mostly women, as well as a string of killings in the restive Sinai Peninsula that caused hundreds of Christians to flee to safer areas of the country. The group has threatened further attacks.

A militant group called Liwa al-Thawra claimed responsibility for an April 1 bomb attack targeting a police training center in Tanta, which wounded 16 people. The group, believed to be linked to the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood, has mainly targeted security forces and distanced itself from attacks on Christians.

Title: Trump to Decide on DACA's Future on Tuesday

Article:

President Donald J. Trump is set to announce a decision on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program on Tuesday. The program, enacted by the Obama administration in June 2012, provides temporary legal status to undocumented immigrants who came to the United States as children.

As a candidate, Trump had pledged to eliminate DACA on his first day in office. However, after taking office, the president has not rescinded the program. In February, Trump confessed to reporters that the DACA situation is "very difficult" for him due to his affection for the young immigrants affected by the program.

While Trump has advocated for tough enforcement of federal immigration law, he has shown sympathy towards DACA recipients, known as Dreamers. Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) has also argued against rescinding the program, stating that it allows some 750,000 undocumented immigrants to remain in the country legally and apply for work permits.

A group of pro-enforcement state attorneys general has reportedly pressured Trump to make a decision on DACA, rather than allowing the program to continue indefinitely. In 2014, these attorneys general sued to stop the expansion of DACA and another Obama mandate, Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA), which provided legal status for 5 million undocumented immigrants.

If Trump rescinds DACA, those who applied for temporary legal status may feel more vulnerable, as they would have registered with the federal government. Organizations advocating for undocumented immigrants and leaders in tech and big business have joined in their concerns.

The future of DACA remains uncertain, and it is unclear what Trump's decision will entail. Some speculate that Trump may reach across the aisle and pass a measure that protects Dreamers but also bolsters enforcement, potentially by funding the border wall. However, it is important to note that any speculation regarding Trump's decision is unverified at this time.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Indicates Coronavirus Likely Occurred Naturally, but Conclusiveness Unavailable

Article:

WASHINGTON - U.S. intelligence suggests that the coronavirus likely originated naturally, as opposed to being created in a laboratory in China, but there is no certainty either way, according to the top U.S. general. Army General Mark Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, made these remarks during a Pentagon news briefing on Tuesday.

Milley's comments could fuel speculation about the coronavirus' origins, a topic that China has dismissed as a conspiracy theory unhelpful to the fight against the pandemic. When asked whether there was evidence that the virus began in a Chinese laboratory and was perhaps accidentally released, Milley was non-committal.

"There's a lot of rumor and speculation in a wide variety of media, the blog sites, etc. It should be no surprise to you that we've taken a keen interest in that, and we've had a lot of intelligence take a hard look at that," Milley said.

"And I would just say, at this point, it's inconclusive although the weight of evidence seems to indicate natural. But we don't know for certain," Milley added.

Milley's comments could potentially escalate tensions with Beijing, where Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian wrote on Twitter last month that the U.S. Army might have "brought the epidemic to Wuhan." This claim was denounced by the U.S. government and angered U.S. President Donald Trump, who cited it when he referred to the coronavirus as "the Chinese virus" in briefings.

As far back as February, the Chinese state-backed Wuhan Institute of Virology refuted rumors that the virus may have been artificially synthesized at one of its laboratories or perhaps escaped from there.

The broad scientific consensus holds that SARS-CoV-2, the virus' official name, originated in bats. A Washington Post opinion column published on Tuesday stated that the U.S. State Department warned in diplomatic cables about safety and management weaknesses at a WIV laboratory in 2018.

The Post noted that scientists generally agreed that the virus came from animals, as opposed to being synthesized. However, it quoted one expert as saying that did not rule out that it may have emerged from the WIV laboratory, which spent years testing bat coronaviruses in animals.

U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo declined to directly address the Washington Post column in interviews on Tuesday. "We know this is a global pandemic that originated in Wuhan, China. We know that there were wet markets there. So we're beginning to piece the facts together," Pompeo said in a radio interview.

A team of 27 scientists published a statement in the Lancet medical journal in February, condemning conspiracy theories, which "do nothing but create fear, rumors, and prejudice that jeopardize our global collaboration in the fight against this virus." They said scientists from around the world "overwhelmingly conclude that this coronavirus originated in wildlife."

Title: Democrats' Use of Campaign Tracker Videos Raises Privacy Concerns

Article:

Democratic political campaigns are employing a controversial tactic by recording and publicly sharing videos of Republican congressmen and candidates' homes, sparking concerns about privacy and safety. This practice, which involves using campaign trackers to record and share raw footage of opponents' homes on the internet, has been criticized by Republicans as a gross invasion of privacy and a potential safety risk.

While campaign tracking, which involves recording every public appearance and statement by an opponent, is a common practice in serious campaigns on both sides, Democrats are reportedly taking it a step further. They are recording video footage of the homes of GOP congressmen and candidates and posting the unedited footage online.

Republicans argue that this level of video surveillance crosses a line, particularly in terms of political standards. Wisconsin GOP Rep. Reid Ribble, who has also been followed by a cameraman while shopping for groceries, described the home videos as inappropriate and disturbing. In Ribble's case, a 38-second, soundless video of his northeastern Wisconsin home was posted online on June 18. The video, taken from a car parked outside the house, shows the large home from several different angles.

Ribble's wife, DeaNa, expressed her discomfort, stating that she would call the police if a tracker were to step onto their private property. Ohio Rep. Jim Renacci, who said a tracker had been hiding in the bushes to take footage of his home, echoed these concerns, stating that filming a home and posting actual addresses should be off-limits out of respect for families and neighbors.

Politicians recognize that they give up a degree of privacy when they run for office. However, the use of campaign trackers to record and share videos of opponents' homes has raised questions about when campaign tracking becomes something more like stalking. This practice has unnerved Republicans, who are already on edge after a deranged gunman shot former Arizona Democratic Rep. Gabrielle Giffords 18 months ago.

Title: Homeland Security Inspector General Finds Illegal Behavior in Implementation of President Trump's Travel Ban

Article:

The Homeland Security inspector general, John Roth, has released a memo to Congress stating that department employees illegally attempted to prevent individuals from the seven majority-Muslim countries affected by President Trump's original travel ban from boarding planes bound for the United States, despite court orders to the contrary.

In the letters to Democratic members of Congress, Mr. Roth also accused the Trump administration of using legal tactics to conceal the illegal behavior from the public. He concluded that leadership was lacking when Mr. Trump issued his original Jan. 27 travel ban, which halted all travel, including immigration and visitors, from the identified countries.

Customs and Border Protection (CBP), the Homeland Security agency responsible for screening arrivals, was left without guidance on the many questions surrounding the order, according to Mr. Roth. CBP also defied two court orders in trying to prevent passengers from boarding planes at overseas airports, issuing "no board" instructions to airlines even after courts had halted the travel ban policy, the report concludes.

For passengers who reached the U.S., Mr. Roth said they were treated well by CBP officers, contradicting some reports from immigrant-rights activists at the time. He said they couldn't substantiate reports of passengers being abused or children being handcuffed. In fact, he said, many CBP officers went the extra mile and provided water and food from their own personal funds.

The administration also made wide use of waivers, allowing most passengers who reached the U.S. in spite of the executive order, according to Mr. Roth. This suggests that Mr. Trump's executive order was more symbolic than enforced when it was being carried out.

The original order was blocked by a number of courts, and Mr. Trump responded with a revised order in March. That second version was also blocked by lower courts, but the Supreme Court partially overruled them in June, allowing some of the ban to take effect. Mr. Trump then updated the policy this fall, and the third version is currently under court scrutiny.

Mr. Roth's new memo looks at the early days after the original policy was put in place on Jan. 27, until it was fully halted by a judge in Seattle on Feb. 3. The inspector general said he submitted his findings to the Homeland Security Department on Oct. 6, but the department is still deciding whether it will classify any of the report as secret, for various reasons.

Democrats who released Mr. Roth's memo on Monday said hiding the findings is "frankly unacceptable." "The rule of law and our constitutional protections mean little if law enforcement is empowered by the president to disregard them," said Sens. Richard Durbin and Tammy Duckworth, both Illinois Democrats. "If the Trump Administration decides to bury an inspector general report suggesting that's what happened, there will be repercussions in Congress."

Tyler Houlton, spokesman for Homeland Security, didn't respond directly to Mr. Roth's findings of illegal behavior, but insisted officers "conducted themselves professionally, and in a legal manner." He also defended the attempt to shield the report's contents, saying that the ability to claim those privileges is "well-recognized law."

Title: "Michael D'Antonio's Book, "The Truth About Trump," Outlines Challenges for Trump in Preparing for Second Presidential Debate"

Article:

Michael D'Antonio, author of the new book "The Truth About Trump," outlines potential difficulties for Donald Trump in preparing for the second presidential debate, which is scheduled for October 9. The opinions expressed in this commentary are D'Antonio's.

According to D'Antonio, Trump's poor sportsmanship following his defeat in the first debate may hinder his preparation for the next one. Ignoring real poll results that show he was significantly behind, Trump has reportedly ordered his aides to cease acknowledging his loss. This denial, D'Antonio suggests, may prevent Trump from recognizing his own shortcomings.

D'Antonio highlights ten areas where Trump could improve for the next debate, but notes that it is unlikely he will be able to make any of these changes. For instance, Trump has a history of avoiding taking responsibility for his actions, and D'Antonio does not expect this to change.

Manners, body language, and debate preparation are areas where Trump is likely to struggle, according to D'Antonio. Trump's tendency to boast and his negative body language were noted during the first debate, and D'Antonio suggests that these traits are ingrained in Trump's personality and unlikely to change.

D'Antonio also points out that Trump's lack of understanding of geopolitical issues, such as his stance on Russia and the Ukraine, may continue to be a problem. Trump's penchant for personal attacks and insults is also expected to remain a feature of his campaign.

Among Trump's advisers, former New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is noted for his similarities with Trump. Like Trump, Giuliani poses as a tough man and has a history of personal attacks. D'Antonio suggests that Giuliani's persona may provide insight into Trump's behavior and may indicate that Trump is unlikely to change his ways.

Title: Economist Bryan Caplan Argues College May Not Be Worth It for Most People

Article:

In a recent YouTube video, economist Bryan Caplan, author of "The Case Against Education," questions the value of a college education for most people. He argues that while college tuition has significantly increased, the connection between college education and job skills is tenuous.

Caplan contends that college primarily serves as a signaling device, indicating that a student was smart enough to complete their education. He suggests that the reason for the income increase associated with higher degrees is not due to the job skills acquired in college, but rather the diploma itself.

Caplan argues that students spend countless hours studying subjects they may never use again, and that the time spent in school could be better utilized elsewhere. He points out that students are often bored and attend college primarily to secure a good job.

Caplan argues that the high cost of college is not just a personal issue, but a national one. He compares the rising cost of college to a concert where everyone standing up blocks each other's view. In this analogy, he suggests that as more people go to college, the value of a college degree decreases.

Caplan also notes that while students may learn little in college, colleges have become increasingly expensive, offering luxurious amenities such as swimming pools and gourmet dining. He suggests that these amenities are unlikely to help students secure a job.

Caplan acknowledges that students studying computer science or electrical engineering may actually learn useful skills, but he questions the value of abstract topics like social justice, diversity studies, and multicultural studies. He also questions the value of liberal arts education, suggesting that it may not expand people's minds as much as teachers might claim.

A study found that a third of people have not learned anything detectably after four years in college. Caplan, despite his criticism of college, acknowledges that there is one group of people who benefit from college: professors like himself. He notes that tenured professors, who cannot be fired, have a secure income and few demands on their time.

Caplan is expected to teach for only five hours a week.

Title: Seven Marines and Four Army Aircrew Missing After Helicopter Crash Off Florida Panhandle

Article:

A Black Hawk helicopter carrying seven Marines and four Army aircrew members has gone missing off the Florida Panhandle, with authorities suspending the air search on Wednesday due to thick fog. The helicopter was first reported missing at approximately 8:30 p.m. on Tuesday, and debris was found around Okaloosa Island near Eglin Air Force Base hours later.

The search-and-rescue mission is expected to resume midday Thursday, with boats scouring the waters throughout the night Wednesday, weather permitting. Human remains have washed ashore in the area near Eglin. The cause of the accident remains unknown, with no indication of anything suspicious.

The Air Force, Coast Guard, and civilian agencies are participating in the intensive search focused on the waters east of the town of Navarre and the Navarre Bridge and near Eglin testing range site A-17. Approximately 100 people are involved in the search effort, according to Eglin spokeswoman Jasmine Porterfield.

The service members were involved in a seven-day training exercise of amphibious operations. The UH-60 helicopter was not alone when it went down; a second Black Hawk safely returned to the base. The aircraft were both assigned to the Louisiana Army National Guard out of Hammond and were participating in a "routine training mission involving the Marine Special Operations Regiment" out of Camp Lejeune.

The Marines involved in the crash were all "highly-trained" members of the Marine Corps' special operations command. The Army aircrew members belonged to the Army National Guard unit out of Louisiana. The names of the service members will not be released publicly until the Coast Guard recovers their bodies or calls off the search.

In January, two Marines died when their helicopter went down at the Marine Corps Air Ground Combat Center in Twentynine Palms, California. Last March, an F/A-18C Hornet's pilot died after a crash about 70 miles east of Naval Air Station Fallon in western Nevada. This week's crash involved a UH-60 Black Hawk, a twin-engine helicopter introduced into Army service in 1979 in place of the iconic UH-1 Huey. Other branches have modified the Black Hawk for their own uses, including the Navy's SH-60 (the Sea Hawk), the Air Force's MH-60 (the Pave Hawk), and the Coast Guard's HH-60 (the Jayhawk). The Army's UH-60 helicopter has an airframe "designed to progressively crush on impact to protect the crew and passengers."

Title: California Defies Federal Government, Restores Net Neutrality Rules, Faces Lawsuit

Article:

California, on Sunday, took a significant step by reinstating Obama-era net neutrality rules, defying the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the Trump administration. The move comes a year after the FCC eliminated these rules. Other states, including Washington, Oregon, and Vermont, have also enacted their own net-neutrality laws, but California's approach is more assertive, prohibiting internet service providers from offering free data for specific applications.

Shortly after Governor Jerry Brown signed the bill into law, the Department of Justice filed a lawsuit against the state. Attorney General Jeff Sessions, in a statement, described the lawsuit as necessary to defend federal prerogatives and the U.S. Constitution. Sessions deemed the law "extreme" and "illegal." The FCC chairman, Ajit Pai, who is a proponent of the Trump administration's net-neutrality agenda, also criticized the measure, labeling it as "anti-consumer," "illegal," "egregious," and "radical." Pai argued that the new law would hurt consumers by prohibiting many free-data plans.

The legality of statewide net-neutrality laws is a matter of contention. Proponents of the California law argue that the FCC has no power to interfere with state legislation, as the FCC has no authority to regulate broadband internet access providers. Barbara van Schewick, a law professor at Stanford Law School, told CNN that the FCC's repeal of the 2015 Open Internet Order removed its authority to adopt such protections, implying that the FCC cannot prevent states from adopting net-neutrality protections.

The legal action against California is set against the backdrop of the Trump administration's ongoing conflict with Silicon Valley. Last month, President Trump cited a partisan study on Twitter suggesting Google's search results were biased against him, prompting Attorney General Jeff Sessions to announce a meeting with several state attorneys general to discuss potential competition issues and the alleged suppression of free speech on tech platforms. The Department of Justice's lawsuit against California is a more tangible threat than the meeting, which experts dismissed as groundless saber-rattling at the behest of a frustrated president.

However, the lawsuit may find support among conservatives, who have historically taken issue with California's progressive stances on various issues, such as clean energy and immigration. The lawsuit's outcome remains to be seen, but it is unlikely to be a political winner, as the majority of voters favor Obama-era net-neutrality rules.

Title: Former Michigan Governor Jennifer Granholm Criticizes Donald Trump's Rhetoric as Harmful to U.S. Democracy

Article:

Jennifer Granholm, the former governor and attorney general of Michigan, has criticized Donald Trump's rhetoric, stating that it is causing irreparable damage to the United States democracy. Granholm, who is currently a senior research fellow at UC Berkeley and senior advisor to Correct The Record, a super-PAC supporting Hillary Clinton for president in 2016, expressed her opinions in a commentary piece.

Granholm, in her piece, expressed her desire for Trump to withdraw from the presidential race, citing his lies and vitriolic rhetoric as the reasons for her stance. She referenced a best-selling book on leadership, "The Leadership Challenge" by James Kouzes and Barry Posner, stating that 89% of people across the globe identify honesty as the most important characteristic of a leader.

Granholm noted that despite Trump's frequent lies and offensive statements towards people of various races, creeds, and colors, he has managed to maintain a lead in the Republican presidential candidate polls for five months. She cited examples of Trump's fabrications, such as embellishing his golf course with historical events and spreading lies about a nonexistent video showing Muslims celebrating in New Jersey after the September 11 attacks.

Granholm criticized Trump for his refusal to acknowledge reality and his continued repetition of his lies, even when presented with facts. She described Trump's behavior as a deliberate attempt to distort reality and portray himself as above the truth, with anyone who confronts him being perceived as an unfair attacker. The media, according to Granholm, has labeled Trump as being "in a league of [his] own" when it comes to making claims that contradict reality.

Title: Fox News Criticizes Obama Administration for One-Year Extension of Canceled Insurance Policies

Article:

Fox News' program Fox & Friends, hosted by Brian Kilmeade, featured a discussion on the Obama administration's decision to allow insurance companies to extend canceled policies for an additional year. Guest C. Edmund Wright, a former health insurance agent, criticized the administration for not allowing individuals to keep their insurance policies indefinitely.

Wright argued that President Obama's decision to allow insurance companies to extend current plans for one year amounted to a "one-year death sentence" for the policies. He compared it to canceling the new Coke and only allowing consumers to have the classic Coke for a year, stating that it was an "absurd fix."

In contrast, The Washington Post's Wonkblog reported that the Obama administration will allow insurance companies to renew policies that do not meet health law standards through the end of 2014. The administration's change does not force insurers to offer their products for another year, but rather encourages them to do so.

MSNBC's Steven Rattner, an economic analyst and former Obama administration official, explained on MSNBC's Morning Joe that half of people on the individual market are there for less than six months, and another 30 percent are there between six and eighteen months.

The Washington Post's fact checker cited a study that measured insurance plans in California, showing that only 24 percent of people with individual coverage kept their plan for more than 48 months.

In a November 2009 letter to former Senator Evan Bayh, the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) explained that because of the naturally high turnover in the individual market, few grandfathered policies would still exist by 2016.

Title: Trump Issues Executive Order to Dismantle Affordable Care Act

Article:

President Donald Trump has issued his first executive order, directing federal agencies to dismantle the Affordable Care Act (ACA) to the maximum extent permitted by law. The order, a political statement about the health care law, instructs agencies to waive, defer, grant exemptions from, or delay any taxes or penalties they can.

The executive order does not grant Trump new powers but signals his intention to swiftly dismantle significant parts of the health care overhaul. Larry Levitt, vice president at the Kaiser Family Foundation, explains, "This order does not in and of itself do anything tangible, but it directs federal agencies to start taking steps to use their administrative authority to unwind the ACA in all sorts of ways. This is a signal that the Trump administration is not waiting for Congress to start making big changes."

The order's directive to dismantle provisions imposing fiscal burdens on states or individuals is seen as a potential target for the individual mandate, a contentious aspect of the ACA. The mandate requires all Americans to have health care coverage, and its implementation is crucial for the law's overall functioning.

While Trump could potentially stop enforcing the individual mandate without Congress, this executive action alone does not unravel the mandate or any other part of Obamacare. Instead, it initiates a lengthy process to change the law's rules, which takes time. Tim Jost, a health law expert and law professor at Washington and Lee College, notes, "Trump is going to have to comply with the law, and that doesn't allow him to repeal the Affordable Care Act unilaterally."

The executive order contains two crucial elements, according to Jost. First, most paragraphs in the order start with the phrase "to the maximum extent permitted by law," acknowledging that federal agencies can only take actions that do not conflict with the ACA. Second, Trump has pledged to follow the Administrative Procedure Act for new rules, a law that governs the rulemaking process, which involves drafting rules, accepting comments, holding public hearings, and ultimately issuing final rules.

In summary, Trump's executive order is a political statement signaling his intention to dismantle the ACA, but it does not have immediate tangible effects. The order sets in motion a lengthy process to change the law's rules, which will require compliance with the Administrative Procedure Act and Congressional action.

Title: Baucus Expected to be Nominated as U.S. Ambassador to China, Leaving Senate Seat Open

Article:

Senator Max Baucus, a long-serving Montana Democrat, is expected to be nominated by the White House to serve as the next U.S. ambassador to China, according to several sources familiar with the matter. Baucus began informing some of his colleagues and his staff about his upcoming nomination on Wednesday evening.

The exact timing of the appointment is unclear, but Baucus would need to be confirmed by his Senate colleagues if he leaves before his term ends. If he departs early, Baucus will relinquish his position as chair of the powerful Senate Finance Committee, where he has been aggressively pushing for a dramatic rewrite of the Tax Code.

Baucus's departure could significantly impact the 2014 Senate landscape, as he is the third longest-serving senator and seniority is highly valued in the institution. His departure could also open up a competitive Senate seat in Montana, where Democratic Governor Steve Bullock appoints the senator when there is a vacancy.

Lt. Governor John Walsh, a Democrat, is already running for the open seat against Rep. Steve Daines, a Republican. If Walsh is appointed by Bullock, he would run as an incumbent, giving him an advantage in a hotly-contested race.

Baucus's nomination had been rumored in congressional circles for the last month. The White House has not yet responded to a request for comment, and Baucus's spokesman declined to comment. However, the president and Baucus maintain friendly relations, with Baucus's long-time former staffer and close personal friend, Jim Messina, serving as Obama's campaign manager in his 2012 reelection effort.

Baucus's departure would open up a key position on the Senate Finance Committee, one of the most powerful positions in Congress given its sweeping authority over tax and health care programs. Sen. Jay Rockefeller, the liberal West Virginia Democrat, is next in line to chair the panel. Rockefeller has been coy about his intentions for the Finance Committee gavel.

Baucus has served on the Senate Finance Committee since 1979, making him the longest-serving senator on the committee in history. He has been an ally and adversary to presidents in both parties, and his departure will leave a significant void in the Senate.

Baucus's confirmation process will be handled by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which quickly approved another senator to a diplomatic post earlier this year. The specifics of Baucus's role in China, including his approach to rising tensions with Japan, China's growing economic might, and diplomatic issues involving North Korea and other regional hotspots, remain to be seen.

Title: Former CIA Director John Brennan Described as "Nonpartisan" Amidst Controversy

Article:

John Brennan, former CIA director under the Obama administration, has described himself on his Twitter account as "Nonpartisan American who is very concerned about our collective future." However, this description has been challenged as inaccurate, with some arguing that Brennan's political leanings and past actions make him a highly partisan figure.

Brennan's ascent to the CIA director position began with a lie-detector test in which he admitted to being a supporter of the Soviet-controlled American Communist party. During the 2016 election, he was accused of playing a role in setting in motion a sham investigation into the Trump campaign. Recently, NBC signed Brennan up as a "national security" correspondent, sparking criticism for giving a platform to a figure with a vested interest in the outcome of the investigation.

Congress is currently investigating Brennan for possible perjury, and his role in the Steele dossier has been a subject of controversy. NBC's decision to hire Brennan as a correspondent has been criticized, with some questioning the media's use of figures with a vested interest in the outcome of a story.

Last week, Jonathan Winer, a former State Department official, outed himself as a cog in the Obamagate scandal. He played a role in briefing John Kerry and other officials on the Hillary-financed Steele dossier during the campaign, and later passed material from Cody Shearer, another dirt-diver for Hillary, to Steele, who then gave it to the FBI.

Winer, who once tried to write a film treatment for Oliver Stone, works hard to affect a nonchalance about his role in the scandal, casting his friendship with Steele and Sidney Blumenthal in a nonpartisan light. Winer plays dumb about Shearer, calling him a "journalist" whose work he "did not know." However, once apprised of Shearer's notes by Blumenthal, Winer decided to share them with Steele to get his "professional reaction."

Susan Rice, who is also under scrutiny for her role in the scandal, recently made headlines for an "I am not guilty" note she emailed herself on her last day in office. In the note, Rice wrote about a conversation with President Obama in which he stressed that the intelligence and law enforcement communities should handle the issue "by the book." This statement has been criticized as a galling propagandistic high-wire act, with some questioning the normalcy of political espionage.

The controversy surrounding Brennan, Winer, and Rice is part of a larger debate about the role of politics in intelligence and law enforcement agencies, and the use of government power to influence elections.
