The debate has sparked calls for greater transparency and accountability in government, and has led to questions about the motivations and actions of those who rose to the top of the ruling class during the Obama administration.

Title: U.S. Imposes New Sanctions on Russia, Sparking Threats of Retaliation

Article:

The United States has announced a new round of sanctions against Russia in response to the nerve-agent attack on former spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter in the U.K. The sanctions have caused the Russian ruble to slide, with the currency reaching its lowest levels since 2016, though it later recovered some of its drop.

The U.S. administration is under pressure to take tougher steps against Russia, even as President Donald Trump has called for closer ties. The new sanctions are required under the 1991 Chemical and Biological Weapons Control and Warfare Elimination Act, which mandates punishment of countries that use chemical weapons in violation of international law.

The initial round of these sanctions will limit exports to Russia of U.S. goods and technology considered sensitive on national security grounds, including electronics, lasers, and some specialized oil and gas production technologies. Waivers will be allowed for space-flight activities and U.S. foreign assistance.

Russia's response was defiant but stopped short of specific measures pending more details on the U.S. plans. Officials said Russia may respond by imposing restrictions on trade with the U.S. under a law passed earlier this year in response to an earlier wave of penalties. That could include cutting off supplies of rocket engines needed for U.S. space launches, one official said, as well as aviation.

The additional sanctions could include a downgrading in diplomatic relations, blanket bans on the import of Russian oil and exports of "all other goods and technology" aside from agricultural products, as well as limits on loans from U.S. banks. The U.S. also would have to suspend aviation agreements and oppose any multilateral development bank assistance.

The added sanctions could be averted if President Trump declared that waiving them would be in the U.S. national interest, a politically risky move in light of criticism that he’s been too soft on Russia on issues including interference in the 2016 presidential campaign. Russia has repeatedly denied having chemical or biological weapons and held out little hope for compromise.

Title: Trump Announces Escalation of Tariffs on Chinese Goods, Stalemate in U.S.-China Trade War

Article:

President Trump has declared his intention to escalate tariffs on Chinese goods, with the first wave of tariffs on $34 billion in products set to be followed by levies on an additional $16 billion. The President has also threatened Beijing with potential tariffs on as much as $450 billion worth of Chinese goods.

At present, the resolution of this trade war remains uncertain, with both parties seemingly at an impasse. China has vowed to retaliate against the U.S., and without scheduled official talks between the two countries, a swift resolution appears unlikely.

Edward Alden, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, stated, "At the moment, I don't see how this ends. This is very much in the president's hands because he's got advisers that seem divided, some substantively, some tactically. I just don't think we've had any clear signs of the resolution he wants."

The Trump administration is engaging in trade wars on multiple fronts, imposing tariffs on foreign steel, aluminum, solar panels, and washing machines from countries including Canada, Mexico, the European Union, and Japan. However, the tariffs on China, the world's largest manufacturing hub, affect a larger share of products and a greater percentage of companies that rely on global supply chains, potentially causing more harm to American companies than the Chinese firms the Trump administration is targeting.

The President's aggressive approach toward China is intended to pressure the country to curtail what the White House describes as a pattern of unfair trade practices and theft of American intellectual property. In addition to the tariffs, the White House is imposing restrictions on investment and on visas for Chinese nationals. The administration claims these trade barriers are being used as leverage to force Beijing to make changes, including opening its markets to American companies and ending its practice of requiring firms operating in China to hand over valuable technology.

Title: Assessment of Policy Proposals in the Democratic Primary: A Closer Look at Clinton and Sanders

Article:

In the ongoing Democratic primary, the contest between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders is often framed by Clinton's supporters as a choice between an unrealistic radical with impractical proposals and a pragmatic political veteran with more achievable proposals. However, this framing raises two significant points of contention.

First, there is little evidence to suggest that less-ambitious proposals will consistently deliver better results. Second, in crucial areas, Clinton has not proposed any concrete solutions at all.

Notable economist and liberal pundit Paul Krugman, a proponent of Clinton, has presented two arguments in response to Sanders supporters who emphasize the value of far-reaching goals for political organizing and as a starting point for negotiations.

The second argument, which we will examine first, suggests that Sanders' single-payer healthcare proposal is unrealistic and would be sold with misleading cost estimates due to its supposed impossibility and the media's alleged bias against social insurance. However, a left-leaning think tank's analysis of Sanders' plan indicates that everyone outside of the top 1% would experience a net positive income, with increased taxation more than offset by the elimination of insurance premiums.

Regarding the argument that Clinton's proposals are more realistic, there is a lack of clarity on how this would significantly improve American healthcare. Clinton's health care section on her issues page does not offer a plan to address the underinsurance problem in ObamaCare or provide insurance to the approximately 30 million uninsured individuals.

Furthermore, on the critical issue of monetary policy, Krugman, who has consistently argued that the Federal Reserve's decision to hike interest rates last December was a mistake, has not mentioned this point in his critique of Sanders. Sanders is the only candidate from either party who agrees with Krugman on this issue, while Clinton's economy page does not even mention monetary policy.

Political campaigns, according to Steve Randy Waldman, serve to advance moral values and set priorities. While experienced policy people are essential for crafting legislative bills, the majority of people vote for candidates who align with their values and trust them to handle the complexities of policy.

In conclusion, while individuals are free to support whichever candidate they choose, it is important to acknowledge that there is no clear-cut policy case for Hillary Clinton, as her policy book appears to be missing some crucial pages.

Title: North Korean Leader's Letter to Trump May Indicate Divergent Views on Denuclearization

Article:

North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has reportedly written a letter to President Donald Trump, expressing his desire to meet with the U.S. President, according to an unnamed foreign official who spoke to the Wall Street Journal on Friday. The letter was hand-delivered to Trump by Kim Yong Chol, a top North Korean official, at the White House on Friday afternoon.

Trump announced that he would meet with Kim Jong Un on June 12 in Singapore, but he has yet to read the letter, stating that he could be in "for a big surprise" once he looks at it. However, the content of the letter suggests that Kim Jong Un does not express a desire for his country to make any concessions regarding denuclearization, despite not threatening the U.S. in any way.

The Trump administration has been advocating for North Korea to agree to complete, verifiable, and irreversible denuclearization (CVID) quickly, which would require Pyongyang to dismantle its nuclear program swiftly. However, North Korea reportedly prefers a phased approach, in which both Washington and Pyongyang make concessions over a long period of time. This could mean North Korea allows inspectors to view its nuclear sites in exchange for the U.S. diplomatically recognizing the Kim regime.

The divergent views on denuclearization could potentially foreshadow a bigger problem later on. Some experts believe that the summit might address these concerns and help narrow the gap between the two sides. Joseph Yun, a US Institute of Peace expert and former top North Korea negotiator in the Trump administration, stated that the meeting could lead to a "meaningful dialogue towards an eventual resolution."

Trump is planning to spend the weekend at Camp David discussing the U.S. agenda for the possible summit. However, it remains unclear what, exactly, he will do after reading the North Korean leader's note.

Title: Giuliani Denies McGahn Flipping, Accuses Mueller Team of Leaking Information

Article:

Trump attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani refuted speculation on Sunday that White House counsel Donald McGahn had cooperated with the special counsel in an attempt to implicate President Trump, accusing investigators of leaking information about McGahn's cooperation with the special counsel in order to lure the president into a perjury trap.

During an appearance on NBC's "Meet the Press," Giuliani stated, "They're down to desperation time. They have to write a report, and they don't have a single bit of evidence."

The New York Times, citing multiple unidentified sources, reported Saturday that McGahn had spent 30 hours over three days answering questions as part of special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian election interference. The report fueled comparisons to Nixon White House counsel John Dean's decision to switch sides during the Watergate investigation.

However, former Trump attorney John Dowd dismissed such comparisons, stating, "Pure fiction on claims of pushback by McGahn," and describing him as a "terrific witness" for the president. Dowd also defended the Trump administration's open-book legal strategy of providing extensive access to witnesses and documents.

McGahn's attorney, William A. Burck, released a statement confirming that his client had cooperated fully. In the statement, Burck said, "President Trump, through counsel, declined to assert any privilege over Mr. McGahn's testimony, so Mr. McGahn answered the Special Counsel team's questions fulsomely and honestly, as any person interviewed by federal investigators must."

Giuliani accused the special counsel's office of leaking the report to spur Trump into testifying and setting him up for a perjury charge by having him contradict statements by former FBI Director James B. Comey about former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn.

In a statement, the New York Times communications department said the newspaper "stands behind the reporting of our Pulitzer Prize-winning reporters." This article is based on information from multiple sources, as stated in the original text. However, the sources remain unidentified, and their identities are not available in the provided text.

Giuliani also accused the special counsel's team of panicking because "they know they don't have a case, there was no collusion, there was no obstruction, they can't prove it, and they are trying to get the president to testify." He added that the president has turned over 1.4 million documents, encouraged more than 30 witnesses, including McGahn, to testify, and declined to assert executive privilege as part of his commitment to transparency.

The article concludes with Giuliani's statement that the president's decision to decline to assert executive and attorney-client privilege has come into question, but Dowd stated, "It was smarter to be transparent and get the case over with." Dowd also noted that the alternative was a "nightmare, just a war."

Title: Sanders Emerges as Front-Runner in Democratic Presidential Race, Offering New Direction for America

Article:

In the aftermath of the Nevada caucuses, Bernie Sanders has taken the lead in the Democratic presidential race. While former Vice President Joe Biden is favored in the upcoming South Carolina primary, bolstered by his support among African American voters, Sanders has gained momentum following his wins in the first three contests.

In Nevada, Sanders demonstrated the breadth of his growing coalition, leading the field among men and women, whites and Latinos, union households and non-union households, voters of all ages except those over 65, Democrats who identified as liberals, moderates, and conservatives.

Sanders, along with Elizabeth Warren, has presented Americans with a new direction, advocating for a modern version of Franklin D. Roosevelt's Economic Bill of Rights. This includes proposals such as Medicare for all, tuition-free public education, universal day care, and a Green New Deal to address climate change while generating jobs. Both candidates plan to fund these initiatives by taxing the wealthy and corporations to invest in public goods.

Other candidates, including Biden, Amy Klobuchar, Pete Buttigieg, and Mike Bloomberg, have criticized these ideas as too radical, bold, costly, and ambitious. They offer a continuation of politics as they were before Donald Trump's presidency. However, the problem with this approach, as the article points out, is that it does not offer much hope for most Americans.

Sanders identifies as a "democratic socialist," while Warren prefers the label "making markets work." Yet, their agendas are substantially similar, with the key difference being in labels, not substance.

The term "democratic socialism" has already become a topic of debate, with some fearmongering and red-baiting. Critics, such as Trump and Mike Bloomberg, have portrayed Sanders' and Warren's views on wealth taxation as communist. As Sanders continues to gain momentum or if Warren gains traction, voters can expect to hear more of these arguments.

However, it is essential to remember that the important word in "democratic socialism" is democratic, not socialist. Sanders is not advocating for making America into Cuba or Venezuela; instead, he is proposing extending social guarantees like those offered in most other advanced industrial states, such as Denmark and Sweden. These countries have universal health care at lower cost, paid family leave, guaranteed paid vacations, higher minimum wages, more generous public retirement programs, vibrant and competitive economies, lower inequality, less poverty, and higher life expectancies.

Sanders is seeking a popular mandate from voters to move in this direction. When considering democratic socialism, it is crucial to remember programs that Republicans and conservatives, as well as corporate lobbies, denounced as socialistic when they were first introduced, such as Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, environmental and consumer protection, banking regulation to protect consumers.

The Federal Aviation Administration, which manages civil aviation and international waters, is a state program. The Food and Drug Administration, which ensures drug safety, is a state program. The minimum wage, food stamps, public housing could all be considered democratic socialist programs.

Our problem has been that we have too much socialism for the rich and the powerful—subsidies for corporations, get-out-of-jail-free cards for crooked bankers, tax breaks for the rich that leave them paying a lower tax rate than their secretaries, monopoly power for corporations that allows them to gouge customers—and too little shared security—democratic socialism—for working people: affordable health care, a living wage, guaranteed paid vacation and family leave, universal childcare, affordable college, public mobilization to deal with the threat of climate change.

When I ran for the presidency, I did not use the label, although some tried to slur me as a socialist or a communist. However, the label does not make a difference. The question is one of direction, not name-calling; of program, not posturing.

Dr. Martin Luther King, often smeared as a "red" or a communist, was clear on this matter. In 1966, he confided to his staff:

"You can't talk about solving the economic problem of the Negro without talking about billions of dollars. You can't talk about ending the slums without first saying profit must be taken out of the slums. You're really tampering and getting on dangerous ground because you are messing with folk then. You are messing with captains of industry. Now this means that we are treading in difficult water, because it really means that we are saying that something is wrong with capitalism. There must be a better distribution of wealth, and maybe America must move toward a democratic socialism."

Therefore, it is crucial to set aside the fearmongering and the red-baiting and focus instead on the substance. There is no question we need big structural change, as Elizabeth Warren puts it. We need a better distribution of wealth and a greater protection of basic human rights like the right to affordable health care, as Sanders argues.

Call it capitalism with a conscience, democratic socialism, or lemonade. It's the substance, not the label, that counts.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Vows Legal Action to Secure Testimony of Former White House Counsel Don McGahn

Article:

In a move that could escalate into another high-profile battle, the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, Jerry Nadler, has vowed to pursue legal action to secure the testimony of former White House Counsel Don McGahn. This decision comes after McGahn defied a subpoena and skipped a committee hearing at President Trump's direction.

According to Nadler, Trump's actions amount to witness intimidation. "When this committee issues a subpoena, even to a senior presidential adviser, the witness must show up. Our subpoenas are not optional," Nadler stated at the hearing that McGahn did not attend.

On Monday, Nadler hinted at the possibility of contempt charges, stating, "I can not emphasize this enough — the chairman’s track record demonstrates he does not actually want information, he wants the fight, but not the truth."

The president directed McGahn not to appear for the committee hearing, citing a Justice Department opinion that he cannot be compelled to testify about his official duties. In a statement, White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders described the subpoena for McGahn as part of Democrats' continued pursuit of Trump investigations.

The related Department of Justice memo asserts that McGahn, like other senior advisers to a president, has "immunity" from being compelled to testify about his official duties. The committee announced the hearing last week, but it was initially unclear whether McGahn would appear due to the ongoing battle between congressional Democrats and the White House over his testimony.

The House committee's subpoena, issued amid a fight over access to the unredacted Mueller report, called for McGahn to appear before the panel to testify and provide documents related to the Mueller investigation. The battle over McGahn's testimony is just one front in the clash between the White House and congressional Democrats.

Earlier this month, the committee voted to hold Attorney General Bill Barr in contempt for defying a subpoena for Mueller’s full and unredacted report, as well as underlying evidence and documents used in the investigation. Trump, prior to the vote, asserted executive privilege over the materials in a bid to protect them from being turned over to the committee. The full House has yet to take a final vote on whether to hold Barr in contempt of Congress.

Title: Mental Health Evaluation of Vester Flanagan: A Look at Delusional Thinking and Its Potential Impact

Article:

The shooting incident at WDBJ7 in Virginia, which resulted in the death of a journalist and cameraman, has brought to light the complex and often unpredictable nature of human behavior. Vester Flanagan, the shooter, reportedly showed signs of being an angry, disgruntled individual or a psychotic individual with delusional beliefs.

In a reflection on his professional experience as a psychiatrist, the author discusses the evaluation of individuals with paranoia, a type of psychotic delusion, that focuses on perceived threats from the government or individuals. It is unclear whether Flanagan's actions were driven by a personal grudge, narcissism, or delusional thinking.

The author recounts a case from his past where a patient believed his friend was secretly undermining his successful corporation. The seemingly innocuous question about the friend's Chinese investors was interpreted as evidence of a plot against him. This illustrates how delusional, psychotic thinking can distort and exaggerate seemingly innocuous events or statements.

The author concludes by emphasizing the importance of recognizing and addressing delusional thinking in individuals who exhibit extreme and irrational behavior. Employers or family members should consider whether such behavior is a manifestation of irritability or a reflection of a deeper, intractable, delusional perspective on the people in their lives and the events around them.

At the time of writing, it remains unclear whether anyone in Flanagan's life was able to make this determination before the tragic incident occurred. The author's account serves as a reminder of the potential dangers of delusional thinking and the importance of early intervention and support for individuals exhibiting such behaviors.

Title: Is Washington's Political Gridlock a Myth? Scholar Argues U.S. Policymakers Perform Better Than Expected

Article:

A senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, Pietro Nivola, has argued that the ongoing criticism of Washington's political system as dysfunctional may be misguided. In a recent analysis, Nivola suggests that, when measured against the challenge of recovering from the Great Recession, U.S. politicians have performed better than their counterparts in other advanced democracies.

Since the financial crisis of 2008, Congress has passed significant legislation, including the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP), the rescue of the domestic auto industry, the extension of the Bush-era tax cuts, and an enormous stimulus bill. Nivola describes Congress's inability to pass more recent budget and tax measures as a "useful stasis," meaning that had the House and Senate agreed on a course of action, the ideas might have done more harm.

However, Nivola acknowledges concerns about how Congress will respond to the fiscal challenges it faces after the November election. The combination of a fresh expiration date for the Bush tax cuts and a spate of automatic spending cuts could lead to what is variously being described as "the fiscal cliff" and "taxmaggedon."

Bill Connelly, a political scientist at Washington and Lee University in Virginia and author of the book "James Madison Rules America," suggests that Congress's partisan brinkmanship is a feature, not a bug, in the American system of checks and balances. Connelly argues that Congress's last-minute deal-making is a long-standing tradition, comparing it to college students who do their work at the last minute when deadlines are looming.

Not everyone shares this optimistic view. Even when Washington does manage to find a resolution, the process of legislative sausage-making has become so open and ugly that some worry bad congressional habits and bipartisan disagreements have become problems in and of themselves. Just last month, the governor of "the other Washington," Democrat Christine Gregoire, complained that Congress's last-minute deal in August to raise the debt ceiling and avoid a government shutdown had almost instantly cost Washington state $1.4 billion in projected economic growth, as consumer confidence took a hit.

Sarah Binder, a colleague of Nivola's at Brookings and a Congress watcher at George Washington University in Washington, D.C., notes that even if the president and Congress do reach an agreement, that may not be good enough. "There's a cost to that type of legislating," Binder says. "Even if at the end of the day we stare at the abyss and reach agreement, that's probably not good enough."

Title: Top 10 Delusional Moments in the 2012 Presidential Campaign Revealed by Campaign Strategists

Article:

In a candid gathering at Harvard University, top strategists from the 2012 presidential campaigns discussed their regrets and mistakes during the eight-hour event. The conference, sponsored by the Institute of Politics since 1972, featured representatives from all GOP primary campaigns and the president's team.

Here are the top 10 delusional moments of the 2012 election, as told by those who lived it:

1. Romney strategist Stuart Stevens defended the much-mocked TV ad the Romney campaign ran in the closing weeks of its Ohio campaign, which claimed that President Obama took GM and Chrysler into bankruptcy and sold Chrysler to Italians who were going to build Jeeps in China. The ad was widely criticized as misleading, and Chrysler quickly issued a statement denying the claim.

2. Romney's strategists believed that having Clint Eastwood speak at the GOP convention in Tampa would draw a larger viewing audience. However, Eastwood's antics, including speaking to an empty chair, ended up becoming the story of the night, upstaging Romney's convention address.

3. Romney's campaign team believed that Rick Perry's back problems would not significantly impact his performance in the debates. However, Perry's back pain was evident during the debates, and his performance was widely criticized.

4. The Romney campaign believed that the "47%" video, in which Romney privately expressed his disdain for 47% of the American people, would not have a significant impact on the election. However, the video was leaked to the media, and it was widely criticized as revealing Romney's true feelings about the electorate.

5. The Romney campaign believed that the "binders full of women" comment, in which Romney discussed his efforts to hire women during his time as governor of Massachusetts, would not be a significant issue. However, the comment was widely criticized as insensitive and tone-deaf.

6. The Romney campaign believed that the "horses and bayonets" comment, in which Romney criticized President Obama's military strategy, would not be a significant issue. However, the comment was widely criticized as showing a lack of understanding of military affairs.

7. The Romney campaign believed that the "self-deportation" policy, in which Romney suggested that undocumented immigrants would self-deport if certain conditions were met, would be a viable solution to the immigration issue. However, the policy was widely criticized as inhumane and unrealistic.

8. The Romney campaign believed that the "Big Bird" comment, in which Romney suggested cutting funding for public broadcasting, would not be a significant issue. However, the comment was widely criticized as showing a lack of understanding of the importance of public broadcasting.

9. The Romney campaign believed that the "binders full of women" comment, in which Romney discussed his efforts to hire women during his time as governor of Massachusetts, would not be a significant issue. However, the comment was widely criticized as insensitive and tone-deaf.

10. The Romney campaign believed that the "you didn't build that" comment, in which President Obama was criticized for suggesting that businesses did not succeed on their own, would not be a significant issue. However, the comment was widely criticized as showing a lack of understanding of the role of government in the economy.

The conference offered insights into how a campaign can delude itself in an attempt to win the presidency. The GOP strategists were candid about their mistakes and regrets, while the Obama strategists shot back with their own perspectives on the impact of the GOP's decisions.

Title: U.S., Other Countries Implement Export Bans on Protective Equipment and Hydroxychloroquine

Article:

In recent weeks, several countries, including the United States, Turkey, Ukraine, Thailand, Taiwan, Indonesia, Bangladesh, Pakistan, South Africa, Ecuador, France, Germany, and India, have imposed export bans on protective masks and related equipment to secure their domestic supplies amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

Last week, the Trump administration invoked a Korean War-era law to restrict exports of U.S.-made protective masks, directing American companies producing such items overseas to prioritize domestic markets. One American company, 3M, stated that halting planned overseas shipments could endanger health workers in Canada and Latin America. On Monday, 3M announced a compromise with the government, agreeing to send some masks to the U.S. and some overseas.

India, the world's largest producer of hydroxychloroquine, an anti-malarial drug being tested for potential benefits against the virus, has also banned exports of the drug, allowing limited shipments under specific circumstances. Britain has prohibited exports of hydroxychloroquine, while Hungary has banned exports of the raw material for the drug and medicines containing it.

Mariangela Simao, assistant director-general for medicines and health products at the World Health Organization in Geneva, stated, "The export bans are not helpful. They can disrupt supply chains of some products that are actually needed everywhere."

President Trump has been vocal in securing an American stockpile of hydroxychloroquine, disregarding the advice of federal scientists who have warned that testing remains minimal, with limited evidence of benefits.

Satish Kumar, an adjunct professor at the International Institute of Health Management Research in New Delhi, commented, "In this situation, each country has to take care of itself. If we are not able to take care of our population, it will be a very critical situation."

Title: Study Suggests Protests May Have Slowed COVID-19 Spread in Cities with Large Demonstrations

Article:

A new study by a nationwide research team, including a University of Colorado Denver professor, has found that protests against racism and police violence may have slowed the overall spread of the coronavirus in cities with large demonstrations, including Denver.

The study, which has not yet been peer-reviewed, used official coronavirus case counts and anonymous, aggregated cell phone data to analyze the impact of protests on the overall transmission of the virus within the entire community. The team found that protests correlated with a net increase in overall stay-at-home behavior in cities where they occurred, and the increase was larger in cities that saw more sustained protests or reports of violence.

The study looked at 315 American cities with populations of over 100,000 and found that 281 of those cities saw protests. The remaining 34 cities, which included Aurora at the time, were used as a control group against which to measure the impact of the protests. The researchers found that protests correlated with a net increase in overall stay-at-home behavior in cities where they occurred, and the increase was larger in cities that saw more sustained protests or reports of violence.

The study also found that, with greater social distancing, COVID case growth slowed in cities with protests from what would be expected, but not by a statistically significant amount. The authors note that there may be other explanations for the trends. Overall, though, they say the data show that any resurgence in coronavirus cases can't be pinned entirely on the protests.

"Public speech and public health did not trade off against each other in this case," the authors wrote in the paper.

The study's findings come as officials in Colorado and other states are concerned about rising infections, especially among young people. New infections among young people have contributed significantly to Colorado's uptick in cases in recent days, reversing a weeks-long trend of falling case numbers and putting Colorado back onto the list of potential coronavirus problem spots. Meanwhile, the number of new infections among older Coloradans has dropped.

With the July 4 holiday approaching, Gov. Jared Polis and county health officials have pleaded with people to be responsible and avoid large gatherings. "We don't have the direct causation of this uptick," Polis told reporters last week, noting that there is evidence that some young people who are part of an outbreak in Boulder had attended protests while other outbreaks are tied to social gatherings. "And we hope this is a trend that is reversed in our state."

On Monday, a spokesman for the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment said that, while the state has now seen rising numbers of new cases for two consecutive weeks, "we have not seen any clear association between the protests and an increase in cases." The spokesman, Ian Dickson, said the uptick in infections "may be partly due to some Coloradans changing their behavior — especially socializing in larger groups, sometimes without proper distancing or mask wearing."

The study's authors note that their research does not attempt to figure out whether the protests spread the virus among the people at the protest. Instead, they say the research took the bigger-picture view: What did the protests mean for overall transmission of the virus within the entire community?

"An outdoor wedding doesn't generate avoidance behavior; we're measuring avoidance behavior," said Andrew Friedson, the CU-Denver professor who is one of the paper's co-authors. "People don't say, 'Oh man, there's an outdoor wedding next door, we should stay home.'"

The study's findings do not provide a green light for governments to fully reopen bars, concert venues, and other places where people gather in large numbers. The key to the researcher's conclusions is that the protests, while receiving lots of support, were ultimately things most people decided to avoid. That's not true of many other large gatherings.

Title: Facebook Announces Redesign of Privacy Controls Amidst Data Privacy Concerns

Article:

Social media giant Facebook has announced an overhaul of its privacy controls, aiming to make them more accessible and user-friendly. However, the changes do not alter Facebook's existing privacy policies or the types of data it collects from its users.

The redesign will be implemented in the coming weeks, according to a post on Facebook's blog. Notable changes include a consolidation of privacy settings for mobile devices, which will appear on a single screen instead of being spread across 20 different ones. Additionally, Facebook is introducing a new Privacy Shortcuts menu to simplify the process of finding privacy, security, and advertising information.

Facebook's history is marked by repeated promises of privacy updates, only to reiterate these efforts in response to subsequent controversies. In 2008, Facebook pledged to introduce "privacy updates that give users more control." This language was almost repeated two years later, when Facebook announced an update would introduce "more powerful controls." In the latest statement, Facebook vowed to "put people more in control of their privacy."

Jessi Hempel, a senior writer at Wired, told CBSN, "Facebook is saying, 'I've made things easier for you, but I've also revealed to you how hard it was' to control your privacy. Facebook had a trust problem before this. This turns a problem into a crisis."

The privacy update may not necessarily alleviate consumer doubts, according to Josh Feldmeth, senior partner at marketing consultancy Prophet. "Facebook is saying, 'I've made things easier for you, but I've also revealed to you how hard it was' to control your privacy. Facebook had a trust problem before this. This turns a problem into a crisis."

The announcement follows growing criticism of Facebook's data-privacy policies in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, which involved the harvesting of data from as many as 50 million Facebook users for political messaging purposes. It remains unclear whether the changes will persuade users who have deleted their Facebook accounts to rejoin the service, or whether they will appease lawmakers and privacy advocates who have expressed concerns about Facebook's collection and use of personal data.

Facebook's chief privacy officer Erin Egan and deputy general counsel Ashlie Beringer stated, "We've heard loud and clear that privacy settings and other important tools are too hard to find. In the coming weeks, we'll be proposing updates to Facebook's terms of service that include our commitments to people."

Title: Multiple People Injured in Shooting Incident Near New Orleans' French Quarter

Article:

A shooting rampage in the early hours of Sunday near the French Quarter of New Orleans left ten individuals wounded, with revelers from an annual football game scrambling for cover and police in pursuit of at least one suspect. The incident occurred on Canal Street near Bourbon Street, an area known for its tourist population and police presence, even at 3:20 a.m.

New Orleans Police Department Superintendent Shaun Ferguson stated that the shooting erupted in this area due to the annual Bayou Classic football game between Grambling State University and Southern University, which had been played the previous day. The game historically attracts a large crowd to the city.

Two of the injured individuals were hospitalized in critical condition, and no officers were among the wounded, according to Ferguson. One person was detained near the scene, but Ferguson did not yet know if this individual played a role in the shooting. No arrests had been made as of Sunday.

Ferguson described the incident as a "cowardly and senseless act" that the city will not tolerate. He emphasized that the investigation is in its early stages, but they will not rest until they identify and apprehend those responsible.

Initially, police reported ten people were wounded, later raised the number to eleven, and then dropped it back to ten. Few other details were released, but Ferguson stated that officers thought they were being fired upon and were within feet of the incident, yet unable to determine who was firing the shots due to the large crowd.

The motive for the shooting has not been determined, and Ferguson did not have names, genders, or ages for the wounded individuals. Police are interviewing witnesses and searching for surveillance and other video that might provide insight into the case.

Ferguson urged the public to leave their guns at home, and he noted that violent crime in the city has been declining for four years. State police and federal authorities are aiding the investigation.

Kenneth Culbreth, a witness, told nola.com he was heading to the Canal Street CVS to make a quick purchase when he heard gunshots. "I heard pops. It was so many, I couldn’t keep count," he said.

Mayor LaToya Cantrell described the shootings as an "ugly disruption" to an otherwise beautiful weekend in the city of 400,000 people. She and Ferguson noted that the city has made significant progress in reducing violent crime over the past four years.

"The city of New Orleans will not allow incidents like this to derail the progress we have made or to further disrupt our community," Cantrell said. "This tragedy will not define us, and it will not deter us from moving our city forward and keeping our people safe."

Title: Trump Discusses Separation from Business Empire, Emoluments Clause Debated

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump stated on Wednesday that distancing himself from his business empire is a routine matter and not as complex as the media portrays it to be. He also mentioned that the American public was aware of the scale of his business ventures before the election.

"That's very routine, honestly - it's a very routine thing," Trump told reporters. "It's not a big deal. You people are making that a big deal, the business."

Trump had initially planned to hold a press conference on December 15 to discuss his plans for separating himself from his hotel and golf course empire before his inauguration. However, he postponed this conference. He indicated that he would hold a press conference in early January instead.

"It's a much bigger business than anybody thought. It's a great business, but I'm going to have nothing to do with it," Trump said on Wednesday. "I don't have to because, as you know, I wouldn't have to do that by law, but I want to do that because I want to focus on the country."

Trump further explained that he ran for office with the public knowing about his extensive business interests. "I don't have to do it [step away from the business] by law, but I want to do that because I want to focus on the country," he said.

Scholars are currently debating whether the Emoluments Clause in the U.S. Constitution, which prohibits elected officials from accepting gifts from foreign governments, would still pose issues for Trump even if he separates himself from his business. This debate arises due to Trump's announced plans to hand control of his businesses to his adult sons.

Trump was accompanied by legendary boxing promoter Don King during the press briefing. He is holding meetings this week at his Mar-a-Lago club in Florida.

Title: Republicans Launch Oversight Hearings on Obamacare Website Issues

Article:

The ongoing implementation of the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, is facing scrutiny from Republicans, particularly in relation to the problems encountered during the rollout of the health care exchanges' enrollment website. The House Energy and Commerce Committee, led by Chairman Fred Upton (R-Michigan), has scheduled a hearing for next Thursday to address these issues.

Upton has requested officials from the Department of Health and Human Services to brief his committee on the problems with the website, as well as to provide records of their communications with website contractors regarding the site's launch and the issues users have faced.

In addition, the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, led by Chairman Darrell Issa, has demanded information about the rollout problems from Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius. This request was joined by Sen. Lamar Alexander, the ranking Republican on the Senate committee on health, education, labor, and pensions.

One issue that has arisen is the ability to log in to healthcare.gov. A senior administration official told CNN that some users, particularly those who signed up early on, have experienced difficulties logging in, but the administration is working on a solution. There has also been conflicting information regarding whether some passwords were deleted if they were created in the first week or so after the launch.

Secretary Sebelius acknowledged the website's rocky launch but emphasized that improvements are being made to expedite the enrollment process. However, some Republicans have called for Sebelius to resign, citing the delays and technical failures.

When asked about accountability for the website's problems, White House Press Secretary Jay Carney stated, "The people who are responsible for making it work are hard at work, fixing the problems that need to be fixed." Carney focused on the benefits the uninsured Americans are now entitled to, stating that the goal is for those who have been shut out of affordable health care options in the past to have those options available to them.

Former White House spokesman Robert Gibbs suggested that, when the website is fixed, those responsible for the problems should be dismissed. Public attention has been focused more on the shutdown fight this month than the problems with enrolling in the exchanges, but with the shutdown ended, part of the emerging Republican message is that the problems with the Obamacare website reflect broader problems with the law overall.

Rep. John Fleming (R-Louisiana) stated, "I think this is emblematic of how problematic this is going to be in the future." Fleming suggested that the implementation of the individual mandate, requiring people to obtain health care, should be delayed. A spokeswoman for Sebelius, however, stated that the online enrollment process is proceeding.

Title: Intensified Fighting in Gaza Strip Following Collapse of Ceasefire; Israel Accuses Hamas of Capturing Soldier

Article:

The fighting in the Gaza Strip has intensified after a truce brokered by the United States and the United Nations was left in tatters. Israel and Hamas, the Islamist group that governs Gaza, each accused the other of violating the ceasefire, which was intended to last for three days and initiate talks for a more lasting settlement.

The truce, the latest attempt to halt fighting that entered its 26th day today, was aimed at reducing the Palestinian death toll, which, according to the Gaza Health Ministry, has surpassed 1,600 due to Israeli air, ground, and naval bombardments. Israel has reported over 60 military personnel and three civilian casualties in their battle against militants who have fired rockets and infiltrated through underground tunnels.

Israel alleges that militants use Gaza civilians as human shields by placing rocket launchers and weapons caches in or near homes, mosques, hospitals, and schools. The Israeli military reported hitting approximately 200 targets since the ceasefire unraveled, bringing the total number of strikes to over 4,500 since the conflict began on July 8.

As the violence escalates, the U.S. House and Senate have approved $225 million in emergency funding for Israel's Iron Dome missile-defense system. The military claims that Iron Dome has intercepted 549 rockets fired at urban areas, including three today. In total, militants have launched 3,030 rockets since the conflict began, according to the military.

President Barack Obama has stated that the U.S. will resume efforts to halt the fighting. "It's going to be very hard to put a ceasefire back together again if Israelis and the international community can't feel confident that Hamas will follow through," he said yesterday at the White House.

Al-Qedra, a spokesman for the Gaza Health Ministry, accused Israel of violating the truce by shelling Rafah in southern Gaza. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stated that Hamas breached the accord by attacking Israeli forces an hour after the ceasefire began, resulting in the death of two soldiers and the suspected capture of a third. Israel identified the missing soldier as Hadar Goldin, 23.

Israeli army spokesman Lt. Col. Peter Lerner stated that troops destroying a tunnel were attacked by militants, and it "looks like" a soldier was taken back through the tunnel. Goldin's father, Simcha, a professor of Judaic Studies at Tel Aviv University, expressed hope that the army would continue searching for his son in Gaza until he is safely returned.

Hamas's military wing denied capturing an Israeli soldier. The Ezzedeen al-Qassam Brigades stated that Israeli ground forces entered Rafah at 2 a.m. yesterday, and a gunfight that broke out at 7 a.m. continued after the ceasefire took effect. Al-Qassam has no information about the missing Israeli soldier, his whereabouts, or the circumstances of his disappearance.

Secretary of State John Kerry, who helped arrange the accord, condemned the killing of the Israeli soldiers and the suspected abduction as an "outrageous violation" of the truce. Israel demands that Hamas, which is considered a terrorist organization by the U.S., the European Union, and Israel, should be disarmed under any agreement, while Hamas demands the lifting of an Israeli-Egyptian embargo on the territory.

The start of the ceasefire was to be followed by negotiations in Cairo, with delegations from Israel, Hamas, the Palestinian Authority, Egypt, and the U.S. involved. Egypt's Foreign Ministry stated yesterday that the invitation still stands, though there was no indication any talks would be held. Hamas's allies, Turkey and Qatar, were also involved in the talks that led up to the truce announcement. Kerry has been in contact with both countries since news broke of the missing Israeli soldier, according to a U.S. official who asked not to be identified due to the sensitivity of the talks.

Title: Obama Administration Releases Data on Payments to Doctors and Hospitals by Pharmaceutical and Medical Device Companies

Article:

The Obama administration has, for the first time, released data detailing consulting fees, grants, travel expenses, and other gifts that companies have paid to American doctors and teaching hospitals. The data, mandated by the health care law, is part of the Open Payments program and covers disbursements from pharmaceutical companies and medical device manufacturers to over 546,000 physicians and 1,360 teaching hospitals from August 2013 to December 2013. The total amount disbursed is $3.5 billion.

Beginning in June, the reports will be published annually and will include 12 months of data, as announced by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS). CMS Administrator Marilyn Tavenner stated, "CMS is committed to transparency, and this is an opportunity for the public to learn about the relationships among health care providers and pharmaceutical and device companies."

The move is being praised by some as a win for transparency, as public interest groups warn that doctors' prescribing behavior could be affected by financial influence from the companies. However, others have expressed concerns about the data's completeness or accuracy. During testing, some physicians found they had been linked to payments that went to doctors with the same name.

CMS stated that payments do not necessarily imply wrongdoing on the part of doctors and teaching hospitals, and they did not parse out which payments may be beneficial or imply underhanded dealing. Shantanu Agrawal, deputy administrator and director of CMS's Center for Program Integrity, said, "We are simply making the data available to the public."

America's Health Insurance Plans (AHIP), the main lobby group for insurers, stated, "The payments, while not nefarious in every case, are a perfect symbol for the misaligned incentives in our health care system." AHIP spokesman Brendan Buck added, "While most health care stakeholders are working together to find ways to lower costs, drugmakers remain focused on strategies to keep them inflated."

Approximately 40 percent of the records do not name the individuals involved in the payments, at least for now, while parties cross-check the information. The agency did not publish more than 190,000 payments, which is stipulated by law because the transactions involved research and disclosure must be withheld for four years or until the product at hand is approved by the FDA, officials said.

Sen. Chuck Grassley, an Iowa Republican, spearheaded the movement to release the data through his Physician Payments Sunshine Act, which passed as part of the Affordable Care Act in 2010. In an op-ed for the Des Moines Register, Mr. Grassley stated that he pushed the legislation because "it started to become clear how little public information exists on the financial relationships between doctors and pharmaceutical and medical device companies." He acknowledged that the database was incomplete and would improve over time, as well as the debate around the data's release.

"The doctors rightly point out that such payments are perfectly legal, unlike kickbacks to steer prescribers toward certain drugs," he wrote. "But studies have shown that exposure to a prescription drug on the lecture circuit or in the lab leads to more prescriptions for that drug, whether the doctor feels influenced or not."

Title: University of Chicago Professor Reinstated After Controversial Tweet on Black Lives Matter and Police Funding

Article:

A University of Chicago professor, Harold Uhlig, has been reinstated as the head of the Journal of Political Economy following a 10-day investigation into a tweet he made regarding the Black Lives Matter movement and police funding. The tweet, which suggested "train them better" instead of "defund the police," sparked a petition demanding his resignation and criticism from prominent economists like Janet Yellen and Paul Krugman.

Uhlig's tweet, however, was not a belittlement of the concerns of the less fortunate, as some claimed. According to Robby Soave, a senior editor at ███ magazine who covers the new "woke" protests, Uhlig's views differed from the protesters, leading to him being labeled a racist.

The incident is part of a growing trend where individuals are being targeted and silenced for expressing views that differ from the prevailing narrative of certain social movements. David Shor, an analyst at Democratic polling firm Civis Analytics, faced similar backlash after tweeting a study that concluded "race riots reduced Democratic vote share."

Shor was attacked on social media, and despite issuing a groveling apology, he was ultimately fired. Soave points out this "cruel streak in activism that says, 'If you disagree with me…you have no right to speak.'"

The case of Uhlig and Shor is not isolated. A Boeing executive was forced out for opposing women's service in the military—30 years ago. A Los Angeles soccer team fired a player because his wife posted racist comments. Michigan State pushed out a physicist when a twitter mob from its "Graduate Employees Union" labeled him a "scientific racist."

In another high-profile case, Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling is being labeled "transphobic" for her views on gender and trans issues. Despite facing backlash, including being refused work by some staff at her publisher and actors in her Harry Potter movies, Rowling has remained vocal and unapologetic.

The trend of silencing dissenting voices extends to academia as well. A physicist at Michigan State was pushed out after being labeled a "scientific racist" for rejecting the idea that scientists should categorically exclude the possibility of average genetic differences among groups.

Soave emphasizes the importance of challenging these individuals and movements that seek to silence dissenting voices. "We just have to speak up," he says. The University of Chicago and Rowling's publisher, among others, have taken a stand in support of free speech. The solution, according to Soave, is to challenge these people and speak up.

Title: Turkey-Russia Tensions Over Syrian Airspace Highlight Challenges in Building an International Coalition Against IS

Article:

The shoot-down of a Russian fighter jet by Turkey on Tuesday highlights the difficulties in building a broad international coalition to destroy the Islamic State (IS), also known as ISIS. Over a year after President Obama announced the creation of a coalition of more than 50 countries to "degrade and ultimately destroy" IS, there is still no effective alliance of major powers.

French President François Hollande, who was at the White House on Tuesday and will be in Russia on Friday, has made building a coalition his goal in the wake of the Paris attacks. However, the same challenge remains: the major players deeply mistrust one another's intentions and visions for a post-Islamic State Syria.

Barry Strauss, a military historian at Cornell University in Ithaca, NY, states, "It was never going to be easy to build a coalition against ISIS, given the complicated relations and competing alliances around the Syrian conflict. But clearly, an event of this seriousness between Russia and Turkey will only make that effort more difficult."

Turkey and Russia exemplify the complex and often contradictory motives that Mr. Hollande will try to manage. The anti-IS coalition supposedly has similar aims to Turkey's: the removal from power of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad as a key step toward reducing IS's allure for Syrian Sunnis. However, it took months of sustained diplomatic effort for the United States to bring Turkey on board. Even now, the differences between the US and Turkey remain pronounced.

From the US perspective, perhaps the most effective fighters against IS have been Syrian and Iraqi Kurds – so much so that the US has sent special operations forces to the region to help them. However, Turkey has a large Kurdish population and worries that empowering Kurds anywhere in the region might create trouble at home.

In fact, Turkey has been "friendlier towards ISIS than Russia" because of Turkey's satisfaction with the setbacks that IS has dealt Syria's Kurdish rebels.

Similarly, many countries in the region "find ISIS useful to have around and are in no rush to get rid of it" because it is virulently anti-Shiite, Professor Strauss notes. In that way, IS acts "as a counterbalance to Iran and the Shiite parties in the region."

For its part, Russia says it entered the Syrian conflict to defeat Syria's "terrorists," but analysts say its airstrikes in Syria have focused on Assad's opponents. Only about a quarter have been against IS, experts say.

Getting Turkey and Russia on the same page for destroying IS – a priority for neither – was always going to be difficult. After the Russian jet shoot-down, the task will be even harder when Hollande meets with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Friday.

Mr. Putin called the downing of the Russian jet a "stab in the back" carried out by "accomplices of terrorists," and he warned that the perpetrators of the "crime" will face "serious consequences."

Russia canceled Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov's visit to Turkey on Wednesday, while NATO called an emergency meeting of alliance ambassadors on Tuesday afternoon. Tuesday's incident was the first shoot-down of a Russian aircraft by a NATO country since the 1950s, officials said.

Russia insists the fighter jet did not stray outside Syria, while Turkish officials said the jet was warned 10 times to turn back from its trajectory into Turkish airspace. President Obama called on Russia, Turkey, and NATO countries to "discourage any escalation," but also asserted that "Turkey, like every country, has the right to defend its territory and its airspace."

Russia is likely to look at the aftermath of the incident as validation that all groups arrayed against Assad are terrorists. A video released following the shoot-down shows Syrian Turkmen rebels claiming to have shot dead two Russian pilots as they parachuted to the ground.

A separate incident further illustrates the difficulty of building a united anti-IS coalition that includes Russia. A group of Syrian rebels armed by the US claims to have damaged a Russian military helicopter, forcing it to make an emergency landing in Syrian government-held territory.

Yet Strauss says perhaps the more formidable impediment to an effective coalition is the widespread ambiguity in the region toward the Islamic State. The region's Sunni powers "may worry about ISIS in the long term, but to some extent they see its usefulness in the short term," he says. That calculation does not fit with Western powers that – now more than ever – want to see IS's demise "sooner rather than later."

Title: Mike Pence Faces Protests at Evangelical College in Virginia

Article:

Mike Pence, the Republican vice presidential nominee, faced protests and a lackluster turnout during a stump speech at Patrick Henry College in Purcellville, Virginia, on Saturday. The evangelical Christian college, known for its anti-Trump sentiment, has a history of opposing Donald Trump, the Republican presidential nominee.

Students protested outside the college, while some stood in silent protest inside until they were ejected mid-speech. The protests and poor attendance at the speech illustrate the challenges that Trump has in appealing to evangelical Christians, especially younger ones, who are turned off by his tone, his campaign ideas, and his personal history, and are not assuaged by his choice of Pence for his running mate.

Sebastian Lopez, a junior studying political theory at the school, was protesting the speech, holding a sign for hours outside in the blazing mid-day sun. "The PHC student body as a whole is very anti-Trump. A lot of them say, 'I don't like him but I'm going to turn up my nose and vote for him because I like Hillary even less,'" said Lopez.

Christian McGuire, a junior at Patrick Henry College studying American politics who was also demonstrating against Pence, estimated 75 percent of the student body opposed Trump. McGuire added, "I don't think that Mike Pence is a bad person, but I think he has made an alliance with someone who is completely unacceptable from a libertarian, conservative, or progressive standpoint."

Pence's visit is not the first misstep by the Trump campaign in Virginia. Donald Trump flubbed his speech in Northern Virginia earlier this month when he lectured the affluent locals in the audience as if they were the Rust Belt and listed factory closures in far-flung areas of the state that were hours away, as well as a plant that closed in North Carolina.

Patrick Henry College is located in Loudoun County, the affluent swing district an hour from Washington, D.C., that voted for Bush twice, and then Obama twice. It's as close to a must-win county as it gets.

When Marco Rubio visited in February during the Republican primaries, students and local residents crammed into the room, filling the bleachers, the gymnasium floor, and the balconies above to get a glimpse of the presidential candidate. The road outside the college was jam-packed. Parking was a nightmare. An enthusiastic Students for Rubio group existed during the primaries. To this day, there is no pro-Trump group on campus.

"There are certainly students who support Trump, though most are not enthusiastic. He was rarely the first choice in such a crowded primary field," said Tim Kocher, a spokesman for the Patrick Henry College Republicans. "I believe Trump has a solid base of support around 15-20%, but many students simply have not made up their minds as far as the presidential race goes."

When Pence visited Saturday, the room was half-empty. A whole set of retractable bleachers sat empty and discarded near the stage; no admiring crowds leaned over the balcony to get a better look at the politician; parking was a breeze. This lackluster turnout took place at a school which in fall 2015 registered just 294 students, yet had about as many White House interns during the Bush administration as Georgetown University, with its nearly 18,000 students.

"I'm a B-list Republican celebrity," Pence said self-deprecatingly, as he thanked attendees for showing up on a beautiful, cloudless Saturday afternoon. It was funny because it was kind of sad, and it was sad because it was kind of true.

Pence also spoke as if he did not quite understand whose ticket he was on. "We believe in free trade," he said, as if Trump had not run a campaign slamming international trade. The governor also slammed Hillary Clinton's plan to tax the rich, as if the Republican nominee had not taken aim at Wall Street during his populist run for the White House. Americans are "tired of politicians who divide our country to unite their support," he said, as if Trump had not run a campaign that regularly disparaged Muslims, foreigners, and women.

As if to bolster this point, a group of protesters critical of Trump's rhetoric on Islam revealed their T-shirts during Pence's speech, engaging in a silent protest of the Republican ticket as they were slowly escorted out. Even the students who supported the Trump-Pence ticket seemed to be doing so with an air of resignation, buoyed only by the threat they believe Hillary Clinton poses to the country.

Sarah Roberts, a student at the college who attended the speech, told The ███, "I haven't done the research to be, like, 'Woo-hoo,' but he's better than the alternative."

"Our options are a little limited, so we're going to have to choose between worse and worse," said another student carrying a Trump-Pence sign. "It's a very conservative school, one of the most conservative schools in the nation... a lot of people don't really believe he's very conservative."

Meanwhile, outside Patrick Henry College, nearly 20 students and alumni from the predominantly conservative school demonstrated against Pence and Trump, to make the point that the Christian college did not support the Republican ticket.

"I don't want my school, and therefore my name, associated with [Trump]," said Erin Lester, an alumni of the school. "It's known for being a conservative school... and I don't want people to assume that because it's a conservative school, that we're Trump's dupes, basically."

The protests for the swing area of Loudoun County continued out in the street outside Patrick Henry College's main entrance, where students held signs reading "PHC is Not Trump Country," "Immigrants Make America Great," and "For Christ and Liberty, Not Bigotry And Idiocy." Some locals passed, honking in support. Eventually, a car drove by, and its angry occupant flipped the bird, yelling "TRUMP!"

Title: Elizabeth Warren Apologizes for Past Native American Heritage Claims at Iowa Forum

Article:

SIOUX CITY, Iowa (AP) — Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren offered a public apology Monday to Native Americans over her past claim to tribal heritage, directly addressing an area that has proven to be a significant political liability.

"Like anyone who has been honest with themselves, I know I have made mistakes," the Massachusetts senator said at a forum on Native American issues in this pivotal early voting state. "I am sorry for the harm I have caused."

Monday's remarks were an effort to move past the fallout from her past claims of tribal ancestry, which culminated in a widely criticized release of a DNA analysis last year. The issue nearly derailed her campaign in the early days as President Donald Trump began derisively referring to her as "Pocahontas."

Now that Warren is gaining in most polls, she is trying to prove to voters that the controversy won't doom her in a general election matchup against Trump. The detailed policy agenda to help Native Americans that she released last week helped secure a warm reception from attendees at the tribal forum.

After drawing a standing ovation, Warren said "I have listened and I have learned a lot" from conversations with Native Americans in recent months, describing herself as "grateful" for the dialogue. She fielded questions about her proposals, which include a legislative change for a Supreme Court ruling that impedes tribal governments' ability to prosecute crimes committed on tribal lands by those who don't belong to a tribe.

She did not receive any questions about her own background.

Warren's DNA analysis—part of a broader pushback against Trump's disparaging nickname—showed evidence of a tribal ancestor as far as 10 generations back, but the Cherokee Nation joined some other Native Americans in rebuking the senator for attributing tribal membership to genetics. Warren later apologized privately to the Cherokee and had addressed her regret before Monday's appearance.

As of Monday, her campaign website's page containing a video and other materials Warren had released on the DNA analysis was no longer active.

The Native American forum this week is expected to draw 10 of her White House rivals.

New Mexico Rep. Deb Haaland, who last year became one of the first two Native American women elected to Congress, introduced Warren on Monday after endorsing her presidential campaign last month and aligning with her for new legislation aimed at helping tribal communities. Haaland lamented that Warren's ancestry has attracted outsized attention when Trump faces his own charges of racism.

Those who "ask about Elizabeth's family instead of issues of vital importance to Indian Country," Haaland told the forum audience, "feed the president's racism."

Warren's remarks were well-received by attendees at the Native American forum.

Manny Iron Hawk, 62, who lives on the Cheyenne River Sioux reservation in South Dakota, said Warren "did excellent" in her Monday appearance and has done a good job of addressing her past mistakes. "I think she did. A person has to admit their mistakes and move on."

Iron Hawk said he had hoped to talk to Warren about tribal governance issues, but she left too quickly for him to catch her.

Snuffy Main, 64, who traveled to the conference from Montana, said he doesn't think Warren needs to continue apologizing for claiming Native American heritage.

"I don't understand why she is constantly apologetic for making a mistake," said Main, who is a member of the Gros Ventre Tribe of Montana. He said he liked what Warren had to say about making sure the country honors its promises and treaties with tribes.

"If she can do even a fraction of what she promised, that would be beneficial," he said.

Gary Funmaker, 72, of Black River Falls, Wisconsin, said Warren had "good energy to her" and he didn't see much need for further apology.

"That's accepted. That's old news," said Funmaker, a Republican who used to work for the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

Later Monday, Warren campaigned in Minnesota, a state Trump hopes to take out of Democrats' column next year. The senator drew her largest crowd yet—12,000 people, according to her campaign—to an outdoor rally at Macalester College, a private liberal arts school in St. Paul.

"I don't want a government that works for giant multinational corporations. I want one that works for our families," she told the crowd.

Schor reported from Washington. ███ writer Kathleen Hennessey contributed to this report from St. Paul, Minn.

Title: FBI Under Scrutiny for Inaction on Florida School Shooting Tip

Article:

Pressure is mounting on the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) following the agency's admission that it failed to act on a tip about Nikolas Cruz, the suspect in the deadly shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida. The shooting resulted in the deaths of 17 individuals, making it the deadliest US school shooting since 2012.

Florida Governor Rick Scott has called for FBI Director Christopher Wray to resign, while Attorney General Jeff Sessions has ordered a review, expressing disappointment in the FBI's actions. Some of those close to the victims have also voiced their dismay. President Donald Trump met with survivors of the attack and thanked law enforcement for their response to the tragedy.

Nikolas Cruz, 19, has confessed to the attack and has been charged with 17 counts of murder. The shooting re-ignited debates about gun control, with many students from the school weighing in.

On January 5, a person close to Cruz contacted the FBI's tip line, providing information about Cruz's gun ownership, desire to kill people, erratic behavior, and disturbing social media posts, as well as the potential of him conducting a school shooting. The FBI stated that this information should have been assessed as a potential threat to life and passed on to the Miami field office, but that "we have determined these protocols were not followed."

FBI Director Christopher Wray stated that the bureau was "still investigating the facts" and was committed to "getting to the bottom of what happened." He also expressed regret for the additional pain caused to those affected by the tragedy.

In September, a disturbing comment was left on a YouTube video by a user named "nikolas cruz," stating, "I'm going to be a professional school shooter." The comment was reported to the FBI, but the agency was unable to identify the person behind the comment at the time.

Questions are also being raised about how local police responded to concerns about Nikolas Cruz. Broward County Sheriff Scott Israel stated that his office had received 20 "calls for service" about Cruz. Each call would be scrutinized, he said, without going into detail about the nature of the calls.

Governor Scott stated that the FBI's failure to act was "unacceptable" and called for Wray's resignation. At a funeral for 18-year-old victim Meadow Pollack, family friend Jeff Richman questioned the value of the FBI's apology, stating, "The FBI apologized? Tell that to families."

Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced a review at the justice department and FBI into how "indications of potential violence" are responded to. The FBI has been criticized in the past for being aware of a potential threat and failing to thwart an attack, such as the gunman of the 2009 Fort Hood shooting in Texas and the gunman who killed 49 people in a gay club in Orlando, Florida, in 2016.

In 2016, the FBI received about 1,300 tips a day through its website, which is staffed around the clock by two dozen people. In addition to online tips, FBI field offices receive dozens of calls. About 100 of the tips are considered "actionable."

Cruz had been expelled from the school he has confessed to attacking, and some students stated they had previously joked he would one day "shoot up the school." One former schoolmate, Chad Williams, described Cruz as an "outcast" who was "crazy about guns." His interest in weapons was apparent on his social media profiles, which the Broward County sheriff said were "very, very disturbing." Cruz had reportedly been treated for mental health issues at a clinic.

Title: Ford's Testimony in Senate Hearing Praised as Credible and Brave

Article:

Christine Blasey Ford, a psychology professor from California, testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday, September 27, 2018, alleging that Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her when they were teenagers. Ford, who was previously unknown to the public, emerged as a significant figure in the #MeToo movement, with many American women identifying with her emotional account of the alleged assault.

Ford's testimony was met with praise for her credibility and bravery, despite thousands of conservatives accusing her of lying to bring down Kavanaugh. Republican senators depicted her testimony as partisan, while being careful not to personally attack Ford. However, many prominent conservatives, such as Alice Stewart, Mike Cernovich, Chris Wallace, and Moira Donegan, praised Ford for her credibility and emotional impact.

Ford's testimony was emotional, with her voice cracking at times, and she appeared close to tears at several points. A GoFundMe page to support Ford and pay for her security and legal expenses quickly doubled its fundraising total after it was mentioned during the hearing. RAINN, a support hotline for victims of sexual assault and crimes, saw a 147% increase in people reaching out for help during the hearing.

An analysis of social media sentiment conducted by the Ipsos polling firm using an artificial intelligence prototype found that positive sentiment directed toward Ford increased each time she spoke. However, it measured posts on Twitter and Facebook and was not a representation of total public sentiment.

Kathleen Pierman, 66, who watched the testimony at home, was convinced by Ford's testimony and found Kavanaugh more convincing than expected. However, Pierman believed confirming Kavanaugh would be a "huge mistake" because "no one will trust the Supreme Court."

Three political scientists who specialize in voting behavior and political psychology told their sources they expected Ford's testimony to galvanize female Democratic voters to vote in November.

Title: Wealthier but Lonely: The Paradox of American Society and Its Impact on Politics

Article:

A paradox has emerged in American society, as indicated by a contrast between increasing standards of living and increased social anxiety and unhappiness. Despite a booming economy, low unemployment rates, and rising wages, Americans report declining happiness levels and a sense of disconnectedness.

The Sustainable Development Solutions Network, a United Nations initiative, attributes the decline in self-reported happiness to weakening social support networks in the U.S. Over the past few decades, marriage rates have dropped significantly, with the number of never-married individuals approaching parity with married individuals. The average number of people per household has also decreased from 3.33 in 1960 to 2.57 today, leading to a dramatic shrinking of social networks.

Surveys show a rise in loneliness, with progressive generational declines in the art of friendship. On average, Americans have one fewer close friend today than a generation ago, and many men report having no close friendships. The youngest Americans, who use social media the most, are socializing the least "in real life."

Despite America's reputation as a religiously devout nation, church attendance has been consistently declining over the past few decades. Barna now estimates that the population of "unchurched" people, 43 percent, has exceeded the population of active churchgoers.

One of the happiest and most upwardly mobile cities is Salt Lake City, Utah, which has a strong religious institution at its core. The culture of Utah is infused with the spirit created by a coherent religious culture that, despite being a minority faith in the country, has the solidarity of a religious community. Salt Lake City is tied with Chattanooga for the country's most churched city.

The decline in neighborliness is another significant trend. Fewer Americans know their next-door neighbors, and fewer still regularly interact with them. This decline is reflected in fewer acts of everyday charity and philanthropy, as well as declines in civic and ethnic organizations.

This depletion and disappearance of a social treasury, as the author refers to it, are the background noise of American politics today. The two insurgent ideological trends on the left and right - socialism and nationalism, respectively - emphasize shared burdens and our duties to one another.

The depletion of the social treasure informs the politics of the Right's populists, explaining some of the contrast between the feelings of precarity that Trump voters report and the income stats that suggest they may be doing just fine, or better. It also partly explains the upsurge in socialism.

However, it is not just the working class that is affected by these trends. America's elites are not immune either. They may have the means to navigate a world in which their communal life has been almost entirely displaced by a networking life. But, they often succeed more when liberated from a life that would impose obligations, throwing themselves more fully into careers and social milieux that run on a more disguised form of conditional favor-trading, rather than reciprocal duties.

Politicians will have to learn to address an America that is wealthier and lonelier, as politics has become one of the only arenas in which Americans can collectively discuss the quality of their social relations and their sense of morality. However, because they see so clearly how much their outcomes in life depend on the favors they put into and extract out of a network, they dread their loss of status, which they value most keenly.
