While leisure hasn't entirely died among American elites, they constantly betray themselves as overworked and under-cultivated.

The decline of the social treasury is not easily amenable to political policy. Until Utah Senator Mike Lee used his position on the Joint Economic Committee to pioneer a social-capital index, it was barely visible to them. But because politics has become one of the only arenas in which Americans can collectively discuss the quality of their social relations and their sense of morality, politicians will at least have to learn to address an America that is wealthier and lonelier, that has higher standards of living but lives marked by quiet desperation, that works hard but doesn't know why anymore.

Title: Federal Judges to Hear Appeal on Trump's Revised Travel Ban, Senate Intel Committee Invites James Comey to Testify

Article:

The Trump administration will present arguments on Monday before a federal appeals court in an attempt to reverse a judge's ruling that blocked the implementation of the second version of the president's controversial travel ban. The arguments will be heard in Seattle before a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

U.S. District Court Judge Derrick K. Watson's March 16 decision halted the overhauled travel ban, a policy the administration claims is a crucial component of a strategy to prevent potential terrorists from entering the country.

Associates of former FBI Director James Comey believe that his first comments on his termination would likely come in an open session before Congress. Comey declined an invitation to speak to a closed session of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday and was replaced on a panel testifying before that committee last Thursday by his temporary replacement, Acting FBI Director Andrew McCabe.

Senate Intelligence Committee Vice Chair Mark Warner (D-Va.) expressed his desire for Comey to testify in a public hearing about his firing. "I think Jim Comey deserves his chance to lay out to the American public his side of the facts," Warner told ABC's George Stephanopoulos on "This Week" on Sunday morning.

U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley defended President Trump's firing of Comey, stating that he can "fire anyone he wants." Haley added that the criticism of Trump stems from discomfort with his propensity to act on his decisions.

Former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper said Russia likely views Comey's firing as "another victory on the scoreboard for them." Clapper noted that the removal of the lead of the investigation about potential collusion between Russia and the Trump campaign has been removed.

The U.S. believes the ballistic missile North Korea launched on Saturday was a KN-17 medium range missile and not a new intermediate range missile, as had been speculated. The launch marked the first successful test of the missile, three previous launches in April had ended in failure.

Reports suggest that White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus recently warned senior staff to stop trying to secretly slip news articles to President Trump. Additionally, the Trump administration is reportedly planning to significantly expand the pro-life Mexico City Policy. Former U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara wrote an opinion piece questioning whether there are still public servants who will say no to the president.

Title: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Discusses Congressional Pay Raise and Cost of Living Adjustment

Article:

Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY) has expressed concerns about the potential lack of a cost-of-living adjustment for members of Congress, which could result in a $4,500 pay raise. According to Fox News' Gregg Re, there has not been a cost-of-living adjustment for Congress members for the past nine years.

In a conversation with Fox News' Chad Pergram on Monday, Ocasio-Cortez, who earns $174,000 per year, discussed the issue of Congressional pay raises. She stated that the pressure to turn to lobbying firms and cash in on member services after leaving Congress is due to the lack of cost-of-living adjustments.

Ocasio-Cortez argued that efforts to increase Congressional pay are superficial and that voting against pay increases might not be politically popular but is necessary to fight for pay increases for American workers. She advocated for a $15 minimum wage pegged to inflation for all workers in the United States.

The Congresswoman continued, stating that members of Congress, retail workers, and everyone should receive cost-of-living increases to accommodate for changes in the economy. She argued that bypassing cost-of-living adjustments increases the pressure on members to exploit legal loopholes to enrich themselves.

Ocasio-Cortez concluded by stating that while voting against a cost-of-living adjustment might not look good in terms of political optics, it is essential to be transparent about cost-of-living increases. She emphasized that every cost-of-living adjustment bypassed is a vote to increase the pressure to exploit legal loopholes and enrich oneself through service.

Title: Sanders Condemns Sandra Bland's Arrest, Calls for Police Reform

Article:

Independent Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders has criticized the conduct of the officer involved in the arrest of Sandra Bland, a 28-year-old African American woman who died in police custody in a small Texas town last week. Sanders is the only presidential candidate to publicly address Bland's death.

The arrest and subsequent death of Bland, which occurred on July 13, sparked a national outcry after local officials ruled her death a suicide in a jail cell. However, cellphone footage later released showed Bland yelling during the arrest that the officer had slammed her head on the ground. Authorities stated that Bland hung herself with a plastic bag in a jail cell three days later.

Following a tense encounter with Black Lives Matter activists at the Netroots Nation conference in Phoenix on Saturday, Sanders added a passage to his stump speech in Houston on Sunday, referencing Bland's death. He stated, "It is unacceptable that police officers beat up people or kill people. If they do that, they have got to be held accountable."

After dashcam video of Bland's arrest was released last night, showing the officer, who had pulled Bland over for failing to signal a turn, open Bland's driver-side door and threaten to "light her up" with his taser if she did not stop smoking a cigarette and exit the vehicle, Sanders released a statement Tuesday condemning the arrest. He described the video as showing "totally outrageous police behavior."

Sanders continued, "No one should be yanked from her car, thrown to the ground, assaulted, and arrested for a minor traffic stop. The result is that three days later she is dead in her jail cell. This video highlights once again why we need real police reform. People should not die for a minor traffic infraction. This type of police abuse has become an all-too-common occurrence for people of color, and it must stop."

Two Texas state lawmakers have already labeled Bland's arrest as unlawful, but neither of the two Texas presidential candidates, Sen. Ted Cruz and former Governor Rick Perry, have commented on Bland's case. Sanders is the only presidential candidate to mention Bland on the campaign trail, so far. Activists have utilized the #SayHerName hashtag on social media to draw attention to the Bland case.

Title: The Need for a Long-Term Strategy in Syria: A Call for Integrated Approach

Article:

The ongoing Syrian conflict, now in its sixth year, has prompted calls for the United States to adopt a long-term strategy. The author, Michael O' Hanlon, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, argues that while President Barack Obama's reluctance to engage in Syria's civil war is understandable, a policy of inaction has allowed Syrian President Bashar Assad to remain in power and facilitated the rise of extremist insurgent groups.

The author suggests that the U.S. should respond to the Syrian regime's use of chemical weapons, a "red line" Obama had previously established, not only to re-establish U.S. credibility but also to re-establish deterrence. The concern is that if the Syrian regime is not deterred from using chemical weapons, it may continue to do so more widely, and the same could apply to Iran's nuclear program.

However, the author cautions against limited military action, such as cruise-missile strikes, due to their limited effects and the challenges in targeting Syrian army units or chemical weapons depots. Instead, the author advocates for an integrated strategy for ending the war, involving a future political settlement among the belligerents. This strategy would require time, potentially involving the deployment of thousands of U.S. troops, and would likely involve a peace implementation force from NATO, the Arab League, and other Islamic countries.

The author warns that without such a strategy, Syria could become a new Somalia, offering sanctuaries to terrorists and causing instability in the region. The author concludes by emphasizing the need for a long-term strategy, rather than an immediate response to the latest tragedy in Syria. The strategy should define a future political settlement, protect all groups, including minorities, and involve a Bosnia-style peace implementation force. The author also calls for international consensus and support for this strategy, acknowledging that it will not be risk- or cost-free but will be a far less daunting effort than either Iraq or Afghanistan.

Title: Supreme Court Challenges Constitutionality of Defense of Marriage Act

Article:

The Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), a law signed into effect in 1996 that bans same-sex married couples from receiving federal benefits, appeared to be on shaky ground at the Supreme Court on Wednesday. During the hearing, a majority of justices expressed doubts about the constitutionality of the 17-year-old law.

Justice Anthony Kennedy, who has often been the deciding vote on similar issues, seemed to be leaning towards siding with the four liberal justices expected to vote for the overturning of DOMA. However, Kennedy's concerns appeared to focus on the traditional right of states to define marriage, rather than a fairness question for gay couples.

Paul Clement, the sole lawyer arguing for the constitutionality of the 1996 law, was retained by Republican leaders in the House after President Barack Obama decided in 2011 that the Justice Department would no longer defend the statute. Clement argued that Congress's key interest in passing the law was preserving the uniform treatment of couples in various states at a time when some states might allow same-sex marriages.

Justice Elena Kagan, however, argued that Congress wasn't preserving tradition but departing from it when it jumped into the marriage issue. She pointed out that the foray into the issue in 1996 was so unusual that it "sent up a pretty big red flag."

The Supreme Court's hearing on Wednesday followed Tuesday's hearing on a case that asks the court to overturn California's same-sex marriage ban, known as Prop. 8. The case was brought by Edith Windsor, a New York woman who was forced to pay $363,000 in federal estate taxes after her same-sex spouse died in 2009. If the couple had been heterosexual, no tax would have been due, but under DOMA federal tax law treated the pair as unmarried.

A previous version of this story misspelled Sri Srinivasan's name.

Title: Navy SEAL Trial Exposes Alleged War Crimes and Divisions Within Elite Force

Article:

A court-martial at Naval Base San Diego is currently underway for Special Operations Chief Edward Gallagher, a 19-year Navy SEAL veteran and Bronze Star recipient, who is charged with murder, attempted murder, and conduct prejudicial to good order and discipline for posing with the corpse of an Islamic State captive he allegedly stabbed and for shooting civilians in Iraq in 2017. The trial has provided a rare glimpse into the inner workings of the Navy SEAL community, revealing challenges within U.S. special forces and shedding light on the insular nature of one of the military's most secretive and revered forces.

The trial has been marked by a heated debate between veterans over brotherhood, morality, and loyalty. The case has also highlighted the struggles of military courts in prosecuting alleged war crimes, with the lead prosecutor being removed for allegedly tracking the defense team's emails to find a news leak, and the lead investigator acknowledging mistakes.

The trial has laid bare a WhatsApp group chat, dubbed "The Sewing Circle," formed by a select few members of Alpha platoon after their return from deployment in 2017. In the group chat, Gallagher was referred to as "El Diablo," Spanish for "the devil." The group allegedly served as a platform for orchestrating a smear campaign against their demanding platoon chief.

Nearly a dozen SEALs have testified over the past two weeks, with most being granted immunity to protect them from being prosecuted for acts they described on the stand. Seven SEALs testified that Gallagher unexpectedly stabbed the prisoner on May 3, 2017, moments after he and the other medics treated the 17-year-old boy. Two SEALs testified they saw Gallagher plunge his knife into the prisoner's neck, including Special Operator Corey Scott, who stunned the court when he said he was the one who ultimately killed the teen by plugging his breathing tube with his thumb as an act of mercy. The Navy is reportedly considering perjury charges against Scott.

The trial is expected to conclude with closing arguments on Monday, as the jury of five Marines and two sailors, one a SEAL, weighs the evidence presented. The jury will decide whether Gallagher, on his eighth deployment, went off the rails and fatally stabbed the war prisoner as a kind of trophy kill, or if the boy died from wounds sustained in an airstrike and Gallagher is being falsely accused by junior SEALs trying to permanently oust a platoon chief they hate.

The trial has also revealed the behavior of the special warfare teams, with the Navy's top commanders conducting a review into the matter. Lt. Jacob Portier, the officer in charge, has been charged separately for overseeing the ceremony and not reporting the alleged stabbing. The trial has also shown the struggles of military courts in prosecuting alleged war crimes, with the lead prosecutor being removed and the lead investigator acknowledging mistakes.

Title: FBI Director's Handling of Anti-Trump Dossier Raises Questions in Senate Hearing

Article:

FBI Director James Comey's consideration of an anti-Trump dossier compiled by a former British intelligence officer as significant enough to include in the final intelligence community report on Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. election has sparked questions during a recent Senate hearing. Sources familiar with the matter, who declined to speak on record due to its sensitivity and relevance to ongoing testimony on the unmasking of American citizens in the FBI's probe into alleged contacts between Trump campaign advisers and Moscow, reportedly told Fox News about the inclusion of the dossier.

The dossier, which was part of the evidence the FBI used to obtain a FISA warrant for Carter Page, a peripheral figure in the Trump campaign, has been a subject of controversy. In an interview with Fox News, Page denied the dossier's central allegations that he was the Trump campaign's point person for Moscow.

The dossier, which contained salacious allegations about then-candidate Donald Trump, was also included as an attachment in the classified version of the intelligence report issued at the end of the Obama administration. Both President Barack Obama and President-elect Trump were presented with the findings.

During a Senate hearing, Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) raised questions about the bureau's relationship with Christopher Steele, the former British officer who wrote the dossier, and his British company Orbis, as well as their relationship with Washington, D.C.-based Fusion GPS.

In the hearing, Comey declined to confirm or deny if Fusion GPS is part of the Russian intelligence apparatus or if he agreed that Fusion GPS's involvement in preparing the anti-Trump dossier would constitute Russian interference in the election. Sen. Charles Grassley (R-Iowa), the committee's chairman, expressed his frustration at the lack of response from the director of the FBI, citing the bureau's failure to meet deadlines and respond to his questions.

Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), the top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee who also sits on the intelligence committee, told CNN on Wednesday that she does not "at this time" have evidence of collusion between Trump associates and Russia during the campaign.

A letter of complaint against Fusion GPS was filed with the Justice Department, alleging the company and its founder, former Wall Street Journal reporter Glenn Simpson, violated the Foreign Agents Registration Act. In response to the complaint's allegation that Fusion GPS acted as an unregistered agent for Russian interests, attorney Joshua A. Levy told Fox News' senior executive producer Pamela Browne via email that "Fusion GPS has complied with the law and was not required to register under FARA. Nor has Fusion GPS ever been a Russian agent. Allegations to the contrary are not true."

Grassley expressed concerns that the FBI has relied on the dossier to justify the current investigation. He questioned the origin of the money used to fund the dossier and the motivations of those writing the checks. During the hearing, Grassley also chided the FBI for providing materially inconsistent information and noted that the man who wrote the dossier admitted in court that it contains unverified claims.

A British court document, first reported by The Guardian and signed by Steele, offers a glimpse into his company's work for Fusion GPS. The document describes "unsolicited intelligence" and "raw intelligence" that "needed to be analyzed and further investigated/verified." Fox News has filed a formal request for copies of court documents with the Queen's Bench Division of the High Court in London.

Title: White House Immigration Policy: Uncertainty and Lack of Consistency

Article:

The current focus lies on the ongoing DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals) issue, with President Donald Trump and the Republican-led Congress facing criticism for their handling of the Dreamers. The Dreamers, as Trump described them last February, are "absolutely incredible kids" who deserve to be treated "with heart." However, in September, he initiated the termination of the program if Congress did not find a permanent solution by March 5. Two weeks ago, Trump promised a "bill of love," but two days later, he rejected a bipartisan deal aimed at addressing the issue.

On Friday, hours before the government shutdown deadline, Trump reportedly reached an agreement with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer that would have protected Dreamers and increased border security. However, he later reversed course, allegedly due to pressure from immigration hardliners within the White House, including Chief of Staff John Kelly and Senior Adviser Stephen Miller. On Sunday, Trump criticized Democrats, accusing them of wanting "illegal immigrants to pour into our nation unchecked."

The inconsistency and lack of clear direction from the White House have led to confusion and uncertainty. As stated by Senator Schumer, negotiating with the president is "like negotiating with Jell-O." This ambiguity has reportedly contributed to the recent government shutdown.

In contrast, during the 2013 government shutdown, President Barack Obama, who was clear from the start that he would not negotiate on defunding the Affordable Care Act, his signature legislative achievement, eventually prevailed.

In 2018, the White House is occupied by a president with no apparent principles beyond promoting his own brand and securing "wins," as he put it. His disinterest in the specifics of governing has led him to state that he would sign any immigration bill sent to him by lawmakers. Negotiating with a chief executive who lacks a clear understanding of what constitutes a good deal presents challenges for all parties involved.

Title: New York Times Editorial Questions U.S. Military's Celebration of White Supremacy in Naming Military Bases

Article:

The New York Times Editorial Board published an editorial on Sunday, titled "Why Does the U.S. Military Celebrate White Supremacy?" The piece argues that it is time to rename military bases after "American heroes, not racist traitors."

The editorial contends that the federal government embraced white supremacist ideology when it named military bases in the South, citing examples such as Fort Benning, Georgia, which honors Confederate General Henry Lewis Benning. The editorial notes that Benning, in a 1861 speech, expressed support for the preservation of slavery and his belief that African-Americans were not fully human.

The editorial also points to Fort Benning's namesake as a Confederate general who may have been a leader of the Ku Klux Klan after the Civil War. Another Georgia base, Fort Gordon, is named after Confederate General John Brown Gordon, who was a leader of the Georgia Ku Klux Klan and may have taken on a broader role in the terrorist organization when its first national leader, Confederate General Nathan Bedford Forrest, suffered declining health.

The editorial board references comments made by an Army spokesman in 2015, who stated that there was no need to remove Confederate base names because the "historic names represent individuals, not causes or ideologies." The editorial counters this argument, stating that the men honored by the bases were traitors and that the names represent oppression before and during the Civil War, as well as state-sponsored bigotry after it.

The editorial concludes by stating that bases named for men who sought to destroy the Union in the name of racial injustice are an insult to the ideals that servicemen and women are sworn to uphold and an embarrassing artifact of a time when the military itself embraced anti-American values. The editorial board calls for the renaming of these bases.

In response to the editorial, President Trump criticized the New York Times and its publisher, stating, "I laugh at them all."

Title: Mike Bloomberg Campaigns Across Super Tuesday States, Promises to "Get It Done"

Article:

Mike Bloomberg, the former New York City mayor, has embarked on a whirlwind tour of states participating in Super Tuesday, the primary election on March 3, in an attempt to capitalize on the unsettled Democratic presidential race. Polls indicate that Bloomberg is gaining traction, as Joe Biden, the previous front-runner, has struggled following disappointing finishes in the first two contests.

Bloomberg is bypassing the early states and focusing on demonstrating his campaign's viability through strong performances on Super Tuesday. His campaign strategy includes a busy schedule of events and substantial television advertising, reinforcing the campaign slogan, "Mike will get it done," which is featured in ads, posters, T-shirts, and other campaign materials.

During his campaign stops, Bloomberg avoids direct attacks on his Democratic opponents and does not mention them by name. He pledges to support the Democratic nominee if he is not the nominee himself. In a clear reference to Bernie Sanders, who advocates for revolutionary change, Bloomberg states, "We need evolution, not a revolution."

Bloomberg's primary focus is on defeating President Donald Trump, whom he portrays as a national emergency. He positions himself as someone who has amassed a fortune estimated to exceed $60 billion, implying that Trump cannot intimidate him. He asserts, "I'm a New Yorker, and I'm not afraid of Donald Trump."

In response to Trump's recent insults, Bloomberg used his rallies to counterattack, stating, "He calls me Little Mike, and the answer is, 'Donald, where I come from, we measure from your neck up.'"

Bloomberg's attacks on Trump were met with cheers in cities such as Chattanooga, Nashville, Winston-Salem, Greensboro, and Raleigh. Some attendees are still undecided, while others, like retiree Michael Day, support Bloomberg as the best candidate to defeat Trump.

However, not all reactions to Bloomberg have been positive. This week, two stories from his past resurfaced, including comments he made in 2015 about New York City's stop-and-frisk policy, which disproportionately targeted African Americans, and his 2008 remarks on the end of the discriminatory lending practice known as "redlining."

The Bloomberg campaign has responded to these issues with endorsements from African American mayors and members of the Congressional Black Caucus, as well as a plan to help a million more Black families buy a house and counteract the effects of redlining and the subprime mortgage crisis.

As Bloomberg is not on the ballot in the upcoming states of Nevada and South Carolina, his appeal to voters can only be measured by his polling numbers. He continues to air television commercials highlighting his stance on climate change, gun violence, and featuring clips of Barack Obama praising him.

Voters will have their first opportunity to assess Bloomberg's formidability as a candidate on Super Tuesday.

Title: Rarity of Convictions in Police Shooting Cases: A Look at the Factors Influencing Outcomes

Article:

The investigation into the police shooting of unarmed African-American teenager Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, has sparked questions about the circumstances surrounding the incident. Attorney William Yeomans, who worked as an attorney and senior official in the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division for 24 years, has stated that convicting a police officer of wrongful death is a rare occurrence.

As Michael Brown was laid to rest on Monday, the shooting that took place two weeks ago remains a contentious issue. Was Brown unjustifiably gunned down by white police officer Darren Wilson, as some contend? Or did Wilson, who reportedly sustained a facial injury during an altercation with Brown, act appropriately in the heat of a confrontation in which Brown reportedly reached for the officer's gun?

Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. traveled to Ferguson to coordinate a Justice Department investigation into the shooting, which was already being probed by local and state law enforcement agencies. Holder's presence instilled confidence in many that justice will be served. However, for some, especially long-aggrieved minority communities with a history of uneasy and often violent relationships with police, justice will only be achieved with Wilson's conviction.

The history of criminal investigations of police shootings demonstrates the rarity of convictions. While hard numbers are difficult to come by, it is known that police shoot hundreds of people each year, and there are at most a handful of successful criminal charges. Factors such as the trust and dependence on police officers, the backgrounds of the participants, and the difficulty of relying on eyewitness testimony contribute to this rarity.

The role of police officers as protectors of the public and the power with which we cloak them creates the potential for abuse. This requires that we impose and enforce limits on their use of force, but cautions against punishing them too quickly for mistakes. Legal standards and the willingness of juries to find officers criminally culpable and send them to jail are shaped by this recognition of the role of police officers.

The backgrounds of the participants in police shootings can color the investigation, grand jury process, and trial. Use of force by police officers is likely to occur in confrontations with individuals who are suspected of criminal wrongdoing. Officers are entitled to use reasonably necessary force in such situations, and the question becomes whether they have exceeded that limit. This dynamic can influence the investigation, grand jury process, and trial, with the tendency to give the benefit of the doubt to the police officer.

Eyewitness testimony can be difficult to rely on in police shooting cases due to the chaotic nature of the incidents and the trauma experienced by witnesses. In contests of credibility between police officers and friends or associates of the victim, investigators and juries often favor the police. Successful prosecutions often turn on a rare combination of extensive forensic evidence and the cooperation, however reluctant, of officers.

Video of the incident can be crucial. For example, in the prosecution of officers who beat Rodney King in Los Angeles in 1991, the federal conviction depended heavily on the ability to parse the individual blows shown in the video taken by a bystander to determine whether officers had exceeded the amount of force necessary to subdue King. The events in Ferguson have generated renewed calls for requiring officers to video confrontations, both as a means of protecting officers from false allegations of excessive force and to preserve the record in those instances that raise legitimate concerns.

Title: US Senate Adopts Ground Rules for Trump's Impeachment Trial

Article:

The United States Senate has adopted ground rules for President Donald Trump's impeachment trial following a contentious 13-hour debate on the first day of proceedings. The trial will resume on Wednesday with arguments from the prosecution, followed by the defense and questions from senators.

President Trump is the third U.S. president to face an impeachment trial. He is charged with abuse of power and obstructing the congressional impeachment inquiry. Trump has denied wrongdoing and accused Democrats of trying to unseat him for political reasons.

The trial is taking place after Trump was impeached last month by the Democratic-led House of Representatives. However, the Senate, which is controlled by his fellow Republicans, is not expected to convict and remove him from office.

Trump is currently attending the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where he dismissed the accusations against him as "a total hoax." On the question of whether new witnesses would be called to the trial, Trump said he would leave that to senators to decide, but the White House has actively worked to block the appearance of certain officials.

Democrats have made it clear they wish to hear testimony from the former National Security Adviser, John Bolton. The Trump administration has said evidence from Mr. Bolton would pose a national security threat - a claim dismissed by Democrats as a smokescreen.

Senators have taken oaths to act as impartial jurors in a trial presided over by US Chief Justice John Roberts. House Democrats known as "impeachment managers" act as the prosecution, while Trump's legal team acts as the defense.

Under the rules approved by the Republican majority, each side will be given up to 24 hours to lay out their case in opening arguments, over three days. Senators are barred from live tweeting and from speaking to those sitting near them while the case is being heard. No outside reading materials are allowed to be brought in.

Opening arguments will begin on Wednesday afternoon. After this finishes, probably early next week, senators will have a chance to ask questions. They have been given 16 hours. Then attention will return again to the key issue of new witnesses and evidence.

Democrats want to hear from key White House aides who worked closely with Trump, including acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney and John Bolton. Republicans have so far blocked their attempts.

By party-line votes of 53-47, the Senate rejected a series of Democratic bids to obtain documents and evidence in the impeachment trial. Senators blocked a motion from Democratic leader Chuck Schumer to subpoena White House files related to Trump's dealings with Ukraine. They also rejected follow-up motions demanding a subpoena of records and documents from the state department and White House budget office. Republican Senators turned back an effort by Democrats to subpoena John Bolton, who has said he would comply with any such order.

In his opening statement, Adam Schiff, the House Democrat leading the impeachment case, said most Americans "do not believe there will be a fair trial."

"They do not believe the Senate will be impartial," he said. "They believe the result is pre-cooked."

The president's legal team had earlier demanded he be immediately acquitted, calling the trial "a dangerous perversion of the constitution." At one point during bitter arguments, Justice Roberts admonished both the House prosecutors and the Trump legal team, asking them to remember that they were "addressing the world's greatest deliberative body."

Backed by the president's lawyers, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell had initially planned to condense the opening arguments from three days to two. Democrats said this would have been no less than a cover-up. But after a meeting with senators, including some Republicans, McConnell agreed on Tuesday to three days for opening arguments.

The senators had expressed concern about how middle-of-the-night sessions would look to US voters. But White House Counsel Pat Cipollone, the president's lead lawyer, had called the plan "a fair process." Several more days of procedural tangles are expected.

The president is accused of seeking help from Ukraine's government to help himself get re-elected in November. It is claimed that, during a call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, he held back military aid as he sought an anti-corruption investigation into Democratic White House candidate Joe Biden, whose son, Hunter, held a board position with a Ukrainian energy firm, Burisma.

The second allegation is that, by refusing to allow White House staff to testify at the impeachment hearings last year, Mr. Trump obstructed Congress. The Senate is hearing the case as the Democratic-led House voted to impeach Mr. Trump on 18 December.

What questions do you have about Donald Trump's impeachment trial?

Title: Trump Campaign Faces Internal Strife as Election Approaches

Article:

Regent University's Dr. Gerson Moreno-Riano has stated that the Trump campaign is currently facing internal strife, and the coming days will reveal whether the candidate can unite not only his inner circle but also the Republican Party. Moreno-Riano discussed Trump's challenges with Evangelicals in a recent interview.

On Monday, Trump dismissed campaign manager Corey Lewandowski amid reports of disagreements and internal conflict within the campaign staff. "I think what's happened with the Trump campaign is, I think it's fractured itself internally," Moreno-Riano said. "I think that it is trying to meet a number of different objectives and keep a number of constituencies very, very happy and it has been unable to do so."

Moreno-Riano added that this internal discord is indicative of a broader, deeper problem within the American electorate, particularly among GOP evangelicals. "The dilemma has always been whether Trump himself has what I'll call the internal character-based resources to pull this off," he explained. "He is a man who is very direct, very strong-minded, and the question is: Does he have enough discipline, both personally and professionally, enough political discipline to pull this off? I think at the end of the day, it's his question to answer."

The decision to fire his campaign manager comes just one day before Trump is set to meet with hundreds of evangelical leaders in New York City to address their concerns about his conservative and Christian bona fides. Moreno-Riano identified abortion, religious liberty, and the Supreme Court as some of the most important issues Trump can address in the meeting, including the question, "Are you truly someone who understands the evangelical mindset—those areas of deep concern?"

Moreno-Riano expressed doubt about Trump's ability to unite evangelicals, stating, "They need to 'bring unity to the table,' and I just don't see that." He added, "Since the 1950s, evangelicals have failed to rally around any candidate, and that's too big a burden to place on Trump. I think they're going to try to assess whether he's truly evangelical or not, so it's a big challenge for him to try and unite them around a common denominator. That's going to be difficult."

Title: Nevada Governor Brian Sandoval Declines Possible U.S. Supreme Court Nomination

Article:

Nevada Governor Brian Sandoval announced on Thursday that he is declining a possible nomination for the U.S. Supreme Court. In a statement, Sandoval said, "I have notified the White House that I do not wish to be considered at this time for possible nomination to the Supreme Court of the United States."

The White House declined to comment on whether Sandoval was ever seriously considered for the nomination. White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest stated, "Even after the fact, I’m not going to get into a lot of details about who's on the president's list and who is not."

Senior U.S. Senator from Nevada, Harry Reid, recommended Sandoval for President Barack Obama's consideration in filling a vacant seat on the Supreme Court. News of Sandoval's vetting for the nomination leaked to the public on Wednesday.

Sandoval's nomination was seen by many as unlikely, with his moderate Republican stance potentially used to pressure Republicans into considering a nominee from their own party. Since the death of Justice Antonin Scalia earlier this month, Republican leaders in the Senate have vowed to block any of the president's proposed replacements.

Richardson, a professor of sociology and judicial studies at the University of Nevada, Reno, stated, "I really do think it was a serious idea for him to be considered." However, he also sees why Sandoval would withdraw his name from consideration once it leaked. "I can understand why the governor wouldn’t want to get caught up in that," Richardson said. "I think, in the future, his name will be brought up again. He’s a moderate Republican. They’re thin on the ground these days."

Sandoval is not a typical Republican, as he does not actively oppose gay marriage or abortion, and he recently pushed through the largest tax increase in Nevada history. Nevada's Republican Senator Dean Heller supports Sandoval's decision to withdraw from Supreme Court consideration but views him as a legitimate candidate. Heller stated, "I hope the next president will consider him in the future."

Historically, the chances of a Supreme Court nominee being appointed have been slim. Since 1956, 21 justices have been appointed to the U.S. Supreme Court, and they share similar backgrounds, according to The Supreme Court Historical Society. Two-thirds of Supreme Court justices attended either Harvard or Yale law schools, with a few earning their law degrees at Northwestern or Stanford universities. Columbia University, Howard University, and the St. Paul College of Law made isolated appearances. Of the eight members currently serving on the Supreme Court, four earned their law degrees at Harvard, three went to Yale, and one attended Columbia. Sandoval earned his degree at Ohio State University Moritz College of Law in 1989.

Title: South Carolina Senator Lindsey Graham Embraces Immigration Reform, Faces No Immediate Backlash

Article:

In a move that may seem counterintuitive, South Carolina Republican Senator Lindsey Graham, who is up for reelection and considered vulnerable to a primary challenge from the right, has endorsed a plan to allow illegal immigrants to gain U.S. citizenship. This controversial stance, often a lightning rod for GOP primary voters, has not yet sparked a backlash in his home state, South Carolina.

The move reflects both Senator Graham's political strength and the rapid evolution of the Republican Party's stance on immigration since the party's November election losses among Latinos. Historically viewed with suspicion by the right wing, Graham's 2007 endorsement of the Kennedy-McCain immigration reform bill was met with skepticism. However, the senator appears to feel secure heading into 2014, taking a politically risky stance on a deeply contentious issue he is passionate about.

Immediately following the November election, Graham reached out to Senator Chuck Schumer (D-NY) to discuss a bipartisan deal on immigration, a topic few Republicans have been willing to engage with in recent years. In 2007, Graham faced boos at town halls for supporting reform, and his proposal was labeled "Grahamnesty" by conservative commentator Rush Limbaugh.

"There are going to be people who are upset," Graham told a media outlet last week. "I do believe that people in the Republican Party are beginning to understand the politics of immigration. But people do want the borders secured; they want to get this issue behind us; and I think I'm in a good spot to go back home and tell people that now is the time to get this done."

Florida Senator Marco Rubio, a fellow member of the Gang of Eight, provides Senator Graham some political cover on his right flank. The 2012 electoral defeat, partly driven by Mitt Romney's 27% showing with Hispanics, has led many Republicans to reconsider their opposition to a comprehensive immigration overhaul.

Randy Page, chairman of the GOP committee in South Carolina's 2nd Congressional District, is one such Republican. He voted last summer to include tough language in the GOP national platform as South Carolina's representative on the committee that drafted its contents.

"A number of us, myself included, have looked at the message that the Republican Party has been sending and looking at the message that the Hispanic community sent us in November, and we've started to listen to what Sen. Rubio and Sen. Graham have been saying," Page said.

"Looking specifically at Hispanics, most of them support us on other issues—whether social issues or fiscal issues—but yet we're saying, 'You're not welcome.' And we want you to go back and self-deport yourself'? That's the wrong rhetoric, and it's, frankly, the wrong solution."

The developments in South Carolina mirror changes in conservative thought leaders' stances on immigration reform nationally. Television host Sean Hannity, columnist Charles Krauthammer, and others have announced changes in their hearts on immigration reform since the election.

Title: Five Killed, Two Injured in Shooting at Annapolis Capital Gazette Newspaper Office

Article:

A shooting at the Annapolis Capital Gazette newspaper office on Thursday resulted in five fatalities and two injuries, according to police. The gunman, identified as Jarrod W. Ramos, a 38-year-old Laurel resident, allegedly targeted the newspaper, killing five employees and wounding two others.

The victims were identified as Wendi Winters, special publications editor; Rob Hiaasen, editor and Sunday columnist; John McNamara, writer; Gerald Fischman, editorial page editor; and Rebecca Smith, sales assistant. The gunman, who entered the building looking for specific people, was taken into custody without exchanging fire.

The shooting was described as a "targeted attack" by police, who stated that the gunman had sent threats to the newspaper on social media. Former Capital Gazette publisher and editor Tom Marquardt had previously expressed concerns about Ramos, stating, "I remember telling our attorneys, 'This is a guy who is going to come in and shoot us.'"

Ramos unsuccessfully filed a defamation lawsuit against the paper in 2012 over coverage of a criminal harassment case against him. The Baltimore Sun, which owns the Capital Gazette, and other news outlets reported similarly.

The Capital Gazette's staff took to Twitter to share details of the assault, describing the gunman as shooting through the glass doors to the office and opening fire on employees. Reporter Phil Davis tweeted, "There is nothing more terrifying than hearing multiple people get shot while you're under your desk and then hear the gunman reload."

Authorities said it took only about a minute to respond to the shooting and evacuated about 170 people from the building. Two others were injured, possibly by glass shattering from gunshot blasts. The Anne Arundel Medical Center confirmed two patients were brought there from the shooting, with only minor injuries, not caused by gunfire.

The shooting prompted wild speculation from some individuals who blamed President Trump for creating an environment that allegedly fueled the shooting. However, no direct link between the president and the shooting has been established.

The Capital Gazette, a 30,000-circulation daily, has offices in a building on the outskirts of downtown Annapolis. It shares the building with other professional offices, and people in those offices described a harrowing ordeal.

The shooting has left the community in shock, with many expressing their condolences and praising the bravery of the first responders. Defiant survivors of the attack vowed to continue their work, with reporter Chase Cook tweeting, "I can tell you this: We are putting out a damn paper tomorrow."

Title: Stormy Daniels Expands Lawsuit Against President Trump, Alleges Defamation by Michael Cohen

Article:

In a legal escalation on Monday, adult film actress Stormy Daniels broadened her lawsuit against President Donald Trump, adding his lawyer Michael Cohen as a defendant. The move comes a day after Daniels' widely viewed 60 Minutes interview in which she provided detailed accounts of an alleged sexual encounter with Trump and claimed she was physically threatened to keep quiet about the president.

The new filing argues that a $130,000 payment for her silence, made days before the 2016 election, constituted an illegal campaign contribution. The defamation claim centers on a statement Cohen made in February, explaining why he arranged the payment. In the statement, Cohen said he used his own money to "facilitate" the payoff and stated that Trump was not aware of his actions at the time.

In her new filings, Daniels contends that Cohen's statement implied she was lying about the affair and exposed her to "hatred, contempt, ridicule, and shame." The White House, in response, denied any campaign-finance law violations in the payment to Daniels and cast doubts on her claim of physical threats.

White House spokesman Raj Shah told reporters that the president does not believe Daniels' claims made in the 60 Minutes interview and that there is no corroborating evidence. Trump himself has been uncharacteristically silent about Daniels, even after she revealed unflattering details about their alleged encounter on national television.

Daniels' updated lawsuit and Shah's remarks from the White House briefing room mark the latest twist in a legal saga that has drawn comparisons to New York tabloid stories. Daniels and her attorney, Michael Avenatti, are actively working to invalidate a confidentiality agreement with Trump's lawyer.

Cohen, a former top attorney for the Trump Organization, is also fighting back. Cohen's lawyer sent a cease-and-desist letter to Avenatti after the interview aired, demanding that Daniels retract "false and defamatory" claims she made to 60 Minutes.

In the CBS interview, Daniels described agreeing to keep silent about the alleged 2006 sexual relationship with Trump in exchange for a $130,000 payment arranged by Cohen, fearing for her safety. Daniels attributed these fears to a 2011 encounter with an unidentified man who threatened her in a Las Vegas parking lot after she first tried to sell her story to a tabloid magazine.

Asked about Daniels' payment to stay quiet before the election if the affair did not happen, Shah said, "False charges are settled out of court all the time, and this is nothing outside the ordinary." Watchdog groups have filed complaints arguing that the payment likely violated campaign-finance laws.

Title: U.S. Accelerates Efforts to Decouple Supply Chain from China Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

The Trump administration is accelerating an initiative aimed at reducing the United States' reliance on a China-based supply chain and is considering imposing new tariffs as a response to China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a report published on Monday.

The economic impact and death toll from the COVID-19 outbreak have prompted a government-wide plan to shift the supply chain from China, an extension of President Trump's pledge to bring manufacturing jobs back to the U.S.

Keith Krach, undersecretary for economic growth, energy, and the environment at the State Department, told Reuters, "We've been working on [reducing the reliance of our supply chains in China] over the last few years, but we are now turbocharging that initiative."

Krach stated, "I think it is essential to understand where the critical areas are and where critical bottlenecks exist." He added that the government could announce new action soon.

A number of agencies, including the Commerce and State departments, are examining how to move the supply chain and manufacturing from China using tax incentives and other measures, the report said. They are also evaluating which manufacturing work should be considered "essential" and how to produce those goods outside of China.

"There is a whole-of-government push on this," an official told Reuters. "The White House's policy on China has always been caught between pro-trade advisers and China hawks, but the current situation has given the hard-liners new ammunition."

A senior U.S. official said, "This moment is a perfect storm; the pandemic has crystallized all the worries that people have had about doing business with China."

The official continued, "All the money that people think they made by making deals with China before, now they've been eclipsed many fold by the economic damage from the pandemic."

President Trump has discussed adding new tariffs on top of the 25 percent levies on $370 billion in Chinese goods already in place. The administration is also considering imposing sanctions on Chinese officials or companies and developing closer relations with Taiwan, which China considers a rogue province.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said late last month that the administration is working with Australia, India, Japan, New Zealand, South Korea, and Vietnam to "move the global economy forward." He stated that the talks include how to restructure supply chains "to prevent something like this from ever happening again."

The pandemic has highlighted China's critical role in the supply chain for generic drugs in the U.S., as well as medical equipment and food supplies. However, many U.S. companies have heavily invested in China and rely on the country's 1.4 billion people for sales.

Doug Barry, spokesman for the U.S.-China Business Council, told Reuters, "Diversification and some redundancy in supply chains will make sense given the level of risk that the pandemic has uncovered, but we don't see a wholesale rush for the exits by companies doing business in China."

John Murphy, senior vice president for international policy at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said building new manufacturing facilities in the U.S. could take up to eight years.

"We're concerned that officials need to get the right fact sets before they start looking at alternatives," he said.

Title: Media Outlets Dispute Romney's Characterization of Obama's Foreign Policy Speeches as an "Apology Tour"

Article:

In the aftermath of the third presidential debate, political commentator Charles Krauthammer, on the ███ Channel, praised Mitt Romney for his assertion that President Barack Obama embarked on an "apology tour" during his first term. However, mainstream media outlets have disputed this characterization, claiming that Obama did not use the word "apologize" in his foreign policy speeches.

During the debate, Obama contested Romney's claim, stating that fact-checkers and reporters have found no evidence to support the "apology tour" characterization. The Dictionary.com definition of apology as "a written or spoken expression of one's regret, remorse, or sorrow for having insulted, failed, injured, or wronged another" has been used to support Romney's claim, with Krauthammer dismissing the journalists' defense as "about as weak an answer you can get."

ABC and CNN have spoken out in defense of the President. ABC anchor George Stephanopoulos questioned if there were any "glaring misstatements" by either candidate, with Jonathan Karl zeroing in on Romney's claim that Obama went on an "apology tour" when he became President. Karl maintained that Obama did not apologize for America, despite acknowledging past mistakes in U.S. foreign policy.

CNN outright labeled the characterization as "False," with anchor John Berman asserting that Obama never used the word "apology" or said he was sorry in any of his speeches. Berman also refused to acknowledge that Obama's critical comments about past U.S. foreign policy constituted an apology.

The Heritage Foundation, however, has compiled a list of instances where Obama has chastised past U.S. foreign policy, including a speech in France where Obama stated that "at times we sought to dictate our terms" and an op-ed about policy toward the Americas where Obama declared that "Too often, the United States has not pursued and sustained engagement with our neighbors."

Other examples include Obama's rationalization that "The United States is still working through some of our own darker periods in our history" while speaking to the Turkish parliament, his urging of CIA employees to acknowledge "potentially we've made some mistakes" in an administration report about enhanced interrogation techniques, and his denunciation of techniques used in the war on terror and his apology for the establishment and operation of the Guantanamo Bay detention camp.

With the election approaching, it appears that the press corps will continue to scrutinize both candidates' statements and fact-check their claims, potentially affecting the outcome in swing states. Brent Baker, the Steven P.J. Wood Senior Fellow and Vice President for Research and Publications at the Media Research Center, oversees the NewsBusters blog and can be found on Twitter as BrentHBaker.

Title: Maine Officials Seek Court Order for Ebola Nurse Kaci Hickox's Quarantine, Nurse Vows to Fight Order

Article:

Maine officials have announced their intention to seek a court order to enforce a mandatory 21-day quarantine for Ebola nurse Kaci Hickox. Hickox, who recently returned from treating Ebola patients in Sierra Leone, expressed her opposition to the quarantine, stating, "I am not willing to stand here and have my civil rights violated."

During a press conference earlier today, Maine Health Commissioner Mary Mayhew stated, "When it is made clear by an individual in this risk category that they do not intend to voluntarily stay at home for the remaining 21 days, we will immediately seek a court order to ensure that they do not make contact with the public." However, legal experts question whether such an order would be approved by a judge.

Public health lawyer Wendy Mariner, who teaches at Boston University School of Law, stated, "The state has the burden of proving that she is infected, or at least was credibly exposed to infection, and also that by her own behavior she is likely to infect others if not confined. The state is not likely to have any evidence of that." Mariner added that Hickox should be able to prove that she is not infected and plans to take precautions to not expose anyone to her bodily fluids.

Earlier today, Maine's governor and other officials stated they were seeking legal authority to enforce what started out as a voluntary quarantine. They also stated that state police were monitoring Hickox's home "for both her protection and the health of the community."

Kaci Hickox, 33, was treating Ebola patients in Sierra Leone for Doctors Without Borders. She returned to the United States on Friday, landing in Newark Liberty International Airport in New Jersey, where she was questioned and quarantined in an outdoor tent despite having no symptoms. Hickox registered a fever on an infrared thermometer at the airport but an oral thermometer at University Hospital in Newark showed that she actually had no fever, she said.

After twice testing negative for the deadly virus, Hickox was released and returned home to Maine on Monday. The following day, the state's health commissioner announced that Maine would join the handful of states going beyond federal guidelines and asking that returning Ebola health workers self-quarantine.

"Our true desire is for a voluntary separation from the public," Main Health Commissioner Mary Mayhew said in a statement. "We do not want to have to legally enforce an in-home quarantine. We are confident that the selfless health workers, who were brave enough to care for Ebola patients in a foreign country, will be willing to take reasonable steps to protect the residents of their own country. However, we are willing to pursue legal authority if necessary to ensure risk is minimized for Mainers."

Kaci Hickox told "Good Morning America" today via Skype from her hometown of Fort Kent, "I will go to court to attain my freedom. I have been completely asymptomatic since I've been here. I feel absolutely great."

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention does not consider health workers who treated Ebola patients in West Africa to be at "high risk" for catching Ebola if they were wearing protective gear, according to new guidelines announced this week. Since they have "some risk," the CDC recommends that they undergo monitoring, avoid public transportation, and take other precautions. However, the CDC does not require home quarantines for these workers.

Someone is not contagious until Ebola symptoms appear, according to the CDC. And even then, transmission requires contact with bodily fluids such as blood and vomit.

Title: North Korea Cuts Military Hotlines, Escalates Propaganda War Against U.S. and South Korea

Article:

North Korea has severed its last military hotlines with South Korea and increased its rhetoric, causing concern in the region. Thousands of North Koreans rallied in central Pyongyang, chanting "Death to the U.S. imperialists." Their leader, Kim Jong Un, has called for "scores to be settled" with the U.S.

This is the latest phase in a propaganda war. Pyongyang also released a video depicting an invasion of Seoul, with North Korean forces flying across the border to destroy American bases in South Korea. The video also shows the cancellation of the armistice agreement that ended the Korean War. However, experts are skeptical about North Korea's threats to attack American bases in Guam, Hawaii, and the U.S. mainland.

Kim Heung-kyu, a professor at Sungshin Women's University in Seoul and an adviser to South Korea's last president, Lee Myung-bak, states, "I do not think they are capable of launching this type of attack against the United States." He anticipates North Korea's provocations to be against South Korea, involving cyberwarfare and targeting military areas or certain scientific facilities.

South Korea's new president, Park Geun-hye, continues to discuss "trustpolitik," aiming to re-establish trust while taking a tough line with the North. Pyongyang is attempting to pressure her to soften her policies and secure direct talks from Washington.

With communication links severed, the biggest danger is miscalculation, according to John Delury of Yonsei University in Seoul. "Both countries are essentially on a kind of war footing. In the South, there's expectation that some provocation could be coming soon, and there's no one on the end of the [hotline] to answer, to clarify," he says. "South Koreans are finger-on-the-trigger ready to do something. That's why it's so dangerous to have no channel whatsoever between the two countries right now."

North Korea has antagonized China, its traditional ally, with its rocket launch and third nuclear test. Peking University's Jia Qingguo states that China's position is much tougher than before, and China is on board for stiffer U.N. sanctions against its old ally. "I think this is a turning point. North Korea has decided to pursue what it believes to be its best interests at the expense of the interest of other countries, including China," Jia says. "I think China has put up with it for a long time, and enough is enough."

However, Beijing's prime concern is still stability, making it unlikely to abandon Pyongyang at the moment. The propaganda war continues, with the escalating threats and massive rallies leaving Pyongyang little room for maneuver. One thing is clear: The new young leader, Kim Jong Un, has learned from his father's playbook and may yet prove to be more unpredictable.

Title: Cruz Wins Iowa Republican Caucus; Clinton and Sanders Tied in Democratic Contest

Article:

Republican Senator Ted Cruz emerged victorious in the Iowa caucus on Monday, securing 28 percent of the vote, while businessman Donald Trump followed closely behind with 24 percent. Senator Marco Rubio, a Florida Republican, came in third with 23 percent, positioning himself as the leading establishment candidate.

In the Democratic contest, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders, a self-described democratic socialist, were neck and neck, with each candidate receiving approximately 50 percent of the vote with 95 percent of precincts reporting results. Sanders declared the results a tie. Former Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley, who struggled to gain traction in the Democratic race, suspended his campaign, taking third place with less than one percent.

Cruz's win and Rubio's strong showing may impact Trump's momentum, as his candidacy has been marked by controversies such as his calls for a temporary ban on Muslims entering the United States. In his victory speech, Cruz, 45, thanked God and expressed gratitude to evangelical voters. Trump, 69, congratulated Cruz and looked forward to the next contest in New Hampshire, where polls show him ahead.

Clinton, 68, said she was relieved after the results, having lost to then-Senator Barack Obama in 2008. Sanders, 74, said he and Clinton were in a "virtual tie" and expressed gratitude for the support of Iowans. The results could shift momentum in both races, with Clinton aiming for a strong finish against Sanders to quell his insurgent campaign and Sanders leading in opinion polls in New Hampshire.

Rubio's third-place finish established him as the Republican mainstream alternative to Trump and Cruz. "I am grateful to you, Iowa. You believed in me when others did not think it was possible," Rubio, 44, said.

The Iowa caucus, held since the early 1970s, gives the state extra weight in the U.S. electoral process, translating into momentum for winning candidates. The caucuses are voter gatherings that take place in 1,100 schools, churches, and other public locations across the Midwestern state.

The 2016 election is shaping up to be the year of angry voters, as disgruntled Americans worry about issues such as immigration, terrorism, income inequality, and healthcare, fueling the campaigns of Trump, Sanders, and Cruz. Financial markets showed a muted response to the results, with U.S. stock futures down around half a percent.

Title: Federal Government's Potential Missed Opportunity to Profit from Strategic Petroleum Reserve

Article:

The federal Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR) has 78.5 million barrels of spare capacity available, as of April 10, according to the most recent data. This spare capacity could have potentially generated a significant profit for the government by taking advantage of the current and future prices of U.S. crude oil.

Had the federal government acted last week, it could have purchased 78.5 million barrels of crude oil for the SPR at Friday's price of $18.27 on the New York Mercantile Exchange and simultaneously agreed to deliver that same amount of oil in December at $33.82. This difference of $15.55 per barrel would have resulted in a potential profit of $1.22 billion for the government. Given the current plunge in oil prices, the profit would be approximately half a billion dollars higher.

However, the government did not take advantage of this opportunity due to several reasons. First, the idea of arbitraging oil by simultaneously buying and selling it is not a common practice for the federal government. Second, the Energy Department did not receive the funds from Congress to buy oil for the SPR in the last stimulus package, and it is unclear if the SPR has the authority to sell oil in the futures market.

The Trump administration has, however, ordered the SPR to store 23 million barrels of oil for hard-pressed oil companies. This reduces the SPR's spare capacity to 55.5 million barrels, resulting in a potential profit of $863 million, based on the same $15.55 per barrel spread. The Energy Department declined to disclose the storage fee or the duration for which the oil will be stored.

The oil companies depositing the oil and then getting most of it back will likely turn a profit that could have otherwise gone to the taxpayers. This is because June oil futures were selling for 34% more than the then-current price, July futures were 57% higher, and the numbers kept climbing. This spread is likely more than the rent rate that the SPR will charge.

While some may oppose anything that helps increase oil production, the potential profit from the SPR's spare storage capacity is likely to go to oil companies if no action is taken quickly by President Trump, Congress, or both. The government could have profited from the SPR, which was established at taxpayer expense, rather than oil companies profiting from it. The potential profit of $1.22 billion, or even $2 billion, is significant compared to the looming budget deficits.

Title: Intense Fighting Erupts at Iraq-Syria Border as Kurdish Forces Battle Islamic State

Article:

Heavy fighting has been reported at a key border crossing between Iraq and Syria, where Kurdish forces are engaged in combat with Islamic State (IS) militants. Iraqi Kurdish troops are said to have recaptured the town of Rabia, but suffered heavy casualties. Meanwhile, IS fighters are attempting to dislodge Syrian Kurdish forces on the other side of the border.

The recapture of Rabia by Iraqi Kurdish troops, according to reports, was aided by two British Tornado jet air strikes, as per information from Kurdish sources. The strikes reportedly helped the Kurds retake an "important border crossing" at Rabia, as stated by the BBC's Clive Myrie in Irbil, northern Iraq.

In Syria, US warplanes conducted 11 air strikes over the last two days, targeting IS positions near Deir al-Zour, Sinjar, Mazra al-Duwud, and Aleppo. These strikes destroyed a number of armed vehicles, artillery pieces, and one tank.

In Iraq, 11 US raids on Tuesday in the north-west, near the Mosul Dam and Baghdad, destroyed IS armoured and transport vehicles and a checkpoint.

Violence has also claimed lives in Iraq, with at least 20 people killed in bomb attacks on Shia areas of the Iraqi capital Baghdad, and similar attacks in the holy Shia city of Karbala.

The United Nations (UN) humanitarian chief, Valerie Amos, stated that 11 million people inside Syria require urgent aid. She warned that without additional funding, the World Food Programme will be forced to end its operations completely within two months.

In a separate development, Turkish tanks have taken up positions along the border near the Syrian town of Kobane after several shells hit Turkish territory during clashes between IS and Kurdish fighters. The Turkish government has requested parliamentary authorization for military action against IS in Iraq and Syria, and MPs are expected to discuss the issue on Thursday.

Senior Iraqi Kurdish officials reported that their Peshmerga special forces made significant progress during their dawn offensive in Rabia. By nightfall, Rabia was said to be firmly in Kurdish control, although IS militants continued to hold out in just one building.

Rabia is approximately 100km (60 miles) north-west of Mosul, the biggest city controlled by IS. However, the Iraqi Kurdish forces also took heavy casualties, including the loss of a senior commander, when three suicide car bombers detonated themselves among the Kurdish troops. The bombers are believed to have travelled from IS-controlled areas further east.

Control of the Rabia crossing and cutting IS supply lines are seen as important steps towards an eventual move to regain the town of Sinjar and its nearby mountain. Militants overran that area in August, forcing tens of thousands of civilians from the minority Yazidi community to flee for their lives.

The other side of the border is controlled by Syrian Kurdish fighters, who themselves have been coming under attacks from IS. More than 30 Syrian Kurdish fighters are reported to have been killed as the jihadists took over several villages south of the border crossing. However, the crossing itself is said to be still under Kurdish control.

Title: Bernie Sanders Aims to Encourage Party Unity Ahead of Democratic National Convention

Article:

In the lead-up to the Democratic National Convention, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders is set to meet privately with his supporters on Monday to address concerns over the nominating process, party platform, and party leadership. Some Sanders backers have expressed frustration and have suggested they may protest or take action on the convention floor.

Sanders, who endorsed Hillary Clinton two weeks ago after a long-fought primary, has sought to find common ground around the party platform and rules. He successfully won major platform concessions, including a $15 federal minimum wage, abolishing the death penalty, and breaking up large Wall Street banks.

At a meeting of the DNC credentials committee on Sunday, comments praising party chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz were met with laughter by some Sanders supporters. At a committee meeting the previous day, Sanders backers shouted "shame, shame, shame" as amendments to abolish or limit superdelegates in future nominating competitions were voted down.

Some Sanders delegates feel the Clinton campaign is not taking their policy concerns seriously. At a news conference on Sunday, Sanders delegate Norman Solomon, 65, of Point Reyes Station, California, said many of Sanders' liberal supporters were disappointed in Clinton's vice presidential pick of Virginia Sen. Tim Kaine. He said most viewed Kaine as not progressive enough, and there had been discussion about a variety of protest actions at the convention, including walking out.

However, Sanders delegate Courtney Rowe, 34, from Cedar Rapids, Iowa, said "we are not here to disrupt for the purpose of disruption." She said she was not currently planning on any action and wanted to hear from Sanders.

Sanders has made clear that he would like to see a full roll call vote at the convention, so that his delegates can show their support. After the unity commission agreement, Sanders supporters seeking to pass amendments to abolish or curtail superdelegates opted against pursuing convention floor fights on the issue.

Title: GOP's Lack of Consensus on Healthcare Reform: A Look at the Challenges and Consequences

Article:

For over three years, the Republican party has been embroiled in a contentious debate over the appropriate response to the passage of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), with some advocating for its repeal and replacement, while others favor repeal without a clear replacement plan. In practice, the latter position has been the Republicans' actual stance, as they have repeatedly voted to repeal the law but have yet to reach a consensus on a single replacement plan.

During the lead-up to the ACA's implementation, this lack of a coherent replacement strategy has been a liability for the Republicans, damaging their credibility as critics of healthcare reform with the press and the public alike. The argument that the old system was flawed and should be reverted to might seem compelling under the troubled ACA rollout, but the Republicans find themselves in a unique position of relief rather than regret.

The relief stems from the fact that a replacement plan would neutralize one of their most effective, yet disingenuous, lines of attack against the ACA. The outrage expressed by Republicans over cancellation notices for individual market insurance plans is seen as insincere because their primary interest in addressing this issue is through the repeal or destruction of the ACA.

Moreover, the most revealing aspect of the Republicans' position, as identified by The New Republic's Jonathan Cohn, is that almost all GOP healthcare plans would disrupt the insurance market more dramatically than the ACA does. The Republicans' inability to reach a consensus on a replacement plan for Obamacare indicates a general agreement that very few people should be allowed to keep their current insurance plans.

Jonathan Cohn explains that almost all GOP plans would result in the disruption of millions of people's Medicaid coverage and would create a significant incentive for healthy workers to abandon their employer-sponsored insurance plans for individual ones, leading to a death spiral in the employer-sponsored insurance market. This would result in more cancellation notices and "rate shock" than currently observed, but without the safety net of the ACA's exchanges to cushion the impact.

The National Review's Ramesh Ponnuru's solution to this problem is to phase out the ACA's disruptions gradually. While the ACA creates an immediate disruption for a relatively small group of individual policyholders, Republicans should create a slow, steady disruption for tens of millions more.

Other conservative policy wonks propose replacing all insurance with subsidized catastrophic coverage and tax-preferred health savings accounts. Under this plan, no one with private insurance or Medicaid would be able to keep their current coverage, regardless of how much they value it.

Another aspect of the Republicans' healthcare reform plans is the elimination of traditional Medicare for future retirees and its replacement with a plan that resembles the ACA. The sales pitch version of the plan is that Republicans aim to keep the promise made to current retirees and those nearing retirement, but to radically overhaul the system for the young and middle-aged. Over time, single-payer Medicare would be phased out.

However, as nearly every healthcare expert will tell you, the phase-out would be massively disruptive. As the program's beneficiaries aged and dwindled in number, it would become unsustainable very quickly. Without scale, the government would lose its purchasing power, and would either have to fork over substantial amounts of money to motivate providers to care for beneficiaries – a bailout – or watch providers abandon the program en masse, leaving the country's oldest, sickest people with little choice but to enter the private insurance market.

The Republicans' portrayal of President Obama's "if you like your plan, you can keep it" promise as the noble lie from which all of the ACA's apocalyptic consequences will ultimately spring is a focus of their criticism. However, the deception they hope to perpetrate against seniors, by promising to maintain traditional Medicare while gradually phasing it out, is far more egregious.

If a consensus GOP plan were to materialize today, the Republicans would have to reconcile their expressed sympathy for young policyholders facing cancellation notices with the radical nature of their own vision. It is unclear how they would address the consequences of their plan without being forthright about them. The truth is, such a plan would likely fail on the House floor due to its radical nature. Given the disruption it would cause, it is doubtful that there will ever be a political constituency for it, even if the Republicans regain control of the government.

Title: House Remains Republican Likely in 2014 Midterm Elections, According to Analysts

 Article:

 In the upcoming 2014 midterm elections, the House of Representatives is expected to remain under Republican control, according to political analysts. The current composition of the House is 233 Republicans, 200 Democrats, and two vacancies. Upcoming special elections to fill the vacancies in Alabama and Massachusetts will likely result in one seat for each party.

 Democratic strategists have identified 17 Republican-held seats they are targeting, including districts carried by President Barack Obama in the 2012 election. Victories in all 17 districts by Democratic candidates would result in a Democratic majority in the House, with 218 seats to 217 for the Republicans. However, this strategy depends on Democrats winning every targeted seat and Republicans picking up no seats.

 On the other hand, Republicans are expected to target the nine districts that went for Mitt Romney for president but sent a Democrat to the House. These include the two closest races in the nation last year: North Carolina's 7th District and Arizona's 2nd, in which Republicans David Rouzer and Martha McSally will square off in rematches with Democratic Reps. Mike McIntyre and Ron Barber, respectively.

 The most vulnerable Democratic-held district in the nation is Florida's 18th District, where 30-year-old Democrat Patrick Murphy edged out conservative Allen West by less than 2,000 votes in 2012. Already, four Republicans have filed for the chance to oppose Murphy in 2014. Murphy's vote against repeal of Obamacare is expected to be a major issue for any Republican opponent.

 For open seats, there is typically greater competition and more "switcheroos" than attempting to dislodge incumbents. So far, there are 14 seats without incumbents—five Democratic-held seats and nine Republican-held seats. The West Virginia seat that Republican Shelley Moore Capito is leaving to run for the Senate could go Democratic, and the Iowa seat Democrat Bruce Braley is giving up for a Senate run could go the other way. For now, few of the other 12 are likely to flip.

 Former Secretary of State James Baker once said, "Overnight is an eternity in politics." Much can change between now and November of 2014. However, at this time, the best prediction is the House remains Republican next year. Just do the math.

Title: Grass-roots Pressure on White House Increases as Immigration Debate Shifts

Article:

The White House is facing mounting pressure from grass-roots organizations to take action on the immigration issue, as progressive groups shift their focus from critics of the president's agenda to the White House itself. With the Republican Party controlling the House and election-year jitters, these organizations view the White House as the most viable avenue for progress on immigration.

The Center for American Progress and National Council of La Raza are the only two progressive immigration organizations that are not demanding President Barack Obama halt deportations himself. Other grassroots groups claim these organizations may be too close to the White House to maintain objectivity.
