The government has stated its intention to identify between six and eight locations where all reunifications will take place. The government's filing did not specify whether it intends to release families after reunification, deport them, or keep them together in detention.

Title: College-Age Americans' Support for Free Speech Decreases Over Decades, Converging with Older Generations

Article:

The General Social Survey, initiated in the '70s, has periodically asked Americans if they believe someone should have the right to give a racist speech in their community. John Sides, a political scientist, has analyzed the responses and categorized the participants into four groups: Americans aged 18 to 25 who have had at least some college education, Americans aged 18 to 25 with no college education, older Americans with at least some college education, and older Americans with no college education.

The data shows a significant decrease in the percentage of college-age individuals supporting the freedom of speech for a racist over the four decades. Interestingly, the college-age group is not leading the way in this regard but is instead converging with the non-college group. Notably, the significant drop in the college-age group's support for free speech ended in the late '80s, with a slight decline in the '90s and a resurgence in the 21st century.

This trend contradicts the common perception that the '90s marked the beginning of the age of political correctness. Instead, Sides suggests viewing this period as a time of backlash against political correctness. The first wave of "PC Kids Gone Mad!" stories that emerged in the national press in 1990 was not a sign of growing pro-censorship sentiments; rather, it indicated a growing resistance to such sentiments.

In addition to the decline in tolerance for controversial speech among college-age individuals, Sides also charts the percentage of Americans in each group who support free speech for communists. The drop in the college crowd's support is less severe, with over 50% still supporting the communist's rights, but there is still a noticeable decrease at the beginning, followed by a flattening in the '90s and a resurgence in the post-9/11 era.

The decline in collegiate civil libertarianism resumed after the '90s is a significant question, and one possible factor could be the increasing number of college-age individuals who do not remember the '80s. Backlashes tend to fade with memory. Another interesting trend observed in Sides' data is the growing tolerance among older Americans with no college education. A third chart, not reproduced here, shows a similar jump in the number of non-college-educated older Americans willing to back the free-speech rights of an atheist.

Title: Bernie Sanders and Ted Cruz Vow to Continue Campaigns Despite New York Primary Losses

Article:

In the aftermath of Tuesday's New York primaries, both the Bernie Sanders and Ted Cruz campaigns have vowed to press on towards their respective party conventions, disregarding suggestions from their rivals that their campaigns are mathematically eliminated from the race.

Following a third-place finish in New York, Cruz's path to overtake Donald Trump in the Republican race before the July convention appears slim. On the Democratic side, Sanders would need to win 73% of the remaining delegates and uncommitted superdelegates to catch up to Hillary Clinton.

Clinton, who could still clinch the nomination even if she loses every remaining primary, declared victory on Tuesday night, stating, "The race for the Democratic nomination is in the home stretch, and victory is in sight." A campaign aide, speaking off the record, suggested Sanders has no mathematical chance of a comeback.

Trump, who declared, "We don't have much of a race anymore," at his own victory party, is aiming to secure the nomination by racking up delegates in the coming weeks. According to The Washington Post, an internal Trump memo projects Trump would get more than 1,400 delegates on the first round of balloting to secure the nomination.

Cruz and Ohio Governor John Kasich, if they can hold Trump under the 1,237 delegates needed to clinch the nomination before the convention, aim to have delegate allies in place from across the country who would peel off from Trump and support them after the first round of voting. Cruz's campaign is also courting "unbound" delegates in several states, including Pennsylvania, in hopes they would support him in the event of a floor fight.

Sanders, presuming he cannot clinch the nomination before the Philadelphia convention, is pursuing a strategy that relies on winning over superdelegates, the party insiders and officials free to support whomever they want. Clinton holds an overwhelming lead among them and is well-positioned to reach the 2,383 total delegates needed by the end of primaries in June, counting both superdelegates and pledged.

Sanders has given mixed signals following his New York loss. He took a day off from the campaign trail Wednesday to return to Vermont, and senior adviser Tad Devine described next week as a "big week." Sanders plans to return to the campaign trail in Pennsylvania on Thursday.

Few in the Democratic Party expect Sanders to exit the race formally before the final contests in June. He continues to attract tens of thousands to rallies and raises millions of dollars, enabling him to sustain his persistent fight.

Title: Egypt's Former President Hosni Mubarak Ordered Conditional Release from Prison

Article:

Egyptian judicial officials have ordered the conditional release of former President Hosni Mubarak, who ruled the nation for three decades before being ousted in a popular revolution in 2011. The decision, which comes amidst ongoing protests and violence in Egypt, could potentially escalate the unrest in the North African country.

The announcement, made as Egypt grapples with new protests following the July 3 ouster of Mubarak's successor, Mohammad Morsi, has sparked fears of further violent reprisals from the Muslim Brotherhood, whose supporters have clashed with security forces and torched dozens of Coptic churches. Over the past week, as many as 1,000 Egyptians, including 70 soldiers and police officers, have been killed in the conflict between the Muslim Brotherhood and more secular Muslims and Christians.

On Sunday, 36 Islamists died while being transported to a prison outside Cairo. Government officials stated they suffocated in the back of a prison van after tear gas was used on them as they rioted. The Muslim Brotherhood accused the interior ministry of killing the detainees "for their opposition to the bloody military council."

Mubarak, currently on retrial for the killings of hundreds of protesters during the 2011 uprising, will be released from jail in the next 48 hours after a prosecutor cleared him of a corruption charge, his lawyer Fareed El-Deeb told Reuters. However, The New York Times reported that the government could still find a way to hold Mubarak, and his release is not imminent.

Mubarak will continue to stand retrial for the protesters' killing but can no longer be held in custody due to a two-year limit for holding an individual in custody pending a final verdict. Mubarak has been in detention since April 2011 and is currently held at Tora prison on the southern outskirts of Cairo, the same facility where senior members of the Muslim Brotherhood are being held.

Mubarak was found guilty and sentenced to life in prison in June 2012 for his failure to stop the killing of some 900 protesters during the 18-day uprising against his rule. His sentence was overturned on appeal, and he is now being retried, along with his security chief and six top police commanders.

Judicial authorities ordered Mubarak's release in one of the remaining corruption cases against him, which alleged he and his two sons embezzled funds for presidential palaces, according to the Associated Press. According to Deeb, the only legal grounds for the ousted president's detention rest on one other corruption case, which is expected to be resolved this week.

If Mubarak is freed, the reversal will be significant, as Morsi has been held at an undisclosed location since being removed from power. The military removed President Mohamed Mursi, a senior Brotherhood official, on July 3 after mass protests against his rule. Mursi is in detention at an undisclosed location and faces an investigation into accusations, including murder, stemming from his escape from prison during the anti-Mubarak revolt.

The U.S. and Europe are monitoring the situation and urging calm as the key Middle Eastern nation unravels. The EU plans to meet Wednesday in Brussels to discuss the situation, while President Obama, back from vacation, has urged calm without explicitly taking sides.

Title: Portfolio Manager Sells Junk Bonds in Anticipation of Debt Rally End

Article:

Pilar Gomez-Bravo, a portfolio manager at MFS Investment Management, has reduced her high-yield exposure from as high as 30% in 2016 to 10% in one of her unconstrained funds, which manages $4.5 billion in fixed-income assets. This move comes as the average U.S. high-yield bond spreads have fallen below 375 basis points, a level that in the past has signified negative excess returns in a year's time.

Gomez-Bravo, who oversees a slew of global credit funds, sees the current corporate debt rally as potentially overextended, with borrowers still holding the upper hand due to cheap-money policies and low defaults. She believes that the long-bemoaned opacity and leverage of junk issuers are now at a tipping point.

In Europe, over a third of private high-yield companies restrict access to financial data in some way, according to unspecified analysis earlier this year. Gomez-Bravo argues that buyers should receive extra compensation for firms that curb access to earnings with password-protected sites.

The speculation of another round of quantitative easing by the European Central Bank is spurring the rally, masking fragile balance sheets. However, leaving the party too early risks leaving profits on the table. Gomez-Bravo is selling into a rising market and taking more political risk by adding to investments in peripheral governments like Greece and Italy.

Gomez-Bravo, who was a portfolio manager at Lehman Brothers' investment arm during the 2008 financial crisis, recalls similar signs of a speculative mania before the last bubble. She anticipates real end-of-cycle fears about what will perform in the current market.

When Lehman Brothers went bust, Gomez-Bravo was a senior credit analyst on Lehman's sellside but moved in 2006, citing frustration with unchecked animal spirits. Like even outspoken naysayers at the time, she didn't anticipate the violence of the downturn. However, in May 2007, Gomez-Bravo became cautious on U.S. risk and issued warnings on corporate health, which bear echoes with the intense hunt for yield today.

Title: Wisconsin to Hold In-Person Voting Despite Coronavirus Concerns

Article:

Wisconsin is set to hold in-person voting next week, as the state's legislature declined to take up an effort to delay the presidential primary due to the coronavirus pandemic. The state's Republican-controlled legislature ended special weekend sessions without taking action on a call by Democratic Governor Tony Evers to make Tuesday's primary an all-mail election and extend the time to return ballots until late May, according to local media outlets.

Reid Magney, public information officer for the Wisconsin Election Commission, confirmed to media outlets that the election will proceed as planned, with in-person voting. Leaders in the legislature, which has the sole authority to delay the ballot, criticized Evers for a late reversal on holding voting and stated that the election, which also decides thousands of state and local offices, must go ahead as planned. Legislators could still reconsider in the coming days.

Republicans also asked the U.S. Supreme Court to prevent the extension of Wisconsin's deadline for absentee voting to April 13, which a federal judge had previously ordered. "Republicans in the Legislature are playing politics with public safety and ignoring the urgency of this public health crisis," Evers said in a statement. "It's wrong. No one should have to choose between their health and their right to vote."

Residents in the state are under orders to stay at home and public gatherings are banned due to the pandemic. Fears about infection have led to a shortage of poll workers and an explosion in requests for absentee ballots. Officials in the state have warned of potential chaos if the voting goes ahead.

The pandemic has disrupted the Democratic race to pick a challenger to run against Republican President Donald Trump in the Nov. 3 election, forcing more than a dozen states to delay or adjust their primaries to limit the health risks. Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden has said it is possible to conduct Wisconsin's in-person vote safely. Rival Bernie Sanders, who trails Biden significantly in the race, called for the primary to be postponed.

Title: Amazon Faces Increased Scrutiny Over Workplace Conditions as Free and Fair Markets Initiative Launches Hotline

Article:

The Free and Fair Markets Initiative, a nonprofit watchdog, has partnered with former Amazon workers to establish a hotline for reporting unsafe working conditions within Amazon warehouses. The initiative aims to address concerns about Amazon's labor practices, particularly in light of the company's ongoing expansion plans.

In a statement, the group's chief spokesperson, Robert B. Engel, criticized Amazon for its alleged disregard for worker safety and well-being. "Amazon grinds its workers until they have nothing left to give," Engel said. "It's time someone did something about it."

The Free and Fair Markets Initiative has been scrutinizing Amazon's practices since its inception last year, focusing on the company's harmful practices, especially in relation to workplace conditions. The National Council for Occupational Safety and Health (NCOSH) has included Amazon on its "Dirty Dozen" list for two consecutive years, drawing attention to companies that regularly put employees and communities at risk.

In its most recent report, NCOSH noted that despite Amazon's vast resources, there is little evidence the company has made a significant effort to address worker complaints about stress, overwork, and other conditions that can lead to illness, injuries, and fatalities. Between October 2013 and 2018, emergency responders were reportedly called to Amazon warehouses at least 189 times for suicide attempts, suicidal thoughts, and other mental-health episodes, according to a report by The Daily Beast.

The hotline, which allows workers to report unsafe conditions anonymously, also provides instructions and resources for taking their complaint further by filing with OSHA either online, physically, or over the phone.

A former Hebron, Kentucky warehouse worker, who wished to remain anonymous due to a non-disclosure agreement, is assisting on the hotline. They stated, "People need to be aware of what's going on inside these warehouses. You're going to need a lot more than just one phone line to hear all these complaints from the workers."

In response, Amazon stated, "We work hard to provide a safe, quality work environment for our associates, who are encouraged to provide feedback through public and private channels and are always welcome to talk to leaders at their site — 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. All of this is on top of our industry-leading $15 minimum wage and comprehensive benefits starting on day one." Amazon also emphasized that workers are encouraged to compare their safety record, employer practices, and work conditions with any major employer or retailer.

Title: Oregon Senate Race: Two Republican Candidates Vie for Democratic-Held Seat

Article:

In the ongoing bid by Republicans to gain control of the U.S. Senate, some are targeting an unlikely state: Oregon. The Beaver State has not elected a Republican in a statewide election since 2002. However, the incumbent Senator Jeff Merkley is seen as vulnerable, partly due to his enthusiastic support for ObamaCare in a state that experienced a disastrous rollout of its failed health care exchange, Cover Oregon.

The Republican primary in Oregon will be held on Tuesday, and it appears to be a two-person race between Dr. Monica Wehby and Jason Conger, two candidates with compelling personal stories who are quite different on social issues.

Dr. Wehby, a pediatric neurosurgeon with 30 years in the field, is the first woman to graduate from UCLA's neurosurgery program. She gained prominence in this race due to her early criticism of ObamaCare. As a member of the American Medical Association's board, she was featured in a 2009 ad opposing the Affordable Care Act.

"It's a 2,700 page law, 20,000 pages of regulations now -- it's impossible to work with this law," Wehby said. "I think the best way is to repeal and replace with a plan that will actually work."

Conger, a two-term representative in the Oregon State House, is also a practicing lawyer. His path to the legal profession was anything but ordinary. His mother abandoned the family when he was young, and he lived with his father, often staying in trailer parks and being homeless, sleeping in the back of his family truck. From those humble beginnings in northern California, he graduated from Harvard Law School.

"I feel extraordinarily blessed to have been able to go from barely graduating from an alternative high school to graduating from Harvard Law School and living what I would consider the American dream," Conger said.

Dr. Wehby has been endorsed by GOP heavyweights like Mitt Romney, Newt Gingrich, and Dr. Ben Carson. She also received a major boost in the form of a $400,000 advertising campaign funded by the New Republican super PAC. The group's ads highlight Wehby's credibility on ObamaCare, her sensitivity to issues important to women, and her professional background.

Conger has raised far less money and polls suggest he's trailing. However, he does have plenty of support, especially from social conservatives. Oregon Right to Life endorsed his candidacy, and former presidential candidate Rick Santorum recently endorsed him in a radio ad. Conger also has wide support among Republican lawmakers in Oregon. He is strong on the Second Amendment, is staunchly pro-life, and opposes gay marriage.

Wehby, who was raised Catholic, says she is personally pro-life, but would not work to take away abortion rights for other women. She is divorced with four teenage children. She says she is not opposed to gay marriage. She believes the GOP can grow if it becomes a little more libertarian on social issues.

"We don't want the government interfering in our business, in our personal lives, in our private lives, in our personal decisions," Wehby said. "As Republicans, we want as little government interference in our lives as possible."

The Republicans have been on a losing streak in Oregon ever since Merkley defeated Gordon Smith in 2002. Mike Riley, of the Portland political consulting firm Riley Research, said gender politics do matter in the state.

"Republican men, particularly senior Republican men, have a very hard time attracting votes in Oregon, among Democrats, of course, but independent women as well," he said.

However, Conger believes moving to the center is the wrong strategy.

"You don't have to be moderate, you don't have to abandon your principles," he said. "You have to offer an alternative to voters to the incumbent, an alternative that is more attractive, that is credible and speaks to issues that they care about."

Wehby might carry some baggage into the general election if she wins the primary. A number of recent stories raise questions about her relationship with a Republican donor who runs a large Oregon lumber company. Andrew Miller, owner of Stimson Lumber, donated $31,000 to a super PAC that helped fund ads attacking Conger. It's been widely reported that Miller and Wehby dated. The Oregon Democratic Party filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission alleging there must have been coordination between Miller and the Wehby campaign, which would have made the donation a violation of campaign finance laws. Wehby told Fox News there was no coordination.

Politico is also reporting Miller accused Wehby of stalking him and harassing his employees as the couple was breaking up in 2013. No charges or restraining orders were ever filed.

Title: New Center's Comprehensive Immigration Reform Proposal Faces Timing and Sequencing Challenges

Article:

A new comprehensive immigration reform proposal, spearheaded by the New Center, a bipartisan think tank, has been introduced, offering an opportunity to review the current state of immigration policy in the United States. The proposal, which faces challenges in terms of timing and sequencing, suggests a shift from a family-based legal immigration system to a merit-based one, prioritizing factors such as education, work experience, job offers, and English skills.

The plan offers legal status and permanent residency after ten years to individuals who have resided in the U.S. continuously since the end of 2011, have paid application fees and back taxes, and have clean criminal records. "Dreamers" who arrived as minors and have not committed felonies would receive green cards immediately. The proposal also includes increased border security, advanced technology for tracking temporary visa holders, and a mandate for the use of E-Verify, a system that allows employers to check whether job applicants are in the country legally.

However, the plan's timing and the sequence of policy implementation have become contentious issues. Conservatives have long advocated for "enforcement first," insisting on demonstrating border control, visa overstay enforcement, and employer sanctions before any amnesty is granted. The New Center plan, on the other hand, does not delay amnesty and instead mandates that E-Verify not be implemented until everyone has had a chance to apply for legal status. This sequencing could potentially weaken conservative leverage to ensure the vigorous implementation of enforcement measures promised after amnesty.

If enacted, the plan may face opposition from both sides, rather than being the result of a bipartisan agreement. The success of comprehensive immigration reform may hinge on finding a compromise on the timing and sequencing of policy implementation, as one side may have to accept a loss in order for a deal to be reached.

Title: Roy Moore's Senate Bid: A Look at the Former Alabama Chief Justice's Path to a Primary Runoff

Article:

After winning the U.S. Senate seat in Alabama in 2017, Roy Moore's political career seemed to come to a halt following allegations of unwanted sexual contact with teenage girls. However, Moore has announced his bid for the Senate again, and his new campaign cannot be entirely dismissed. Despite President Trump's disapproval, Moore still has a dedicated base of support, particularly among conservative evangelical Christians.

As of now, there are four notable candidates running, with a fifth set to join the race. According to two early surveys of the Republican primary field, Moore could earn support from 18 to 27 percent of the primary electorate. However, it remains unclear how much Moore can raise his ceiling of potential support, as many in his own party have a negative opinion of him.

One factor working in Moore's favor is a crowded primary field. With Alabama being 27 points more Republican than the country as a whole, the eventual GOP nominee stands a good chance of beating the incumbent, Doug Jones, in the general election. A large primary field may fragment the vote, making it unlikely that a candidate could win a majority and avoiding a runoff, making it easier for Moore to advance to a runoff with only the support of his base.

Rep. Bradley Byrne and Tommy Tuberville, a former Auburn University football coach, are the major contenders so far. Alabama Secretary of State John Merrill is also gearing up to run, and State Rep. Arnold Mooney has received an endorsement from the Senate Conservatives Fund. Former Attorney General Jeff Sessions is also a possibility for running for his old seat and potentially clearing the field.

If Moore does finish in the top two in the primary and makes it to a runoff, it would still be challenging for him to clinch the GOP nomination. However, some of Moore's major opponents have potential weaknesses. Tuberville, a political outsider, might face "carpetbagger" attacks due to voting in Florida just last November. Byrne, the current establishment favorite, had difficulty in past primary battles and was critical of Trump in the 2016 cycle, although he did support the GOP ticket in the end.

In conclusion, Moore does have a path, especially a path to a primary runoff if there's a crowded GOP field. If he does get there, he would be only one step away from a rematch with Jones. National Republicans may have an "Anyone But Moore" attitude, and GOP groups would undoubtedly pound Moore with negative ads. However, a Trump endorsement of Moore's opponent in 2017 could not stop him from winning, so it's not impossible that Moore does end up winning his party's nomination.

Title: Quadcopter Crashes on White House Grounds, Secret Service Investigating

Article:

The Secret Service has identified a device found on the White House grounds overnight as a "quadcopter." The agency reported that the operator of the device lost control, causing it to crash.

In a statement released Monday afternoon, the Secret Service stated that an individual called around 9:30 a.m. ET to "self-report" the crashed copter. The agency added that the individual has been cooperative, and the incident appears to stem from recreational use of the device.

According to the Secret Service, an on-duty officer saw and heard the 2-foot-wide commercial quadcopter fly low onto the grounds of the executive mansion at approximately 3:08 a.m. ET. The quadcopter crashed on the southeast side, the agency said in a statement.

"There was an immediate alert and lockdown of the complex until the device was examined and cleared," a spokesman said, adding that an investigation is underway.

Earlier, the White House stated that the device posed no threat to the first family. President Obama and first lady Michelle Obama are in India; their daughters, Sasha and Malia, stayed behind in Washington with their grandmother, Marian Robinson.

"There is a device that has been recovered by the Secret Service at the White House," said White House spokesman Josh Earnest, who is with Obama in New Delhi. "The early indications are that it does not pose any sort of ongoing threat to anybody at the White House."

Drones, as previously reported, come in a variety of sizes and are used in counterterrorism, surveillance, aerial photography, and even as toys.

This incident follows a series of security lapses at the White House for which the Secret Service has been widely criticized. As previously reported:

"The Secret Service was criticized last year after several lapses, including one in which a knife-wielding man scaled the White House fence and made it inside the executive mansion's main level. The scandal resulted in the resignation of its then-director, Julia Pierson. In December, a panel appointed by the Department of Homeland Security recommended changes at the Secret Service, saying it was'starved for leadership.'"

Several top officials at the Secret Service were asked to leave earlier this month.

Title: Appeals Court Upholds Order for Trump's Accountants to Release Tax Records

Article:

The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled that President Donald Trump's accounting firm, Mazars USA, must release his personal and business tax returns to Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr. The decision comes in response to an investigation into potential violations of New York state laws regarding payments made to two women who claimed to have had affairs with Trump before the 2016 election.

The president has indicated his intention to appeal the ruling to the Supreme Court, as stated by Jay Sekulow, one of Trump's outside attorneys. Sekulow described the appeals court's decision as raising significant constitutional issues.

The subpoena for the tax records is directed to Trump's accountants, not the president himself, and the appeals court's ruling does not address the question of presidential immunity. In a statement, Judge Robert Katzman, who wrote on behalf of the three-judge panel, noted that compliance with the subpoena does not require the president to take any action.

The investigation by Vance's office is focused on whether any New York state laws were broken when Trump's then-attorney, Michael Cohen, arranged payments to adult film actress Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in the closing weeks of the 2016 election. Trump has denied having sexual relationships with both women.

In addition to this legal battle, Trump is also fighting efforts by the House of Representatives to obtain his tax records. Unlike other past presidents, Trump has not divested from his business interests while in office. As a candidate and as president, Trump has chosen not to make his tax returns public.

Title: President Trump Signs Bill to Combat Rape Kit Backlog, Providing Funding for Testing and Training

Article:

President Donald Trump signed the Debbie Smith Reauthorization Act of 2019 on Monday, a bill aimed at reducing the number of untested rape kits in the United States. The legislation will provide funding from the Department of Justice to help local governments clear the backlog of untested rape kits, which currently exceeds 100,000, according to ABC News.

The White House stated that the bill, as per a statement from press secretary Stephanie Grisham, will ensure that "criminals are brought to justice." Grisham's statement read, "We know that DNA is much more likely than fingerprints to result in the identification of a criminal, yet thousands of rape kits currently sit untested in labs and on police storage shelves across the Nation."

The bill will allocate $151 million to the Debbie Smith DNA Backlog Grant Program, $12.5 million for DNA training and education programs, and $30 million for the Sexual Assault Forensic Exam Grant Program, according to ABC News. The bill, originally passed in 2004, is named after a victim who was attacked in 1989, and whose evidence wasn't tested until five years later. Since 2005, it has led to more than 40 percent of DNA matches due to its funding, the network reported.

Advocates argue that fighting the backlog is crucial due to the statute of limitations in some jurisdictions. The funding for the bill traditionally has bipartisan support but got caught in the middle of the debate surrounding the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act this year, according to ABC News.

Title: House Democrats Express Concerns Over Emergency Aid Package for Border Crisis

Article:

As the deadline for passing a funding bill approaches, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi stated that the bill under consideration reflects Democratic values but expressed concern about the limited time remaining. The statement came after President Donald Trump's decision to suspend Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) raids for two weeks to facilitate a bipartisan compromise on changing asylum laws and closing immigration "loopholes."

Pelosi praised the postponement and, in a subsequent statement, called for the passage of the emergency aid package. She argued that the bill protects families and does not fund the administration's failed mass detention policy. The bill, however, would not meet Trump's demands for changes to asylum laws.

Despite Pelosi's efforts to advance the bill, numerous House Democrats have expressed concerns. In separate conference calls on Sunday, more than 30 members of the Progressive Caucus and over 15 members of the Hispanic Caucus voiced their apprehensions. Many argued that the legislation did not set high enough standards for migrant shelters or do enough to block funds from being used for enforcement.

Representative Pramila Jayapal, a Democrat from Washington and co-chairwoman of the Progressive Caucus, stated, "We all want to address the problems at the border, but we don't know that there are enough sticks in this bill to make sure that the Trump administration actually spends the money the way they're supposed to." Jayapal added, "He's creating these crises and then trying to point a finger at Democrats to give him more money, which he then uses for his own purposes."

Jayapal expressed doubt that the Trump administration would adhere to any restrictions or standards included in the legislation, given its "lawless" behavior regarding immigrants. The specifics of the concerns raised by the Democratic representatives were not available in the provided text.

Title: Former Air Force Linguist Charged with Leaking Classified Documents

Article:

A 25-year-old woman, Reality Leigh Winner, has been charged with leaking classified documents to The Intercept. The documents allegedly reveal that Russian agents attempted to hack into U.S. voting systems prior to the November election.

Winner, a former U.S. Air Force linguist who speaks Pashto, Farsi, and Dari, was indicted in federal court on Monday. According to the federal complaint, Winner stole the classified documents from Pluribus International, a defense contractor that does work for the National Security Agency (NSA) from its offices in Augusta, Ga.

Winner admitted to FBI agents that she stole the documents and provided them to The Intercept. The news site published an article on Monday that appears to be based on the stolen materials.

The federal complaint filed against Winner reveals that she stole the classified documents on May 9, four days after they were published by the NSA. She printed the report and sent it through ground mail to The Intercept. On May 30, a reporter with the outlet contacted the NSA inquiring about the documents. The agency then contacted the FBI, which dispatched agents to interview and apprehend Winner at her home in Augusta.

Winner's social media footprint suggests that she is politically active. On February 14, a day after Winner took her Top Secret job at Pluribus, Winner posted a photo outside of the Atlanta offices of Georgia Sen. David Perdue. She wrote that she had a 30-minute private meeting with the Republican lawmaker's state policy director, discussing her concerns regarding climate change and the state of Georgia's efforts to reduce dependency on fossil fuels.

Winner's posts on Facebook also show that she is a supporter of liberal causes, including the Women's March and the Islamic Society of North America, a Muslim civil rights group. She referred to President Trump as a "piece of shit" because of his position on the Dakota Access Pipeline (DAPL) protests.

Jon Swaine, a reporter with The Guardian, also identified Winner. A spokeswoman for Perdue released a statement on Tuesday calling the allegations against Winner "very serious."

"The allegations against Ms. Winner are very serious, and if true, directly threaten our national security. We trust our Justice Department will get to the bottom of this and handle it appropriately," the spokeswoman said.

Winner was heavily critical of Trump just after he took office, using the hashtags "#NeverMyPresident" and "#Resist" in a Facebook post about his position on DAPL. Winner posted on Facebook most recently on Friday, the day before she was interviewed by the FBI.

"You are what you love, not who loves you," she wrote.

This article has been updated with additional information, including about Winner's meeting in February at the offices of Georgia Sen. David Perdue.

Title: House Votes to Hold Lois Lerner in Contempt of Congress

Article:

The United States House of Representatives has voted to hold Lois Lerner, the former head of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) tax-exempt division, in contempt of Congress. The vote took place three days before the anniversary of the day Lerner's actions ignited the tea party targeting controversy.

The Republican-led chamber voted 231-187 to hold Lerner in contempt for refusing to answer House Republicans' questions. Six Democrats joined the Republicans in the vote.

"You don't get to use a public hearing to tell the public and press your side of the story and then invoke the Fifth," said Oversight Committee Chairman Darrell Issa (R-Calif.) on the House floor. "That is not how the Fifth Amendment is meant to be used. It is a shield; Lois Lerner used it as a sword."

Democrats dismissed the process as a political move designed for election season. "Bringing this political circus, this witch hunt to the floor purely because it polls well with your base is ludicrous," said Rep. Jim McGovern (D-Mass.).

Lerner's lawyer, William Taylor, said in a statement that "it is unfortunate that the majority party in the House has put politics before a citizen's constitutional rights." Lerner has stated that she has broken no laws.

The contempt citation now goes to the Justice Department, where the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia could bring the issue to court. The department has not responded to a request for comment on whether it will proceed with the case.

In a separate measure, the House called on Attorney General Eric Holder to appoint a special counsel to probe the matter. If tried and found guilty, Lerner could serve up to a year in prison or face a fine of up to $100,000, according to a Congressional Research Service report.

The contempt charge allows the House to arrest Lerner and detain her in a Capitol jail cell until she complies with the subpoena or until the end of the 113th Congress—a power not exercised since the early 20th century.

Lerner is known for the IRS's practice of pulling conservative groups applying for exemptions for additional scrutiny if they used words like tea party, patriot, and 9/12 in their applications.

House Republicans have chosen to forgo any civil contempt citation against Lerner, a strategy that, if won, would force her to testify before the House. This strategy has confused some lawyers.

The contempt citation does not necessarily mark the end of the IRS scandal, with nearly a half-dozen congressional investigations expected to wrap up in the coming months. However, a criminal contempt conviction, if upheld in court, will not require Lerner to testify.

At one point, the Oversight Committee and Lerner's lawyer, William Taylor III, were close to a deal allowing Lerner to testify without immunity in public, but the agreement fell through. Since Lerner broke news of the practice following a planted question at a May 10, 2013, legal conference, she has become the target of Republican scorn.

Initially, Republicans looked to the White House, equating the scandal to Watergate and calling it a scheme by President Barack Obama to target his enemies. However, when no smoking gun appeared, they toned down that rhetoric. The Treasury inspector general for tax administration, in the first official report on the scandal, attributed the unfair practice to gross mismanagement—not political bias.

Since then, House Republicans have built a case around Lerner, accusing her of using her top IRS position for political mischief.

Title: Democratic Operatives Urge Donors to Support House Campaigns for Potential Clinton 2016 Advantage

Article:

Democratic operatives are urging donors to continue supporting House campaigns in the final weeks before the election, with the goal of securing a majority for Democratic candidates should Hillary Clinton win the White House in 2016. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) and the Democratic-aligned House Majority PAC have been making this argument to major donors, with the National Republican Congressional Committee making a similar case to their own donors.

John Podesta, senior White House counselor and expected to have the top position in Clinton's presumptive campaign, has already met with a small group of labor leaders to keep donations coming in for the fall. The pitch is not just about holding on for 2016, but also about the potential benefits of a Democratic House in the days following the inauguration.

Ali Lapp, who runs the House Majority PAC, stated, "So many of our donors and our activists are really, really excited about Hillary running for president. The thing we have to say to them is, ‘We are too, but let's think about all the days that follow the inauguration and what she'll be able to do with a Democratic House versus the Republican House we have now.'"

Rep. Steve Israel of New York, DCCC Chairman, added, "It's safe to say that there's a lot of enthusiasm among Democrats around the country for the prospect of a Hillary Clinton candidacy, and that unquestionably factors into many donors' decision making."

While the DCCC and House Majority PAC are not guaranteeing a majority for the Democrats, they are emphasizing the importance of maintaining and expanding their current seats to create a more effective legislative body for Clinton's presidency. A senior Democrat stated, "It's clear that she's so potent and demands the respect of the donor community around the country."

Donors who have dealt extensively with House Majority PAC described the message as "Keep the flame alive." One donor explained, "They're not going to win a majority; they still need to hold onto what seats they can and be competitive heading into a presidential year."

Title: Examination of White Privilege and Racial Stereotypes in America

Article:

The article discusses the concept of white privilege and the perpetuation of racial stereotypes about African Americans in American society. It begins by describing white privilege as a metaphorical pair of binoculars that allow white individuals to view black life from a distance, without intimate understanding.

The text suggests that these binoculars are not only physical objects but also stories and beliefs that portray black people as lazy, dumb, or immoral. These beliefs are not typically found in contemporary books or classrooms but are informally passed down from one white individual to another.

The article further discusses the reluctance of many white individuals to learn about the hardships faced by African Americans, often attributing their success to undeserved advantages. The author criticizes this mindset, suggesting that it stems from a belief that resources and opportunities should be prioritized for white individuals.

The article also touches upon the resentment and slow-building hate that some white individuals feel due to their perceived loss of privilege, which they often project onto political figures who amplify their prejudiced thoughts.

The text also addresses the terror experienced by African Americans, citing instances of police brutality and the fear it instills in the community. The author suggests that this fear is not unfamiliar to African Americans, as they are often targeted by law enforcement for minor infractions or perceived discomfort.

Finally, the article mentions the hypocrisy of holding entire populations accountable for the actions of a few, as is often the case with the stereotyping of Muslims, while white individuals rarely take responsibility for their own prejudices. The article concludes by urging white individuals to put down their "binoculars" and see the world from the perspective of African Americans.

Title: Beto O'Rourke's Authenticity: A Key Factor in 2020 Democratic Primary

Article:

In the crowded 2020 Democratic primary, one candidate stands out for his authenticity: Beto O'Rourke. This quality, some argue, could potentially propel him to the nomination.

While Donald Trump's authenticity has been a subject of debate, it has enabled him to connect with people, as evidenced by his victory in the 2016 presidential election against Hillary Clinton. Similarly, Beto O'Rourke's authenticity could be a significant factor in his political success.

In a critical op-ed published a few weeks ago, the author expressed concerns about O'Rourke's performance in 2019, citing his lack of focus on traditional campaign activities such as fundraising, hiring staff, and meeting voters. However, the author also acknowledges O'Rourke's natural political ability and his potential to unite the Obama coalition, a feat that has been challenging for other candidates in the primary field.

O'Rourke's authenticity is not about sharing personal details on social media or writing lengthy blog posts about road trips. Instead, it is about his ability to connect with people on a personal level, as demonstrated by his openness, his liberal political stance, and his willingness to take far-left positions in a red state.

The challenge for O'Rourke lies in learning from his mistakes and capitalizing on his political ability to unite the Obama coalition, a group that includes minority voters, white liberals, and young people. Out of the entire field, O'Rourke has the best shot at achieving this, as other candidates, such as Kirsten Gillibrand and Joe Biden, will have to address their more moderate pasts and long histories in Congress.

While Kamala Harris has struggled to come across as authentic during her early state trips, O'Rourke seems to avoid these problems, presenting himself as genuine and unfiltered. What you see is what you get, and that authenticity could take him farther than many expect.

Title: Former Biden Staffer Files Criminal Complaint Against Joe Biden for Alleged Assault

Article:

A former staffer for Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden has filed a formal criminal complaint against him with the Washington, D.C. police, alleging sexual assault in 1993. Tara Reade, who made the allegations last month, told police that Biden "assaulted her in a Senate corridor, shoving his hand under her skirt and penetrating her with his fingers," according to Business Insider's report on Saturday. The statute of limitations for the alleged assault has passed.

Reade initially shared her allegations last month with writer and podcast host Katie Halper, stating, "This is a story that @ReadeAlexandra has been trying to tell since it happened in 1993. It’s a story about sexual assault, retaliation, and silencing."

In her conversation with Halper, Reade described the alleged incident, saying, "We were alone, and it was the strangest thing. There was no, like, exchange really. He just had me up against the wall. His hands were on me and underneath my clothes. And then, he went, he went down my skirt and then up inside it, and he penetrated me with his fingers...and um...He was kissing me at the same time and he was saying something to me."

Reade continued, "He got finished doing what he was doing and I, how I was pulled back and he said, ‘Come on man, I heard you liked me.’ And that phrase stayed with me because I kept thinking what I might have said. I can’t remember exactly if he said ‘I thought’ or if ‘I heard.’ It’s like he implied that I had done this."

Biden's campaign has vehemently denied the allegation. In a statement to Fox News, deputy campaign manager Kate Bedingfield said, "Women have a right to tell their story, and reporters have an obligation to rigorously vet those claims. We encourage them to do so, because these accusations are false." (RELATED: Alyssa Milano Says Joe Biden Deserves 'Due Process' in Sexual Assault Allegation)

Title: Jeb Bush Endorses Ted Cruz in 2016 Presidential Race

Article:

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, who suspended his presidential bid in February following several primary losses, endorsed Texas Senator Ted Cruz on Wednesday. Despite Bush's frequent criticisms of Cruz during the campaign and his perceived alignment with Ohio Governor John Kasich, Bush endorsed Cruz, stating that he is a "consistent, principled conservative who has demonstrated the ability to appeal to voters."

As of Wednesday, Trump leads the race with 739 delegates, followed by Cruz with 465, and Kasich with 143, according to the Associated Press. A candidate needs 1,237 delegates to win the nomination outright at the convention. With his current standing, Trump appears to be the only candidate capable of reaching this number. Cruz, according to polls, has the best chance of beating Trump one-on-one and preventing Trump from reaching the 1,237 delegate threshold.

Bush's endorsement is the latest sign that the so-called Republican establishment is coalescing around Cruz's campaign. If neither candidate manages to reach 1,237 delegates, the two candidates will head into a contested convention where delegates will be free to vote with their conscience. Bush's tweet announcing his endorsement reads, "I am endorsing @ TedCruz. Ted is a consistent, principled conservative who has shown he can unite the party."

Title: Lawyers for President Trump Seek $20 Million in Damages from Stormy Daniels for Alleged Breach of Non-Disclosure Agreement

Article:

Lawyers for U.S. President Donald Trump are pursuing $20 million in damages from adult film actress Stormy Daniels, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford, for allegedly breaching a non-disclosure agreement signed before the 2016 elections. The lawyers argue that Daniels breached the agreement at least 20 times.

Daniels claims she had an affair with Mr. Trump that began in 2006 and lasted several months. The president's lawyer, Michael Cohen, has stated that he paid Daniels $130,000 of his own money to remain silent about the alleged affair. This is the first time President Trump has become directly involved in the case. He "vehemently denies" the alleged affair.

This month, a lawsuit was filed by Daniels' lawyer, Michael Avenatti, aiming to scrap the non-disclosure agreement. Avenatti described the filing by the law firm representing the president as "unprecedented" and "yet another bullying tactic" against Daniels. The filing also sought a change of venue from state to federal court.

Daniels asserts that the 2016 agreement is invalid as Mr. Trump did not sign it. She first made claims of a sexual relationship with Mr. Trump in a 2011 interview with InTouch magazine. The story resurfaced earlier this year when reports emerged she was paid not to discuss the alleged affair in the run-up to the 2016 election.

Cohen has acknowledged paying Daniels $130,000 privately, but stated neither Mr. Trump nor his company was a party to the transaction. A similar request made on Mr. Trump's behalf came from another lawyer, Charles Harder - best known for his handling of the Hulk Hogan sex tape case against Gawker and for defending Melania Trump in a suit against the Daily Mail.

The motion filed on Mr. Trump's behalf states, "Mr. Trump intends to pursue his rights to the fullest extent permitted by the law." It is thought that moving the case to a federal court would help keep the case behind closed doors in arbitration, a view expressed by Daniels' lawyer in a tweet.

Mr. Avenatti alleged on Friday that Daniels had been physically threatened, but did not provide further details. Daniels has recorded an interview with the CBS network's 60 Minutes program to air later this month about her fight to void the agreement. A CrowdJustice campaign to raise funds for her legal fees has already raised almost $200,000.

Mr. Trump has also obtained a restraining order against Daniels to try to prevent her from sharing "confidential information" about their alleged relationship.

Title: Advocacy Groups Sue Georgia Over Voting Registration Law

Article:

A coalition of advocacy groups, including the Campaign Legal Center and Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, has filed a lawsuit to prevent Georgia from enforcing a voting registration law that critics argue disenfranchises over 50,000 voters. The lawsuit, filed in a federal district court on Thursday, alleges that the state's "exact match" requirement violates the Voting Rights Act, the National Voter Registration Act, and the First and Fourteenth Amendments.

The "exact match" system, used by the state's Secretary of State from 2013 to 2016, was halted in 2017 as part of a settlement stemming from separate litigation. However, the Republican-held state legislature passed the protocol into law soon after. According to a recent Associated Press report, around 53,000 people, nearly 70% of whom are African-Americans, had their registrations placed on hold due to mismatches in drivers' license or social security information.

Georgia Secretary of State Brian Kemp, who is currently running for governor in a closely contested race with Democratic former state House Minority Leader Stacey Abrams, stated in a tweet, "The 53,000 Georgians on our 'pending' list can vote in the Nov. 6th election."

In response to the AP report, the Abrams campaign called for Kemp to resign as the state's top elections official to ensure Georgia voters have confidence that their Secretary of State will competently and impartially oversee the election.

The lawsuit, initially threatened in July, has no connection to the campaign. The plaintiffs argue that the controversial "exact match" checks have disproportionately and negatively impacted the ability of voting-eligible African-American, Latino, and Asian-American applicants, even before the process was signed into law by the current governor, Republican Nathan Deal, in 2017.

Title: Weakness in American Leadership: Syria Crisis Highlights Decay of Party Discipline and Media Influence

Article:

The Syria crisis has become a significant moment in modern presidential history, with the United States' response to the conflict revealing weaknesses in multiple institutions and leaders. The unsteady handling of the Syria crisis by President Barack Obama has been particularly noteworthy, highlighting his uncertain views and limited options.

However, the focus on Obama's performance has overshadowed a larger reality: the Syria episode has exposed the decay of party discipline and the diminishment of the parties in American politics. The inability of the president and congressional leaders to garner enough support for authorizing force in Syria, particularly in response to the alleged use of chemical weapons, underscores this weakness.

Historically, party discipline has been a defining characteristic of American politics. In the Iraq War, only six Republicans in Congress voted against President George W. Bush's request for authorization. In contrast, President Obama has lost two Democrats in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee alone, with additional opposition from other members.

The decay of party discipline is a result of the rise of outside groups and politicians who do not depend on their parties for money and influence. This reality is the main reason Washington has been paralyzed in recent years, with neither House Speaker John Boehner nor Obama having the confidence to bring their parties along on deals over budget, entitlements, or other domestic issues.

In response to this reality, party leaders have emphasized their lack of leverage in pressing for passage of the White House-backed resolution. "It's not a question of whipping," said House Speaker Nancy Pelosi last week. After House Speaker John Boehner endorsed the Syria resolution, his spokesman declared that the president should take the lead on any whipping effort.

In other words, good luck with all that, Mr. President.

The Syria crisis also highlights the changing media landscape. Presidents have traditionally relied on their power to make everyone stop and pay attention. However, the media landscape has fractured, and presidents can no longer command universal interest or attention from the American people. President Obama has only addressed the nation twice from the Oval Office, a stark contrast to his predecessors.

In his political campaigns, Obama has attempted to counteract the fracturing of the media landscape by speaking in unconventional venues. However, this approach has its limits, and moving mass opinion on a serious matter in a short period of time is challenging.

President Obama faces a potentially public display of this media schizophrenia Tuesday with the prospect that his speech making the case for punishing Syria could take place simultaneously with coverage of Russia's efforts to broker a diplomatic end game. The president acknowledged Monday that these efforts might lead him to call the whole thing off.

Title: Federal Government Implementing Supreme Court Ruling on Same-Sex Marriage

Article:

Four months have passed since the U.S. Supreme Court struck down a law that defined marriage as between a man and a woman, paving the way for thousands of same-sex married couples to receive federal benefits. A special group of government lawyers has been working to ensure that these benefits are extended to same-sex couples.

The task was clear: review over 1,000 rules and laws that cover various federal benefits to make sure gay and lesbian couples receive their due. This initiative was prompted by President Obama's instructions issued hours after the high court's decision.

Attorney General Eric Holder described this as a civil rights matter, comparing it to the struggle African-Americans faced in the 1950s and 1960s for equal treatment. Federal employees in same-sex marriages can now extend health and life insurance coverage to their spouses, and immigration authorities are reviewing petitions from same-sex couples in the same manner as opposite-sex couples. At the IRS, tax officials say legally married gay and lesbian couples can now file jointly.

Assistant Attorney General Stuart Delery, who leads the effort to implement the Supreme Court ruling for the Justice Department, stated, "Our job has been to make the promise of that decision, the words on the page in the Supreme Court's opinion, real for real people."

However, there are still challenges in extending benefits to same-sex couples who live in states that do not recognize their marriages. The Supreme Court struck down the part of the law that defined marriage as between one man and one woman, but it did not create a universal right to marry. This leaves open the question of what happens to same-sex couples who live in states that do not recognize their marriages.

Associate Attorney General Tony West mentioned that many of the legal issues the Justice Department has faced were relatively straightforward, but there are harder questions, such as whether the place of domicile or the place of celebration is the key factor in determining spousal benefits.

Advocates are still anxiously waiting for answers on Social Security and the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). Ultimately, Congress may need to change the language in those laws to fully extend benefits to married couples who live in states that do not recognize their marriages.

In some cases, same-sex couples have been forced to travel to federal facilities, sometimes long distances, to enroll in federal benefit programs for National Guard members. This situation has been met with criticism, as these are federal benefits programs that are funded with federal money and run by the federal government.

Justice Department officials say the Supreme Court has spoken, and history is on the side of same-sex couples. However, there has been some pushback from states, particularly in the areas of Medicaid enrollment, tax time, and states where gay marriage is outlawed.

Despite these challenges, Attorney General Eric Holder expressed optimism, stating, "I would hope their elected representatives could reflect the magnanimity of the American people."

Title: Analysis of Hillary Clinton's Performance in the 2016 Presidential Election Using VAR Metric

Article:

According to Inside Elections' 'Vote Above Replacement' (VAR) metric, Hillary Clinton overperformed a typical Democratic candidate in 19 states during the 2016 presidential race, while Donald Trump overperformed a typical Republican candidate in 15 states. The VAR metric measures the strength of a political candidate relative to a typical candidate from the same party by comparing the percentage of the candidate's vote to the party's Baseline, which is the trimmed mean of each party's performance in partisan, contested statewide elections over the four most recent general election cycles.

Clinton underperformed in key states, such as Michigan (-0.2 VAR), New Hampshire (-2.5), Pennsylvania (-3.3), and Wisconsin (-0.9). Losing three (and nearly four) of these states prevented her from securing the presidency. She also underperformed in Minnesota (-4.1) and came close to losing that state as well.

On the other hand, Clinton overperformed in states like California (+6 VAR), Illinois (+3.1), and Massachusetts (+2.5). This overperformance in Democratic states has led some to argue that Democrats are "wasting" votes by running up the score in these states and not changing the math of the Electoral College.

However, it's not all bad news for Democrats. Clinton overperformed in Florida (+4.2 VAR), a perennial battleground state, and in the former battleground state of Nevada (+2.8). The emerging battleground state of Maine also showed positive results for Democrats, with Clinton's VAR at +3.1.

The best news for Democrats might be in growing states where Clinton overperformed and Trump underperformed, such as Texas (Clinton +5.1, Trump -5.8) and Georgia (Clinton +3.1, Trump -4.3).

David Wasserman of the Cook Political Report has noted that Trump could lose the popular vote by 5 million votes and still win re-election. This underscores the importance of focusing on key states in future elections.

Title: Democrats Break Tradition, Counter RNC with High-Profile Visits and Speeches

Article:

In the lead-up to the Republican National Convention (RNC) next week, the Democratic Party is deviating from tradition by actively engaging in counter-programming, dispatching high-profile figures to Tampa and other cities to deliver speeches and campaign messages.

Vice President Joe Biden, who was initially scheduled to visit Tampa for the RNC's opening day, has postponed his trip due to inclement weather. Instead, he will join Hollywood actress and Obama for America co-chairwoman Eva Longoria in Orlando, where he is also expected to speak. Longoria is also slated to speak at the Democratic National Convention (DNC) the following week in Charlotte, North Carolina.

Meanwhile, President Barack Obama has scheduled campaign stops in the battleground states of Ohio, Colorado, and Virginia on Tuesday and Wednesday. First lady Michelle Obama is scheduled to appear on "The Late Show with David Letterman" on Wednesday, hours after GOP vice presidential candidate Rep. Paul Ryan, R-Wis., is expected to deliver his speech.

This concerted effort by the Democrats aims to ensure their message is not overshadowed during the tightening presidential race, as noted by Christopher Arterton, former dean of the George Washington University's Graduate School of Political Management. Arterton stated, "Decorum has broken down. It's accepted practice now. We may well see each party make news during the other's convention."

Arterton explained that Obama's status as president makes his statements newsworthy, making it easier for the Democrats to intrude, particularly after a news event "like a hurricane, just suppose," he said. Arterton also noted that convention week is beneficial for rival-party fundraising, as campaigns can gather donors to "yell at the TV" while the other convention is being broadcast.

Presidential candidates have historically kept a low profile during their opponents' conventions, but this practice has changed in recent years. During the 2008 RNC, for example, Obama campaigned in Ohio and Pennsylvania while Biden courted voters in Florida and Virginia.

Romney campaign officials have announced that their candidate will hold events in Charlotte during the week of the DNC, though specific details have not been released. Obama campaign spokeswoman Jen Psaki described Biden's visit to Tampa as "going to the belly of the beast." Romney senior adviser Kevin Madden characterized the Biden trip as an attempt to distract from the Democrats' economic record and to draw a contrast between the parties' visions for the country.

Title: Climate Change and Hurricane Harvey: A Debate on the Role of Global Warming

Article:

The aftermath of Hurricane Harvey, a Category 4 storm that made landfall in Corpus Christi, Texas, on August 25, 2017, has sparked a debate on the role of climate change in the storm's intensity and impact. The storm brought catastrophic flooding and an unprecedented 50 inches of rain in the Houston area by Tuesday, as it stalled over the region.

Climate activists and scientists, such as meteorologist and climate activist Eric Holthaus, the Climate Reality Project, and 350.org, have argued that climate change exacerbates hurricanes, making them more devastating. Michael E. Mann, a Penn State professor of atmospheric science, stated that while Hurricane Harvey was not caused by climate change, it was worsened by it.

However, some scientists, such as Judith Curry, a climatologist and retired Georgia Tech professor, and Roger Pielke Jr., a professor at the University of Colorado Center for Science & Technology Policy Research, have challenged these claims. Curry argued that linking Harvey to global warming is unwarranted, while Pielke pointed out that there were only four U.S. landfalls of Category 4 or greater hurricanes from 1970 to 2017, despite rising greenhouse gas emissions in the atmosphere.

Roger Pielke Jr. also noted that there were 14 U.S. landfalls of Category 4 or greater hurricanes from 1926 to 1969, but only four from 1970 to 2017. He suggested that the low number of hurricanes during the Obama administration was due to luck rather than climate change.

Assessments by the U.N. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and others suggest that rising sea levels and surface temperatures create more moisture in the atmosphere, which can lead to greater rainfalls and flooding. However, the role of climate change in specific weather events is complex and not always straightforward.

Roy W. Spencer, principal research scientist at the University of Alabama in Huntsville, disagreed with the assertion that global warming may explain why Hurricane Harvey stalled over Southeast Texas, producing record rainfall. Spencer argued that the flooding disaster in Houston was the result of a combination of factors that can be explained naturally, without invoking human-caused climate change.

The National Weather Service reported that Harvey produced more than 50 inches of rain in Cedar Bayou, Texas, surpassing the measured single-storm rainfall record for the continental United States. However, Spencer noted that if the system had been moving a little faster, it would have dispersed the rainfall over a wider area and missed the record despite producing the same amount of precipitation.

In conclusion, the debate on the role of climate change in Hurricane Harvey's intensity and impact is ongoing, with some scientists arguing that climate change exacerbates hurricanes, while others suggest that the storm's characteristics can be explained naturally. The National Weather Service has reported that Harvey produced unprecedented rainfall, but whether this represents a new normal or a rare combination of events remains to be determined.

Title: South Carolina Governor Calls for Removal of Confederate Flag from State Capitol, Retailers Ban Sale of Confederate Merchandise

Article:

In the aftermath of a mass shooting at a historically black church in Charleston, South Carolina, Governor Nikki Haley called for the removal of the Confederate flag from the state capitol grounds on June 22. The call for the flag's removal has gained support from leaders around the state and the country.

During a news conference attended by Republican senators Lindsey Graham and Tim Scott, along with other state leaders, Haley stated, "Today, we are here in a moment of unity in our state, without ill will, to say it is time to move the flag from the Capitol grounds."

Following the shooting, several retailers, including Walmart, Amazon, Sears, and eBay, announced they will ban the sale of Confederate flag merchandise. The announcements are the latest indication that the flag, a symbol of the slave-holding South, has become increasingly controversial in the wake of the attack.

The debate over the use of the Confederate flag has intensified, with some viewing it as a symbol of hate and others seeing it as a representation of bravery from the Civil War. Fox News host Bill O'Reilly asserted that the flag "represents bravery" to some, while others, such as The Weekly Standard editor Bill Kristol, accused liberals of "expunging every trace of respect, recognition or acknowledgment of Americans who fought for the Confederacy."

Fox News' Kimberly Guilfoyle and Rush Limbaugh have also weighed in on the issue, with Guilfoyle asking during a June 23 edition of Fox News' The Five, "Is the American flag next?" and Limbaugh claiming that liberals' true mission in removing the Confederate flag is "destroying the South as a political force."

The controversy surrounding the Confederate flag continues to divide opinions, with some viewing it as a symbol of hate and others as a representation of history and bravery. The debate is likely to continue as the nation grapples with the complex and controversial history of the flag.

Title: Trump May Not Insist on Border Wall Funding in DACA Legislation, According to White House Aide

Article:

WASHINGTON - U.S. President Donald Trump may not demand funding for a border wall with Mexico in legislation addressing protections for children brought to the United States illegally, according to a senior aide. White House legislative director Marc Short stated this during a Tuesday briefing with reporters at a Christian Science Monitor breakfast.

Short clarified that the administration will outline its priorities for a DACA program fix in the coming weeks. While Trump remains committed to his campaign promise to construct a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border, Short expressed that the specific inclusion of the border wall in a DACA package or a separate legislative package has not been decided.

Short emphasized, "I don't want to bind ourselves into a construct that makes reaching a conclusion on DACA impossible." He added, "I don't want to prejudge here today."

Short's comments indicate a potential shift in the Republican president's approach, aiming to collaborate with both Democrats and Republicans in enacting his agenda. On Tuesday evening, Trump is scheduled to dine with a bipartisan group of senators, whose support he hopes to secure for tax code overhaul legislation.

Democrats welcomed Short's DACA comments, stating they remove a significant obstacle to legislation aimed at helping DACA recipients, often referred to as Dreamers. Democrats have consistently stated they will not allow border funding to be part of any legislation and would likely have the Senate votes to block a provision they object to.

Senator Dick Durbin, a senior Democrat who has been advocating for Dreamers for the past 16 years, commented, "That's an important position because we cannot make a 2,200-mile (3,540 km) wall a condition for passing the Dream Act, and we've been very clear from the start."

Democrats are open to working with the White House and congressional Republicans on other border security measures as part of the legislation, Durbin added. However, Mark Krikorian, executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies, criticized the potential shift on DACA, stating the White House appears to be seeking an "escape hatch" on the controversial DACA program.

Trump announced last week that he was ending an Obama-era program that shields from deportation immigrants brought illegally into the United States as children. The move leaves nearly 800,000 Dreamers facing uncertainty about their status in a country that many consider their only home.

Title: Conservative Candidates Face Increased Criticism from Liberal Media Ahead of Elections

Article:

The liberal media and the Democratic National Committee have been vocal in their criticism of several top Republican candidates, with a recent attack on Kentucky Senator Rand Paul by The Washington Post. The escalation of negative coverage towards conservative figures is a common tactic as the left perceives the threat level to their political ideology.

Senator Paul, a leading libertarian conservative, has been a vocal opponent of interventionist foreign policy, and his stance on Syria may have prevented the U.S. from joining forces with ISIS. In 2013, many prominent political figures, including President Obama, Hillary Clinton, and John McCain, advocated for military intervention against the Assad regime, supporting the Free Syrian Army. Some members of the Free Syrian Army later became ISIS fighters.

Senator Paul's caution in Syria was warranted, as he correctly identified the Al Qaeda-affiliated jihadists in Syria as the real threat, and advised against actions that would aid ISIS. In the following years, the foreign policy establishment has shifted its stance, now advocating for the destruction of ISIS.

The increased criticism of conservative candidates in the mainstream media should be met with caution, as it may stem from fear of losing power. With the upcoming November midterm elections and the 2016 presidential election, the Democrats are at risk of losing their majority in the Senate and important committee chairs. The author expresses support for the return of conservative, libertarian, and free market principles in U.S. politics.

Title: U.S. Foreign Policy Under Obama: A Review of Key Decisions and Their Implications

Article:

The Obama administration's foreign policy has been marked by a series of decisions that have led to a perceived disengagement from global affairs, leaving power vacuums that have been filled by various adversaries. This assessment is based on the administration's approach to several key international issues, including the Iran nuclear deal, the "reset" with Russia, and the withdrawal from Iraq.

During the first six months of President Obama's tenure, he embarked on an "apology tour," seeking to mend relations with other nations, particularly Russia. This was followed by the dispatch of Secretary of State Hillary Clinton to Geneva with a "reset" button, which was quickly followed by the cancellation of the U.S.'s missile defense system in Eastern Europe. This move was seen as a betrayal of U.S. allies and a sign of the administration's willingness to find common ground with adversaries.

In late 2011, the U.S. abandoned support for the Iraqi military, weakening its ability to defend the country. This withdrawal created a vacuum that was exploited by the rise of ISIS. The Obama administration's perceived inaction in response to the use of chemical weapons by Syrian President Bashar Assad, which was labeled a "red line," is another example of this disengagement.

The Iran nuclear deal, announced in 2015, has been criticized for lifting sanctions in exchange for a pause in Iran's nuclear weapons development. The deal, which has been described as a windfall for the Iranian regime, is expected to provide Iran with over $100 billion almost immediately, access to conventional arms in five years, ballistic missile technology in eight years, and an unfettered path to nuclear weapons in 10 to 15 years.

Representative Darrell Issa, a California Republican and member of the House Foreign Relations Committee, has expressed concern over the Iran deal, stating that it only delays the inevitable while pushing the problem's ultimate resolution onto a future administration. He also criticizes the deal for offering only short-term limitations on nuclear enrichment while failing to secure unfettered "anytime, anywhere" inspections.

The Iranian regime, with a history of reckless behavior and support for terrorism, has been accused of having no intention of changing its ways. Critics argue that the deal rewards Iran for its actions, while failing to secure the necessary oversight to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons.

In conclusion, the Obama administration's foreign policy has been characterized by a perceived disengagement from global affairs, leaving power vacuums that have been filled by various adversaries. The Iran nuclear deal, in particular, has been criticized for its perceived lack of oversight and the potential for rewarding Iran for its actions.

Title: Majority of Americans Fail U.S. Citizenship Test, Raising Concerns About Historical and Civic Literacy

Article:

A new study by the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation has revealed that a majority of Americans, excluding those from Vermont, would fail the U.S. citizenship test. The survey, conducted between November 14, 2018, and January 3, 2019, among 41,000 adults, used 20 history-specific questions from the practice tests for people taking the citizenship exam.

The results are concerning, with only 4 out of 10 Americans passing the test. The age group that performed the worst was those under 45, with just 27% passing. The gender divide showed a higher failure rate for women (68%) compared to men (44%). The oldest age group, however, performed the best, with more earning an A or B than an F (27% A or B, 26% F).

The survey also revealed that there was virtually no difference in the test scores between self-identified liberals and conservatives. The test results have sparked discussions about the state of historical and civic literacy in the United States, with some suggesting that high school students should be required to pass a standardized civics test to graduate.

Indiana is currently considering such a bill, Senate Bill 132, which calls for all high school students to take and pass a civics test equivalent to the one administered by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, starting with the 2020-2021 academic year. The bill, authored by Indiana Sens. Dennis Kruse, John Ruckelshaus, and Eric Koch, passed the Indiana Senate on a 31-17 vote and now awaits a House vote.

The test from the national fellowship named after Woodrow Wilson, a former U.S. president and a controversial figure, is available for those interested in testing their historical and civic knowledge. The test's questions cover various aspects of U.S. history and government.

The poor performance on the citizenship test has sparked discussions about the need for remedial history and civics courses, as well as remedial math courses, to improve the historical and civic literacy of Americans. The concern is that a lack of understanding of American government and history could lead to uninformed decisions and a lack of engagement in the political process.

Title: Trump and Schiff Face Off Over Ukraine Call Transcript, Whistleblower Complaint

Article:
