In a series of tweets and public statements, President Donald Trump and Representative Adam Schiff have engaged in a heated exchange over the transcript of Trump's call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and a subsequent whistleblower complaint.

Trump accused Schiff, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, of fabricating a version of the call's transcript and lying about the contents during a committee meeting last Thursday. Schiff's office did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

"Adam Schiff made up what I said. He actually took words and made it up... The reason is, when he saw my call to the president of Ukraine, it was so good that he could not quote from it. Because there was nothing done wrong. It was perfect," Trump said during a swearing-in ceremony for his new Labor secretary, Eugene Scalia, on Monday.

Schiff's portrayal of the call, which he offered during a hearing last week, bore no resemblance to the actual transcript, according to Trump. Trump previously demanded that Schiff be "questioned at the highest level for Fraud & Treason" and claimed that his "lies were made in perhaps the most blatant and sinister manner ever seen in the great Chamber."

Rudy Giuliani, Trump's personal attorney, and Eric Trump, the president's son, also assailed Schiff on Monday, with Giuliani charging that Schiff "did not embellish but instead lied about" the White House's summary of the Zelensky call.

In addition to his criticism of Schiff, Trump sought to cast doubt on the accuracy of the whistleblower complaint that detailed his call with Zelensky and alleged efforts by White House officials to "lock down" records of the conversation. The president claimed that the complaint was "mostly about the call to the Ukrainian President" and that the whistleblower "knew almost nothing."

The whistleblower complaint, filed in early August, alleged that the president's actions could be used by foreign powers to interfere in the 2020 election. The complaint's description of the call between Trump and Zelensky is largely similar to the readout the White House produced last Wednesday.

Trump has also criticized the whistleblower, asserting that "I deserve to meet my accuser" and that the person who provided the information to the intelligence official may have been spying on the president. The whistleblower acknowledged in the complaint that he or she was not a direct witness to most of the events described but wrote that the complaint's allegations were informed by the accounts of more than half a dozen U.S. officials provided over the prior four months.

The whistleblower complaint's description of the call between Trump and Zelensky is largely similar to the readout the White House produced last Wednesday. Joseph Maguire, the acting Director of National Intelligence, testified before Schiff's Intelligence committee last Thursday that "the whistleblower's complaint is in alignment with what was released yesterday by the president."

Title: Senate News: Sanders Calls for Repeal of GOP Tax Law, McConnell Promotes Tax Cuts, and Judicial Appointments Confirmed

Article:

Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) has called for the repeal of the Republican tax law, citing concerns over the projected increase in the federal budget deficit. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has projected that the budget deficit will reach $804 billion for 2018 and $1 trillion in 2020, two years earlier than anticipated. The national debt is also expected to hit $33 trillion in ten years, up from the current $21 trillion mark.

Democrats have criticized the tax law, passed in December, for contributing to the acceleration of the deficit and debt. However, Sen. Sanders' call for repeal comes amidst his own proposed single-payer healthcare scheme, which could inflict tens of trillions in unfunded and debt-bloating federal liabilities upon America's budget.

Meanwhile, Republicans are running ads online, including on Facebook, highlighting the day-to-day impact of their tax cuts and warning about potential tax increases under a Democratic administration. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is also promoting elements of the law that are helping small businesses across the country.

In other Senate news, Rick Scott has officially entered the Florida Senate race against Bill Nelson. Scott, whose job approval as governor is strong, will face a tough challenge in a tough election year. The current, razor-thin GOP upper chamber majority continues to confirm President Trump's judicial appointments at an aggressive pace.

This week, the Senate is expected to confirm Claria Horn Boom as U.S. District Judge for the Eastern and Western Districts of Kentucky, and Rebecca Jennings as W. District Judge for Kentucky. This confirmation of judicial appointments is considered crucial by many conservatives for retaining a tight Republican majority in the Senate.

Title: Call for Elimination of Midterm Elections in U.S. Due to Perceived Harmful Effects on American Politics

Article:

In the 2022 midterm elections, approximately 90 million Americans are expected to cast their votes, with less than 40% of the electorate participating. Despite the significant spending on campaigns, amounting to over $1 billion and more than two million ads, the midterm elections are likely to exacerbate partisan divisions and increase gridlock in governance.

The author argues that the two-year term for federal midterm elections no longer serves a purpose, especially given the low confidence in the government's ability to address pressing concerns. They suggest that the elimination of federal midterm elections could be beneficial, as there are few offices with two-year terms at any level of government.

In Durham, for example, school board members and county sheriffs are elected to terms that are twice as long as federal midterm terms. The author also points out that modern technologies, such as Twitter, video cameras, and 24-hour cable news, provide a level of hyper-accountability that the framers could not have imagined, making frequent elections unnecessary for communicating voters' desires to their elected officials.

However, the author contends that the two-year cycle is not only unnecessary but also harmful to American politics. The main impact of the midterm election in the modern era has been to weaken the president, the only government official (other than the vice president) elected by the entire nation. Since the end of World War II, the president's party has on average lost 25 seats in the House and about 4 in the Senate as a result of the midterms. This trend is consistent across Democratic and Republican presidencies.

Title: Romney's Debate Performance and Its Potential Impact on the Presidential Race

Article:

The upcoming presidential debate between Mitt Romney and incumbent President Barack Obama is generating significant anticipation, with both campaigns downplaying expectations ahead of Wednesday's event. The debate is expected to be a crucial moment for Romney, who is aiming to deliver a standout performance that could potentially shift the polls in his favor.

According to The Week magazine, Romney has a 60% chance of delivering a game-changing performance. Some Republicans suggest that Romney plans to "fact-check" the president, indicating an aggressive strategy of highlighting damning statistics, such as the unemployment rate above 8% or the national debt of $16 trillion.

However, even a stellar performance by Romney does not guarantee a shift in the polls. Undecided voters would need to tune in, the media would need to share a positive opinion of Romney's performance, the campaign would need to effectively communicate his victory to the public, and voters would need to be convinced to care.

The debate's significance is noteworthy in this election cycle, as the focus has been on culture, morals, personality, and trust rather than the economy. Romney aims to use the debate to showcase himself as a compelling politician and a relatable human being, discussing his family and father, subjects close to his heart, in an effort to redefine his national image.

If Romney manages to make an impact, it could significantly alter public perception of both candidates. In 1980, Ronald Reagan's debate performance helped shift public sentiment, convincing a broadly hostile audience that he was not a raging, radical conservative but actually a placid, funny guy. While the debate was not the sole factor in the election's outcome, it did contribute to a shift in public sentiment.

Advice on how Romney should approach the debate is coming from various sources, ranging from going on the attack to articulating a positive vision. One piece of advice Romney should disregard is from Newt Gingrich, who suggests the nominee should use humor. Given Romney's history of turning a joke into a global laughingstock, it would be wiser for him to stick to the facts.

Title: US Congresswomen Protest Dress Code, Advocate for Relaxation of Sleeves Rule in Capitol Building

Article:

A group of US Congresswomen staged a protest in the Capitol building on Friday, advocating for a relaxation of the long-standing dress code that has been enforced in parts of the building. The protest, dubbed "Sleeveless Friday," was initiated by Representative Jackie Speier who encouraged colleagues to wear sleeveless clothing to highlight the issue.

Approximately 25 women gathered on the steps of Congress, wearing sleeveless shirts and dresses, to protest the rule that prohibits bare arms in the lobby area where press meets US politicians. The rule, which also applies to men who are required to wear suit jackets and ties, has been a point of contention for some, particularly female reporters who have been prevented from entering the lobby area due to their outfits.

Representative Chellie Pingree tweeted, "It's 2017 and women vote, hold office, and choose their own style. Time to update House Rules to reflect the times!" The rules, which are rarely enforced, have recently come under scrutiny as those affected have expressed surprise at their application.

In a press conference on Thursday morning, House Speaker Paul Ryan acknowledged the issue, stating, "It came to my attention that there was an issue about dress code." He emphasized that the code had not been devised under his term and agreed that it needs to be modernized.

In the UK, a similar debate erupted recently when House of Commons Speaker John Bercow expressed a willingness to relax the rules. In June, he accepted a question from a member of parliament who was not wearing a tie. However, what constitutes appropriate attire in 2017, especially with the rise of more casual media and tech companies, is not always clear.

Title: Senate Impeachment Trial: Enforcing Subpoenas and the Potential Legal Battle Ahead

Article:

The Democratic leadership's decision to send articles of impeachment to the Senate without countering President Trump's alleged interference with House proceedings is seen as a missed opportunity. However, the Senate impeachment trial provides a second chance for confrontation, with the added benefit of bipartisan support for any subpoenas issued.

The enforcement of subpoenas is crucial to maintain the impartiality, independence, and integrity of the impeachment process. The President's assertion of executive privilege, allowing him to prevent witnesses from testifying or withholding incriminating documents, is a concern. This expansion of executive privilege, as demonstrated by the President's encouragement for witnesses to defy subpoenas and his proposed use of executive privilege to block current and former administration officials from testifying, challenges the constitutional balance of power.

If the Senate subpoenas witnesses, the Trump legal team may assert executive privilege or testimonial immunity to block their enforcement. This would be a misuse of these concepts, as it could weaken congressional authority and establish the President's entitlement to use his office to evade scrutiny.

Enforcing subpoenas during an impeachment trial could be complex. The Senate Impeachment Rules grant the Senate the power to compel witness attendance and enforce obedience to its orders. However, the sergeant-at-arms, who enforces Congress' orders, lacks a jail or a full police force. Congress has not used its enforcement powers since 1934, which could lead to the Senate turning to the courts for assistance in enforcing subpoenas. Alternatively, witnesses could defend against a Senate order to testify in a federal court.

This could result in a legal battle between Congress' power and the executive branch's claims of executive authority, potentially reaching the Supreme Court during Chief Justice John Roberts' presiding over the trial. If Justice Roberts were to recuse himself, the country might face the specter of a Supreme Court deadlocked on the critical question of whether a sitting President undergoing an impeachment trial has the right to assert executive privilege to block witnesses at his own trial.

Title: New York Representative Recognizes Concerns Over 9/11 Responder Cancer Compensation, but Approves Link to Toxic Substances

Article:

Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Democrat from New York and a primary sponsor of the 2010 law establishing the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund, acknowledged concerns about the decision to link certain cancers to the toxic substances found at Ground Zero but stated that the decision was the correct one.

One cancer patient, Ernest K. Matthews, 62, who typifies the complex nature of the decision, developed lung cancer in 2008 and had part of his right lung removed. He was part of a crew that cleaned elevators for the Merrill Lynch building near Ground Zero after the terrorist attack. He was also a smoker.

However, Mr. Matthews stated that he was able to walk up six flights of stairs carrying a heavy tool bag without difficulty before September 11. He developed breathing problems soon after, he said.

"It's a good day," Mr. Matthews said on Friday. "Look at all the people that suffered and lost their lives, sacrificing for the cleanup. It took so long for them to decide to help the people that were suffering."

Dr. Howard's decision represents a shift from immediate assurances by the federal government after the terrorist attacks that there was no cause for concern regarding the air quality. In July 2011, Dr. Howard himself stated that there was not enough scientific or medical evidence to link cancer to September 11.

However, in a lengthy report explaining his decision, Dr. Howard cited a New York Fire Department study published last fall in the British medical journal The Lancet, which showed that firefighters exposed to Ground Zero toxic substances had about a 20 percent higher rate of cancer than firefighters who were not exposed.

Beyond the Lancet study, Dr. Howard relied on recommendations made by a scientific and technical advisory committee consisting of experts from the fields of cancer, environmental medicine, toxicology, and epidemiology, as well as neighborhood activists and union officials. He fully adopted the committee's recommendation that 14 broad categories of cancer, encompassing 50 specific types, should be deemed as related to the attacks.

Among the cancers Dr. Howard approved are some of the most common, including lung, breast, colon, trachea, esophageal, kidney, bladder, skin, thyroid, blood, and ovarian cancers. Dr. Howard also approved childhood cancers, which are relatively rare, because children are more susceptible to toxic substances.

People with covered cancers who lived, worked, or attended school in Lower Manhattan—generally the area below Canal Street—between September 11, 2001, and May 30, 2002, would be able to apply for compensation for their economic losses, pain, and suffering. Until the decision on Friday, the only ailments approved for compensation were mainly respiratory and digestive ones. Survivors of patients who have died, as well as people caught in the dust cloud downtown on the day of the attack, may also apply.

The amount of compensation will depend on the severity of the illness and duration of exposure, as proven by records like employment or housing documents, or city personnel records for fire, police, and other public workers.

The new rules would apply to Pentagon and Shanksville, Pa., responders as well, and it allows those cancer patients to tap into a treatment fund to pay for medical costs not covered by insurance.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has consistently deferred to scientific rulings on health hazards at Ground Zero, said that his administration had called for periodic reviews of the medical evidence on cancer, and that the decision was "an important step."

The advisory committee had stated that 70 known or potential carcinogens, including asbestos, arsenic, and formaldehyde, had been found in the smoke, dust, and fumes from the disaster, that 15 of those were known to cause cancer in humans, and that 37 were "reasonably anticipated" to cause cancer.

The advisory committee considered but rejected, by a 14-to-3 vote, the notion of adding all cancers to the list. It explicitly rejected pancreas, brain, and prostate cancers, for various reasons. The committee could meet again to discuss other potential additions to the list.

The broad sweep of the committee's recommendation raised some eyebrows among epidemiologists, several of whom have said that it appeared the committee was appealing to societal concerns that the cancer patients not be left out of the fund.

"Clearly this was a difficult decision, and primarily motivated by concern for a sympathetic population," said Dr. Alfred I. Neugut, an oncologist and professor of epidemiology at the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia. "The scientific evidence currently is certainly weak; whether future evidence bears out the wisdom of this decision will have to be seen."

Dr. Howard made a nod toward a concern of some epidemiologists that because cancer was a common disease, it would be hard to distinguish who got cancer because of September 11 from those who did not. He also said that hard scientific data conclusively linking September 11 to cancer might take years to obtain.

"Requiring evidence of positive associations from studies of 9/11-exposed populations exclusively does not serve the best interests" of the patients, he wrote.

Title: Michigan Primary: Cruz and Kasich Compete for Second Place as Sanders Aims for Surprise Win

Article:

The Michigan primary on Tuesday, March 8, is set to be a significant event in the 2016 U.S. presidential race. The state, traditionally a Democratic stronghold, is expected to provide insights into the strategies of the Republican candidates, particularly Ted Cruz and John Kasich, as they vie for second place behind front-runner Donald Trump.

Ted Cruz's performance in Michigan is uncertain, as the state is a blue state with fewer evangelical voters, a demographic that Cruz has relied on in previous contests. Cruz has faced challenges in states with a more liberal lean, and his performance in Michigan could indicate his ability to compete in upcoming Democratic-leaning states such as California, New Jersey, and New York.

John Kasich, on the other hand, could potentially benefit from the struggles of Marco Rubio, who has performed poorly in recent primaries. Kasich, a relatively moderate governor from a neighboring state, is polling closely with Cruz for second place in Michigan. The race for second place serves as a test for both Cruz and Kasich, each aiming to present themselves as the strongest alternative to Trump.

In the Democratic race, Bernie Sanders faces a challenging situation in Michigan. The state, with its high percentage of white, working-class voters and history of outsourcing, seems to align with Sanders' economic message. Michigan also has significant college towns like Ann Arbor and East Lansing, which tend to lean liberal. However, the state is whiter than the nation as a whole, and black voters, who have been a significant factor in Hillary Clinton's Southern victories, make up roughly the same share of the electorate in Michigan as they do nationally.

Given Sanders' performance in the early primaries, his need for a strong showing in Michigan is particularly high. Polls suggest that Clinton is on track for a decisive victory, and a surprise win for Sanders in Michigan would demonstrate his continued viability in the race.

The Michigan primary on Tuesday will provide valuable insights into the strategies and momentum of the candidates as the primary season moves forward.

Title: President Trump's Campaign Commits $10 Million for Midterm Advertising Blitz

Article:

President Donald Trump's campaign operation is planning an advertising blitz for the final two weeks before the midterms, as part of a multimillion-dollar bid to help Republicans maintain control of Congress. According to the campaign, this commitment includes a $6 million TV and digital ad buy set to launch on October 29 and last through Election Day. The campaign is also sending $3 million to the Republican National Committee (RNC) to boost GOP campaigns, while Trump plans to host at least 10 more "Make America Great Again" rallies in support of Republicans before the election.

In total, the president's campaign reports that the nearly $10 million commitment is part of more than $20 million the operation is spending on the midterm elections, including rally costs.

"President Trump is all-in for the midterms to lead the GOP to victory on Election Day," Trump Campaign Manager Brad Parscale said in a statement Tuesday. "His winning spirit is energizing Americans across the country to get out the vote and keep the momentum of our America First agenda going strong."

Trump's 2020 campaign has already amassed a massive war chest, raising roughly $100 million to date. He enters his re-election battle with a sizable fundraising advantage against any Democratic candidate, but will draw down some of that this fall in the fight to keep Congress in Republican hands.

The MAGA rallies being held on a regular basis serve a dual purpose—boosting GOP candidates in the midterms while allowing Trump to connect with his base and keep them energized ahead of the 2020 fight. Since the summer, Trump has held 20 such rallies so far. Over the last several months, Trump and Vice President Mike Pence also have attended dozens of candidate and GOP committee fundraisers, according to the campaign.

At the two-week mark, Republicans are seen as holding the edge in the race for control of the Senate, while Democrats remain favored in the race for the House—but their advantage is narrowing in recent polling. According to the latest NBC-Wall Street Journal Poll, in competitive districts, Democrats and Republicans are in a dead heat on the question of which party should control Congress. A Washington Post survey out Tuesday reported that Democrats hold a "statistically insignificant lead" in battleground districts.

The ultimate impact of Trump's policies and presence on the campaign trail remains to be seen, but he has shown no hesitation about latching his name and his brand to Republican candidates across the country—most recently, former primary rival Ted Cruz, during a Texas rally Monday night. While many Democrats are trying to damage GOP incumbents by linking them to Trump, some of those same incumbents are openly embracing the Trump agenda and the president's visible campaign role.

"President Trump energizes our base like no one else. The overwhelming amount of time and money he’s spending is fueling grassroots enthusiasm for all of our candidates," Republican National Committee Chairwoman Ronna McDaniel said in a statement to the news source. "That support has enabled the RNC to build our largest field program ever to get out the vote and defy history on Election Day."

Aside from rallies, the next big commitment will come in the form of the ad buy set to launch on October 29.

"With so much at stake in the midterms, we’re leaving everything on the field to build our incredible progress for the American people," Lara Trump, a campaign senior adviser and daughter-in-law to the president, said in a statement.

Meanwhile, the RNC last week announced a record $269.9 million raised in a non-presidential election year, with $56.8 million raised in the third quarter. The RNC told the news source that 40 percent of the total were small-dollar donations. The Democratic National Committee has raised $136 million so far this cycle, including $9.6 million in September, compared with the RNC's $26.2 million.

The RNC piggy bank will grow a bit bigger with the Trump campaign vowing to transfer $3 million. The new transfer is in addition to direct contributions of $214,000 made by the campaign in August to 107 House and Senate campaigns.

Despite the RNC's fundraising edge over its counterpart, Democratic candidates have benefited from a windfall of individual donations, fueled in part by the fundraising tool "ActBlue," which has sent more than $1 billion in donations to Democrats this cycle.

Both parties are taking an equally urgent tone in appealing to voters not to sit out the election.

"This is the most important election of our lifetime," DNC Chairman Tom Perez tweeted.

Title: Democratic Senators Accuse SBA of Politically-Motivated Action in Planned Parenthood PPP Loan Controversy

Article:

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) and other Democratic lawmakers are accusing the Trump administration of unfairly targeting Planned Parenthood affiliates amid reports that some affiliated health care centers are being pressured by the government to return federally-funded, potentially forgivable small business loans granted through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) during the coronavirus pandemic.

In a letter to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Small Business Administration (SBA) Administrator Jovita Carranza, Democrats argue that by seeking to reclaim the PPP funds, the SBA is taking an "ideologically-driven action" in order to "score political points for this administration by attacking nonprofit health care providers."

The lawmakers add that "the administration's longstanding campaign against reproductive health generally, and Planned Parenthood specifically, strongly suggests that Planned Parenthood is being arbitrarily singled out amongst over 4.3 million loans that have been issued under this program." Forty Democratic senators and one independent senator endorsed the letter.

The SBA has notified at least three Planned Parenthood affiliates that they should return their PPP loans. It's unclear if other clinics have been contacted. SBA officials declined to respond to questions from ABC News, saying that they do not comment on individual borrowers. ABC News reached out to the Treasury Department as well, but received no response.

Planned Parenthood maintains that their affiliates rightfully qualified for the PPP funding. "Like many other local nonprofits and health care providers, some independent Planned Parenthood 501 (c) (3) organizations applied for and were awarded loans under the eligibility rules established by the CARES Act and the Small Business Administration (SBA), which they met," Jacqueline Ayers, Planned Parenthood Federation of America's vice president of government relations and public policy, said in a statement.

The eligibility rules, outlined by the SBA, allow for most businesses and nonprofits with fewer than 500 workers to qualify for PPP. However, Republicans have argued that since Planned Parenthood Federation of America has organizational control over its affiliates, and it should be considered as one large enterprise with too many employees to qualify for the lending program.

In their own letter last week, Senate Republicans urged the Department of Justice to open an investigation into reports that Planned Parenthood affiliates received roughly $80 million from the program. However, Planned Parenthood says that because the individual affiliates that received PPP loans have their own governing boards, they must be considered as smaller, standalone entities that lawfully qualify for the program.

The SBA's rules for determining eligibility for the PPP have been a source of confusion since their implementation, but in their letter, Democrats claim the intention of the program has always been clear. "The decision to fund PPP was based on a mutual and bipartisan consensus that it was important for this program to assist the broad universe of nonprofit organizations in this country, many of whom provide food assistance, health care services, child care, charitable services, and other essential functions that constitute a critical component of our social safety net," the lawmakers wrote.

Title: Rep. Louie Gohmert Discusses Second Amendment on Fox News Sunday

Article:

In a discussion on Fox News Sunday, Representative Louie Gohmert (R-TX) expressed his views on the Second Amendment in light of recent mass shootings, including the Connecticut massacre and the Aurora movie theater shooting.

During the segment, Eric Holder, the U.S. Attorney General, expressed a need for a national discussion on the freedom and rights Americans have, and how they can be used responsibly. In response, Rep. Gohmert brought up the Fast and Furious operation, in which the Department of Justice forced the sale of guns that led to the deaths of individuals, including Border Patrol Agent Brian Terry.

When asked about the Aurora movie theater massacre and his argument for more people to carry weapons to prevent similar incidents, Rep. Gohmert stated that every mass killing of more than three people in recent history has occurred in places where guns were prohibited, except for one. He argued that having armed individuals could have prevented such tragedies, citing the defensive wounds on children and the heroic actions of the principal who tried to protect them.

In response to the question of why people need semi-automatic weapons, Rep. Gohmert referenced George Washington's statement that a free people should be an armed people, ensuring against the tyranny of the government if the American people are the largest armed force. He also argued that allowing concealed carry has led to a decrease in crime rates.

The discussion concluded with Rep. Gohmert stating that emotional reactions should not lead to the immediate call for the elimination of all guns, and that a rational, fact-based approach should be taken when considering gun control measures.

Title: Health and Human Services Plan to Share Medical Records with 35 Federal Agencies Sparks Concerns Over Privacy and Security

Article:

The Health and Human Services Department has announced a plan to share individuals' medical records with over 35 federal agencies, sparking concerns over privacy and security. The plan, detailed in the Federal Health IT Strategic Plan 2015-2020, aims to improve healthcare, individual and community health, and research by collecting, sharing, and using electronic health information.

The plan, according to The Weekly Standard, outlines the roles of these 35 departments and agencies in the collection, sharing, and use of electronic health information. The plan includes the Department of Defense, NASA, the Federal Trade Commission, the Department of Agriculture, the Department of Labor, the Federal Communications Commission, and several other federal agencies.

Critics argue that this plan is the start of a single-payer health care infrastructure, a concern due to the potential for government control over health care delivery. The concern is that the sharing of personal health care information with multiple federal agencies poses a threat to privacy and personal security.

The Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act requires physicians and hospitals to transfer secure paper-based medical records to an "electronic" system, i.e., the Internet. This transfer of records removes privacy and control in the relationship between patients and their doctors, as records are moved from office file cabinets to the Internet "cloud."

The plan has been met with criticism, with some arguing that it has nothing to do with delivering health care and instead serves to establish a single-payer health care infrastructure. The plan's proponents argue that it will make the health care system more efficient.

The plan has been met with opposition, with some calling for the public to voice their concerns during the two-month public comment period ending on Feb. 6. Critics argue that the plan represents everything dangerous about an expanding federal government and is an unacceptable violation of privacy and expansion of the federal government's control of our lives.

Title: Pelosi Refuses to Rule Out Indictment of President Trump While in Office

Article:

House Speaker designate Nancy Pelosi (D, Calif.) has declined to confirm or deny the possibility of indicting President Donald Trump while he is in office. In an interview with NBC's Savannah Guthrie that aired Thursday on "Today," Pelosi seemed to suggest that the Department of Justice guidelines suggesting a sitting president cannot be indicted might not be absolute.

When asked about the special counsel Robert Mueller respecting the Department of Justice guidelines that suggest a sitting president cannot be indicted, Pelosi responded, "I do not think that that is conclusive. No, I do not."

Mueller's team is currently investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election and possible coordination with the Trump campaign. Mueller has indicted multiple high-ranking Trump campaign officials on crimes seemingly unrelated to Russian interference, and he is expected to release a report to Congress detailing his findings as soon as mid-February.

The relevant Justice Department guidance, drafted in 2000 by the office of legal counsel, states, "The indictment or criminal prosecution of a sitting President would unconstitutionally undermine the capacity of the executive branch to perform its constitutionally assigned functions."

In making the case that the guidance in question might be ignored, Pelosi pointed out that there is no existing legislation prohibiting the indictment of a sitting president.

"It's not the law," Pelosi told Guthrie. "Everything indicates that a president can be indicted after he is no longer president of the United States."

When asked directly if Mueller can indict a sitting president, Pelosi responded, "Let's just see what Mueller does. Let's spend our time on getting results for the American people."

When asked if Mueller could indict a sitting president, Pelosi said, "I think that is an open discussion. I think that's an open discussion in terms of the law."

Pelosi, who served as the first female Speaker of the House from 2007 to 2011, is expected to reclaim the gavel in a Thursday afternoon leadership vote. The veteran California lawmaker has attempted to avoid the question of Trump's impeachment in the weeks leading up to the leadership vote but has pledged to thoroughly investigate the president using Congressional subpoena power.

Title: House GOP to Address Immigration Reform in Upcoming Conference Meeting

Article:

The House Republican Conference is set to convene on July 10 to discuss the approach to address the Senate-passed immigration reform bill. The meeting, which will take place in the Capitol basement, follows a week-long recess during which lawmakers returned to their districts to gather constituent feedback on the Senate plan.

Leadership anticipates differing opinions within the party, with some members feeling compelled to act swiftly, while others may advocate for a more cautious approach. However, top GOP aides and lawmakers are privately skeptical that any immigration bill, even with enhanced border security measures, can secure the support of 218 Republicans, the number required for passage.

Speaker John Boehner and his leadership team are aware of the political pressure that will mount but do not view immigration as a time-sensitive issue. They are comfortable allowing the process to extend until the end of the year.

Key lawmakers have been meeting with groups of rank-and-file Republicans, but have found it challenging to discern the "coalitions" - the pockets of opposition and support for various proposals. Rep. James Lankford (R-Okla.), a member of leadership, expressed uncertainty when asked about potential measures that could garner enough Republican support for a floor vote.

The leadership's strategy is taking shape, with the July 10 meeting expected to chart a course forward on immigration reform. The meeting, dubbed the "Special GOP conference meeting," will be structured into a three-step process.

GOP leadership, likely including Boehner, Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.), and Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.), will deliver a brief presentation, urging lawmakers to express their views to help the party develop a policy.

Judiciary Chairman Bob Goodlatte (R-Va.) and Homeland Security Committee Chairman Mike McCaul (R-Texas) will explain what House committees have already passed and the options moving forward. The leadership aims to determine where members stand on four main areas: the future flow of immigrants into the U.S., a possible pathway to citizenship, government benefits, and border security.

The House may choose to address these items separately or combine them in a single bill. Putting the bills together could allow members to claim support for a package containing items they both favor and oppose. Alternatively, the House could take up the Senate bill in committee, strip it down, and rewrite it.

Much of the decision-making process will occur in a more discreet manner.

Title: Hillary Clinton Meets with President Obama and Vice President Biden at the White House

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton returned to the White House on Monday for a lunch with President Barack Obama, marking her first visit to the building since leaving her post earlier this year. The meeting, which was largely a social gathering, took place in the midst of preparations for Middle East peace negotiations in Washington.

Deputy Press Secretary Josh Earnest stated that the lunch was an opportunity for Clinton and Obama, who had a strong working relationship and genuine friendship during Clinton's tenure as secretary of state, to catch up. Clinton also met with Vice President Joe Biden on Tuesday at the Naval Observatory.

The lunch menu consisted of grilled chicken, pasta jambalaya, and salad. Current Secretary of State John Kerry was also present at the White House, but it appears he did not join the lunchtime meeting. Clinton did, however, stop by to say hello while Kerry met with National Security Adviser Susan Rice.

The meeting between Clinton and Obama was arranged after the pair saw each other at the George W. Bush Presidential Center dedication ceremony in April. With both individuals having busy schedules this summer, July 28th was the agreed-upon date for the get-together.

Clinton, a potential candidate for the 2016 White House race, has been active post-State, appearing at events focused on women's empowerment and maintaining a busy speaking engagement schedule. She has also launched an initiative through the Clinton Foundation dedicated to early childhood development and signed a book deal in April for a diplomacy-centered memoir to be released in 2014.

Title: Biden's Unconventional Approach at Democratic Presidential Town Hall on LGBTQ Issues

Article:

During the Democratic presidential town hall on LGBTQ issues on Thursday, former Vice President Joe Biden took an unconventional approach to demonstrate his emotional concern for the queer community. In a series of unexpected and somewhat uncomfortable moments, Biden flirted with multiple men, joked about coming out as gay, and mimed kissing Anderson Cooper, the gay CNN anchor moderating his portion of the town hall.

Biden's actions, which included telling a well-dressed audience member he looked like he "just stepped out of Gentlemen's Quarterly" and reenacting a kiss with President Barack Obama, were met with a mix of laughter and discomfort from the audience. The former vice president's actions were described as "hilariously off-tone, uncomfortable, and strained" in a report by The Cut.

Biden's actions were not the only awkward moments of the night. Senator Kamala Harris stated her pronouns as she/her/hers, to which CNN's Chris Cuomo replied, "Mine, too." However, Biden's actions were the most persistent and bizarre of the night.

Despite the controversy surrounding his actions, Biden ended his time with Cooper on a note of acceptance, affirming that being queer in 2019 is "normal" and "normalized." He also noted the progress made in public discourse around LGBTQ issues in recent decades, stating that discussions about LGBTQ issues in the past were often focused on "gay bathhouses" and "round-the-clock sex."

The town hall was intended to discuss the future of LGBTQ lives in America, but Biden's actions overshadowed much of the intended discussion. The former vice president's approach to demonstrating his support for the LGBTQ community was met with a mix of amusement and discomfort by many observers.

Title: Mortgage Industry Faces Potential Crisis Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

The coronavirus pandemic has led to industry estimates suggesting that between 25 and 50 percent of mortgage borrowers may be unable to make their payments. This could potentially threaten the viability of mortgage servicers, particularly nonbank servicers, according to a letter from the Conference of State Bank Supervisors (CSBS) to Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on March 25.

If 25 percent of borrowers fail to make their mortgage payments, the industry would require approximately $40 billion to cover three months of payments, according to Jay Bray, CEO of the servicing company Mr. Cooper. Depending on the duration of the situation, demands on servicers could exceed $75 billion and potentially climb above $100 billion, according to industry expert Michael Broeksmit.

Andrew Jakabovics, vice president for policy development at Enterprise Community Partners, an affordable housing nonprofit, stated that if mortgage companies fail en masse, "the system breaks down." He explained that the relief measures implemented during the foreclosure crisis were crucial to maintain U.S. mortgage-backed securities as a safe investment, and any disruption could have serious implications for the availability and price of mortgage credit.

Industry experts believe that the Federal Reserve will implement an emergency lending program to support the industry. Mark Toomey, who previously managed the $2 trillion portfolio of government-run mortgage financier Ginnie Mae, expressed confidence that the Fed would provide such a program.

Mark Calabria, Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, which regulates Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two government-sponsored mortgage giants that support about half of the nation's $11 trillion market, stated that large banks would continue to extend credit to mortgage servicers for the time being. However, he noted that if the situation persists beyond two months, a more substantial solution would be necessary.

Broeksmit suggested that some mortgage companies may not survive if their loan portfolios are heavily concentrated in areas of the country where the virus has had a significant impact. He also emphasized the need for the emergency lending facility to be established promptly, as some servicers may require liquidity sooner than others.

Margaret Liu, CSBS senior vice president and deputy general counsel, stated that the credit lines from banks would not be sufficient to keep the system afloat. She highlighted the interconnected nature of the mortgage market and the crucial role of the government as a reliable source of credit during a crisis.

In the interim, the industry is hopeful that individual cash relief in the Senate bill will result in fewer people needing to request forbearance on their payments. Broeksmit expressed hope that the take-up rate won't be high and that the duration won't be extended, but they are preparing for both scenarios.

Title: House Democrats Advance Legal Action for Unredacted Mueller Report, Court Enforcement of Subpoenas

Article:

WASHINGTON - U.S. congressional Democrats have moved closer to suing in federal court for access to the unredacted Mueller report on Russian election meddling and its underlying evidence, taking a step that is bound to intensify their clash with President Donald Trump.

In a resolution unveiled on Thursday, the House Judiciary Committee authorized the enforcement of subpoenas against U.S. Attorney General William Barr and former White House Counsel Don McGahn, who have refused to cooperate with the Judiciary Committee's requests for the unredacted report, related documents, and testimony from McGahn.

The resolution, which the Democratic-controlled House of Representatives is expected to consider on Tuesday, replaces an earlier plan to vote formally on whether to hold Barr and McGahn in contempt of Congress.

The measure, introduced by the House Rules Committee, also outlines terms for possible court action by other House committees that are investigating the president and authorizes the Judiciary Committee to petition a federal judge for access to Mueller's grand jury evidence.

The House Ways and Means Committee is similarly poised to file a federal lawsuit to enforce subpoenas of Trump's individual and business tax returns.

Congressional committees already have the authority to seek court remedies. However, Tuesday's vote is intended to reaffirm congressional authority to enforce subpoenas against White House efforts to stymie investigations by six separate House committees, according to Democratic aides.

"We will not allow this president and his administration to turn a blind eye to the rule of law," said Rules Committee Chairman James McGovern, who will take up the measure on Monday. "The Trump administration is waging an unprecedented campaign of stonewalling and obstruction... This resolution will allow Congress to hold the president accountable."

Justice Department officials were not immediately available to comment on the resolution.

The measure follows through on House Democrats' plans to go to court in their quest for an unredacted copy of Mueller's report. Democrats say they are confident of swift court victories after decisive court rulings against Trump's efforts to block subpoenas of his financial records issued by three other House panels.

Barr released a redacted version of the 448-page report on April 18. He later disregarded a House Judiciary Committee subpoena demanding the full report, along with the underlying evidence that Mueller relied on. The House Judiciary panel voted on May 8 to cite Barr for contempt of Congress.

In a letter to Cummings on Thursday, the Justice Department called a contempt vote "entirely premature" and declined to hand over the specific documents demanded, saying they were protected by attorney-client privilege and other doctrines. It said it was still working to produce other papers the committee requested.

The White House has asserted the seldom-used principle of executive privilege to try to keep the full Mueller report under wraps, even though Trump allowed aides to speak with Mueller during his investigation.

House Judiciary also subpoenaed McGahn, seeking his testimony, which he refused to provide in line with a pattern of stonewalling by Trump of Democrats' inquiries. Lawmakers have said they would vote to hold Barr and McGahn in contempt. However, on Thursday, aides said a formal contempt vote would have referred the case for criminal prosecution, a move unlikely to succeed with Barr at the helm of the Justice Department. Lawmakers instead opted for the new resolution.

Title: White House Launches Three-Week "Made in America" Campaign to Emphasize President Trump's Agenda

Article:

The White House is initiating a three-week "Made in America" messaging campaign starting on Monday, with the aim of refocusing President Donald Trump's public agenda. The three-week emphasis will highlight key tenets of Trump's agenda, potentially serving as preparation for the Senate's push to rewrite the U.S. tax code.

The first week will feature American-made products, followed by "American Heroes week," which is expected to focus on American jobs. The final week will be dedicated to the "American Dream." According to a White House official, healthcare will not be the focus of a separate week, with the official stating, "Every day and every week, in a sense, is a healthcare week. It’s something that enormous White House and administration resources have been devoted to since day one."

On Monday, Trump will showcase a variety of locally made products from all 50 states. He will tour products displayed at the White House and on the South Lawn, and then address the media on his administration's support of manufacturing companies in America. White House press secretary Sean Spicer told the Wall Street Journal that the campaign will underscore the president's emphasis on reforming the tax code.

The campaign follows the White House initiative to promote "theme weeks" on policy areas, such as "infrastructure week" in early June, during which the president tweeted about infrastructure issues daily. Subsequent theme weeks focused on energy and technology. The campaign's launch comes as White House aides are reportedly grappling with determining which of the president's policy priorities to focus on. Former Speaker Newt Gingrich (R-Ga.), a political adviser to Trump, told the Journal that the White House communications team is "still learning" how to wield its political influence, and that the team was unclear in stating its goals for the healthcare debate.

Title: U.S. Economy Adds 80,000 Jobs in June, Unemployment Rate at 8.2%

Article:

The United States economy added 80,000 jobs in June, according to a report by the Labor Department on Friday. This figure represents a slight increase of 3,000 jobs compared to May. The 8.2% unemployment rate is lower than it has been in the last three Junes, but the slow job growth has raised concerns for the current administration.

Deanna Hubbard, who serves customers at Ann's Place in Akron, Ohio, expressed her concerns about the economy's impact on her business and personal life. "The economy is doing bad. Right now, we've been blessed, but the economy has taken a toll on us with the food prices and delivery prices and people losing their homes," she said.

The slow job growth in June does not bode well for President Barack Obama, but political experts argue that what matters more is a candidate who offers a better long-term plan for economic recovery. Frankly, I think no matter who had been president, the last four years we would have seen very sluggish recovery. It's normal after a financial crisis, but there is a question of where things are going from here," said Ken Rogoff, an economics and public policy professor at Harvard University and former International Monetary Fund chief economist.

Ohio, a swing state with an unemployment rate of 7.3% in May, is particularly concerned about the economy's future. Before the release of the flat job-growth numbers, President Obama spoke with diners who worked at Goodyear Tire & Rubber and toured the Summer Garden Food Manufacturing plant, which makes pasta sauce, in Boardman, Ohio.

In a speech to a gathering of a few hundred at an elementary school gym in Poland, Ohio, the president highlighted the economy's slow but steady recovery under his watch, such as businesses creating "4.4 million new jobs over the past 28 months, including 500,000 new manufacturing jobs," and a government program to shore up the ailing U.S. auto industry.

Republican challenger Mitt Romney called the jobs figures "another kick in the gut to middle-class families." Romney's economic recovery plan includes reducing the corporate income tax rate and curbing some of the regulatory policies he says have driven up energy costs, among other measures to help whittle down the unemployment rate.

The June jobs figures may make news now, but presidential candidates and voters will be more closely watching a critical jobs report due just days before the November 6 general election, said Tom Smith, an assistant professor at Emory University's Goizueta Business School. If there's an uptick in jobs creation just before the election, Obama is in good stead. But a downtick could bode well for Romney, Smith said.

"There are two things that are going to impact this election: the unemployment rate and jobs creation... People are looking for things to get better," said Smith. "People don't have the money to eat."

Title: Social Media Reactions Highlight Light-Hearted Moments During State of the Union Address

Article:

During the State of the Union address delivered by President Donald Trump, social media platforms were abuzz with political analysis, partisan debate, and a series of light-hearted talking points. One of the most popular memes of the night revolved around House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a high-profile opponent of the president.

A photo of Pelosi applauding after Trump called for compromise in politics became a subject of discussion, as many on social media perceived this as a symbol of the political rivalry between the two. The incident came after Trump broke traditional protocol by not waiting for the customary introduction from the House speaker before beginning his speech.

Another notable event was the powerful political statement made by women in Congress, who wore white to celebrate the centenary of women's right to vote in the US. The move highlighted the higher number of female Democrats compared to Republicans in the House.

When President Trump stated, "no one has benefited more from our thriving economy than women," the female representatives remained stony-faced. However, after Trump mentioned that women "filled 58% of the newly created jobs last year," they started enthusiastically cheering and clapping each other.

Many of the Democratic lawmakers cheering took office after the recent mid-term elections, which saw a record number of women elected, and the Democrats win a majority in the House of Representatives. The irony of this was not lost on many Twitter users.

President Trump and First Lady Melania Trump invited 11-year-old Joshua Trump from Wilmington, Delaware, who has been bullied at school because of his surname. Photos of the boy, who is not related to President Trump, dozing off during the speech earned him some fans on Twitter. His parents pulled him out of school as they said his classmates had called him an "idiot" and "stupid" for sharing the same name as the president.

Eline, the girl sitting next to him, has been treated for brain cancer. She seemed to enjoy the evening a lot more.

Some Twitter users were also distracted by less weighty issues, such as the position of the president's tie. Many took to social media to point out that the president's trademark red tie was off-centre.

During the almost 90-minute address, many social media users seemed preoccupied by trying to guess what Nancy Pelosi was reading. Some took to Twitter to suggest that Ms. Pelosi was being "disrespectful" by reading while the president spoke.

After President Trump finished his address, Stacey Abrams delivered the Democratic response. While Abrams spoke about immigration, voting rights, healthcare, and the economy, Twitter-users homed in on the way the address looked.

Ms. Abrams could be seen standing at a lectern in front of a group of people blurred out behind her. Many wondered if she was appearing in front of a green screen. However, as can be seen below, after Ms. Abrams finished speaking and the camera zoomed out, it is clear that a green screen was not used.

Title: Democrats Face Challenges in Seven Key Senate Races Ahead of Midterm Elections

Article:

Democrats are bracing for potential losses in seven key Senate races, with three seats vacated by retiring Democrats and the party struggling to maintain control of the Senate. Four weeks before the 2014 midterm elections, some Democratic operatives find it difficult to envision a scenario where they retain control of the U.S. Senate.

A new CNN/ORC poll released Thursday suggests a Republican lead over a Democratic incumbent in Alaska, adding to Democrats' concerns. A Democratic consultant, speaking anonymously, expressed pessimism, stating, "If you put a gun to my head, I guess I'd say that we're going to lose the Senate."

The challenges for Democrats are not solely attributed to President Obama, who is often seen as a drag on their candidates. A Democratic operative acknowledged, "I love the guy and I don't think there's anything he could do to fix it, but he's a real drag." However, the bigger issue is the economy, with the economy improving but wages remaining stagnant.

Many of the Democrats defending their seats in GOP-leaning states were swept into office by then-Senator Barack Obama in 2008. In Alaska, for example, Senator Mark Begich won by a narrow margin against Senator Ted Stevens in 2008. However, recent polling shows Begich trailing his GOP opponent, Dan Sullivan, by six percentage points among likely voters.

The Democrats are defending seven competitive Senate races, including Alaska, Arkansas, Louisiana, Colorado, Iowa, New Hampshire, and North Carolina. They are feeling cautiously optimistic about only two of these races, Sen. Jeanne Shaheen in New Hampshire and Sen. Kay Hagan in North Carolina.

Sen. Hagan currently polls at 44% against her GOP opponent Thom Tillis, with 40%. In 2008, Obama narrowly won North Carolina, and Hagan defeated then-Sen. Elizabeth Dole with 52.7% to 44.2%. However, four years later, North Carolinians opted for Mitt Romney, a GOP governor, and Democrats were down to four out of 13 U.S. House seats. Hagan could still win this November, but it will not be due to a wave; instead, she will have successfully fought against it.

Each race is its own individual microcosm, and the Senate GOP Leader, Mitch McConnell, has a competitive race in Kentucky. Kansas is a unique case, with the Democratic candidate having withdrawn, and Republican Sen. Pat Roberts facing an independent challenger who has not stated which party he will caucus with. Democrats are hoping that if the final vote comes down to Independent Greg Orman, he will remember that Democrats cleared the field for him. A CNN/ORC poll out Wednesday showed the race in a virtual tie with Roberts just one percentage point ahead.

The Democratic operative noted that his party was benefiting from some GOP struggles, such as the Republican party's inability to raise as much money as intended, infighting among GOP Super-PACs, and general infighting among conservatives. However, midterm elections are generally more difficult for the party that holds the White House, and opposition to Washington appears to be a motivating factor for many voters.

"A lot of these races are tight right now, but this is not the sort of environment where late-deciding voters are going to break for Democrats," the Democratic consultant said, adding that with Democrats in tight races but under 50%, it's tough to imagine all of them breaking in favor of the party that holds the White House. Those Democrats include the ones fighting for their jobs in all seven of these toss-ups. The most recent polling, which could change between now and election day, suggests extremely close margins or a Republican advantage in all of them.

Title: Massachusetts Legislature Recalls Mitt Romney's Tenure as Governor

Article:

During Mitt Romney's tenure as governor of Massachusetts, Democrats held a majority in the state legislature. Romney, who is currently a senator representing Utah, is often praised by Democrats for his work in passing health care reform.

However, Romney's leadership style sometimes alienated Democrats, who were accustomed to a different approach. Robert Hedlund, the second-ranking Republican in the state Senate, described Romney as a CEO-style leader who brought over the corporate culture from his former private investment firm, Bain Capital.

Romney replaced many career bureaucrats in the executive staff with private sector outsiders. This management structure, according to Hedlund, produced results in balancing the state's budget.

Across the aisle, Romney still gets positive reviews for his willingness to work with Democrats to pass health care reform. However, many rank-and-file Democrats are still bothered by what they describe as a distant and guarded leader.

State Rep. Frank Smizik, chairman of the House Committee on Global Warming and Climate Change, recalled Romney's unprecedented move to block off one State House elevator specifically for the governor's office. Romney's security measures and the installation of ropes outside his office turned off some lawmakers, according to Smizik and other Democratic lawmakers.

Democratic state Rep. Ellen Story described Romney as treating government like a big business, while Democratic state Rep. John Scibak was more blunt in his feelings about Romney. Scibak quipped about Romney's decision to forgo a second term to run for the presidency in 2008, saying, "Many people said, 'Good riddance. Don't let the door hit you on the way out.'"

Aides to the Romney campaign chalked up some of the hard feelings among State House Democrats to election-time loyalties to President Barack Obama. However, the campaign called on Democratic lawmaker, state Rep. Jim Vallee, to offer some positive comments on Romney's time as governor.

Vallee noted that Romney had an ego but described him as "high-caliber." He also acknowledged that some people did not have a positive relationship with Romney.

Mike Widmer, a government watchdog with the nonpartisan Massachusetts Taxpayers Foundation, noted that Romney set aside his CEO approach to woo Democratic leaders to pass health care reform. The law, widely considered Romney's signature achievement, is memorialized in his official State House portrait, sitting on a small table along with a framed picture of the former governor's wife, Ann.

Romney struggled in other areas such as job creation, Widmer said, in part because of the governor's CEO style. However, Romney was beginning to divert his attention to pursuing the White House, Widmer and other state lawmakers recalled.

State House insiders often contrast Romney's style with another recent Republican governor, William Weld, who seemed to revel in the kind of behind-closed-doors backslapping that Democrats had come to expect over the years.

Democratic leaders, who now dominate the Massachusetts State House and control the governor's office, gleefully note the rope lines are gone, and the Romney executive elevator has since been reopened to the general public. Romney's Democratic successor, Gov. Deval Patrick, conceded he made those changes after taking office.

Vallee noted Patrick has also upset Democratic lawmakers with his reform efforts. "You can pick apart any of these guys," Vallee said.

Title: National Vigil for All Victims of Gun Violence Held in Washington

Article:

Washington, D.C. - Neil Heslin, whose 6-year-old son, Jesse, was among the victims of the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre in Newtown, Connecticut, last year, attended the National Vigil for All Victims of Gun Violence held at the Washington National Cathedral on Thursday. The vigil, organized by the Newtown Foundation, was attended by hundreds of people seeking solace and an end to gun violence.

Heslin, who had previously advocated for stricter gun laws, stated, "I'm not here for any political reason. I'm just here to honor Jesse." He found peace at the cathedral during Easter and hoped to find it again during the vigil.

Following three minutes of church bells tolling in honor of the 30,000 people killed by gun violence over the past year, a series of multi-faith leaders offered prayers for an end to the violence. Rev. Mel Kawakami of the Newtown United Methodist Church said, "We gather to say 'No more.'" Dr. Rajwant Singh, chairman of the Sikh Council on Religion and Education, added, "America must not allow these kinds of massacres...to take place. Only then can we call this nation a perfect union."

Relatives of victims from various shootings, including the Empire State Building in New York and the Aurora, Colorado, theater massacre, shared their stories and expressed their pain. Anthony Hardmon, 15, whose 19-year-old sister, Ashley, was shot to death five months ago near their Chicago home, said, "We stand with you through your trials and hard times. You're not alone."

Some speakers urged stricter gun control legislation, both at the local level and in Washington. Rev. Gary Hall, the dean of the National Cathedral, who plans to dedicate this Sunday's sermon to victims of gun violence, called for "moral courage and political will to lead us all to a new, safer era in American history."

Inside the cathedral, TV monitors displayed a constant loop of gun violence victims. Outside, a group of women wore sashes made from yellow and black tape, similar to police tape, that read "Stop Gun Violence."

Babe Healy King, who started the group after the Newtown massacre was a "tipping point," expressed hope that the tape-wrapped trees in her Chevy Chase, Maryland, neighborhood would mobilize support for stiffer gun laws. "People are numb (to gun violence)," said King, 68. "I hope there will be a huge explosion of people standing up and trying to make a difference."

The event was sponsored by the Newtown Foundation and the National Cathedral.

Title: House Speaker Paul Ryan Secures Easy Primary Victory in Wisconsin

Article:

House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-WI) has secured a decisive victory in his primary race against businessman Paul Nehlen, with Ryan receiving a 5-1 margin of votes. The election took place on Tuesday, and Ryan attributed his win to his strong support in his home district.

Ryan rejected the idea that his easy win spells danger for Donald Trump's presidential prospects in the swing state of Wisconsin. He stated that the primary victory indicates his popularity in the district where he was born and raised and has represented since 1998.

Nehlen, who had been courting Trump supporters and won praise from the Republican presidential nominee last week, was unable to overcome Ryan's popularity despite the strained relationship between the two. Trump endorsed Ryan days later.

Ryan had largely ignored Nehlen in what had been a sleepy primary before Trump thanked Nehlen on Twitter for his comments defending Trump. Nehlen won the backing of some prominent conservative figures, including former Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin, but it was not enough to overcome Ryan's popularity in his southeastern Wisconsin district.

Ryan responded with a blitz of radio appearances and added a pair of campaign stops the day before the election, determined to avoid the fate that befell House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, when the Virginia Republican lost a primary to a little-known tea party challenger.

Meanwhile, the primary's other top race was in northeastern Wisconsin, where GOP Rep. Reid Ribble's retirement opened a swing congressional seat. Mike Gallagher, a former Marine who served as national security adviser for Gov. Scott Walker's presidential campaign last year, handily defeated two opponents in the Republican primary.

Gallagher told The Associated Press that his campaign benefited from his being a political outsider. This was his first run for office, while his closest challenger, Sen. Frank Lasee, has been in the Legislature since 1995.

Ryan will face Democrat Ryan Solen, an Iraq war veteran, in the Nov. 8 general election. Three other congressional incumbents—Democrats Gwen Moore and Ron Kind and Republican Sean Duffy—all won.

In an unusual legislative race, incumbent Democratic state Sen. Lena Taylor easily dispatched with a challenge from state Rep. Mandela Barnes. No Republican was running in the Milwaukee race, making it all but certain Taylor would retain the seat.

Title: President Trump Announces "Most Dishonest & Corrupt Media Awards"

Article:

In a move that has been described as a "stunt" and a "finger in the media's collective eye," President Donald Trump has announced plans to present the "Most Dishonest & Corrupt Media Awards of the Year." The event is scheduled for Monday at 5:00 p.m. and will reportedly recognize instances of "dishonesty & bad reporting" from the "fake news media."

The categories and recipients of these awards are yet to be announced, but it is widely speculated that media outlets frequently targeted by the White House, such as CNN and The New York Times, will be among the "winners." It is also expected that the recipients, except in cases where they have retracted false stories, will view the awards as a badge of honor.

Television host Stephen Colbert, known for his anti-Trump stance, has expressed interest in receiving an award. He has purchased a Times Square billboard that lists humorous reasons why he should be honored, such as "Outstanding Achievement in Parroting George Soros' Talking Points" and "Least Breitbarty."

Trevor Noah's "Daily Show" has also displayed a "For Your Consideration" graphic on its Twitter feed.

While it is unlikely that these awards will win the president any votes or advance his agenda, they are expected to generate significant media coverage, appealing to his base, which already distrusts the press and enjoys the president's media-bashing.

Trump's approach to his presidency is characterized by an hour-by-hour focus on programming, as evidenced by his Twitter feed and his ability to drive the narrative to new topics when he wishes to change the storyline. The media dishonesty awards are expected to be a brief distraction, but Trump is likely to enjoy the attention they generate.

Title: Attorney General Barr Calls for Antitrust Legislation to Address Tech Companies' Alleged Censorship

Article:

In an exclusive interview with Maria Bartiromo on "Sunday Morning Futures," Attorney General William Barr expressed concern over recent incidents where technology companies, including Google and Twitter, allegedly attempted to censor content. The interview, which aired on Sunday, followed reports of Google's apparent influence over NBC in punishing two conservative news sites for coverage deemed offensive during the protests following the death of George Floyd.

Google, in response, stated that The Federalist was never demonetized and that they had worked with the site to address issues related to the comments section. Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) also mentioned that Twitter allegedly tried to censor his account for refusing to censor his tweets on the topic of riots and looting.

Attorney General Barr explained that tech companies initially gained their strong market position by marketing themselves as open to all viewpoints, but have since started to censor different viewpoints. He noted the concentration of these large companies and their influence on the sharing of information and viewpoints in society.

Barr expressed concern that this concentration of power allows for the quick galvanization of public opinion by presenting one viewpoint and pushing the public in a particular direction. He stated that the Constitution's foundation is based on a wide diversity of voices, and the current situation with the Internet and these big concentrations of power could lead to the oppression of minorities.

Barr suggested that the antitrust laws could be used to address companies engaging in monopolistic practices. The Department of Justice is pushing for new legislation that would hold Facebook, Twitter, and other tech giants accountable for content posted on their platforms, potentially rolling back protections that Silicon Valley has enjoyed for decades.

The Justice Department's proposals aim to update the outdated immunity for online platforms under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996. The DOJ is calling for lawmakers to address the outdated immunity, with Bartiromo asking, "What prompted this?" Barr responded by stating that problems with Section 230 were arising, and they have proposed changes to address that.

Barr explained that in the early days of the Internet, tech companies were encouraged to take down obscene or offensive material, but they should not be considered publishers under Section 230 if they do so. However, he noted that tech companies have started taking down viewpoints and being selective based on whether they agree with a viewpoint or not, which should make them publishers.

Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) introduced legislation on Wednesday that would give Americans the ability to sue major tech companies like Facebook, Google, and Twitter if they engage in selective censorship of political speech.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates' Performance in Second Debate

Article:

The second Democratic primary debate saw a mix of performances from the candidates, with some rising to the occasion while others struggled to meet expectations.

New Jersey Senator Cory Booker was praised for his strong showing, balancing attacks on former Vice President Joe Biden with an optimistic demeanor. Booker spoke powerfully about criminal justice reform and immigration, and made a notable point regarding the need for more ambitious action on climate change.

Senator Booker also criticized Biden for trying to take credit for former President Barack Obama's achievements while distancing himself from the Obama legacy when it is politically convenient.

In the healthcare debate, both Biden and Senator Kamala Harris faced challenges. Harris has struggled to provide clear answers on key questions, while Biden appeared to mix up copays with deductibles in one of his answers. The core disagreement between the two remained the same: Harris wants to fundamentally overhaul the system to cover everyone, while Biden wants to build on the current system to cover many more, but not all, people.

Senator Harris was unable to replicate her dominating performance from the first debate, and her answers on healthcare continued to sound unclear. Both Harris and Booker are in a position where they need Biden to falter, but for the moment, that isn't happening.

Biden was described as "perfectly adequate," with some criticizing his eloquence, rehearsed delivery, and understanding of modern technology. However, he was praised for his energy and preparation, which was a marked improvement from his lifeless performance at the first debate.

The candidates were quick to praise Obama the man, despite running against certain Obama policies. It is surprising to see Obama almost discarded as a party asset, given that he remains very popular and is still liked by almost nine in ten Democrats. The Democratic Party is moving leftward, but the candidate who is tying himself most closely to Obama, Joe Biden, continues to lead the polls.

Title: China Plans to Deploy Nuclear-Armed Submarines in the Pacific Amid South China Sea Tensions

Article:

China is reportedly planning to send nuclear-armed submarines for patrols in the Pacific Ocean for the first time, according to The Guardian, citing Chinese military officials. The timing for the maiden patrol has not been determined, but Beijing insists that such action is inevitable.

The announcement comes days after U.S. President Barack Obama lifted a decades-long arms embargo against Vietnam. Chinese officials have publicly praised the move, but a state-run newspaper warned that any attempt to enlist Vietnam in an effort to contain China could risk turning the region into a "tinderbox of conflicts."

U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry responded Monday by stating that it was China's actions in the South and East China Seas that could create a tinderbox. "I would caution China to not unilaterally move to engage in reclamation activities and militarization of islands," he said.

The Pentagon reports that China has reclaimed more than 3,200 acres of land in the South China Sea and is developing and building military installations on the man-made islands. As a consequence, the U.S. and Vietnam have steadily strengthened their relationship in recent years, in line with growing Vietnamese concern over Chinese moves to assert its maritime claims.

Despite China and Vietnam being Communist countries, clashes in 1988 over their conflicting claims in the South China Sea resulted in the deaths of dozens of people. Tensions re-emerged in 2014, when China parked an oil rig off Vietnam's central coast, sparking confrontations at sea and deadly anti-China riots in Vietnam.

Last week, the Pentagon reported that two Chinese fighter jets flew within about 50 feet of a U.S. Navy reconnaissance plane in what was termed an "unsafe intercept." China responded by demanding that the U.S. end surveillance patrols around the South China Sea, with a foreign ministry spokesman claiming that such missions "seriously endanger Chinese maritime security."

Earlier this month, a U.S. Navy destroyer sailed within 12 miles of China's Fiery Cross reef, an artificial island made after months of dredging operations. It was the third time the Navy sailed a warship close to a contested Chinese island in what the Pentagon calls "freedom of navigation" operations. Beijing responded by scrambling fighter jets to show its displeasure.

Title: Trump's Actions Prompt Constitutional Concerns as He Pushes for Inquiry into FBI's Alleged Campaign Infiltration

Article:

In a move that has raised constitutional concerns and sparked a political storm, President Donald Trump has initiated an inquiry into claims that the FBI infiltrated his 2016 campaign, a controversy first propagated in conservative media. The President delivered his order for the investigation to FBI Director Christopher Wray and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein during an Oval Office meeting on Monday.

In a strategic maneuver, Rosenstein may have temporarily defused Trump's anger by requesting the Department of Justice's inspector general to look into the President's claim. Top Justice Department officials will also share highly classified information with lawmakers regarding the Russia investigation.

The meeting's occurrence underscores the extraordinary times in Trump's Washington, where a President has turned against his own Justice Department and incites his political followers to do the same, potentially escalating the confrontation.

Michael Hayden, a former director of the CIA and the National Security Agency under presidents of both parties, expressed concern over the recent events, describing them as "a little scary."

"Our President is more limited by norms than he is (by the) Constitution or law. It is the traditions of the office that keep the President, I think, in his lane," Hayden said on CNN's "The Situation Room."
