Hayden further stated that Trump's actions have stepped so far beyond these norms that "people lose confidence in the independence of the judiciary, which frankly is our only off-ramp from this overhang currently over the entire nation," referring to the Russia investigation.

Questions surrounding Trump's actions include whether he is using his power to subvert an investigation into his own alleged misconduct, and whether a sitting President could potentially use the weight of his office to launch investigations into political enemies—an unprecedented step.

Trump, who intensified the crisis with a weekend of rampant tweeting, may be temporarily mollified by Rosenstein's move. However, given his persistent pressure on the Justice Department and the FBI, it's almost certain the showdown will flare up again soon. In fact, it seems to be in Trump's interests to keep the fire burning.

In an extraordinary step on Monday, the Trump campaign sent out a campaign blast email to supporters, urging them to sign a petition to force an investigation into "whether Obama's FBI and DOJ infiltrated or surveilled our campaign for political purposes."

"This could be the greatest political scandal in American history," the email, signed by Trump, declared in block capitals.

The email appears to be the most overt sign yet of how Trump and his allies are building a political campaign to tarnish special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation, apparently designed to discredit any eventual findings of wrongdoing by the President.

Democrats immediately denounced the move as a symptom of a President acting out of control.

"That he would issue such an absurd and abusive demand based on no evidence shows just how little regard the President has for the rule of law," said Democratic Senate leader Chuck Schumer of New York. "President Trump seems to have the terribly misguided view that the Department of Justice is there to protect his political interests and prosecute his enemies."

Even some of Trump's allies on Capitol Hill are uncomfortable with his latest turn. Utah's GOP Sen. Orrin Hatch told CNN's Manu Raju that "the question is whether it's advisable or not."

"You know, the Justice Department has been a pretty honest department all these years. As far as I'm concerned, he's got to leave it up to the Justice Department," Hatch said.

CNN's Jake Tapper reported that a loose and informal group of Trump advisers outside the White House have been pushing the President to attack Rosenstein and to frame him as part of a "deep state" plot against the White House. The campaign is using Trump-friendly media and the President to force Rosenstein to reveal details about the investigation that both the Justice Department and FBI do not want disclosed.

CNN has reported that the FBI did not insert an informant into the Trump campaign. Rather, the use of an asset is standard practice in counterintelligence operations—in this case, it was likely intended to gather information from campaign advisers who may have been the targets of a Russian espionage operation.

The fact that there is no evidence that the FBI, the Justice Department, or senior Obama officials came up with a "spy" scheme does not matter in this context—this is an active political campaign rather than a legal defense to the Mueller investigation.

"We are eroding the reality and the appearance of the independence of the judiciary and the Department of Justice and the special counsel," Hayden concluded.

Title: Attorney General Sessions Cites Bible Passage in Defense of Immigration Policy, Sparks Debate Among Religious Leaders

Article:

Indianapolis — Attorney General Jeff Sessions, while speaking in Fort Wayne on Thursday, sparked a heated debate on immigration and the interpretation of a Bible passage when he cited a chapter in Romans to defend the Trump administration's policy of separating parents from their children at the border. The policy has been widely denounced by religious leaders, immigration advocates, and others.

Sessions, who is also a Sunday school teacher at a United Methodist Church in Mobile, Alabama, said, "I would cite you to the apostle Paul and his clear and wise command in Romans 13 to obey the laws of the government because God has ordained them for the purpose of order."

The first three verses of Romans 13 in the Common English Bible, traditionally used by the United Methodist Church, read:

1. Every person should place themselves under the authority of the government. There isn’t any authority unless it comes from God, and the authorities that are there have been put in place by God.
2. So anyone who opposes the authority is standing against what God has established. People who take this kind of stand will get punished.
3. The authorities don’t frighten people who are doing the right thing. Rather, they frighten people who are doing wrong. Would you rather not be afraid of authority? Do what’s right, and you will receive its approval.

However, some who share Sessions' faith disagree with his interpretation of the passage. Mike Mather, the senior pastor at Broadway UMC in Indianapolis, said, "It was terrible." He added, "If you read the first 11 chapters of Romans, you get a pretty good idea of what the context of that community was. If you read (Chapter) 12, you see love is supposed to be the guiding force...(Sessions) did not read on very far."

Romans 12 includes the line, "Contribute to the needs of God’s people, and welcome strangers into your home." Those verses, Mather said, seem to run contrary to the policy Sessions was defending. Launched in May, the policy forcibly removes children traveling with parents caught at the border and places them in government care.

Sessions said the goal of the policy is not "to see if we can be mean to children." He said the point is to crack down on potential child trafficking or abuse and discourage parents from bringing their children on the often-dangerous border crossing.

On Thursday, White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders, a conservative Christian, answered a question about Sessions' comments, saying, "It is very biblical to enforce the law."

However, public backing for the policy—and the religious argument that Sessions used to support it—has been hard to come by.

Romans 13 has a history of being used by government officials in defense of their decisions or edicts. The Rev. Rob Saler, executive director for the Center for Pastoral Excellence at Indianapolis' Christian Theological Seminary, said the verses were used by Lutherans in Nazi Germany to justify supporting Adolf Hitler.

"Romans 13, for a long time, has been appealed to in an incorrect way, as a justification for 'Obey the laws, no matter what,'" he said. "Whether they're just or not. I don’t want to be too extreme, but...in Nazi Germany, Lutherans, for the most part, supported Hitler and they used Romans 13 to validate that."

In an interview with The Washington Post, John Fea, a professor of American history at Messiah College in Pennsylvania, said the verse was also used to support slavery in the 1840s and 1850s.

"(It) is invoked by defenders of the South or defenders of slavery to ward off abolitionists who believed that slavery is wrong," he said. "I mean, this is the same argument that Southern slaveholders and the advocates of a Southern way of life made."

Saler noted that it's important to consider when Paul wrote Romans. At that time, Christians were being executed by the Roman Empire, he said. What Paul was penning, Saler added, was meant to be a road map to living a gentler life full of charity, a stark contrast to how Paul would have viewed the empire.

"It's flat-out irresponsible (for Sessions) to use it without attention to the broader context," Saler said. "It's basically practical advice: While you're doing this, sure, go ahead and pay your taxes, give the government its due.

"But taken as a whole, Romans stands as a counter to unjust government and unjust rule."

Mather, who has served at UMC Broadway for 15 years, echoed that sentiment. When he learned Sessions had been a Sunday school teacher, he chuckled.

"I didn't know he'd been a Sunday school teacher, but I think this would be a bad interpretation to give to kids, or anyone for that matter," Mather said. "I'm constantly surprised by people who argue that they're Christians, but don't seem to know the essence of our faith."

Title: Comparative Analysis: Biden's South Carolina Strategy Mirrors Jeb Bush's in 2016

Article:

In a striking resemblance to the 2016 Republican contender, former Vice President Joe Biden, during his presidential campaign, shares many similarities with Jeb Bush, particularly in their strategies during the South Carolina primary.

Like Biden, Bush was closely associated with his party's last president, George W. Bush. Both led in early polls and struggled in debates. In the case of Iowa and New Hampshire, Bush came in sixth and fourth, respectively, while Biden faced similar results in the same primaries this year. Both candidates staked their candidacies on a comeback in South Carolina.

Bush's strategy in South Carolina mirrored Biden's recent approach, positioning himself as the defender of his party's old guard. At a debate in South Carolina, Bush contrasted the insurgent Donald Trump's nativist stance with former President George W. Bush's more welcoming message. He defended immigrants, stating, "The great majority of immigrants are coming to provide for their families. And we should show a little more respect for the fact that they're struggling."

Bush also defended his brother's response to 9/11 during the debate, countering Trump's accusations of lying about weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. "While Donald Trump was building a reality-TV show," Bush retorted, "my brother was building a security apparatus to keep us safe. And I'm proud of what he did."

The younger Bush, according to The New York Times, "seems to be embracing his inner dynast, joking about his family in speeches, pointing out relatives in his crowds, and going out of his way to speak with pride about his father's and brother's achievements." Two days before the South Carolina primary, he brought his brother to campaign, with George W. Bush stating, "If serving as president of the United States makes me part of the so-called establishment, I proudly wear that label."

Biden, in this year's campaign, has also adopted a similar strategy. Although he failed to secure Barack Obama's endorsement, Biden has made his relationship with the former president the centerpiece of his South Carolina campaign. His surrogates have repeatedly used Obama's campaign chant, "Fired up, ready to go." The former vice president frequently references the "Obama-Biden" administration in speeches and uses Obama as a battering ram against his opponents.

The results, however, could not have been more different. Bush lost to Trump in South Carolina by 25 points and quickly dropped out of the race. In contrast, Biden beat Sanders by 29 points and, buoyed by a new series of high-profile endorsements, went on to beat him in a series of other states last night.

Title: Obama Administration and House Republicans Remain Far Apart in Fiscal Cliff Negotiations

Article:

In the ongoing discussions regarding the "fiscal cliff," President Obama and his White House team seem to have drawn a clear position on the issue of tax rates for the wealthy. The only question that remains is the extent of the increase. Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner, in an interview on ABC's "This Week," stated unequivocally that "those rates are going to have to go up." He further emphasized that maintaining low tax rates in the current climate of significant threats and challenges is irresponsible for future generations.

However, the president's plan, as presented last week by Geithner, has left the two sides significantly apart. In a conversation on "Fox News Sunday," House Speaker John Boehner expressed his surprise, stating, "I was flabbergasted. I looked at him and said, 'You can't be serious.'" Boehner added, "The president's idea of negotiation is: Roll over and do what I ask."

The president's proposal seeks an additional $1.6 trillion in tax revenue over the next 10 years, including a return of the tax rate on income above $250,000 per year to 39.6 percent. In exchange, the president suggests $600 billion in cuts to Medicare and other programs. House Republicans argue that this is not sufficient, but have not publicly detailed their proposed cuts.

Geithner stated that the ball is now in the Republicans' court, and the White House appears content to wait for the Republicans to present their proposals. "They have to come to us and tell us what they think they need. What we can't do is to keep guessing," he said.

The president is also advocating for additional stimulus spending totaling $200 billion for unemployment benefits, training, and infrastructure projects. House Speaker Boehner commented that this stimulus spending would exceed the spending cuts the president was willing to propose.

Boehner also expressed skepticism over the president's proposal to remove Congress's power over the country's debt limit. "Congress is not going to give up this power," he said. "It's the only way to leverage the political process to produce more change than what it would if left alone."

The "fiscal cliff," a combination of automatic tax increases and spending cuts, is set to take effect on Jan. 1 if Congress and the White House do not reach a deficit-cutting agreement beforehand. Economists predict that the average family will face a loss of between $2,000 and $2,400 per year due to the tax increases, coupled with the $500 billion in spending cuts, could potentially push the country back into recession.

Title: Joe Biden Recounts 1960s Dormitory Incident During Ohio University Visit in 2008

Article:

In a 2008 clip resurfaced recently, Joe Biden, then the Democratic presidential nominee Barack Obama's running mate, recounted an incident from over 40 years prior when he was attending a football game between the University of Delaware and Ohio University. During his speech to supporters near Ohio University's campus, Biden joked about being arrested for mistakenly entering an all-female dormitory.

According to CNN's Wolf Blitzer, Biden made the playful admission on the "Political Ticker" program. He said he was attending a football game between his university and Ohio University, and he followed a group of women into the dormitory, which was not allowed at the time. Biden joked that the incident was only a temporary detention.

CBS News also published an article on the same day about Biden's remarks. In the article, Biden recalled wandering into the dormitory and being arrested by a police officer because men were not allowed in women's dormitories back then. Biden emphasized that he never breached the first floor and that the detention was only temporary.

The incident was also documented on a CNN Political Ticker blog, which reported that Biden's remarks were nearly identical to the CBS News report. The blog post also mentioned that Biden was visiting Ohio University to speak to supporters and that he had fond memories of the university's beautiful town.

███, a leading provider of conservative news, reported on the incident, highlighting the story's importance and relevance to readers. The article provided inside access to ███ by becoming a member.

Title: U.S. Attorney General Nominee Loretta Lynch Discusses Immigration and Law Enforcement during Senate Confirmation Hearing

Article:

During a Senate confirmation hearing on January 28, 2014, U.S. Senator Jeff Sessions, a Republican from Alabama, and U.S. Attorney General nominee Loretta Lynch engaged in a discussion regarding immigration and employment rights.

Sessions questioned Lynch, stating, "In the workplace of America today when we have a high number of unemployed, we’ve had declining wages for many years, we have the lowest of Americans working, who has more right to a job in this country? A lawful immigrant who’s here, a green-card holder or a citizen, or a person who entered the country unlawfully?"

Lynch responded, "I believe that the right and the obligation to work is one that’s shared by everyone in this country regardless of how they came here. Certainly, if someone here, regardless of status, I would prefer that they be participating in the workplace than not participating in the workplace."

Sessions continued the discussion, asking, "We’re talking about rights—who has the most rights? Does a lawful American immigrant or citizen have the right to have the laws of the United States enforced so that they might be able to work, or does a person who came here unlawfully have a right to demand a job?"

Lynch countered, "Certainly, the benefits of citizenship confer greater rights on those of who are citizens than those—than those who are not."

Later in the hearing, Lynch spoke about the challenges faced by law enforcement officers and the importance of community engagement. She stated, "With respect to our brave law enforcement officers, we ask so much of them. We ask them to keep us safe. We ask them to protect us literally from ourselves, and we ask them to do it often without the resources that they need to be safe and secure themselves. Yet they still stand up every day and risk their lives for us. Many of our community residents, because of a host of factors, feel disconnected from government in general today, and when they interact with law enforcement, transfer that feeling to them as well, even if someone is there to help."

She continued, "What I have found most effective is getting people together and simply listening to their concerns, being open, helping them see that, in fact, we are all in this together and that the concerns of law enforcement, a safe society, a free society are the exact same concerns of every resident of every community there."

Title: ACLU's Temporary Tweet on Catcalling Ban Sparks Controversy

Article:

On Friday, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) appeared to advocate for a ban on catcalling, a move that would potentially infringe upon the First Amendment rights. However, the tweet was swiftly deleted, but a screenshot of the post remains.

A U.S. ban on catcalling, defined as street harassment of women, would likely conflict with the First Amendment, unless the law is narrowly tailored to prohibit severe, pervasive, objectively offensive conduct or threatening behavior. Even then, the Supreme Court might strike it down, as seen in the Snyder v. Phelps case.

The ACLU's call for a catcalling ban could be seen as a significant blow to civil liberties and may undermine other important goals, such as criminal justice reform. In the U.S., the government would disproportionately arrest poor people, immigrants, and people of color for catcalling.

It is important to note that a single tweet does not necessarily indicate a broad shift in the ACLU's thinking. Most likely, this was the action of a social media editor. The author expresses surprise that such a person, who seems to be unclear about the ACLU's core values, would manage the ACLU's Twitter feed.

The author previously expressed concern that the American Civil Liberties Union may be wavering on its unwavering commitment to free speech. This concern seems to be confirmed by the stray tweet. The author's fear is that free speech is becoming a secondary concern for the ACLU, with generic lefty social justice goals taking precedence. The notion that the organization would vehemently oppose catcalling legislation is no longer obvious to the ACLU's employees; they view it as a progressive organization, not a civil liberties organization.

Title: California Democratic Party's Shift: A Look at Dianne Feinstein's Contested Senate Bid

Article:

In a political landscape that has significantly evolved over the past three decades, the California Democratic Party has shown a marked shift in its ideological stance, as evidenced by the recent convention where incumbent Senator Dianne Feinstein failed to secure the party's endorsement for a fifth term in the U.S. Senate. Feinstein, who lost a gubernatorial race to Republican Pete Wilson in 1990 due to perceived left-leaning views, is now facing criticism from within her own party.

Feinstein, often characterized as a centrist Democrat, has a reliably left-of-center voting record. According to the American Conservative Union's most recent congressional rankings, she scored an 8, with a lifetime rating of 9.15. On the other hand, left-leaning Americans for Democratic Action gives Feinstein an 85 rating. Her ratings have varied over the years, with scores of 75 in 2015, 90 in 2014, 100 in 2013, and a 95 in 2012.

Despite this reliably left-wing voting record, Feinstein's support within the California Democratic Party has waned. This shift is attributed to the party's perceived leftward swing, with State Senator Kevin de León gaining popularity due to his harder stance against the Trump administration and his portrayal as a young, energetic leader. De León, who nearly won the endorsement, was serenaded with chants of "Your time is up! Your time is up!" at the end of Feinstein's speech during the convention.

The California Democratic Party's shift could potentially impact the state's electoral landscape, with concerns that the party's leftward swing may resonate with voters, leading to further political and economic challenges. Since the Golden State became the "Cerulean State," public-employee pensions have become a fiscal concern, taxation has increased, businesses have fled due to a hostile commercial and regulatory environment, the middle class is shrinking, the poverty rate is the nation's highest, and the state's quality of life has been ranked the worst in the nation. The state's homeless problem is a national embarrassment, its housing crisis remains unaddressed, and its public school system is failing students and parents.

If the Democratic Party's leftward swing indeed resonates with voters, California could face challenges similar to those experienced by Rust Belt states in the 1980s, with economies, prospects, and populations receding at alarming rates. This potential future is a cause for concern, as the state grapples with a myriad of pressing issues.

Title: DNC Forms Cybersecurity Advisory Board in Response to Email Leaks

Article:

The Democratic National Committee (DNC) has established a cybersecurity advisory board in response to the hack attack that led to the leak of thousands of internal party emails online, according to Politico. The four-member board was announced by interim chairwoman Donna Brazile in a memo, following her appointment as DNC chief last month after the publication of stolen emails resulted in the ousting of former chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz.

In the memo, Ms. Brazile stated, "To prevent future attacks and ensure that the DNC's cybersecurity capabilities are best-in-class, I am creating a Cybersecurity Advisory Board composed of distinguished experts in the field." The board will work closely with the DNC to ensure the party is prepared for cyber threats.

The decision to form the board is a direct response to what Ms. Brazile described as an "illegal cyber attack by state-sponsored Russian hackers," according to the Wall Street Journal. Federal investigators believe the DNC was one of several entities associated with the Democratic Party to be successfully targeted by hackers widely assumed to be agents of the Russian government.

In addition to the release of emails that led to Ms. Wasserman Schultz's stepping down, other emails published by WikiLeaks last month included credit-card data and other sensitive information concerning DNC staffers and their contacts. The DNC has promised to provide assistance to those affected by the data breach.

The inaugural members of the new DNC board, according to Politico, include Rand Beers, former acting secretary of the Department of Homeland Security; Nicole Wong, a former technology lawyer for Google and Twitter; Aneesh Copra, co-founder of Hunch Analytics; and Michael Sussmann, a former Justice Department cybercrime prosecutor. Ms. Wong and Mr. Copra both previously held positions as technology officers with the federal government, Politico said.

Title: Trump, Health Advisers Differ on Timeline for Easing Social Distancing Measures

Article:

President Donald Trump and two of his top public health advisers have expressed differing views on the timeline for easing social distancing measures and reopening businesses.

Trump, in a recent interview with Fox News, stated that his decision on when to adjust federal social distancing guidelines and ask businesses to reopen would be based on "a lot of facts and a lot of instincts." However, two of his health advisers, Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, and Dr. Stephen Hahn, Food and Drug Administration (FDA) commissioner, have advocated for a decision based solely on data.

In separate appearances on CNN's State of the Union and ABC's Meet the Press, both officials emphasized that their recommendations would be based on constantly changing data and were hesitant to make firm or sweeping predictions. They also challenged the notion of a single, set time when the entire country will be "ready" to resume normal life.

Dr. Fauci stated on CNN that the reopening process would depend on the severity of the outbreak in different areas and would not be a simple on-off switch. Dr. Hahn, in a separate interview, declined to set a specific date for the decision, stating that it was too early to tell if May 1 would be the appropriate time to reopen the economy.

President Trump has expressed a desire to see relaxed social distancing and businesses reopened as soon as possible. In late March, he stated that he hoped to have the economy "opened up and raring to go by Easter," a goal that both health officials and economists warned would accelerate the spread of the coronavirus and likely lead to a rapid reshuttering of the economy.

Trump has signaled his intention to create a concrete plan to see the economy functioning as normal again. He plans to announce the members of a new "opening our country task force" or "opening our country council" this week, consisting of "great business leaders, great doctors, and some governors."

Every day, ███ aims to answer your most important questions and provide information that has the power to save lives. Our mission has never been more vital than it is in this moment: to empower you through understanding. ███'s work is reaching more people than ever, but our distinctive brand of explanatory journalism takes resources—particularly during a pandemic and an economic downturn. Your financial contribution will not constitute a donation, but it will enable our staff to continue to offer free articles, videos, and podcasts at the quality and volume that this moment requires. Please consider making a contribution to ███ today.

Title: Senate Republican Estimates Potential Cost of Legalizing Illegal Immigrants in Billions, Rubio Disputes Numbers

Article:

Senate Republican staffers have estimated that the annual cost to taxpayers of legalizing illegal immigrants could be in the billions, if they use their status to apply for federal benefits from Medicaid and ObamaCare. This claim, however, was challenged by Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, a key Republican engaged in immigration bill talks.

Responding to an emerging immigration proposal that includes a path to citizenship for millions of illegal immigrants, Republicans on the Senate Budget Committee estimated that the cost could total up to $40 billion in 2022, "just for Medicaid and ObamaCare." The estimates were crunched by budget committee Republican staff.

Alex Conant, spokesman for Sen. Rubio, disputed the numbers, stating in a late Thursday statement that it's not possible to provide cost estimates since a legislative proposal has not yet been introduced. Conant added that Rubio is concerned about the "potential fiscal impact" of the bill and will request an "in-depth" budget analysis.

Rubio, a key member of the "Gang of Eight" drafting a proposal, has stressed that he would ensure there are limits on benefits being applied to these individuals. In January, he told a news outlet that the first phase for them would be to get a nonimmigrant visa—not a green card—and "you don't qualify for any federal benefits under that." Their eligibility, though, would change once they get a green card.

Sen. Jeff Sessions' office voiced concern Thursday that a law—which dates back a century and was renewed by Congress in 1996—meant to prevent immigrants from taking root in the U.S. only to live on the government dole would not be applied here. The office claimed that nothing in the current plan would apply to those already in the country before they are granted legal status.

The Department of Homeland Security recently reported that the "public charge" standard, which is supposed to turn away those immigrants who are likely to become a "public charge," is not aggressively enforced. The department found just one case for most of fiscal 2012 where the claim was leveled at an immigrant, but the charge was later withdrawn. The department blamed "data entry quality" for not having complete information on how many immigrants became public charges.

Despite widespread reports and speculation about the immigration bill being drafted, a bill has not yet been introduced. Senators are working out the details in hopes of bringing it before Congress in the coming weeks.

Title: Hillary Clinton Positions Herself as Liberal Democratic Front-Runner, Moves Left on Key Issues

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton is pursuing a liberal platform in her bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, aiming to capture the young and diverse coalition that propelled President Barack Obama's victories in 2008 and 2012, according to a report by The Washington Post.

Clinton's campaign has strategically positioned her to the left on various issues, including gay marriage, immigration, and climate change, among others. This shift, as stated by Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta, is not about finding an ideal ideological position but rather addressing the challenges faced by American people and families.

Clinton's advisers believe that her stance on issues such as paid family leave, a higher minimum wage, and more affordable college will resonate with the public, while minimizing concerns about her hawkish foreign policy views. She has also taken liberal positions on climate change, abortion rights, and economic inequality.

By adopting such positions, Clinton's advisers aim to avoid a significant challenge from the left while garnering support through the general election. According to The Washington Post, conservative America Rising PAC director Colin Reed wrote in a position paper that Clinton's positioning could backfire, reinforcing her worst attributes as a candidate and hurting her image among voters of all stripes.

Political strategists have expressed mixed opinions about Clinton's ability to replicate Obama's coalition, particularly among nonwhite voters. However, they predict that her positions will draw strong support. Neera Tanden, president of the liberal Center for American Progress and a longtime Clinton confidant, told The Washington Post that the Democrats have a strategic advantage due to the shorter distance between their base and the middle compared to the Republicans.

Clinton has not yet taken positions on the Keystone XL pipeline or Obama's free trade deal, according to The Washington Post. Her advisers predict that her silence on these issues will not harm her standing, the report said.

Title: Democrats Argue for Nationwide Subsidies in Affordable Care Act Case

Article:

Congressional Democrats involved in drafting the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, have stated their intention for consumers in all states to be eligible for subsidies. In a brief filed with the Supreme Court on Wednesday, they argued that excluding some states would contradict the law's purpose of making health insurance affordable for all Americans.

The case, known as King v. Burwell, could potentially undermine the economic assumptions that the law relies on. The court case rests on language in the law that states subsidies will be paid to those in exchanges "established by the state."

Opponents argue that this language means the federal exchange, which covers the two-thirds of states that refused to set up their own exchanges, are not eligible for subsidies. They claim that Congress intended to use the subsidies as an incentive for states to set up exchanges rather than leaving the job to federal officials.

However, the Democratic lawmakers who wrote and passed the law argue that this interpretation is "so weak" and that they never intended to draw such a distinction. They contend that the law grants subsidies to "applicable taxpayers" and defines them by income, not by geography.

Part of the problem Democrats face is the convoluted way the law was passed. Senate Democrats forced their bill through on Christmas Eve in 2009, expecting to work out differences with the House, which passed a different bill. However, the victory of Scott Brown in a special Senate election in Massachusetts cost Democrats their filibuster-proof majority, and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi had to resort to using budget gimmicks to force the bill through exactly as it passed the Senate.

Opponents have pointed to former Senator Ben Nelson, a Democrat who was one of the key final votes to get the bill through the Senate in that Christmas Eve vote and who insisted that states be able to set up their own exchanges. They argue that the subsidies were created as an incentive to get states to set up exchanges.

However, Senator Nelson wrote a letter dated Tuesday stating, "I always believed that tax credits should be available in all 50 states regardless of who built the exchange, and the final law also reflects that belief as well."

Title: Swing Votes on Kavanaugh Nomination Appear to Have Made Up Their Minds

Article:

As of Friday afternoon, all five senators considered to be swing votes in the confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court have indicated their voting intentions. The latest developments suggest that Kavanaugh's nomination will likely pass in the Senate, given the Republicans' razor-thin 51-49 majority.

The focus was on Republican Sens. Jeff Flake, Lisa Murkowski, and Susan Collins, as well as Democratic Sens. Heidi Heitkamp and Joe Manchin. Their collective votes would be crucial in determining whether Kavanaugh is ultimately confirmed.

By Friday, all five senators have now expressed their voting intentions. Heitkamp and Murkowski are expected to vote against Kavanaugh, while Flake, Collins, and Manchin have signaled their support.

Sen. Susan Collins announced on Friday that she will be voting in favor of Kavanaugh. She had hinted at her decision on Thursday, expressing confidence in the FBI report on sexual misconduct allegations against Kavanaugh. Collins stated that she would personally review the FBI report, but as of Friday afternoon, she had not yet finished going through all the materials.

Sen. Jeff Flake also indicated his intention to vote in support of Kavanaugh, unless circumstances change before the floor vote. Flake echoed Collins in his reaction to the FBI report, stating that it was thorough but did not contain new corroborative information. Flake was at the forefront of calls for a one-week delay on a Kavanaugh vote, which would allow the FBI to conduct an investigation. He voted in favor of limiting debate on the nomination and advancing Kavanaugh to a floor vote on Friday.

In a surprising turn, Sen. Lisa Murkowski voted against limiting debate on the nomination and advancing Kavanaugh to a floor vote on Friday. This vote is likely indicative of how she ultimately plans to vote on Kavanaugh. Murkowski stated, "I believe Brett Kavanaugh is a good man, but it may be that in my view, he's not the right man for the court at this time." Previously, Murkowski had been more cautious about revealing her voting intentions, stating that she was still working on reading the entirety of the FBI report herself.

Sen. Heidi Heitkamp has not yet made a public statement regarding her voting intentions, but it is expected that she will oppose Kavanaugh's nomination. Sen. Joe Manchin has also not made a public statement, but it is expected that he will support Kavanaugh's nomination.

Title: House Republicans Question Obama Administration's Authority in Delaying Health Care Law Implementation

Article:

House Republicans are intensifying their examination of the decision to postpone a significant aspect of the health care overhaul, raising questions about the Obama administration's authority to bypass the law without Congress's approval.

Last week, the administration announced a one-year delay of a requirement that large employers offer health insurance access. Officials described the delay as a pragmatic concession to businesses who found the rules burdensome, and maintained the Treasury Department was acting within its rights.

A Treasury official told FoxNews.com that the move was an exercise of administrative authority under the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) code. The official stated that the department has "longstanding" authority to "grant transition relief when implementing new legislation" like the health care law.

A number of Republicans view the sudden change as a sign of potential issues with the comprehensive health care law. However, as lawmakers return from the holiday break, they are also challenging whether the adjustment was an abuse of power.

Rep. Phil Roe (R-Tenn.) stated, "This action raises a lot of questions about whether the Obama administration can simply ignore the law when it's convenient for them." He has requested the Congressional Research Service to "investigate" this issue, stating, "I don't think any president has the authority to pick and choose what parts of the law to follow."

The matter will be discussed on Capitol Hill later this week. Rep. Kevin Brady (R-Texas), chairman of a House Ways and Means subcommittee, has scheduled a hearing for July 10, which will, in part, examine the administration's authority to alter the law.

Rep. Darrell Issa (R-Calif.), chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, went a step further, describing the move as "another in a string of extra-legal actions taken" by the Obama administration.

The complaint about the administration's authority is just one of several concerns Republicans have regarding the delay of the mandate. They question whether further delays and changes will occur before the January 1 launch of many of the law's major provisions. They also question why the individual mandate—the requirement for individuals to purchase health insurance—was not also delayed.

However, the Treasury Department and White House, in announcing the delay last week, explained that they did so after businesses complained about the reporting requirements. As the administration works to simplify the rules, they stated, they would provide businesses more time to comply.

"We have heard concerns about the complexity of the requirements and the need for more time to implement them effectively," said Mark J. Mazur, the assistant secretary for Tax Policy at the Department of the Treasury, last week on the Treasury blog.

Title: The Navy Yard Massacre and the Sterility of the Gun Control Debate

Article:

The recent Navy Yard massacre in Washington D.C. has not rekindled the gun control debate in Congress, as the author notes, due to the impracticality of gun control measures that would have prevented the incident. The implication is that the massacre, committed with a shotgun, demonstrates the inherent limitations of the gun control debate.

Initially, erroneous reports from law enforcement led to the assumption that an AR-15, a popular rifle often used in mass shootings, was the weapon used in the attack. However, it has since been confirmed that Aaron Alexis, the perpetrator, used a shotgun during his rampage.

Media outlets, such as the Daily News, rushed to blame the AR-15 for the attack, with columnist Mike Lupica expressing outrage over the gun. Lupica's column would have been inaccurate if an AR-15 had been the murder weapon, as hundreds of thousands of them are bought annually by people with no interest in killing innocent people.

Alexis' choice of a shotgun, a weapon endorsed and promoted by Vice President Joe Biden, highlights the complexity of the gun control debate. Shotguns, like other firearms, can be dangerous, especially in permissive environments where few are armed. This undermines the belief that banning certain guns based on cosmetic features can reduce shooting rampages.

Other common solutions, such as background checks, would have had no effect on the Navy Yard massacre. Alexis bought his shotgun from a licensed dealer, passed a federal background check, and did not possess a high-capacity magazine. He may have obtained the handgun or handguns used in the attack after shooting a security officer.

The essential sterility of the gun control debate is underscored by the fact that the Navy Yard massacre, like other mass shootings, was committed by a deeply disturbed individual. The focus on gun control, the article suggests, is misguided, as it overlooks the root cause of these tragedies: mental illness.

The article calls for a shift in the debate towards addressing mental illness, arguing that the current simplistic approach is akin to focusing on tinfoil hats to prevent radio wave-induced madness. The author suggests that if we had the same callous disregard for people suffering from Alzheimer's, they would be left to fend for themselves.

The article concludes by stating that there will be another Aaron Alexis, and that the mental state of the perpetrator, rather than the gun used, is the common thread in these tragedies. The article calls for a more nuanced approach to mental illness, emphasizing the need for easier access to treatment for the mentally ill to potentially reduce the occurrence of such incidents.

Title: U.S. Weighs Response as Intelligence Suggests Syrian President Assad Used Chemical Weapons

Article:

The White House is considering various options for direct action against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad following intelligence suggesting the use of chemical weapons in Syria's civil war. President Barack Obama has previously warned that such actions would constitute a "red line" and a "game changer."

In a letter to Congress on Thursday, the U.S. administration stated that U.S. intelligence officials believe, with varying degrees of confidence, that al-Assad has used the nerve agent sarin, based on the results of "physiological samples." However, the administration did not immediately move towards military action, instead calling for a "comprehensive United Nations investigation" and the need to "establish all the facts" before deciding on a course of action.

A White House official stated that "all options are on the table in terms of our response," but declined to "get into hypotheticals at this juncture." The official emphasized the need for a "strong, firm, evidentiary basis to inform the way we consult our friends and allies."

The official also referenced the run-up to the invasion of Iraq as a reason for caution, stating, "Given our own history of intelligence assessments, especially given intelligence assessments related to weapons of mass destruction, it's very important we are presenting the public with information that is airtight, presented in a public and credible fashion."

Skepticism in Washington has arisen over the potential delay in action, with concerns that inaction or slow action might not only embarrass the U.S. for backing away from earlier rhetoric, but also lead to further atrocities by al-Assad.

House Speaker John Boehner expressed concern, stating, "I am deeply concerned with reports that further confirmation of use may be outsourced to the United Nations." He added, "If Assad sees any equivocation on the red line, it will embolden his regime."

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, shared similar concerns, stating, "The'red line' has clearly been crossed, and 'action must be taken to prevent larger scale use.'"

House Armed Services Committee Chairman Buck McKeon, who called al-Assad's attack an "astounding violation of human rights," questioned the utility of red lines if they lack clear boundaries and meaningful consequences.

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel stated that he would be prepared to provide military options to Obama "at such time as the president requires options," but also emphasized the need for investigation and consultation with allies.

Title: Bipartisan Legislation Aims to Improve Wireless Networks in Rural America

Article:

A bipartisan bill introduced by Senators Cory Gardner (R-Colo.) and Maggie Hassan (D-N.H.) on Tuesday seeks to enhance wireless networks in underserved rural areas of America. The Advancing Innovation and Reinvigorating Widespread Access to Viable Electromagnetic Spectrum (AIRWAVES) bill aims to open up spectrum space for commercial licensed and unlicensed use, with the goal of driving down wireless costs and increasing accessibility.

The senators believe this will bring increased broadband access to rural areas, whose connectivity coverage rates and speed lag significantly compared to urban areas. In a statement, Gardner said, "This legislation offers innovative ways to avoid a spectrum crunch, pave the way for 5G service, and provide critical resources to rural America to continue rural buildout in unserved and underserved areas throughout Colorado and the country."

Currently, different bands of spectrum—ranges of radio frequencies—are used to transmit audio, video, and data by various groups. Broadcasters, for example, transmit TV signals over spectrum bands, while wireless providers use them to distribute wireless broadband.

The bill has received praise from technology trade associations, who argue it is necessary to help rural communities. In a statement, the Information Technology Industry Council’s (ITI) Vice President of Government Affairs Vince Jesaitis applauded the bill, stating it would help the rollout of 5G high-speed wireless. Similarly, Kelly Cole, Senior Vice President for Government Affairs at CTIA, a trade association representing wireless companies, echoed this sentiment.

However, some observers appreciate the bill's sentiment but call for improvements as it moves through the legislative process. Michael Calabrese, director of New America's Wireless Future Program, commended the bill but criticized its focus on a one-time auction of spectrum for wireless broadband distribution, arguing that opening other, additional underutilized bands of spectrum would be more effective.

Lawmakers and government officials in Washington, D.C., have made bridging the connectivity gap between rural and urban portions of America an increasingly large priority over the past year. Senators Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) and Shelley Moore Capito (R-W.Va.) have advocated for deploying better broadband in rural portions of their states. At the Federal Communications Commission, Chairman Ajit Pai has pushed for solutions that would make it easier for broadband companies to increase access to internet in rural areas. Many companies wouldn't otherwise have a financial incentive to create the expensive infrastructure to bring broadband to such areas.

Title: U.S. Accuses Iran of Attacking Oil Tankers in Gulf of Oman; Iran Denies Involvement

Article:

WASHINGTON – President Donald Trump stated on Friday that Iran was responsible for an attack on two oil tankers in the Gulf of Oman. "Iran did it," he said during a 50-minute interview on Fox News. "It was them that did it." He also referred to Iran as "a nation of terror."

The U.S. Navy rushed to assist the stricken vessels in the Gulf of Oman, off the coast of Iran, including one that was set ablaze Thursday by an explosion. The ships' operators offered no immediate explanation on who or what caused the damage against the Norwegian-owned MT Front Altair and the Japanese-owned Kokuka Courageous, each loaded with petroleum products. The Front Altair burned for hours, sending up a column of thick, black smoke.

The U.S. military released a video that officials say shows Iran's Revolutionary Guard removing an unexploded limpet mine from one of the oil tankers targeted near the Strait of Hormuz. The video suggests that the Islamic Republic sought to remove evidence of its involvement from the scene. Iran has denied being involved, accusing the U.S. instead of waging an "Iranophobic campaign" against it.

U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo told journalists on Thursday that the U.S. assessment of Iran's involvement was based in part on intelligence, as well as the expertise needed for the operation. It was also based on recent incidents in the region, which the U.S. also blamed on Iran, including the use of limpet mines in the Fujairah attack. U.S. oil prices could spike due to "sporadic" attacks from Iran, according to a U.S. think tank.

In Tokyo, the owner of the Kokuka Courageous said its sailors saw "flying objects" before the attack, suggesting it wasn't damaged by mines. Company president Yutaka Katada offered no evidence for his claim, which contradicts the U.S. military account. Katada also said crew members saw an Iranian naval ship nearby, but did not specify whether this was before or after the attacks.

The suspected attacks occurred at dawn Thursday about 40 kilometers (25 miles) off the southern coast of Iran. The Front Altair, loaded with the flammable hydrocarbon mixture naphtha from the United Arab Emirates, radioed for help as it caught fire. A short time later, the Kokuka Courageous, loaded with methanol from Saudi Arabia and Qatar, also called for help.

The U.S. Navy sent a destroyer, the USS Bainbridge, to assist, said Cmdr. Joshua Frey, a 5th Fleet spokesman. He described the ships as being hit in a "reported attack," without elaborating. Tensions have escalated in the Mideast as Iran appears poised to break the 2015 nuclear deal with world powers, an accord that President Donald Trump repudiated last year. In the deal, Tehran agreed to limit its enrichment of uranium in exchange for the lifting of crippling sanctions. Now, Iran is threatening to resume enriching uranium closer to weapons-grade levels if European nations don't offer it new terms to the deal by July 7. Already, Iran says it has quadrupled its production of low-enriched uranium. Meanwhile, U.S. sanctions have cut off opportunities for Iran to trade its excess uranium and heavy water abroad, putting Tehran on course to violate terms of the nuclear deal regardless.

Title: Obama and Boehner Reiterate Opposing Positions on Taxes Ahead of Fiscal Cliff Negotiations

Article:

In the aftermath of signals suggesting compromise, President Barack Obama and House Speaker John Boehner restated their contrasting positions on taxes over the weekend. The president advocated for higher taxes on the wealthy, while Boehner called for tax code reform and lower overall tax rates.

President Obama, who has invited Mr. Boehner and other congressional leaders to the White House next week to discuss ways to avoid the "fiscal cliff," a series of automatic spending cuts and tax hikes set to take effect at the end of the year, emphasized that part of the solution will involve increased taxes for individuals earning more than $250,000.

"If we're serious about reducing the deficit, we have to combine spending cuts with revenue – and that means asking the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more in taxes," the president said in his weekly Internet and radio address. "That's how we did it when Bill Clinton was president. And that's the only way we can afford to invest in education and job training and manufacturing – all the ingredients of a strong middle class and a strong economy."

The president reaffirmed his belief, expressed a day earlier, that the results of Tuesday's election, which saw the re-election of the Democratic incumbent and the addition of more Democrats to the Senate and the House, constituted a mandate for "action."

"On Tuesday, America went to the polls. And the message you sent was clear: You voted for action, not politics as usual," he said. "That's why I've invited leaders of both parties to the White House next week, so we can start to build consensus around challenges we can only solve together."

"This is even more important because at the end of this year, we face a series of deadlines that require us to make major decisions about how to pay down our deficit – decisions that will have a huge impact on the economy and the middle class, now and in the future," he said.

Part of the "fiscal cliff" facing the U.S. economy involves the scheduled expiration of the Bush tax cuts, which would result in a broad-based tax hike in 2013. The president urged Republicans to take action to prevent this scenario.

"We need a majority in Congress to listen – and they should start by making sure taxes don't go up on the 98 percent of Americans making under $250,000 a year starting January 1. This is something we all agree on," the president said.

Mr. Boehner has stated that tax increases would send the fragile American economy into a double-dip recession.

"Instead of raising tax rates on the American people and accepting the damage it will do to our economy, let's start to actually solve the problem. Let's focus on tax reform that closes special interest loopholes and lowers tax rates," the Ohio Republican said in the GOP's weekly address.

"If there was a mandate in this election, it was a mandate to work together to do what's in the best interest of our country," the Republican leader said. "And right now, what's best is getting our economy moving again and keeping it moving, so we can begin to restore our children's future."

Mr. Boehner and Republicans support extending the Bush tax cuts. The White House supports the extension for income under $250,000, but seeks higher rates for income above that level.

Title: Tulsi Gabbard Drops Defamation Lawsuit Against Hillary Clinton

Former U.S. Representative Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii) has withdrawn her defamation lawsuit against former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, according to Reuters. Gabbard filed the lawsuit in federal court in January, seeking at least $50 million for remarks Clinton made that suggested Gabbard was a "favorite" of Moscow and was being "groomed" by the Kremlin, and reportedly implied that she is a "Russian asset."

Gabbard and her campaign filed a notice of dismissal, stating they "remain certain of the action's legal merit" but they wanted to focus on the current coronavirus pandemic and "defeating Donald Trump in 2020, rather than righting the wrongs here."

The lawsuit claimed that Clinton "carelessly and recklessly impugned" Gabbard's reputation during an October podcast interview. The interview in question was one Clinton gave on the "Campaign HQ" podcast with host David Plouffe. During it, Clinton indicated that Moscow was "grooming" Gabbard for a spoiler campaign.

Clinton reportedly said, "They're also going to do third-party again. I'm not making any predictions, but I think they've got their eye on someone who's currently in the Democratic primary and are grooming her to be the third-party candidate. She's the favorite of the Russians."

When asked if she was referring to Gabbard, Clinton responded, "If the nesting doll fits." Clinton added that the attempt to get a Democrat to run third party would happen only if the Russians did not use 2016 Green Party candidate Jill Stein to accomplish the same thing.

"And that's assuming Jill Stein will give it up, which she might not because she's also a Russian asset," Clinton said. "Yeah, she's a Russian asset—I mean, totally."

Title: Planned Parenthood Under Investigation, Criticized for Double Billing Medicaid and Obamacare Navigation Services

Article:

The nation's largest abortion provider, Planned Parenthood, is currently under investigation by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) for double billing Medicaid. Additionally, the organization is receiving over $650,000 as official "Obamacare Navigators" to encourage individuals to sign up for Obamacare, a program they stand to benefit significantly from.

This revelation has sparked controversy, with some accusing Planned Parenthood of relying on a vicious cycle of questionable decisions. Students for Life of America is taking their Planned Parenthood Project to over 40 schools in 20 states, aiming to expose the organization's practices.

The most surprising finding on campuses so far has been the gratitude expressed by pro-choice students for the truth being unveiled. The crux of the issue lies in Planned Parenthood's use of taxpayer dollars to lobby for and, in some school districts, teach comprehensive sex education, which promotes promiscuity, carcinogenic contraception use, and normalizes inappropriate relationships and abortion.

Contraception methods offered by Planned Parenthood to sexually active teens and young adults have been found to be of low quality. Consumer Reports has rated Planned Parenthood condoms as the lowest quality, meaning they will fail more times to prevent pregnancy than other condoms. Furthermore, the hormonal contraception they promote has been labeled by the World Health Organization as a Type 1 Carcinogen, a category that includes cigarettes and asbestos, indicating it causes cancer.

With young people becoming sexually active, in part due to Planned Parenthood's efforts, and using defective and cancer-causing contraception, they often turn to Planned Parenthood when they contract a sexually transmitted disease (STD). Subsequently, when they become pregnant, they return to Planned Parenthood for abortion services.

Planned Parenthood performs an average of 915 abortions per day, making abortion 92% of their pregnancy services. These abortions generated revenue of $150 million last year alone. Options counseling is reportedly scarce, with former Planned Parenthood employees admitting that their "options counseling" is primarily about encouraging women to have abortions to meet mandated abortion quotas.

Planned Parenthood's primary focus, critics argue, is abortion. With the organization receiving over $542 million in taxpayer funds annually and boasting a profit exceeding $100 million, it is not surprising that they would seize the opportunity to push Obamacare on women in need. The more women enrolled in Obamacare, the more women they can charge the government and taxpayers for servicing.

Title: Young Republicans Call for Break from Intellectually Suffocating Conservative Media Bubble

Article:

A generational divide within the Republican Party is escalating after last week's election results, with younger operatives and ideologues advocating for the party to break free from a self-reinforcing media bubble that they deem intellectually stifling and self-defeating.

GOP officials have attributed their electoral losses to various factors, including shifting demographics, a poorly timed hurricane, and inadequate voter turnout systems. However, a group of Republicans under 50 believes the party's problem is more fundamental.

This media bubble, they argue, is not geographically confined but rather a self-selected media universe that reinforces their views and reflects an alternate reality. The term "Pauline Kaelism" has been invoked, referring to a famous quote by Pauline Kael, a New Yorker film critic who, in the aftermath of Richard M. Nixon's 1972 landslide, stated that she knew only one person who voted for Nixon.

Young Republicans express concern that they are the ones in this hermetically sealed bubble. Rasmussen polls are considered gospel, the Benghazi controversy is equated with Watergate, and Fox News, talk radio, and the Drudge Report are seen as political oracles.

Even after a convincing Obama win, some far-right conservatives continue to believe in mass voter fraud and the disappearance of military ballots. This denial and refusal to confront reality have been likened to a political version of "Thelma and Louise," with some conservatives preferring to drive off a cliff rather than face a reality they'd rather not acknowledge.

Technology has further solidified this conservative media bubble, with Facebook, Twitter feeds, and email inboxes replacing the old newspaper front page. Consumers now have the power to choose what they see each day and can largely shut out dissenting voices.

Trey Grayson, the former Kentucky secretary of state and the current head of Harvard's Institute of Politics, noted, "The Internet amplifies talk radio and cable news, and provides distribution for other sources like Newsmax. Then your friends, who usually agree with you, disseminate the same stories on Facebook and Twitter. And you assume that everyone agrees with you!"

Grayson further explained, "It's very striking for me living in Cambridge now. My Facebook feed, which is full of mostly conservatives from Kentucky, contains very different links to articles or topics than what I see in Cambridge. It is sort of the reverse up here. They don't understand how anyone would eat Chick-fil-A, watch college sports, or hold pro-life views."

Title: U.S. Airlifts $400 Million in Cash to Iran in January, Coinciding with Release of American Prisoners

Article:

The Obama administration secretly airlifted $400 million in cash to Iran in January, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal. The money was the first installment of a $1.7 billion settlement the administration reached with Iran to resolve a 37-year-old dispute over a failed arms deal signed just before the fall of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi in 1979.

The cash was flown into Iran on an unmarked cargo plane, with wooden pallets stacked with euros, Swiss francs, and other currency. The money was not disclosed by President Obama when he referred to the resolution of the arms dispute in January, stating, "with the nuclear deal done, prisoners released, the time was right to resolve this dispute as well."

The timing of the cash transfer and the release of the American prisoners has led to criticism and accusations of a ransom payment. White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest denied the payment was a ransom for the release of the prisoners, stating that such a move would violate U.S. policy.

Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump took to Twitter to criticize his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton, over the report. "Our incompetent Secretary of State, Hillary Clinton, was the one who started talks to give 400 million dollars, in cash, to Iran. Scandal!" Trump tweeted.

The four prisoners included two Iranian-Americans arrested by Iranian security services during Obama's first term, the detention of Jason Rezaian, The Washington Post's Tehran bureau chief, in 2014 on espionage charges, and the arrest in 2015 of a fourth Iranian-American.

The newspaper reported that U.S. and European officials would not disclose exactly when the cash-laden plane landed in Tehran, but a report by the Iranian Tasnim news agency, with close ties to the Revolutionary Guard, said it arrived at Mehrabad airport on the same day the Americans left the country.

In Washington, White House spokesman Josh Earnest defended the deal by stating, "first of all, it's Iranian money" and noting that the money had been paid into a U.S. account in 1979 as part of a deal to buy military equipment that never took place because of the overthrow of the shah. As for why cash was used in the transaction, Earnest said, "the fact of the matter is that the U.S. doesn’t have a banking relationship with Iran" due to continued concerns about Tehran's "nefarious" behavior in such areas as terrorism and human rights.

Earnest also acknowledged that "it’s possible that some of the money" has been used by Iran to support Hezbollah and the regime of President Bashar Assad in Syria.

Title: Vice Presidential Debate: Biden and Ryan Prepare for High-Stakes Showdown

Article:

With the presidential race tightening following President Obama's lackluster performance in the first debate, Vice President Joe Biden is under pressure to deliver a strong showing in Thursday's debate against Republican vice presidential nominee Paul Ryan. The vice presidential debates typically do not have a significant impact on the election's outcome, but this year could be different due to the increased stakes.

Biden, who does not have the burden of projecting a presidential demeanor, has the opportunity to be more aggressive in his approach against Ryan, a budget expert 27 years his junior. However, veering off script and appearing angry could backfire, reminding viewers of Sen. John McCain's grumpy performance in the 2008 debate against Biden.

To prepare for the prime-time clash at Centre College in Danville, Ky., Biden has spent much of the week in a hotel in Wilmington, Del., scrutinizing videos of Ryan's speeches and interviews, and holding mock debates with Rep. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) and David Axelrod, a senior adviser in the Obama campaign.

Biden's frequent gaffes on the campaign trail have provided ample material for Republicans, but the vice president has been focused on keeping his tongue in check during the debate. "I don't want to say anything in the debate that's not completely accurate," he told reporters last week.

Biden, a seasoned debate veteran who has run for president twice and delivered a strong performance against then-Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin in 2008, faces a relatively untested opponent in Ryan. Ryan, who has only participated in a debate once, during his first run for Congress 14 years ago, has spent the past week in debate preparation at a resort in the Blue Ridge Mountains, 150 miles southwest of Washington. Former Solicitor General Ted Olson played the role of Biden in the mock debates.

Four years ago, Biden approached the debate against Palin cautiously, careful not to get too rough with the newcomer to the national stage. However, after Obama's lethargic showing last week, Biden is expected to come out swinging.

"I expect the vice president to come at me like a cannonball," Ryan told reporters earlier this week. "He'll be in full attack mode, and I don't think he'll let any inconvenient facts get in his way."

During the debate, Biden is likely to focus on forcing Ryan to defend Romney's proposals on taxes and spending and seizing any opportunity to tie Romney to Ryan's Medicare plan, which includes caps on future spending and a plan to partially privatize it.

In a recent CNN poll, Obama led Romney-Ryan on Medicare, 53 percent to 44 percent. In early September, while campaigning in Ryan's home state of Wisconsin, Biden said the Romney-Ryan ticket would turn Medicare into "voucher-care." However, Ryan has not tried to run away from the Medicare issue, memorably joining his 78-year-old mother, Betty Douglas, when he delivered a speech on Medicare reform in The Villages, Fla., a large retirement community in mid-September.

During the address, Ryan accused Obama of siphoning off hundreds of billions of dollars from Medicare to pay for his 2010 health care overhaul. "Medicare should not be a piggy bank for Obamacare," he said, reassuring seniors that he is committed to protecting the Medicare guarantee for current seniors and for generations to come.

It remains to be seen how the debate will unfold, but both candidates have been preparing diligently for the high-stakes showdown.

Title: Iowa Caucuses Result in Tie for Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders

Article:

In the 2020 Iowa Democratic caucuses, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders finished in a tie, with each candidate receiving approximately 27% of the votes. This marks the second time in eight years that Clinton has underperformed in the state, following her third-place finish in the 2008 caucuses.

The Iowa caucuses, often criticized for their unpredictable and idiosyncratic nature, have once again proven to be a challenging terrain for Clinton. In 2008, her third-place finish was a harbinger of her eventual loss to then-Senator Barack Obama. This year, Sanders, who was virtually unknown to most of the country a year ago, managed to fight Clinton to a standstill, erasing any remaining traces of inevitability surrounding her campaign.

For Sanders, the results in Iowa cap a remarkable year. He has enlisted a groundswell of grassroots support and thoroughly defined the contours of the primary race. This was evident in his speech, which was entirely focused on domestic issues, mirroring the themes Sanders has embraced. In contrast, Clinton's speech made no mention of foreign policy, specifically ISIS.

The race now moves to New Hampshire, where Sanders currently holds a commanding lead. After that, the campaign heads to Nevada and South Carolina, where Clinton is way up in the polls. However, polls can change, and it seems more likely than not that Sanders will ultimately be overwhelmed by Clinton. The duration of the race, however, is expected to be longer than initially anticipated.

The reasons for Clinton's current predicament are the subject of much analysis. It is suggested that to truly understand the situation, one must look beyond the narrow confines of party politics. Sanders' success can be attributed to the influence of various social movements, such as Occupy Wall Street, Black Lives Matter, women's rights activists, climate change activists, immigrants' rights activists, and LGBT activists. These movements have pushed the boundaries, forced the scope of discourse to open up, and trickled down into the political process. There were people waiting for Bernie Sanders, and the best idea he ever had was to show up.

Title: Study Finds No Differences in Science Trust Between Liberals and Conservatives

Article:

A study titled "The Partisan Brain: How Dissonant Science Messages Lead Conservatives and Liberals to (Dis) Trust Science," to be published in The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science next month, suggests that both liberals and conservatives exhibit similar levels of distrust in science when it contradicts their political beliefs.

The research, conducted by Erik Nesbit, R. Kelly Garrett, and Kathryn Cooper from Ohio State University, examined audience reactions to both conservative-dissonant and liberal-dissonant science messages and their impact on trust in the scientific community. The study involved 1,518 adults, who were divided into three groups.

One group, identified as conservatives, was asked questions about scientific research on climate change and evolution that contradicted their political leanings. The second group, labeled as liberals, were asked similar questions on fracking and nuclear power that went against standard liberal political beliefs. The third group was asked more politically neutral questions.

According to the study, both liberals and conservatives were less likely to trust the scientific results in the groups where those results were out of sync with their own ideology. The Christian Post reported these findings, stating, "Both liberals and conservatives were less likely to trust the scientific results in the groups where those results were out of sync with their own ideology."

The Christian Post also noted that while conservatives have often been considered less likely, especially by liberals, to accept findings of science that run counter to their political prejudices, the study challenges previous research reporting that the brains of conservatives are fundamentally different and less capable of rationally processing scientific evidence.

The researchers state, "There has been deepening concern about political polarization in public attitudes toward the scientific community. The 'intrinsic thesis' attributes this polarization to psychological deficiencies among conservatives as compared to liberals." However, the study's findings "link to the larger debate about political polarization of science and implications for science communicators."

Title: Obama's Gun Control Options: Policy Proposals and Challenges

Article:

President Barack Obama's call for action following the Newtown massacre has sparked hope among anti-gun advocates, despite the president's avoidance of specific details. The White House has maintained this tactic, with Obama discussing the shootings with Vice President Joe Biden and several Cabinet secretaries, but providing no specific agenda.

Senators Mark Warner (D-Va.) and Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.), who both have high National Rifle Association ratings, have expressed openness to new gun restrictions. One of the top policy proposals circulating is an updated assault weapons ban, which Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) is reportedly working on and plans to introduce in the new Senate session. Feinstein hopes to gain Obama's support, stating, "I'd like to talk to him about his help in moving forward with this."

Speaker John Boehner has expressed sympathy for the Newtown victims but has not mentioned any legislative action. His spokesman provided no additional comment on proposed gun laws. Rep. Peter King (R-N.Y.), a supporter of an assault weapons ban, is skeptical about significant changes. "I hope I'm wrong, but I'm just being realistic," King said. "Maybe this is the incident that is going to drive common-sense regulation forward, but we've seen so much in recent years and none of them have done anything."

Obama himself acknowledged that individual government actions may be limited in preventing future gun attacks. "No single law, no set of laws, can eliminate evil from the world or prevent every senseless act of violence in our society," he said. However, he will need legislation to achieve any major action on the issue.

Dan Gross, president of the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence, stated that his organization is in regular contact with the White House and is encouraged by Obama's message. Gross believes that significant progress will require policy, and he does not believe Obama can make sufficient progress without Congress. "We're not at the point where we're talking about executive action," Gross said. "It's almost kind of limiting to think that way. I think this is a moment to do what's we've needed on this issue for a long time."

Title: New Poll Shows Divide on Healthcare for Illegal Immigrants Among Americans

Article:

A new poll by CNN has revealed a significant divide among Americans regarding the provision of government-backed healthcare to illegal immigrants. The poll, released on Monday, found that 58% of Americans oppose giving healthcare to illegal immigrants, while 38% support the idea.

The poll, which surveyed 1,001 adults, also showed that all ten Democratic candidates who participated in the second night of the debate raised their hands in support of providing healthcare to illegal immigrants when asked during the debate. The debate included Joe Biden, Sen. Bernie Sanders, Sen. Kamala Harris, and South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg.

The poll results are in line with a previous poll by NBC, which found that ten out of ten candidates raised their hands in support of covering illegal immigrants in their healthcare plans during a debate last Thursday.

The poll also revealed that Americans are skeptical of the idea of completely replacing private health insurance with a national program. Only 21% of voters support this idea, with most of those in favor of a single-payer system also wanting to allow private coverage to coexist.

The poll results come as the Democratic candidates continue to debate the merits of various healthcare proposals, with some, such as Sen. Bernie Sanders, Sen. Kamala Harris, and Elizabeth Warren, advocating for a single-payer system that would eliminate private insurance coverage for the majority of Americans. Other candidates, such as Pete Buttigieg and Kirsten Gillibrand, have also expressed support for a single-payer system, but have stated that it would not necessarily drive private insurance out of business.

The poll also found that a large majority of Americans oppose bills that would make private coverage illegal, with only about one-in-five voters in favor of such proposals. This would cancel and eliminate the plans of roughly 180 million Americans. Even among Democratic voters, a large majority oppose such a proposal.

The poll results come as the Democratic candidates continue to debate the merits of various healthcare proposals, with some advocating for a single-payer system and others advocating for a more moderate approach that allows for the coexistence of private and government-backed healthcare. The poll also revealed a significant divide among Americans on the issue of providing healthcare to illegal immigrants.

Title: Obama Calls for Replacement of Budget Cuts, Renewing Spending Debate

Article:

President Barack Obama on Tuesday called for replacing the automatic spending cuts, known as sequesters, with a combination of smaller cuts and tax increases. This renews the debate over spending that has dominated Washington for the past two years, but seemed to cool after the January deal that raised taxes across the board.

The president proposed another round of tax reform targeting the wealthy, cutting deductions and loopholes. However, he emphasized that at the very least, Congress should avert the sequester, which he described as an "avoidable self-inflicted economic wound."

Republican leaders were quick to reject the president's offer. House Speaker John A. Boehner issued a statement saying it was the president who came up with the sequester idea. He also stated that House Republicans have passed two bills to avert the sequesters, so Mr. Obama must lay out his own specific plan.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell rebuked Mr. Obama for lecturing Congress about the need to avoid the cuts he proposed. He suggested that if Democrats have ideas for smarter cuts, they should bring them up for debate. McConnell also criticized Mr. Obama for failing to submit a budget by the statutory deadline this year.

The White House first came up with the idea of the arbitrary, across-the-board spending cuts during budget talks in summer 2011 as a way to pressure Democrats and Republicans in Congress into coming up with their own spending cut plan to reduce the deficit over the next decade. However, partisan gridlock quickly took hold, and a supercommittee of lawmakers tasked with coming up with a plan to find alternative spending cuts to replace the sequester failed to reach a deal after negotiating for months.

The Pentagon has grown increasingly pessimistic about the chances of avoiding the cuts, and the branches of the military have issued memos outlining what programs and sections would be hit hardest. Washington think tanks and policy centers have warned repeatedly of the havoc that the cuts could wreak on the economy.
