The Koch brothers and other billionaires have capitalized on the Janus case to finance efforts, through emails and door-to-door canvassing, to persuade government workers, including teachers, police, firefighters, social workers, and many others, to leave their unions and cease paying union fees.

President Trump's latest Supreme Court nominee, Brett Kavanaugh, does not appear to be a supporter of workers or unions. In a 2014 opinion in a case involving a SeaWorld trainer killed by an orca whale, Kavanaugh wrote that the Labor Department was incorrect to fine SeaWorld. Dissenting in a 2-to-1 case, he suggested that the Labor Department should not regulate the safety of SeaWorld's trainers because they, like tiger tamers and bull riders, were sports and entertainment figures who accepted the risk of injury in hazardous businesses that usually regulated their own dangers.

Labor unions may benefit from President Trump's efforts to increase coal, steel, and aluminum production and from his push to renegotiate NAFTA to stimulate domestic auto production. These actions could lead to the return of tens of thousands of mining and manufacturing jobs, potentially boosting union membership, but these gains would likely be a small fraction of the losses expected from the Janus ruling. Some experts estimate that more than a million workers will leave their unions over the next few years due to the Janus ruling.

There has been some positive news for labor. A new Gallup Poll found that public approval for unions has reached its highest level in 15 years. Unions have achieved several significant victories, particularly among white-collar workers: adjunct professors at many universities have unionized, as have journalists at The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune, The New Yorker, HuffPost, and Slate, and graduate teaching assistants at Harvard, Columbia, Brandeis, and other universities. There have also been unionization gains among nurses, bus drivers, and service-sector workers in Silicon Valley.

The U.S. labor movement is already weaker than in any other major industrialized nation. Only one in 10 American workers belongs to a union, down from more than one in three in the 1950s. Despite decades of employer resistance, compounded by the Trump administration's hostility, unions are not making the gains needed to reverse their decline. If America's unions do not rebound, this is likely to result in even more income inequality, wage stagnation, and control of the levers of power by corporations and wealthy donors.

Steven Greenhouse, a labor and workplace reporter for The New York Times for 19 years, is writing a book about the history and future of the American labor movement.

Title: Bipartisan Dishonesty in Healthcare Policy: A Critique of the Obamacare Repeal and Replace Debate

Article:

The ongoing debate surrounding health-care policy, particularly the repeal and replace of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), has been marked by partisan dishonesty rather than bipartisan cooperation, according to a recent analysis. The article argues that both the Republican and Democratic parties have made false promises and misrepresented their intentions in the health-care policy arena.

For seven years, Republicans campaigned on the promise to repeal Obamacare. However, it is now clear that for many of these politicians, this pledge was a sales pitch that expired after the election. On the other hand, Democrats, who passed Obamacare, made promises such as "You can keep your plan!", "You can keep your doctor!", and "Your premiums won't go up!", which have been proven false.

The article contends that the Republican "repeal and replace" bills debated over the past six months did not actually repeal Obamacare. Instead, they kept most of its regulations intact, particularly the popular ones. The GOP did seek to repeal and reform the Medicaid expansion under Obamacare, but that is not the same as repealing Obamacare.

The article suggests that both parties are more concerned with political victories and protecting past lies than with genuinely addressing the issues at hand. For instance, President Donald Trump has shown a desire for a win, willing to sign any bill that claims to repeal Obamacare, while Democrats are determined to deny Trump the ability to claim such a victory.

The analysis concludes that the polarized, tribal climate in Washington is frustrating, as many of the debates are not about real issues but rather liars protecting past lies in the hope of making new lies seem plausible enough to continue repeating them. The Medicaid fight, while real, is the exception rather than the rule. The article calls for a more honest and fact-based approach to health-care policy-making.

Title: Majority of Democratic Voters Support Clinton's Continued Presidential Bid Despite Email Scandal, According to Poll

Article:

A new poll has revealed that a strong majority of Democratic voters believe Hillary Clinton should continue her presidential campaign, even if she is charged with a felony in connection with her private email use while serving as Secretary of State. The Rasmussen poll, released on Tuesday, found that 71% of Democratic voters support Clinton's continued candidacy under such circumstances, a view shared by only 30% of Republicans and 46% of unaffiliated voters. Overall, 50% of those polled said Clinton should keep running.

Last week, the State Department inspector general released a report criticizing Clinton's email use, finding repeated warnings about cybersecurity were ignored and staffers who expressed concerns were told "never to speak of the Secretary's personal email system again." The FBI investigation into Clinton's email practices is still ongoing.

Democratic primary rival Bernie Sanders has avoided commenting specifically on the ongoing FBI probe, but campaign manager Jeff Weaver, in a Wednesday interview, questioned whether Clinton could continue her campaign if an indictment is handed down. "That would be difficult to continue running a race," Weaver said.

The email scandal could potentially impact Clinton's general election prospects, with 40% of all voters saying they are less likely to vote for Clinton due to the email issue. However, 48% of voters said the email scandal would have no impact on their vote.

The poll also suggests that Clinton's argument that she did nothing illegal with her email use is not convincing many voters. According to the poll, 65% of voters consider it likely that Clinton broke the law with her email use, with 47% saying it's very likely.

The poll of 1,000 likely voters was conducted May 29-30 and had a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

Title: U.S. Government Expands Use of DNA Tests for Immigration Matters in Response to Court Order

Article:

The United States government, under a court order to swiftly reunite parents and children who were separated after crossing the border illegally from Mexico, has increased its reliance on DNA tests to establish paternity in immigration matters. According to government officials, DNA testing is a more expedient method of confirming parentage than relying on documents such as birth certificates.

Under the administration of President Barack Obama, DNA testing of unauthorized border-crossers was seldom used, former administration officials stated, but it was occasionally employed as a last resort to verify family connections when placing unaccompanied minors with sponsors in the United States. DNA testing is also employed to verify family ties of many refugees seeking permission for family members to join them in the United States.

The testing involves analyzing a small portion of DNA, known as "short tandem repeats," to identify inherited regions of DNA that can vary from person to person. In a declaration filed with the U.S. District Court in San Diego on Thursday, U.S. Health and Human Services official Jonathan White described the testing as a "faster but costlier method for confirming parentage than collecting and assessing documentation and anecdotal information."

The filing was made in a class-action lawsuit brought by the American Civil Liberties Union against Immigration and Customs Enforcement on behalf of parents who were separated from their children by immigration officials. The judge in that case has ordered that children under the age of 5 be reunited with their parents by Tuesday, and that all minors separated from their parents be reunited by July 26.

White stated that field teams are taking swabs from the cheeks of children and adults and sending them to a third-party laboratory for analysis. The process takes about a week, he said in the declaration, though it can take longer to complete verification.

LabCorp, one of the largest providers of DNA testing to prove parentage, stated it is not involved in the current testing of immigrant parents and children. DNA Diagnostics, another company certified for DNA testing, declined to comment on any testing authorized by the federal government.

Dave Silver, marketing director at DNA Diagnostics, said the company's tests to identify relatives can cost in the "hundreds of dollars," due in part to expenses associated with ensuring "chain of custody" for the DNA. After the company conducts a DNA test at its laboratory, a written report is generally issued to whoever purchased the test, and the collected DNA is destroyed after six months.

"DNA testing is the method of parental verification most likely to protect children from harm given the compressed time frame imposed by the court's order," White said in his declaration. The testing is just one part of the reunification process, White said. Separately, DHS assesses parental fitness and potential child endangerment.

Neither HHS nor the Department of Homeland Security responded to requests for information on the testing.

Title: 2012 Presidential Race Reaches Record Degree of Triviality, Strategists and Observers Agree

Article:

The 2012 presidential race is being described as reaching a record degree of triviality by strategists and observers, with the campaign unfolding as a grinding, joyless slog that falls short of the larger-than-life personalities and debates of previous elections.

For years, operatives, reporters, and potential nominees envisioned the 2012 presidential campaign as a titanic clash of media-swarmed combatants with big ideas about the future. However, the Republican primaries, in particular, were almost a mantra: this is the most important campaign in a generation.

Since the beginning of the cycle, 2012 has unfolded as a campaign fought hour by hour in 140-character Twitter increments and blink-and-you-miss-it cable segments. The endless flood of caustic television ads and small-ball tactics have contributed to the race's triviality.

The Obama and Romney campaigns spend all day strafing each other on Twitter, decrying the campaign's lack of serious ideas for a serious time. Yet, at most junctures when they've had the opportunity to go big, they've chosen to go small. Obama has spoken in broad strokes about his accomplishments but has not yet outlined a detailed agenda for a second term. Romney has openly declared that he will not detail his policy proposals, such as slashing the size of government, to avoid giving his opponents ammunition.

Instead, they have embraced a campaign that has been defined almost entirely by tactics and daily trench warfare, whether that's the chair of the Democratic Party labeling Romney a "job cremator" or the Romney campaign driving its campaign bus in circles around an Obama event honking the horn, in a stunt reminiscent of a third-tier frat house. Some antics satisfy their partisans but don't focus the national dialogue.

"Here's the sad part: They all believe it's a total crock but they can't abandon it," said Todd Purdum, the Vanity Fair editor and former New York Times White House reporter. "Who's going to say, in the middle of an election year, we're going to come up with a new system and here's how we're going to play, and everyone's going to come along? History's shown that's not too successful."

Purdum continued, "Both campaigns right now are in a kind of defensive crouch. They're both very tightly clenched, and I don't think either one sees any advantage in talking expansively or philosophically."

"For the first time in my memory, we have a presidential race in which neither one of these candidates really likes to campaign," added Dan Rather, the longtime national news anchor who now hosts HDNet's "Dan Rather Reports." "They're not naturals like a Ronald Reagan or a Bill Clinton. I can't remember a race in my lifetime when you had candidates in both parties who didn't really like to campaign."

The expanding and hyperactive press corps doesn't help matters, Rather said.

"You have not just a 24-hour news cycle but a deadline every nanosecond.... So much of the reporting focuses on who said what in the last five minutes and who said what in response to that," he explained, musing that the tenor of the race could change after Labor Day. "I think reporters, together with the inaccessibility of candidates, get caught up in a kind of ennui, if you will—it's probably the only French word you'll ever hear me use—and we are only in June."

Title: Vice President Biden Advocates for Amnesty, Criticized for Potential Deportation Policy Changes

Article:

Vice President Joe Biden, in a speech at Miami Dade College in South Florida, may have prematurely announced the Obama administration's plans to review and potentially alter deportation policies. During the speech, Biden, who has expressed support for granting amnesty to illegal immigrants, reportedly responded to a shout of "Stop deportations!" by saying, "We'll do that, too, kid, but let me finish my speech."

The Obama administration has faced pressure from pro-amnesty activists to unilaterally halt deportations and grant more amnesty, a notion that has been debunked by mainstream press reports from the Los Angeles Times and the New York Times. In response, the administration has reportedly initiated an administrative review of deportation laws, considering actions such as granting more forms of amnesty, not deporting illegal immigrants who have not committed major crimes, and allowing bond hearings for illegal immigrants.

Twenty-two senators recently wrote a letter to President Barack Obama, criticizing his administration for potentially nullifying the nation's immigration laws and threatening the constitutional system. The senators' letter stated, "Your actions demonstrate an astonishing disregard for the Constitution, the rule of law, and the rights of American citizens and legal residents."

In addition, Biden reportedly praised Florida for becoming the 20th state to grant in-state tuition to illegal immigrants, a move that could cost taxpayers up to $50 million. In 2012, Biden also declared his support for gay marriage before President Barack Obama had a chance to formally announce his position on the issue, a statement that reportedly led to a temporary freeze in their public appearances together.

Title: Key Figures in Trump Administration Admit to Controversial Actions in Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

In the aftermath of a trip to Ukraine, President Trump's personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, has admitted to pushing for the removal of former US Ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch due to her perceived obstruction of investigations aimed at benefiting Trump politically. This admission is consistent with a strategy employed by Trump and his associates throughout his presidency: admitting to controversial acts, despite previous denials, and relying on loyalists in Congress and conservative media to defend the actions.

In a statement to the New Yorker, Giuliani said, "I believed that I needed Yovanovitch out of the way. She was going to make the investigations difficult for everybody." This admission comes as the House of Representatives impeached Trump on Wednesday, with only one non-Democrat, Rep. Justin Amash (I-Mich.), voting for impeachment.

The admission by Giuliani, Trump, White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, and US Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland, among others, contradicts the denials made by Congressional Republicans regarding Trump's alleged abuse of power by withholding a White House meeting and military aid until Ukraine launched investigations into former Vice President Joe Biden and a conspiracy theory about a Democratic National Committee server being in Ukraine.

1. On October 3, Trump admitted to urging Ukraine to investigate Biden and his son, Hunter Biden, during a press conference on the White House lawn.
2. During an October 17 press conference, Mulvaney admitted to withholding military aid in exchange for an investigation into the DNC server, a "quid pro quo."
3. Sondland testified before the House Intelligence Committee that Trump refused to grant Zelensky a White House meeting until Zelensky announced the investigations Trump wanted.
4. Trump, during a call to Fox & Friends, admitted to seeking investigations into corruption but clarified that he was referring to his conspiracy theory about the DNC server being in Ukraine.
5. Since returning from a trip to Ukraine, Giuliani has provided new details about his efforts to force Yovanovitch's removal, claiming she obstructed justice and enabled Ukrainian collusion.

These admissions by Trump, Mulvaney, Sondland, and Giuliani do not deny the actions that Trump was impeached for ordering. They argue that the actions were justified, and the Republican-led Senate will have to decide if they agree.

Title: Trump Urges GOP Critics to Overlook Recent Remarks on Judge's Heritage

Article:

Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has urged Republicans who are critical of his recent comments regarding a judge's Mexican heritage to "get over it." In an interview on Fox News' "Hannity" program, Trump stated, "I don't care where the judge comes from or where judges come from - I just want to get a fair shake."

Trump has been criticized for his remarks about Judge Gonzalo Curiel, who is of Mexican heritage and is overseeing a case against Trump University. Trump has argued that Curiel has a conflict of interest due to his heritage and Trump's pledge to build a wall along the United States' southern border.

Many Republicans, including former 2016 GOP candidates Jeb Bush and John Kasich, have criticized Trump for these remarks. Trump acknowledged this criticism, stating, "It's a little disappointing, some of the Republicans. And in all fairness, they're some of the people that I went through war with, and I won, and there's a lot of anxiety there. There's a lot of anger."

Trump added, "They just can't come back. They can't get over it. So they have to get over it, ideally. As to whether or not they endorse me, it's okay if they don't. But they have to get over it. They shouldn't be so angry for so long."

GOP Sen. Mark Kirk, who is in a tough re-election fight this year in Illinois, also announced that Trump's comments about the judge, along with other attacks, pushed him to the point where he will not support the presumptive nominee. Kirk had previously stated he would support Trump if he was the nominee.

In a lengthy statement on Tuesday, Trump said his comments had been "misconstrued as a categorical attack against people of Mexican heritage." He added, "I do not feel that one's heritage makes them incapable of being impartial, but, based on the rulings that I have received in the Trump University civil case, I feel justified in questioning whether I am receiving a fair trial."

Title: Kellyanne Conway Found to Have Violated Federal Law Twice

Article:

The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) announced on Tuesday that Kellyanne Conway, senior counselor to the president, violated the Hatch Act in two television interviews last November and December. The OSC stated that Conway advocated against one Senate candidate and gave an implied endorsement of another candidate in the first interview, and advocated for the defeat of one Senate candidate and the election of another candidate in the second interview.

The interviews occurred during President Donald Trump's support for Judge Roy Moore in Alabama's U.S. Senate special election. Conway appeared in her official capacity as counselor to the president on both "Fox and Friends" and CNN's "New Day" and discussed why voters should support Moore over his Democratic opponent Doug Jones.

The OSC's statement reads, "Ms. Conway’s statements during the Fox & Friends and New Day interviews impermissibly mixed official government business with political views about candidates in the Alabama special election for U.S. Senate."

During her "Fox and Friends" interview, Conway said, "Doug Jones in Alabama, folks don’t be fooled, he’ll be a vote against tax cuts. He’s weak on crime, weak on borders. He’s strong on raising your taxes. He’s terrible for property owners. And Doug Jones is a doctrinaire liberal, which is why he’s not saying anything and why the media are trying to boost him."

The OSC has referred its report to President Trump, but the White House quickly disputed the OSC finding, making it unlikely Conway will face any serious discipline. The White House deputy press secretary, Hogan Gidley, said in a statement, "Kellyanne Conway did not advocate for or against the election of any particular candidate. She simply expressed the President’s obvious position that he have people in the House and Senate who support his agenda."

Rep. Elijah Cummings, the top Democrat on the House Oversight Committee, wants the president to take disciplinary action against Conway. Cummings stated, "This is not the first time that an independent government agency has recommended that the White House discipline Kellyanne Conway for breaking the law. Ms. Conway has received multiple trainings and warnings, yet she still refuses to follow basic ethics rules. The President must take swift and serious disciplinary action against Ms. Conway. Anything else sets a terrible example."

The report from the OSC claims the office gave Conway ample opportunity to respond to their report, which included a commitment from the White House counsel's office that Conway never followed through on. The report also details how Conway was briefed in some manner at least five separate times on the Hatch Act and the consequences for violating it.

The Hatch Act, which dates back to 1939, is intended "to ensure that federal programs are administered in a nonpartisan fashion, to protect federal employees from political coercion in the workplace, and to ensure that federal employees are advanced based on merit and not based on political affiliation." There are a few exceptions to the rule, including the president, vice president, and some other federal employees.

In early 2017, Conway was similarly found to have violated federal ethics rules in an appearance on "Fox and Friends" when she urged viewers to purchase items from Ivanka Trump's clothing line. No significant disciplinary action was taken as a response.

Conway is not the first Trump White House official to be found in violation of the Hatch Act. Social media director Dan Scavino was issued a warning by the OSC after writing a tweet from his personal verified account against Rep. Justin Amash, R-Mich., calling for his defeat in a primary.

Title: Arizona Senators and Representatives Divided on Family Separation Policy at U.S.-Mexico Border

Article:

Arizona Senator John McCain has condemned the Trump administration's family separation policy at the U.S.-Mexico border, marking a break within Republican ranks on the controversial issue. Three of Arizona's five GOP House members have remained silent on the matter, while all four of the state's U.S. House Democrats have criticized the policy.

U.S. Senator Jeff Flake, R-Ariz., has hinted at his dismay in questions about the policy he posed to Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen. In a tweet on June 18, McCain, R-Ariz., stated, "The administration's current family separation policy is an affront to the decency of the American people, and contrary to principles and values upon which our nation was founded. The administration has the power to rescind this policy. It should do so now."

The family separations have sparked a national outcry and have become a searing test of how far Americans are willing to go in their efforts to enforce immigration and border control. The White House has offered conflicting accounts of the policy and the reasons behind it. Officials have alternately blamed Democrats for the policy, denied its existence, or suggested it is intended as a deterrent to reduce illegal immigration.

As the administration founders, congressional Republicans have taken a wait-and-see approach, a tactic they have often employed in other high-profile spasms of controversies involving President Donald Trump. On June 18, U.S. Rep. Martha McSally, a Republican whose Tucson-based district includes part of the border with Mexico, issued a statement that suggests she does not like the separation tactics but does not find fault with the Trump administration.

U.S. Rep. Kyrsten Sinema, a Democratic opponent of McSally in the race for the state's open Senate seat, has criticized the administration's policy. U.S. Rep. Paul Gosar, R-Ariz., has pointed the blame at former President Barack Obama.

McCain and Flake are Republicans who have cast themselves as the conscience of their party as their congressional careers wind down. McCain, the 2008 GOP presidential nominee, is battling an aggressive form of brain cancer; Flake is not seeking re-election this year.

Title: Federal Judge Allows Lawsuit Alleging Trump's Alleged Emoluments Clause Violation to Proceed

Article:

A federal judge on Wednesday dismissed President Donald Trump's latest attempt to halt a lawsuit accusing him of violating the Constitution by conducting business with foreign governments. Judge Peter J. Messitte's ruling in a Maryland court allows the plaintiffs, Maryland and the District of Columbia's attorneys general, to proceed with their case.

The lawsuit, which charges that Trump has violated the Constitution's little-used emoluments clause, seeks to investigate whether foreign countries have spent money at Trump's hotel in Washington. The Justice Department and Trump's attorneys did not immediately respond to requests for comment from The Washington Post.

The Trump Organization could appeal the decision and request that Messitte deny the attorneys general access to Trump Organization employees and records until the appeal is decided. The Constitution bars federal officials from accepting emoluments from any "King, Prince, or Foreign State."

The modern interpretation of the emoluments clause has not been settled, as most presidents, unlike Trump, do not run or take part in running their businesses while in office. Trump has maintained ownership of his business empire, including more than 10 hotels and golf clubs around the world. Although Trump has said he relinquished day-to-day management of his businesses, he still owns them and can withdraw money from them at any time, according to The Washington Post.

A number of foreign governments have reportedly spent significant amounts of money at the Trump International Hotel on Pennsylvania Avenue, Washington, a few blocks from the White House. The hotel has rented out ballrooms to Kuwait and the Philippines and hosted leaders from Malaysia and Romania.

The plaintiffs may also seek access to Trump's tax returns, which he has refused to reveal, fueling speculation that the president has something to hide.

Title: University of Illinois Student Ruth George Strangled and Sexually Assaulted in Parking Garage, Suspect Arrested

Article:

Donald Thurman, a 26-year-old man, has been charged with first-degree murder and aggravated sexual assault in the death of 19-year-old Ruth George, an honor roll student at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC). According to prosecutors, Thurman strangled George after she ignored his catcalls while walking to her car in a UIC parking garage early Saturday morning.

The incident occurred when Thurman, who saw George walking to the UIC parking garage around 1:25 a.m. on Saturday, approached her and attempted to talk to her. George ignored Thurman's catcalls and efforts to engage her in conversation, and proceeded to her car. Prosecutors allege that Thurman then approached George from behind, put her in a chokehold, and dragged her from the ground before throwing her in the backseat of her car while she was unconscious.

George's family grew concerned when she did not return home and reported their concerns to UIC police. Tracing her cellphone to the parking garage, George's sisters and UIC police found her body in the backseat. She died from strangulation, according to a medical examiner.

Thurman was arrested on Sunday and is being held without bail. He was released last December after serving two years of a six-year prison sentence for armed robbery, UIC police said. During a hearing on Tuesday, Cook County prosecutors described the chilling circumstances that led to George's death.

Authorities recovered a condom and semen in the car, and surveillance camera footage showed Thurman, wearing a "distinguishable white jacket," following George into the parking garage and running away from it 35 minutes later, authorities said. On Sunday, Thurman was spotted in the area and arrested. He admitted to choking George, throwing her in the car, and sexually assaulting her when she was unconscious, but "denied having sexual intercourse with her," prosecutors said.

The University of Illinois at Chicago has not yet released a statement regarding the incident. The case is ongoing, and further details are not yet available.

Title: Highlights of the Republican National Convention in Tampa

Article:

The Republican National Convention, initially delayed by Hurricane Isaac, is set to commence in earnest this afternoon in Tampa, Florida. The following are some of the anticipated highlights from the schedule:

1. Potential Dissent: Following the Pledge of Allegiance, the National Anthem, and the invocation, there may be a floor fight over new rules concerning the selection of delegates. Supporters of Texas Representative Ron Paul are expected to voice their objections, although their efforts to change the rules are unlikely to succeed.

2. The Roll Call: In the late afternoon, delegates will officially nominate their candidates for president and vice president. The roll call is scheduled to conclude before 6:40 p.m. EST. The nominees are former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney for president and Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin for vice president.

3. Rick Santorum: The last major challenger to Romney's bid for the presidential nomination, Rick Santorum, is scheduled to address the delegates during the 7 p.m. EST hour. Santorum was a vocal advocate for conservative views during the primaries.

4. Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker: Facing a recall vote due to his efforts to restrict public union collective bargaining rights, Walker has garnered support from many within the party. He is set to speak during the 8 p.m. EST hour.

5. Former Representative Artur Davis: In 2008, Senator Joe Lieberman played the role of a former Democrat endorsing the Republican ticket. This year, that role will be filled by former Alabama Congressman Artur Davis, who is scheduled to speak during the 9 p.m. EST hour.

6. Ann Romney: Widely regarded as her husband's most effective spokesperson, Ann Romney is expected to speak about her husband during the 10 p.m. EST hour. Mitt Romney may also make an appearance in the hall.

7. New Jersey Governor Chris Christie: Known for his passionate and often humorous speeches, Christie is expected to deliver the keynote address in the hour before adjournment.

The convention is scheduled to adjourn at 11 p.m. EST, although it may run slightly over schedule if proceedings are delayed.

Title: Abortion Debate and Supreme Court Nomination Impacting Midterm Elections

Article:

The ongoing debate over the Supreme Court and its potential impact on abortion rights is gaining significant prominence, potentially influencing the midterm elections in an unpredictable manner. The issue is mobilizing both Democratic and Republican bases, creating a volatile environment for incumbents.

Democrats argue that the prospect of a Supreme Court nominee who could overturn the Roe v. Wade decision, legalizing abortion, will motivate their voters, potentially disadvantaging Republicans, particularly in the House of Representatives. Democratic pollster Celinda Lake stated, "Our biggest ally here is their own rhetoric because they’re not trying to finesse this in any way. They’re clear about their agenda."

Republicans, on the other hand, are confident that the issue will energize their grassroots, which supported President Trump in 2016 due in part to his promises on Supreme Court nominees. A Senate Republican pollster noted, "If you look at the way Trump won in 2016, a big part of that was energizing the evangelical base that didn’t turn out in 2008 and 2012."

The potential impact of the abortion debate on the midterms could be twofold. Jennifer Duffy, a senior editor at The Cook Political Report, suggests that the battle could drive up Democratic turnout in districts won by Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton in 2016. However, it could also help Republicans maintain their Senate majority.

In the Senate, Republicans are concerned that a big battle over the court and abortion could cost them seats in states like Indiana, West Virginia, North Dakota, and Missouri, and potentially Montana. Conversely, Democrats, particularly Sens. Joe Donnelly (Ind.) and Joe Manchin (W.Va.), are at risk in an abortion fight due to their states' less supportive attitudes towards abortion rights.

In West Virginia, only 35 percent of adults said abortion should be legal in all or most cases, according to a 2014 Pew Research Center poll. In Indiana, 43 percent said it should be legal, while 51 percent said it should be illegal in all or most cases.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) aims to have Trump’s pick confirmed before the midterms. If a conservative nominee wins confirmation, it could "fire up the Democratic base," according to Duffy. Conversely, if Senate Democrats seek to slow down or stop the confirmation process, it could "wake up" the Republican base in pro-Trump states, potentially helping Trump and the GOP shore up support from evangelical voters.

Abortion rights could play out differently in various states. In Montana, more than 50 percent of voters favor abortion rights, which could help Sen. Jon Tester (D-Mont.). In Nevada, a Gravis Marketing poll of registered voters found that 54 percent would oppose a ban on the ability to obtain an abortion. In Arizona, 49 percent of voters said abortion should be legal in all or most cases, according to a Pew poll.

In West Virginia, voters will also consider a state constitutional amendment declaring that "nothing in this Constitution secures or protects a right to abortion or requires the funding of abortion." In Indiana, the issue is expected to heavily influence Sen. Joe Donnelly's (D-Ind.) reelection, given Vice President Pence's involvement in vetting potential Supreme Court nominees and a meeting between Trump and Donnelly to lobby him to support the pick.

Title: Miller Affirms Commitment to CARES Act's Inspector General Provisions, Rejects Trump's Position on Presidential Supervision

Article:

In a two-hour confirmation hearing before the Senate Banking Committee, Brian D. Miller, President Trump's nominee for the Special Inspector General for Pandemic Recovery, asserted his intention to uphold the language in the $2 trillion CARES Act, which requires the new inspector general to report to Congress if impeded in his investigative work. This stance contradicts Trump's position, as expressed in a March 27 signing statement, which stated that the newly established watchdog could not be permitted or required to report to Congress without "presidential supervision."

During the hearing, Miller also indicated that he would inform Congress "immediately" if any agencies asked him to withhold information, and that he would review any effort to distribute massive sums of taxpayer money to states for political gain as a violation. The exchange marked the most critical part of the hearing, which featured numerous questions from Democrats about Miller's independence given his current role as a White House lawyer.

Miller repeatedly vowed to resist any pressure from the president or other administration officials seeking to undermine his independence. He cited his track record of battling with officials from George W. Bush's administration as a federal watchdog and vowed he wouldn't "bend" for anyone in Trump's orbit either.

However, Miller declined to discuss his role in Trump's recent dismissal of intelligence community watchdog Michael Atkinson or the president's subsequent move to sideline another watchdog, Glenn Fine, who was initially picked to oversee the government's broad coronavirus response. Miller also declined to say whether he agreed with Trump's characterization of Atkinson as a "disgrace to IGs."

The hearing became a skirmish in Congress' broader confrontation with Trump's efforts to dismantle or assert control over the independent watchdogs charged with monitoring his administration. Republicans largely backed Miller, rejecting suggestions that he might not be independent enough of the president.

Miller is the first inspector general nominee to come before the Senate since Trump began a concerted effort to remake the community of federal watchdogs and remove those he has deemed, without basis, as acting with an anti-Trump bias. Senate Democrats have raised concerns about whether a White House aide can truly exercise independence from a president determined to tighten his grip on the inspector general community.

Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), the top Democrat on the Senate Banking Committee, stated, "Looking at the last 20 years, we found only one IG candidate was nominated while serving in the White House counsel's office, another nominee served in the White House counsel's office under an earlier administration. Both of them resigned, one for politicizing the office, the other for a lack of independence. Not a great track record."

Miller and Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) sparred as she pressed him to make commitments on what might constitute potential abuses worthy of investigation. Though he initially resisted engaging in "hypotheticals," he agreed that a bailed-out corporation that lays off employees could spur an investigation, as well as companies that lobbied the White House and Congress before receiving funds.

Under questioning from Sen. Mark Warner (D-Va.), Miller said all inspectors general should be willing to face firing for providing honest information to their superiors. "You should never be afraid of stating the truth and if you have to be fired, you're fired," he said. "But you always have to be prepared, at least, to walk away from your job."

For his part, Miller, who Trump tapped as "special inspector general for pandemic response," pledged to operate free of political influence, in rooting out waste, fraud, and abuse. Miller, who is likely to be confirmed in the Republican-controlled Senate, would oversee a $500-billion fund managed by the Treasury Department and Federal Reserve meant to shore up companies and industries ravaged amid the coronavirus crisis.

"I think independence is vital for the effective operation of any inspector general," Miller said in response to questioning from the committee's chairman, Sen. Mike Crapo (R-Idaho). "I met with resistance throughout my tenure as inspector general. I conducted investigations of major contractors, much to the chagrin of leaders at the GSA...Ultimately I was proven right."

Title: Obama Assures NATO Commitment, Addresses Greece's Economic Woes and Refugee Crisis in Final Foreign Trip

Article:

President Barack Obama began his final foreign trip as president on Tuesday in Athens, Greece, emphasizing the U.S. commitment to NATO and offering support for the Greek people amid economic struggles and a refugee crisis. In a meeting with Greek President Prokopis Pavlopoulos, Obama stated that a strong NATO is of "utmost importance" and will provide "significant continuity even as we see a transition in government in the United States."

Pavlopoulos expressed gratitude for U.S. support during Greece's time of social and economic crisis and expressed confidence that President-elect Donald Trump "will continue on the same path." Trump's election has generated significant unease in Europe due to his campaign rhetoric suggesting the U.S. might withdraw from NATO if other countries do not pay more.

Obama also met with Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and offered support for the Greeks as they navigate economic woes and a massive influx of refugees. Obama pledged to continue advocating for the view that "austerity alone can not deliver prosperity" and that "it is going to be important both with respect to debt relief and other accommodative strategies to help the Greek people in this period of adjustment."

The U.S. president is making the first visit by a sitting U.S. president to Greece since Bill Clinton in 1999. Security measures were tight, with major roads closed along Obama's motorcade route, a ban on public gatherings and demonstrations in certain areas, and boats prohibited from sailing near the coastline. More than 5,000 police were deployed in Athens for the two-day visit, and left-wing and anarchist groups have planned protest demonstrations for Tuesday afternoon.

On Wednesday, Obama is scheduled to tour the Acropolis and give a major speech about democracy and globalization before flying to Berlin. From Germany, Obama will travel to Peru for an Asian economic summit before returning to Washington on Saturday. Greece's government has hailed Obama's visit as being of "huge importance" for both Greece and Europe.

Greece's left-led coalition government has been grappling with a six-year financial crisis that has devastated its economy and left more than a quarter of the workforce unemployed. The government is relying on emergency loans from three consecutive multi-billion euro bailouts from other European Union countries and the IMF since 2010. The U.S. has praised Greece's economic reforms but has stressed the need for continued austerity measures.

The government is also seeking recognition of Greece's role in Europe's refugee crisis, which saw hundreds of thousands of refugees pass through Greece from Turkey on their way to the more prosperous countries of the European north. More than 60,000 people are currently stranded in Greece, living in poor conditions in overcrowded camps. Rights organizations have urged Obama to highlight the refugees' plight and Europe's response to the crisis during his visit.

Title: Medical Guidelines and Decisions Regarding Hormone Treatment for Transgender Youth

Article:

Deciding to start estrogen or testosterone treatment for transgender youth is a significant decision, as these hormones can cause irreversible cosmetic changes such as body fat redistribution and voice changes. Medical guidelines generally recommend that such treatments should not be initiated until the age of 16, or at the earliest, 14. However, existing data suggests that access to estrogen or testosterone is associated with improved mental health for these young individuals.

Recent attention has been given to the possibility that some transgender youth may later choose to discontinue hormone treatment. A case study published by a group from Harvard Medical School reported a rare instance of an adolescent who started estrogen and later chose to stop. The young person expressed that they did not regret the trial of estrogen, as it helped them better understand their gender identity, despite experiencing cosmetic changes to their body, primarily body fat and hair distribution.

In other cases, transgender youth may "de-transition" due to societal pressure to conform to cisgender norms. While conservatives often highlight the potential for youth to regret the physical changes from estrogen or testosterone, doctors who care for these patients argue that it is far more likely that a young transgender person will have regrets when physicians refuse to provide the medical care to pause the puberty that is causing distress.

The potential benefits of providing gender-affirmative care generally outweigh the minor risks associated with treatment. These medications are administered only after thoughtful conversations between patient, family, and physician. Medical interventions are not started without all three being on board and understanding the risks and benefits. Legislation that puts these decisions in the hands of the government instead of families and physicians is dangerous.

Conservatives often use phrases like "sex change surgery" to alarm the general public. Under current medical guidelines, genital surgeries for transgender patients are never offered before adulthood. The only surgeries that are sometimes considered before the patient is an adult are the removal of breast tissue. This requires careful evaluation before proceeding. Easier access to puberty blockers in the first place could eliminate the need for this kind of surgery.

State legislators are encouraged to educate themselves about transgender youth and their medical care before introducing legislation that may harm them. They should reach out to physicians and professional medical societies for input, talk to researchers in this area, and most importantly, bring in the transgender youth themselves. If their bodies are going to be legislated, they should have the opportunity to be heard by the legislators who would do this to them. The medical profession has made it clear: This kind of legislation is dangerous and should not become law.

Dr. Jack Turban, a resident physician in child and adolescent psychiatry at the Massachusetts General Hospital, researches the mental health of transgender youth. Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook, Twitter (@NYTopinion), and Instagram.

Title: U.S. Has Evidence and Legal Justification for Syria Strike, Officials Say

Article:

The United States has both the evidence and legal justification to carry out a military strike against Syria, according to U.S. officials. The strike is aimed at deterring Syrian President Bashar al-Assad from using chemical weapons again.

A key piece of the intelligence, according to these officials, is an intercepted telephone call between Syrian military officials. One of the officials seems to suggest that the chemical weapons attack was more devastating than intended, with one intelligence official stating, "It sounds like he thinks this was a small operation that got out of control."

However, Republican lawmakers have said White House officials dismissed suggestions that the scale of the attack was a miscalculation, indicating that the officials believe Syria intended to inflict widespread damage. Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, stated, "I'm comfortable that the things the president told Assad not to do he did."

The briefing by the White House chief of staff, Denis R. McDonough, was attended by seven other Republican senators, as well as Secretary of State John Kerry, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, the director of national intelligence, James R. Clapper Jr., and the national security adviser, Susan E. Rice. The conference call was unclassified, meaning the administration provided lawmakers with limited details about the intelligence they assert bolsters the case for a military strike.

Before the call, some prominent lawmakers expressed anger that the White House was planning a strike without significant consultations with Congress. Representative Mike Rogers, the Michigan Republican who is chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, said on MSNBC, "When we take what is a very difficult decision, you have to have buy-in by members and buy-in by the public. I think both of those are critically important and, right now, none of that has happened."

Title: Trump Excludes Romney from Coronavirus Task Force, Continuing Feud with Senator

Article:

The White House has announced a list of senators invited to be part of the president's task force focused on reopening America during the coronavirus pandemic. Notably absent from the list is Republican Senator Mitt Romney, one of President Donald Trump's most vocal critics within his own party.

Trump's exclusion of Romney from the task force, dubbed the "Opening Up America Again Congressional Group," appears to be a continuation of their ongoing feud. The group is aimed at addressing strategies for reopening the economy amid the ongoing pandemic.

An official told CNN that the president personally reviewed the list of invited lawmakers before its public release on Thursday. A spokesperson for Romney confirmed to The Hill that he was not asked to participate in the task force.

The relationship between Trump and Romney dates back to Trump's presidential campaign in 2016, when Romney, then a fellow Republican, made a speech urging Americans to strategically vote to prevent Trump from winning the party's nomination. Despite a brief reconciliation, during which Trump considered Romney for a cabinet position and supported Romney's Senate bid in 2018, their relationship has since deteriorated.

Romney has continued to criticize Trump in the media, and was the only Republican senator to vote in favor of impeaching the president on charges of abuse of power earlier this year. In response, Trump has labeled Romney as a "Democrat secret asset," a "failed presidential candidate," a "Republican in name only," and "one of the dumbest and worst candidates in the history of Republican politics."

Title: Michigan Legislature to Vote on Abortion Coverage Ban, Bypassing Governor's Veto

Article:

Michigan's Republican-controlled Legislature is set to vote on a measure that would prohibit abortion coverage from all health insurance plans, requiring women to purchase a separate policy to cover the procedure. The state election board certified on Monday that anti-choice group Right to Life of Michigan collected the necessary signatures to put the measure before lawmakers, a majority of whom support the ban.

Last year, Republican Gov. Rick Snyder vetoed an identical ban on abortion coverage, stating the measure "went too far." This time, Michigan Right to Life introduced the restriction through a rarely used initiative petition, which can become law without executive action by the governor. The ban contains no exceptions for pregnancies resulting from rape or incest.

The move to bypass Snyder's veto has been criticized by reproductive health advocates, who have labeled the proposal as an attempt to force women to purchase "rape insurance." Meghan Groen, director of government relations for Planned Parenthood Advocates of Michigan, told RH Reality Check, "You couldn’t buy a rider once you were pregnant to have [an abortion] covered. It’s not like, oh, I was raped and so now I’ll buy this rider. Nobody is anticipating being a victim of crime."

Jessica Tramontana, communications director for Progress Michigan, said in a statement on the proposal, "It’s unconscionable that Right to Life has launched a campaign against women’s rights by finding a loophole in the law and skirting a signature from the governor. The president of Right to Life went as far as describing this extra insurance like buying coverage for a 'flood or a car accident.' Rape is not an accident."

The measure itself is also deceptive, as Michigan and federal law prevent taxpayer dollars from funding abortion care. However, anti-abortion activists have circulated the false idea that the Affordable Care Act will change the status quo. "There’s a lot of misinformation out there about what this actually does," Groen added.

A majority of Michigan voters appear to oppose the measure, and identical proposals have been vetoed -- twice -- by Republican governors. However, advocates say the state Legislature has taken an extreme rightward turn and may push the measure through despite the lack of support.

Title: Obama Addresses Nation on Navy Yard Shooting, Calls for Change in Gun Violence Policies

Article:

President Barack Obama delivered a speech on Sunday, addressing the shooting incident at Washington's Navy Yard that left 12 people dead and 8 wounded. The president emphasized that the United States "cannot accept" the shooting as "inevitable," but rather, it should "lead to some sort of transformation" in the nation's approach to gun violence.

Obama honored each victim, sharing personal details about their lives and the last things they said before they died. He expressed his condolences to the families of those killed, stating, "Our tears are not enough."

Twelve people were killed and eight were wounded when Aaron Alexis, a Navy contractor, entered the large naval installation in Washington and opened fire in Building 197. The victims, whose ages ranged from 46 to 73, all worked at the Navy Yard.

The issue of gun violence has been a significant focus of Obama's second term in office, with a concerted effort to strengthen gun laws following the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, in December 2012. However, the proposed changes failed to pass in the U.S. Congress, with lawmakers on Capitol Hill unable to pass any laws tightening gun restrictions.

In response to last week's shooting at Navy Yard, most gun-control advocates were resigned to the fact that not much in the way of legislative changes would be made. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a supporter of gun control, stated on Tuesday, "We don't have the votes. I'd like to get them, but we don't have them now."

Obama called for a change in the nation's approach to gun violence, stating, "I do not accept that we cannot find a common-sense way to preserve our traditions, including our basic Second Amendment freedoms and the rights of law-abiding gun owners, while at the same time reducing the gun violence that unleashes so much mayhem on a regular basis."

Throughout the speech, the president acknowledged a hesitance in Washington to fight over gun laws and stated that change would need to come because of the American people's desire for it. He concluded, "If we really want to honor these 12 men and women, if we really want to be a country where we can go to work and go to school and walk our streets free from senseless violence without so many lives being stolen by a bullet from a gun, then we're going to have to change. We're going to have to change."

Washington, D.C., Mayor Vincent Gray joined Obama on Sunday in calling for tighter gun laws in response to the shooting, stating, "Our country is drowning in a sea of guns." In taking the stage, Obama was stepping into a role he has become very familiar with, counselor-in-chief, and Sunday's remarks were reminiscent, in some ways, of past speeches he has given at memorial services for mass shootings.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Email Scandal and Polling Numbers in Swing States

Article:

Last week was a challenging one for Hillary Clinton, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee. A Q-poll of voters in the swing states of Colorado, Virginia, and Iowa showed her with substantial unfavorable margins on trust, empathy, and overall favorability. A new NBC/WSJ survey corroborates Quinnipiac's findings, measuring Mrs. Clinton's ratings approximately 20 points underwater in two early battleground states.

Chuck Todd, host of Meet the Press, described the numbers as "dismal" and "troubling" for the Clinton campaign during yesterday's program. According to Todd, Clinton's favorability ratings stand at 37/56 in Iowa and 37/57 in New Hampshire.

On Friday, it was reported that two Inspectors General have requested a Department of Justice (DOJ) investigation into Hillary Clinton's improper email server and usage. MSNBC tastemaker Mark Halperin described this development as a "disaster" for her campaign if a criminal probe moves forward.

In response to the New York Times' reporting, the Clinton campaign has been engaging in what some perceive as "highly Clintonian parsing." It remains unclear whether the IG referrals to the DOJ were explicitly criminal in nature or if that determination has not yet been made. The investigation may focus on those responsible for Clinton's emails, not necessarily Clinton herself.

It is worth noting that Hillary Clinton ordered the (scandalously under-secured) server to be set up in the first place, misused it, and then ordered its contents culled prior to putting on a belated smoke-and-mirrors show of "complying" with records-keeping requirements.

Gabriel Malor, a political commentator, provided a quick Twitter primer on the implications of Clinton's classified "spillage" problem. Aside from her lying about it, which is hardly unusual for her, key takeaways include:

1. Any government employee with a 10% spillage rate would be fired immediately and face a difficult search for other spills.
2. Clinton email situation referred to FBI counterintelligence for investigation.
3. IG review: Clinton sent classified material.

Clinton has been ignoring her problems and playing the woman card, as she is wont to do in times of distress. For instance, she mentioned "those guys on the other side" and then said, "They're all guys, btw. Oh, there's one woman." She then paused and said, "Oh, I forgot about that."

With Team Hillary's 'deflect, deny, distract' machine in full swing, Wall Street Journal reporter Byron Tau is trying to focus people's attention on two core facts:

1. Exactly. Frustrated by stonewalling, two IGs referred the matter of Hillary Clinton's improper email usage to the DOJ for an investigation, which evidently involves the FBI's counterintelligence division.
2. In direct contradiction of her previous assertions, Clinton did use her private server and account(s) to share classified materials.

As it happens, Carly Fiorina, a potential Republican candidate, appears to be gaining steam with the GOP electorate, and deservedly so.

Title: Tillerson, Rubio Clash Over Russia, Cuba, and Saudi Arabia at Senate Confirmation Hearing

Article:

Secretary of State nominee Rex Tillerson and Sen. Marco Rubio engaged in a series of contentious exchanges during a Senate Foreign Relations Committee confirmation hearing on Wednesday. The discussions centered on policy regarding Russia, Cuba, Saudi Arabia, and the Philippines.

Sen. Rubio (R-Fla.) cross-examined Tillerson, pressing him on his stance towards Russia, Cuba, and Saudi Arabia. In response to Rubio's questioning, Tillerson emphasized his deliberative approach and sought to allay any concerns Rubio may have had.

During the exchanges, Rubio attempted to get Tillerson to label Russian President Vladimir Putin a "war criminal" and to categorize Saudi Arabia as a "human rights violator." Tillerson, however, declined to make such declarations.

In his opening statement, Tillerson took a harder line towards Russia, describing it as a "danger" but stopping short of labeling it an "enemy" of the U.S. He also criticized Russia's annexation of Crimea, stating that it was an "illegal taking of territory that was not theirs."

Russia dominated the early proceedings of the hearing, with senators questioning Tillerson about alleged meddling in U.S. politics by the Kremlin and Tillerson's own business ties to Russia. Tillerson emphasized his loyalty to the U.S. and stated that he would serve no one's interests but those of the American people.

Tillerson also addressed other areas, taking aim at China's "illegal" building of man-made islands in the South China Sea and expressing concern over radical Islam and cyber intrusions as the "greatest and most complex threat" facing the U.S.

On Syria, Tillerson stated that the U.S. currently had too many competing goals and needed to focus on defeating ISIS before discussing who should lead the country. He also criticized the Obama administration's dual priorities of ousting President Bashar al-Assad and eradicating ISIS, stating that these priorities sometimes conflicted with each other.

Tillerson called ISIS an imminent threat but named cyber intrusions as the "gravest and most complex threat" facing the U.S. He also criticized the Obama administration, stating that the U.S. government had "stumbled" under its leadership.

One moment of levity occurred when Sen. Tim Kaine asked Tillerson about ExxonMobil's climate change policies. Tillerson responded that Kaine would need to ask current executives, to which Kaine asked if Tillerson lacked "the knowledge to answer my question or are you refusing to answer my question?"

On the topic of President-elect Donald Trump's frequent use of Twitter, Tillerson stated he would not "tell the boss how to communicate with the American people. That's going to be his choice."

The hearing took place a day after a contentious Senate session involving Attorney General nominee Sen. Jeff Sessions. Protesters, including Code Pink activists dressed as the Statue of Liberty, a man dressed in a suit made of money, and some protesters in T-Rex costumes, were present at the hearing. One early protester was ejected after she screamed "I reject you!" at Tillerson.

Title: Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump Discuss Possible Debate Ahead of California Primary

Article:

Bernie Sanders, the Vermont senator and Democratic presidential candidate, has expressed interest in debating Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, before the California primary on June 7. The discussion between the two candidates was initiated by ABC's Jimmy Kimmel during a Thursday night interview, and Trump has indicated a willingness to participate in the debate.

During the interview, Kimmel asked Sanders if he had seen Wednesday's show, where the host had posed a hypothetical debate question from Sanders' campaign to Trump. Trump jokingly asked about the payment for such an event. Sanders responded by stating that the proposed debate would provide an interesting comparison of two candidates with different worldviews.

Trump, in his response on Wednesday, expressed a desire for the proceeds of the debate to go to charity, and he reiterated this stance on Thursday. "That could happen," he said. "I've been saying that should happen anyway. If he paid a nice sum for charity, I would love to do that."

Sanders himself broached the topic of a potential debate during a Revolt TV town hall on Thursday morning in Hollywood. He stated, "I understand that yesterday on the Jimmy Kimmel show, which I'm going to be recording later today, Donald Trump has agreed to debate me. I look forward to that."

Later in the day, Sanders' campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, expressed hope that Trump would not "chicken out" after discussing the possibility of a one-on-one debate. Trump, however, stated that he would "love to debate Bernie."

Trump suggested that the debate could raise funds for women's health issues and could potentially take place in a large arena. He also mentioned that his team has been in discussions with several networks about hosting the debate.

Throughout the day, both candidates submitted questions for each other to answer on their respective shows. Trump submitted a question for Kimmel to ask Sanders about running as an independent if the Democratic primary process is perceived as rigged. Sanders responded humorously, expressing his intention to run as the Democratic nominee and expecting to win the election.

During the town hall, Sanders also commented on Hillary Clinton's statement that she is the "nominee for my party...That is already done." Sanders noted that the recent primary results do not align with Clinton's assessment and expressed optimism about his chances in the upcoming California primary.

Title: Prosecutors Allege "Brazen" Lawbreaking by Paul Manafort in Sentencing Memo

Article:

Prosecutors for special counsel Robert Mueller have stated in a sentencing memo that Paul Manafort, President Trump's former campaign chairman, acted in a "bold" manner to commit multiple crimes. Manafort is scheduled to be sentenced next month after pleading guilty in a Washington, D.C. court last year to charges of conspiracy against the United States and conspiracy to obstruct justice.

In a sentencing memo submitted to the court on Friday but made public on Saturday, prosecutors told Judge Amy Berman Jackson that Manafort "brazenly violated the law." The memo states, "Manafort chose repeatedly and knowingly to violate the law— whether the laws proscribed garden-variety crimes such as tax fraud, money laundering, obstruction of justice, and bank fraud, or more esoteric laws that he nevertheless was intimately familiar with, such as the Foreign Agents Registration Act (FARA)."

The memo further describes Manafort as demonstrating a "hardened adherence to committing crimes." It states, "His criminal actions were bold, some of which were committed while under a spotlight due to his work as the campaign chairman and, later, while he was on bail from this Court."

Manafort had initially agreed to cooperate with the Mueller investigation after pleading guilty, but the plea deal fell apart after Judge Jackson ruled earlier this month that he intentionally lied to Mueller's office, the FBI, and the grand jury in his case. The ruling meant prosecutors were no longer bound by the plea deal.

In the D.C. case, Manafort faces a maximum sentence of 10 years. In a separate case in Virginia, Manafort was found guilty on eight counts in a sprawling bank and tax fraud case. He faces up to 24 years in prison and tens of millions of dollars in possible fines for that conviction. Manafort's sentencing in the Virginia case is also scheduled for March. Prosecutors have urged Judge Jackson to consider stacking his sentence in D.C. on top of his punishment in Virginia. Lawyers for Manafort are due to file their sentencing recommendation in D.C. on Monday.

Separately, authorities in New York are reportedly preparing charges against Manafort for violating state tax laws and other financial crimes, according to reports by Bloomberg News and The New York Times on Friday.

Title: President Trump Denies Asking Comey to Halt Flynn Investigation

Article:

In a series of tweets on Sunday morning, President Donald Trump denied that he had ever asked former FBI Director James Comey to halt the investigation into former national security adviser Michael Flynn. Trump's tweets came in response to reports that Flynn had pleaded guilty to lying to federal investigators about his conversations during the presidential transition with the Russian ambassador to the U.S. about sanctions related to the Kremlin's election interference.

"I never asked Comey to stop investigating Flynn," Trump tweeted. "Just more Fake News covering another Comey lie!"

In June, Comey testified before Congress that Trump pressured him during an Oval Office meeting in February to end the investigation into Flynn. Trump's lawyers have disputed that account.

Flynn pleaded guilty on Friday to lying to federal investigators about his conversations during the presidential transition with the Russian ambassador to the U.S. about sanctions related to the Kremlin's election interference. He became the first person to have held a position in the Trump administration to be charged by the special counsel.

In an apparent shift on Saturday, Trump tweeted that he had to fire Flynn as national security adviser because the retired Army general lied to Vice President Pence and the FBI.

"I had to fire General Flynn because he lied to the Vice President and the FBI. He has pled guilty to those lies," Trump said in the tweet. "It is a shame because his actions during the transition were lawful. There was nothing to hide!"

Two sources familiar with that tweet told The Washington Post on Saturday that John Dowd, Trump's personal lawyer, had crafted that tweet.

After Flynn was fired, Trump said in February that "I fired him because of what he said to Mike Pence. Very simple."

Some legal experts have speculated that if Trump knew that Flynn had lied to the FBI and then asked Comey to drop the investigation, it could amount to obstruction of justice.

"This is a pretty substantial confession to essential knowledge elements of an obstruction of justice charge," Susan Hennessey, a national security fellow at the Brookings Institution, tweeted on Saturday.

Trump told NBC News in May that he was thinking of "this Russia thing" when he decided to fire Comey, who had been leading the FBI probe into Russia's election meddling.

"When I decided to just do it, I said to myself, I said 'you know, this Russia thing with Trump and Russia is a made-up story, it's an excuse by the Democrats for having lost an election that they should have won,'" Trump said.

The White House days earlier had attributed Comey's firing to his handling of the investigation into Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton's email server.

Comey himself offered a cryptic message on Saturday shortly after Trump's tweet about Flynn's firing.

Title: Trump Urges Federal Reserve for Further Rate Cuts, Citing Competitive Disadvantage

Article:

President Donald Trump on Tuesday called for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates further, following the central bank's decision to reduce rates by 50 basis points in response to the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. In a series of tweets, Trump stated, "The Federal Reserve must further ease and, most importantly, come into line with other countries/competitors. We are not playing on a level field. Not fair to USA. It is finally time for the Federal Reserve to LEAD. More easing and cutting!"

The Fed's rate cut on Tuesday brought interest rates down to a range of 0.25% to 0.50%. The move followed a news conference by Fed Chairman Jay Powell, who emphasized that the decision to cut rates was due to the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. He stated, "The magnitude and persistence of the overall effects on the economy, however, remain highly uncertain and the situation remains a fluid one."

Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin praised the central bank's move, saying, "I applaud the Fed on this move." Trump, who has often used stock market gains as a measure of his presidency, has been vocal about his desire for the Fed to lower interest rates. On Monday, he tweeted, "As usual, Jay Powell and the Federal Reserve are slow to act. Germany and others are pumping money into their economies. Other Central Banks are much more aggressive."

Trump added, "The U.S. should have, for all of the right reasons, the lowest Rate. We do not, putting us at a competitive disadvantage. We should be leading, not following!" The current Fed benchmark rate stands in a range of 1% to 1.25%.

The Fed's move to lower rates came on the same day the G-7 announced a commitment to unspecified tools to help the global economy deal with the threat of the coronavirus outbreak, and as Wall Street was in the midst of another market sell-off. The market turned in its worst performance since the financial crisis last week, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling more than 12%. It made up some of that ground on Monday, rising more than 1,200 points, for the biggest one-day point gain ever.

Later on Tuesday, Trump reiterated his disappointment in the Fed's decision, telling reporters, "The Fed is following, not leading." The exact implications of the Fed's decision and its impact on the economy remain to be seen.

Title: U.S. Commemorates 9/11 Anniversary, Reflects on Lessons Learned and Rebuilding Efforts

Article:

Eleven years have passed since the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks on the United States, and the nation continues to remember and learn from the events. In the years following, the U.S. foreign and domestic security policy has been revamped, and there have been no subsequent attacks on American soil.

President George W. Bush addressed a joint session of Congress mere days after the atrocities, delivering a message of vigilance, tolerance, and thoughtfulness. In his speech, Bush identified the perpetrators as loosely affiliated terrorist organizations known as al Qaeda. He demanded that the Taliban hand over the leaders of al Qaeda, close terrorist training camps in Afghanistan, and release foreign nationals, including American citizens, unjustly imprisoned.

Fast forward to the present day, Ground Zero in New York City has faced numerous challenges in the rebuilding process, but progress has been made in recent years. Most of the memorial site opened last year, but work continues.

Both presidential campaigns will pause their usual activities to commemorate the fallen. President Barack Obama and Republican nominee Mitt Romney will observe moments of silence, attend memorial services, and visit wounded warriors on the anniversary. President Obama will also attend a memorial service at the Pentagon, while Mitt Romney will speak to the National Guard Association Convention in Nevada.

Title: Senate Document Alleges Christopher Steele Misled FBI in Obtaining FISA Warrant

Article:

A Senate document released Tuesday evening has alleged that Christopher Steele, the author of the infamous Trump-Russia dossier, misled the FBI to secure a wiretap on a Trump campaign volunteer, Carter Page, under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA). The disclosure further tarnishes an FBI already under fire from Republicans for concealing the dossier's Democratic financing.

The controversy revolves around the FISA warrant issued by a judge on Oct. 21, 2016, to monitor Carter Page. According to the Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman, Charles E. Grassley, the document refers to Christopher Steele and suggests that the FBI believed it had corroboration for the dossier when it did not.

The discredited dossier, the referral states, was the primary piece of evidence cited by the FBI in the FISA application. Steele accused the Trump campaign of colluding with the Kremlin, with Page being implicated. All involved deny the charges.

The Senate referral, signed by Sen. Lindsey Graham, asks the Justice Department to investigate potential criminal charges against Steele. It reports that a Sept. 23, 2016, Yahoo News story reporting the same information was cited by the FBI to the judge as corroboration. However, the FBI did not have corroboration, only the dossier and a news story based on that very dossier.

Moreover, the FBI misrepresented Steele's role in the Yahoo News story to the FISC judge, stating that he did not directly provide the information to the press, when in fact he did. The FBI continued to seek 90-day wiretap renewals based on Steele's reputation, even after he misled agents.

The document also reveals that Steele wrote a memo on Oct. 19, 2016, showing that he received anti-Trump information from Clinton associates funneled through the State Department. Chairman Grassley is investigating the roles of Clinton operators Sid Blumenthal and Cody Shearer.

Rep. Devin Nunes, California Republican and chairman of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, reported Friday that the FBI never told the FISC judge that the dossier was financed by Hillary Clinton and the Democratic Party. The application has a footnote that refers only to possible political backing.

Title: Senate Confirms Vivek Murthy as U.S. Surgeon General After 17-Month Vacancy

Article:

The United States Senate confirmed Vivek Murthy as the nation's Surgeon General on Monday, ending a year-long confirmation process that began in November 2013. The vote was 51-43.

Dr. Vivek Murthy, an MD and MBA, practices and teaches at Brigham and Women's Hospital and Harvard Medical School. He co-founded a clinical trials company, an HIV education organization, and Doctors for America, formerly known as Doctors for Obama.

The National Rifle Association (NRA) was critical of Murthy's nomination, citing tweets he had written criticizing guns and the NRA. The NRA also viewed Doctors for America as being against guns. However, the group's advocacy for the Affordable Care Act, rather than its stance on gun control, was the primary concern that delayed Murthy's confirmation.

Doctors for America also supports stricter gun control laws, including background checks, mandatory safety training, and banning certain semiautomatic weapons. Murthy has stated that, if confirmed, he would target obesity, not guns. His colleagues, including Dr. Chris Lillis, the Virginia state director for Doctors for America, have defended him.

Murthy's confirmation was also delayed due to the midterm elections, as many Democrats up for reelection in red states said they would join Republicans and vote no. With Congress now in a lame-duck session, he received more support from Democrats.

Since former Surgeon General Regina M. Benjamin left the post in the summer of 2013, it has been filled on an interim basis by Rear Admiral Boris D. Lushniak. President Obama issued a statement on Murthy's confirmation, praising his qualifications and expressing confidence in his ability to promote public health and keep Americans safe.

Title: Majority of Americans Disapprove of Senate GOP's Health Care Bill, According to New Poll

Article:

A new NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll has revealed that a majority of Americans disapprove of the Senate Republican's health care bill, known as the Better Care Reconciliation Act. Only 17% of those surveyed approve of the bill, while 55% disapprove. About a quarter of respondents said they had not heard enough about the proposal to have an opinion on it.

The Senate GOP's health care plan has faced mounting defections within the Republican caucus, leading to a delay in a vote on the legislation until after Congress returns from its July Fourth recess. A Congressional Budget Office analysis released Monday found that if the bill were enacted, 22 million fewer people would have health insurance over the next decade due, in part, to the bill's rollback of Medicaid expansion.

Lee Miringoff, the director of the Marist Institute for Public Opinion, stated, "With numbers like these, it's not surprising the Republican leadership in Congress is having a difficult time building consensus."

While Democratic opposition to the bill is high, GOP support for the Senate GOP's plan is very soft. Twenty-one percent of Republicans oppose the bill, and just 35% support it. Sixty-eight percent of independents also oppose the proposed legislation.

The poll also found that while many Americans want changes to the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, they want it to be more far-reaching. A 46% plurality say they want to see the ACA do more, while just 7% want it to do less. Keeping the ACA and having it do less is essentially what GOP congressional plans are doing.

Only 17% want the 2010 bill left intact and unchanged, while a quarter of Americans want it repealed completely—including just over half of Republicans.
