If Congress does not go through with a repeal of the ACA, 37% of Americans said they would blame Republicans in Congress, while 23% would blame Democrats, and 15% would blame President Trump.

Among Republicans, Trump would not bear the brunt of the blame if Congress is unable to repeal and replace Obamacare. Just 6% would blame him, and half said they would blame congressional Democrats. Another 20% said they would blame GOP lawmakers.

The NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll surveyed 1,205 adults from June 21-25, 2017, contacted by live interviewers using a mix of landline and mobile numbers. The margin of error is ± 2.8 percentage points. A sub-sample of 995 registered voters were also surveyed, with a ± 3.1 percentage points margin of error. Questions relating to how congressional Republicans are handling the issue of health care, the plan proposed by Senate Republicans, and whom should be blamed if Congress does not repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act were fielded from June 22-25, 2017, with 939 adults and 769 registered voters. The margin of error is +/- 3.2 percentage points and +/- 3.5 percentage points, respectively.

Title: Four Strategies for Confronting the Populist Challenge in Western Politics

Article:

The political landscape in the West is currently marked by a significant divide between technocracy and populism, a fault line that does not align neatly with traditional conservative and liberal ideologies. This article explores four strategies that liberals and technocrats can employ to address the populist challenge.

1. Passive Resistance:
One approach is to wait for populism to falter on its own. Given the stigmatization of populist ideas by technocratic liberalism, it is possible that the incompetence of populist leaders will become apparent, leading to their removal from office. This strategy relies on the assumption that the populist movement's failures will serve as a lesson, discouraging future attempts at similar political movements.

2. Triangulation:
Another strategy is to adapt liberalism to accommodate some populist concerns. This approach involves compromising on certain issues to preserve democracy, such as accepting trade barriers as a result of the democratic process or slowing down the rate of immigration to maintain a core national culture.

3. Brinksmanship:
A third strategy is to assimilate the worst aspects of populism in order to counteract it. This approach involves taking extreme measures, such as ignoring democratic verdicts, delegitimizing elections, or leveraging digital platforms to control information, in the name of preserving liberalism.

4. Democratic Triangulation:
The final strategy is democratic triangulation, which involves finding common ground between liberal and populist ideologies. This strategy involves taking populist concerns seriously and addressing them in a way that preserves democratic values and promotes compromise.

Each strategy carries its own risks, and their applicability varies. For instance, the Brexit cause, initially led by a pro-EU prime minister, has faced difficulties, while populist leaders in Poland have presided over periods of economic growth and increased popularity. The success of these strategies remains to be seen, and the future of Western politics remains uncertain.

Title: Trump's Vice Presidential Pick Mike Pence Holds Opposing Views on Key Issues with Presidential Nominee Donald Trump

Article:

Donald Trump's vice presidential pick, Mike Pence, has held opposing views on trade, Russia, Iraq, and Muslims compared to the billionaire businessman. Throughout his 16-year political career, the 57-year-old Indiana governor has adhered to traditionally muscular Republican policies on foreign affairs.

Trump, however, has taken a more isolationist approach and placed less emphasis on foreign issues. The issues that he has put at the center of his campaign are largely the ones he and his running mate disagree on.

Trump made his opposition to the Iraq intervention a major theme, criticizing Democratic opponent Hillary Clinton for her 2002 vote backing the war when she was in the Senate. Pence, near the beginning of his 12-year tenure in the U.S. House, voted for the resolution authorizing the 2003 Iraq invasion as well.

Pence, who chaired the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on the Middle East, was also a prominent backer of the 2007 "surge" strategy sending more U.S. troops to the faltering effort in Iraq, telling CNN's Wolf Blitzer at the time that "the surge is working" while also defending the original decision to invade despite the absence of weapons of mass destruction.

Pence has also struck a harder line on Russia than Trump, whose authoritarian president, Vladimir Putin, the presumptive GOP presidential nominee has praised. Trump asked an audience at a California rally in May, "Wouldn't it be nice if we could get along with Russia? Wouldn't that be nice?" Pence has opted for stronger rhetoric, telling the Conservative Political Action Conference in 2015 that "A new Iron Curtain is descending down the spine of Europe as modern Russia seeks to redraw the map of Europe by force."

He added, "Putin's Russia ignores talk of sanctions, claims land and supports rebels in Ukraine with impunity." Pence has previously taken issue with some of Trump's national security proposals, calling his proposal to ban Muslim foreigners from entering the U.S. "offensive and unconstitutional" in a December tweet.

Trump has since refined the proposal, saying it would only apply to citizens from countries with connections to terrorism. Perhaps more than any other international issue, Trump has made global trade a defining aspect of his campaign -- yet Pence has taken a diametrically opposed position.

The real estate mogul has frequently called NAFTA, which regulates trade between U.S., Canada, and Mexico, "a disaster." During a Republican primary debate in February, he declared, "We are killing ourselves with trade pacts that are no good for us and no good for our workers."

Pence, in contrast, praised the role of global trade and slammed protectionism in a 2010 speech to the Detroit Economic Club. "Protectionism and closing our doors to other countries does not help us, or people in the rest of the world," he said. "We must support expanded free trade to renew American exceptionalism and create jobs."

Pence also backed free trade deals with Panama, Colombia, and South Korea while in Congress. Potentially most problematic for Trump, Pence has been a strong proponent of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a regional trade deal involving 12 countries pushed by the Obama administration.

"The Trans-Pacific Partnership is another disaster done and pushed by special interests who want to rape our country -- just a continuing rape of our country," Trump said in a speech last month in Ohio. But in a September 2014 tweet, Pence gave the deal a ringing endorsement and called for its "swift adoption."

However, the Indiana governor has found common ground with Trump on some national security issues -- especially when it comes to criticizing President Barack Obama. Like Trump, Pence has slammed Obama for reductions in the size of the American military.

"This administration has reduced our Army, now its smallest size since 1940. The Navy has fewer ships than at any time since 1916, and our Air Force has its smallest tactical fighter force in history," Pence said at the Conservative Political Action Conference.

Trump made similar statements in an April foreign policy address. "Our active-duty armed forces have shrunk from 2 million in 1991 to about 1.3 million today. The Navy has shrunk from over 500 ships to 272 ships during this same period of time. The Air Force is about one-third smaller than 1991," Trump said.

The Indiana governor has also echoed Trump's critique of the President's preferred terminology for terrorist groups. "Lecturing the American people about the crusades while refusing to call Islamic extremism by name is an abdication of leadership," Pence told CPAC.

Pence is an avid backer of the Middle Eastern ally, telling the CPAC audience, "Israel's cause is our cause" and voicing approval of the decision by then-House Speaker John Boehner to invite Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to address Congress to lobby against the Iran nuclear deal the White House was then negotiating with Tehran.

Trump has also blasted the deal, and has recently staked out an aggressively pro-Israel stance. "Israel is a very, very important ally of the United States and we are going to protect them 100%," he said last week, rebuffing an audience member's criticism of the country.

But last winter, Trump was castigated by many Republicans for declining to promise to keep Jerusalem as the undivided capital of Israel. He also said peace would depend on whether Israel is willing to make sacrifices and that he would remain "neutral" in negotiations.

Title: Romney's Transition Team Plots Modest Accomplishments for Potential Presidency, Focuses on Fiscal Reform and Economic Growth

Article:

Mitt Romney's transition team, known as the "Readiness Project," is intensifying its activities as the nominee gains ground in the polls. The team is planning a series of modest but swift accomplishments should Romney win the presidency, while taking care to avoid over-promising due to the narrow Republican majority in Congress.

The team's focus will be felt most immediately on health reform, with Romney's promise to "repeal Obamacare" likely to be tempered, even with a Republican Senate. According to one official, under a Democratic Senate, the team would aim to make changes to Obamacare through regulatory measures.

Romney's team, working out of government-issued emails and office space on C Street Southwest, is calling its opening legislative agenda a "200-day plan" rather than the traditional 100-day plan of President John F. Kennedy, due to the current political climate making it difficult to promise much in three months.

The team is not planning an ideological crusade, but rather positioning Romney as a problem solver, primarily on economic issues. One Republican official who frequently speaks with top campaign aides said Romney's presidency will be focused on removing barriers to economic growth and providing certainty to businesses on taxes and regulation.

Already, Romney aides acknowledge they have promised more than they can deliver. Talk of immigration reform in the first year, a Romney promise from the second presidential debate, has caused aides to express skepticism.

However, conservatives do expect Romney to make a few changes by executive decree in the first 48 hours if he is elected president. Among these changes are re-implementing the "Mexico City policy" that prohibits federally funded nongovernmental organizations from promoting or performing abortions and issuing waivers to states that do not wish to participate in elements of the Affordable Care Act.

One of the biggest challenges for a Romney administration, according to the aides, will be keeping conservative lawmakers happy while dealing with the nation's fiscal emergency, an issue that is likely to alienate the conservative wing of House Republicans resistant to raising revenues, despite their leaders recognizing it as a mathematical necessity.

Title: Republican Jeb Bush Aims for $100 Million in Funding for SuperPAC by June 1

Article:

Republican presidential hopeful Jeb Bush is aiming to raise $100 million for the Right to Rise SuperPAC by June 1. This fundraising goal mirrors the high-end price tag for luxury penthouses in Manhattan and the amount donated by conservative businessman David Koch and Hollywood mogul David Geffen to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

Bush has been actively fundraising since January, hosting private dinners with millionaires and billionaires. As a non-candidate, he is legally allowed to engage in heavy-lifting fundraising for the superPAC, as he has not yet declared his presidential candidacy.

The lack of a formal campaign committee allows Bush to bypass contribution limits, as he would be subject to a maximum contribution of $2,700 per donor if he were an official candidate. The superPAC, however, can accept unlimited contributions.

Another radical development is the potential for campaigns to outsource their advertising efforts to designated superPACs, a practice that is currently under speculation, particularly in Bush's campaign. While superPACs are not allowed to coordinate messages with the candidate's campaign committee, this outsourcing could blur the lines between the two entities.

Dan Backer, a conservative campaign finance lawyer, downplayed the role of superPACs, stating, "They probably have relationships with the candidates that they're ultimately going to support, but they are distinct legal entities—and very intentionally so."

However, Michael Malbin, director of the Campaign Finance Institute, expressed concern about the growing closeness between superPACs and federal candidates and elected officials. He predicted that this relationship could lead to situations where candidates solicit and extort large amounts of money from donors.

Malbin compared the current era of unlimited campaign contributions to previous periods in U.S. history when presidential candidates were able to solicit unlimited campaign cash, such as the 1890s and 1900s, the early 1970s, and the "soft money" period of the 1990s. Each of these eras closed with the enactment of new laws regulating political money.

Title: House Votes to Fund Government Through Mid-December, Conditional on Defunding ObamaCare

Article:

The U.S. House of Representatives voted on Friday to keep the government open through mid-December, but only if Congress removes funding for the Affordable Care Act, also known as ObamaCare. The current funding for the government is set to expire at the end of the month, and lawmakers must approve the stopgap bill to keep Washington functioning.

The GOP measure would fund the government through Dec. 15 at current funding levels. Representative John Culberson (R-Texas) stated on the House floor, "Today, the constitutional conservatives in the House are keeping their word to our constituents and our nation to stand true to our principles, to protect them from the most unpopular law ever passed in the history of the country- ObamaCare- that intrudes on their privacy and our most sacred right as Americans to be left alone."

The vote sets the stage for a showdown next week in the Democratic-led Senate. Realistically, the chance of the measure surviving a Senate vote is slim to none. One Senate Democrat has already announced the bill as dead on arrival and called Friday's vote a "waste of time."

Republican leaders, including House Speaker John Boehner, have argued that the Affordable Care Act is unpopular and negatively impacting businesses. Boehner stated at a noon rally on Capitol Hill, "You've got businesses all over the country who are not hiring because of the impact of this law. You've got other businesses who are reducing the hours for their employees because of this law."

The House measure would replace ObamaCare with a plan that expands tax breaks for Americans who buy their own insurance, setting the stage for a showdown with Senate Democrats that could push the government toward a partial shutdown at the end of the month. More than 140 congressional Republicans have signed on to the bill to keep the government running at existing funding levels and delay the health care law.

Democrats have vowed to oppose the bill, warning that the strategy risks a government shutdown with funding set to expire by Oct. 1. Under the proposal, Americans who purchase coverage through state-run exchanges can claim a $7,500 deduction against their income and payroll taxes, regardless of the cost of the insurance. Families could deduct $20,000. The plan also increases government funding for high-risk pools.

Internal divisions have plagued Republicans this year as they struggle to produce alternatives to the Obama plan. Legislation backed by House Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.) to increase funding for high-risk pools was pulled without a vote after some conservatives objected to improving ObamaCare at a time when they want to repeal it. Obama and Democrats frequently criticize Republicans for focusing so much attention on repeal efforts without coming up with an alternative.

As of now, it remains unclear whether the Senate will strip the health law provision from the continuing resolution, and if the House Republicans will stand firm and hold their ground in the face of potential opposition from the Senate.

Title: Facebook Announces Ban on Deepfakes with Caveats and Criticism

Article:

Facebook, a leading social media platform, announced on Monday that it will ban certain types of deepfakes - videos manipulated to make it appear as though individuals are doing or saying things they did not. This policy marks Facebook's first attempt at regulating deepfakes, but it comes with caveats.

In a blog post on Tuesday, Facebook Vice President Monika Bickert stated that the ban will not apply to "parody or satire, or video that has been edited solely to omit or change the order of words." The company's moderators will remove videos edited through artificial intelligence or machine learning "in ways that are not apparent to an average person and would likely mislead" viewers. Bickert did not elaborate on how the company would assess an average person's understanding of altered videos.

The new policy has drawn criticism, with some arguing that it would not have barred a well-known recent example of an altered video that went viral. In May, a video of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi edited to make it seem as though she were slurring her words while speaking at a public event was viewed millions of times.

Representative Jennifer Wexton, a Democrat from Virginia, criticized Facebook's policy on Twitter, stating, "Call it what you want—deepfake or cheapfake—it’s still disinformation and @ Facebook needs to do more to stop it from spreading."

Jason Kint, the CEO of Digital Content Next, a trade group that represents digital publishers, expressed concern about the speed at which viral videos spread, stating, "We're entirely at risk here in letting Facebook turn this into a censorship debate while ignoring the fact these videos only receive their velocity and reach due to Facebook's algorithm and recommendations not because they're simply allowed to exist."

Kint also criticized the timing of Facebook's announcement, noting that Bickert is scheduled to appear before a House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Wednesday.

Saniat Sohrawardi, a researcher who studies deepfakes and methods used to identify them, echoed Kint's concern about the speed with which viral videos move. Sohrawardi stated, "There are not any very reliable ways to detect the fakes yet, at least none published that would be good for open-world detection."

Sohrawardi also noted that when technology to effectively detect deepfakes is created, the fight against them will have only just begun. "If we create a good enough detector and it gets popular enough that everybody knows about it, including the attackers, they will theoretically be able to create better fakes using that machine learning," said Sohrawardi.

Title: Can the U.S. Government Quarantine Individuals Against Their Will? Due Process Requirements Explained

Article:

The question of whether the U.S. government, or state governments, can enforce quarantines against individuals' will, ostensibly for public health and safety, is a complex issue that requires an analysis of both federal and state powers. As local and regional governments derive their powers from the states in which they are located, this analysis pertains to them as well.

The fundamental premise is that freedom is the default position in a free society. The Declaration of Independence, as well as various amendments in the Bill of Rights, unambiguously reflects the view that our rights—to think, speak, publish, worship, defend ourselves, travel, own property, and be left alone—are natural to our humanity. These rights preexist the government, and their source is our humanity, not the government. The government's primary purpose, as stated in the Declaration of Independence, is to protect these rights.

Though the courts have interpreted the Constitution to possess lamentable exceptions, the framers and ratifiers arguably accepted the non-aggression principle, which declares that all aggression against persons and property, even by government, is immoral. In the case of the federal government, it is one of limited, delegated powers.

The states formed the federal government, and not the other way around. However, today, the federal government maintains power by bribing the states with cash grants, the rich with bailouts, the middle class with tax breaks, and the poor with transfer payments.

Despite this, the courts continue to recognize the concept of personal liberty in a free society. All this is background to the issue lurking beneath the headlines this week: Can the government quarantine people without proof of contagion and imminent assault? The short answer is no.

Under the Fifth Amendment, if any government—state or federal—wants to impair the life, liberty, or property of any person, it must follow due process. The substantive component asks if the impairment of liberty is proper to the government that seeks the impairment, and the procedural component asks if the impairment has come about fairly.

In a public health crisis, there are no emergency provisions or triggers in the Constitution; yet, Congress has given itself the power to regulate public health and safety under various pretexts. The pretexts exist because the nanny state urge of members of Congress to regulate is confronted by the reservation in the Tenth Amendment of health and safety to the states. Those pretexts are regulating commerce and all that affects commerce, and paying the states to do Congress' will.

Stated differently, the Supreme Court has ruled that both the federal government and the states can confine a person who has not committed a crime, or one who has but has served one's full sentence, in order to protect society from the person's intentional or uncontrollable harmful tendencies.

However, it is contrary to the plain meaning of the Constitution for Congress to give itself powers that were not delegated to it by the Constitution, but the courts have permitted this. Yet, even in the case of a lunatic who has committed a crime and served his full sentence but remains dangerous, the courts have recognized constitutional safeguards to protect his natural rights.

Now, back to our question of whether the government—state or federal—can confine persons against their will in order to protect public health. The short answer is yes, but the Constitution requires procedural due process. Thus, a government-ordered quarantine of all persons in a city block or a postal zip code or a telephone area code would be an egregious violation of due process, both substantively and procedurally.

Substantively, no government in America has the lawful power to curtail natural rights by decree. Procedurally, notwithstanding the fear of disease contagion, the states and feds may only quarantine those who are actively contagious and will infect others imminently. And it must present evidence of both at a trial at which it bears the burden of proof.

While the non-aggression principle permits offensive aggression in self-defense when an attack is imminent and certain, that is a high standard for the government to meet, as it should be. Freedom—even the freedom of a madman or a dangerously sick and contagious person—is the default position. Infringing upon it without procedural due process is always constitutionally impermissible.

The Constitution was not written for the government to right every wrong. We know that government itself causes most wrongs—the theft of property by taxation, the impairment of economic liberty by regulation, the slaughter of innocents by war, the infringement of expressive liberties by majority vote. Yet, the Constitution still mandates an exacting due process for all whom the government would restrain.

That means a trial before any quarantine, no matter the public danger, and a fair trial, not one animated by mass hysteria or government-generated fear.

Title: CFPB Student Loan Ombudsman Resigns, Cites Prioritization of Financial Companies Over Consumers

Article:

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) student loan ombudsman, Seth Frotman, has resigned, citing the agency's leadership prioritizing powerful financial companies over consumers, according to a report by National Public Radio (NPR) on Monday. In his official resignation letter, Frotman stated that the CFPB's leadership has "turned its back on young people and their financial futures."

Frotman, who served as the student loan ombudsman for the past three years, led the agency's Office for Students and Young Consumers. In this role, he evaluated thousands of complaints from student borrowers and reviewed questionable practices from private lenders, loan services, and debt collectors.

Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) tweeted that the administration's actions are "shameful." He stated, "The Trump Administration has forced another cop from the beat when it comes to protecting students from predatory #4profit colleges, loan servicers, and repayment scams."

The CFPB has reviewed over 60,000 student loan complaints and returned over $750 million to aggrieved borrowers since 2011, according to NPR. However, the office has changed under the Trump administration. For example, in August 2017, the Department of Education announced it would no longer share information with the CFPB regarding its review of federal student loans.

Frotman's resignation comes as the Department of Education continues to propose changes regarding aid meant for defrauded students. In December 2017, the Department of Education announced new rules for providing aid to students who said they were defrauded by their colleges. The new system would limit some student loan refunds by tying it to their income.

In May, The New York Times reported that the Education Department had largely dismantled a team charged with investigating abuses by for-profit colleges. Frotman's resignation letter, as reported by NPR, states, "The Bureau's current leadership folded to political pressure...and failed borrowers who depend on independent oversight to halt bad practices."

Title: Early Voting Reshapes Presidential Election Landscape in Iowa and Beyond

Article:

In Des Moines, Iowa, voters began casting their ballots on Thursday, marking the start of early voting in the state. This trend is not confined to Iowa, as waves of absentee ballots have already started arriving in mailboxes in 30 other states. The presidential election is no longer a fixed-date event, but rather an item on the fall checklist, a civic duty that is increasingly becoming part of everyday life.

The rise of early voting is changing the dynamics of how Americans elect their presidents. Candidates are no longer as focused on winning more votes on Election Day, but on executing a plan to accumulate more votes over the next 40 days. For millions of Americans, the election is becoming Election Month, with as much as 40 percent of the electorate expected to vote early this year, including voters in crucial swing states such as Ohio, Florida, Colorado, and others.

Jim Messina, the campaign manager for President Obama, has built the president's re-election strategy around the growing trend of early voting. In a close election, he stated, early voting can significantly increase the number of votes. The Obama campaign is actively encouraging early voting, with the president himself delivering speeches urging voters to start voting early.

In Iowa, Democrats have requested temporary voting locations, such as La Tapatia Tienda Mexicana, a restaurant, and Johnston Evangelical Free Church. Election officials have granted these requests, along with those for voting sites at libraries, grocery stores, and community centers.

While some people will vote in person, more will do so by mail. In Iowa, Democrats have a significant edge over Republicans in the number of absentee ballots requested statewide, but Republicans expect the numbers to level out over the next five weeks.

The proportion of people nationwide casting early ballots has increased from 23 percent in 2004 to 31 percent in 2008, according to Michael McDonald, who studies early voting at George Mason University. This year, party strategists estimate that up to 40 percent of voters will cast ballots before Nov. 6, but the proportion is far higher in many battleground states.

In Florida, North Carolina, Colorado, and Nevada, advisers to both campaigns say as many as 70 percent of ballots will be cast before Nov. 6. In Ohio, Wisconsin, and Iowa, the campaigns estimate at least 30 percent of people will vote early. Virginia and New Hampshire are the only battleground states without widespread, no-excuse early voting.

Republican officials in several states acknowledge that the Obama campaign may start with a slight advantage in early voting due to Democrats' greater familiarity with early voting. To level the playing field, the Republican secretary of state in Ohio sent absentee ballot requests to every registered voter in the state.

As the early voting period progresses, both campaigns are deploying resources to maximize turnout and find voters through exhaustive micro-targeting. The Obama campaign is using hundreds of field organizers and volunteers to "chase ballots," or return envelopes to county election offices. The Republican Party is sending a mailing to all of its voters, urging them to request an absentee ballot and vote before Election Day.

As the election approaches, the race remains tight, and both campaigns are working to secure every possible vote. The early voting trend is reshaping campaigns, with Election Day becoming Election Month for a significant portion of the electorate. The outcome of the election will depend on which campaign can most effectively execute their early voting strategy.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie Endorses Donald Trump for Presidential Race

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie has endorsed Donald Trump for the presidential race, marking a significant shift in the political landscape. The announcement was made in a press conference in Texas on Friday.

Trump, in his usual casual manner, dismissed the importance of endorsements, stating, "I could have had quite a few good ones. This was an endorsement that really meant a lot." He praised Christie as an outstanding man with an outstanding family.

The endorsement comes after a series of attacks on Trump by Christie during the Republican debates, most notably in the debate before the New Hampshire primary where he labeled Trump as a "robot." However, Christie's endorsement may not be a complete surprise, as he had been contemplating further involvement in the race after a poor showing in the New Hampshire primary.

In a joint press conference, Christie and Trump traded places at the podium, reminiscent of tag-team WWE wrestlers. Christie explained that he and his family decided to support Trump as the candidate who could provide the best leadership for America and ensure that Hillary Clinton does not come close to the White House.

Despite their past criticisms of each other, Trump and Christie have found common ground in their shared disdain for Marco Rubio, who gained media attention after the latest debate. Christie, who has not been involved in vice presidential talks yet, stated, "Turn away from the amateur acts from Washington, D.C. and turn toward a strong leader. That's who this is."

The endorsement comes amidst speculation about the two's rocky relationship in the past. In August, Christie compared Trump's campaign to that of Herman Cain and Michele Bachmann. He also stated in an interview with Greta Van Susteren that Trump doesn't have the temperament or experience for the presidency. Similarly, Trump had criticized Christie over the Bridgegate scandal.

However, today, the two appeared united, possibly motivated by their shared dislike for Rubio, who has been the focus of media attention after the latest debate. Christie, when asked about Rubio's attack lines, responded, "Desperate people do desperate things."

The endorsement marks a significant development in the presidential race, as Christie brings with him a list of donor emails and supporters, which he sold to Rubio this morning. The endorsement could potentially strengthen Trump's position in the race, as Christie's endorsement could sway undecided voters and provide Trump with a boost in the upcoming primaries.

Title: Study Reveals Political Homogeneity Among Elite College Faculty

Article:

A new study by Brooklyn College professor Mitchell Langbert, titled "Homogeneous: The Political Affiliations of Elite Liberal Arts College Faculty," has highlighted a significant political imbalance among faculty members at top-ranked liberal arts colleges in the United States. The study, published by Academic Questions, an organization fighting leftist propaganda in academia, reveals that 39 percent of the colleges in the sample have zero registered Republicans on their faculties, and 78 percent of academic departments have no Republican members or so few as to make no difference.

The study examines the political affiliation of Ph.D.-holding faculty members at 51 of the 66 top-ranked liberal arts colleges according to U.S. News & World Report. The findings show a clear dominance of Democrats among faculty members. For instance, engineering departments have 1.6 Democrats for every Republican, while chemistry and economics departments have about 5.5 Democrats for every Republican. The situation is particularly severe in anthropology departments, with a Democrat-to-Republican faculty ratio of 133-to-1, and in communications departments, with a ratio of 108-to-0.

Langbert notes that he could not find a single Republican with an exclusive appointment to fields like gender studies, Africana studies, and peace studies.

The study also reveals extreme Democrat-to-Republican faculty ratios at some of the most elite colleges. At Williams College, the ratio is 132-to-1, at Amherst College, it's 34-to-1, at Wellesley, it's 136-to-1, at Swarthmore, it's 120-to-1, and at Claremont McKenna, it's 4-to-1. Only two colleges of the top 66 on U.S. News & World Report's 2017 list have a modicum of equality in numbers between Democratic and Republican faculty members. They are the U.S. Military Academy, aka West Point, with a Democrat-to-Republican ratio of 1.3-to-1, and the U.S. Naval Academy, whose ratio is 2.3-to-1.

The study also suggests that many professors spend class time indoctrinating students with their views, which can be described as leftist, socialist, or communist. This is a cowardly act for a professor to take advantage of student immaturity by indoctrinating pupils with his opinions before the students have developed the maturity and skill to examine other opinions. It is also a dereliction of duty of college administrators and boards of trustees to permit the continuance of what some professors and students are doing in the name of higher education.

The study's findings suggest biases in college research and academic policy, where leftist political homogeneity is embedded in the college culture. The leftist bias at most of the nation's colleges is in stark contrast to the political leanings of the nation, as most Americans identify as conservative, according to a number of Pew Research Center surveys. These Americans are seeing their tax dollars and tuition dollars going to people who have contempt for their values and seek to indoctrinate their children with leftist ideas.

Title: Supreme Court Ruling on Health Care Law Defines Individual Mandate as Tax, Provides Political Victory for Obama

Article:

The Supreme Court's ruling on Thursday declared President Obama's signature health care law a constitutional tax, providing a political victory for the president as he campaigns for re-election. The decision validates the president's decision to prioritize the legislation during a time of economic turmoil in 2009, a move that contributed to the Democrats' loss of House control in 2010.

Democrats celebrated the decision, although President Obama and some others tried to downplay the political benefits. "I know there will be a lot of discussion today about the politics of all this—about who won and who lost," Mr. Obama said, adding that such talk "completely misses the point" of the law's benefits.

Republicans, on the other hand, argued that the ruling leaves in place 21 tax increases in the health care law, costing over $675 billion over the next 10 years. Of these, 12 tax hikes would affect families earning less than $250,000 per year, according to the House Ways and Means Committee.

The high court's ruling was a significant win for Mr. Obama, who has been campaigning on the health care law as a major achievement of his presidency. If the justices had overturned the law or key portions of it, Mr. Obama would have been portrayed as having wasted his term on a demonstrably failed policy.

The ruling also sparked a flurry of political activity, with both President Obama and presumptive GOP nominee Mitt Romney engaging in dueling news conferences within two hours of the decision. Mr. Romney, who has pledged to repeal the law if elected, criticized the law as "bad policy" and promised to repeal it if he is elected.

The Romney campaign reported raising about $1 million in the first three hours after the decision was announced, while the Obama campaign sent out a fundraising email to supporters before the ruling was made public. However, an Obama for America spokeswoman said later that the campaign does not give out specifics on fundraising except at filing time.

The Supreme Court's decision leaves the political landscape of the upcoming election uncertain, with both sides claiming victory and using the ruling to rally their bases. The ruling's impact on the election remains to be seen.

Title: CBO Warns of Doubling Federal Debt by 2037, Urges Bipartisan Action

Article:

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has issued a report stating that the federal debt will likely double by the middle of the next decade and reach more than twice the size of the entire U.S. economy by 2037, unless Congress takes action on taxes and spending. This is the worst fiscal outlook since a brief period during World War II, according to the nonpartisan agency.

The CBO attributes the growing debt to an aging population requiring increased spending on healthcare and higher interest payments on the debt. The federal debt held by the public will be equal to 70 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) at the end of this fiscal year, up from 40 percent at the end of 2008. By 2037, it is projected to exceed 200 percent of GDP.

The CBO's report suggests that deep deficits and debt do not have to occur. If Congress implements major tax increases and deep spending cuts already built into the law, debt would begin to shrink almost immediately. However, these tax increases and spending cuts have proven unpalatable on both sides of the aisle.

Political leaders have offered differing perspectives on the issue. House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan (R-WI) criticized the current policies, stating, "The president’s policies are not working. The sobering reality of our economic challenges require leadership and action. The president and his party’s leaders have failed on both counts."

On the other hand, House Minority Whip Steny H. Hoyer (D-MD) emphasized the need for bipartisan cooperation, saying, "The CBO’s report is a warning that we must get our fiscal house in order by achieving big and balanced deficit reduction that includes both spending and revenues."

In response to the CBO's report, a bipartisan group of senators has shown signs of cooperation, meeting behind closed doors to discuss the country's fiscal situation in light of the European debt crisis. The senators emerged from the meeting expressing a new sense of urgency about the country's fiscal picture.

The CBO's analysis presents two sets of numbers, one assuming certain tax increases and spending cuts take effect, and another assuming they are delayed. Under the former scenario, debt decreases, while under the latter, debt explodes, leading to a 4.4 percent lower economy in 2027 and a 13.4 percent lower economy in 2037.

The CBO's analysis also provides insights into the future of the budget and the economy, including predictions about the U.S. population reaching 389 million in 2037 and surpassing 500 million by 2087, with the population skewing older. Older workers are expected to work fewer hours, and the growth in the labor force will slow, keeping economic growth to an average of 2.2 percent over the long term. The interest rate on debt will be higher, at an average of 2.7 percent, a reversal from recent years when economic growth and interest rates were about the same.

For each dollar the deficit rises, national savings are reduced by between 32 cents and 72 cents, and domestic investment is reduced by between 10 cents and 50 cents, according to the CBO.

Title: Political Implications of Obamacare Emerge as Economic Concerns Persist

Article:

The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, has been a topic of debate in the political arena since its inception in 2010. While the economic implications of the costly national health care plan have been a point of contention, the political implications are now gaining attention.

Initially, health care reform was not typically viewed as a political strategy, with terms such as "accessibility" and "affordability" used to demonstrate commitment to quality health care for all Americans. However, the signing of the act into law on March 23, 2010, emboldened Democrats, and the political strategy shifted from rhetoric to action.

The political language surrounding Obamacare still emphasized "accessibility" and "affordability," but also included terms like "protection" (of Americans, as well as Medicare and Medicaid) and "fairness" (to reduce inequalities in the system). Various demographic groups, including seniors, minorities, liberals, and women, were initially targeted. Over time, the underlying political message was sold on a wider basis to all Americans.

Critics argue that Obamacare will reportedly cost taxpayers $1 trillion and will be a financial burden for future generations. It is expected to increase government influence over health care, reduce consumer choice, and potentially lead to the loss of an estimated 80,000 jobs, according to the Congressional Budget Office. The extensive phase-in period between 2014 and 2020 will serve as a constant source of confusion, and businesses may struggle under the weight of the 2,700-page document.

Republican opposition to Obamacare has been significant, with a Reuters-Ipsos poll in June 2012 showing 56 percent of Americans surveyed were against it. However, the general consensus was that Obamacare would not adequately fix health care, and that real reform was necessary.

In a surprising move, 19 Republican governors in mostly red states have decided not to establish their own health care exchanges, opting instead to let the federal government manage them. This strategy could potentially empower the federal government at the expense of the states and could be used as a political tactic to blame the White House for forcing the issue.

The political implications of this decision remain to be seen, but some speculate it could lead to moderate Republicans using the non-exchange exchange to distinguish themselves from more vocal conservative Republicans and Tea Party supporters. Critics argue that maintaining radio silence about Obamacare could backfire, as the economic cost of implementing it will be significant, and the economic and political costs of doing nothing could be immense.

As the political battle over Obamacare continues, it is crucial for both parties to consider the long-term economic and political implications of their actions.

Title: Uninsured Population in the U.S. Remains Significant Despite ACA, Disparities Wide Among Low-Income and Minority Groups

Article:

In the aftermath of the failed American Health Care Act, the focus has shifted back to the real effects of health reform in the United States. In a new book, "An American Sickness," journalist Elisabeth Rosenthal laments the transformation of the U.S. healthcare system from a patient care system to a multitrillion-dollar business.

One major issue highlighted by Rosenthal is the persistence of an uninsured population in the U.S., which is nearly as large as the population of Canada. Since 2013, the number of uninsured Americans has decreased from 18 percent in 2013 to 11.9 percent in 2016, but there are still nearly 30 million people living in America without health insurance.

"When you look at it from the perspective of much of the rest of the developed world — to have 10 percent of the population without good access to health care shows how far we still have to go," said Rosenthal, a doctor, former New York Times writer, and now the editor in chief of the nonprofit Kaiser Health News.

The size of the uninsured group is well-known, but less clear is what this group looks like. A new series in the Lancet on health inequality paints a clearer picture. People who go without insurance in America are not refusing coverage for ideological reasons; they simply cannot afford to pay.

Most uninsured Americans have yearly incomes that are near or below the poverty line ($11,770 for an individual in 2016). "Among non-elderly adults, 7.6% of the non-poor were uninsured in 2015 compared with 25.2% of the poor and 24.1% of the near-poor," the Lancet reports. In other words, the poor and near-poor were more than three times more likely to be uninsured than their higher-income counterparts.

The other group that is less likely to be insured are people of color, according to the Lancet. "With respect to racial disparities, in 2015 the uninsurance rate among adults aged 18–64 years remained far higher for Hispanics (27.7%) and non-Hispanic blacks (14.4%) than for non-Hispanic whites (8.7%)," the Lancet reports.

The disparities in access to care are wider in the U.S. than in other developed countries. "Before the 2010 passage of the ACA, which progressively expanded health insurance coverage, 39% of Americans with below-average income reported not seeing a doctor for a medical problem because of cost, compared with 7% of low-income Canadians and 1% of those in the UK," the Lancet reports. They are also linked to a big mortality gap: The richest 1 percent in America live up to 15 years longer than the poorest 1 percent.

The Lancet researchers do not think the kind of market-based reforms the GOP is pushing are the solution to the problem, and point out they will make inequality worse. Instead, they are siding with a certain American champion of universal health care: "A single-payer, Medicare-for-all reform — championed by Senator Bernie Sanders during his upstart presidential campaign, as well as by many physicians and the nation's largest nurses union — would, in our view, best address health-care inequalities."

Rosenthal is more of an incrementalist. She does not think blowing up the system is realistic. "This system progressively got built one action at a time, the perversion of one incentive at a time," she said. To bring the U.S. more in line with other wealthy countries — in terms of both cost and access — she thinks we need to unravel those perverse incentives, one small step at a time.

Title: Former Trump Campaign Aide George Papadopoulos Sentenced to 14 Days in Prison for Lying to FBI

Article:

George Papadopoulos, a former foreign policy adviser to the Trump campaign, was sentenced to 14 days in federal prison on Friday for lying to the FBI during the early stages of the Justice Department's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election. In an interview on ABC's "This Week" on Sunday, Papadopoulos stated that he felt "pinned" during his interview with FBI officers in January 2017 and lied to investigators in an attempt to protect President Donald Trump.

Papadopoulos explained that he was attending parties with senior-level transition officials at the time of his interview, and he understood that there was an incipient investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. He expressed that he found himself in a difficult position, as he had worked hard to help elect Trump, and then found himself potentially incriminating the sitting president.

Reports have indicated that statements by Papadopoulos to an Australian official in May 2016 triggered the initial investigation into Russian interference in the election. Papadopoulos pleaded guilty in October to lying to the FBI about his meetings in London with a Maltese professor, Joseph Mifsud, making him the first person to admit guilt to Robert Mueller in the special counsel's sprawling Russia inquiry.

Papadopoulos described Mifsud as a well-connected individual who claimed to be able to connect him and the campaign to Russian officials and other leaders around the world. Mifsud told Papadopoulos in the spring of 2016 that he had obtained "dirt" on Hillary Clinton, and would claim to have amassed troves of emails connected to Clinton's campaign. A month before that meeting, the emails of Clinton's campaign chairman, John Podesta, were stolen in a data breach.

Papadopoulos maintained that he was not made aware of the hacks on Podesta or the Democratic National Committee and has testified that he did not tell any Trump campaign officials about his conversation with Mifsud regarding Clinton's emails. Papadopoulos stated that he chose to keep the professor's claim under wraps because Paul Manafort, who became the Trump campaign chairman in May 2016, quashed the idea of a potential summit between then-candidate Donald Trump and President Vladimir Putin of Russia, which Papadopoulos had been trying to broker.

Sen. Mark Warner of Virginia, the top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, stated on Sunday that it was unlikely that Papadopoulos did not tell other members of the Trump campaign about his talks with Mifsud. Warner added that it was implausible that, if Papadopoulos had this knowledge and wanted to try to further ingratiate himself with the campaign, he would not have shared that information with someone on the campaign.

Papadopoulos also stated that he had "no opinion on" and "no knowledge of" Trump's alleged attempts to obstruct Mueller's investigation and could not answer whether the special counsel would be able to demonstrate coordination between the Trump campaign and the Kremlin.

Title: Trump Faces Delegate Challenges as Cruz Outmaneuvers in Delegate Selection Process

Article:

In the ongoing Republican presidential race, Donald Trump is facing challenges in the delegate selection process as his campaign attacks his own party for what he perceives as a rigged nominating process. The billionaire businessman has been criticized for missing critical deadlines and being outmaneuvered by the Ted Cruz campaign, according to frustrated party leaders.

At a CNN town hall on Tuesday, Trump stated that he knows the rules "very well" but that the rules are "stacked" against him by the establishment. This prompted a cutting retort from Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus.

The dispute over process is building as Cruz's operation has proved more adroit lately in getting supporters elected as the actual delegates who will attend July's convention. Last weekend at the Colorado state convention, Cruz gained all 34 delegates to this summer's convention in Cleveland. On the sidelines, he's also working to get allies elected as delegates in states that hold traditional primaries and caucuses that allocate delegates based on voting.

In those states, delegates "bound" to Trump or Cruz or Ohio Gov. John Kasich would have to vote for their respective candidates on the first ballot at the convention. However, if there's an open convention – meaning nobody has the necessary 1,237 delegate to clinch the nomination – Cruz is banking on his delegate allies to surge over to his side on a second ballot, which many would be allowed to do.

The Washington Post reported Wednesday that based on their own analysis, Cruz could pick up at least 130 – and as many as 170 or more – additional delegate votes on the second ballot at an open convention. This would make it even harder for Trump to lock down the nomination, upping the pressure on the front-runner to clinch the party nod by the final June contests.

The Trump campaign has insisted they can do this, and that Cruz won't get the opportunity to use his backup delegate allies on a second ballot. However, the Trump campaign has made it harder on itself by missing crucial deadlines in a number of states to lock up delegates who would stay loyal beyond the first ballot.

Trump's team is only now starting to engage in the delegate selection process, the choosing of the actual people who will attend and vote at the convention. Republicans have already selected delegates in at least nine states. In others, such as Virginia and Arizona, the deadline to apply to be a delegate has passed. Indiana's primary, for example, won't take place until next month. However, the deadline to become a national convention delegate was in mid-March. Anti-Trump forces reportedly have already been lining up delegates who would turn on Trump at a contested convention.

"Are we concerned? Yes, definitely," said Tony Samuel, vice chairman of Trump's Indiana campaign. "Even if [Trump] jumped into high gear, he can't do it," said Shak Hill, a Cruz campaign leader in Virginia. "That's where he's been shut out of the game."

Trump is just ramping up his operation, but in some states, he's too late. In Virginia – a state where Trump won the primary – he has missed the deadlines to assemble lists of potential delegates. Cruz, however, has delegate candidates in 10 of Virginia's 11 congressional districts.

Indiana's primary is May 3, but 27 of the state's 57 delegates – the actual people – have already been selected at congressional district caucuses. The deadline to register as a candidate for delegate was March 15.

In the at least nine states that have picked some or all of their delegates, Trump has won a total of 100 delegates in primaries and caucuses in these states. In most, however, the candidates had no formal role in selecting the people who will fill those slots.

Trump, meanwhile, is banking on rallying popular support – which so far has kept him far out in front in the Republican field – in hopes of winning the nomination outright.

During a rally in a packed airport hangar in Rome, N.Y., on Tuesday evening, Trump stated, "Our Republican system is absolutely rigged. It's a phony deal." He added, "These are dirty tricksters." He placed the blame on the Republican National Committee, stating, "They should be ashamed of themselves for allowing this kind of crap to happen."

Cruz tore into Trump in a radio interview Tuesday, accusing his rival of being a bully, inciting violence, and using dirty tricks to intimidate voters and delegates. Cruz unloaded on Trump over reports that his supporters were publishing the home addresses of delegates in Colorado and threatening to make public the hotel room numbers of delegates at the convention this summer.

"That is the tactic of union thugs," Cruz told host Glenn Beck. "That is violence. It is oppressive." Cruz conceded that Trump will do well in upcoming primaries, including in Trump's home state of New York next Tuesday. Cruz said he will fare better when the race shifts back west to Indiana, Nebraska, South Dakota, and Montana, before finishing in California on June 7.

Title: Former First Lady Laura Bush Condemns Family Separation Policy at U.S.-Mexico Border

Article:

Former U.S. First Lady Laura Bush has criticized the controversial policy that separates families who illegally enter the country at the Mexican border, describing the practice as cruel, immoral, and heart-breaking. In an opinion piece published in the Washington Post, she wrote that the policy is "cruel, immoral, and breaks my heart."

The policy, which has been a subject of growing controversy, is a result of President Donald Trump's "zero-tolerance" immigration policy. According to fact-checkers, the policy was introduced by Attorney General Jeff Sessions and does not require congressional action to be stopped.

In a six-week period, there were nearly 2,000 family separations following a crackdown on illegal border crossings. Adults who try to cross the border outside of official entry points, many planning to seek asylum, are placed in custody and face criminal prosecution for illegal entry. As a result, hundreds of children and babies are now being housed in detention centers, including warehouses and converted supermarkets, and kept away from their parents.

Laura Bush, wife of the former Republican President George W. Bush and a Texas resident, launched an outspoken attack on the policy. "This zero-tolerance policy is cruel. It is immoral. And it breaks my heart," she wrote in the Washington Post. "Our government should not be in the business of warehousing children in converted box stores or making plans to place them in tent cities in the desert."

She compared the policy to the Japanese American internment camps of World War Two, which are now considered one of the most shameful episodes in U.S. history. "These images are eerily reminiscent of the Japanese American internment camps of World War Two," she added.

Earlier, Mrs. Trump said she "hates to see children separated from their families and hopes both sides of the aisle [Republicans and Democrats in Congress] can finally come together to achieve successful immigration reform."

The first ladies' comments come amid growing alarm over the impact of the policy. On Monday, UN human rights chief Zeid Ra'ad al-Hussein called on the U.S. to end what he called its "unconscionable" strategy of forced separations.

In a tweet on Saturday, President Trump urged Democrats to work with Republicans to create new legislation. However, critics have pointed out that detaining children separately from their parents is the consequence of a policy announced by Attorney General Jeff Sessions last month to deter new arrivals. The significant change, analysts say, is the justice department's decision to prosecute parents if they illegally cross the border, even if it is their first offense. The children are not charged with a crime, which means they can not be jailed together.

Until this policy was announced, such families were usually subject to civil deportation proceedings, which did not require separation. The recent child detentions have resulted in some shelters and foster homes reporting that they are running out of space.

On Sunday, Democratic lawmakers visited shelters and processing facilities in New Jersey and Texas, demanding to see detainees. "They call it zero-tolerance, but a better name for it is zero-humanity. And there is zero logic to this," Sen. Jeff Merkley of Oregon, who organized a visit to Casa Padre detention center in Brownsville, Texas, told the BBC.

Vermont congressman Peter Welch said he saw children held "in chain link cages" in a processing facility and one shelter "filled to capacity." Meanwhile, officials announced plans to erect tent cities that will hold hundreds more children in the Texas desert where temperatures regularly reach 40C (105F).

Local lawmaker Jose Rodriguez described the plan as "totally inhumane" and "outrageous," adding, "It should be condemned by anyone who has a moral sense of responsibility." Protesters marched to one such tent city in Tornillo, Texas, on Sunday where hundreds of children were being held separately from their parents. They chanted "Families united!" and "Free our children now!"

The policy faces legal challenges, including a federal case brought by the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU). The number of families trying to enter the U.S. overland without documentation is on the rise. In the first two weeks of the new "zero-tolerance" approach, 658 minors - including many babies and toddlers - were separated from the adults that traveled with them, according to U.S. border officials. In many of the cases, the families have been reunited after the parent was released from detention. However, there are reports of people being kept apart for weeks and even months.

It is not clear if this new tougher policy will stop the migrants from traveling. This is because many are fleeing violence and poverty in countries such as Honduras and El Salvador, and staying put is often fraught with dangers.

Title: House Republicans Call for Transparency as Schiff Blocks Release of Witness Interviews from Trump-Russia Probe

Article:

A group of over two dozen House Republicans, led by Representative Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), have called on House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) to stop what they perceive as the withholding of 53 witness interviews from the Trump-Russia probe. In a letter sent on Tuesday, the group expressed concern over the alleged lack of transparency regarding accusations made by public figures, including Schiff, during the investigation.

The letter states that the American people deserve access to the transcripts of the interviews, as the House Intelligence Committee voted to release them in September 2018. However, the transcripts have yet to be made public, with 43 of the 53 interviews reportedly already declassified. The remaining 10 transcripts are under review by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI), with the intention of being reviewed by the White House as part of the declassification process. This review process, according to the Republicans, has been blocked by Schiff.

The Republicans argue that, despite the delay, they still require access to the material for their ongoing oversight of the Department of Justice and Federal Bureau of Investigation. On Monday, Jordan and Representative Mike Johnson (R-La.) requested that FBI Director Christopher Wray turn over all documents and communications related to the FBI's "Crossfire Razor" investigation of former Trump national security adviser Michael Flynn. The request comes in the wake of the release of FBI notes that Republicans have argued prove Flynn was ensnared in a "perjury trap."

The letter from the Republicans states, "For almost four years, prominent Democrat politicians and commentators alleged that President Trump colluded with Russia, with Chairman Schiff going as far as to say that he had 'direct evidence' of collusion." The letter also mentions that the House Intelligence Committee voted to release the interviews in September 2018, and a spokesperson for the ODNI stated in May 2019 that the review process would be completed "very soon." However, the transcripts have not been made public as of yet.

Title: U.S. and North Korea Establish Direct Communication Channels Amid Escalating Tensions

Article:

The Trump administration has confirmed for the first time that it is in direct communication with North Korea over its nuclear and missile programs. U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, during a trip to China's capital, acknowledged that the administration is speaking to North Korea "directly, through our own channels."

Tillerson stated, "We have lines of communication to Pyongyang. We're not in a dark situation, a blackout. We can talk to them. We do talk to them." The top U.S. diplomat also mentioned that there are "three channels" open with the regime of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

Tillerson added that broad sanctions against North Korea over its nuclear program "are beginning to have an effect." He noted, "We are seeing, from what we can observe, and the Chinese are telling us, that it is having some effect." Tillerson also highlighted the international community's unified stance against North Korea's nuclear program.

The situation with Pyongyang is currently described as "overheated" by Tillerson, following exchanges of barbs between President Donald Trump and Kim Jong Un. Tillerson attributed the rising tensions to North Korea's continued missile testing, stating that if North Korea were to stop testing, "that would calm things down a lot."

U.S. Department of State spokesperson Heather Nauert issued a statement Saturday, stating that there are "several open channels" for the Trump administration to communicate with the North Korean government. However, North Korean officials have shown no indication that they are interested in or ready for talks regarding denuclearization.

Tillerson's comments and his visit to Beijing come after North Korea's foreign minister accused the U.S. of declaring war earlier this week. The foreign minister's remarks followed President Trump's threat at the United Nations last week to "totally destroy" North Korea if the U.S. has to defend itself or its allies from the regime.

Tillerson reiterated in Beijing on Saturday that a nuclear-armed North Korea will never be acceptable to the U.S. and its allies. The U.S. calculated over the summer that Kim Jong Un's regime controlled as many as 60 nuclear weapons, according to an assessment by U.S. intelligence officials. However, some independent experts think the number is far smaller.

As to the value of negotiating directly with North Korea, opinions among U.S. officials and America's allies vary. While Tillerson says the U.S. is "directly" talking with the regime, both Trump and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe have stated that now is not the time to engage with the Kim Jong Un's government. Meanwhile, South Korean President Moon Jae-in has remained open to such talks.

Title: GOP, Conservative Groups Resist Obama's Call for Debt Ceiling Compromise

Article:

Republicans and conservative groups have rejected President Obama's latest effort to persuade GOP lawmakers to abandon the use of the debt ceiling as a bargaining chip for long-term spending cuts with Democrats.

Following a White House news conference on Monday, during which the president labeled Republican threats to hold firm on the nation's borrowing as "irresponsible," Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, expressed his view that the upcoming debt limit debate offers an opportune moment to compel Democrats to address the deficit.

"The president and his allies need to get serious about spending, and the debt-limit debate is the perfect time for it," Mr. McConnell said. "I do know that the most important issue confronting the future of our country is our deficit and debt. So we are hoping for a new seriousness on the part of the president with regard to the single biggest issue confronting the country, and we look forward to working with him to do something about this huge, huge problem."

President Obama countered that Republican threats to default on the nation's debts are "absurd," warning that such a move would send stock markets plummeting and jeopardize any hope of a significant economic recovery this year.

House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, a Virginia Republican, swiftly rebutted, characterizing the president's remarks as more of the same from Mr. Obama.

"The American people deserve better from Washington. We cannot deliver meaningful change and necessary reforms if we refuse to address out-of-control spending," he said. "Under President Obama, we have seen record-setting deficit spending and trillions added to our nation's debt. This is a leadership failure."

Mr. Cantor also criticized the White House for its failure to meet the deadline for delivering its budget for the upcoming fiscal year to Congress. The White House informed the House Budget Committee late last week that it would not comply with a Feb. 4 deadline to send its budget to Congress, as required by law.

Rep. Paul Ryan, a Wisconsin Republican and vice presidential nominee last year, who oversees the panel, commented, "The Senate hasn't passed a budget in nearly four years, and that is inexcusable."

The Tea Party Patriots, the nation's largest tea party group, asserted that Mr. Obama has spent four years driving up the deficit and stalling when it comes to spending cuts, forcing Republicans to take drastic measures such as threatening to hold the line on raising the debt limit or shutting down the government to prompt Democrats to negotiate on spending.

"It is the president who is holding our economy hostage to his vision of spending more now regardless of the consequences," said Jenny Beth Martin, national coordinator of the Tea Party Patriots. "It is the president whose deadbeat policies handicap our economy and stunt growth. It is the president and his party who pass deadline after deadline without passing a budget so that the American people can review and analyze it."

Mr. Obama maintains that his November re-election victory is evidence that the public supports his plan for higher taxes on the wealthy and a "balanced" approach to deficit reduction.

"While I am willing to compromise and find common ground on reducing the deficit, America can not afford another debate over whether it should pay the bill [Congress] already racked up," he told reporters.

Over the weekend, he also rejected suggestions by some congressional Democrats that he bypass Congress in the debate and unilaterally act to ensure the federal government's debts are paid.

The Treasury, which has been managing federal finances since the nation hit the debt limit of $16.4 trillion last month, has informed the president and Congress that it will exhaust short-term fixes within weeks.

Some Republicans, disgruntled with the "fiscal cliff" deal that Mr. McConnell negotiated with Vice President Joseph R. Biden this month, are beginning to embrace the idea of shutting down the government to force Mr. Obama's hand when it comes to cutting spending.

Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers, a Washington Republican who heads the GOP conference, told Politico that she believes House Republicans could very well shut down the government to extract spending cuts from Democrats. The shutdown would be imposed if Congress does not pass another spending bill to fund the government's general operations by March 27.

"We always talk about whether or not we're going to kick the can down the road," she said. "I think the mood is that we've come to the end of the road."

The White House, citing the impact of the last standoff over the borrowing limit, has stated repeatedly that there will be no negotiations with Republicans over raising the debt ceiling. After months of brinkmanship over the debt limit, the credit ratings firm Standard & Poor's downgraded U.S. debt for the first time in 70 years in 2011.

The government hit the debt ceiling on Dec. 31, but the Treasury started taking emergency measures to allow it to continue issuing debt and prevent any type of default for just a short window of time.

The Bipartisan Policy Center states that the Treasury will exhaust its options for meeting the government's bills between Feb. 15 and March 1.

Title: Former Ohio State Wrestlers Accuse Rep. Jim Jordan of Ignoring Sexual Abuse Scandal

Article:

Over the weekend, a seventh former wrestler at Ohio State University came forward, accusing Rep. Jim Jordan (R-OH) of being aware but doing nothing in response to the largest sexual abuse scandal in U.S. sports history. For weeks, Jordan has maintained that he was unaware of the systematic abuse by team trainer Richard Strauss while serving as an assistant coach for the Buckeyes wrestling team in the 1980s and 1990s.

Three former wrestlers told NBC News that Jordan had knowledge of the allegations and did not take action to stop the abuse. Since then, four more former teammates have corroborated these accounts, stating that it was impossible for Jordan to be unaware of the abuse. The seventh wrestler came forward on Friday in an interview with the Washington Post.

David Range, who wrestled for Ohio State in the late 1980s, stated, "Jordan definitely knew that these things were happening — yes, most definitely. It was there. He knew about it because it was an everyday occurrence."

No one has accused Jordan of engaging in any abusive behavior himself, but several of his former athletes, including some who considered Jordan a friend, have expressed resentment over the congressman's denial of knowledge about the abuse.

In a Politico report last week, other former Ohio State personnel described the wrestling team as a "cesspool of deviancy" during the period in which Jordan served as an assistant coach. Even Jordan's supporters have acknowledged that the toxic culture was widespread and well-known.

Jordan himself acknowledged as much during an interview on Fox News Friday evening, seemingly contradicting his earlier pleas of ignorance when he told host Brett Baier, "Conversations in a locker room are a lot different than allegations of abuse."

Part of the hangup appears to be over semantics. In the 1980s, exactly what constituted sexual abuse—as opposed to merely "inappropriate" or "creepy" behavior—was even less understood than it is today. Jordan has insisted no wrestler ever came to him with a story of "sexual abuse." However, Dunyasha Yetts—one of the first wrestlers to come forward, who says he asked Jordan to accompany him to Strauss's office because he feared he would be groped—says it's a difference without a distinction.

"Yeah, you can say we never told you those words because we didn't know those words, which is true," Yetts told Politico. "But for him to say he didn't know? I asked him to come in there with me!"

Not only has Jordan remained unapologetic for his role in Ohio State's still-unfolding scandal, he has threatened at least one victim of sexual assault with the capitol police.

The accusations have threatened to upend Jordan's once-promising political career. His fellow far-right extremists in Congress were urging Jordan to seek a leadership position in the Republican caucus once retiring Rep. Paul Ryan (R-WI) relinquishes his title as Speaker of the House, and Jordan himself has said he wishes to succeed Ryan as Speaker, a position held by other Republican luminaries including former wrestling coach Dennis Hastert.

Title: Greta Thunberg's Address at the United Nations Climate Action Summit

Article:

Greta Thunberg, the teenage climate activist, delivered a passionate speech at the United Nations Climate Action Summit on September 23, 2019. The speech, which was met with applause and criticism, saw Thunberg criticizing world leaders for their inaction on climate change.

Thunberg, a 16-year-old from Sweden, accused the leaders of stealing her dreams and childhood with their empty words. She stated, "You have stolen my dreams and my childhood with your empty words." Thunberg's journey to the summit was noteworthy, as she sailed across the Atlantic last month to avoid jet travel.

Thunberg is the face of a global youth movement against climate change, which includes a global "climate strike" last week. The movement is being promoted and celebrated by adults who find it useful for their own purposes.

The article suggests that young people, including Thunberg, are being used as pawns by adults with their own agendas. The author argues that children have little to offer in terms of nuanced and mature perspectives on complex issues. The article also criticizes the adults who feed children apocalyptic warnings, which the children then repeat as urgent insights.

The article also highlights the achievements made in various areas such as poverty reduction, life expectancy, and primary school completion rates, suggesting that today's youth will have more resources and technology to address climate change than any other generation in history.

The article also mentions that some young activists have dropped out due to depression, anxiety, and fears that world leaders will not act in time to prevent irreversible environmental harm. The author attributes this to the adults who enable and feed the children apocalyptic warnings.

The article concludes by stating that the children will grow up, even in a warming world, and that the ultimate responsibility lies with the adults who enable and feed the children apocalyptic warnings.

Title: U.S. and China Agree to Reduce Greenhouse Gas Emissions

Article:

In a significant climate change agreement, U.S. President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping have pledged to curb their greenhouse gas emissions over the next two decades. Under the agreement, the United States will reduce its 2005 level of carbon emissions by 26-28% before 2025, while China will peak its carbon emissions by 2030 and aim to obtain 20% of its energy from zero-carbon emission sources by the same year.

President Obama, who was in Beijing for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit, stated, "We have a special responsibility to lead the global effort against climate change." The announcement marks the first time China has agreed to peak its carbon emissions, according to the White House.

Xi is calling for an "energy revolution" that would include broad economic reforms addressing air pollution. Obama expressed hope that the deal will encourage other nations to tackle climate change. Xi and Obama are committed to working toward the goals before the U.N. Climate Conference in Paris next year.

The Center for Climate and Energy Solutions described the joint announcement as "an extremely hopeful sign." The agreement could put climate change back on the G20 agenda, according to researcher David Holmes of Monash University in Australia. However, some critics argue that the goals laid out by Obama and Xi were not as ambitious as hoped.

The White House stated that the ultimate target is to "achieve deep economy-wide reductions on the order of 80% by 2050." The Obama administration hopes to sell the plan back home by touting the anticipated savings on energy costs and initiatives and incentives to develop more solar and wind power in both countries.

However, the Senate's top Republican, Sen. Mitch McConnell, stated that the climate change deal will hurt the U.S. economy. China has agreed to provide another 800-1,000 gigawatts of nuclear, wind, solar, and other zero-emission generation capacity by 2030, exceeding all the coal-fired power plants that exist in China today and close to total current electricity generation capacity in the United States.

Title: Illegal Immigrants from Central America Abandoned in U.S. States After Border Apprehension

Article:

Scores of illegal immigrants, primarily from Central American countries such as El Salvador and Guatemala, have been apprehended by authorities in Texas while attempting to enter the United States via the Rio Grande Valley.
