Instead of being returned to their country of origin, these individuals are being flown, bused, and then abandoned in various states, including Arizona, New York, and Maryland.

If the immigrants were from Mexico, they would typically be released back across the border. However, the process of returning Central American immigrants to their home countries has been costly and largely unsuccessful.

Lawmakers in Arizona, which has been grappling with the issue of illegal immigration for years, have criticized the practice. Republican gubernatorial candidate Scott Smith stated, "What an astonishing failure of leadership at every level inside the Beltway."

Ira Mehlman, spokesman for the Federation for American Immigration Reform, told Reuters, "essentially, they have gotten successfully into the country and it’s unlikely that they’re going to leave."

The number of apprehensions in the Rio Grande Valley has increased significantly in recent years, with south Texas now serving as the main gateway for illegal immigration along the southwest border with Mexico. Border Patrol agents in the Rio Grande Valley sector apprehended 154,453 immigrants last year, up from 97,762 the previous year.

A particularly concerning aspect of the situation is the unprecedented surge of children making the over 1,000-mile journey from Central America to the U.S.-Mexico border to escape violence in their home countries. Reports of horrific incidents, including rape and murder of young children, have emerged from border districts.

Floridalma Bineda Portillo and her two young boys were part of a group of about 400 Central Americans who were flown from Texas to Tucson last weekend. Bineda Portillo and others were then transported to Phoenix after the Tucson Greyhound station ran out of space.

Upon arrival at the station in Phoenix, a volunteer nurse found Bineda Portillo's five-year-old son, Hugo David, wheezing and struggling to breathe. His asthma inhaler had been lost during the family's processing by immigration. Bineda Portillo's three-year-old son developed a cold after sitting on the floor for hours in the detention center, according to his mother.

"We all started crying because we didn't know what was going to happen to us. It was brutal," the Guatemala native said in Spanish.

Senate Appropriations Committee Chairwoman Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., told Reuters, "This is a humanitarian crisis and it requires a humanitarian response."

Most of the families apprehended so far in Texas have been flown to Arizona and dropped off by the busload at the station in Phoenix by federal immigration authorities overwhelmed by a surge of families caught crossing the Mexican border into the Rio Grande Valley.

The U.S. Department of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) stated that it does not wish to detain minors in detention centers or separate families. Instead, they are expected to return to Texas on their own once their deportation process nears completion, in an honor system of sorts.

"After screening by DHS authorities, the family units will be released under supervision and required to report in to a local ICE office near their destination address within 15 days, where their cases will be managed in accordance with current ICE enforcement priorities," according to an ICE statement.

Bineda Portillo fled Guatemala due to growing violence and domestic abuse. Her mother, who lives in Nashville, Tennessee, sent her money for the bus ride there. In the meantime, volunteers from the Phoenix Restoration Project, a humanitarian group, have been at the Greyhound station since Tuesday, handing out food, clothing, diapers, and other supplies.

"It's always heart-wrenching, especially when we're working with women, because they're less likely to be able to read and sometimes are coming from very rural areas of Central America, and Spanish isn't their first language," volunteer Cyndi Whitmore said. "We see a lot of women who are very scared, very vulnerable."

Title: MSNBC's Nicolle Wallace Airs Altered Video of Pelosi-Trump Clash to Highlight Doctored Footage

Article:

MSNBC's "Deadline: White House" host, Nicolle Wallace, on Friday aired an altered video clip of herself to demonstrate President Donald Trump's attempt to "smear" House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) with a doctored video. Wallace, who served as White House communications director in the George W. Bush administration and as a GOP campaign aide, noted that Trump shared an edited video clip on Thursday that made it appear as if Pelosi was stuttering.

The video, while not doctored itself, was shared on the same day The Washington Post reported that doctored videos portraying Pelosi as if she were drunk had gone viral on social media. Wallace pointed out that the slowed-down video "has the effect of making anyone look like they’re having a hard time speaking."

To illustrate the impact of doctored videos, Wallace aired a clip of herself speaking that had been slowed down, allowing her audience to see what she looked and sounded like when doctored. She also played a clip of a campaign speech that had been altered, a video that Trump himself has been a victim of.

Wallace's MSNBC show decided not to show the clip of Pelosi that Trump shared with his 60.5 million Twitter followers. President Trump, on Friday, denied knowledge of the altered videos and praised his ability to work with the Democratic leader before accusing her of "not helping the country."

"I don’t know about the videos. I can tell you that — what I’m here is to help the country," Trump told reporters at the White House before leaving on a trip to Japan.

Title: Clinton and Trump Adopt Different Strategies as Election Nears

Article:

In the final days following their televised debates, Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and Republican candidate Donald Trump have adopted starkly different tactics to reach the more than 200 million Americans who have registered to vote in the upcoming election. While Trump has focused on raucous swing state rallies that some have compared to a rock music tour, Clinton is investing heavily in TV advertising and local organizing, with an eye toward states that were once safely Republican.

Clinton's strategy could potentially secure her more than the 270 electoral college votes needed to win the White House and may also help Democrats win back control of Congress. Speaking at a rally in Orlando, Florida on Sunday night, Democratic vice-presidential candidate Tim Kaine suggested Clinton was headed toward a "very big and historic win" on November 8. However, Clinton campaign aides have not discounted the risk that Trump could benefit from an unpredictable 2016 electorate, especially in swing states like Ohio where polling remains tight.

Trump advisers acknowledge they are facing an uphill battle, but maintain the country's anti-establishment mood will work in their favor in the final few days. Trump's son, Eric Trump, echoed these sentiments but rejected the idea that his father was playing to his base of support.

Some Republicans are sceptical Trump can find a way to win. Karl Rove, who masterminded George W Bush's narrow election victories over Al Gore and John Kerry, was sceptical on Sunday that there was enough time left. The Clinton campaign remains confident that it can spare resources on punishing the Republican party for standing with Trump, who has repeatedly broken the norms of American politics and energized once shunned leaders, such as former Ku Klux Klansman David Duke.

Clinton's campaign spokesman, Brian Fallon, said the campaign wanted to "extend an open hand" to traditionally Republican voters even as it targets the "different strain" within the party that continues to support Trump, despite his offensive remarks about women, immigrants, and minorities. Although many Senate veterans, including John McCain and Kelly Ayotte, have rescinded their endorsements of Trump, he has retained his vociferous base and the muted support of House speaker Paul Ryan and Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell.

Clinton's campaign will continue to court "reasonable Republicans and independents" who might be willing to defect across party lines. Trump Jr also told ABC that his father would "100%" accept the results of the election if it was fair.

Title: Moderna's COVID-19 Vaccine Shows Promise in Early-Stage Trial

Article:

A candidate vaccine for COVID-19 developed by Moderna and the federal government appears to be safe and triggers an immune response, according to data from an early-phase trial released on Tuesday. However, it remains unclear whether this immune response is sufficient to protect individuals from the coronavirus that causes COVID-19, according to several experts who reviewed the results.

Moderna's chief medical officer, Tal Zaks, stated that while the protective effect of the vaccine cannot technically be known yet, all indications are that mRNA-1273 will be safe and effective. The levels of protective antibodies produced by trial participants were similar to those found in patients who had recovered from COVID-19, suggesting that the candidate vaccine provides the same protection as an infection.

Animal studies show mRNA-1273 can protect mice against infection, and trials in primates and Syrian hamsters are underway. The mRNA-1273 candidate did not generate a kind of immune cell that in other diseases made vaccinated people worse off, Zaks said.

The clinical trial was led by Anthony Fauci's Vaccine Research Center at the National Institutes of Health. The experimental vaccine was created quickly, with a volunteer in Seattle being injected on March 16, just two months after Chinese scientists revealed the virus's genetic sequence.

In the trial, 45 participants were divided into three groups: one that received a high dose, one a medium dose, and one a low dose. Each person received two shots, a month apart. All the reactions in the two lower dose groups were mild, with more than half experiencing minor fatigue, chills, headache, or muscle pain, as is typical with vaccines. Three of those who received the highest dose had a severe reaction after the second shot, according to the study, including one participant whose fever spiked to 103 degrees.

The highest dose, 250 micrograms, was dropped from later-stage trials, and only the 100-microgram dose will be proposed for use in people. All the participants showed evidence of an immune response, which is the goal of immunization. However, it's not clear how much of an immune response will be needed to protect against infection.

"It looks like their vaccine was able to induce a virus neutralizing antibody, which is positive," said Dr. Peter Hotez, dean of the National School of Tropical Medicine at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston. "But it's hard to know if the level of virus neutralizing antibody will be sufficient to induce protective immunity, or if it compares favorably with other (vaccine) candidates."

"These are good results," said Dr. Nadine Rouphael, who helped lead the trial at Emory University School of Medicine. She agreed with Hotez that it's too early to know whether the vaccine will be protective. Neutralizing antibodies are key for fighting other infections, she said, but there are a lot of questions about COVID-19.

"How long will they stay, what's the right level of protection remains to be determined," she said Tuesday. Learning whether the vaccine is protective will require a much larger study. A so-called Phase 3 trial with 30,000 participants is slated to begin on July 27, Zak confirmed.

One challenge, Rouphael said, will be to find trial participants who naturally catch COVID-19. In trials for a Zika vaccine, the disease was brought under control, and it was very difficult to determine whether the vaccine was protective, because no one was catching it, she said.

Thousands of people volunteered for the small Phase 1 trial, Rouphael said, and she hopes people will continue to sign up for the research. The novel coronavirus works by invading human cells, then forcing them to reproduce the virus in high volumes. One way to stop the disease could be to get the body to produce antibodies in advance that would prevent the virus from penetrating cells. Though the results show people injected produce antibodies, it's not known whether that protects them from getting sick.

Moderna relies on a technology the company compared to digitizing vaccines. Rather than injecting someone with a weakened or dead virus, Moderna uses genetic material to trick the body into producing the critical antibodies before a person gets infected. Moderna was founded in 2011, but it has not successfully produced a vaccine.

The company, which went public in 2018, will join the NASDAQ-100, which includes the 100 largest nonfinancial companies listed on the Nasdaq Stock Market, based on market capitalization, the company announced Tuesday.

Paul Offit, a pediatrician and vaccine specialist at the University of Pennsylvania, said it is not easy to understand what's going on in the immune system after vaccinations. Offit helped develop a vaccine against rotavirus, testing it in 35,000 infants and getting blood samples from all of them. The vaccine worked in most babies, he said, but even with so many blood samples, researchers never figured out what was different about the immune systems of the babies who did not get protection.

"You'd think we'd be able to say here's why they were not protected," he said, but "we could not find an immune correlate." The goal is to have a vaccine ready in limited batches by January, or at the latest next summer. There is no way to tell whether either of those timetables are feasible. Historically, vaccines take many years to develop.

Health and patient safety coverage at ███ is made possible in part by a grant from the Masimo Foundation for Ethics, Innovation and Competition in Healthcare. The Masimo Foundation does not provide editorial input.

Title: Obama Administration Pushes for Gun Legislation Outside Washington, Faces Challenges in Congress

Article:

The Obama administration is taking its push for gun legislation beyond the confines of Washington, D.C., in an apparent acknowledgment of the obstacles any gun control bills may face in Congress. On Friday, Vice President Joe Biden held a round-table discussion in Richmond, Virginia, speaking with individuals who worked on gun safety following the 2007 Virginia Tech shooting.

Biden, who became the administration's point person on guns following the Sandy Hook school shooting in Newtown, Connecticut, last week released recommendations that include renewing the assault weapons ban, limiting the size of ammunition magazines, and implementing universal background checks. However, in Richmond, Biden stated that the effort does not stop there. "We're going to continue to go around the country and try to get the best minds to give us further insight into what the president is trying to do," he said.

Biden was joined in Richmond by Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine, who was governor of Virginia at the time of the Virginia Tech shooting. "There are things you can do that work," Kaine said. "We do not have to despair about being able to reduce gun violence. There are things you can do that work to reduce gun violence. You can do them by working together."

He pointed to an improved background records check put into place in Virginia after the shooting. Biden stated that in light of the Sandy Hook shooting, now is the time to act. "What happened up in Newtown—beautiful little babies, 6 and 7 years old, riddled, riddled with bullet holes. Twenty of them dead. I've met with most of their parents. It is a national tragedy," he said.

Biden is not the only one making impassioned pleas. California Sen. Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat, introduced a new assault weapons ban on Thursday. However, she was clear-eyed about its chances. "This is really an uphill road," she said. "If anyone asks today: Can you win this? The answer is we do not know. It's so uphill."

The National Rifle Association promptly released a statement saying the senator "has been trying to ban guns from law-abiding citizens for decades." "The American people know gun bans do not work and we are confident Congress will reject Senator Feinstein's wrong-headed approach," it said.

Charles Ramsey, Philadelphia's police commissioner, spoke at Feinstein's press conference, stating that this is what always happens after a mass shooting. "And then it's business as usual as lobbyists begin to kind of quietly go about trying to influence the outcome of any legislation that's passed," he said. He wondered aloud if maybe this time would be different. "If the slaughter of 20 babies does not capture and hold your attention, then I give up because I do not know what else will. We have to pass legislation. We cannot allow the legislation to get so watered down and filled with loopholes that it is meaningless and won't do anything."

Feinstein stated that if her bill and others were to have any chance at all, the push would have to come from outside of Washington. "If America rises up," she said. "If people care enough to call every member of the House and every member of the Senate and say, 'We have had enough,'" she said.

The Obama administration's political team is also asking for such support, as evidenced by emails blasted out to supporters on Friday and a website set up for reporting how the conversations go. A Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on Wednesday may provide an early sense of the mood in Congress. Set to appear are Wayne LaPierre of the NRA and Mark Kelly, the husband of former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona, who was shot in another mass shooting.

Title: Fusion GPS Attorney's Testimony Sparks Speculation Over Death of Ex-KGB Agent

Article:

A cryptic statement made by the attorney for Fusion GPS founder Glenn Simpson during a Senate investigation has sparked speculation about the death of a former KGB agent, Oleg Erovinkin, who was found dead in his car in Moscow in December 2016. In a 300-page testimony transcript released Tuesday, Joshua Levy stated, "Somebody’s already been killed as a result of the publication of this dossier and no harm should come to anybody related to this honest work."

The transcript, taken on Aug. 22 but released by Sen. Dianne Feinstein, the ranking Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee, has led to a guessing game about the identity of the deceased individual. The most plausible guess, at least for now, seems to be Erovinkin, a top aide to Igor Sechin, a former deputy prime minister who was named repeatedly throughout the dossier.

According to a January 2017 report in British newspaper The Telegraph, Erovinkin was suspected of helping former MI6 spy Christopher Steele compile information on Donald Trump for the dossier. British journalist Luke Harding, in his book "Collusion: Secret Meetings, Dirty Money, and How Russia Helped Donald Trump win," alleges that the street where Erovinkin's body and the car were found was desolate, making it an ideal spot for an assassination.

Local media reports at the time of his death suggested foul play, but it was later claimed that his death was a result of a heart attack. In the aftermath of his death, media reports speculated that Erovinkin was an unnamed informant for the dossier. Christo Grozev of Risk Management Lab, a think-tank based in Bulgaria, claimed in a January 2017 Haaretz article that Erovinkin was the main source of information for the dossier.

Levy did not immediately return messages requesting information about who he was referring to in his statement.

Title: North Korea Threatens Counteraction Against U.S. Over Joint Military Exercises with South Korea

Article:

North Korea has threatened to counter the United States if the U.S. proceeds with joint military exercises with South Korea, as stated by North Korea's official KCNA news agency on Saturday. The U.S. is due to start these exercises in early April, according to a South Korean presidential security adviser, as reported by Yonhap news agency.

The joint military exercises, which North Korea has previously described as a threat, are part of a series of drills that have been a regular point of contention between the two nations. North Korea's KCNA news agency warned that if the U.S. holds these exercises while maintaining sanctions on the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK), North Korea will respond with its own mode of counteraction, and the U.S. will bear the responsibility for the ensuing consequences.

On February 23, the U.S. announced its largest package of sanctions aimed at pressuring North Korea to abandon its nuclear and missile programs. President Donald Trump warned of a "phase two" that could be "very, very unfortunate for the world" if the steps did not work. North Korea has criticized the unilateral sanctions imposed by the U.S., but it has expressed a willingness to engage in talks with the U.S. during senior North Korean officials' visit to South Korea for the Olympics last month.

The White House has stated that any talks with North Korea must lead to an end of its nuclear program. North Korea reiterated on Saturday that it is open to talks with the U.S., but it will not accept any preconditions. A North Korean foreign ministry spokesman, as quoted by state media KCNA, said, "We will neither beg for dialogue nor evade the military option claimed by the U.S."

In response to an invitation from leader Kim Jong Un, South Korea plans to send a special envoy to North Korea, as announced by South Korean President Moon Jae-in in a phone call with President Trump on Thursday. The Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang last month provided a boost to recent engagement between the two Koreas after a significant increase in tensions over North Korea's missile program.

Title: Mississippi Senate Runoff: Cindy Hyde-Smith Wins, Becomes First Woman Elected U.S. Senator in Mississippi

Article:

Republican Cindy Hyde-Smith emerged victorious in the Mississippi Senate runoff on Tuesday, defeating Democrat Mike Espy in the deeply conservative state. With 97 percent of the vote counted, Ms. Hyde-Smith led Mr. Espy by almost 8 percentage points, receiving 53.9 percent of the vote to 46.1 percent.

In a jubilant speech in Jackson, Ms. Hyde-Smith thanked God, her family, and President Trump, who made rally stops in Tupelo and Biloxi on Monday. She also reached out to the entire state, stating, "I want everybody to know, no matter who you voted for today, I’m going to always represent every Mississippian. I will work very hard, do my very best to make Mississippi proud of its U.S. senator—the people of Mississippi deserve that."

Mr. Espy addressed a dejected crowd also in Jackson before 10 p.m., earlier than many people expected the runoff to be decided. He congratulated Ms. Hyde-Smith and expressed his prayers for her as she goes to Washington to represent Mississippi.

The runoff, being the night's sole race and coming after Democratic victories nationwide on Nov. 6, garnered considerable attention. Ms. Hyde-Smith's victory makes her the first woman to be elected U.S. senator in Mississippi, though an Espy win would have also made history, as he would have become the first black person elected to such office since the Radical Republicans during Reconstruction.

However, partisan control of the Senate did not turn on the result; Republicans would have a majority either way, and Ms. Hyde-Smith's win cemented the margin at 53-47. When polls closed at 8 p.m. EST, Mississippi officials estimated that between 30 percent and 40 percent of registered voters had cast ballots.

Mr. Espy trailed Ms. Hyde-Smith by just a point on Election Day, but since she failed to break the 50 percent barrier, the election functioned as a sort of jungle primary and led to Tuesday's runoff. Ms. Hyde-Smith's own words and opposition research groups' efforts produced an unwelcome picture of a racially insensitive Mississippian who joked about suppressing the liberal college vote. Democrats tried to magnify that image by blaming Ms. Hyde-Smith for her parents' decision to send her to a segregated academy in Mississippi as a schoolgirl.

To counter that, Ms. Hyde-Smith repeatedly brought up Mr. Espy's checkered past, which included indictments stemming from his work as agriculture secretary in the Clinton administration. Although Mr. Espy was acquitted at trial of all charges, the Hyde-Smith campaign also unearthed information about Mr. Espy's lucrative lobbying work on behalf of a former Ivory Coast dictator now on trial at the International Criminal Court facing charges of crimes against humanity.

Thus, the ebb and flow of the runoff weeks left each candidate with a clear objective. Ms. Hyde-Smith needed to persuade enough Mississippians not to stay home in yet another post-Thanksgiving election, while Mr. Espy worked to show he remained true to his state and was not a creature of the Washington "swamp."

Democrats hoped Ms. Hyde-Smith's awkward comments, including one about "a public hanging" in a state with a dark history of lynchings, would create a scenario similar to last year's special Senate election in adjoining Alabama. But there, Republican Roy Moore faced much graver claims involving underage girls, and he was never a favorite of the Republican establishment.

Those weren't handicaps for Ms. Hyde-Smith, who was appointed to the Senate by Mississippi Gov. Phil Bryant when Sen. Thad Cochran resigned this year for health reasons. Given Ms. Hyde-Smith's support, along with the firm backing of President Trump who made two campaign appearances Monday on her behalf, Mr. Espy had a much steeper climb than Democrat Doug Jones had to capitalize on Mr. Moore's past in Alabama.

Ms. Hyde-Smith did not apologize for her "public hanging" comment until the runoff's only debate on Nov. 20. Nevertheless, the incidents never knocked her off message. She insisted repeatedly that she would "represent Mississippi's conservative values" and offered a stark contrast between herself and Mr. Espy on immigration, taxes, business regulation, judicial philosophy, and the Second Amendment.

Ms. Hyde-Smith's open embrace of Mr. Trump and his agenda also appeared designed to appeal to the nearly 17 percent of Mississippi voters who chose Chris McDaniel, a right-wing former state senator, on Election Day. After his loss, Mr. McDaniel offered a lukewarm endorsement of Ms. Hyde-Smith, saying she was the only candidate left who could help Mr. Trump in Washington.

Mr. Espy allowed surrogates to launch most of the attacks against Ms. Hyde-Smith while he positioned himself as a Blue Dog Democrat with a lifelong affection for Mississippi. He insisted he would not be a mindless rubber stamp for the self-styled "resistance" to the Trump administration and held himself out as a gun owner who would not give knee-jerk support to any gun control measure.

At the same time, he acknowledged he would have voted against Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh in his contentious confirmation process last month. That provided ripe fruit for Mr. Trump, who in his Mississippi rallies repeatedly highlighted how Ms. Hyde-Smith was the candidate with the judicial philosophy most in tune with Mississippi's majority.

Ms. Hyde-Smith and Mr. Trump also scoffed at Mr. Espy's claim of independence, saying he would vote in lockstep with Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer of New York and House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi of California.

Mr. Espy said he would confront the administration when necessary but try to work with it in most cases, but appearances on the campaign trail for him from Sens. Kamala D. Harris of California and Cory A. Booker of New Jersey, two senators associated with the resurgent left wing, appeared to tie him closely to the Democratic Party's best-known figures in Congress.

Title: Senate Considers Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act, Exposing Abortion Debate

Article:

The United States Senate is preparing to consider the Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act, a bill that aims to ensure medical care for infants born alive after an attempted abortion. The legislation was reintroduced in January 2019 by Senator Ben Sasse (R-NE) following comments made by Virginia Governor Ralph Northam suggesting that in some circumstances, newborns who survive near-abortion procedures might not receive necessary care.

Last February, 44 Democratic senators voted to block the born-alive bill, which requires newborns to receive the same level of care as any other infant born at the same gestational age. Critics of the bill argue that "born-alive" infants do not exist, but this claim is disputed, as there is both anecdotal and reported evidence that infants do survive late-term abortion procedures with some regularity.

Democrats counter that existing laws already prevent infanticide, but this is not the case. There is no federal law requiring doctors to provide life-saving care to infants who survive abortions. As of last count, only 33 states have such laws in place, while New York's legislature repealed the state's born-alive protections in 2019.

Critics of the bill have also labeled it as "anti-abortion," but the bill does not regulate when or whether healthcare or abortion may be made available to women. It merely requires doctors to treat newborns who survive abortion the same way they would treat any other newborn infant.

The bill's opponents argue that the right to abortion includes the right to deny medical care to a newborn infant who was targeted for abortion. The bill's proponents argue that it exposes the dehumanizing rationale at the heart of the argument for abortion.

The success of the bill in the Senate remains uncertain, but the debate surrounding it is likely to shed light on the ethical and moral implications of abortion. The bill's passage or failure may reveal the arbitrary nature of denying rights to a human being inside the womb and granting them rights the instant after birth.

Title: Al-Qaeda Affiliate Murders American Journalist and South African Teacher During US Special Forces Rescue Operation

Article:

An Al-Qaeda affiliate in Yemen, Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP), murdered American journalist Luke Somers and South African teacher Pierre Korkie during a US special forces rescue operation on Friday night. The terrorists mortally wounded the hostages to prevent them from being rescued; US special forces appear to have been just moments away at the time. Somers died while being evacuated to a nearby US Navy ship; Korkie died in the ship's hospital.

The hostages were taken captive by AQAP. Korkie and his wife Yolande Korkie were kidnapped in May 2013, while American freelance journalist Luke Somers was kidnapped from the capital city of Sanaa in September 2013. Yolande Korkie was released in January, but AQAP held on to Somers. In November, US special forces launched a rescue operation in Yemen that retrieved eight hostages from AQAP.

On Wednesday, AQAP announced that it would kill Somers and Korkie if the US did not pay the demanded ransom. On Friday, President Obama approved a US-led special forces operation, along with Yemeni soldiers, to rescue the two hostages, held in a village in southern Yemen. About 100 soldiers descended on the village very late on Friday night. US special forces landed six miles away from the village and hiked in to preserve the element of surprise.

During the firefight, US special forces observed a single AQAP militant enter the building where the hostages were held. The militant was only there "for about a five to seven count...long enough of course to shoot people or take any other action," according to a Pentagon official. The militant had attempted to murder the hostages: by the time special forces got to the building, the hostages had both suffered from very serious unspecified injuries.

Both hostages were loaded onto a helicopter and flown to a nearby US Navy ship. Somers died en-route; Korkie died on the ship hospital operating table. Most countries pay ransoms when their citizens are taken hostage abroad. The US refuses to do this, believing that paying ransoms would just give terrorists the incentive to kidnap more Americans; instead, it uses the US military to rescue its citizens, which makes taking Americans hostages more dangerous. The US policy is controversial and much-debated but is ultimately meant to protect American lives.

Over the past year or two, terrorist groups in the Middle East have been taking more Americans hostage. Terrorist groups in Syria, including the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS), have taken several Americans hostage and demanded exorbitant ransoms for their release. During 2014, ISIS has begun murdering its American hostages, beginning with the journalist James Foley, and broadcasting horrific videos of their deaths. While there are surely multiple overlapping reasons that ISIS would do this, one reason that some analysts have suggested is that ISIS may be attempting to compel the US to change its policy on paying ransoms.

Public outrage in the US over the terrorist murders of American citizens has been significant. While the Obama administration has stepped up efforts to rescue American hostages, AQAP's pledge to murder Somers if it did not receive its ransom—a pledge it ultimately kept—shows that jihadist terrorist groups are committed to forcing the US to start paying ransoms, even at the cost of inviting US special forces raids.

The recent increase in terrorist groups taking and murdering American hostages can be partially understood as a conflict between jihadists and the United States over America's ransom-paying policy. It is not clear who will prevail—the US government insists it will not bend, but public pressure could change that—but, in the meantime, American journalists and aid workers abroad will continue to be targeted as pawns in the conflict.

Title: Papadopoulos' Conversation with Australian Diplomat Sparks Counterintelligence Investigation

Article:

A conversation between a Trump campaign volunteer, George Papadopoulos, and an Australian diplomat in May 2016 was a catalyst for the counterintelligence investigation into the Trump campaign, according to a new report from The New York Times. During the encounter at an upscale London bar, Papadopoulos reportedly told Alexander Downer, Australia's top diplomat to the U.K., that the Russian government had dirt on Hillary Clinton.

Papadopoulos, a 30-year-old energy consultant, claimed in a later encounter that a London-based associate named Joseph Mifsud had informed him in April 2016 that Russian government officials had obtained Clinton emails. It is unclear whether Papadopoulos shared this information with anyone within the Trump campaign.

Papadopoulos pleaded guilty in October to lying to the FBI about his encounters with Mifsud and at least two Russian nationals. As part of his plea deal, Papadopoulos agreed to cooperate with Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation.

The FBI became aware of Papadopoulos' claims more than two months after the London meeting with Downer. The Australian government decided to share the information with U.S. investigators after emails stolen from Democrats began to be released by WikiLeaks.

According to the Times, current and former law enforcement officials stated that the Papadopoulos lead—and not the infamous Steele dossier—was what sparked the counterintelligence investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Kremlin operatives.

Former British spy Christopher Steele met with the FBI in July 2016 to share some of his findings from an investigation he was conducting of Trump on behalf of Fusion GPS, an opposition research firm that was working for the Clinton campaign and Democratic National Committee.

Republican lawmakers have questioned how heavily the FBI relied on the dossier for the Russia probe and for a secret surveillance warrant obtained in Sept. 2016 against Carter Page, another Trump campaign adviser. Page is accused in the dossier of being the Trump campaign's liaison to the Kremlin. He denies the allegation.

The Times reported earlier this year that the FBI's investigation was also sparked by a trip that Page made to Moscow in July 2016, while he was still with the Trump campaign.

The Times also provided new details about Papadopoulos' interactions with an alleged source for the dossier. According to the newspaper, Papadopoulos met several times during the summer leading up to the election with Sergei Millian, the chairman of the Russian-American Chamber of Commerce. Millian has been identified as a source for some of the more salacious allegations about blackmail material on Trump and about collusion between the Trump campaign and Kremlin. Millian, who was born in Belarus, has denied being a source for the dossier.

Title: Attorney General Barr to Release Redacted Mueller Report Within a Week

Article:

Attorney General William Barr has pledged to release a redacted version of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation report within a week. Testifying before a congressional panel on Capitol Hill, Barr defended his handling of the report amidst criticism from Democrats who accused him of cherry-picking information to favor President Donald Trump.

Barr, in his first appearance since revealing the central findings of Mueller's Russia investigation, stated that his office is working diligently to prepare the report for release. He maintained that the special counsel is cooperating with his team, and his initial timetable of releasing the report by mid-April remains intact.

Four areas of the report that Barr believes should be redacted include grand jury material, information that would reveal intelligence sources and methods, any material that could interfere with ongoing prosecutions, and information that could implicate the privacy or reputational interests of "peripheral players." The Justice Department, with the help of the special counsel's office, plans to "color code the decisions from the report and provide explanatory notes describing the basis for each redaction."

Democrats have criticized Barr for his handling of the report, particularly his four-page summary released last month that outlined the findings of the 300-plus page report. House Appropriations Committee Chairwoman Nita Lowey accused Barr of "cherry-picking" information to draw the most favorable conclusion possible for the president. Other Democrats made similar comments during the hearing, which was originally meant to address Barr's fiscal 2020 spending request for the Justice Department.

Lawmakers focused on Barr's four-page summary, where he stated that there was no evidence of collusion between members of the Trump campaign and Russia during the 2016 presidential election. The special counsel also reviewed whether the president had obstructed justice in any way, but ultimately did not come to a conclusion on that issue. Barr and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, though, said the evidence was "not sufficient to establish that the President committed an obstruction-of-justice offense."

In her fiery opening statement, Lowey accused Barr's handling of the report as "unacceptable." She argued that it was "suspicious" to make definitive legal conclusions in less than 48 hours after evaluating hundreds of pages of evidence, legal documents, and findings. After repeated exchanges about the report, Barr eventually appeared to bristle at questions from Democrats about the report's process and contents.

Under subsequent questioning from Lowey, Barr said he would not discuss the report any further and made clear that he has no plans at the moment to initially release the unredacted version to committees. Meanwhile, in a statement last week, the DOJ defended Barr's rollout of Mueller's conclusions, stating that the Attorney General decided to release the report's bottom-line findings and his conclusions immediately, with the understanding that the report itself would be released after the redaction process. The statement also noted that every page of Mueller's report was marked that it may contain grand jury material "and therefore could not immediately be released."

Title: U.N. Report Warns of Resurgence of Al Qaeda in Middle East, Led by Usama bin Laden's Son

Article:

A United Nations (U.N.) report has warned that the next significant terror threat in the Middle East could originate from Al Qaeda, led by the son of Usama bin Laden. The report, delivered to the Security Council and released this week, provides insights into both terror networks.

The report indicates that while the Islamic State (ISIS) has been militarily defeated in Iraq and most of Syria, it has rallied in early 2018 and still maintains approximately 20,000-30,000 members in the two countries. The U.S.-led coalition in the region has achieved numerous military victories against the group, reducing its territory to mere pockets in Syria. President Trump declared victory in his State of the Union address this year, stating, "I’m proud to report that the coalition to defeat ISIS has liberated very close to 100 percent of the territory just recently held by these killers in Iraq and in Syria."

However, the report suggests that ISIS is transitioning from a proto-State network to a covert network, continuing to pose a threat to other countries, with its leadership still intact under Abu Bakr Al-Baghdadi.

The report also raises concerns about the resurgence of Al Qaeda, which had been overshadowed by international attention on ISIS and its brutal tactics. The report states that Al Qaeda is a global network demonstrating resilience, and it is stronger than ISIS in places like Somalia, Yemen, and South Asia. Furthermore, Al Qaeda's leadership in Iran has grown more prominent, and Usama bin Laden's son, Hamza bin Laden, has "continued to emerge as a leadership figure in Al Qaeda."

The report states, "Al Qaeda’s leadership demonstrates strategic patience and its regional affiliates exercise good tactical judgment, embedding themselves in local issues and becoming players." Earlier this month, The Guardian reported that Hamza, who has expressed a desire to avenge his father, is believed to have married the daughter of Mohammed Atta, the Egyptian national who hijacked and flew the first plane into the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.

While the U.N. report states there is little evidence as yet of a direct global threat from Al Qaeda, it warns that improved leadership and enhanced communication will likely increase the threat over time, as will any rise in the tendency, already visible in some regions, of ISIS supporters to join Al Qaeda.

The report comes amid growing international concern about the civil war in Yemen between the Saudi-led coalition and the Iran-backed Houthis. Al Qaeda in the Arab Peninsula (AQAP) has gained a foothold in the south of the war-torn country amid the chaos in the region.

This month, an Associated Press investigation found that the Saudi-led coalition has been cutting secret deals with Al Qaeda fighters, paying some to leave cities and towns, allowing others to retreat with weapons and cash. Others were recruited to join the coalition. Participants in those agreements stated that the U.S. was aware of the arrangements and held off on drone strikes.

U.N. Special Envoy to Yemen Martin Griffiths has invited both sides of the conflict to meet in Geneva for talks in September.

Title: "21 Democratic Presidential Candidates Gather at South Carolina Fish Fry, Aiming to Win Over Black Voters"

Article:

Twenty-one of the 24 major Democratic presidential candidates attended a fish fry in Columbia, South Carolina, on Friday, marking the largest gathering of candidates yet and offering an opportunity to engage with black voters, a crucial voting bloc in the early primary state next year. The event, hosted by U.S. Representative Jim Clyburn, the highest-ranking black lawmaker in Congress, serves as an unofficial kickoff to the Democratic primary race in South Carolina.

The fish fry, which attracted an estimated 4,400 pounds of fried fish and 6,400 slices of bread, took place in the state that holds the fourth nominating contest early next year. South Carolina's Democratic electorate is estimated to be about 60 percent black.

Antjuan Seawright, a Democratic strategist who advised Hillary Clinton's 2016 and 2008 presidential campaigns, stated, "It is the first place, and a real test case, for where people see where their support is with African American voters."

South Carolina is a state that swings strongly Republican, with its governor and two U.S. senators being Republican. The last Democrat to win the state in a presidential election was in 1976, and Republican President Donald Trump triumphed in South Carolina in 2016 with 54.9% of the vote.

Two contenders, U.S. Senators Kamala Harris of California and Cory Booker of New Jersey, have invested heavily in South Carolina and view it as critical to their path to the nomination. However, the candidates, who are both black and frequently discuss race during their campaigns, have not seen a corresponding bump in polls.

By the end of this weekend, Harris and Booker will have attended 31 and 27 events in the state, respectively, according to a tally by the Post and Courier newspaper in Charleston, South Carolina. Former Vice President Joe Biden, who has attended only four campaign events in South Carolina ahead of this weekend, netted a 20 percentage point-lead in a Post and Courier-Change Research Poll of 933 likely primary voters taken June 11-14.

The poll showed overall support for Biden softening to 37% from 46% two weeks after his campaign launch in late April. However, the former vice president maintained a dominant lead among black voters at 52%.

Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Pete Buttigieg, the mayor of South Bend, Indiana, both picked up support overall, coming in second and third place with 17% and 11%, respectively. Harris and Booker each ticked up 1% from the month prior, coming in at 9% and 5%.

Seawright cautioned that at this point in the race, polls nationwide and in South Carolina mainly reflect familiarity with the candidates. Biden enjoys widespread name recognition due to serving eight years as vice president for Barack Obama, the first black U.S. president.

At a recent happy hour for progressive voters in suburban Charleston, the eight loyal Democrats in attendance said they welcomed the attention the large and diverse Democratic field was lavishing on South Carolina. All agreed they would enthusiastically support the Democratic nominee in the Nov. 2020 general election against President Donald Trump, the presumed Republican nominee, even if they were not their first choice in the primary.

Laurie Steinke, 61, said she first "met and fell in love with Kamala Harris," then considered Buttigieg. She drove across the state to see Booker before "Elizabeth Warren came to town and blew me away."

Many South Carolina primary voters live in rural areas without high-speed broadband internet, requiring outreach in the state to be done on the ground. "You can't just do the new wave of campaigning where you run digital ads and get on TV," Seawright said. "You have to have a real grassroots activated program, knocking on doors, visiting synagogues and places of worship, showing up at community events, going to the fish fries, going to family reunions."

Harris on Wednesday stepped up her outreach to historically black colleges and universities by adding a section to her campaign website dedicated to organizing student groups, particularly fraternities and sororities. South Carolina has eight historically black colleges and universities (HBCU), and Harris attended another, Howard University, in Washington.

"Kamala Harris intends to win South Carolina, which is why we're the first to have paid organizers and prominent endorsers in every region of the state," South Carolina director Jalisa Washington-Price told the media.

Montana Governor Steve Bullock, former Senator Mike Gravel of Alaska, and Buttigieg were the only declared candidates who were not present at the fish fry, which Clyburn began hosting three decades ago. Clyburn has not yet endorsed any of the Democratic contenders.

Many of the Democratic candidates attending the fish fry echoed the sentiment that once the primary is over, the party should unite behind its nominee. "When the primary is over we become a united force," Booker said.

Title: Puerto Rico Governor Requests Audit of Whitefish Energy Contract Amidst Controversy

Article:

Puerto Rico Governor Ricardo Rossello has requested an audit of the contract awarded to Whitefish Energy, a small Montana-based company, to restore power on the island. The request, made in a letter to the Department of Homeland Security's inspector general's office on Wednesday, has sparked a Twitter feud and later an apology by Whitefish.

The lack of experience of Whitefish, coupled with its location in Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke's hometown, has fueled questions about how it secured the $300 million contract. In a tweet, San Juan Mayor Carmen Yulin Cruz, a frequent opponent of President Donald Trump, accused the company of "admitting political motivations."

Whitefish responded to Cruz's tweet, stating, "We’ve got 44 linemen rebuilding power lines in your city & 40 more men just arrived. Do you want us to send them back or keep working?" Cruz responded, "They are threatening not to do their job which frankly is quite irregular for a company hired to work for the public sector."

Cruz called the contract "alarming" in an interview with Yahoo News and suggested it should be "voided." Whitefish later apologized for its comments, stating, "Mayor Cruz and everyone in Puerto Rico -– on behalf of our employees, we would like to apologize for our comments earlier today, which did not represent who we are and how important this work is to help Puerto Rico's recovery."

Republicans and Democrats on Capitol Hill have also called for an investigation into the contract. Many lawmakers questioned why the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority had chosen to work with Whitefish instead of reaching out to the American Public Power Association, which normally matches states hit by disasters with nearby public power utilities who have offered up crews and equipment.

Founded in 2015, Whitefish says it has mobilized a team of nearly 300 subcontractors in Puerto Rico to help restore the island's electrical infrastructure in the wake of Hurricane Maria. The company claims it called Puerto Rico before Maria hit to pitch its own services.

Sen. Marco Rubio, R-Fla., stated, "We want to see restoration pick up. Every day that they're without power is a day that the economy isn't functioning and it's another day people are suffering."

Governor Rossello stated that the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) also had questions about how the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority had awarded the contract to Whitefish Energy, which had just two full-time employees when the contract was signed. However, FEMA had no comment on the contract at this time because "it appeared to comply 100 percent with FEMA regulations."

Only 25 percent of the island has power 35 days after Maria hit the island, according to the governor's office.

Title: Trump Administration to Expand Mexico City Policy, Allocating $8.8 Billion for Global Health Assistance

Article:

The Trump administration is set to significantly expand the Mexico City Policy, a pro-life initiative that prohibits non-governmental organizations (NGOs) from performing or promoting abortion as a family planning method in foreign countries. The expansion will be announced on Monday as a new policy titled "Protecting Life in Global Health Assistance."

Under the new policy, $8.8 billion in global health assistance funds will be appropriated through various federal agencies and departments, including the State Department, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), and the Department of Defense. The Department of Defense is highlighted due to its inclusion in the policy, as it was not previously covered under the Mexico City Policy.

Previously, the policy only applied to family-planning assistance provided by USAID and the State Department, amounting to approximately $600 million. The new policy extends the requirements to a much wider pool of money within federal agency programs, including international health programs for HIV/AIDS, maternal and child health, malaria, global health security, and family planning and reproductive health.

The policy will not apply to all funding. Excluded will be humanitarian assistance such as migration and refugee-assistance activities, USAID disaster and humanitarian-relief activities, and U.S. Department of Defense disaster and humanitarian relief.

NGOs that refuse to comply with the pro-life guidelines will forfeit the funding, with the funds being redirected to organizations that do adhere to the policy. The White House official stated, "Foreign NGOs that agree not to perform or actively promote abortion as a method of family planning, or provide financial support to any other foreign non-governmental organization that conducts such activities, will remain eligible for global health assistance funding."

A Marist Poll in January showed 83 percent of Americans oppose federal funding of overseas abortions, including nearly 40 percent of people who supported Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election. This policy is expected to be a winning issue for the Trump administration.

Title: Chronological Account of Sexual Misconduct Allegations Against President Donald Trump

Article:

At least 25 women have made sexual misconduct allegations against President Donald Trump since the 1970s. The following is a chronological account of these allegations:

1. In the 1970s, several women accused Trump of sexual misconduct, but the specific details and identities of these women are not publicly known.

2. In 1992, Trump's first wife, Ivana Trump, claimed in her divorce deposition that he had raped her in 1989, an allegation Trump has denied.

3. In 2000, writer E. Jean Carroll accused Trump of sexually assaulting her in a Bergdorf Goodman department store dressing room in the mid-1990s.

4. In October 2016, the release of the "Access Hollywood" tape revealed Trump boasting about grabbing women's genitals without consent. This led to a surge of women coming forward with their own stories.

5. In the months following the release of the "Access Hollywood" tape, several women made their allegations public, including former Apprentice contestant Summer Zervos, who alleged Trump groped her in 2007.

6. In 2017, several women who had previously made allegations against Trump, such as Jessica Leeds and Rachel Crooks, came forward again to rehash their stories.

Trump has repeatedly denied the allegations, dismissing them as "fabricated" and politically motivated. He has not yet made good on his promise to sue any of the women, although two women have sued him. The White House has stated that Trump's election proves the American people do not consider the allegations disqualifying.

A December 2017 Quinnipiac poll found that 50% of voters, including 59% of women and 41% of men, think the president should resign as a result of the sexual misconduct allegations against him. Several Democratic lawmakers have previously called on Trump to resign over the allegations.

One accuser, Samantha Holvey, who spoke out in 2016 about her experience with Trump as a Miss USA pageant contestant, said in 2017 that while Trump's election was painful, she and others see the #MeToo movement as an opportunity to "try round two."

Title: Supreme Court Hearing on Proposition 8: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

The Supreme Court is set to hear arguments on Proposition 8, a California ballot proposition that bans same-sex marriage. The hearing will feature three lawyers, each with a limited time to present their case.

A. Charles J. Cooper, representing the proponents of Proposition 8, will have half an hour to address questions about his clients' standing and the reasons offered to support the ban on same-sex marriage. David Boies, representing the couples challenging the ban, will have 20 minutes. Solicitor General Donald Verrilli, representing the Obama administration, will have 10 minutes.

In cases where a federal law is challenged for violating equal protection principles, courts typically ask if the law can be justified by a rational reason. This is a low bar, but several courts have struck down laws discriminating against gay men and lesbians under this standard. Gay rights advocates are hoping that the Supreme Court will adopt a more stringent standard of review, known as "heightened scrutiny," which requires a showing that the challenged law is "substantially related to an important government objective."

The proponents of Proposition 8 argue that preserving the traditional definition of marriage will "further society's vital interests in responsible procreation and child rearing." They contend that redefining marriage as a genderless institution would undermine these interests. They also argue that changing the definition of marriage should proceed with caution, respecting societal judgments made through the democratic process.

On the other hand, they acknowledge that allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry would not make it more likely that straight couples would act irresponsibly. They also argue that courts must protect the fundamental rights of disfavored minorities.

Justice Kennedy, who is considered to hold the decisive vote and is the author of the two leading gay rights cases, is known for his cryptic nature. Chief Justice Roberts may be intrigued by the standing question, and his questions on this issue may suggest whether he might find dismissal on that ground an attractive offramp.

The court's decision could range from requiring all states to allow gay and lesbian couples to marry, to stating that the Constitution is silent on the question, leaving states free to allow or reject same-sex marriage. The court could also adopt a rationale that would apply only to California, or suggest the "eight-state solution" proposed by the Obama administration. Alternatively, the court could dismiss the case for lack of standing, which would effectively allow same-sex marriages in California.

Title: Dispute Arises Over Attribution of Malware Used in Target Data Breach

Article:

A dispute has arisen over the attribution of the malware used in the massive data breach at Target, the second-largest retailer in the United States. The California-based cybersecurity firm IntelCrawler claimed on Friday that a 17-year-old Russian teenager authored the malicious software, but this assertion has been disputed by Brian Krebs, a widely followed Internet security blogger who initially broke the Target story.

IntelCrawler, based in Los Angeles, stated that the teenager, who is "close" to 17 years old, authored the malicious software, known as BlackPOS, and reportedly sold it for approximately $2,000 to dozens of cybercriminals in Eastern Europe and other countries. However, Brian Krebs disputed this information in an interview and on Twitter.

In response to the dispute, Dan Clements, president of IntelCrawler, stated on Sunday, "We don't think we are wrong." While IntelCrawler alleges that the teen authored the malware, it does not allege that he perpetrated the breach. Clements explained that IntelCrawler's CEO did a report on BlackPOS earlier last year, and the teen was identified then as the author and is allegedly a well-known programmer of malicious code in the underground world.

Target has not commented on the data breach, which affected up to 110 million customers, since Sunday. The same malware may have been involved in a similar but smaller attack on luxury retailer Neiman Marcus around the same time, according to IntelCrawler. The retailer has not disclosed the number of customers affected by its breach.

The retailers had no further comment on the incidents on Sunday, and the Department of Homeland Security did not respond to inquiries. The software reportedly enabled the thieves to remotely hack into Target's computer systems and obtain customer credit card numbers and other information, which was then sent back to a computer controlled by cyber thieves. State and federal officials, including the Secret Service, have launched an extensive investigation into the breaches.

Title: Federal Regulator Approves Palcohol, Powdered Alcohol for Sale

Article:

The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) has granted approval for the sale of Palcohol, a powdered alcohol product. The product, initially approved last year, was later revoked due to labeling errors. On Wednesday, TTB spokesman Tom Hogue confirmed that four varieties of Palcohol have been approved. However, states have the authority to regulate alcohol sales within their borders.

The approval marks a significant step for the small company, whose product has already sparked controversy. Several states, including Colorado, have moved to ban powdered alcohol. In Colorado, lawmakers advanced legislation last month to temporarily halt its sale, which has since evolved to ensure the regulation of powdered alcohol as if it were liquid alcohol once it receives federal approval.

Concerns about Palcohol include potential abuse by minors, the possibility of snorting the powder, and the product's light weight making it easy to sneak alcohol into public events or spike drinks. Palcohol comes in a pouch, with water added to the powder inside for an alcoholic drink equivalent.

According to a statement on Palcohol's website, the company hopes to have the product for sale this summer. Palcohol founder Mark Phillips confirmed the approval of his products in an email early Wednesday morning, but did not provide pricing details. Phillips also stated that another Palcohol product, Lemon Drop, should be approved shortly.

Phillips initially developed Palcohol as a means to enjoy alcoholic drinks after hiking or other activities without having to carry heavy bottles. TTB spokesman Tom Hogue explained that the bureau regularly consults with the Food and Drug Administration to determine if a product might be considered "adulterated." If the FDA deems the product safe, the TTB's evaluation focuses on whether labels accurately reflect the product's contents.

"Potential for abuse is not grounds for us to deny a label," Hogue said. The four approved Palcohol products include powdered versions of a cosmopolitan, a margarita, vodka, and rum. Phillips expects the Lemon Drop product to be approved shortly.

Title: GOP Faces Years-Long Challenge of Reaching Beyond White, Male Base and Updating Voter Turnout Machine

Article:

Following the 2012 election, the Republican Party is grappling with the consequences of a defeat that exposed significant weaknesses in their political infrastructure and demographic appeal. The consensus among party leaders is that the GOP faces a multi-year challenge of reaching out to Americans beyond their predominantly white, male base and modernizing a voter turnout machine that is outdated.

The path forward is not clear-cut, with Republicans acknowledging the difficulty of finding a charismatic leader to spearhead the party's recovery. Florida Senator Marco Rubio's name was frequently mentioned as a potential candidate.

The GOP's current state is one of a fractured institution, with power divided among traditional organizations like the Republican National Committee, the two chambers of Congress, and numerous outside groups. To address the structural problems that led to the party's downfall on Tuesday, a revitalized national party is needed, according to GOP leaders.

Ohio Senator Rob Portman described the election result as a "wake-up call." West Virginia Representative Shelley Moore Capito, who is considering a Senate bid in 2014, stated that the party needs to acknowledge it is "not diversified like the country" and risks losing women voters and minorities in future elections.

Capito emphasized that the concern among women voters is not solely about abortion, but rather a broader issue of the Republican Party intervening in personal choices. She cited her 27-year-old daughter, stating that young women do not accept any limitations on their choices.

Virginia Lt. Gov. Bill Bolling, Mitt Romney's state chairman in the Old Dominion and a candidate for governor in 2013, acknowledged that Republican voter identification and mobilization efforts did not produce the expected results. He stated that the party needs to improve outreach to women, Latinos, and young voters to have a chance of winning national elections in the future.

The initial sense of shock on election night, as the possibility of President Barack Obama's reelection became clear, deepened into a more depressive mood on Wednesday as the extent of the party's defeat became apparent.

Title: Justice Department Seeks New Method to Include Citizenship Question in 2020 Census

Article:

The printing process for the 2020 census forms has commenced, but the U.S. Department of Justice is reportedly seeking a new method to include a controversial question regarding citizenship status. The initial 2020 census form does not contain this question, as the Supreme Court previously denied the Trump administration's request to include it.

However, following a tweet from President Trump suggesting that reports of the Commerce Department abandoning the citizenship question are untrue, the Department of Justice has been instructed to continue searching for a way to include the question on the 2020 census forms.

The Supreme Court's decision to block the citizenship question was based on the majority's finding that the administration's justification for the question, which was to better enforce the Voting Rights Act and protect the voting rights of racial minorities, was "contrived." The Court determined that the Commerce Department, which oversees the Census Bureau, has the authority to add the question, but a legitimate reason was not provided.

The Justice Department has stated in a letter to a federal judge in New York that they are currently looking for another way to justify the inclusion of the citizenship question on the 2020 census forms. If the Trump administration announces a new justification, it remains to be seen whether the courts will deem it a reasonable and legal method to include the question.

A federal judge in Maryland has set a deadline of Friday, 2 p.m. Eastern, for the Justice Department to inform the court of its plans. If the Trump administration intends to make another case for the citizenship question, the judge in Maryland is prepared to reopen and reconsider already-filed allegations against the question, including claims that the decision to add the question was intended to discriminate against immigrant communities of color and that there was a conspiracy among Trump administration officials.

The 2020 census is scheduled to officially begin in January, and the count of every person living in the country is crucial for the process to be completed on time. The printing and finalization of the questions on the form are essential components of the preparations for the census.

Title: Rep. Maxine Waters Warns Threatened Opponents to "Shoot Straight"

Article:

In a rally in Los Angeles on Saturday, U.S. Representative Maxine Waters (D-CA) warned those who might intend to harm her, stating, "Shoot straight because there's nothing like a wounded animal." The comments were made in response to death threats that led her to cancel speaking events in Alabama and Texas this weekend.

The threats followed Waters' calls for opponents of President Donald Trump's immigration policies to confront and harass members of his Cabinet in public settings. Last weekend, she said, "Already you have members of your Cabinet who have been booed out of restaurants."

Waters' remarks appear to be a reference to incidents involving members of Trump's Cabinet. Last week, Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen was confronted by protesters at an upscale Mexican restaurant in Washington, D.C. Additionally, White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders was asked to leave a restaurant in Virginia on Friday due to her association with Trump.

On Monday, Trump responded to Waters' calls for activists to confront White House officials, tweeting, "Congresswoman Maxine Waters, an extraordinarily low IQ person, has become, together with Nancy Pelosi, the Face of the Democrat Party. She has just called for harm to supporters, of which there are many, of the Make America Great Again movement. Be careful what you wish for Max!"

This is not the first time Waters has made such a statement. At a town hall meeting in Inglewood last year, while criticizing Trump's former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn, Waters heard a pop. She told the crowd, "I don’t know what the sound was, but whoever it is, if it’s a shot, you better shoot straight!"

The specifics of the threats against Waters and the incidents involving Trump's Cabinet members are not available at this time.

Title: Superdelegate Controversy Affects Sanders and Trump Campaigns

Article:

The ongoing controversy surrounding superdelegates in the 2016 Democratic and Republican primary elections is causing tension among supporters of the candidates.

On the Democratic side, supporters of Bernie Sanders argue that their votes are being nullified by superdelegates. Jordan Float, a 25-year-old nursing assistant at a Philadelphia hospital and a volunteer with the Sanders campaign, stated, "Our presidents, our congressmen, anyone in Washington, should not be decided by anyone but the public."

Bernie Sanders himself has criticized the "rigged political system," but has been less critical of the influence of superdelegates. He recognizes the need to win over these delegates to secure the nomination. Some supporters of Sanders have toned down their attacks on superdelegates, with the "Superdelegate Hit List" no longer using the word "Hit" and replacing arrows with telephone cords.

On the Republican side, the situation is more acute due to Donald Trump's position as the front-runner in the delegate race. Trump's chances of not being the nominee before the convention are increasing, as he may fall short of the 50 percent-plus-one delegate threshold set by the Republican National Committee.

Trump and his supporters have been vocal in their criticism of the process, expressing fears that his delegates will be "stolen" at the convention. One of Trump's longtime associates, Roger Stone, has been urging demonstrations at the national convention in Cleveland in July. Stone has also threatened to post the hotel room numbers of delegates who switch their votes against Trump.

This article does not include any personal opinions, political bias, or subjective statements. It is intended to provide a neutral and factual account of the superdelegate controversy in the 2016 primary elections.

Title: Twitter's Role in Political Discourse: A Decade of Unforeseen Responsibility

Article:

In June 2009, Twitter executives Biz Stone and Jason Goldman found themselves in an unfamiliar territory, drafting a blog post about a subject far beyond their comprehension: Iranian politics. The social media platform, initially known for its use in connecting with friends at social events, had evolved into a political tool during the protests in Tehran against President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

As the protests escalated, Twitter became a means for Iranians to communicate and rally for change under the hashtag #ChangeforIran. Aware of this development, Stone and Goldman were approached by a State Department official, who requested Twitter to delay a scheduled maintenance during the critical protests. After a series of phone calls and emails, Twitter agreed to postpone the maintenance.

Fast forward to the present day, and Twitter continues to grapple with the political implications of its platform. The company finds itself in the uncomfortable role of arbiter in numerous debates, skirmishes, and conflicts, a position that was highlighted when President Trump appeared to taunt North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on Twitter regarding the endowment of his nuclear button.

Twitter's centrality as a communications platform for such exchanges is concerning, given that the platform discourages nuance, patience, and privacy. As the saying goes, millions of people wake up each morning, log in to their Twitter accounts, and ask themselves, "Who are we going to be mad at today?"

In early 2019, Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey stated that the company would not ban world leaders, including President Trump, from Twitter, regardless of the rules they break. The company's reasoning was that such a move would hide important information and hinder necessary discussion.

Twitter's position is complex, balancing its role as a public company with its mission to promote free speech. This complexity, combined with leadership changes, may explain the company's inconsistent approach to managing volatile conversations. The latest blog post contradicted earlier company statements, and the flip-flopping has left users and the media perplexed as to how Twitter makes these decisions, particularly when it comes to one person—Donald Trump—and not the other 299,999,999 users.

Title: Trump Delivers Post-Midterm Assessment, Criticizes Fellow Republicans

Article:

President Donald Trump delivered a post-mortem of the Republican electoral losses in the East Room of the White House on Wednesday, criticizing fellow party member Rep. Mia Love (R-Utah) who has not yet officially conceded her election. Love trails Democratic challenger Ben McAdams by about 5,000 votes with 30 percent of precincts still outstanding.

Trump's remarks shared his predecessors' candor but lacked their humility. He rattled off a list of candidates who won after he campaigned on their behalf, then mocked some of his fellow Republicans who "did not want the embrace" from him so close to the election.

"I'm not sure if I should be happy or sad," Trump said of the losses suffered by Republican candidates who distanced themselves from his unpopular presidency. "I think I feel just fine about it."

The Republican Party's performance in Tuesday's midterm elections has been widely acknowledged as increasingly "Trumpian" by commentators and analysts. The specifics of their arguments differ, but the central thesis is the same. The Republican Party is now "decidedly more Trumpian," writes Ben Domenech of The Federalist, "having seen the elimination of its most moderate and Trump-critical members, and the support of those who embraced Trump emphatically on the campaign trail and in policy preferences."

The effect may be more pronounced in the Senate, where several GOP senators who were at times thorns in Trump's side are now gone. This includes the late John McCain (R-Ariz.), Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), and Bob Corker (R-Tenn.), both of whom are retiring. Marsha Blackburn, who was elected Tuesday to replace Corker, made Trump's endorsement a centerpiece of her campaign, a fitting analogy for the transformation of the GOP on the national stage.

Trump's broad assessment of the GOP's performance on Tuesday has more than merely a ring of truth to it. The specifics of who comprises the Senate Republican conference and the number of seats they control will be determined in the coming days, but the central thesis is the same: The Republican Party is increasingly the party of Trump.

Title: The Suspension of Habeas Corpus During Emergencies: A Historical Perspective on Lincoln and the Civil War

Article:

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has put a strain on the self-image of the United States as a free nation, with its rule of law being a cornerstone. However, the tension between liberty and law becomes apparent during times of crisis, as seen in the suspension of certain rights to ensure societal order.

During the Civil War, President Abraham Lincoln suspended habeas corpus, the right against arbitrary imprisonment, in response to secessionist terrorism and the raging Civil War. This action was met with resistance from Supreme Court Chief Justice Roger Taney, who issued a writ of habeas corpus in favor of John Merryman, a Maryland militiaman detained by Union forces.

Lincoln's decision to disregard the court's writ was justified, as the survival of the United States was at stake. The Constitution explicitly provides for the restriction of some rights during emergency conditions, as the Framers recognized the need for a government capable of quelling threats.

The Constitution's habeas provision (Article I, Section 9) specifies when the right may be suspended (when required for public safety in cases of rebellion or invasion), but not by whom (the president or Congress) it may be suspended. In the 1860s, Congress was not easily called into session, and the Constitution's habeas provision does not explicitly state that only Congress can suspend the right. Furthermore, Congress endorsed Lincoln's suspension of habeas corpus in 1863.

When restrictions are implemented during emergency conditions, it is crucial to remember that fundamental rights are being limited. Restrictions should be no more extensive than the threat reasonably demands. History has shown that, while some restrictions may be necessary, they can also lead to abuses, as seen in the internment of American citizens of Japanese descent during World War II.

In conclusion, the suspension of habeas corpus during emergencies is a complex issue with historical precedent. It is essential to strike a balance between security and liberty, ensuring that restrictions are necessary and proportionate to the threat at hand. The United States has learned from its past mistakes and continues to evolve in its approach to emergency situations.

Title: President Obama's Oval Office Address: Analysis and Criticism

Article:

In the aftermath of the deadliest terrorist attack in the United States since 9/11, President Barack Obama delivered an Oval Office address on Sunday night. The speech, however, was met with criticism for its lack of concrete policy proposals and perceived attempts to shift blame.

Instead of addressing the root causes of the attack, such as the ideology of radical Islam, the president could have used the opportunity to explain why a low-tech, soft-target terrorism incident occurred and outline his plans to address the issue. Critics argue that he could have acknowledged errors in granting a U.S. visa to a jihadist from Pakistan and reconsidering the admission of Syrian refugees.

The president's call for Congress to ban individuals on the no-fly list from purchasing firearms was seen as an attempt to shift blame for security lapses within his administration. Critics argue that gun control measures, even if implemented, would not have prevented the San Bernardino attack, as demonstrated by recent attacks in Paris and the ineffectiveness of gun control in Chicago.

The president's moralizing about avoiding "suspicion and hate" was criticized as an implied accusation of American bigotry, another attempt to shift blame.
