Manufacturing cut 6,000 jobs, indicating the struggling global economy and U.S. trade fight with China are taking a bigger toll. Retail, which is shrinking as shoppers shift their purchases online, cut 12,000 jobs after shedding 20,000 in February.

The average hourly earnings rose 4 cents to $27.70, lowering the annual gain from a 10-year high of 3.4% to 3.2%. Wage growth has picked up as employers compete for a dwindling supply of available workers. The faster pay increases haven't yet prompted most companies to pass their rising labor costs onto consumers through higher prices, keeping inflation subdued.

However, further earnings gains could lead to stronger inflation, posing a dilemma for the Federal Reserve that has vowed to remain patient and forecast no interest rate hikes this year. The March jobs report helps keep the Fed in its market-friendly wait-and-see mode.

The share of American adults working or looking for jobs fell to 63% from 63.2%. This could indicate that labor force participation is resuming its longer-term decline as baby boomers retire. A lower participation rate means a smaller labor supply for employers, which could push up wages and inflation further.

This was about as ideal a jobs report as markets could expect. Job growth bounced back forcefully from its poor February performance, alleviating worries of an imminent downturn in the economy. Yet, yearly wage growth, while still healthy, retreated some from the 10-year high reached two months ago. That should keep the Fed on hold for now. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up about 20 points, or less than 0.1%, in mid-day trading.

The report offers no reason for the Fed to consider cutting rates, as President Trump has urged. "Today's data supports our call that the Fed's next move is more likely to be a hike than a cut," Bank of America wrote in a research note.

Title: House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Defends GOP Tax Overhaul Plan Amid Middle-Class Tax Increase Criticism

Article:

Rep. Kevin Brady, the House's top tax-code writer, defended the chamber's tax overhaul plan on Sunday, countering criticism that many middle-class Americans will pay more, potentially turning voters against the Republican Party. Brady, R-Texas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, told Fox News Sunday that he believes there is tax relief for families across various income levels.

The lawmaker's defense comes in response to criticism from congressional Democrats and two analyses, including one in The New York Times that concluded one-third of middle-class families will face a tax increase. Brady disputed the analysis, stating, "They're describing an America that doesn't exist—one where the economy never grows and one where your paycheck stays stagnant no matter what happens."

Senate Democrats have also criticized any GOP plan that will eliminate state and local tax deductions, warning that congressional Republicans representing suburban districts will face voter backlash for their support. Maryland Sen. Chris Van Hollen, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, told Fox on Sunday, "The reality is many middle-class families are going to end up paying more."

The GOP-controlled House and Senate have each introduced separate plans, which must pass in each chamber before leaders can craft a compromise bill that gets passed by the entire Congress and put on President Trump's desk before the end of the year. The major differences between the plans include the Senate bill wanting to delay a corporate tax cut by one year and eliminate all state and local tax deductions.

Brady emphasized the common ground between the plans, stating, "There are some [differences], but there is far more common ground." He also essentially guaranteed the House plan will keep some state and local deductions and was optimistic about his committee voting on the plan in the coming days, with final passage before a self-imposed Thanksgiving deadline.

Brady also disputed analysis that the GOP plan will increase the federal deficit by $1.5 trillion, arguing that critics don't take into account that the tax cuts will stimulate economic growth. Brady repeated what House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis., and others in the GOP leadership have said about the plan, stating that it increases paychecks and allows Americans to decide what to do with their money before the IRS gets its hands on it.

Title: George Washington University Law Professor Warns of Dangerous Precedent in President Obama's Executive Order on Immigration

Article:

As President Barack Obama prepares to issue an executive order on immigration that could potentially legalize five million undocumented immigrants, the move has sparked criticism from both sides of the political spectrum.

On Friday, George Washington University Law School professor Jonathan Turley, who identifies as a liberal, appeared on The Kelly File to discuss the issue. Turley expressed concern that the President's actions could violate the separation of powers and warned that the country is at a "tipping point."

"What I'm hearing certainly causes great concern that he will again violate the separation of powers," Turley said. "No president can take on the power of all three branches, and that's what he seems to be doing. He certainly seems to be taking on legislative authority. He is not being particularly coy about this, you know he says 'this is what I wanted to get out of legislation and I'm going to do it on my own,' and that does become a government of one."

Turley also cautioned the President against ignoring the results of the 2014 midterm elections by going around Congress on this issue, despite partisan disagreements.

"It's a very sad moment, but it's becoming a particularly dangerous moment if the president is going to go forward, particularly after this election, to defy the will of Congress yet again," Turley continued. "I can understand the frustration, these are two political parties that can't get along, but as you said, we have a democratic process, and a Congress that's coming in with the full voice of the American people behind them, that's what an election is, you may disagree with the outcome, but you have to respect the outcome."

"What the President is suggesting is tearing at the very fabric of the Constitution," Turley added. "We have a separation of powers that gives us balance, and that doesn't protect the branches. It's not there to protect the executive branch or the legislative branch, it's there to protect liberty."

"I always tell my friends on the Democratic side, we will rue the day when we helped create this uber presidency," he said. "What the Democrats are creating is something very, very dangerous. They're creating a president who can go at it alone, and to go at it alone is something that is a very dangerous thing that the framers sought to avoid in our Constitution."

Title: Supreme Court's Overturning of DOMA: Implications and Challenges

Article:

The United States Supreme Court's 5-4 decision to overturn the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) on Wednesday marks a significant victory for advocates of same-sex marriage. The 1996 federal law, which confined marriage to a man and a woman, has been declared unconstitutional.

The court's decision does not establish a national constitutional right to same-sex marriage, but it does make married gay couples living in states where their unions are legal eligible for federal benefits already enjoyed by married heterosexual Americans. These benefits range from public employee benefits and bankruptcy to estate taxes and immigration.

The DOMA case involved a claim by a New York woman who, on the death of her legal same-sex spouse, paid $363,000 more in federal estate taxes than would have been collected from a heterosexual surviving spouse.

Fred Sainz of the Human Rights Campaign, a gay advocacy organization, states, "Legally married couples in states that allow same-sex marriage are good to go. The court's decision will be final in 25 days, and they should start seeing all the same federal rights and benefits."

However, complications arise for legally married couples living in states that do not recognize same-sex marriage. Twelve states and the District of Columbia have legalized same-sex marriage; the Supreme Court's Wednesday decision also effectively made California the 13th state with legal same-sex marriage by rejecting a high court challenge to a lower court-ordered right.

The tricky part in the fall of DOMA involves how states and federal agencies currently recognize marriage. Some federal agencies, such as the Department of Defense, adhere to a "place of celebration" standard, meaning no matter where a couple is legally married anywhere in the world, the union is recognized for the purpose of federal benefits.

On the other hand, other agencies, including the Internal Revenue Service and the Social Security Administration, hew to a "place of residence" standard. Marriage has to be recognized in the place the couple is living for them to be eligible for those federal spousal benefits.

Both Sainz and Ari Ezra Waldman, legal editor at Towleroad, a widely read LGBT-oriented website, predict crucial roles can be played by both the Obama administration and Congress.

Same-sex marriage advocates predict, however, that with a Republican-dominated House, congressional action to resolve marriage definition disparities baked into law is unlikely. Congressional Democrats have written legislation that would uniformly apply a place of celebration standard, but it's unlikely to move beyond the Democratic-controlled Senate.

The task of implementing the court's decision falls to the Obama administration, which has shown a commitment to federal equality, according to Susan Sommer, director of constitutional litigation at Lambda Legal, the nation's oldest organization working for gay rights. President Obama has directed the Attorney General to review all relevant federal statutes to ensure the decision, including its implications for federal benefits and obligations, is implemented swiftly and smoothly.

"The administration can and should adopt a universal regulation that marriages, for federal purposes, are recognized under a state of celebration standard," says Waldman. "Administrations have had the power to do that since the New Deal."

"If someone has a problem with that, then it should be up to them to challenge the changes," he said. "It's a great day, but we have more litigation, more rule-making, and more work to do."

Title: Military Leaders' Support for Trump Met with Skepticism Amidst Past Controversies

Article:

In the lead-up to a major policy speech on the state of the U.S. military, former President Donald Trump released a letter signed by 88 retired generals and admirals, aiming to demonstrate his support within military leadership. However, the media's response to the letter has been critical, with several outlets scrutinizing the backgrounds and past controversies of some of the signatories.

The letter, which praised Trump as a commander in chief capable of dealing with "enemies of this country [who] have been emboldened" by perceived weakness in Washington, was met with immediate skepticism. The Washington Post, for instance, highlighted retired Lt. Gen. William G. "Jerry" Boykin, who was reprimanded for disclosing classified information in a 2008 memoir. Boykin, a co-founder and former commander of the elite Delta Force, has a storied career that includes missions in Iran, North Korea, Somalia, and Colombia.

Boykin's past statements have also been controversial. In 2003, he angered Muslims worldwide when he said, "I knew that my God was a real God, and his was an idol." Boykin, who had become the executive vice president at the conservative Family Research Council by the time the Pentagon investigated him, has maintained that the disclosures were permitted and suggested that the probe was politically motivated.

The Daily Beast also investigated the list of signatories and reported that four had been involved in the 1991 Tailhook Association scandal, in which more than 100 Navy and Marine Corps aviation officers were alleged to have sexually assaulted 90 people at the 35th Annual Tailhook Association Symposium in Las Vegas. None of the signatories were charged, although one later served as a Navy lawyer in the case.

The Washington Post attempted to create a rift between Trump and his military backers by noting that retired four-star Army Gen. Burwell Bell III was once a top NATO commander, while Trump has questioned NATO's usefulness. Three other four-star generals supporting Trump "all retired more than 20 years ago," the Post wrote.

CNN's Anderson Cooper interviewed retired Army Lt. Gen. Mark Hertling, who dismissed the names on Trump's list, stating, "I didn't recognize many of those names as being there in the fight with me over the last 16 years... There are not a whole lot of names in the fight against Al Qaeda or several of the other forces."

Hillary Clinton, Trump's opponent in the November presidential race, also expressed skepticism, stating, "Compare where Trump is with where both Romney and McCain were... They had between 300 and 500 [supporters]. I am doing better than any Democrat. He is doing worse than recent Republicans."

For his part, Trump thanked the military brass for their support. "I thank each of them for their service and their confidence in me to serve as commander in chief," Trump said in a statement. "Keeping our nation safe and leading our armed forces is the most important responsibility of the presidency."

Title: U.S. Federal Workers' Data Breach: 4 Million Records Compromised, Suspected Chinese Hackers Involved

Article:

China-based hackers are suspected of breaching the computer networks of the U.S. government personnel office, resulting in the theft of identifying information of at least 4 million federal workers, American officials announced on Thursday. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) stated in a statement that data from the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) and the Interior Department had been compromised.

The FBI is currently investigating the incident to determine how and why it occurred, according to the statement. The hackers are believed to be based in China, as stated by Sen. Susan Collins, a Maine Republican and member of the Senate intelligence committee.

Collins described the breach as "yet another indication of a foreign power probing successfully and focusing on what appears to be data that would identify people with security clearances." A U.S. official, who chose to remain anonymous, suggested that the data breach could potentially affect every federal agency. One key question is whether intelligence agency employee information was stolen, and if former government employees are also affected.

Ken Ammon, chief strategy officer of Xceedium, stated that the attack fits the pattern of those carried out by nation states for the purpose of espionage. The stolen information could be used to impersonate or blackmail federal employees with access to sensitive information, he said.

The OPM is the human resources department for the federal government and conducts background checks for security clearances. The agency stated it is offering credit monitoring and identity theft insurance for 18 months to individuals potentially affected. The National Treasury Employees Union, which represents workers in 31 federal agencies, is encouraging members to sign up for the monitoring as soon as possible.

In November, another cyberbreach compromised the private files of more than 25,000 DHS workers and thousands of other federal employees. DHS said its intrusion detection system, known as EINSTEIN, identified the hack of OPM's systems and the Interior Department's data center, which is shared by other federal agencies.

It remains unclear why the EINSTEIN system did not detect the breach until after so many records had been copied and removed. DHS is continuing to monitor federal networks for any suspicious activity and is working aggressively with the affected agencies to conduct investigative analysis to assess the extent of this alleged intrusion, according to the statement.

Rep. Adam Schiff, ranking Democrat on the House intelligence committee, called the hack "shocking," as Americans may expect that federal computer networks are maintained with state-of-the-art defenses. Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Richard Burr, R-N.C., stated that the government must overhaul its cybersecurity defenses, as the current response can no longer simply be notifying people after their personal information has been stolen. Instead, the focus should be on preventing these breaches in the first place.

Title: South Carolina Congressman Jim Clyburn's Endorsement of Biden and the Democratic Establishment's Support

Article:

South Carolina Congressman Jim Clyburn has endorsed former Vice President Joe Biden in the Democratic primary race. According to exit polls, 61% of voters said Clyburn's endorsement was an "important factor" in their decision, and 27% said it was "the most important factor." Clyburn explained that Biden is his friend and has been a reliable vote for government programs that benefit the African-American community. He also argued that with Biden on the ticket, reelection prospects for congressmen and congresswomen running for election down the ticket would be better.

"We need to keep the House Speakership under Nancy Pelosi," said Clyburn.

The Democratic establishment is now largely backing Biden and pushing out Senator Bernie Sanders. However, the differences between a President Biden and a President Sanders in terms of policy outcomes may not be as significant as some might think. According to American Enterprise Institute economist Mark Perry, in 1950, transfer payments made up less than 20% of the federal budget, but by 2012, they were 70%.

Former Senate Banking Committee chairman Phil Gramm and former Bureau of Labor Statistics assistant commissioner John Early have highlighted the extent to which government now redistributes economic resources, or in other words, the level of socialism in the United States, in a recent Wall Street Journal opinion column. They noted that more than 80% of all taxes are paid by households with incomes in the top 40%, and more than 70% of government transfer payments go to households with incomes in the bottom 40%.

Programs like Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, and food stamps, which make up around 95 federal programs, are significant contributors to this redistribution. The average household income in the bottom 20% is $4,908, and this household receives $45,389 in government transfers, according to Gramm and Early. Unfunded liabilities of Social Security and Medicare are around $50 trillion, which is more than twice the annual GDP.

The question of whether President Biden or President Sanders would introduce reforms to bring more market forces into the picture is uncertain. However, it is worth noting that the unfunded liabilities of Social Security and Medicare are significant, and government will need to take more taxes to keep these programs going, which would mean more socialism.

Star Parker, president of the Center for Urban Renewal and Education, argues that socialism and charity are fundamentally different. While charity is voluntary, individualized, and motivated by personal caring, socialism is an atheistic institutionalized system that pretends to solve human challenges through politics. Socialism, she contends, ultimately destroys the human spirit and is the real problem in poor communities.

Title: South Korea's Successful Response to COVID-19: A Case Study

Article:

South Korea, which reported its first coronavirus case on the same day as the United States (Jan. 20), has managed to limit the spread of the virus and deaths in contrast to the U.S. By April 2, the U.S. had more than 240,000 cases and over 5,800 deaths, while South Korea had fewer than 10,000 confirmed cases and 169 deaths. The difference lies in South Korea's early and aggressive approach to testing, contact tracing, and isolation.

In early January, South Korea began developing and stockpiling test kits as soon as Chinese scientists released the virus's genetic code, before a single Korean had been infected. When the first case appeared, authorities started tracking the health of some 3,000 people who had traveled to Wuhan over the previous two weeks. The country assembled a vast public-private network to produce and administer tests, including drive-through centers, and established labs to process them.

An outbreak in Daegu, the third-largest city, caused by a "super-spreader" who infected hundreds of people at several services at the Shincheonji Church of Jesus, led to a surge in cases. Over 10 days, cases soared from fewer than 50 to more than 5,000. South Korea quickly increased testing to some 20,000 people a day, but it also took more extreme measures.

President Moon Jae-in allowed the use of invasive surveillance tactics to track worshippers at Shincheonji churches across the country. South Korea's phone companies have each user's national ID number, allowing authorities to follow the movements of infected people and identify those they had interacted with over the past 14 days. Those contacts were then told to self-isolate and report their temperatures daily. Their compliance was voluntary, but South Koreans know the government can monitor their movements through phone data and an extensive CCTV network of 8 million cameras.

Other Asian countries with effective responses to the pandemic are Singapore, Vietnam, and Taiwan. All were previously hit by the 2003 epidemic of another coronavirus, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), which had a terrifying 10% fatality rate. Because of swift measures in affected areas, it killed just 774 people. In the aftermath, all three countries adopted new health policies involving mask wearing, testing, and tracking.

When COVID-19 hit, populations in those countries had masks at home, and high enough levels of social trust to quickly obey government orders to report for testing and stay at home. Taiwan has had just five deaths from COVID-19; Singapore has had six. "The situation in [Western] countries now resembles the situation we were in during the first few weeks of the SARS spread in Taiwan in early 2003," Su Ih-jen of Taiwan's CDC told the Financial Times. "You are not ready, you have no experience."

The Trump administration's failure to test and impose distancing rules for two months let the virus gain a foothold and led to the current exponential increase in cases. However, it's not too late to implement much wider testing. South Korea has tested 1 in every 119 of its people. The U.S. says it has performed 1.2 million tests, but since each patient is given at least two tests, that works out to fewer than 1 in 500 Americans. Most Americans who suspected they were infected have not been able to get tested. At this point, with more than 300,000 known infections and probably far more, tracking contacts will be impossible. "To try to do contact tracing on thousands on thousands of people is like trying to do the census in a couple of hours," says Michael Osterholm of the University of Minnesota's Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy. And the U.S.'s culture of individualism and states' rights make it unsuited to extensive contact tracing, surveillance of infected people, and other extreme measures. Governors in eight states were still resisting pleas this week by federal health officials that they issue mandatory stay-at-home orders, citing fears of infringing on "personal liberty." Even when he finally surrendered to pressure, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis—who earlier allowed spring breakers to party on beaches for weeks—exempted religious services. "I do not think that the government has the authority to close a church," DeSantis said.

Title: Pelosi Leaves Impeachment Proceedings Against Trump Open, Addresses Government Shutdown and Border Wall Dispute

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, in an interview with NBC's "Today" show, has stated that impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump are not ruled out, pending the findings of the special counsel investigating Russia's interference in the 2016 election. Pelosi is set to assume the role of House speaker on Thursday.

Regarding impeachment, Pelosi said, "We'll have to wait and see what comes from Robert Mueller's probe of contacts between Trump's presidential campaign and Russia." Democrats, who will now control the House, are expected to initiate impeachment proceedings as per the U.S. Constitution.

Pelosi, who previously described impeachment as a "divisive activity," has been cautious about using the term during the 2018 midterms due to potential political backlash. However, she did not shy away from the topic on Thursday, stating, "We should not be impeaching for a political reason, and we should not avoid impeachment for a political reason."

The question of whether a sitting president can be indicted is unclear, with Justice Department guidelines suggesting it is not possible. Pelosi referred to this as an "open discussion" and added, "Everything indicates that a president can be indicted after he is no longer president."

Trump has denied any wrongdoing in the campaign or with his former lawyer, Michael Cohen, who pleaded guilty to federal campaign finance violations.

Pelosi also addressed the ongoing U.S.-Mexico border wall dispute and the government shutdown. Trump has stated that the shutdown will last "as long as it takes" to secure funding for the wall. Pelosi told Guthrie, "How many more times can we say no?" She added, "There is no amount of persuasion he can use."

Pelosi noted that negotiating with Trump is challenging, stating, "He resists science, evidence, data, truth." She added, "It's hard to pin the president down on the facts."

In response to criticism from Trump regarding her holiday trip to Hawaii while he canceled his planned visit to Florida due to the shutdown, Pelosi said, "The president may not know this, but Hawaii is part of the United States of America." She also stated that she was available on 24-hour notice.

Title: Justice Department Indicates Special Counsel's Russia Investigation is Near Completion

Article:

The Special Counsel's Russia investigation, which has been ongoing for nearly two years, is "close to being completed," according to Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker on Monday. This marks the first official statement from the Justice Department regarding the status of the investigation into potential coordination between Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign and Russia.

Whitaker's comments, made at the end of an unrelated news conference in Washington, represent a departure from the department's usual practice of maintaining silence on the matter. He provided no timetable for the conclusion of the investigation.

To date, Special Counsel Robert Mueller has charged 34 individuals, including several close to the president, but has yet to accuse anyone from the Trump campaign of conspiring with the Kremlin to influence the election. Whitaker, who is seen as a Trump ally, took over the Justice Department and oversight of the Mueller probe following the resignation of former Attorney General Jeff Sessions at Trump's request in November.

Whitaker has faced criticism for not recusing himself from the Russia investigation, despite his past public criticisms of it. A top justice department ethics official advised him to step aside out of "an abundance of caution," but Whitaker declined to do so.

According to justice department regulations, Mueller must provide a report to the attorney general at the conclusion of his investigation detailing his prosecution decisions. However, the form the report will take and whether it will be released publicly remains unclear. The report's completion may not occur under Whitaker, as Trump has nominated William Barr to serve as the next attorney general. Barr's confirmation hearing was held this month, and he is awaiting a Senate vote.

Barr has expressed a desire to release as much information as possible about Mueller's findings, but has been vague on specifics. Trump has repeatedly referred to the Russia investigation as a "witch-hunt" and maintains there was no collusion.

Evidence so far indicates that a broad range of Trump associates had Russia-related contacts during the 2016 presidential campaign and transition period, and several have been found to have lied about the communication. These contacts occurred while the Russian government was carrying out a multifaceted effort to influence the 2016 presidential campaign and sway it in Trump's favor, according to Mueller's indictments and US intelligence agencies.

On Friday, longtime Trump confidante Roger Stone became the sixth Trump associate to be charged by Mueller. Stone is expected to plead not guilty to charges of lying to lawmakers, engaging in witness tampering, and obstructing a congressional investigation into possible coordination between Russia and the Trump campaign.

In a departure from typical behavior for defendants facing charges, Stone has opted to speak publicly about the case, holding an impromptu news conference outside a Florida courthouse, appearing on weekend television interviews, and posting on Instagram.

Additionally, on Monday, a judge delayed the sentencing of Trump's former campaign chairman Paul Manafort in Virginia, as a judge in Washington decides whether Manafort intentionally lied to investigators. Manafort was convicted of eight financial crimes last year.

Title: Stagnant Wages Persist Despite Economic Recovery, Affecting American Households and the Economy

Article:

In the run-up to the 2020 U.S. presidential election, National Public Radio (NPR) examines four major issues that the next president will confront from the outset of their term. One of these issues is the problem of stagnant wages, which has persisted despite the improving economy.

Michael Hall, a 30-year-old elevator operator at Seattle's Space Needle, has witnessed the ups and downs of American paychecks from a unique vantage point. For seven years, he shared in the success of the popular attraction, receiving regular raises due to a union contract. However, when the contract expired, Hall's pay has remained unchanged for the past four years.

"I could put some money into savings every check. Still go out, grab a beer. But after about two or three years, suddenly it was like there's seven of us in a house. And then finally I started to find myself, about a year ago, living paycheck to paycheck," Hall said.

This story is not unique. Most Americans are not seeing significant wage increases, even as the job market recovers. In April, the official unemployment rate dropped below 5.5 percent for the first time in seven years. However, the issue of stagnant wages dates back much further. Since 1979, average wages have barely kept pace with inflation.

John Pallaoro, a self-employed truck driver, recalls that his paychecks stretched further four decades ago. "I was able to purchase a suburban house in the mid-'70s for the price of barely one year of wages, two years at the most," Pallaoro said. "My standard of living is probably reduced by 50 percent from 40 years ago."

Stagnant wages are not just a problem for individuals. When workers like Hall and Pallaoro do not have money to spend, it affects the entire economy. Experts point to a variety of causes for wage stagnation, including sluggish productivity growth. In the first decades after World War II, American productivity climbed steadily, nearly 3 percent every year. However, in the mid-'70s, that growth slowed to less than 2 percent.

James Pethokoukis, an economic policy scholar at the conservative American Enterprise Institute, suggests that boosting economic growth through reduced taxes and spending could address wage stagnation. "The default Republican position would be you need to reduce taxes, you need to reduce spending so more of America's economic resources are being run by the private sector," he said. "And that would boost economic growth."

Other proposals, such as education reform and increased investment in public works, are also intended to boost productivity. However, there is another challenge: the disconnect between productivity and wages, so even as workers produce more, they do not necessarily see the benefits.

Larry Mishel, president of the left-of-center Economic Policy Institute, notes that "We have created lots of income, lots of output, lots of wealth over the last three decades, but the problem is it has not accrued to the vast majority." Virtually all of the gains have gone to those at the top of the income scale.

Politicians have sometimes attempted to address this issue through the tax code, taking a slightly larger cut from the wealthy and using tax credits to benefit the poor. However, there are political limits to this approach. Some people consider such government redistribution akin to adding or taking away points after the game has ended. Mishel and others argue that policymakers need to focus more on shaping the rules of the economic game so that average workers can command higher pretax wages.

"The problems with people's paychecks is not what the federal government is taking out in taxes. It's what employers are not putting in," Mishel said.

Elevator operator Hall agrees. He notes that while his paycheck has remained stagnant for the past four years, business at the Space Needle has been booming. "We're busier than we ever were," Hall said. "One full elevator, that pays most of us working for the day. And we'll do that 100 times. It's sort of insulting that they can't afford to keep paying us enough to live in the city."

There is one period in the past 35 years that offers a glimmer of hope for struggling workers: the late 1990s, a time when not only was the economy growing rapidly but the gains were widely shared, so workers on every rung of the economic ladder were climbing together.

Economist Jared Bernstein of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities attributes this to "very full employment," with unemployment below 5 percent and, in some months, below 4 percent. This gave workers everywhere leverage to demand higher wages.

Short of full employment, Bernstein suggests that there are other policies that could boost workers' bargaining power, including a higher minimum wage, steps to make it easier for unions to organize, and immigration policies that limit the growth of a shadow workforce.

Many of these policies will be debated over the next year and a half by those seeking to occupy the White House. As the U.S. economic elevator starts to climb again, a central challenge for the next president will be ensuring that more American families are not stuck on the bottom floor.

Title: Federal Indictment Marks Major Step Forward in Russia Investigation

Article:

A federal indictment, as of yet unspecified in terms of the individual or individuals involved, has marked a significant advancement in the ongoing Russia investigation. This development, which is expected to send shockwaves throughout the Trump administration and the nation's capital, follows a year of the Russia investigation casting a shadow over President Trump's political career without substantially altering it.

The news comes after a week of escalating conservative criticism of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe. Trump-aligned media figures have seized upon a CNN report suggesting that Clinton campaign officials funded the creation of the Steele dossier, an intelligence document detailing Trump's Russian ties, to discredit the overall Russia investigation. It is important to note that the FBI's inquiry predates the dossier, and officials have reportedly stated that it played no role in the intelligence assessment of Russia's interference in the 2016 election.

President Trump himself has joined the chorus of criticism, claiming on Twitter that former presidential candidate Hillary Clinton should be the focus of scrutiny.

The indictment signifies a major step forward for the Russia investigation, which was initiated when Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein appointed Mueller as special counsel to oversee the Justice Department's investigation on May 17, 2017. This appointment followed a two-week political firestorm for the White House after President Trump fired former FBI Director James Comey on May 9, 2017. Trump initially cited the director's controversial actions in the Hillary Clinton email investigation the previous year to justify the dismissal.

However, in the days that followed, Trump undermined that narrative on multiple occasions. He told NBC News' Lester Holt that Comey's firing was related to the Russia investigation, and that he would have fired Comey regardless of the Justice Department's recommendations. He also warned the former director on Twitter that Comey should hope there were no tapes of their White House conversations. In response, Comey asked an intermediary to provide reporters with a series of contemporaneous memos the director had drafted after meetings with Trump earlier in the year.

The memos collectively depicted a president who had little regard for the traditional firewall between the White House's political operations and the Justice Department's criminal investigations. In one instance, Comey wrote that Trump asked him to drop the investigation into Michael Flynn shortly after Flynn's departure as national-security adviser. Trump had fired Flynn, a close but controversial political ally, in February for lying to Vice President Mike Pence and other White House officials about his conversations with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak.

Title: Elizabeth Warren's Native American Ancestry Claims Under Scrutiny

Article:

Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) has faced criticism over her claims of Native American ancestry, following the release of a DNA study that suggests a distant Native American ancestor in her family tree. The study, conducted by Professor Carlos Bustamante of Stanford University, indicates that Warren's Native American ancestry is "in the range of 6–10 generations ago," which would make Warren between 1/64th Native American and 1/1024th Native American.

Warren, who has previously identified as Native American in legal directories and in her professional career, has faced backlash for her claims, particularly from President Trump, who has often referred to her as "Pocahontas." In response, Warren released the results of the DNA study this week, hoping to quell the controversy. However, the release of the study has instead sparked further criticism, with some arguing that the results do not substantiate her claims.

The Cherokee Nation released a statement this week, criticizing Warren for her claims of Native American group membership. The statement read, "Senator Elizabeth Warren is undermining tribal sovereignty with her continued claims of tribal heritage."

The question remains as to why Warren chose to claim Native American ancestry. While the Boston Globe reported six weeks ago that Warren's Native American status was not a factor in her hiring at Harvard Law School, Warren has benefited from her claims of minority status in academia and politics.

In academia, Warren's Native American status was listed in the University of Pennsylvania's Minority Equity Report and in Harvard Law's annual affirmative-action report, where she was listed as Native American from 1995 to 2004. In politics, claiming minority status adds luster to a resume, particularly in the left-leaning political climate.

Warren has argued that she claimed Native American ancestry because she believed the stories she was told by her female relatives, and that those claims may have turned out to be false but had no impact on her career development. However, by claiming minority status, Warren has positioned herself as part of a coalition of historically disadvantaged minorities, rather than as a white woman in a predominantly white political landscape.

The controversy surrounding Warren's claims of Native American ancestry highlights the complex and contentious nature of identity politics in contemporary American politics. Critics argue that Warren's claims are an example of radical dishonesty in the pursuit of political gain, while supporters argue that Warren is simply claiming a heritage that she believes to be true, regardless of its veracity. The saga of Elizabeth Warren demonstrates the power and potential pitfalls of identity politics in shaping political narratives and career trajectories.

Title: Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius Takes Responsibility for Obamacare Website Issues

Article:

Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius has admitted that she is accountable for the problems with the Obamacare rollout, which she described as a "debacle." In a hearing before the House Energy and Commerce Committee on Wednesday, Sebelius apologized for the botched launch of HealthCare.gov and pledged to fix the issues and regain the public's trust.

Despite the apology, HealthCare.gov experienced problems on Wednesday morning, creating a split-screen moment on cable TV that showed the website's "system down" message and Sebelius under fire. The hearing marked a significant moment in the public's perception of the first month of the Obamacare rollout.

Sebelius acknowledged that the law's messy rollout has hurt the administration's credibility, but assured the public that the Obamacare website should be functioning smoothly for most users by November 30. However, she noted that no confidence in that date will be established until the issues are resolved.

Sebelius also revealed that she will not release signup numbers until mid-November and will not allow contractors to speak about them until she is certain the information is confirmed and reliable. She admitted that insurers are not receiving accurate and complete data about their new customers due to the system's malfunctions.

Republican lawmakers criticized Sebelius during the hearing, with some calling for her resignation. However, no one demanded that she quit during the three-and-a-half-hour hearing. Only Rep. Michael Burgess (R-Texas) requested that Sebelius call for the resignation of Gary Cohen, the administration official heading the federal exchange office within HHS. Sebelius declined.

Despite the criticism, Sebelius has become the face of the Obamacare website mess, and she did not receive the same polite treatment that Marilyn Tavenner, administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, received during a separate hearing on Tuesday. HealthCare.gov experienced problems on Wednesday due to an outage at a data center hosted by Verizon Terremark, just days after a similar outage took down the system on Sunday night. HealthCare.gov is the main portal for coverage in the 36 states that are not running their own health insurance exchanges, and the system also provides key information to the state-run exchanges.

Title: Manchin Pursues Bipartisan Gun Control Measures, Aims to Win Over NRA-Backed Senators

Article:

Senator Joe Manchin, a lifelong member of the National Rifle Association (NRA), is reportedly President Barack Obama's best hope for a bipartisan gun control package this year. Manchin, along with Senator Chuck Schumer (D-NY), has been attempting to broker a compromise with Senator Tom Coburn (R-Okla.), but their efforts have hit roadblocks.

Manchin has urged Senator Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) to keep an open mind, but to no avail. He has also tried to persuade Senator Dean Heller (R-Nev.) to consider signing on as a prime sponsor, but was quickly rebuffed. Manchin's efforts are growing ever more critical as the battle over gun control hits the Senate floor as soon as next month.

The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved a sweeping assault weapons ban opposed by the NRA, as well as a prohibition on high-capacity ammunition magazines. However, these proposals stand little chance of becoming law.

Manchin is leading a bipartisan group crafting legislation to expand background checks on purchasers of firearms. The group is trying to lure at least one pro-NRA Republican in hopes that will open the floodgates for more support. Support from the GOP will help determine how much backing the effort gets from red-state Democrats, who so far have been lukewarm.

Manchin has floated an idea to pro-NRA Senator Mark Begich to combine the Alaska Democrat's bipartisan proposal modifying gun restrictions for the mentally ill with a new background check plan in an attempt to piece together a broader coalition.

Senator Begich's response was that Manchin needs to win over more Republican senators than just moderate Illinois Senator Mark Kirk. "I know he would like to get a criminal background check completed," Begich said of Manchin. "His challenge is, and I wait for him to finish off his discussions, he needs to bring one or two A-rated NRA Republicans on board. With all due respect to Sen. Kirk, he's an F-rated. You need an A-rated."

The effort to more broadly expand background checks could be the most significant gun control measure to pass a bitterly divided Senate—if a bipartisan deal can first be reached. The central sticking point is whether records of gun sales or purchases must be retained by retailers.

Manchin, who calls himself an "eternal optimist," is working furiously to win over Republicans and believes he's making steady progress before he officially proposes a new bill, either with a small group of senators or with a bipartisan coalition. When a bill finally is unveiled and it hits the floor, Manchin is confident pro-gun senators will vote for it—even if they decline to sign on for the moment.

Title: Alabama Senate Race Officially Declared Over, Doug Jones Wins Close Contest Against Roy Moore

Article:

Alabama Republican Party Chairman Terry Lathan announced late Tuesday that the state's Senate race has concluded, with Democrat Doug Jones defeating GOP candidate Roy Moore. In a statement, Lathan expressed the party's disappointment over the close race but emphasized respect for the democratic process.

Lathan noted that Jones, during his campaign, repeatedly discussed reaching across the aisle to work with Republicans. She stated, "While these issues weren’t discussed, and no other Democratic Senator has worked with the Republicans, all eyes will be on his votes."

Lathan also mentioned that Alabamians are conservative and have no intentions of moving toward the policies of the Democrat Party. She added, "If Mr. Jones aligns himself with the liberal Democrats in Washington, Alabama voters will remember his choices in the 2020 U.S. Senate election."

Roy Moore, in a speech on Tuesday night, refused to concede the special election, stating, "When the vote is this close, it is not over." Alabama state law requires an automatic recount when election results are within 0.5 percentage points. With 100 percent of precincts reporting, Jones holds 49.9 percent of the vote, compared to Moore's 48.4 percent, a 1.5-point gap, according to The New York Times.

Jones delivered an exuberant speech in Birmingham, where he emphasized the importance of finding common ground and unity. Jones is the first member of his party to win a Senate seat in the state since 1992.

Title: Uncertainty Over Sequester Cuts Threatens Hiring in Fall

Article:

Lawmakers are expected to take their time deciding how to replace the sequester of automatic cuts scheduled for next year, which has caused uncertainty and could potentially lead to hiring slowdowns and possible layoffs, according to experts and businesses. The so-called sequester, which involves heavy-handed automatic spending cuts set to take effect next year, would total about $110 billion. Half the cuts would come from defense and the other half from non-defense spending on domestic programs.

Most do not expect lawmakers will reach a decision until the lame-duck session of Congress after Election Day, and possibly not until early 2013. The problem is that prolonging the uncertainty is likely to cause serious hiring slowdowns and possible layoffs, experts and businesses said.

Businesses and agencies need to plan for the year ahead, but they simply cannot because they do not know how many contracts will be funded and how many programs they'll need to cut back on. The point is not lost on Democrat Carl Levin, who chairs the Senate Armed Services Committee.

"[T]hat uncertainty which is created by... the specter of sequestration... is a real threat to this economy. So not only must we avoid sequestration... we must do it in time to avoid a severe weakening to this economy," he said at a National Press luncheon.

Those in the defense industry say the sequester is already having a chilling effect. "In the past we'd add head count [in summer] to prepare for new work. This year, we'll clearly take a more conservative approach until we see what's going to shake out," said Samuel Strickland, CFO of defense contractor Booz Allen Hamilton (BAH, Fortune 500) during a recent investor call.

At Lockheed Martin (LMT, Fortune 500), the largest U.S. defense contractor, the story is similar. "We are already taking action by not hiring and training new workers, not investing in new plants and equipment and not investing in new R&D," said company chairman and CEO Robert Stevens during a Senate caucus lunch in March.

However, Stevens also warned that if he does not get clarity soon, he may be forced to issue notice this fall of possible layoffs in 2013. The federal WARN Act requires businesses with more than 100 employees to notify workers at least 60 days in advance of a mass layoff or plant closing.

Since the sequester takes effect Jan. 2, 2013, the WARN Act requirement could mean layoff notices come out a few days before the Nov. 6 election. But layoff notices are likely to be a measure of last resort for both federal agencies and private sector contractors, said government contracts expert Dan Gordon, who used to run the White House Office of Procurement.

Instead, he said he is expecting "a dramatic slowdown in hiring" this fall. "It's very slow and expensive to cut back on the government's commitment under an existing contract. For both [federal agencies and private contractors], it's always easier to stop hiring than to lay off existing employees," Gordon noted.

He also expects federal agencies over the next seven months to be very reluctant to enter into new commitments with contractors, even though government has become more heavily reliant on contractors to do everything from guarding office buildings to running IT departments.

"Why make a commitment that might end up being costly to you?" said Joseph Minarik, senior vice president of the Committee for Economic Development.

Like Gordon, he believes hiring freezes are the greatest risk on the jobs front this fall. But more than anything, Minarik said, for everyone in the public and the private sector, "all the time being spent on planning for this situation is pure economic waste."

Title: Democratic Establishment Rallies Behind Biden Amid Sanders Momentum

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, the Democratic Party establishment has rallied behind Joe Biden following his victories in several states during Super Tuesday. At the time of writing, Biden was projected to have won Virginia, North Carolina, Massachusetts, Alabama, Oklahoma, Minnesota, Arkansas, Texas, and Tennessee, with close races in Maine.

The surge in support for Biden, who was previously struggling in the polls, can be attributed to a combination of factors, including the endorsement of House Majority Whip Jim Clyburn in South Carolina and the withdrawal of several Democratic candidates, such as Pete Buttigieg, Amy Klobuchar, and Beto O'Rourke.

The establishment's support for Biden is primarily driven by concerns about electability and party unity. The argument is that Biden, who is not Bernie Sanders, is the best candidate to take on Donald Trump in the general election.

However, the sudden rally around Biden was not due to a belief that he has the best policies or the best temperament to face Trump. Instead, the establishment's support is a reaction to the momentum Sanders had gained after winning the popular vote in each of the first three primary states.

The primary race is now expected to be a grueling contest that will likely extend until the convention, with Sanders also performing well in several states, including Utah, Colorado, Vermont, and California.

While the electability argument is the only one with a semblance of plausibility, it is not the case that Biden is a sure thing, while Sanders is a risky gamble. Sanders, who would be the most left-wing president in history, has consistently polled well against Trump and has a strong fundraising machine and dedicated activist base.

On the other hand, Biden has several risks, including a history of being creepy with women, cognitive decline, a poor campaign performance, and a record that is at odds with the modern Democratic Party's branding.

Nominating Biden could potentially lead to a deflated activist energy and a lower voter turnout among younger voters, who are a significant portion of Sanders' support base.

In conclusion, the Democratic establishment's support for Biden is a gamble, and the outcome of the primary race remains uncertain. Democratic voters are advised to carefully consider their choices and not be swayed solely by the establishment's fear of a Trump re-election.

Title: Trump's Criticism of Federal Reserve Chairman and the Dual Mandate of the Federal Reserve

Article:

In a series of tweets, President Donald Trump has publicly criticized Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, questioning whether Powell or Chinese President Xi Jinping is America's "bigger enemy." Trump has also accused Powell of being "clueless" and has called for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates significantly.

The Federal Reserve's primary role, as set by the 1977 amendment to the Federal Reserve Act, is to maintain price stability and maximum sustainable employment. The first part of this mandate involves controlling the money supply to prevent inflation and create financial stability. However, research suggests that the Federal Reserve has struggled to achieve this goal, with its failures contributing to several severe banking crises throughout U.S. history, including those in the 1920s, 1930s, 1980s, and 2000s.

The goal of maintaining employment is also questionable, as it reflects the belief that the government should create, control, and maximize the number of jobs. The Federal Reserve has historically relied on the now academically debunked idea of a negative relationship between inflation and unemployment, known as the "Phillips curve." However, the Fed's own experience contradicts this notion.

Since the 2008 financial crisis, the Fed's balance sheet has grown from $1 trillion to $4 trillion as it pursued policies of quantitative easing and super-low interest rates. At the same time, it pursued "tightened" money by effectively paying banks not to lend. The result of these contradictory policies was to prolong the recession.

Quantitative easing can lead to higher inflation, making the lives of retirees and others who live on fixed incomes more difficult by reducing their spending power. While there has been very little inflation this time around, the Fed has undershot its 2% target. The policies have also reduced the return seniors earn from their savings, encouraged higher risk-taking, discouraged saving and investment, and slowed the growth of labor productivity and real output after the recession.

The second part of the dual mandate also encourages presidents to think that the Fed's job is to bail them out when the economy is taking a hit, such as due to destructive trade policies. The politicization of the Fed has led it to pursue policies that go against the objective of price stabilization and financial stability.

Milton Friedman once said, "Money is much too serious a matter to be left to the central bankers." Given the existence of the Federal Reserve, it is crucial to ensure that it is not being swayed by political interests.

Title: President Trump Expresses Satisfaction with Removal of FBI Officials Involved in Trump-Russia Probe

Article:

President Donald Trump has expressed his satisfaction with the removal of FBI officials who were involved in the Trump-Russia investigation, referring to it as one of his "greatest achievements" in office.

During a press briefing at Mar-a-Lago, where he is currently on Christmas vacation, Trump stated, "These were dirty people. These were bad people. These were evil people, and I hope that someday I'm going to consider it my greatest, or one of my greatest achievements, getting rid of them."

The president's comments came in response to a question about a potential pardon for Roger Stone, a longtime Republican operative who was indicted in the special counsel's investigation on charges of making false statements to Congress. Stone, who worked briefly on the Trump campaign and has known Trump for decades, was convicted on November 15.

Trump stated that he has not yet considered a pardon for Stone, but believes he was treated "very unfair" in the special counsel's case. "I haven't thought of it. I think it's very tough what they did to Roger Stone, compared to what they do to other people on their side," Trump said.

The president also reiterated his belief that his campaign was spied on, stating, "Now they're finding out it was a big hoax. They're finding out it was a horrible thing. We were spied on, my campaign was spied on."

Trump did not specifically identify whom at the FBI he is glad to have ousted. Former FBI Director James Comey was fired on May 9, 2017. Andrew McCabe, who served as FBI deputy director, was fired on March 16, 2018, after the bureau's Office of Professional Responsibility and the Justice Department's inspector general found that he lacked candor during interviews about the authorization of media leaks in October 2016.

Peter Strzok, the former deputy chief of counterintelligence, was fired on August 10, 2018, over anti-Trump text messages he exchanged with FBI lawyer Lisa Page. Page resigned from the bureau on May 4, 2018.

Strzok was the lead investigator on Crossfire Hurricane, the counterintelligence probe into the Trump campaign. Comey and McCabe were also directly involved in the investigation.

The Justice Department's inspector general found that the FBI made "significant inaccuracies" in applications for surveillance warrants against Trump campaign adviser Carter Page. The FBI relied heavily on the Steele dossier to obtain the warrants, even though investigators had evidence that undermined dossier author Christopher Steele's credibility.

Title: Married Women's Voting Preferences in 2020: A Potential Shift Away from Traditional Trends

Article:

Christine Garcia, a 37-year-old stay-at-home mother, identifies as a fiscal conservative but social liberal and does not consider herself a particularly political person. However, she expresses strong opinions about President Trump.

"Maybe on the business side... the money is better as far as I understand," Garcia said. "But a lot of the other things are very worrisome," she added, laughing, as she pushed her daughter on a swing in a park in Birmingham, Mich., an affluent suburb of Detroit.

Garcia declined to disclose whom she voted for in 2016, but she finds Trump un-presidential and stated that she would not vote for him in 2020. "I tell you, I don't like him as a person," she said. "I don't have a good feeling when he comes on and when I see him."

For decades, research has suggested that married women, like Garcia, tend to be more conservative than unmarried women, in part due to social networks, spousal influence, and economics. Election results have confirmed this academic research.

However, recent interviews and polling suggest the traditional marriage gap might shrink this November. Anna Greenberg, a Democratic pollster with Greenberg Quinlan Rosner, stated that married women, especially in the last six months, have turned against Trump and are starting to lean towards voting more Democratic in the congressional races, which is a significant change.

Greenberg's most recent polling shows that 57 percent of married women disapprove of President Trump's job performance. This number has increased significantly in the last year and a half. In March 2017, the president's disapproval rating was at 40 percent among married women, according to Greenberg.

"I think there's some real partisan realignment here," said Greenberg. But the question remains: is the possible shift in the marriage gap a side effect of President Trump's administration or a permanent realignment?

Birmingham is located in Michigan's 11th Congressional District, where two women, both in their 30s, are vying for an open seat in Congress. It's a tight race between Republican Lena Epstein, 37, the co-chair of Trump's 2016 presidential campaign in Michigan, and Democrat Haley Stevens, 35, who worked on the Obama administration's auto bailout. The two women are ideologically poles apart.

Republican women, married or single, consistently tout the health of the economy. Deb O'Hagan, 60, during lunch at a country club where the Bloomfield Republican Women's Club was meeting, stated, "Oh my gosh, it took off the day after the election. People knew what his policies were going to be, they knew what his goals were going to be."

Esther Littmann, a 78-year-old Republican mother of three grown children, has noticed younger women have a different view of the economy. "A lot of younger women, they haven't experienced life enough," she said. "I feel like right now a lot of younger women who are in favor of socialism don't really understand the economy, don't understand what they've grown up with, the advantages that they've had."

Fewer than 50 percent of American women are married, according to data from the Census Bureau. Single women tend to be younger, more racially diverse, and less educated. The voting gap among women is not entirely about all those single ladies. It's also tied to age. Young women, like 25-year-old Bridget O'Connor, regardless of whether they're married, tend to be Democrats.

O'Connor, on a lunch break from her marketing job, says she does not know who's running for Congress in her district, but she plans to vote this November, and her main priority is to get the president out of office.

Around Michigan's 11th Congressional District, NPR met many married women who say they were never engaged in Democratic Party politics, but now they're knocking on doors and volunteering for candidates.

"2016 was the time I said, 'I don't know if I can ever vote for a Republican again,'" said Louri Jouppi. Jouppi states that voting Democratic probably costs her more money, given her husband's income, but she's willing to pay more taxes if it means she is not sacrificing her moral values. Her friend Sonia Patel agreed.

"I'll pay taxes if it means the children can be with their parents," said Patel, referring to the Trump administration's immigration policies. Patel, a stay-at-home mom from Canton, Mich., says she used to vote for a mix of Democrats and Republicans. For instance, she voted for Michigan's Republican governor, Rick Snyder. But after the 2016 election, she joined the board of the local Canton Democratic Club, saying motherhood and age have turned her from a moderate into a Democrat.

"My kids started growing up. I started looking at the world differently. I think it wasn't just about me anymore, and I started thinking about the world I'm leaving them," said Patel.

Title: Partisan Divide in U.S. Electorate Widens Ahead of Election Day

Article:

The upcoming U.S. presidential election will find the winner leading a deeply divided American electorate, according to a new study by the Pew Research Center. The two major political parties are drifting apart, with significant differences in race, religion, and other demographic measures, the study suggests.

The Pew report, titled "Election 2016," indicates that the ongoing demographic changes in the country have reshaped both party coalitions. The divide between the parties is expected to widen in the coming years.

The Republican Party is becoming whiter, older, and more religious than the general population, while the Democratic Party is becoming more diverse, younger, and less religious at a faster rate than the U.S. population.

In terms of race, the parties are not becoming monolithically white or non-white. Instead, the racial makeup of the two parties is becoming increasingly dissimilar, as racial minorities disproportionately favor Democrats. In 2008, whites made up 88% of all Republicans and Republican-leaning voters, according to Pew's data. By 2016, this had dropped to 86%. On the other hand, whites made up 64% of Democrats and Democratic-leaners in 2008, and they are now 57%, a seven-percent drop over the period of Obama's two terms.

The divide is also evident in age, with Republicans becoming relatively older, education, with college-educated voters declining as a percentage of the GOP and increasing as a percentage of the Democratic vote, and religion. Fully 29% of the Democratic coalition now identifies as atheist, agnostic, or nothing in particular, compared to 12% for the GOP.

"Democrats are becoming the party of minorities and college-educated whites, while Republicans are becoming the party of whites with lower levels of education," writes William Galston of the Brookings Institution in a study of the problems facing the next administration.

These groups are not just divided by inflammatory, nonsubstantive wedge issues. They have real differences of outlook and interest, Galston notes. Minorities are more likely to support affirmative action, college-educated voters are more likely to support increased federal aid for education, and religious voters are more likely to oppose abortion.

Overall, the Democratic coalition is more comfortable with diversity, believes that the present is better than the past, and looks forward to the future with optimism. The Republican coalition sees increasing diversity as a threat, prefers past decades over today, and looks ahead with foreboding.

Galston suggests that the winner of the 2016 presidential election will find it challenging to narrow this divide unless they focus on an agenda of national reconciliation starting on Day 1 of the transition.

Title: Former CIA Director Petraeus Warns Iran of Escalating Tensions with U.S.

Article:

Former CIA Director David Petraeus has issued a warning to Iran, stating that the Middle Eastern nation must exercise caution as tensions between Iran and the United States escalate. In an interview on ABC's "This Week," Petraeus stated, "They are going to have to make a decision. Either they are going to have to really tighten their belt and keep tightening, because it's going to get worse."

Petraeus further explained, "There are going to be further screws tightening down in the maximum pressure campaign and try to grit their teeth and get to November 2020 in hopes that their desired outcome emerges." He added, "They're going to have to be very careful not to overplay their hand and result in some kind of response that is quite punitive."

The Trump administration's recent actions, including the deployment of an aircraft carrier and other military resources to the Persian Gulf region, and the withdrawal of nonessential personnel from Iraq, have raised concerns among some lawmakers about the possibility of a confrontation with Iran.

President Trump has downplayed any potential for conflict, but questions remain about the reasons behind these actions, and many lawmakers have demanded more information. The tension between Tehran and Washington is largely due to reports of bombings and attacks across the region that have been linked to Iranian-backed terror groups, as well as the U.S. withdrawal from the nuclear accord with Iran over a year ago.

Trump pulled out of the agreement, which he has criticized as "the worst deal in history." He argued that the accord should have restrained Iran's ballistic missile program and curbed what his administration considers Tehran's hostile activities in the region. The administration reimposed crippling economic sanctions on Iran that had been lifted under the agreement.

In response, Iran has threatened to enrich its uranium stockpile closer to weapons-grade levels in 60 days if world powers fail to negotiate new terms for its 2015 nuclear deal. Iran has also stopped its sale of excess uranium and heavy water, as required under the deal.

Title: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal Delivers Keynote Address at New Hampshire Republican Fundraiser, Renewing Speculation for 2016 Presidential Bid

Article:

Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal will deliver the keynote address at a Republican fundraiser in New Hampshire on Friday, an appearance that has renewed speculation about a potential 2016 presidential bid. The event, hosted by the Republican State Senate Political Action Committee, is taking place in Manchester, with ticket prices ranging from $1,000 to $5,000.

Steven Duprey, a member of the Republican National Committee from New Hampshire, commented on the significance of the Granite State, which hosts the first primary in the nation. He stated that the state is an ideal location for candidates to begin laying the groundwork for a presidential run, particularly for those who may not have as much financial backing or national recognition.

"For candidates who might not have as much money as some others, or who aren't yet nationally known, this is a great time to come to New Hampshire to start to introduce themselves and to listen to what New Hampshire voters are concerned about," Mr. Duprey said. "Anyone who thinks the Republican rules only favor the better known and better funded candidates should not complain. Instead they should come to New Hampshire, Iowa, South Carolina, and Nevada. There are lots of low fares to each of those states."

Mr. Duprey served as the campaign manager for Sen. John McCain during the Arizona Republican's bid for the White House in 2008. After finishing fourth in the Iowa caucus, which initiates the nomination contests, Mr. McCain went on to win the New Hampshire primary, a victory that contributed to his eventual Republican nomination. Former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney also won the New Hampshire primary last year on his way to winning the Republican nomination.

President Obama, however, won the state in the 2008 and 2012 general elections.

The University of Virginia's Center for Politics this week handicapped the field of potential 2016 candidates, and placed Mr. Jindal, an Indian-American, in the second tier of candidates for the GOP nomination. The Center for Politics identified Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie as the frontrunners, with Mr. Jindal and Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky considered to be close behind.

Mr. Duprey suggested that the key to performing well in New Hampshire is not to give speeches, but to hold town halls that provide candidates with a more intimate setting to interact with voters. "John McCain set the standard. Follow his playbook," he said.

Title: Alabama Chief Justice Suspended for Ordering Prohibition of Gay Marriage Licenses

Article:

Alabama's Supreme Court Chief Justice, Roy Moore, was suspended on Friday due to potential removal from office for issuing an order in January that prohibited state probate judges from granting marriage licenses to same-sex couples. The Alabama Judicial Inquiry Commission has charged Moore with violating the state's judicial ethics laws, according to news website AL.com.

The legality of gay marriage was a contentious issue for years until the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in June that the U.S. Constitution provides same-sex couples the right to marry, marking a historic victory for the American gay rights movement. Despite the ruling and a federal court ruling that made gay marriage legal in Alabama, Moore's administrative order instructed state probate judges not to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, according to court documents.

The complaint states that Moore "flagrantly disregarded and abused his authority" and knowingly ordered probate judges to commit potential violations, subjecting them to potential prosecution and removal from office. Moore contends that the commission has no authority over administrative orders or the court's ability to prohibit probate judges from issuing same-sex marriage licenses.

In his order, Moore argued that the U.S. Supreme Court ruling was at odds with a decision in March 2015 by the Alabama Supreme Court that instructed probate judges to stop issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples. The conflicting opinions resulted in "confusion and uncertainty," Moore said, with many probate judges issuing marriage licenses to gay couples while others refused to do so. Until the Alabama Supreme Court decides the matter, probate judges "have a ministerial duty not to issue any marriage license," he said.

The complaint asserts that Moore's order was "contrary to clear and determined law about which there is no confusion or unsettled question."

Moore, a Republican, has been a prominent figure in conservative causes. In 2003, he was removed from office after a federal judge ruled he was placing himself above the law by refusing to take down a Ten Commandments monument. He regained the chief justice job in 2012, vowing not to do anything to create further friction with the federal courts.

Title: U.S. Investigators Sought Warrants for Michael Cohen's Emails in July 2017, Nine Months Before FBI Raids

Article:

U.S. investigators, including Special Counsel Robert Mueller's office, sought warrants to access Michael Cohen's emails in July 2017, nine months before the FBI raided the home and office of President Donald Trump's former personal lawyer. The nearly 900 pages of documents released by a federal judge in New York provide more detailed accounts of Cohen's financial relationships than previously known.

The requests for emails were made six months into Trump's presidency, with the emails sought dating back as far as June 2015. Mueller is investigating Russia's role in the 2016 U.S. election and possible coordination with Trump campaign members.

Cohen had been Trump's personal lawyer and self-described fixer for more than a decade, but began cooperating with federal investigators soon after the April 2018 raids on his home, office, and hotel room. He later pleaded guilty in separate prosecutions to lying to Congress, bank fraud, and campaign finance violations, including paying hush money to silence two women who claimed they had sexual encounters with Trump.

Cohen is scheduled to begin a three-year prison term on May 6. Trump has denied having had sexual relationships with the two women: Stormy Daniels, the porn actress whose real name is Stephanie Clifford, and former Playboy model Karen McDougal.

Much of the discussion about campaign finance issues in the released documents was redacted. They were released after U.S. District Judge William Pauley on Monday ordered prosecutors to make redacted versions public, in response to requests by news media organizations.

Lanny Davis, a lawyer for Cohen, said in a statement on Monday night that the document release "only furthers his interest in continuing to cooperate and providing information and the truth about Donald Trump and the Trump organization to law enforcement and Congress."

Since pleading guilty, Cohen has publicly turned on Trump, telling the House Committee on Oversight and Reform on Feb. 27 that his former boss was a "racist," "con man," and "cheat." In his congressional testimony, Cohen said he was "ashamed of my weakness and misplaced loyalty, of the things I did for Mr. Trump in an effort to protect and promote him."

Cohen began working for Trump in 2007. The Republican president in December called his former lawyer "a rat" and in January said Cohen was "lying to reduce his jail time."

Moscow has denied meddling in the 2016 election, though U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that it interfered to help Trump win. Trump has denied that his campaign colluded with Russia, and described the Mueller probe as a political witch hunt.

The newly released documents showed how the FBI made extensive use of its access to Cohen's Apple iCloud account, which allowed him to coordinate his work across such devices as an iPhone, iPad Mini, and laptop. FBI agents said they located a hotel room in New York's Loews Regency Hotel where Cohen was staying by using a device known as a Triggerfish that mimics cell phone towers to find a specific device.

The bank fraud case stemmed from Cohen dealings unrelated to Trump, and suggest that his financial situation was dire. According to the documents, Cohen was in default by December 2017 on more than $20 million in loans backed by New York taxicab medallions he owned. The FBI believed Cohen misrepresented his finances to banks he owed money to.

According to the documents, Cohen concealed fees being paid to Essential Consultants, a firm he controlled, for political consulting, including from international clients with issues pending before the Trump administration. Among the payments Cohen was believed to have received was $600,000 from AT&T Inc for consulting about "political issues, including net neutrality, the merger between AT&T and Time Warner and tax reform." Another $583,333 came from an investment firm controlled by Russian businessman Viktor Vekselberg, the documents showed.

Republicans in Congress have criticized Cohen's consulting work, arguing he should have made his contracts public through disclosures. The warrant does not appear to detail any violations to lobbying disclosure laws.

Cohen also used Essential Consultants to pay hush money to Daniels.

Title: Obama Urges Congress to Act on Comprehensive Immigration Reform, Outlines Key Principles

Article:

President Barack Obama on Tuesday called on Congress to move forward with a comprehensive bill to overhaul the nation's immigration system, stating that "the time is now" to address the issue. During a speech in Las Vegas, Nevada, the president outlined key principles he believes should be included in immigration reform, such as a pathway to citizenship for the estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants residing in the U.S.

In his speech at Del Sol High School, Obama emphasized the need for Congress to act swiftly on a comprehensive approach to dealing with the undocumented immigrants currently in the country. He indicated that if Congress does not act promptly, he will send his own bill to Capitol Hill and insist that they vote on it immediately.

While Obama set a deadline for Congress, he expressed optimism about lawmakers' efforts to craft their own proposals. On Monday, a bipartisan group of senators, known as the "Gang of Eight," unveiled their own outline for comprehensive reform.
