This plan includes a pathway to citizenship for the undocumented, increased border security, crackdowns on businesses that employ undocumented immigrants, and the admission of skilled immigrant workers to the United States.

Obama praised the Senate framework, stating that it aligns with the principles he has advocated for in the past few years. He expressed hope that there is a genuine desire among lawmakers to get this done soon, but emphasized that action is necessary.

Republican reactions to Obama's speech were generally cautious. Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.), a member of the Gang of Eight, acknowledged the differences between himself and the president but expressed optimism about finding common ground.

Passage of a comprehensive immigration reform bill in the House of Representatives could prove challenging. House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) did not rule out taking up a bill based on Obama's comments, but expressed a desire for a bipartisan solution and warned against the president dragging the debate to the left.

The president's address highlighted the similarities between his proposals and the Gang of Eight's, but there are indications that the two may differ in key areas. For example, the senators' plan would allow undocumented immigrants to apply for legal status but not seek permanent legal residence until the border is deemed secure. In his speech, Obama did not specifically link border security to a pathway to citizenship.

Obama's principles for a path to citizenship include undergoing a background check, paying fines and back taxes, learning English, and going to the back of the line, meaning they could not obtain citizenship until backlogs of legal immigrants are cleared.

The White House made it clear before the speech that the president is withholding judgment on the Senate's plan until actual legislative language is drafted. Obama also emphasized the need for the government to stay focused on enforcement and for any immigration reform bill to crack down on businesses that knowingly hire undocumented immigrants with stiffer fines and penalties.

However, the president's stance on a path to citizenship did not satisfy all Republicans working on an immigration reform plan. Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) expressed concern about the president's unwillingness to accept significant enforcement triggers before current undocumented immigrants can apply for a green card.

In addition, the president's speech and fact sheet did not mention a temporary, guest-worker program, a provision that business groups and Republicans have called for in agricultural industries and other companies that rely on low-skilled immigrant labor. Labor unions have been hesitant to support such programs without strong labor protections.

Obama has faced criticism from lawmakers in both political parties and Latino groups for not bringing up a comprehensive immigration reform bill during his first term and for his record deportation numbers. However, the president was warmly received by the crowd inside Del Sol High School's gymnasium, who chanted "sí se puede!" during the speech.

Immigration reform is not just a policy debate, Obama said, but a matter of people, emphasizing that the men and women seeking a chance to earn their way into the American story have made the nation stronger throughout history.

Title: Former ICE Director Thomas Homan's Outburst at Congressional Hearing Sparks Controversy

Article:

Thomas Homan, the former acting director of the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) from January 2017 to June 2018, testified before the House Subcommittee on Immigration and Citizenship on Thursday. The hearing focused on ICE detention centers, which have been the subject of numerous human rights abuses allegations.

During the hearing, Homan faced criticism for ICE's conduct and policies under his leadership. More than 50,000 immigrants are currently being held in ICE custody, with private, for-profit prisons housing nearly three-fourths of them. Reports issued by the Department of Homeland Security's Office of Inspector General in June 2019 and September 2018 found that ICE facilities are filthy, brutal, and dangerous. Immigrants, including children, are routinely denied access to medical care, live in filthy conditions, are given expired and unsafe food, denied hygiene items, and denied recreation and visitation. Detainees are illegally placed in solitary confinement and strip-searched. At one facility, inspectors found nooses in 15 different cells. At least 24 immigrants have died in ICE detention under President Trump.

Democratic Rep. Pramila Jayapal, who chaired the subcommittee on Thursday, is the sponsor of a bill, the Dignity for Detained Immigrants Act of 2019, that seeks to address these problems. The measure would heighten standards for ICE facilities, increase inspections, grant more robust rights to detainees, and phase out ICE's use of private prisons. The bill has 130 co-sponsors in the House of Representatives, all Democrats.

Witnesses at the hearing included Selene Saavedra Roman, a Dreamer wrongfully detained by ICE for six weeks; Denis Davydov, a gay HIV-positive immigrant wrongfully detained by ICE while seeking asylum from Russia; and Blanche Engochan, a Cameroon refugee subjected to horrific mistreatment in ICE detention.

Homan's testimony was marked by repeated interruptions and outbursts, including shouting at congressional Democrats and refusing to stop speaking when his time expired. In one instance, Homan refused to stop speaking even after Rep. Jayapal gaveled him down, shouting, "I'm a taxpayer, you work for me!"

This was not Homan's first blowup at the prospect of having to answer to criticism. Earlier this month, Homan engaged in a similar performance, attempting to shout down Democratic Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez after his time expired. Like Jayapal, Ocasio-Cortez had to gavel him down.

The incidents demonstrate how ICE operated under Homan's watch. Agents felt free to illegally detain immigrants, then deceive courts to secure their deportation. They treated their targets as legal non-persons, in a crusade to detain and deport as many as possible. ICE has gone after lawful immigrants, too, attempting to revoke their green cards for no good reason. Homan claimed he simply sought to enforce the laws on the books. However, when state legislators began to limit local law enforcement's ability to cooperate with ICE, Homan announced on Fox News that those lawmakers should be charged with crimes.

The first wave of coverage of Homan's outburst on Thursday came from right-wing media, praising his defiance. It was pure Trumpism, the elevation of culture war over the basic constitutional order. Thomas Homan does not recognize the authority of Pramila Jayapal or Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. He does not think he has to follow their rules. He does not believe that two women of color have any right to hold power over him. "You work for me!" the former government employee screamed at an elected member of the government. He is a man who is used to wielding power against people who look like Jayapal and Ocasio-Cortez. He is the embodiment of ICE under Trump, certain—as so many ICE officers are—that he answers to no one.

Title: Russian President Putin Emerges from 11-Day Absence, Amid Speculation on Health and Public Appearances

Article:

Russian President Vladimir Putin made a public appearance on Monday in St. Petersburg, marking his first sighting in 11 days. The absence of the 62-year-old leader had sparked a flurry of speculation regarding his health, control of the government, and personal life.

Putin's last public appearance was on March 5, when he was seen with Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi. Over the past week, the Kremlin released undated photo and video footage of Putin, which only fueled the conjecture about his health.

When asked about the health rumors, Putin jokingly told reporters in Russia's second city that "It would be boring without gossip." Images published on social media did not indicate any unusual changes in his appearance.

Independent Russian TV channel Dozhd reported that Putin might have been suffering from the flu and isolating at his residence in the Novgorod region. Meanwhile, Austrian newspaper Kurier suggested he was receiving treatment in Moscow from an Austrian orthopedist for back problems. The Kremlin has not commented on these reports.

Alexei Makarkin, vice president of the Moscow-based Center for Political Technologies, stated, "Discussing the president's health is the same thing as aiding the enemy." Makarkin attributed this secrecy to the legacy of the former Soviet Union.

Earlier on Monday, Putin added to the speculation when he ordered an unscheduled inspection of parts of the nation's military but did not show up for the drill. The inspection of Russia's Northern Fleet, which includes 38,000 military personnel and 3,360 pieces of military hardware, was confirmed by Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu, according to the Interfax news service.

Further fueling the speculation, a planned visit by Putin to Kazakhstan was rescheduled to March 20. Moscow has expressed concern about an increase in NATO exercises held near the Russian border. One year ago, Russian forces took over the Black Sea Peninsula, annexing the Ukrainian territory of Crimea.

Title: President Trump's UN General Assembly Agenda: Pushing Reforms, Confronting Threats, and Pursuing Economic Deals

Article:

President Donald Trump arrived at the United Nations General Assembly on Monday, marking his first appearance at the international body with a mission to implement his "America First" agenda and engage in diplomatic discussions with world leaders. The four-day event in New York will see Trump pushing for reforms to the United Nations, rethinking America's financial contributions, brokering economic deals, and addressing global threats such as North Korea, Iran, and Islamic State.

U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley stated, "We can all say it is a new day at the U.N. It's not just about talking. It's about action." However, the new direction the president has set for America has left many of the approximately 120 world leaders attending the assembly, who were more comfortable with President Obama, questioning Trump's approach.

In the eight months since taking office, Trump has demonstrated his willingness to use American military and economic power, with missile strikes on Syria, get-tough trade measures on China, and threats against North Korea. Jon Alterman, senior vice president of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, noted, "For a number of leaders, this is going to be their first chance to see him, to judge him, to try to get on his good side."

The grueling schedule of the week-long event will test Trump's skills and endurance, as he is a novice in international diplomacy. The tightly choreographed week also poses a unique challenge to Trump, who has a propensity for going off script and delighting in upsetting convention.

Trump's schedule for the four-day event includes a hotly anticipated speech to the assembled delegations on Tuesday, discussions on reforms to the United Nations on Monday, meetings with leaders of France and Israel, a working dinner at Trump Tower with presidents of Peru, Colombia, and Brazil, and sit-downs with leaders of Jordan, the Palestinian Authority, Britain, Egypt, and African leaders, among others.

On Tuesday, Trump will deliver his first address to the assembly, emphasizing the need for states to promote peace and prosperity while upholding sovereignty and accountability as indispensable foundations of international order. The president will also meet with U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, General Assembly President Miroslav Lajcak of Slovakia, and the emir of Qatar.

Later in the week, Trump will have meetings with leaders of Jordan, the Palestinian Authority, Britain, Egypt, and Africa, focusing on strengthening security and economic relationships. The final day of the assembly on Thursday will include meetings with leaders of Turkey, Afghanistan, and Ukraine, as well as the leaders of South Korea and Japan, where North Korean nuclear weapon and long-range missile programs will be the main topic.

Trump may also face resistance in his efforts to end or renegotiate the Iran nuclear deal, as administration officials hint that he will likely face resistance at a meeting with foreign ministers of the U.S. partners in the deal: Russia, China, France, Britain, and Germany.

The North Korea crisis may no longer be in the hands of the Security Council, according to U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley, who stated that the North Korea problem may now be one for the Pentagon to resolve. Trump may also face uncomfortable moments over his sharp criticism of the Iran nuclear deal.

Title: James Comey's Descriptions of President Trump in New Book Draw Criticism for Childish Tone

Article:

Excerpts from James Comey's new book were released Thursday night, and the former FBI director's descriptions of President Donald Trump have drawn criticism for a perceived childish tone. The book, "A Higher Loyalty," includes details of Comey's interactions with Trump, including his recollections of the president's physical appearance.

In the book, Comey describes Trump's face as slightly orange with bright white half-moons under his eyes, which he assumes are from tanning goggles, and impressively coifed, bright blond hair. He also notes the size of Trump's hand, stating that it was smaller than his, but not unusually so.

Critics argue that these descriptions, particularly the ones about Trump's appearance, are unnecessary and detract from the serious nature of the book's content. Some have suggested that these comments make Comey look more like a high-school bully than a former FBI director.

The concern is that these descriptions, particularly those about Trump's appearance, undermine Comey's credibility as a witness and author. For example, the passage where Comey refers to the "soft white pouches" under Trump's "expressionless blue eyes" precedes a section where he writes that he believed the president did not understand the FBI's role in American life.

The criticism is that these descriptions, particularly those about Trump's appearance, make Comey look more like a disgruntled former employee rather than an unbiased narrator. Some argue that these descriptions are petty and juvenile, and that they are hack, as they are jokes that have probably been made millions of times before.

It is unclear why Comey chose to include these descriptions in the book, but some suggest that he may have been trying to get a rise out of Trump, given his previous reactions to similar comments about his hands and skin tone.

In response to the book's release, President Trump tweeted, "James Comey is a proven LEAKER & LIAR. Virtually everyone in Washington thought he should be fired for the terrible job he did-until he was, in fact, fired. He leaked CLASSIFIED information, for which he should be prosecuted. He lied to Congress under OATH. He is a weak and….." (April 13, 2018).

Some argue that, regardless of one's political leanings, it would be beneficial for all parties involved to act more mature and avoid childish attacks and personal jabs.

Title: Third-party Candidates Race Against Time to Qualify for Presidential Debate Stage

Article:

Third-party candidates Gary Johnson and Jill Stein are racing against the clock to meet the 15 percent national polling threshold to qualify for the presidential debate stage. The first debate is scheduled for Sept. 26 at Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York, but a decision on qualifying candidates is expected in early September, giving the underfunded and little-known candidates about one month to reach the threshold.

Both Johnson, the Libertarian Party nominee and former Republican governor of New Mexico, and Stein, the Green Party nominee, have surpassed one hurdle by being included in the polls that will determine the debate participants. However, reaching 15 percent in five national surveys leading up to the debate remains a steep climb.

GOP pollster David Winston noted that this year presents a unique opportunity for third-party candidates, as both major party presidential candidates, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, have high disapproval ratings. "You have two historically unappealing candidates in Clinton and Trump that a majority view unfavorably, so a lot of voters are looking for alternatives," Winston said.

Johnson has approached the 15 percent mark in several surveys, reaching as high as 12 percent in a Fox News poll released this week. Johnson's campaign has relied heavily on digital content and media coverage to get their message out, and Johnson and his running mate, Bill Weld, have participated in two prime-time town hall events on CNN. The first event received fewer than 1 million viewers, while the second, which took place on Wednesday, reached 1.6 million viewers, making it the most-watched cable news program in its time slot.

Now, the campaign is looking beyond the press to more traditional campaign activities. Johnson and Weld will hold their first rallies of the cycle this weekend in Nevada and Utah, with additional rallies in Colorado and New Mexico expected later. The campaign is also set to release a national radio ad soon, and a national TV ad is in the works.

Weld has embraced the role of fundraiser for the campaign, boasting in the CNN town hall about having secured $1 million in commitments in one day. That would nearly match what the campaign had raised in the first half of the year. Campaign manager Ron Nielson said small-dollar fundraising is also picking up, with the ticket raising $500,000 in grassroots donations over a two-day stretch this month.

The Johnson-Weld campaign has more than 40 paid staffers now and nearly as many full-time volunteers. Nielson is cautiously optimistic about their chances of making the first debate. "We think we're moving up right now," he said. "We see a lot of support. We feel good. We think we can get above 15 percent."

Stein has topped out at 6 percent in the polls and is only at 4 percent in the RealClearPolitics average. The liberal Green Party candidate is making a concerted push to attract supporters of former Democratic contender Bernie Sanders. Stein has grabbed headlines for being fiercely critical of Clinton, though in a new television ad running on cable news she savages both major party candidates.

The third-party candidates suffered a setback on Friday when a district court judge threw out a case they brought against the Commission on Presidential Debates (CPD) challenging the polling threshold. Johnson still has a separate legal challenge against the commission outstanding. The nonpartisan agency, which declined to comment for this story, could come under pressure as the debates near if Johnson or Stein are climbing in the polls.

Nielson, of Johnson's campaign, lashed out at the agency in a statement. "With Governor Johnson consistently polling in double-digits, we continue to believe that the CPD should make the right and fair decision to invite him to participate in the upcoming debates," Nielson said. "There is clearly an unprecedented desire for alternatives to the Republican and Democratic nominees, and voters deserve an opportunity to see and hear that there are, in fact, other credible, serious choices," he continued. "The CPD could act today to end the two-party stranglehold on the debates, and that is precisely what they should do."

Pollsters interviewed by ███ are doubtful either candidate will make the debate stage. "I think it's unlikely, unless both major party candidates start leaching base support," said Monmouth University pollster Patrick Murray. "While third-party candidates are set to do better this year than in most cycles, the 15 percent threshold is too high a hurdle."

If they miss on the first round, there will be a vice presidential match-up in October and two more presidential debates that month.

Title: Florida Reports Record-Breaking 15,000 New Coronavirus Cases, Raising Concerns Among Public Health Experts

Article:

Florida reported over 15,000 new coronavirus cases on Sunday, surpassing the daily record reported by any single state and drawing international attention to a state that has become one of the world's biggest virus hotspots. The Florida Department of Health received 135,992 results from people who have never been tested before, and 15,299 of those tests came back positive for Covid-19. The positivity rate of new infections was 11.25 percent, which is at least a two-week low and down significantly since the state's record high of 18 percent reported on Wednesday.

Governor Ron DeSantis' administration has continued its messaging strategy of presenting the numbers in a positive light, an approach that has drawn increasing criticism as Florida has emerged as one of the biggest virus hotspots in the world. On Sunday, DeSantis' communications director, Helen Aguirre Ferré, tweeted, "Florida COVID positive cases decline for a third day in a row to 11.25 % despite a record 142,981 tests results returned in a single day." The tweet used a figure that includes those who have been tested multiple times.

DeSantis has routinely turned to the median age of new positive cases to downplay the recent spike, as younger people often show fewer symptoms and rarely require hospitalization. However, public health experts note that the spread in younger populations increases the likelihood of people in at-risk populations, like seniors, getting sick. Young "survivors are reporting significant remaining health issues (fatigue, inability to return to normal levels of exercise) and significant financial burden (loss of work, medical costs)," Jill Roberts of the University of South Florida College of Public Health told a news outlet last week.

On Friday, the DeSantis administration released current hospitalization numbers, which showed 6,974 patients hospitalized with coronavirus as their primary diagnosis, a number that jumped to 7,507 on Sunday. For months, the administration refused to disclose the information, but relented after continued pressure by the Miami Herald and other media outlets.

The issue of reopening Florida's schools has become the newest politicized coronavirus battlefield. Education Commissioner Richard Corcoran, a DeSantis appointee and former Republican speaker of the Florida House, issued an order last week telling school districts they must open classrooms for five days a week beginning next month. Corcoran must approve a district's reopening plan before they can get their cut of state funding. The demand to reopen the state's schools coincided almost to the day with President Donald Trump's beginning a forceful push to get the nation's schools back open, an effort the administration is making as Trump's poll numbers slump less than four months ahead of Election Day.

Title: Romney Delivers Scathing Speech Against Trump, Calls Him a "Phony" and a "Fraud"

Article:

Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, launched a critical attack against Donald Trump, the current GOP front-runner, on Thursday, labeling him as a "phony" and a "fraud." In a speech at the University of Utah, Romney warned that a Trump presidency would lead to recession and "make America and the world less safe."

Romney, who lost to President Barack Obama in the 2012 election, criticized Trump's business record, mocking some of his lesser-known ventures like Trump Mortgage. He also claimed that if Trump were to be nominated, it would enable Hillary Clinton to be elected president.

Trump responded to Romney's criticism on Twitter, claiming he is the "only one who can beat Hillary Clinton" and recalling Romney's record in the presidential elections. Trump also did not rule out mounting an independent bid.

Romney's speech came ahead of the Republican primary debate Thursday night in Detroit, the candidates' first showdown since Super Tuesday. The address amounted to an unprecedented full-court press by Romney to stop Trump from winning the party's nomination.

Romney's speech was not the first time he has criticized Trump. Last week, he told Fox News' Neil Cavuto that he believes there may be a "bombshell" in Trump's tax returns and called for Trump to release his returns as soon as possible. He also criticized Trump for not immediately disavowing the support of former Ku Klux Klan Grand Wizard David Duke.

Although Romney has not endorsed a candidate in the race, there has been widespread media speculation that he could be tempted back into the race in the case of a contested Republican convention as a last-ditch effort to derail Trump. The speech comes after Trump racked up a string of Super Tuesday wins, building a wide, though not insurmountable, delegate lead over his closest rivals, Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio.

Title: Ryan's Email Campaign Sparks Speculation Among Republican Leaders

Article:

Hollywood, Fla. — House Speaker Paul Ryan has been sending a series of emails to select Republican leaders, causing some recipients to question the intentions behind the messages. Some recipients view the emails as self-advertisements, while others interpret them as campaign materials for a potential presidential run if neither Ted Cruz nor Donald Trump secure the nomination after multiple ballots.

Ryan, who has previously stated he has no interest in running for president, has been in the role of Speaker since October, following the vacancy created by Rep. John Boehner of Ohio. One email states, "no matter the outcome of this year’s crucial presidential election, your Republican House majority will continue to fight for conservative values."

The email also includes a "Leadership Priority Survey" to collect input and guide the party's agenda for the election year. A prominent RNC member, who received multiple emails from Ryan in the past week, expressed confusion and asked, "What do you think is up?"

A state GOP chairman attending the Republican National Committee's annual spring meeting in Florida, who also requested anonymity, believed the emails were self-advertisements for Ryan. The speaker has faced criticism from conservatives for his promises to rein in President Obama's liberal policies after the Republican Party gained control of both the Senate and the House.

The Ryan email campaign is relevant to the RNC meeting, as members will debate on Thursday whether to adopt rules for the party's national presidential nominating convention that would make it more difficult to nominate a "white knight" to take the nomination from Cruz or Trump.

Title: Koch Brothers Launch Multi-Million Dollar Campaign Against Trump's Trade Tariffs

Article:

Billionaire brothers Charles and David Koch, co-owners of Koch Industries, one of the world's largest privately-owned firms, are funding a multi-million dollar campaign against President Donald Trump's trade tariffs. Three political groups backed by the brothers, including Freedom Partners Chamber of Commerce, Americans for Prosperity, and the LIBRE Initiative, are urging the president to lift the recent tariffs on aluminum and steel imports, as well as proposed tariffs on other imports from China.

The campaign, which will utilize advertising, lobbying, and grassroots campaigns, aims to highlight the benefits of free trade. The move comes after Trump imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from the EU, Canada, and Mexico.

On Tuesday, David Koch, 78, stepped down from Koch Industries due to health reasons. In a letter, Charles Koch, 82, expressed his sadness about his brother's departure, stating, "David has always been a fighter and is dealing with this challenge in the same way."

The Koch-backed groups are urging the president to reconsider his tariff policies, citing potential negative impacts on American consumers and businesses. Americans for Prosperity president Tim Phillips said the tariffs would "hamstring our full economic potential."

"There are better ways to negotiate trade deals than by punishing American consumers and businesses with higher costs," Phillips added.

The campaign signals growing concern among business groups, typically Republican supporters, about the impact of the tariffs. Leaders from the EU, Canada, and Mexico have criticized the move and threatened retaliation, sparking fears of a trade war. On Tuesday, Mexico imposed a wide range of new tariffs on US goods, including steel, pork, and bourbon.

Trump has defended the steel tariffs, stating they will protect US steelmakers, which he considers vital to national security. However, the Koch network of political organizations, a reliable cash machine for Republicans for more than a decade, is now expressing opposition to the president's tariff policies.

Since Trump's surprise victory, Charles and David Koch have sought common ground with the president, particularly on tax reform. However, they continue to be far from ideological soul mates, and their relationship is becoming increasingly strained as the president pushes for protectionist trade policies.

The Koch brothers' company, the second-largest privately-owned business in the US, has interests ranging from pipelines to paper towels. According to Forbes Magazine, each of the men is worth about $60 billion (£45 billion), and they are tied for eighth richest man in the US. According to the Koch Industries website, they have more than 120,000 employees between all their businesses and subsidiaries.

The brothers have previously put money into groups denying climate change and attacking unions and workers' rights. However, they have also pushed for criminal justice reform and made large donations to the American Civil Liberties Union. Last November, the brothers helped fund Meredith Corporation's deal to buy US magazine publisher Time Inc.

To many Americans, they are known more for their political activism than their corporate brands. The brothers are political mega-donors who have spent millions of dollars on supporting conservative policies, particularly causes that seek to roll back regulations. In 1980, David Koch ran as a vice-presidential candidate of the Libertarian Party.

Title: CBO Estimates $10.2 Billion in Earned Income and Additional Child Tax Credits Cost Over a Decade Due to President Obama's Executive Amnesty

Article:

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has estimated that President Obama's unilateral executive amnesty will cost taxpayers $10.2 billion in Earned Income and Additional Child tax credits over the next ten years. In a letter to Sen. Thad Cochran (R-MS), CBO Director Douglas Elmendorf outlined the financial implications of the House of Representatives Department of Homeland Security funding bill, which aims to undo both of Obama's executive amnesty programs: the 2012 Deferred Action for Childhood Arrival (DACA) program and the 2014 Deferred Action for Parental Accountability (DAPA) program.

The letter states that the House of Representatives Department of Homeland Security funding bill would decrease on-budget deficits by $8.8 billion over ten years due to billions in tax credit spending cuts. The earned income tax credit and the child tax credit are refundable tax credits, according to the letter, which reduce a taxpayer's overall income tax liability. If the credits exceed the other liability, the excess may be refunded to the taxpayer, and these refunds are classified as outlays in the federal budget.

The CBO letter further explains that the decrease in outlays for refundable credits projected for the 2015–2025 period would be largely attributable to decreases in earned income tax credits. The letter continues, stating that H.R. 240 would decrease the amount of earned income tax credits by decreasing the number of people with Social Security numbers, which are required for taxpayers and dependents to qualify for earned income tax credits.

In essence, since Obama's amnesty gives millions of illegal immigrants Social Security numbers, it will cost American taxpayers billions in new spending on those same illegal immigrants. This CBO letter contradicts Obama's promise to the American people that illegal immigrants given amnesty under his program would not be offered "the same benefits that citizens receive."

The CBO letter also estimates that amnestied immigrants will pay $22 billion in Social Security payroll taxes over the next ten years. However, like all Social Security recipients, unless they are deported, amnestied immigrants will eventually be a net drain on the Social Security system, taking out far more in benefits than they paid in.

Title: Tea Party Shifts Strategy: Moderate Senate Candidates Receive Support Over Hardcore Conservatives

Article:

In a significant shift from their 2010 strategy, members of the Tea Party Patriots and Tea Party Express have prioritized winning the Senate over electing hardcore conservatives. Senators Pat Roberts and Scott Brown have received their support, according to The Hill.

The Tea Party Express has also endorsed South Dakota Governor Mike Rounds for Senate, as reported by The Hill. This "hold your nose and vote" attitude, based on the growing awareness among tea party supporters that a moderate win is better than no win at all, has taken root, according to Adam Brandon, Executive Vice President of FreedomWorks.

Jenny Beth Martin, president of the Tea Party Patriots, echoed this sentiment, stating that their members consider a Republican-controlled Senate and ousting Majority Leader Harry Reid as their top priority.

This new approach represents a near 180-degree turn from the principles that propelled the tea party into legislative prominence in the 2010 elections. In 2010, the tea party's mantra was maintaining principles, regardless of potential GOP losses. This shift comes after the tea party failed to win any key battles in the latest primary fight.

Sal Russo, founder of the Tea Party Express, explained, "In 2010, we thought it was very important to get people's attention and so we had to make that statement and challenge the establishment. 2014 was the time to take back the Senate—it wasn't a time to purify the party."

This shift in strategy also follows declarations from Republican Party figures like Karl Rove and Senator Mitch McConnell that tea party influence is harmful to the GOP, a rift that has yet to be fully repaired in recent months.

Ken Cuccinelli, president of the Senate Conservatives Fund, a group that has yet to join the moderate-leaning tea party bandwagon, stated, "Conservatives didn't take out a hatchet. Mitch McConnell and the establishment Republicans did. There is no evidence they have buried that hatchet, and the grassroots is very, very aware of the establishment-induced rift in the party."

Title: Defense Department Inspector General Investigates $400 Million Border Wall Contract Awarded to Fox News-Favored Firm

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — The Defense Department's internal watchdog is investigating a $400 million border wall contract awarded to North Dakota-based firm Fisher Sand and Gravel Co., which has made multiple appearances on Fox News to advocate for the job. The Pentagon's inspector general sent a letter to House Homeland Committee Chairman Bennie Thompson on Thursday, announcing an audit of the contract awarded on Dec. 2, 2019, to build 31 miles of wall in Arizona.

Thompson, D-Miss., requested the review last week, citing concerns that the proposals did not meet operational requirements and prototypes came in late and over budget. Tommy Fisher, the head of the family business, said on Thursday that "there will be nothing to find" in an audit.

The border wall is one of President Donald Trump's top priorities. He campaigned on a promise to build a "big beautiful wall" between the U.S. and Mexico, with Mexico paying for it, and promised to build 450 to 500 miles by the end of 2020. As of Nov. 1, Trump had built 78 miles.

Trump's effort to secure funding for the wall, using money from the Pentagon after Congress refused to fund the wall, has been met with resistance and lawsuits. A federal judge this week blocked the administration from spending some Defense Department money on the barrier, including the contract for Fisher.

Fisher had made a number of appearances on Trump's favorite cable news channel, Fox News, discussing his desire to win a contract. However, the firm, which has little experience with such construction, had a previous proposal rejected. Fisher said his company could do the work for $13 million a mile, while the next closest bid was $20 million a mile.

A letter from the Army Corps when Fisher was awarded the contract stated that the company's proposal was both technically acceptable and the best priced. Two administration officials familiar with the matter told The ███ this year that Trump aggressively pushed the Fisher firm's bid with the heads of Homeland Security and the Army Corps of Engineers, which manages wall contracts. The interference in federal contracting by a president concerned some overseeing the process, but the officials said Trump insisted Fisher could get the wall up faster and cheaper than other bidders. The officials weren't authorized to speak about internal discussions and spoke to the AP on condition of anonymity.

Thompson had expressed one of his concerns was that officials from Homeland Security, the department managing border security, had toured a private barrier built by the company shortly before the contract was awarded. The Pentagon watchdog said it was assessing how to complete the audit and would formally announce it soon.

"The company had never been awarded a construction contract before and their wall prototype was late and over budget," Thompson said in a statement. "Given the President's multiple endorsements of this company and the amount of taxpayer money at stake, I remain concerned about the possibility of inappropriate influence on the Army Corps' contracting decision." The award was the second-largest contract in the company's history. Previously, Fisher built highways, sold heavy equipment, and did excavation work. The company unsuccessfully sued the government in April when it was not awarded a similar contract.

Title: Presidential Election 2012: Candidates Make Last-Minute Push in Battleground States

Article:

As the 2012 United States presidential election approaches, the focus of Sunday morning pre-football television programming shifted from sports to politics. On the eve of the contentious election, political surrogates from both the Republican and Democratic parties engaged in rhetorical sparring about the election's outcome.

David Plouffe, a White House adviser who managed Barack Obama's 2008 campaign, expressed confidence on NBC's "Meet the Press" that Obama would be re-elected on Tuesday. In contrast, Mitt Romney's campaign manager, Rich Beeson, predicted a significant victory for Romney, stating that he would win 300 electoral votes, surpassing the 270 necessary to secure the presidency.

David Axelrod, a senior adviser to Obama, dismissed Republican claims that Pennsylvania had become a competitive state on Fox News. "They understand that they're in deep trouble," Mr. Axelrod said. "They understand that the traditional, or the battleground, states that we've been focusing are not working out for them. Now they're looking for somewhere, desperately looking for somewhere."

In the crucial battleground state of Ohio, the Real Clear Politics polling average shows Obama ahead by nearly three percentage points. However, US Sen. Rob Portman (R-OH), a prominent Romney campaign surrogate, told CNN's Candy Crowley that he believes the GOP candidate has a good chance of taking the state. "All the polls are going in the right direction, so I'm very happy about the polling," he said. "I feel very good about Ohio."

Last-minute polls indicate a race that is virtually tied. A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll of likely voters published Sunday shows Obama leading Romney by a narrow margin, 48% to 47%. Another new poll, Politico/George Washington University's battleground tracking poll of 1,000 likely voters, shows the two candidates tied at 48%. The Real Clear Politics national polling average has Obama ahead by a minuscule fraction: 2/10ths of 1%.

Politico's James Hohmann notes that most of the 3% of remaining undecided voters are unlikely to vote on Tuesday, and the winner will be determined by which candidate can mobilize more of their supporters in the competitive states. This is the aim of both candidates as they make their final push toward Election Day. Obama began his Sunday in New Hampshire before heading to Florida, Ohio, and Colorado, while Romney's schedule included stops in Iowa, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Virginia.

Hurricane Sandy, this year's "October Surprise," appears to have benefited Obama as he balances campaigning, meeting with federal emergency management officials, and staying in close touch with state and local officials in states affected by the superstorm. In the Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll, nearly 70% approved of Obama's handling of the storm. Former Mississippi Gov. Haley Barbour acknowledged this on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday.

Some Republicans have criticized New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie for his focus on the storm response rather than the campaign, with some viewing him as a potential attack dog for the Romney campaign. Speaking after former President Bill Clinton in Bristow, Virginia, on Saturday night, Obama stated that at this point in the campaign, he was largely "a prop" and the race was in the voters' hands. "The power is not with us anymore," he told the estimated crowd of 24,000 gathered on a cold night. "It's all up to you."

Title: President Trump Calls for Accurate and Fair Media Reporting Amidst Recent Violent Incidents

Article:

President Donald Trump has called for the media to report news accurately and fairly, citing inaccurate and even fraudulent reporting as a cause of "great anger" in the country. The president's statement, made in a series of tweets on Monday, comes in the wake of a violent week that saw a spate of mail bombs and a shooting that killed 11 people at a Pittsburgh synagogue.

In his tweets, Trump referred to the media as the "true Enemy of the People," reviving a derisive term for the press less than a week after an explosive device was mailed to CNN's New York City offices. The president's tweets were among several punchy messages he sent on Monday, also criticizing Florida gubernatorial candidate Andrew Gillum and describing a caravan of immigrants headed through Mexico to the U.S. border as an "invasion" of the country.

CNN reported another suspicious package had been intercepted in Atlanta on Monday morning. The package bombings, which also targeted a number of prominent Democrats, led to the arrest of a suspect on Friday. The president's tweets criticizing the media were not the only ones he sent on Monday; he also called Gillum a "thief" and described the immigrant caravan as an "invasion."

Gillum is running in a tight contest against a Trump favorite, former Rep. Ron DeSantis, in Florida's governor contest. Trump is headed to Florida on Wednesday to hold a rally in the state. Race has been a part of the heated contest between DeSantis and Gillum, who is black. Gillum has been drawn into a corruption investigation related to his administration, and has come under scrutiny after records showed he accepted a ticket to the musical "Hamilton" from an undercover FBI agent who he believed was a local developer.

Trump does not have a crowded public schedule on Monday, which often leads to him tweeting throughout the day against his favorite targets. The president often derides negative coverage of his administration as "fake news" and has escalated his attacks in recent months, describing the media as the "enemy of the people." Earlier this month, he praised Rep. Greg Gianforte for body-slamming a reporter last year.

The president has repeatedly lashed out at the media and his critics in recent days, undercutting his own calls for unity following the shooting at the Pittsburgh synagogue and the package bombings. Authorities on Friday charged Cesar Sayoc Jr. with addressing more than a dozen explosive devices to former President Barack Obama, former Vice President Joe Biden, Bill and Hillary Clinton, and Rep. Maxine Waters (D-Calif.), among others. Each intended target has spoken out against the president, and Trump has criticized each person.

The next day, Robert Gregory Bowers was arrested after police said he opened fire in the Tree of Life Synagogue in Pittsburgh, killing 11 people and wounding six. Trump condemned both attacks and has vowed that he will not allow political violence to take root in the country. Democrats and the president's critics have suggested that the president's rhetoric has further inflamed the country's divisions, pointing to his attacks on the Democratic Party as an "angry mob" and the chants of "CNN sucks" and "lock her up" that mark his campaign rallies, referring to Hillary Clinton. The tweets on Monday led Democrats and other critics of Trump to double down on their criticism. Trump told reporters before departing for a rally last Friday that he felt he had been restrained in his rhetoric, rejecting calls to tone it down amid the bomb scares. "I could really tone it up because, as you know, the media's been extremely unfair to me and to the Republican Party," Trump said.

Title: CIA Director Warns of Russian Election Interference, While Trump Administration Fails to Implement Sanctions as Expected

Article:

CIA Director Mike Pompeo has expressed his expectation that Russia will attempt to interfere in the upcoming midterm elections, citing ongoing efforts by Russian intelligence agencies to spread misinformation in the U.S. and Europe as part of a larger strategy to undermine Western politics. Pompeo assured that countermeasures will be taken to minimize the impact on the U.S. elections.

However, the Trump administration's response to the issue seems to contradict Pompeo's statements. On Monday, the Trump administration announced that it would not be imposing any new sanctions against foreign companies doing business with blacklisted Russian defense and intelligence bodies, as required by the Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act (CAATSA). The law, which Congress passed last year despite Donald Trump's objections, was expected to apply additional pressure on the Kremlin following Moscow's targeted campaign to help defeat Hillary Clinton.

Trump only signed the bill under a veto threat and dismissed it as "deeply flawed." The administration did, however, comply with a CAATSA requirement by publishing a list of 114 Russian politicians and 196 oligarchs with a net worth of $1 billion or more. The timing of the list's release, just before a midnight deadline, has been criticized as dilatory, further highlighting the administration's perceived antipathy towards the law.

The administration declined to punish anyone on the list, angering critics. Rep. Eliot Engel, the ranking Democrat on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, stated, "I'm fed up waiting for this administration to protect our country and our elections. They chose instead to let Russia off the hook yet again."

CAATSA requires sanctions against large purchasers of Russian arms, but it grants exceptions for various reasons. The exception cited on Monday was that the mere existence of the legislation was deterring such dealings, according to State Department spokeswoman Heather Nauert. The New York Times notes that CAATSA presents the Trump administration with a challenging issue, as several American allies, including India and Turkey, still purchase military equipment from Russia.

Republican Senator Bob Corker, who helped write the CAATSA, expressed no concern about the lack of announced new sanctions and suggested that additional sanctions may still be forthcoming. "This is when sanctions season begins, and so they'll be rolling them out," he told reporters on Monday. "We feel pretty good about the process."

Title: GOP Strategists Advise Expanding Campaign Focus Beyond Obamacare for 2014 Elections

Article:

Republican strategists are urging their candidates to expand their campaign focus beyond the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) for the 2014 elections, despite the law's unpopularity among conservatives. The Republican Party, with a favorable environment and a competitive lineup of candidates, aims to expand its House majority and take the Senate. However, some within the party are concerned that relying too heavily on Obamacare as a campaign issue may not be sufficient to win over enough voters.

Experts advise the party to transform their criticism of Obamacare into a broader critique of Democrats, addressing other issues and making a broader point about the failures of big-government liberalism. The GOP also needs to demonstrate that they have their own ideas and solutions, as the party brand has been damaged.

"What we need to do is to convince voters that we have the wherewithal and the ideas to fix issues, to put forward those solutions that can address those concerns," said Republican strategist Danny Diaz. "That is the core component of the argument and one I think you're going to see candidates across [the] country do to a greater degree than they have before."

Some House Republicans are already discussing their own proposals on immigration and healthcare, although these are more guidelines than actual legislation. The National Republican Congressional Committee is making a concerted effort to define what the party stands for, with Chairman Greg Walden stating, "The point is, you need something positive to run on."

Other GOP campaigns have already broadened their messages. For example, Mitch McConnell, in Kentucky's race, criticizes his Democratic opponent Alison Lundergan Grimes for her position on coal, an issue of particular resonance in the state's race. Attacks on Obamacare can offer GOP candidates an opening to make a broader point about their opponent.

Despite concerns about focusing too much on Obamacare, the issue's broad-spectrum nature, affecting voters' health care, the country's debt, and the economy, makes it an inherently broad-spectrum attack. This was bolstered this week when the Congressional Budget Office predicted the economy will lose the equivalent of 2.5 million workers by 2024 due to the health law.

"If James Carville were a Republican, there'd be a sign hanging in his office that said, 'It's Obamacare, stupid,'" said GOP pollster Glen Bolger. He argued that Republicans shouldn't be worried about dwelling too much on Obamacare; they should be worried about not talking about it enough.

"Yes, we do need more than just Obamacare," he said. "But we don't need a lot more."

In a close race, the "more" that Bolger is talking about could make the difference between winning and losing. And it's why many Republicans, as thrilled with the political gift of Obamacare as they are, aren't ready to bet the house on it just yet.

Title: Misconceptions and Consequences of U.S. Tariffs on Chinese Imports

Article:

The ongoing trade tensions between the United States and China have sparked a debate among free market advocates, with some supporting tariffs on Chinese imports despite their usual opposition to trade barriers. The concern is that China's "Made in China 2025" plan, aimed at dominating various industries, could lead to China's economic dominance.

George Mason University economist Don Boudreaux has commented on this inconsistency, stating that those on the political right who typically believe in free markets are now supporting trade barriers due to concerns about China's plan. Boudreaux notes that these individuals believe foreign governments, particularly those with authoritarian histories, can improve their economies with subsidies, trade restrictions, and industrial policies, despite the U.S. government's inability to outperform the market in "picking winners."

The argument that China's overproduction of steel and other goods is detrimental to the U.S. and other countries is puzzling, as it could lower costs for thousands of small U.S. manufacturers and steel consumers. However, this "overproduction" is a burden for the Chinese people, as their government's subsidization of steel production diverts resources from other areas of the Chinese economy.

The notion that trade is the primary cause of the steel industry's struggles is misleading. For decades, the U.S. has imported between 25% and 30% of its steel, leaving domestic steel with a healthy 70% to 75% of the market. The loss of steel jobs is primarily due to labor-saving innovations (technology) implemented by American steel executives, which increased individual steel workers' productivity and wages. Steel employment in the U.S. peaked in 1956, long before China entered the picture.

Another common argument is that China steals intellectual property from the U.S. However, imposing import taxes (tariffs) to retaliate against China is an inefficient and unfair policy that could put thousands of other American jobs at risk, expose the U.S. to retaliation, and cause U.S. companies to move their production abroad. The best solutions involve using international organizations to challenge China's actions and forming alliances with like-minded allies.

It is essential to clarify that this article is not a defense of the Chinese regime's human rights abuses or lack of free market economic policies. However, many arguments against China in terms of trade either misidentify the true victims or advocate for the wrong remedies. Furthermore, increased U.S. trade and investment restrictions will not make China more like the U.S., but rather, more government control over the U.S. economy will make the U.S. more like China.

Title: President Trump's Market Claims and Economic Indicators

Article:

President Donald Trump has been touting the stock market's performance during his presidency, but recent market volatility, such as the Dow Jones Industrial Average's 1,500-point drop on February 5, 2020, has raised questions about attributing market fluctuations to a single administration.

During the State of the Union address last week, the president highlighted the stock market's growth, stating, "The stock market has smashed one record after another, gaining $8 trillion in value." However, when the market experiences a downturn, as it did on February 5, the president's spokespeople have shifted the narrative, stating, "We're always concerned when the market loses any value, but we're also confident in the economy's fundamentals."

The market's volatility appears to be influenced by two significant factors: the increasing federal deficit due to tax cuts and the potential adjustment of interest rates by the Federal Reserve in response to signs of a heating economy. The tax cuts, which have been implemented without any offsetting spending cuts, will push the deficit higher and bring the debate over the debt ceiling back to Congress. Additionally, the Federal Reserve may adjust interest rates in response to new wage data, causing investor concern.

It is essential to note that presidents do not control the stock market. While the market can respond to political events, attributing market upswings to a president's policies does not absolve them from responsibility when the market experiences downturns. President Trump's tendency to take credit for factors outside of his control, such as low airline fatalities and Christmas wishes, extends to the stock market as well.

Furthermore, the unemployment rate, which previously reached a low that prompted the president to boast, has spiked back up. As with the stock market, the president neither gets all the credit nor all the blame for economic indicators.

Title: EPA Eases Enforcement of Environmental Regulations in Response to COVID-19 Outbreak

Article:

The United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has announced a decision to ease enforcement of environmental regulations affecting polluting industries in response to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The move follows requests from the oil lobby and other industry groups for regulatory relief as governments worldwide grapple with the pandemic's impact, which has infected nearly half a million people, decimated travel, and caused widespread disruptions.

In a press release, EPA Administrator Andrew Wheeler stated, "EPA is committed to protecting human health and the environment, but recognizes challenges resulting from efforts to protect workers and the public from COVID-19 may directly impact the ability of regulated facilities to meet all federal regulatory requirements."

The EPA's memo outlining the changes states that it will not impose fines on polluting industries for violating certain monitoring and reporting requirements during the outbreak. Instead, the EPA will focus its resources on situations that may create an acute risk or imminent threat to public health or the environment.

The EPA also stated that it does not expect to seek penalties for violations of routine compliance monitoring, integrity testing, sampling, laboratory analysis, training, and reporting or certification obligations in situations where the EPA agrees that COVID-19 was the cause.

The EPA will also work with the Department of Justice to "exercise enforcement discretion" related to penalties previously assessed on polluting companies, according to the memo signed by Susan Bodine, EPA's Assistant Administrator for Enforcement and Compliance.

The changes are retroactive to March 13, 2020. Last week, the American Petroleum Institute (API) asked U.S. President Donald Trump for temporary relief from regulatory requirements on the oil and gas industry to ensure steady fuel supplies during the coronavirus outbreak.

The API's main concern was that the coronavirus would leave it with limited numbers of healthy staff to run critical operations, making it harder to comply with federal environmental and safety requirements. The oil industry also seeks waivers allowing the sale of winter-grade gasoline deep into spring and summer to deal with a supply glut caused by the coronavirus outbreak's reduction in demand for motor fuels.

The EPA memo on Thursday did not address fuel waivers. More than a dozen environmental groups criticized the agency for putting the public at risk as it eased its enforcement of air and water protections.

"Excusing the potential release of excess toxic air pollutants and other pollution that exacerbates asthma, breathing difficulty, and cardiovascular problems in the midst of a pandemic that can cause respiratory failure is irresponsible from a public health perspective," said a letter from groups including the Environmental Integrity Project and Wild Earth Guardians.

Title: Walmart Urged to Release Surveillance Tape of John Crawford III Shooting Incident

Article:

A call for transparency has been made regarding the fatal shooting of John Crawford III, a 22-year-old black man, in a Walmart store in Beavercreek, Ohio last month. The incident, which occurred while Crawford was shopping with his girlfriend, has sparked controversy due to the presence of video evidence that some believe could shed light on the circumstances surrounding his death.

Crawford and his girlfriend had gone to the Walmart to purchase ingredients for a family cookout. While browsing, Crawford picked up an unpackaged BB gun from a store shelf and continued shopping. A man named Ronald Ritchie, who saw Crawford, called 911, stating that a black man was "walking around with a gun in the store" and "pointing it at people."

In a matter of minutes, Crawford was shot by police. The BB gun, which was a toy and unloaded, was found at the scene. Crawford's last words were reportedly, "It's not real."

The incident has raised questions about implicit bias and the role it may have played in the shooting. Some speculate that Ritchie may have been more likely to perceive danger due to Crawford's race, and that the police may have been more likely to respond with lethal force due to the same factor.

Implicit bias, also known as unconscious bias, is a term used to describe the subtle prejudices that people may hold, even if they are not consciously aware of them. These biases can influence decisions and actions, often without the individual realizing it.

The release of the surveillance tape is being sought by Crawford's family and thousands of supporters who have signed a petition on ColorOfChange.com. The family believes the tape will demonstrate that Crawford was never a threat and was gunned down in cold blood. Even Ronald Ritchie, the man who called the police, has reportedly changed his story, stating that Crawford never pointed a gun at anyone after seeing the tape.

Ohio Attorney General Mike DeWine has expressed concerns about releasing the tape, stating that it could potentially bias the jury. However, he has shown no issue with using the tape to clarify facts with Ritchie, a witness for the prosecution, or with media speculation about Crawford's criminal record, which was dropped.

Walmart, the largest employer of black people in the country and a significant retailer for black consumers, has been urged to release the tape to promote transparency and ensure the safety of its customers. The release of the tape could potentially help address the lingering realities of racial bias and contribute to a more open and honest discussion about the issue.

Title: Major Broadcast Networks Ignore Hillary Clinton's Remarks on Job Creation

Article:

In a departure from standard news coverage, the major English and Spanish broadcast networks have omitted any mention of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's remarks on job creation made during a campaign event for Massachusetts Democratic gubernatorial candidate Martha Coakley on Friday. Clinton stated, "Do not let anybody tell you that, you know – it's corporations and businesses that create jobs. That old theory, trickle-down economics. That has been tried, that has failed."

Since her remarks, the English-language networks ABC, CBS, and NBC, as well as Spanish-language networks Telemundo and Univision, have not covered the story in their morning or evening newscasts. This is a stark contrast to how they would typically handle potentially controversial statements from a Republican figure or future presidential hopeful.

On the Fox News Channel's evening news program, Special Report with Bret Baier, senior political analyst Brit Hume devoted a segment to the subject. After an introduction from Baier, Hume discussed Clinton's comments, stating, "Hillary Clinton created quite a fervor over the weekend, saying that corporations and businesses do not create jobs."

In response to the backlash, Clinton attempted to clarify her remarks during a campaign event in New York on Monday. She stated, "Let me be absolutely clear about what I've been saying for a couple of decades: Our economy grows when businesses and entrepreneurs create good-paying jobs here in an America where workers and families are empowered to build from the bottom up and the middle out – not when we hand out tax breaks for corporations that outsource jobs or stash their profits overseas."

Despite Clinton's clarification, the networks have not covered her original remarks or her subsequent "walk back" of the statement. With the 2014 midterms taking place next Tuesday and media coverage focusing on Jeb Bush's possible 2016 presidential run, the coverage of Clinton's anti-business statements remains to be seen.

The full transcript of the segment that aired on FNC's Special Report with Bret Baier on October 27 can be found below.

Title: Capitol Hill Republicans Threaten to Block Climate Funding for Paris Summit

Article:

Capitol Hill Republicans are seeking to undermine President Obama's push for a global climate agreement at next week's international summit in Paris, with the threat of withholding vital funding if the president attempts to bypass Congress. The two-week U.N. conference, starting Monday under heightened security following the Paris terror attacks, aims to address climate change and build a better future for future generations.

At a press conference alongside French President Francois Hollande, President Obama described the climate summit as a global statement of solidarity. "What a powerful rebuke to the terrorists it will be when the world stands as one and shows that we will not be deterred from building a better future for our children," Obama said earlier this week.

However, at home, the country and Congress remain deeply divided over the president's plans for cutting emissions. Lawmakers are concerned that the president may etch an international pact without seeking Senate approval.

Critics of the president's climate agenda have focused on the president's goal of directing $3 billion, including $500 million in the near-term, for the U.N. Green Climate Fund, which would help developing nations deal with climate change. Ahead of the president's trip, dozens of lawmakers warned the president: "No vote, no money."

Sen. John Barrasso, R-Wyo., stated at a hearing last week, "Without Senate approval, there will be no money – period." He emphasized that any agreement with legally binding requirements must come before the Senate for a vote. Sen. Jim Inhofe, R-Okla., and Sen. Joe Manchin of West Virginia, along with Republican Sen. Roy Blunt of Missouri, have also sent a letter to Obama urging the president to have his special envoy relay to developing nations' representatives that Congress "will not be forthcoming" with the Green Climate Fund money absent a Senate vote.

In addition, Inhofe joined Manchin and Blunt in introducing a resolution calling for the Senate to have a say in any climate agreement. Republicans generally argue that any deal with legally binding elements should be handled like a treaty and subject to Senate ratification. The Obama administration, however, has given varying statements on how it views any potential pact.

Secretary of State John Kerry rattled European officials when he was quoted earlier this month in the Financial Times saying any agreement was "definitively not going to be a treaty." French President Hollande bristled at the notion that a deal would not be legally binding and was quoted saying if that's the case, "there won't be an agreement."

The State Department clarified that the U.S. wants binding and non-binding components. An official told Politico: "The FT interview with Secretary Kerry may have been read to suggest that the U.S. supports a completely non-binding approach. That is not the case and that is not Secretary Kerry's position. Our position has not changed: the U.S. is pressing for an agreement that contains provisions both legally binding and non-legally binding."

House Science Committee Chairman Lamar Smith, R-Texas, stated at a recent hearing that the president doesn't want to come to Congress with a Paris agreement because "he knows the Senate will not ratify it." Smith also warned a centerpiece of the U.S. commitment that Obama will bring to the table in Paris – the Clean Power Plan, regulations on power plant emissions – "represents massive costs without significant benefits."

As lawmakers threaten to block U.S. support for the U.N. climate fund, The Wall Street Journal reports that the House next week also plans to vote on measures to repeal those EPA rules for power plants, on the heels of the Senate doing the same. It's doubtful Republicans could overcome a presidential veto, but the vote is a reminder of the resistance facing those regulations, which are the subject of a massive federal court case brought by mostly Republican-led states.

The administration suggests it has high hopes for the summit. Obama struck a climate deal with China before the Paris talks and plans to meet one-on-one with Chinese President Xi Jinping – as well as Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi – in Paris next week. Ahead of the summit, Christiana Figueres, executive secretary of the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change, told FoxNews.com a historic deal will be reached. "Everyone has actually realized that there is more risk in not addressing climate change and there is more opportunity in addressing it," she said.

Title: House Defeats President Reagan's Tax Reform Bill, Setting a Precedent for Modern Political Struggles

Article:

In a significant political event that echoes modern-day legislative battles, President Ronald Reagan faced a stunning defeat in the House of Representatives during a crucial vote on a top priority of his second term, tax reform. Although there is a slim chance that he could switch enough votes to reverse the outcome, prospects seem grim.

The tax reform bill, passed in 1986, marked a turning point in Reagan's legislative agenda. For months, as Reagan worked with the Democratic majority to overhaul the tax code, House Republicans felt increasingly marginalized, believing they were being left out of the process and giving too much to the opposition. GOP leaders aligned with a group of Democrats who disliked the bill and hatched a plan to defeat the procedural rule for considering it.

Remarkably, Reagan managed to secure the necessary votes to get the bill back on track. The President, known as the "Gipper," made an unusual trip to Capitol Hill and asked his partisans to reconsider. He followed up with a letter pledging that he would work for changes in the Senate and that he would veto any final bill that fell short of his objectives. The measure soon passed the House, and after some gyrations in the Senate, it became law in 1986.

The story of Reagan's tax reform struggle offers a potential lesson for President Obama, who recently suffered a trade defeat. However, Obama's situation differs from Reagan's in several ways that do not work to his advantage.

In December 1985, Reagan was still popular, with Gallup putting his approval rating at 63 percent. President Obama's approval has been about 20 points lower. Even pro-Obama Democrats still feel disappointment. The artist who created the iconic "Hope" poster recently faced the question of whether the president had lived up to it, to which he responded, "Not even close."

With Reagan's election in 1980, Republicans won their first Senate majority since Eisenhower and picked up a large number of seats in the House. Though they had since lost some ground in the lower chamber, they still had about two dozen more seats in 1985 than before Reagan. Under Obama, by contrast, Democrats have lost their majorities in both chambers. Apart from the presidency, they are now in their weakest position since the 1920s.

Since the GOP controlled the Senate in 1985, Reagan's promise to work for changes in the bill carried some weight. Obviously, Obama cannot do anything similar. In his meeting with House Democrats last week, he took a different tact, suggesting that opponents of the bill were not playing straight. His message backfired and cost him votes instead.

Time is growing short. Ironically, Obama can now pull off a legislative miracle with Democratic liberals only by emulating the man who personified Republican conservatism.

Title: Pew Research Center Poll Reveals Increased Political Polarization Among Americans

Article:

A new survey conducted by the Pew Research Center has revealed a significant increase in political polarization among Americans over the past 20 years. The poll, titled "Political Polarization in the American Public," aimed to understand the extent and nature of political polarization in relation to government, society, and personal lives.

The survey found that the percentage of Americans who hold either consistently conservative or consistently liberal positions on major issues has doubled over the past decade, accounting for 20 percent of all Americans. Thirty-nine percent of Americans hold equally liberal and conservative positions on issues.

The survey also found that the most politically active have become increasingly partisan and entrenched in their positions. According to Pew, many Americans who view themselves as consistently conservative or consistently liberal are making their voices heard through greater participation in every stage of the political process, including primary voting, writing letters to officials, volunteering for or donating to a campaign, and amplifying their views.

The survey also found that Americans who view themselves as consistently conservative or consistently liberal is at a 20-year peak. Ninety-two percent of Republicans are to the right of the median Democrat, compared with 64 percent twenty years ago. Similarly, 94 percent of Democrats are to the left of the median Republican, up from 70 percent in 1994.

The survey also found that these Americans' views are so polarized that most of these intense partisans believe the opposing party's policies are so misguided that they threaten the nation's well-being.

Political views also spill over into virtually every area of partisan Americans' lives, according to the study of 10,013 people. Sixty-three percent of consistent conservatives and 49 percent of consistent liberals – compared with 25 percent of those with mixed ideological views – told Pew that most of their close friends share their political views.

Title: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's Defense of Free Speech Faces Backlash

Article:

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg testified before the House Financial Services Committee in Washington, D.C., on October 23, 2019. In his defense of free expression, Zuckerberg has faced criticism for running a "hate-speech machine" and has been boycotted by major American companies.

In a speech at Georgetown University last fall, Zuckerberg emphasized the importance of free speech and its role in the worldwide fight for democracy. He praised Supreme Court jurisprudence that has strengthened First Amendment protections.

The reaction to Zuckerberg's stance on free speech has been markedly different in 2020 compared to previous years. Instead of praise, the response has been calls for his removal from his position.

Internet companies are often tasked with drawing the line between permissible and non-permissible content, but the current Facebook controversy is more significant. The company is under attack by left-wing activists who have managed to force a wave of cancellations and seek to influence a social media giant to align with their views.

The Georgetown speech led activists to view Zuckerberg as a staunch defender of free speech. One point of contention was Zuckerberg's reference to the importance of the First Amendment to the cause of civil rights, which some activists found offensive.

Another point of contention was Zuckerberg's stance on not censoring politicians or fact-checking political ads. The final straw was Facebook's refusal to act against President Donald Trump's post stating, "when the looting starts, the shooting starts."

Activists have pursued two lines of attack. One has been to pressure companies to stop advertising with Facebook, and many have joined the advertising boycott. The other has been to associate Facebook with the words "racism" and "hate" to create the impression that Facebook profits from neo-Nazi posts rather than from ordinary users who find the platform useful.

Despite the backlash, Facebook's stance on free speech has been defended by some, including the author of this article. The public benefits from a robust online debate, where individuals can make their own decisions about the merits of political figures' statements. The stakes are high, as Facebook is an institution too big to cancel, and the advertising boycott has minimal impact on the company's revenue. If Zuckerberg can be pressured into abandoning his support for a free-speech-centric approach to his platform, it could serve as a significant warning in a period of national life full of them.

Title: Federal Lawsuit Filed Over University of California at Berkeley's Handling of Conservative Speakers

Article:

The University of California at Berkeley (UC Berkeley) is facing a federal lawsuit over its handling of conservative speakers, following a series of incidents that have sparked controversy and prompted a rebuke from President Trump on Twitter. The lawsuit, filed on Monday, alleges that UC Berkeley's unwritten policy regarding "high-profile speakers" unconstitutionally discriminates against unpopular viewpoints.

The Berkeley College Republicans (BCR) and Young America's Foundation (YAF) argue that the policy, adopted after violent protests led to the cancellation of a February 1 appearance by former Breitbart News editor Milo Yiannopoulos, unlawfully restricts free speech. As a result, UC Berkeley canceled a scheduled speech by conservative commentator Ann Coulter and offered to reschedule it for next Tuesday afternoon, during the "dead week" between classes and exams.

BCR and YAF claim that the university has not applied the restrictions imposed in the name of public safety to left-leaning speakers, and that these restrictions amount to an "unlawful heckler's veto" that marginalizes conservative voices. The organizations also cite the cancellation of a talk by conservative journalist David Horowitz, who was scheduled to speak on April 12, due to the university's insistence on an inconvenient location and an early end time.

President Trump, in a tweet following the February Milo Yiannopoulos incident, suggested that UC Berkeley risks losing federal funds if it "does not allow free speech." However, the administration's commitment to protecting First Amendment rights has been questioned, as it has reportedly demanded that Twitter reveal the identity of a Department of Homeland Security (DHS) critic and is considering criminal charges against individuals who share classified information leaked by others.

Last month, a special agent in charge at Customs and Border Protection (CBP), a division of DHS, issued a summons to Twitter seeking records that would unmask the person or persons behind the @ ALT_USCIS account, which regularly criticizes the Trump administration's immigration policies. The summons, which appeared to be a blatant attempt to intimidate critics, was dropped the day after Twitter filed a lawsuit arguing that it threatened the First Amendment right to engage in pseudonymous political speech.

DHS Inspector General John Roth is currently investigating whether the CBP summons was "improper." Last week, Sen. Ron Wyden (D-Ore.) inquired about government inquiries that might have a "chilling effect on individuals' free speech rights." Meanwhile, the Justice Department is reportedly considering prosecuting WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange for sharing classified documents with the public, a move that could set a precedent for criminalizing common journalistic practices.

CIA Director Mike Pompeo has stated that Assange is not a real journalist, a debatable and constitutionally irrelevant point. The "freedom of the press" guaranteed by the First Amendment is not the freedom of people who work for officially recognized news outlets; it is the freedom to use technologies of mass communication.
