This freedom extends to everyone in the United States, whether or not they are professional journalists or American citizens. If Assange broke the Espionage Act by distributing classified material within the U.S., that means he used "the press" there.

Trump, who once declared "I love WikiLeaks!" when it was revealing embarrassing information about Hillary Clinton, has since changed his tune, stating, "It's OK with me." The article does not provide further details about the potential criminal case against Assange.

Title: Chris Rock's Insight on Inequality and the American Dream

Article:

Comedian Chris Rock's recent comments on inequality and the American Dream during an interview with Frank Rich have sparked discussion, with his remarks on the public's perception of wealth disparity being particularly noteworthy. In the interview, Rock stated, "If poor people knew how rich rich people are, there would be riots in the streets."

Rock's assertion, on a factual basis, is supported by multiple studies that show Americans significantly underestimate the degree of inequality in the U.S. economy. For instance, a study found that subjects estimated the top 20 percent of U.S. households owned about 59 percent of the country's net worth, while the actual figure is closer to 84 percent.

Rock's statement goes beyond the reality of inequality itself and touches upon the public's perception of American society and its influence on politics. He expanded his remarks to include the "average person," stating that they too would be outraged and bewildered by the lifestyle of the 1 percent.

The sustainability of such inequality in the U.S., as compared to other democracies, is attributed to the American Dream, a long-standing belief in the possibility of upward mobility through hard work and perseverance. However, a recent study by Gregory Clark, a researcher at the University of California, Davis, suggests that the American Dream is no longer operational today. Clark argues that social mobility today does not fulfill the American Dream's promises and, in fact, never did.

Clark's findings challenge the notion that the American Dream, with its promise of upward mobility, has been a significant factor in papering over the gap between perception and reality in U.S. society. As more Americans come to terms with the reality of the American Dream, the 1 percent and the stewards of government may face increased challenges.

Title: Obama and Romney Hold First Post-Election Meeting at the White House

Article:

In a significant development, President Barack Obama and his Republican rival, Mitt Romney, held their first meeting since the election at the White House on Thursday. The lunch, which took place in the White House's private dining room, marked the fulfillment of a promise Obama made in his victory speech on November 6.

The conversation between the two presidential contenders focused on America's global leadership and the importance of maintaining that position. According to the White House, Romney congratulated the president on his successful campaign and wished him well for the upcoming four years.

The lunch menu consisted of white turkey chili and Southwestern grilled chicken salad. The meeting, lasting over an hour, was reportedly their most extensive private talk to date, with limited interactions between the two during the 2012 election, confined primarily to the three presidential debates.

Prior to the lunch, Romney and his former running mate, Paul Ryan, had a meeting to discuss the economic challenges facing Washington. Details of this meeting were not disclosed, as the aide who provided the information was not authorized to discuss the private discussions.

The economic debate between Obama and Romney during the campaign centered on the expiring tax cuts first enacted during the George W. Bush administration. The two candidates had differing views on the matter, with Romney advocating for the extension of the cuts for all income earners, while Obama ran on a pledge to let the cuts expire for families earning more than $250,000 a year.

The White House views Obama's victory as a sign of public support for his tax proposals. Since his election loss, Romney has largely remained out of the political limelight, spending the past three weeks in seclusion at his family's California home. He has made no public appearances, drawing media attention only after being photographed at Disneyland, as well as visits to the movies and the gym with his wife, Ann.

Title: Boko Haram Releases Video Showing Over 100 Kidnapped Schoolgirls; Negotiations for Their Release Underway

Article:

A new video believed to be from the Nigerian terror group Boko Haram shows over 100 kidnapped Christian schoolgirls praying in Arabic and declaring their conversion to Islam. The video, obtained by the Associated Press, features Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau, who is reportedly negotiating with the Nigerian government for the release of the girls in exchange for imprisoned militants.

In the 27-minute video, the girls, ranging in age from 15 to 18, are seen wearing black and gray hijabs and reciting the Koran. Some appear fearful or desolate, while one girl stated in the video that they had not been harmed. Three of the girls are shown speaking in the video, with two stating they were Christian and had converted to Islam, and the other stating she is Muslim.

Shekau is seen in military fatigues cradling an assault rifle on the video, which is imprinted with the Boko Haram insignia. The United States put a $7 million bounty on Shekau's head last year. The video is the first sighting of the abducted girls since more than 300 were taken from their school in the northern town of Chibok by Islamist militants on April 14. Although more than 50 girls have escaped their captors and are now safe, at least 276 remain missing.

The search for the missing girls has centered on the Sambisa forest, with Nigerian troops being aided by advisers from the U.S., Britain, and France. The U.S. has more than 50 military personnel and advisors based at the Nigerian Embassy to help "advise and assist" in the search for the missing girls. The teams have expertise in communications, logistics, civil affairs, and intelligence. There are no plans to put additional U.S. military forces on the ground in Nigeria.

When asked about the video, U.S. State Department spokesperson Jen Psaki said U.S. intelligence agents are hoping to use it to help rescue the girls. "We have no reason to question its authenticity. Our intelligence experts are combing through every detail of the video for clues that might help in ongoing efforts to secure the release of the girls," Psaki said.

The video emerged as the Nigerian government reportedly made "indirect contact" with Boko Haram. The Nigerian government has been heavily criticized for how it has conducted its search for the missing girls, who were taken after taking final exams. On Friday, the group Amnesty International claimed that Nigerian security forces were aware that a convoy of fighters from Boko Haram was approaching the town of Chibok four hours before the kidnapping but did nothing to stop the kidnappings. It is believed that 53 girls were able to escape the kidnappers. One of them, 19-year-old Sarah Lawan, told the Associated Press that her ordeal was "too terrifying for words" and added that she was afraid to go back to school.

Boko Haram, whose name, loosely translated, means "Western education is forbidden," is believed to have killed approximately 1,500 people in Nigeria so far this year and has been waging an insurgency in the country for the past five years. Shekau claimed credit for the abductions in a video last week, saying, "I abducted your girls! By Allah, I will sell them in the marketplace!"

Title: Pro-Life Movement Shifts Focus After House Flips to Pro-Choice Majority

Article:

In the aftermath of the U.S. midterm elections, the pro-life movement has faced a significant setback as the House of Representatives has transitioned into a pro-choice majority, while the Senate has seen an increase in pro-life lawmakers. Mallory Quigley, a spokesperson for the Susan B. Anthony List (SBA), expressed her concerns about the shift, stating, "We cannot get around the fact that this is certainly a loss for the pro-life movement, that the House, which has been a vanguard, is now going to be back in the hands of someone like Nancy Pelosi who is absolutely an abortion radical."

In light of this development, pro-life activists, such as Quigley, are refocusing their efforts on preventing federal funding for Planned Parenthood. Quigley stated, "This is a fight that we have to take up, a mantle that we have to pick up every day." SBA teams began door-to-door canvassing in July and, according to Quigley, their efforts resulted in a reliably pro-life Senate.

Quigley emphasized the importance of the Senate, as it serves as a crucial platform for the confirmation of Supreme Court justices. She noted the battles to confirm Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh, and expressed optimism that future nominations by President Donald Trump, who is considered the most pro-life president in American history, would not be blocked by pro-choice senators like Lisa Murkowski (AK) and Susan Collins (ME).

Trump, in his 2018 address to tens of thousands of activists during the March for Life, reaffirmed his commitment to the pro-life cause, stating, "Every child is a precious gift from God." In his presidential campaign, he pledged to take several actions to protect life, and Quigley noted that he has been keeping his promises.

In the near future, the Department of Health and Human Services is expected to finalize the "Protect Life Rule," which will cut off approximately $60 million in funding for Planned Parenthood, the organization's second-largest source of funding. If Planned Parenthood continues to perform abortions, they will no longer receive Title X funding.

Despite the loss of a pro-life majority in the House, Quigley remains optimistic, stating, "It's a very encouraging time to be pro-life." SBA teams are expected to resume door-to-door canvassing in 2020 to rally the pro-life vote.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Prepares for Vote on Impeachment Inquiry Procedures, Despite Lack of Support Among Democrats

Article:

The House of Representatives' impeachment process, despite parliamentary procedures, consists of three straightforward steps. First, the House authorizes the Judiciary Committee to open a formal impeachment inquiry. Next, the committee conducts an investigation to determine if the president has committed any offense warranting removal from office. Finally, if such evidence is discovered, the full House votes to approve one or more articles of impeachment.

Currently, the Democrats, despite accusations of wrongdoing at the White House, lack the necessary votes in the House to initiate the first step toward removing President Trump. As a result, House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler has decided to conduct an impeachment inquiry, a move that has been criticized by some Democrats.

Over the weekend, CNN reported that the House Judiciary Committee is preparing to vote next week on a resolution outlining the procedures for its investigation. The vote, expected to occur on Wednesday, will establish the ground rules for conducting hearings now that the committee has publicly announced it is considering recommending articles of impeachment against Trump.

Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii), a Democratic presidential candidate, is among those who oppose the impeachment inquiry. She stated, "I don't support impeachment. I think it's important for us to think about what is in the best interest of the country and the American people, and continuing to pursue impeachment is something that I think will only further tear our country apart."

The Democratic National Committee has arranged the rules to exclude Rep. Gabbard from the next presidential debate, reflecting her disagreement with the party's far-left faction. However, she aligns with moderate Democrats, who are likely to face the consequences of Nadler's plan to cater to the radical left.

Vulnerable Democrats and cautious consultants, as well as a majority of the electorate, oppose Nadler's expanded impeachment inquiry. A solid majority of voters are against impeachment, according to various public opinion polls, including the latest Monmouth University Poll, which found little support for investigations and less for impeachment.

The House Judiciary Committee's actions have been criticized by both sides of the political aisle. Sen. Doug Collins (R-Ga.), Ranking Member of the Judiciary Committee, told Fox News that the impeachment inquiry is a "show" and a "publicity stunt" driven in part by Nadler's desire to avoid a primary challenge from the left. Collins also suggested that Nadler's inquiry is a desperate measure to prevent Trump from being reelected while the GOP recaptures the few seats it needs to deprive the Democrats of their House majority.

The impeachment inquiry's legitimacy and purpose have been questioned by many, including Sen. Collins, who expressed sympathy for Nadler, stating, "This is really pathetic. Nothing like this has ever happened in the House before."

Title: Trump Defends Sharing ISIS Threat Information with Russian Officials

Article:

In a series of tweets on Tuesday, President Donald Trump defended his decision to share sensitive information about an Islamic State terrorist threat with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and Russian Ambassador to the U.S. Sergey Kislyak during a White House meeting last week.

Trump stated that he had the "absolute right" to reveal "facts" to the Russian officials for "humanitarian reasons," with the aim of encouraging Russia to intensify its fight against ISIS and terrorism.

"As President I wanted to share with Russia (at an openly scheduled W.H. meeting) which I have the absolute right to do, facts pertaining to terrorism and airline flight safety," Trump tweeted. "Humanitarian reasons, plus I want Russia to greatly step up their fight against ISIS & terrorism."

However, Trump's statement contradicts that of his national security adviser, H.R. McMaster, who, on Monday night, told reporters outside the West Wing that the president did not disclose "intelligence sources or methods."

McMaster's statement was in response to a Washington Post report that claimed Trump "went off script" during the meeting and discussed details about an Islamic State terrorist threat related to the use of laptop computers on aircraft.

"The story that came out tonight, as reported, is false," McMaster said. "The president and the foreign minister reviewed a range of common threats to our two countries, including threats to civil aviation. At no time—at no time—were intelligence sources or methods discussed."

Dina Powell, who serves as the deputy national security adviser for strategy, also denied the story in a statement, saying, "This story is false. The president only discussed the common threats that both countries faced."

The Washington Post report also stated that the information Trump shared had been provided by a U.S. partner through an intelligence-sharing arrangement considered so sensitive that details have been withheld from allies and tightly restricted even within the U.S. government.

"I get great intel. I have people brief me on great intel every day," Trump said, according to the Washington Post report.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie Accuses President Obama of Lying in Debate Ad

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie has accused President Barack Obama of lying in a campaign advertisement attacking Mitt Romney's economic plan. During an interview on ABC's "This Week," Christie stated that President Obama's accusation that Romney wants to cut taxes for the wealthy is false.

"Stop lying, Mr. President...Governor Romney is not talking about more tax cuts for the wealthy. In fact, what he said is that the wealthy will pay just as much under a Romney administration as they pay today," Christie said.

The Obama campaign released an advertisement last week that accused Romney of sticking with policies that led to the financial crisis in 2008. In the advertisement, President Obama stated, "Governor Romney believes that with even bigger tax cuts for the wealthy, and fewer regulations on Wall Street, all of us will prosper. In other words, he'd double down on the same trickle-down policies that led to the crisis in the first place."

White House senior adviser David Plouffe, who was interviewed after Christie's interview, called the accusation that the president was lying "not true." Plouffe stated, "Analysts have looked at this. Someone who makes over $3 million a year would get over a $250,000 tax cut if Governor Romney's plan were to be enacted."

Plouffe also stated that the notion that the middle class would be unaffected by Romney's tax cuts is false. "The middle class needs to understand, if - if Mitt Romney wins this presidential election, they're going to be paying the bill, not to reduce the deficit, not to reduce jobs, but to give huge tax cuts to the wealthy," he said.

Christie also stated that Romney would perform well in the upcoming debate and that it would be a positive turning point for his campaign. Plouffe, on the other hand, stated that the president would lay out his plan for the next four years during the debate.

The first presidential debate is scheduled for Wednesday, October 3.

Title: Mueller's Investigation of President Trump: Trump Not a "Criminal Target," but Still Under Investigation

Article:

Special counsel Robert Mueller reportedly informed President Trump's legal team in March that the president is not a "criminal target" of the Russia investigation, but rather a "subject" in the probe. This may offer Trump a sense of relief, but legal experts clarify that it does not indicate Trump is out of the woods regarding the Russia investigation.

The term "target" refers to an individual whom investigators believe has committed a crime and are likely planning to bring charges against. Being labeled a "subject," however, means that Mueller is examining Trump's conduct for evidence of a crime, but has no immediate plans to bring charges.

Andrew Wright, a professor at Savannah Law School, stated, "Being a subject is better than being a target of a criminal investigation by a federal grand jury, but it is cold comfort. In effect, Robert Mueller told the Trump legal team that he is investigating the president's conduct but has not determined as yet whether the president has committed specific federal crimes."

It's crucial to consider the context of the "criminal target" comments, which were made in relation to a potential Mueller interview of Trump under oath. Mueller's staff reportedly wants to question Trump about why he fired FBI Director James Comey and what Trump knew about contacts between his team and Russian officials.

Trump himself is said to want to sit down with Mueller's staff, and his legal team is divided over whether it's a good idea. Saying that Trump isn't a target doesn't impede Mueller's investigation into his conduct, and might increase the likelihood of Trump agreeing to an interview.

Miriam Baer, a law professor at Brooklyn Law School and a former federal prosecutor, explained, "It's important to stress the fluidity between categories. Depending on the prosecutor's case, a subject can very quickly become a target (and although less likely, a target might for some reason morph back into a subject)."

It's also possible that Mueller views Trump as a subject rather than a target because he has concluded he literally cannot indict Trump. White House lawyers have argued since the Nixon administration that the president cannot face criminal charges because it would interfere with their ability to run the country. Legal experts disagree on whether this is correct, but many believe that Mueller wouldn't risk testing this theory in court.

Jens David Ohlin, a professor of law at Cornell, stated, "Mueller may believe that he can't currently indict Trump no matter how much evidence he has against him. Designating him a'subject' as opposed to a 'target' may reflect nothing more than the fact that Trump is the current occupant of the Oval Office."

Mueller reportedly insists that he needs to interview Trump before he can finish his investigation, but Trump's lawyers have hesitated to allow Trump to testify, partially based on Trump's history. In the past, Trump has been known to exaggerate or lie during testimony, as evidenced by his deposition in the 2007 lawsuit brought by journalist Timothy O'Brien.

O'Brien's lawyers caught Trump lying 30 times during the deposition, acknowledging that he had repeatedly exaggerated or outright misrepresented facts about his business in the past. Even if Mueller can't charge Trump criminally, lying under oath is what led to Bill Clinton's impeachment.

Title: House to Discontinue NSA Phone Data Collection Program Due to Expiration of Patriot Act Provision

Article:

In a significant development, the House of Representatives is set to discontinue the National Security Agency (NSA) phone data collection program, as the provision of the USA Patriot Act that allows for such collection will not be renewed after its expiration at the end of 2015. This decision was announced by Rep. F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., the Wisconsin Republican who was the chief author of the Patriot Act in 2001.

Sensenbrenner stated that there are not sufficient votes in the House to renew Section 215 of the Patriot Act, which permits the government to collect data from businesses without a warrant. He added that the intelligence community has expanded, rather than limited, its data-gathering efforts after Congress tried to rein them in.

The revelation of the NSA phone data collection program, following former NSA employee Edward Snowden's disclosure of details last month, has sparked a major debate in Congress. In Wednesday's hearing, lawmakers expressed concerns about the program, with some accusing the administration of trying to hide it.

Administration officials who testified during the hearing acknowledged that they had the technology to track ATM transactions and the locations of cellphones on which they are already gathering metadata. They also admitted that they had not sought permission for the existing program, which some lawmakers criticized.

In a four-page letter to Sensenbrenner this week, Peter J. Kadzik, principal deputy assistant attorney general, outlined the administration's reasoning for the program's justification. He stated that the bulk collection of telephony metadata is necessary to identify terrorist-related telephony metadata records and to discover whether known or suspected terrorists have been in contact with other persons who may be engaged in terrorist activities.

Under the terms of the program, phone companies turn over the data, which is then stored by the government for five years. However, officials stated that they can only query the data to look for specific numbers if they have a "reasonable articulable suspicion" that someone is involved with terrorism.

The administration officials also noted that they involve all three branches of government by regularly briefing some congressional committees about the program, undergoing rigorous review within the executive branch, and seeking approval for collecting the data from the special secret Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) court every 90 days.

However, members of Congress have expressed a preference for the FISA courts to sign off before anyone goes digging through the data, rather than leaving that decision to 22 employees at the NSA. This preference reflects concerns about the potential for abuse of power and the need for greater transparency and accountability in the program.

Title: U.S. Senators Express Concern Over International Implications of State Marijuana Legalization

Article:

In a joint letter to Secretary of State John Kerry and Attorney General Eric Holder, Democratic Sen. Dianne Feinstein of California and Republican Sen. Chuck Grassley of Iowa have expressed concern over the Obama administration's decision to allow states like Oregon, Alaska, and the District of Columbia to legalize recreational marijuana. The senators argue that this decision violates federal law and U.S. obligations under the United Nations Convention on Narcotics.

The senators' letter, sent on Jan. 6, states that the Department of Justice's decision to defer its right to challenge legalization laws to the states has put the United States in a difficult position regarding its compliance with international treaties. They argue that the nation's position as a global leader against drugs has been weakened by this decision.

In 2013, the Justice Department issued a clarification of federal drug policy, stating that it would defer to state laws regarding marijuana legalization. The letter sets a deadline of Feb. 1 for Kerry to clarify the State Department's interpretation of the treaties.

The senators' concerns are shared by United Nations officials, who have spoken out after Assistant Secretary of State William Brownfield called for a "flexible interpretation" of UN Drug Control Conventions last October. Brownfield stated that nations should "accept the fact that some countries will have very strict drug approaches" and "we must have some tolerance for those differing policies."

After the November elections, Yury Fedotov, executive director of the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, stated he did not "see how [the new laws] can be compatible with existing conventions."

Tom Angell of the Marijuana Majority agrees with the senators that there is an inconsistency. He told The Washington Post, "When the U.S. has legal marijuana, it makes it difficult for U.S. officials to go around the world and say they should continue to prohibit marijuana."

Angell also agrees with the senators' request for the Justice Department to put together, by Feb. 15, a plan to compile information on the impact of legalization "disaggregated by state and comparable over time, so that data before and after the legalization of marijuana can be compared."

Feinstein and Grassley, who serve as co-chairs of the Senate Caucus on International Narcotics Control, have worked together before on anti-drug efforts and released a report in December outlining recommendations on ways to counter illicit activities and corruption surrounding the Afghan drug trade.

Title: Al Qaeda's Persistence: Experts Warn of Resurgence Despite US Embassy Closures and Osama bin Laden's Death

Article:

The killing of Osama bin Laden in May 2011 and the absence of any Al Qaeda-orchestrated terrorist attacks on US soil since 9/11 may have led some Americans to perceive Al Qaeda as a diminished or obsolete threat. However, the recent extension of US embassy and consulate closures across the Middle East and Africa, as well as an increased focus on Al Qaeda's affiliate in Yemen, has prompted several terrorism experts to caution against such assumptions.

Factors such as the post-Arab Spring chaos in the Middle East and the Obama administration's drone-strike wars in Pakistan and Yemen have contributed to a different but no less lethal Al Qaeda than the one that carried out the 9/11 attacks, according to these experts.

Bill Roggio, editor of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies' Long War Journal, which tracks and analyzes the "global war on terror," states, "Those who have been claiming Al Qaeda has been defeated or is on its death bed either have bad analysis or have been dishonest with the American people."

Roggio argues that the expansion of Al Qaeda affiliates in regions where the US government acknowledges they are growing in size and reach contradicts claims of the terrorist organization's defeat. Bruce Riedel, a leading terrorism analyst and director of the Brookings Institution's Intelligence Project, concurs, stating, "The Arab Spring has engendered a lot of chaos across the Arab world and broader Middle East, and Al Qaeda thrives on chaos."

Riedel points to recent large jailbreaks by Al Qaeda prisoners in Iraq, Pakistan, and Libya, and adds that such actions in quick succession, coupled with the past month's spike in Al Qaeda-originated violence in Iraq and successes in Syria, suggest Al Qaeda's resurgence.

However, some terrorism experts argue that the new Al Qaeda affiliates are primarily focused on local insurgencies and local goals, such as establishing strict Islamist states in Syria, Iraq, and Yemen. Riedel and others caution against drawing this conclusion, stating that Al Qaeda's leadership and affiliate leaders have expressed a global agenda.

Riedel cites last January's deadly attack by Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) on an Algerian gas plant, which targeted the large number of Western workers present, as evidence of Al Qaeda's global ambitions. The Long War Journal's Roggio notes that it was less than four years ago that Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) dispatched a terrorist who attempted to detonate a bomb in his underwear on a flight over Detroit.

Some experts interpret the closings of US diplomatic facilities across the Middle East and parts of Africa as evidence that a weakened Al Qaeda has shifted its focus to regional targets. However, Roggio counters this argument by citing Al Qaeda's historical track record, particularly the eight-year time lag between the two World Trade Center attacks, during which Al Qaeda continued to refine its plans and carry out attacks such as the October 2000 attack on the USS Cole in the Yemeni port of Aden and the August 1998 bombings of two US embassies in East Africa.

Roggio also warns of the potential for a similar "if-at-first-you-don't-succeed" mentality in the efforts of a Saudi citizen thought to be AQAP's chief bomb maker, Ibrahim al-Asiri, who is believed to be experimenting with new failsafe bombs and training a class of bomb makers to take over should the US succeed in taking him out with a drone strike.

Brookings' Riedel sounds another cautionary note for Americans who might have thought Al Qaeda was a threat of the past, stating that much of the success at "depleting" Al Qaeda's core leadership in Pakistan is a result of US pressure, but that this success could quickly be reversed if that pressure subsides as a result of the withdrawal of US and NATO forces from Afghanistan at the end of 2014. Riedel warns, "Reduce the US presence and focus, and we can expect a rapid regeneration of Al Qaeda in Pakistan." And no one has much doubt about where Al Qaeda's leadership in Pakistan would like to carry out a successful attack.

Title: Bipartisan Support for CARES Act Highlights Lack of Meaningful Differences Between Democrats and Republicans

Article:

The $2 trillion CARES Act, the largest spending bill in U.S. history, passed with a unanimous vote in the Senate, despite four absent senators. In the House of Representatives, the bill passed on a voice vote, with no individual members going on record supporting it. This bipartisan response to the coronavirus pandemic highlights the lack of meaningful differences between the Democrats and Republicans, as one of the dissenters, Rep. Justin Amash (MI-03), a Michigan independent, officially submitted a no vote.

Amash, who consistently criticized the CARES Act for favoring corporations and special interests over individuals, expressed his dissent in a series of tweets. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) and the National Republican Congressional Committee (NRCC) both issued statements criticizing Amash's vote. In response, Amash tweeted, "There's about as much independent thinking here as there is in Congress."

The DCCC tweeted, "Congressman Justin Amash officially submitted his 'no' vote in the congressional record on the bipartisan coronavirus relief bill that puts #FamiliesFirst amid the COVID-19 pandemic. #MI03 'During a national crisis, it's unfortunate that Congressman Justin Amash would once again adhere to an extreme, out-of-touch ideology, even when it means risking the health, well-being, and economic security of thousands of #MI03.'"

Thirty minutes later, the NRCC tweeted, "Congressman Justin Amash officially submitted his 'no' vote in the congressional record on the bipartisan coronavirus relief bill that puts #FamiliesFirst amid the COVID-19 pandemic. #MI03 'During a national crisis, it's unfortunate that Congressman Justin Amash would once again work against President Trump, even when it means risking the health, well-being, and economic security of thousands of #MI03.'"

The lack of meaningful differences between the two parties is further evidenced by the increasing federal spending over the past two decades. Since 2000, there have only been three years in which federal spending declined year over year (2010, 2012, and 2013). Since Donald Trump's election in 2016, Washington has increased real spending by $1,441 per person, with more federal spending increases expected before the end of the fiscal year on September 30. The 2020 budget was already a record-high $4.8 trillion; it will likely end up coming in somewhere between $6 trillion and $7 trillion.

Despite disagreements about spending priorities, the identical responses to Amash's dissent and the consistent increase in federal spending suggest a fundamental agreement between Democrats and Republicans on more fundamental issues.

Title: Senate Confirms William Barr as Attorney General, Placing Him in Charge of Mueller's Russia Probe

Article:

The United States Senate confirmed William Barr as attorney general on Thursday, installing a seasoned lawyer with decades of Washington experience to head the Justice Department and oversee Special Counsel Robert Mueller's long-running investigation into potential collusion between President Donald Trump's 2016 campaign and Russia.

The Senate voted 54 to 45, largely along party lines. A Justice Department spokeswoman stated that Barr will be sworn in at 4:45 PM ET in the Oval Office of the White House by Chief Justice John Roberts.

Many Democrats opposed Barr due to concerns he might not make Mueller's findings fully public. However, the Senate is controlled by Trump's fellow Republicans, ensuring Barr's confirmation.

"Today is a great day for the Department of Justice with the confirmation of William Barr to be the next Attorney General," said Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Lindsey Graham. "He is a steady hand at a time of turmoil and he will bring much-needed reform to the Department of Justice."

Previously attorney general from 1991 to 1993 under President George H.W. Bush, Barr has won praise from lawmakers in both parties for his expertise and grasp of the workings of the Justice Department.

Barr will be the third man to occupy that post in barely two years, replacing acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker, who replaced Attorney General Jeff Sessions. Trump ousted Sessions last November after criticizing him repeatedly.

Mueller is investigating meddling by Russia in the 2016 U.S. presidential election and whether Moscow colluded with Trump's campaign to try to influence the election in Trump's favor, as well as possible obstruction of justice.

Before being nominated, Barr wrote a 19-page legal memo, in which he called part of Mueller's probe into whether the president obstructed justice "fatally flawed." He shared it with Trump's legal team and Justice Department officials.

Barr has stated he will not let himself be bullied by Trump and will protect the integrity of Mueller's investigation and make public as many of its findings as he can. Barr has not promised to release Mueller's report in its entirety. He has warned he may not be allowed to reveal the identities of people who escape prosecution. That stance troubles many Democrats, who say Barr's expansive views of executive power might lead him to suppress parts of the report.

"The Justice Department needs a leader who will be independent of the White House and who is able to stand up to President Trump," said Senator Dianne Feinstein, the top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee, in a statement. "Bill Barr hasn't demonstrated that he would be that independent leader."

Despite Democrats' opposition, many were anxious to have Barr installed quickly so he would replace Whitaker, whose tenure has been fraught with controversy since Trump appointed him in November. Critics have alleged Whitaker's appointment was unlawful. Democrats fear Trump installed Whitaker to undermine Mueller's probe because Whitaker had criticized it when he was a conservative pundit.

Barr is widely expected to back many of Trump's tough immigration policies. He will also be under the microscope for how he implements a new law that eases prison sentences for non-violent criminals, after he advocated for the opposite, tough-on-crime approach for decades.

Title: Tulsa Police Officer Craig Johnson Dies After Shooting Incident, National Media Coverage Questioned

Article:

Tulsa Police Sergeant Craig Johnson, a 15-year veteran, passed away on Tuesday following a gunshot wound to his head sustained during a traffic stop on Monday. Six-week rookie Officer Aurash Zarkeshan remains in critical condition after also being shot during the same incident.

On Monday, CBS Evening News provided a brief 16-second news report on the shooting, but neither ABC nor NBC mentioned the incident. ABC News, however, did publish an online report by Christina Carrega, which detailed the events leading up to the shooting.

According to Tulsa Police Chief Wendell Franklin, the suspect refused to comply with officers' commands to step out of his car. Sergeant Johnson displayed a stun gun and asked the suspect to exit the car 12 times before firing. A struggle ensued, and the suspect pulled out a gun and fired "several shots at close range," striking both officers in the head.

Both officers were taken to the hospital in critical condition. Sergeant Johnson died on Tuesday afternoon, leaving behind a wife and two young sons. Officer Zarkeshan remains in critical condition.

On Wednesday morning, Fox News Channel's Fox and Friends discussed the shooting incident, with co-anchor Brian Kilmeade bringing up the slaying to retired Dallas police officer C' Mone Wingo. Wingo expressed her concern about the increasing demonization of police officers in society.

Meanwhile, the networks have been promoting efforts to "defund the police," and NBC has scoffed at the fact that police officers are being increasingly targeted in attacks. NBC also criticized President Trump's "unusual step" to continue "defending" the police.

CBS's brief news report and lack of follow-up on the incident has raised questions about the level of national media coverage of the shooting. The networks' promotion of efforts to "defund the police" and their criticism of the police have been met with criticism from some quarters, with concerns that such coverage may contribute to the increasing targeting of police officers in attacks.

Title: Jared Kushner Fined for Late Financial Disclosure

 Article:

 President Trump's senior advisor and son-in-law, Jared Kushner, has been fined $200 by the U.S. government for failing to disclose recent financial transactions on time as required by federal law. The U.S. Office of Government Ethics (OGE) ordered Kushner to pay the fine for not timely notifying the government of transactions that occurred in February involving JCK Cadre LLC, a holding company in his name with a stake in a successful New York tech startup, McClatchy reported on Thursday.

 At least 18 members of the Trump administration filed late financial disclosure statements with the ethics office this year, including Kushner, according to data collected by a Democratic opposition research firm, American Bridge 21st Century, and confirmed by McClatchy. The report stated that Trump's former chief of staff, Reince Priebus, was four days late with his filing, and Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders was 23 days behind with her own paperwork. Chief strategist Steve Bannon was more than a month tardy in filing his personal financial disclosure statement, and Christopher Ford, a member of the president's National Security Council, filed his 46 days behind schedule, said American Bridge.

 "President Trump acts like the rules for the rest of us don't apply to him, and now his entire administration is doing the same," Harrell Kirstein, a spokesperson for the group, told McClatchy.

 Individuals required to file financial disclosure statements with the government are typically subject to fines if they're 30 days late in doing so, McClatchy reported, though fees are sometimes waived. Kushner, however, failed to disclose on time a pair of transactions from February 17 involving JCK Cadre each valued at between $100,000 and $250,000, according to an ethics filing dated July 20 and published by McClatchy on Thursday.

 The federal government assessed fees last year on just 3.6 percent of the 12,000 staffers who filed late periodic transaction reports, making Kushner's penalty a rare occurrence, McClatchy reported.

 The White House declined to comment on the record, but a Trump administration official familiar with the matter told McClatchy that Kushner will pay the fine.

 Kushner, 36, married the president's eldest daughter, Ivanka Trump, in 2009. Combined, the couple disclosed assets valued at between $206 million and $760 million in separate disclosures filed with the OGE last month. "Jared and Ivanka have followed each of the required steps in their transition from private citizens to federal officials," their attorney, Jamie Gorelick, said in a statement following last month's filings.

Title: Obama Administration Grants Unprecedented Access to Bergdahl Family During Son's Captivity

Article:

The Obama administration granted unprecedented access to the parents of Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl by allowing them to participate in a series of secure video conferences with senior military and government officials during their son's five-year captivity in Afghanistan. This access, according to a former government official involved in American hostage issues, is unparalleled in such situations, and questions have been raised about the potential disclosure of sensitive information.

In June 2009, Sgt. Bergdahl went missing in Afghanistan, prompting the Obama administration to approve an outreach program that involved the Bergdahls traveling from their home in Hailey, Idaho, to the state's National Guard headquarters in Boise. There, they were connected to secure video conferences with representatives of U.S. Central Command, the White House, the State Department, and intelligence officials.

Robert Bergdahl, Sgt. Bergdahl's father, has expressed concern for prisoners at the U.S. military detention facility at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. In May 2014, the U.S. released five senior Taliban commanders in exchange for Sgt. Bergdahl, who was held by the violent Haqqani Network, a Taliban ally.

Air Force Col. Timothy Marsano, Idaho's National Guard spokesman, confirmed that the Bergdahls participated in video conferences quarterly, or as many as 20 times, over the five-year period. "Mr. and Mrs. Bergdahl were regularly informed about what was happening throughout the duration using video teleconferencing [with] various military and other government agencies," Col. Marsano said. "There was a great effort to keep Mr. and Mrs. Bergdahl updated on developments."

The Bergdahls did not have access to a specific Army post. The Guard offered to help the Bergdahls with media relations, and they accepted, said Col. Marsano, who has served as the family's spokesman.

When asked about the video conferences, Navy Cmdr. Elissa Smith, a Pentagon spokeswoman, said, "While I don't have specific details to provide, I can tell you that we actively communicated with the Bergdahl family on a regular basis through a variety of means to keep them informed on the efforts to recover Sgt. Bergdahl and to highlight the close coordination and teamwork between U.S. Central Command, the Department of Defense, and other U.S. government agencies."

Robert Bergdahl has expressed sympathy for the al Qaeda and Taliban captives at Guantanamo, as he has for other prisoners, both Christian and Muslim, around the world. Before his son's release, he tweeted, "I am still working to free all Guantanamo prisoners. God will repay for the death of every Afghan child, ameen!" That message on Twitter was later deleted.

In 2011, he issued a personal video urging the Pakistani military to secure his son's release. "Strangely to some, we must also thank those who have cared for our son for almost two years," Mr. Bergdahl said, addressing the Haqqanis. "We know our son is a prisoner and, at the same time, a guest in your home."

Larry Johnson, who worked on the issue of the American hostages in Lebanon while at the State Department in the 1980s, said he had never heard of bringing families into top-level discussions about efforts to free their relatives. "It's wrong," Mr. Johnson said. "The Bergdahls shouldn't have been part of that for no other reason than on the off chance they may inadvertently divulge some tactic."

Asked whether the Bergdahls exposed any sensitive information, Col. Marsano said, "I certainly don't know of anything like that happening." He declined to discuss whether classified matters arose or whether the couple had a security clearance.

"It was very clear to me that the agencies involved, to include the Department of Defense, had a strong interest in ensuring this family had up-to-date information and did not leave them in the dark," Col. Marsano said.

Sgt. Bergdahl is currently undergoing the military's reintegration process, which at some point includes debriefings on his captivity. Former Army colleagues accuse Sgt. Bergdahl of desertion, saying he walked off their forward operating base in Paktia province and into the hands of the enemy.

Title: Senate Republicans Divided Over Budget Negotiations as Ted Cruz Leads Conservative Faction

Article:

Senate Republicans are currently embroiled in a contentious internal dispute over budget negotiations, with a rift emerging between the old and new guard, the mainstream and the tea party, and Senators John McCain and Ted Cruz at the forefront. This public discord is a departure from the party's usual practice of keeping disagreements behind closed doors while criticizing Democrats on various issues, such as taxes and healthcare.

Senator Cruz, along with a group of Senate conservatives, is refusing to engage in budget negotiations with the House, instead engaging in open conflict with more senior Republicans like McCain who are perplexed by their hardline tactics. This conflict has given Cruz a new platform as he seeks to establish himself as a conservative instigator, but it has also left the Texas Republican increasingly isolated from many of his colleagues.

The unusual public squabbling has placed Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) in a precarious position, as he must decide between the conservative firebrands who hold significant influence from the right and could potentially run for president in 2016, and ending the intraparty feud that is causing an unwelcome distraction for the party. This situation recalls the tea party versus establishment fights that have disrupted Senate primaries in recent years, but this time, the battles are unfolding on the Senate floor.

GOP leaders are currently observing the situation, unsure of how it will resolve itself. At present, it appears that more Republicans favor initiating conference talks rather than blocking them, although the voices in favor of the latter may be more vocal.

Senator John Cornyn, the No. 2 Republican and Cruz's Texas colleague, stated, "I'm just watching," even as Cornyn supports beginning conference talks.

Cruz is not alone in this fight, which he describes as an effort to prevent a debt limit increase from being included in the budget talks. He has been spearheading the charge alongside fellow tea party Senators Marco Rubio of Florida, Mike Lee of Utah, and Rand Paul of Kentucky. This struggle also serves as a sign of how 2016 primary politics are shaping the Senate, with Rubio, Cruz, and Paul all seen as potential presidential candidates.

On Wednesday, Cruz took the fight to his own party, stating that he does not even "trust" Republicans to resolve the country's fiscal problems or avoid increasing the debt ceiling. On Thursday, he portrayed the conference proceedings as a ruse to increase the ceiling by a simple majority instead of the 60 votes usually required.

The controversy began after Senate Democrats passed a budget in March, their first such plan in four years. Afterward, Democrats sought to begin conference negotiations with House Republicans, who passed their own budget under the leadership of Rep. Paul Ryan (R-Wis.). A conference is part of the regular order that the GOP has long demanded. However, Senate conservatives objected to Majority Leader Harry Reid's attempt to initiate the proceedings, demanding written assurances to exclude tax hikes and a debt limit increase from the negotiations.

Title: Obama and Top Democrats Push for Comprehensive Immigration Reform in House

Article:

President Barack Obama and top Democrats on Capitol Hill have reportedly shifted their focus towards the Republican-controlled House passing a comprehensive immigration reform bill, rather than a piecemeal approach, as lawmakers prepare for the Christmas holiday break.

During a year-end press conference on Friday, President Obama urged the House to support the bipartisan immigration bill the Senate passed in the summer, a departure from his previous comments suggesting he was content with the House's apparent step-by-step plan.

"The Senate bill has the main components of comprehensive immigration reform that would boost our economy, give us an opportunity to attract more investment and high-skilled workers who are doing great things in places like Silicon Valley and around the country," Obama said. "So let's go ahead and get that done."

In contrast to his remarks in November, where he expressed no issue with House leaders dividing the immigration bill into multiple pieces, Obama stated, "As long as all five pieces get done, I don't care what it looks like." He added, "What we do not want to do is simply carve out one piece of it...but leave behind some of the tougher stuff that still needs to get done."

House Speaker John Boehner has consistently stated he will not schedule a vote on the Senate bill nor negotiate with Senate Democrats on the upper chamber's legislation. "We have no intention of ever going to conference on the Senate bill," Boehner said last month.

Although the House has yet to vote on any part of an immigration bill, the chamber appears to prioritize securing the U.S.-Mexico border and not including a path to citizenship for some of the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants already in the United States.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid suggested this weekend that Boehner may negotiate on comprehensive reform next year. Boehner has expressed a willingness to pass reform, but he reportedly wants to wait until after the congressional primaries this spring and summer.

Reid also suggested that House members facing reelection in Democratic-leaning or middle-of-the-road districts might need to vote for immigration reform. However, any effort to pass a bill perceived by conservatives as too lenient on legalization and insufficient on border security is likely to face strong opposition from some outspoken Republican Party members, including Alabama Sen. Jeff Sessions, Iowa Rep. Steve King, and South Carolina Rep. Trey Gowdy.

Even Florida GOP Sen. Marco Rubio, a Tea Party-backed lawmaker who co-sponsored the bill, now appears to favor a more piecemeal approach, with a spokesman stating in the fall, "The most realistic way to make progress on immigration would be through a series of individual bills."

Title: Democrats Focus on State-Level Races to Rebuild Party in 2018 and Beyond

Article:

The Democratic Party is looking to state-level races as a means to rebuild and rebrand in the coming years. With 38 governorships up for election in the next two years, Democrats see an opportunity to introduce new faces and ideas to the political landscape.

Thirty-eight governorships will be contested in the next two years, providing fertile ground for new Democratic leaders to emerge. In 16 states, including swing states such as Ohio, Florida, Nevada, and Michigan, Republican governors will step down due to term limits or retirement, leaving open-seat races. New Mexico, Maine, and New Jersey, all blue states with Republican governors, will also be electing new chief executives in the next two years.

Winning a number of governorships could bring a new generation of party leaders into the spotlight and help rebrand the Democratic Party. Governors can operate autonomously from Washington and pursue new policy ideas that bolster a party image of innovation.

"In governors, people see a leader. They can pursue fresh policies that spread quickly around the country," says Jared Leopold, communications director for the Democratic Governors Association (DGA). "There is a lot of opportunity to be on the offense here [in 2018]...Governors quickly become the stars of their party."

Many of America's recent presidents, from Jimmy Carter to George W. Bush, served first as governors. After the 2008 election, Republicans found themselves in a similar position to the Democrats now, with Barack Obama winning the presidency and Democrats controlling both chambers of Congress. However, within the next two years, conservatives took 11 governorships out of Democratic hands. This year, Republicans won the presidency as well as majorities in the House and Senate.

"Republicans rebuilt after 2008 by electing new governors who pushed policies and had a story to tell," says Mr. Leopold. "Governorships are the best way to quickly rebuild and inject fresh blood."

Republican governors elected to their first term in 2010 made a name for themselves in the conservative field. Ohio Gov. John Kasich took his state from a $6 billion deficit to a $2 billion surplus. New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie reached an approval rating of 77 percent after helping his state through superstorm Sandy, before his reputation was tainted by the Bridgegate scandal. Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker cut his state's unemployment rate by almost half – though that largely mirrored national trends.

Governorships are the perfect means to audition a new party message, says Connecticut Gov. Dannel Malloy, who chairs the DGA. This could be especially helpful in the Midwest, where many Democrats worry the Republican Party has found a new stronghold with the white working class.

"Gubernatorial campaigns by their very nature take that one on," Governor Malloy told Politico. "If you're running for governor, you are going to get known and visit every community. It's very personal ownership and people want to know you. That doesn't mean there won't be close elections, but it's different."

Governors Kasich, Christie, and Walker's successes also served the conservative cause in a more obvious way: They added to the party's list of credible presidential candidates in 2016.

"The Democratic Party needs some stars, some younger faces to advance their issues and to be potential national candidates in 2020 and beyond," says John Weingart, director of Rutgers University's Center on the American Governor in New Jersey.

During Mr. Obama's tenure, Democrats have not only lost 12 governorships, dropping from 28 in January 2009 to 16 in January 2017; they have also lost more than 950 state legislative seats to Republicans since Obama took office, the largest net loss for either party since World War II.

"Obama paid no attention to party development as president and the results have been disastrous," says William Crotty, an emeritus professor of political science at Northeastern University in Boston. "His record in this regard is terrible."

The number of Democratic governors and state legislators over the next few years may be more important than ever. When the next census is held in 2020, state legislatures – and to some extent governors – will lead the subsequent redrawing of congressional districts. Success for Democrats at the state level is "essential," adds Mr. Weingart.

However, for Democrats to reap the rewards of state-level wins at the national level, party donors and voters need to invest in the 2018 midterm elections.

"The trouble is that very few people find state politics compelling, and I'll admit I'm no exception," writes The Week's Paul Waldman. "It can be hard to care about what happens at the minor league ballpark when the World Series is going on...But it's necessary."

Title: Trump's State of the Union Address: A Look at the U.S. Economy under His Administration

Article:

During his State of the Union address last week, President Donald Trump highlighted the strength of the U.S. economy, stating, "I am thrilled to report to you tonight that our economy is the best it has ever been." While the accuracy of such a bold statement may be debated, there is no denying that the economy, by certain metrics, is indeed booming.

The U.S. economy is currently experiencing the longest expansion in American history, having recovered from the worst days of the Great Recession. Unemployment is at a 50-year low, and the stock market has reached record levels.

The strong economy may be one of the most potent arguments Trump has as he campaigns for a second term. Historically, voters tend to reward incumbent presidents for a strong economy and punish them for a weak one. The last two presidents to lose reelection, George H.W. Bush and Jimmy Carter, were defeated during periods of a flagging economy.

Trump's supporters attribute the economic highs the U.S. has reached since he took office to his policies, particularly his trillion-dollar tax cut and trade battles with China, Mexico, and others. They argue that these policies have boosted investment and created jobs in the U.S.

Trump's detractors, however, claim that the gains made in the past three years are merely an extension of the progress made by former President Barack Obama. They argue that Obama prevented another depression and built a solid foundation on which the current economic expansion has grown. Some also contend that Trump's policies, such as tax cuts and increased spending, will ultimately destabilize the economy by creating a short burst of growth that will lead to another recession.

Another group asserts that the economy is not doing as well as it may seem, with most of the gains experienced by the wealthy while the working class has fallen further behind.

Though the economy is still growing, the rate of that growth slowed last year to the lowest levels in the Trump presidency. Whether this is a sign that the economic upswing is reaching its peak is unclear, economists say. Economies can't grow forever, and another recession will come eventually.

Opinions on the Trump administration's economic policies are divided, with some praising them for producing economic benefits for American workers and others criticizing them for exacerbating inequality and the federal deficit. The impact of Trump's policies on the economy remains a topic of ongoing debate.

Title: Sparks Middle School Teacher Hailed as Hero After Confronting Shooter, Saving Students

Article:

Authorities have not disclosed the identity of the shooter who fatally wounded popular Sparks Middle School teacher Michael Landsberry and injured two students on Monday morning. Landsberry, a 45-year-old math teacher, is being remembered as a hero for his actions that saved lives by confronting the gunman and allowing students to escape the scene.

According to Michael Mieras, Chief of the Washoe County School District, Landsberry, a former Marine and member of the Army National Guard, began his teaching career in 2001 and joined Sparks Middle School in 2006. Landsberry was highly respected by his peers and was a popular teacher among students, coaching the boys' basketball and girls' volleyball teams.

During a Tuesday afternoon press conference, Mieras described Landsberry's actions, stating that he "calmly walked toward the shooter" and "put his hands up in a motion to stop [the shooter's] actions." Landsberry's actions are credited with preventing further students from being shot.

The identity of the shooter, who took his own life after shooting Landsberry and two students, has not been released. One student was shot in the shoulder, while the other was struck in the abdomen. Law enforcement did not fire any shots during the incident.

The motive for the Sparks Middle School shooting remains unclear as of Tuesday afternoon. A law enforcement figure stated during the news conference, "The answer is we don't know why right now, but we're proactively trying to determine why."

A Facebook page, "Remembering Mr. Michael Landsberry," has been created to honor the slain teacher. Tributes pour in, with one post reading, "I Just want everyone to know how A.W.E.S.O.M.E and brave this man was... He is a true H.E.R.O in my book and always will be!" Another post reads, "Parents sometimes forget what we as teachers are willing to do for their children. Mr. Landsberry is a true American Hero!"

The community mourns the loss of Landsberry and prays for the recovery of the injured students and their families.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Tweet on Kavanaugh's Birth Control Remark Sparks Debate

Article:

In the political landscape, generating attention often requires provoking opposition, as demonstrated by Hillary Clinton's tweet regarding Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh's characterization of birth-control pills as "abortion-inducing drugs" during his confirmation hearings. Clinton's statement, made on September 12, 2018, sparked controversy and was later debunked by fact-checkers.

Clinton's tweet, which drew criticism for its inaccuracy, stated that Kavanaugh deliberately distorted "basic science" and offered a "dog whistle to the extreme right." This claim was widely debunked when California Senator Kamala Harris attempted to peddle it with a deceptively edited video.

Fact-checkers, such as The Washington Post's Glenn Kessler and PolitiFact, ruled that the characterization was dishonest. Kessler awarded four Pinocchios, the worst rating, to the claim, stating that Kavanaugh was quoting the views of specific plaintiffs in a specific case, Priests for Life v. HHS, rather than offering a personal view.

The timing of Clinton's tweet has raised questions about her motives. Some speculate that Clinton deliberately lied to pander to her base and further unfairly demonize Kavanaugh, while others suggest that she may not have been paying attention, and her staff was incompetent. However, it is also possible that Clinton's tweet was an example of a broader phenomenon in which people define themselves by what they hate, and what motivates them the most isn't support for their side's policies but their hatred of the opposing party.

This dynamic, in which people are motivated by their opposition to others rather than support for their own side, is a dominant feature of the current political climate. It is not limited to presidential candidates but saturates both parties and both sides of the culture war. This dynamic can distort how people process basic facts, as demonstrated by a report from the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, which found that people will misinterpret objective data if there is any hint that the data came from a Republican or Democratic source.

In a media climate where every news outlet caters to a relatively small niche audience, one of the best ways to gain attention and support is to be attacked by the opposition. This phenomenon, often referred to as "trolling," is a lucrative vocation in which individuals say or do something awful to provoke the opposition, resulting in their own side rallying to their support.

Senator Ben Sasse of Nebraska discussed this phenomenon on the Remnant podcast, stating that cable-news producers and magazine editors prioritize a deep and sticky 1% audience, and one of the most effective ways to achieve this is by being attacked, as it draws visibility to oneself. Sasse pointed to The New Yorker's "exposé" of Chick-fil-A's "creepy infiltration" of New York City as an example of this phenomenon.

In conclusion, Hillary Clinton's tweet about Brett Kavanaugh's characterization of birth-control pills as "abortion-inducing drugs" was widely debunked by fact-checkers. The timing and content of the tweet have raised questions about Clinton's motives, with some speculating that she deliberately lied to pander to her base and further unfairly demonize Kavanaugh. However, the broader phenomenon of people defining themselves by what they hate and the role of trolling in the current media landscape may provide additional context for Clinton's tweet.

Title: House Republicans Unveil Government Spending Bill, Aiming to Avoid Shutdown

Article:

Washington, CNN - House Republicans unveiled a government spending bill on Monday that aims to keep federal agencies funded through September and avoid a potential government shutdown. The bill, which was drafted by House Appropriations Committee Chairman Hal Rogers (R-Kentucky), lessens the impact of forced spending cuts for the Pentagon and the Department of Veterans Affairs, while maintaining funding for FBI and border security, embassy security, federal prisons, and weather satellite launches.

The bill, known as a "continuing resolution" or "CR," keeps federal agencies at last year's spending levels, but factors in reductions from the forced spending cuts, known as "sequester." As a result, the actual level of federal spending will drop below a trillion dollars, to $982 billion.

The bill prioritizes defense programs and allows the Pentagon some leeway to manage its funding. For instance, it cuts roughly $10 billion from procurement and other areas to beef up the Defense Department's "operations and maintenance" account to ensure funding for military readiness and training programs.

In addition to defense programs, the bill protects some other agencies from across-the-board budget cuts that took effect on Friday. It maintains FBI and border security staffing at current levels and increases funding for embassy security by $2 billion in response to the deadly terror attack on the U.S. diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, last September.

Sen. Barbara Mikulski (D-Maryland), who chairs the Appropriations Committee, has stated her priorities for the bill, which include housing, education, health care, transportation, and infrastructure projects.

Democrats are expected to try to amend the House bill to soften the impact of the spending cuts on some domestic programs. The final outcome of these amendments and the overall bill's passage remains uncertain.

Before the legislation was released, the White House declined to say whether it would support the House GOP bill, citing a desire for a practical, nonpolitical, and consistent bill with the levels established in the 2011 debt deal, known as the Budget Control Act.

The House is expected to begin debate on the spending bill on Wednesday and vote on it on Thursday. The bill's future in the Senate and the potential for amendments remain unclear.

Title: "Analysis of the "Tax the Rich" Movement and Its Claims"

Article:

A movement known as the "Tax the Rich" has gained traction, with the slogan being a central theme in discussions surrounding wealth distribution and tax policy. The movement is spearheaded by a group called Patriotic Millionaires, as evidenced by the "Tax the Rich! Save America" conference they hosted in 2017.

The movement's mission statement suggests that the rich should pay more taxes to save America, but the claim that the rich do not currently pay taxes is misleading. According to the Tax Foundation, the top 1 percent accounted for 37.3 percent of all income-tax revenue in 2016, a share greater than the bottom 90 percent combined. The top half of taxpayers paid 97 percent of income taxes.

The movement's call for the rich to "pay their fair share" is a more debatable claim, as the definition of "fair" can be subjective. However, it is not preposterous to argue that the rich should pay a few percentage points more in income tax in the name of fairness. Conversely, it is also not preposterous to say that when the top 1 percent of taxpayers provide more than a third of income-tax revenue, they are already paying their fair share.

Another common argument for increasing taxes on the wealthy is the notion that the rich do not deserve their wealth or that it should be redistributed. This argument has been made by various political figures and pundits, including Presidential candidates Elizabeth Warren, Beto O'Rourke, and Bernie Sanders, as well as Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. However, experts argue that even confiscating all the wealth of the entire 1 percent would not be sufficient to fund proposed policies like Medicare for All, which has an estimated price tag of $32 trillion.

In conclusion, the "Tax the Rich" movement's claims should be approached with caution. While it is true that the rich do pay a significant portion of taxes, the notion that they are not paying their fair share or that their wealth is undeserved is a subjective and potentially irresponsible argument. The assumption that the wealth of the rich is the primary cause of the problems faced by ordinary Americans is also questionable, and the feasibility of using wealth redistribution to fund large-scale policies is debatable.

Title: The Rise of the Imperial Presidency: A Conservative Perspective on the Obama Administration

Article:

In November 2010, the Obama administration faced a Republican-majority House following a wave of discontent with President Obama's policies. Instead of adjusting course, the article argues that President Obama chose to bypass the elected representatives and pursue an "imperial presidency."

The article cites several instances of executive overreach, including the president's decision to cease enforcing federal immigration policies, his refusal to defend the Defense of Marriage Act, and his authorization of military action in Libya without congressional approval.

The article also points to the president's use of recess appointments and his exchange with then-Russian President Dmitry Medvedev as examples of his alleged disregard for the Constitution and the balance of powers. The author argues that these actions demonstrate President Obama's willingness to flout established laws for political gain and convenience, and his proclivity for placing himself and his political objectives ahead of the people, the Constitution, and the nation's security.

The article concludes by urging voters to unite in defense of limited government and executive restraint, and to put an end to the "era of the imperial presidency." The author suggests that the American people should demand answers from the president regarding his intentions on missile defense with Russia.

Title: Special Counsel Investigates 2016 Meeting Between Flynn and Rohrabacher

Article:

Special Counsel Robert Mueller is questioning witnesses about a September 2016 meeting between former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn and GOP Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, in connection with his investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. According to NBC News, the meeting took place in Washington on Sept. 20, 2016, and involved several of Flynn's business associates from the Flynn Intel Group, a private security firm.

Rohrabacher, a veteran Republican congressman who advocates for friendlier ties with Russia, is also under scrutiny as the special counsel reviews emails exchanged between Flynn associates and the congressman's staff. It is unclear why Mueller is focusing on this meeting, but Rohrabacher has longstanding ties to the Kremlin and WikiLeaks, which U.S. defense officials have described as a hostile intelligence agency. He has also had contact with Rinat Akhmetshin, one of the Russia-aligned lobbyists present at Donald Trump Jr.'s June 2016 meeting with Russian political operatives at Trump Tower in New York.

Previously, it was reported that Rohrabacher attempted to broker a deal between Julian Assange and the Department of Justice, under which Assange would surrender data exonerating Russia of involvement in the 2016 hack of the Democratic National Committee. Rohrabacher met with Assange at the Ecuadorian embassy in London in August. Federal prosecutors have not indicted Assange for any crimes, but the Justice Department has long sought to bring a case against him for his role in facilitating the release of hundreds of thousands of sensitive intelligence documents via Chelsea Manning.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of California joked last year that Rohrabacher's frequent apologies for Russian President Vladimir Putin create the impression that the congressman is on Putin's payroll. "There's two people I think Putin pays — Rohrabacher and Trump. Swear to God," he said.

Flynn served as President Donald Trump's national security advisor for less than one month before he resigned in disgrace for lying to administration officials about the nature of his communications with the Russian government during the transition. His extensive and undisclosed ties to the Erdogan government in Turkey are expected to prompt an indictment in the coming weeks.

The congressman's office did not return a request for comment by press time.

Title: Online Grocery Shopping: A Potential Seismic Shift Amidst the Pandemic

Article:

The ongoing pandemic has led to a significant change in consumer habits, particularly in the grocery sector. With dining out restricted due to lockdowns, consumers are still required to eat, leading to a surge in online grocery shopping, both delivery and pickup. This method of shopping is cheaper, reduces the number of trips food workers have to make, and keeps shoppers out of stores, where personnel are at risk of infection.

Bryan Leach, the CEO of the digital-shopping-promotions company Ibotta, predicts that online grocery shopping will rise from 3% to double-digits as a result of the pandemic. This shift could see the majority of food shopping continue to occur in physical stores, but the way people approach food shopping may change.

Leach suggests that this change could lead to better remuneration for grocery workers and a shift towards embracing smaller, local supermarkets. Online grocery shoppers might be viewed as the small shopkeepers of the turn of the century, or the community-supported agriculture services that deliver fresh, local goods at small scales today.

This shift towards smaller-scale, more attentive grocery service has already begun, with the rise of specific market shops like Trader Joe's and Whole Foods, and the resurgence of small butcher shops. This trend is partly driven by increased urban densification and the growing popularity of buying non-perishable consumer packaged goods online. If online grocery can supply the basics, this could be a boon for Main Street-style local shopping.

Title: Former Governor Mark Sanford Wins House Seat After Political Scandals

Article:

In a surprising political comeback, former South Carolina Governor Mark Sanford has won the special election for the 1st Congressional District, a seat he previously held. Sanford, who was once embroiled in a well-publicized extra-marital affair and ethics violations, overcame these scandals to secure a victory over Democratic opponent Elizabeth Colbert Busch.

From the start of his bid for Congress, Sanford was open about the affair and made it the subject of his first TV ad. He asked for, and received, political redemption from the voters.

"I want to acknowledge a God not just of second chances but third, fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth chances, because that is the reality of our shared humanity," said Sanford at his victory celebration Tuesday night. "I am one imperfect man saved by God's grace."

Elizabeth Colbert Busch's campaign, as well as two national Democratic groups, highlighted the affair. At their only general election debate, Colbert Busch confronted Sanford about his 2009 secret trip to Argentina to see his mistress. Her campaign also ran a TV commercial that criticized Sanford for using "tax dollars to visit his mistress in Argentina, disappeared for a week leaving no one in charge, betrayed all who trusted him, then lied to cover it up. Mark Sanford, it's a question of character."

For all his political baggage, Mark Sanford is a veteran on the campaign trail. Elizabeth Colbert Busch showed her campaign inexperience at times.

"Sanford may be a flawed candidate but he's a fabulous campaigner," said Republican strategist Hogan Gidley, a former executive director of the South Carolina Republican Party. "Forget the rhetoric or the policy or the delivery -- hand-to-hand, eye-to-eye he's very good and it's impossible to outwork him."

Sanford also seemed to win this election one voter at a time. He appeared to be everywhere in the campaign's closing days, holding nearly 15 events on Monday and another 10 on Election Day.

The 1st Congressional District is traditionally Republican, with Mitt Romney carrying the district by 18 percentage points in the 2012 presidential election. Even with a candidate with serious political baggage like Sanford, he was able to win.

Sanford won all five counties in the district, including his home base of Charleston County, where the most voters were at stake. Colbert Busch's campaign outspent Sanford's operation in the closing weeks, but money matters in campaign politics, and it's just one factor in determining a race.

Title: White House Faces Internal Debate Over Timing of Immigration Announcement

Article:

The White House is currently grappling with a contentious internal debate regarding the timing of President Barack Obama's anticipated announcement on immigration policy. Chris Newman, the legal director for the National Day Laborer Organizing Network, has urged the president to act swiftly, expressing hope that Obama's conscience will guide his decision.

Representative Luis V. Gutiérrez, a Democrat from Illinois, has criticized the administration's approach in the past. He stated that any delay in the announcement comes at a significant cost, including families being separated and children being placed in foster care. Gutiérrez expressed confidence that the president will prioritize families and security over short-term political maneuvers.

Within the White House, the timing of the announcement has become a subject of intense discussion, even as immigration lawyers at the Department of Homeland Security work to develop legally defensible policy options for the president.
