Some advisers to the president are advocating for a delay, concerned about the potential political backlash from a broad action to protect millions of immigrants in the country illegally from deportation and to provide many of them with official work papers.

The concern is that such a move could ignite a heated conflict with Republicans and potentially harm Democratic Senate candidates running in Arkansas, Louisiana, North Carolina, and potentially Iowa. Control of the Senate hinges on the outcomes of several close races in states where Obama is not popular, particularly in Southern states where opposition to an immigration overhaul is high. Strategists fear that an immigration announcement could negatively impact Democratic candidates.

Democratic senators have reached out to top White House officials, including Denis McDonough, the chief of staff, to argue that the recent crisis with unaccompanied minors crossing the border into the United States justifies a delay. Several Democratic officials on Capitol Hill stated that the angry reaction to that border crisis has eroded public support for changing immigration policy, and in some cases, turned the issue into a liability for them.

However, others within the White House are advocating for the president to adhere to his promised schedule, regardless of the immediate political consequences. They argue that Republicans will criticize the president and attack Democratic candidates even if Obama delays parts of his announcement until after the election.

Title: Grand Jury Decision Not to Indict Ferguson Officer Darren Wilson Does Not End Legal Troubles

 Article:

 FERGUSON, Mo. — The grand jury decision not to indict Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson in the shooting death of 18-year-old Michael Brown will not end Wilson's legal troubles. Although the decision is likely the last word from Missouri's criminal courts, Wilson, whose shooting of Brown on Aug. 9 sparked months of protests, could face civil rights charges brought by the Department of Justice or a civil wrongful death lawsuit filed by Brown's parents.

 The federal inquiry into the incident, led by Attorney General Eric Holder, remains ongoing. Wilson could have been charged with first- or second-degree murder or manslaughter. The exact circumstances surrounding Brown's death in the shooting are still in dispute. Police say Brown, who was unarmed, struggled with Wilson inside his police car before reaching for Wilson's weapon. Brown's family and some witnesses say Wilson killed Brown as he raised his hands in surrender.

 Police officers rarely face indictment for on-the-job shootings. In 2011, police killed 404 people in the line of duty, according to the FBI's Uniform Crime Report. In 2012, officers killed 410, and in 2013, the number grew to 461—the most in two decades. The FBI data do not include any information on criminal charges.

 The grand jury, which convened on Aug. 20, did not weigh whether Wilson had a justifiable reason to shoot Brown. "They did not find probable cause to believe a crime was committed and Darren Wilson committed it," said Susan McGraugh, a criminal defense lawyer and a professor at the St. Louis University School of Law. "They do not have to explain their reasoning, and they won't. They simply have a form and sign something that says 'no true bill.'"

 "They are not making a decision on Officer Wilson's guilt," said Peter Joy, a criminal defense attorney and law professor at Washington University in St. Louis School of Law.

 Wilson has been on paid leave from the department since the incident. Ferguson Police Chief Tom Jackson told MSNBC that Missouri law would allow Wilson to return to the force if he is cleared of any charges. The Police Department would conduct an internal review of the Brown shooting to see whether Wilson violated any policies.

 Brown's family could sue Wilson and the Ferguson Police Department for excessive force and wrongful death, said James Cohen, a professor at Fordham University Law School. In a civil trial, Brown's family could seek monetary damages, as the victim's family did in the case of football player O.J. Simpson, who was acquitted in a criminal trial of his wife's murder but ordered by a court in a civil trial to pay millions to her family.

 The federal government's probe could have wide-ranging consequences not only for Wilson but also for the entire Police Department. "Their claims would not just be excessive force, which would be directly associated with the police officer, but failure to adequately train the police officer," Cohen said. "Then, you sort of implicate the whole department and its structure."

 More unlikely, the St. Louis County prosecuting attorney could take a crack at Wilson. The grand jury's decision would not preclude a prosecutor from bringing new evidence to another grand jury or bypassing the grand jury entirely by filing a criminal complaint, McGraugh said.

 Wilson may never escape public infamy, but he will not have a criminal arrest record, McGraugh said. Since St. Louis County Prosecuting Attorney Robert McCulloch did not bring a criminal complaint against Wilson and he was never charged, arraigned, or arrested, she said. McCulloch also took the unusual step of presenting both incriminating and exculpatory evidence, she said.

 The court's treatment of Wilson's case may affect how prosecutors handle future cases, including whether evidence that does not support an indictment may be presented. "I think we will see a call for a real wholesale review of how the criminal justice system functions," McGraugh said. "People want to be heard in terms of a lot of the systemic injustices in the criminal justice system."

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Affordable Care Act: Challenges Ahead in Implementation and Enforcement

Article:

The Supreme Court's decision to uphold the Affordable Care Act (ACA) has marked a significant victory for President Obama and his supporters. However, political scientist Eric Patashnik's book "Reforms at Risk" warns that the survival of the ACA is not guaranteed, and its success depends on its ability to endure over time and build strong political support.

Congressional Republicans have vowed to continue attacking the ACA's funding and have expressed intentions to repeal the law if they gain control of the White House or Congress. House Speaker John Boehner and presidential candidate Mitt Romney have both publicly stated their support for repeal.

In addition to political challenges, there are practical hurdles in implementing and enforcing the ACA. Questions remain about how penalties will be enforced on those who refuse to purchase insurance, the effectiveness of cost controls, and the quality of insurance choices offered through state-run health care exchanges. Some state officials have announced plans to delay implementing the law until after the November elections, potentially leading to federal intervention.

Historically, well-regarded federal programs like Social Security and Medicare faced similar challenges during their early stages. Social Security, for example, faced a freeze on taxes during World War II and concerns about its survival due to the popularity of other programs for the elderly. However, Congress made adjustments to the program, expanding coverage and revising the tax system, ultimately leading to its success.

Similarly, the Supreme Court's 1936 decision to strike down an agricultural-processing tax supporting a farm subsidy program led to Congress reworking the program, resolving constitutional issues and protecting farmers.

In light of these historical precedents, the ACA's success will depend on Congress's ability to refine and improve the law to ensure its effectiveness. The 2012 election could prove to be a more significant moment for health care reform than the Supreme Court decision, as the outcome could determine the law's long-term viability. If Democrats fail to make the ACA work well, a future Congress may use its power to repeal the legislation and finish what the Supreme Court did not accomplish.

Title: Comparison of Nixon's "Enemies List" and Woodward Email Incident Unfounded, Historical Inaccuracies Abound

Article:

A comparison by Matt Drudge between the firestorm over an email sent by a White House aide to Washington Post reporter Bob Woodward and the Nixon White House's "Enemies List" has been deemed absurd and ahistorical. The Nixon White House's "Enemies List" was a plan to use the power of the federal government to financially damage political opponents, including journalists.

The "Enemies List" was a 1971 memorandum from White House Counsel John Dean to White House Chief of Staff John Haldeman's assistant, titled "Dealing with our political enemies." The memo outlined a plan to use federal machinery to damage political opponents, including grant availability, federal contracts, and litigation prosecution.

Furthermore, the actions of Nixon administration and campaign official G. Gordon Liddy were far more sinister than a mere email. Liddy served four and a half years in prison for his role in the Watergate break-in and the break-in at the office of Daniel Ellsberg, the military analyst who leaked the Pentagon Papers. Liddy has acknowledged preparing to kill someone during the Ellsberg break-in, plotting to murder journalist Jack Anderson, plotting with a "gangland figure" to murder Howard Hunt, plotting to firebomb the Brookings Institution, and plotting to kidnap "leftist guerillas" at the 1972 Republican National Convention.

In contrast, Woodward received an email from White House economic adviser Gene Sperling in which the aide stated, "I do truly believe you should rethink your comment about saying saying that [President Obama] asking for revenues is moving the goal post. I know you may not believe this, but as a friend, I think you will regret staking out that claim." Woodward replied to that email, "I also welcome your personal advice. I am listening."

The comparison between the two incidents is unfounded, as the Nixon White House's actions were far more severe and involved direct threats and plots to harm opponents, while the email sent to Woodward was a personal appeal to reconsider a comment.

Title: House Republicans Introduce STEM Jobs Act Amendment to Address Family-Based Green Card Backlog

Article:

House Republicans, following their poor showing among Hispanics in the U.S. presidential election, are set to vote on immigration legislation next week that aims to expand visas for foreign science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) students and make it easier for those with green cards to bring their immediate families to the U.S.

The legislation, known as the STEM Jobs Act, is being viewed as a potential first step in overhauling the nation's dysfunctional immigration system, a top priority for Hispanic communities. The House previously voted on a STEM bill in September, but it was defeated due to a two-thirds majority requirement and opposition from more than 80 percent of Democrats, who objected to the bill's offsetting increase in visas for high-tech graduates by eliminating another visa program for less-educated foreigners.

This time, Republicans are changing the formula by adding a provision to expand a program that allows the spouses and minor children of people with permanent residence, or green cards, to wait in the United States for their own green cards to be granted. Currently, there are about 322,000 spouses, wives, and children waiting in this category, with an average wait time of more than two years.

Under the new proposal, family members would be allowed to come to the U.S. one year after they apply for their green cards, but they would not be able to work until they actually receive the card. The bill applies to the families of green card holders who marry after getting their residency permits.

Bruce Morrison, a former Democratic congressman who chaired the House immigration subcommittee and authored a 1990 immigration law, described the bill as neither increasing the number of green cards nor granting green cards early. However, he noted that the bill provides the "most important benefit" of allowing family members to live legally in the United States with their spouses.

Morrison, an immigration policy lobbyist who advocates for groups such as American Families United, called the bill a stepping-stone to more comprehensive immigration reform. He viewed the Republicans' initiation of the bill as a positive gesture that they want to engage in discussions about this subject.

Megan Whittemore, spokeswoman for House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, a key proponent of the STEM Act, described the bill as "family friendly," helping spouses and minor children who would otherwise be separated from their families for extended periods of time.

The bill will be taken up this time under normal procedures requiring only a majority vote, and it is almost certain to pass the Republican-led House. However, it remains to be seen whether it will garner enough Democratic support to gain momentum as it heads to the Democratic-controlled Senate.

The bill would grant 55,000 green cards a year to doctoral and masters graduates in the STEM fields. The measure, strongly backed by U.S. high-tech companies, would make it easier for people trained in the United States to put their skills to work for American companies rather than non-American competitors.

However, the legislation would still eliminate the Diversity Visa Lottery Program, which gives out a similar 55,000 green cards a year to those from countries, including many in Africa, with traditionally low rates of immigration to the U.S. This prompted the House's Hispanic Caucus, Congressional Black Caucus, and Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus to all come out against it in September.

The three caucuses argued that Republicans were trying to increase legal immigration for people they want by ending immigration for people they do not want. Crystal Williams, executive director of the American Immigration Lawyers Association, described the bill as a message from Republicans that "we are here and we are ready to talk about immigration reform."

However, Williams expressed doubt that the bill will make much progress in the Senate during the short lame-duck session. She noted that people "are now starting to think about broader reform," adding that a limited bill that does not increase visas will not receive a lot of support.

Title: Bernie Sanders Suspends 2020 Presidential Campaign, Clearing Path for Biden-Trump Race

Article:

In a livestreamed speech from his hometown of Burlington, Vermont, on Wednesday, Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders announced the suspension of his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination. The departure of Sanders leaves former Vice President Joe Biden as the last remaining candidate in the Democratic race, setting up a long battle for the White House between Biden and incumbent Republican President Donald Trump.

Sanders, who promised to lead a grassroots political revolution into the White House, acknowledged he no longer had a path to victory after a string of decisive nominating contest losses to Biden. The independent U.S. senator from Vermont cited the coronavirus outbreak, which has taken him off the campaign trail and limited his ability to get his message out, as a reason for his decision.

"I can not in good conscience continue to mount a campaign that can not win, and which would interfere with the important work required of all of us in this difficult hour," Sanders said.

Sanders, 78, called it a "difficult and painful decision" but said he would stay on the ballot in future primaries and continue to gather delegates in order to push the Democratic platform toward his populist anti-corporate agenda, including a government-run healthcare system and tax hikes for the rich.

The departure of Sanders sets up a long battle for the White House between Biden, 77, and Trump, 73, who is seeking a second four-year term in office. That matchup for the foreseeable future will revolve around Trump's handling of the public health crisis that has upended all aspects of American life and rocked the country's economy.

Related Coverage:
- Factbox: Biden is the last person standing in the 2020 Democratic presidential race
- Biden on Wednesday signaled he was ready for a bruising general election fight and the challenge he now faces in trying to unite the Democratic Party's liberal and moderate wings.
- In a separate statement, Biden praised Sanders and promised his ideas would be incorporated into Biden's White House run.

Winning over Sanders' most ardent supporters will not be easy. Sanders' speechwriter David Sirota said Biden should rethink his opposition to parts of Sanders' agenda that opinion polls show are popular among Democratic voters.

"Biden's campaign has to do its part to bring those voters into the fold and energize them in a real way, and they're going to have to do more than just saying Donald Trump is bad. So far Biden has not done that," Sirota said.

Democrats said Sanders' decision to pull out of the 2020 race now would give the party time to come together before the August nominating convention. Some Democrats blame Sanders for staying in his 2016 race against Hillary Clinton too long, hurting her general election bid against Trump.

"I think that allows more time for healing," said Democratic operative Joel Payne, who worked for Clinton's campaign in 2016.

Trump, who has courted Sanders' supporters and said the senator was treated unfairly by the Democratic Party establishment, reacted quickly on Twitter.

"This ended just like the Democrats & the DNC wanted, same as the Crooked Hillary fiasco. The Bernie people should come to the Republican Party, TRADE!," Trump wrote.

Many of Sanders' policy positions have become part of the everyday Democratic Party debate, including his Medicare for All proposal that would create a government-run healthcare system to replace the current blend of private medical insurance and public programs. He also advocated a $15 minimum wage, tuition-free public colleges, and higher taxes on the wealthy.

"It was not long ago that people considered these ideas radical and fringe. Today they are mainstream ideas, and many of them are already being implemented in cities and states across the country. That is what we have accomplished together," Sanders said in his announcement.

Title: Romney Advocates Tying Foreign Aid to Market Opening, Sparks Debate

Article:

In a speech at the Clinton Global Initiative, former Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney called for a reevaluation of the disbursement of American foreign aid, suggesting that it could be linked to the opening of markets and promotion of employment. Romney stated, "The aim of a much larger share of our aid must be the promotion of work and the fostering of free enterprise."

This proposal is likely to ignite debate, as many labor rights organizations and American labor unions argue that free trade agreements, similar to those advocated by Romney, lead to job losses overseas.

During the event, Romney shared a smile with former President Bill Clinton, who has been criticizing him in swing states on behalf of President Obama. Romney jokingly commented, "If there’s one thing we’ve learned this election season, it’s that a few words from Bill Clinton can do a man a lot of good."

President Obama, speaking at the United Nations, addressed the topic of freedom of speech and its significance in the United States. He emphasized the country's commitment to protecting the right to express offensive or hateful speech, stating, "We do so because in a diverse society, efforts to restrict speech can become a tool to silence critics or oppress minorities."

Obama's speech came two weeks after violent anti-American protests resulted in the deaths of four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, in Benghazi, Libya. In his address, Obama vowed to continue supporting democratic freedoms in the Muslim world and to hold accountable those responsible for the attacks.

The president devoted most of his remarks to the Arab democracy movement and its aftermath. His speech was reportedly influenced by his own thoughts after learning of the Benghazi attacks and his subsequent visit to the State Department to console grieving employees.

Title: Trump Accuses Ted Cruz of Imitating His Border Wall Plan

Article:

In an interview aired on Sunday, Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump criticized Texas Senator Ted Cruz for allegedly copying his call to build a wall on the Mexican border and positioning himself as a leader in the national immigration debate.

"Ted Cruz is trying to step up his whole game on amnesty and on illegal immigration because it was actually quite weak," Trump told CBS's "Face the Nation."

When asked whether Cruz's plan is stricter on undocumented workers, Trump responded, "Well, first of all, his plan just happened. In fact, I was watching the other day. And I was watching Ted talk. And he said, 'We will build a wall.' The first time I've ever heard him say it."

Trump continued, "My wife, who was sitting next to me, said, 'Oh, look. He's copying what you've been saying for a long period of time.'"

The real estate mogul then discussed deportation, stating that people can return to the country legally and that he advocates for a "strong border."

"And I'm the one that came up with it. Look. When I announced that I was running, I brought up illegal immigration. It was not even a subject that would have been discussed in this debate. And now it's one of the very big subjects," he said.

Trump also compared Cruz's stance on immigration and amnesty to that of Florida Senator Marco Rubio, stating that both are attempting to address past weaknesses.

"So they're trying to get stronger. But, look, nobody has that position like I have that position. I want the wall. I want strong borders. I want everybody out. Now, people are coming to me. But nobody has that issue like me," he said.

"And nobody's going to be able to do it like me. Nobody. As an example, on the wall. Nobody is getting Mexico to pay for the wall, the cost of the wall, but me. They do not even know about that. That's not even in their vocabulary," Trump concluded.

Title: Historical Suppression of Free Speech and Press in the United States: A Long-Standing Trend

Article:

The United States, often perceived as a bastion of free speech and a free press, has a history of suppressing these liberties, particularly during times of war and in the name of national security. The First Amendment guarantees these freedoms, but attempts to restrict them have been prevalent since the country's inception.

One of the earliest examples of such attempts can be traced back to the Alien and Sedition Acts of 1798. Authored by Federalists such as John Adams, these acts prohibited the publication of "false, scandalous, and malicious" writings against the government. The acts led to the imprisonment of newspaper editors, the denial of entry to the U.S. for immigrants, and the deportation of foreigners.

During the Civil War, President Abraham Lincoln suspended the writ of habeas corpus, allowing individuals to be arrested and held without formal charges. Suspected political prisoners were tried before military tribunals. Lincoln's actions were criticized on constitutional grounds, as only Congress has the power to suspend habeas corpus.

During World War I, the Sedition and Espionage Acts were enacted, forbidding the use of "disloyal, profane, scurrilous, or abusive language" about the government, the flag, or the military. The early 1900s saw the formation of the Bureau of Investigation (later the FBI), which was used to clamp down on civil liberties in an unprecedented manner.

Historian Jennifer Weber notes that Wilson's administration systematically pursued leftists, immigrants, and political dissidents not because of their actions but because of their political beliefs. Violators faced substantial fines and prison sentences of up to 20 years.

Censorship during the 1918 flu pandemic, which resulted in 50-100 million deaths worldwide, is another example of suppressed free speech. Early reports of the flu's spread were minimized to maintain wartime morale.

In the decades that followed the First World War, the nation saw increased suppression of civil rights on a variety of fronts, with labor unions, feminists, and communists among the targeted groups.

World War II brought us the House Un-American Activities Committee (HUAC) and McCarthyism. The Civil Rights Movement in the 1950s and 60s was characterized by government suppression of individual rights. The Vietnam War Era was marked by anti-war protests and corresponding efforts by the government to control dissent.

Today, the nation is subject to NSA spying on American citizens and the Patriot Act, which "arms law enforcement with new tools to detect and prevent terrorism." One hundred years ago, a journalist writing on this topic could face imprisonment. Today, the only consequence might be attention from the NSA. Past precedents could change this yet again in the future.

In conclusion, while the United States is often celebrated for its commitment to free speech and a free press, its history reveals a persistent conflict between individual rights and national security, with numerous instances of suppression of these liberties.

Title: Illinois Teen Warns Against Vaping After Suffering Severe Lung Injury

Article:

An 18-year-old from Gurnee, Illinois, Adam Hergenreder, has issued a warning to young people about the dangers of vaping after being hospitalized with a severe lung injury caused by vaping. According to the Chicago Tribune, Hergenreder has been in the hospital since Saturday at Advocate Condell Medical Center in Libertyville, where he is currently receiving oxygen therapy.

Hergenreder, who started vaping at the age of 16, told the Chicago Tribune that his preferred flavors were mint and mango. He ignored warnings from teachers, parents, and health officials to stop vaping until it was nearly too late. He was rushed to the hospital after several days of uncontrolled vomiting and faces a prolonged recovery period, with the possibility of permanent lung damage due to scarring from inflammation.

"People just see that little pod and think, how could that do anything to my body?," Hergenreder said Tuesday from Advocate Condell Medical Center. "I'm glad I could be an example and show people that [vaping products] aren't good at all. They will mess up your lungs."

Hergenreder initially used about one and a half Juul pods per day, he told WLS-TV. He then began vaping marijuana, purchasing devices from street dealers that can be altered or contaminated with unknown substances. This daily regimen led him to an emergency room, where a doctor ordered a scan of his stomach and saw that "something wasn't right," his mother told the Tribune.

Hergenreder's condition has since improved thanks to oxygen therapy, steroids, and antibiotics, but he is one of at least 27 patients in Illinois who have been hospitalized in recent weeks with severe respiratory illnesses, including one who died, according to the newspaper.

Health officials in Oregon on Wednesday also announced that a second person has died from a severe lung illness linked to vaping, and the first such death connected to a vaping product purchased at a marijuana dispensary.

As of late last week, a total of 215 possible cases of severe lung disease associated with e-cigarettes have been reported by 25 states, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

In a statement to The Washington Post, a Juul spokesman said the company takes the health of its users seriously, labeling its products with "ingredient disclosures" and health warnings. The company also stated that its devices and manufacturing facilities are subject to numerous quality and certification standards, and it conducts extensive preclinical and toxicological testing of the ingredients and analytes in Juul e-liquids and aerosols.

The company is also working to stop counterfeit products compatible with its devices, which are often marketed in violation of Food and Drug Administration (FDA) laws, according to the statement.

"As to this particular reported event, we do not have any details beyond what is being reported by the media, including what or whose products were actually consumed," the statement read. "We will continue to vigilantly monitor for any evidence of safety issues."

Hergenreder hopes to leave the hospital in days if his condition continues to improve. However, only "time and further pulmonary testing" will tell if his breathing will ever return to normal in the weeks and months ahead, his doctor told the Tribune.

"I feel stupid," Hergenreder told the newspaper. "I want other people to stop. It's going to attack your lungs."

Title: California Eliminates Retroactive Tax Deduction for Qualified Small Businesses

Article:

California has announced the elimination of a tax deduction that encouraged entrepreneurs and investors to start and maintain companies within the state. The deduction, which allowed for a 50% exclusion of any gain on the sale of Qualified Small Business (QSB) stock, has been a significant factor in keeping businesses in California instead of relocating to lower-tax states.

The state's capital gains taxes are currently at 9%, and the deduction reduced the capital gains rate to 4.5%. However, California has decided to eliminate the deduction retroactively, affecting those who sold their California companies in the past five years and took advantage of the tax deduction.

Entrepreneur Brian Overstreet, who sold his company last year, wrote about this tax decision on Xconomy. As a result of the retroactive change, Overstreet, like many others, will now have to pay the tax. Overstreet argues that this decision will have far-reaching implications and may encourage companies to reconsider locating in California.

Overstreet states, "California changed the rules after the fact, and that’s just not right." He further notes that the California Franchise Tax Board's (FTB) retroactive action will send a "terrifying message" that may drive young, growing businesses to more friendly environments. This decision could have significant consequences for the state's startup community, as entrepreneurs and investors face potentially debilitating tax bills in the coming months.

Overstreet's company was a small, locally-focused business with a vibrant workforce. The elimination of the QSB tax deduction may impact the decision-making process for similar businesses considering California as a location. The full extent of the impact remains to be seen.

Title: SolarCity Corp. Under Investigation for Potential Misuse of Federal Tax Credits

Article:

California-based solar company SolarCity Corp., a significant recipient of federal tax credits and a company backed by high-profile Obama supporter Elon Musk, is under investigation for potential misuse of federal tax credits. The investigation, led by the Treasury Department's Office of Inspector General, follows concerns raised by Alabama Sen. Jeff Sessions, the top Republican on the Senate Budget Committee.

Sessions' letter to the Treasury Department expressed concern that SolarCity might become the next Solyndra, a solar-panel maker that received significant federal funding but went bankrupt in 2011. SolarCity, in response, dismissed the Solyndra comparison, stating that the declining prices of solar panels, which have allowed more Americans to adopt solar energy, are the driving force behind the company's success.

Beyond SolarCity reportedly received millions in tax credits and cash grants through the 2009 stimulus law, Sessions also alleges that the company may have overestimated the "fair market value" of its products to secure higher tax credits, potentially reaping financial benefits at the expense of American taxpayers.

SolarCity officials, including Lyndon Rive, a fellow Obama donor and Musk's cousin, acknowledged in the company's initial public offering (IPO) document the continued need for government support. They stated that the expiration, elimination, or reduction of rebates, tax credits, and incentives would adversely impact their business.

Solyndra, another solar-panel maker touted by Obama, received an estimated $535 million in Energy Department loan guarantees before declaring bankruptcy in 2011, repaying only a projected $143 million of the funds. Though the cash-grant program for SolarCity and others has concluded, the tax-credit program could continue through 2016.

SolarCity reported a third-quarter profit after years of losses in the recent past. However, Elon Musk, the company's chairman, has benefited significantly from government credits and funding through his various ventures, including a $465 million loan from the Obama administration for Tesla, which was recently paid off, and thousands in federal tax credits for Tesla.

Musk, who has donated $750 toward Obama's first election effort, and Rive, who donated $1,500, are among other SolarCity investors who have supported Obama's campaigns. The investigation into SolarCity's practices is ongoing, and the company has yet to provide a detailed response to the allegations.

Title: Former Trump Campaign Adviser Richard Gates Pleads Guilty in Mueller Probe

Article:

Former Trump campaign adviser Richard Gates pleaded guilty to two charges brought against him by Special Counsel Robert Mueller's team in federal court in Washington, D.C. on Friday afternoon. The charges include one count of conspiracy against the United States and one count of making a false statement to the FBI agents investigating Russian interference.

As part of the plea deal, Gates has agreed to cooperate "fully, truthfully, completely, and forthrightly" with Mueller's office as well as other law enforcement officials. He is required to turn over relevant documents, attend meetings when requested, and testify when requested both before and after he is sentenced. By agreeing to "fully cooperate," additional criminal charges will not be brought against him.

According to the criminal information filed by Mueller on Friday, Gates lied to federal investigators about a March 2013 meeting during which former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort, an unnamed member of Congress, and an unnamed lobbyist discussed Ukraine.

Mueller filed the criminal information one day after he unveiled a new superseding indictment charging Gates and Manafort with a slew of financial-related crimes stemming from their work for pro-Russian political forces in Ukraine over the past decade. The alleged crimes are unrelated to the work Manafort and Gates did for the Trump campaign.

Mueller accused the two longtime business associates of laundering more than $30 million dollars in income that they hid from the U.S. government.

Speculation has mounted over the past week that Gates would plead guilty and cooperate in Mueller's probe, making him a key witness who could testify in the criminal case against Manafort. The development is expected to ratchet up pressure on Manafort to cooperate in Mueller's probe.

Manafort, who resigned as Trump's campaign chairman in August 2016 after reports surfaced about his work for Russian-backed Ukrainian oligarch Viktor Yanukovych, could offer key details about the campaign relevant to Mueller's broader inquiry into whether Trump campaign associates colluded with Moscow.

Manafort issued a statement in response to Gates's guilty plea, saying he is innocent. "Notwithstanding that Rick Gates pled today, I continue to maintain my innocence," Manafort said. "I had hoped and expected my business colleague would have had the strength to continue the battle to prove our innocence. For reasons yet to surface he chose to do otherwise. This does not alter my commitment to defend myself against the untrue piled up charges contained in the indictments against me."

Gates served as Manafort's deputy on the campaign and went on to work for Trump's transition team. In a letter obtained by ABC News earlier Friday, Gates told friends and family that he had decided to plead guilty for the sake of his children. "Despite my initial desire to vigorously defend myself, I have had a change of heart," Gates wrote. "The reality of how long this legal process will likely take, the cost, and the circus-like atmosphere of an anticipated trial are too much. I will better serve my family moving forward by exiting this process."

Title: Obama's Mixed Messages on Islamic State Strategy Cause Confusion

Article:

President Barack Obama sent seemingly conflicting signals Wednesday regarding the United States' ultimate goal in the fight against the Islamic State (IS), stating that the objective is to "degrade and destroy" the terror group, but later claiming he wants to make it a "manageable problem."

During a press conference in Europe, Obama first took a hard line, condemning the execution of American journalist Steven Sotloff as "horrific" and "barbaric" and vowing "justice will be served." He later clarified that if the U.S. is joined by an international coalition, they can "continue to shrink IS's sphere of influence, its effectiveness, its financing, its military capabilities to the point where it is a manageable problem."

The remarks have caused confusion on Capitol Hill and among allies, with some lawmakers criticizing the president's "mixed messages" on the Islamic State. Rep. Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.) told Fox News that the president has not answered whether the U.S. goal is to contain or crush IS. Sen. Saxby Chambliss (R-Ga.) also criticized the president's statements, saying "The time to stop and destroy ISIL is now."

The president is in Europe this week for meetings with allies, where everything from ISIS to the crisis in Ukraine will be on the table. Secretary of State John Kerry is heading to the Middle East to try and build a stronger coalition to go after the Islamic State while boosting the Iraqi and Kurdish governments.

The Obama administration has stressed that the problems in Iraq must be addressed in large part by a new and inclusive government in Baghdad. However, the president continues to weigh whether to expand the current airstrike campaign in northern Iraq into Syria. On Wednesday, Obama still did not give a timeline for deciding on a strategy to go after the extremist group's operations in Syria.

The execution of freelance reporter Steven Sotloff, who reportedly held dual American-Israeli citizenship, was the second such killing in two weeks. In the Sotloff video, a masked militant warns that as long as U.S. airstrikes against the militant group continue, "our knife will continue to strike the necks of your people." Obama responded that he will continue to fight the militant threat and the "barbaric and ultimately empty vision" it represents.

Sotloff, a 31-year-old Miami-area native who freelanced for Time and Foreign Policy magazines, vanished a year ago in Syria and was not seen again until he appeared in the video that showed Foley's beheading. In the video distributed Tuesday and titled "A Second Message to America," Sotloff appears in a similar jumpsuit before he is apparently beheaded by a fighter with the Islamic State, the extremist group that has conquered wide swaths of territory across Syria and Iraq and declared itself a caliphate.

Title: Democratic Establishment Confronts Unexpected Challenge from Bernie Sanders

Article:

The Democratic party is currently grappling with the unexpected surge of Bernie Sanders, a self-proclaimed socialist, in the 2016 presidential race. This development mirrors the Republican establishment's struggle to contain Donald Trump and Ted Cruz in the previous year.

The political class was taken aback by the intensity of voter anger and frustration, a sentiment that was underestimated by the media, as was the case with the Trump and Sanders campaigns. The conventional wisdom at the start of 2015 predicted a strong front-runner in Jeb Bush and a lock for Hillary Clinton. However, Jeb Bush's failure to emerge from single-digit standings and Hillary Clinton's early-state strategy being second-guessed are evidence of this underestimation.

Both Clinton and Bush, hailing from political dynasties, were expected to secure their respective nominations with substantial financial backing from mega-donors. They are also 20th-century figures attempting to adapt to a new century, with Clinton having stood by her husband during the 1992 campaign and the Monica Lewinsky scandal, while Jeb Bush first ran for Florida governor in 1994 and has not held office since 2006. They are perceived as steady, serious, and somewhat dull.

Trump and Sanders, who were not initially given a chance by prognosticators, have drawn larger crowds and generated more enthusiasm than their rivals. Despite their ideological differences, both candidates are running against the establishment. Sanders, an independent throughout his career, has even criticized Planned Parenthood and the Human Rights Campaign, organizations that are backing Hillary Clinton, as part of the establishment.

Trump, who does not rely on campaign contributions, has disrupted the rules of engagement, forcing his rivals to adopt a more aggressive stance on issues such as illegal immigration. Sanders, who has raised significantly more funds than anticipated, has compelled Clinton to shift her positions on healthcare and taxes.

Liberal commentators have enjoyed the spectacle of a Republican civil war, with some prominent voices on the right predicting that the party will self-destruct by nominating Trump or Cruz, a freshman senator who has alienated the establishment. However, it is now the Democratic elders who are expressing concern about the possibility of a socialist leading their ticket and potentially damaging down-ballot candidates.

"The Republicans won't touch him [in the primaries] because they can't wait to run an ad with a hammer and sickle," Sen. Claire McCaskill, a Hillary Clinton supporter, told the New York Times.

In most campaigns, the insurgent candidate captures media attention but ultimately fades: Herman Cain, Rick Santorum, Howard Dean, Bill Bradley, Pat Robertson, and Gary Hart. However, 2016 is not a typical campaign year. Trump, Cruz, and Sanders have exposed the weaknesses of the establishment in both parties, as well as the media's myopia.

Title: Republicans Face Backlash Over Budget Agreement, Projecting Permanent Trillion-Dollar Deficits

Article:

In a statement, Andy Roth, Vice President of the conservative Club for Growth, expressed concern that the recently passed budget agreement will result in permanent trillion-dollar deficits. Roth argued that such fiscal behavior is not in line with the Republican platform.

According to the U.S. Treasury Department, the government is expected to borrow $955 billion this fiscal year, with over $1 trillion in borrowing anticipated for both 2019 and 2020. This increased borrowing is contributing to recent volatility in financial markets, as investors worry that the additional fiscal stimulus, combined with a strengthening economy, could lead to higher inflation and interest rates.

On Thursday, major stock indexes experienced a significant drop, entering a market correction, or a decline of more than 10% from their peak. This decline was largely due to comments from the Bank of England suggesting it might raise interest rates sooner and to a higher degree as it addresses potential inflation. As a result, investors flocked to bonds, pushing the yield on the 10-year Treasury bill to a four-year high of 2.88%.

For many Republicans, supporting the budget agreement represents a departure from conservative fiscal orthodoxy that could pose risks in the upcoming midterm elections. The party's commitment to limited government and deficit reduction played a significant role in the Republicans regaining control of the House and Senate during the Obama administration and in President Trump's election, with the candidate promising to curb federal spending.

Last May, the Trump administration released a budget projecting the U.S. would transition from a deficit of $440 billion in 2018 to a surplus of $16 billion in 2027. The budget proposed deep cuts to domestic programs and a substantial increase in military spending. The current budget agreement appears to deviate from these proposed fiscal measures.

Title: Putin's Foreign Policy: A Historical Perspective on Syria Intervention

Article:

Russian President Vladimir Putin has characterized Russia's intervention in Syria as a fight against the Islamic State. However, Putin's motivation for this intervention can be traced back to events as far as 1989, specifically the fall of the Berlin Wall.

In 1989, the Berlin Wall fell, and crowds stormed the secret police compound in Dresden, breaking its grip on German society. A young Vladimir Putin, then an officer of the KGB, kept them from storming his headquarters. Despite his success, he felt abandoned by Moscow, and the subsequent collapse of the Soviet Union into chaos left a lasting impact on him.

Putin believes that the state's authority is the ultimate bulwark against chaos, and it must be protected, whether in Russia or beyond. He views democracy as something that can quickly dissolve into mob rule, a perspective he has expressed throughout his career.

In 2004, massive protests in Ukraine overturned the alleged victory of Viktor Yanukovych, Russia's favored candidate. This event, known as the Orange Revolution, was a significant defeat for Putin, who came to believe it was a model for plotting revolution inside Russia.

In 2011, Putin stepped down as president but continued to serve as prime minister alongside his protege, Dmitry Medvedev. Protests were sweeping through the Arab World, and Medvedev voiced his sympathy, not blocking American and NATO intervention in Libya. Putin, however, lashed out, referring to the intervention as a medieval call to crusade.

The public breach between Putin and Medvedev contributed to Putin's decision to return to the presidency. In the years that followed, Putin pursued a foreign policy much more hostile to the West, at the same time tightening laws to stifle any public protest at home.

In 2013, protests erupted yet again in Ukraine, this time over efforts to move the country closer to the European Union. Putin has expressed his opposition to such moves, stating that any citizen has a right to express their opinion about the decisions made, but this must be kept within the law.

Putin has also warned that if the authorities encounter a coup attempt, they simply have no choice but to force things in order to prevent chaos. This perspective is reflected in Russia's intervention in Syria, where Putin supports President Bashar al-Assad, whom he views as the state, against an unruly mob.

Putin has expressed concern that the West is repeating past mistakes by exporting revolutions, this time of so-called 'democratic' ones, and that chaos is the result. Putin's foreign policy, as demonstrated by his intervention in Syria, appears to be rooted in his belief that the state's authority is the ultimate bulwark against chaos.

Title: New York City Mayor Criticizes Donald Trump's Remark on Gun Violence and Presidential Fitness

Article:

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio has criticized Republican presidential front-runner Donald Trump for his statement that support for his campaign would not diminish even if he shot someone in the middle of a crowded street.

At a campaign rally in Sioux Center, Iowa, Mr. Trump said, "I could stand in the middle of Fifth Avenue and shoot somebody, and I wouldn't lose voters."

In response, Mr. de Blasio, a Democrat, expressed his disapproval on ABC's "This Week," stating, "It's incredibly insensitive." He further added, "We had a moment in our nation's history we're talking about how to deal with the scourge of gun violence. And for someone who says he wants to be president to say that, it shows he's just not presidential."

De Blasio also commented on Trump's perceived arrogance, stating, "It's incredibly arrogant, too, of him to suggest that his voters will be with him no matter what he does."

Trump has often highlighted his loyal supporters as a source of pride for his campaign, and many of his supporters have publicly expressed their devotion to the flamboyant billionaire real estate developer.

In addition, Mr. de Blasio addressed the possibility of former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg entering the presidential race as an independent candidate, expressing concern about the influence of billionaires in the country.

"I respect my predecessor for sure," he said. "But two things, I'd say. One, my candidate is Hillary Clinton, and I really believe she will be the next president of the United States."

"And the second thing is, I don't think the people of this country want to give more power to billionaires at this point. I think that's what this election increasingly is about, how do we address income inequality, how do we restore the middle class? I don't think most Americans think that billionaires are the ones who are going to help give us a more fair economy," Mr. de Blasio said.

Title: U.S., Allies Accuse Russian Hackers of Targeting COVID-19 Vaccine Research Organizations

Article:

U.S. security agencies, in collaboration with their British and Canadian partners, have accused Russian hackers of targeting organizations involved in the development of COVID-19 vaccines. The allegations, outlined in an advisory issued on Thursday, have sparked condemnation on both sides of the Atlantic and warnings to companies whose research may be at risk of being stolen.

The hacking group, known by names such as "APT29," "the Dukes," and "Cozy Bear," has reportedly targeted organizations in the U.S., Britain, and Canada with the "highly likely" intention of stealing intellectual property related to the vaccine's development, according to the advisory. No targeted organizations were named in the publicized version of the document, and it did not indicate whether any specific data was actually stolen by hackers.

The advisory did, however, say the hackers have successfully exploited known computer vulnerabilities to gain "initial footholds" within an unspecified number of organizations involved in fighting COVID-19. The hackers used custom malware not publicly associated with any campaigns previously attributed to the group, which has been active since at least 2008 and implicated in several high-profile intrusions, including breaching the Democratic National Committee during the last U.S. presidential race.

Sen. Mark Warner (Virginia Democrat), ranking member of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, stated, "It should be clear by now that Russia's hacking efforts didn't stop after the 2016 election. Moving forward, the United States and the western world need to be prepared for increasingly aggressive cyber-attacks from Russian actors."

Senate Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (California Republican) told The Times, "These continued malicious actions to weaken our pandemic response must not go unchecked." Mr. McCarthy said he intends to introduce legislation soon that would ensure the hackers are held responsible.

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Rep. Adam B. Schiff (California Democrat) urged President Trump to act and said he was asking for a briefing from his administration. "There is no issue more critical to the health and safety of our nation and its citizens right now than testing, tracing, treating, and vaccinating," said Mr. Schiff. "The consequences are literally life and death."

White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany told reporters the administration was aware of the activities included in Thursday's advisory, saying the U.S. "worked very closely with our allies" to ensure COVID-19 vaccine research was protected.

British Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab on Thursday called it "completely unacceptable" that Russia would allegedly target organizations working to combat the pandemic. Canada's Communications Security Establishment, one of the agencies that issued Thursday's advisory with the U.S. National Security Agency, the Department of Homeland Security's Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency, and Britain's National Cyber Security Centre, said the attacks would "hinder response efforts at a time when health care experts and medical researchers need every available resource."

Russia flatly denied responsibility, as it has with other major computer intrusions blamed on President Vladimir Putin's regime. "We find such accusations unacceptable," said Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov on Thursday. "We have no information on who could have hacked pharmaceutical companies and research centers in the U.K. We can say only one thing, Russia has nothing to do with these attempts."

Title: Electoral College Confirms Donald Trump as President Despite Anticipated Protests

Article:

The Electoral College is set to confirm Donald Trump as the next President of the United States on Monday, despite efforts to disrupt the 227-year-old process that have so far resulted in only one openly "faithless" elector. The anticipated outcome, however, has been met with uncertainty by both Democrats and Republicans.

Reince Priebus, White House Chief of Staff in the incoming Trump administration, expressed confidence in a smooth process during an interview on "███ Sunday." Electors will convene in state capitals across the country to make the results of the November 8 election official.

In most presidential election years, the Electoral College vote would be a formality. However, electors have been under pressure for weeks from anti-Trump forces to upend the November results, with protests also expected at state capitals on Monday.

Trump's win in the Electoral College, despite losing the popular vote to Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, is attributed to his victories in many smaller, less-populated states in the Midwest and South, as well as Florida, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, and the big coastal state of Florida. Trump needs 270 electoral votes on Monday, and the state victories put him in line to get 306 of the 538, with each state getting one vote for each House and Senate member. The three remaining votes go to the District of Columbia.

Priebus, who still runs the Republican National Committee, which is trying to keep count of the apportioned or "pledged" votes, cited the only known "faithless" balloter, who lives in Texas and whose vote goes to Trump but plans to vote for another, yet-to-be-named Republican.

Arizona elector Robert Graham reported receiving hundreds of thousands of emails telling him not to vote for Trump and claimed that some of the other 10 electors have been followed or have received death threats. Graham, chairman of the Arizona Republican Party, emphasized the importance of the Electoral College, stating, "The Electoral College is part of the Constitution."

All electors swore to party officials that they will back Trump, even though they're not legally bound to do so, and plan to hold to that pledge. Trump responded to the reports of elector harassment and intimidation, stating, "If my many supporters acted and threatened people like those who lost the election are doing, they would be scorned & called terrible names!"

There is no federal law on electoral votes. Some states bind their voters—often state party officials—to the popular vote. However, the penalties for violations are minor, such as being disqualified from future balloting.

John Podesta, Clinton campaign chairman, suggested that 37 electoral voters bound to Trump could defect, which would be enough to create at least a tie and send the vote to the GOP-controlled House, where Trump would still likely win. Podesta, as he has in recent days, pressed the argument that Russians hacking the emails of Democrats during the election led in part to Clinton's loss. He also made a last-minute argument that members of the Electoral College should have an intelligence briefing about the hackings before voting on Monday.

The Associated Press attempted to reach all 538 electors and was able to interview more than 330 of them. Many reported getting tens of thousands of emails, calls, and letters asking them to vote against Trump. However, the canvass found overwhelming support for the system and the nominee among Republican electors. The AP found only one pledged to Trump who will refuse to vote for him but did not identify him as the voter in Texas.

Title: State and Local Campaign Finance Reform Efforts Gain Traction Amidst Federal Gridlock

Article:

In the face of perceived inaction at the federal level, efforts to rein in money in politics are gaining traction in statehouses and city halls across the United States. From the conservative statehouse in Texas to the liberal city council in Philadelphia, reform measures aimed at curbing the flow of political money or disclosing its sources are being introduced and supported by members of both parties.

Over the past five months, more than 125 bills dealing with campaign finance reform have been introduced in 33 statehouses, according to the National Institute on Money in State Politics. More have been introduced in cities as well.

A major bipartisan win for reform advocates came in April when Montana's Democratic Governor Steve Bullock worked with the GOP-controlled Legislature to pass a bill requiring all groups, including 501(c)(4)s, to disclose their donors if they spend money on targeting or supporting a candidate within 60 days of an election.

Politicians on the state and local level, many of whom are afraid an outside group could fund a primary opponent against them, point to polls that show overwhelming support for campaign finance reform. A recent New York Times/CBS poll found that 85 percent of those surveyed believe the system for funding political campaigns needs either "fundamental changes" or a complete overhaul. Based on the same poll, Republicans were almost as likely as Democrats to favor further restrictions on campaign contributions.

On the federal level, since the Supreme Court opened the door to unlimited giving in the Citizens United v. FEC ruling, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has remained staunchly against efforts to limit political contributions, making it harder to garner GOP support on the issue.

In recent days alone, a bill requiring all groups to disclose their donors and expenditures proposed by the Philadelphia Board of Ethics advanced and could go into effect as early as July 1. In Texas, the state House passed a similar bill. However, under pressure from independent groups, the state Senate and Governor Greg Abbott opposed including the measure in an ethics package, upending the entire deal.

With the agency's six-member panel, split equally between Republicans and Democrats, in perpetual gridlock, Republicans on the state and local level have been particularly receptive to backing reform efforts aimed at providing the public with more disclosure, such as the bills in Texas and Montana, despite opposition from powerful groups like the Koch-backed Americans for Prosperity. McConnell also opposes more political disclosure, saying it would lead to harassment and donor intimidation.

"When somebody's hiding in the shadows and gut-shoots you, you have a right to know who's taking a shot at you," said Montana state Senator Duane Ankney to the Montana Standard earlier this year.

A new group, Take Back Our Republic, formed by John Pudner, who served as a political consultant to David Brat, the academic who ousted former House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, is also trying to bring more conservatives on board with reform efforts. The group recently launched 17 chapters in states across the country.

Pudner said there's a lot more resistance from Republicans within the Beltway on the issue compared with the rest of the country. "It seems to be the more conservative members who are most concerned," he said, adding that the issue has created a "true left-right coalition" in many places.

Dale Eisman, spokesman for Common Cause, which has state chapters pushing for campaign finance reform across the country, pointed to polls showing strong support for at least disclosure—if not other campaign finance reforms—to explain recent GOP support.

"It's not surprising because every poll we see shows that the public is in strong support of disclosure," he said. "The people want this. Legislators—whether Republicans or Democrats—if they want to do what their constituents want, should support disclosure."

Title: Walmart Discontinues Sale of Certain Ammunition, Handguns, and Open Carry of Firearms in Stores

Article:

Walmart, the largest firearms seller in the United States, has announced it will discontinue the sale of certain types of ammunition and handguns, following a series of mass shootings, including one at a Walmart store in Texas that left 22 dead. The decision comes amid increasing pressure on the company, with CEO Doug McMillon stating, "It's clear to us that the status quo is unacceptable."

In a note to employees and on the firm's website, McMillon explained that the company would discontinue sales of bullets used in assault-style weapons and those used in handguns. The company will also discontinue handgun sales in Alaska, the only place it still offered such weapons. Walmart has also asked customers at its Walmart and Sam's Club stores to stop carrying firearms openly, even in states where it is legally permitted.

The changes have been met with praise from celebrities, politicians, and several Democratic presidential candidates, but the National Rifle Association (NRA) has criticized the move, calling it "shameful" and predicting the company will lose business. Another major US retailer, Kroger, has also changed its policy, asking customers to stop openly carrying guns in stores where state laws allow it.

Walmart's decision to discontinue the sale of certain ammunition and handguns is expected to reduce the company's share of the ammunition market from about 20% to a range of 6% to 9%. The company will continue to sell hunting rifles and shotguns, and much of the ammunition for those weapons. Walmart stock was little changed after the announcement, but shares in some gun-makers, such as Vista Outdoors, slumped.

Guns and ammunition represent a tiny fraction of overall Walmart sales, according to Burt Flickinger III, a managing director of the retail consulting firm Strategic Resource Group. He predicted the decision would pay off, allowing the retailer to provide more store space to faster-growing categories such as baby nappies.

Walmart's decision follows two incidents at stores in August, in which a gunman killed 22 people in El Paso, Texas, and a former employee killed two workers at a Walmart store in Mississippi. Last month, mass shootings in Ohio and Texas left more than a dozen dead. There have been more than 110 mass shootings in the US since 1982, according to investigative magazine Mother Jones.

Walmart has lagged behind other US retailers in changes to its gun policies. Kroger-owned Fred Meyer stopped selling guns in 2018 after a mass shooting at a school in Parkland, Florida. That same year, Dick's Sporting Goods ended the sale of assault weapons and raised the minimum age to 21 for gun purchases. The move reflects a shift since Walmart stopped being a family-run company, with Sam Walton, who founded the company in 1962, being a known hunting enthusiast.

Title: G-20 Seating Arrangement: Obama and Putin to be Separated at St. Petersburg Summit

Article: The upcoming G-20 summit of world leaders in St. Petersburg, Russia, is set to begin on Thursday, and the seating arrangement has sparked discussions regarding the state of U.S.-Russian relations. According to Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, the initial seating plan would have had U.S. President Barack Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin separated only by the Saudi king. However, the seating order has been reshuffled, with five leaders, including British Prime Minister David Cameron, placed between the two key adversaries over Syria and other issues.

The Russian organizers of the summit reportedly rewrote the seating plan using the Latin alphabet to ensure that Putin and Obama are not seated near each other, as reported by Izvestia on Sept. 4. Minnesota Public Radio's The Daily Circuit blog describes the upcoming Obama-Putin encounter as "awkward."

NPR's Scott Horsley, who is covering Obama's trip to Europe, reports that the two leaders are expected to have brief conversations at some point during the summit, but no lengthy discussions are anticipated. The U.S.-Russian disagreement over Syria and the cancellation of a planned one-on-one summit due to Russia's decision to grant temporary asylum to "NSA leaker" Edward Snowden have contributed to the "frosty" relationship between the two leaders.

In the past, President Obama has compared Putin's behavior at previous summits to that of a "bored kid in the back of the classroom." However, he added that their conversations are often candid, blunt, and constructive.

Voice of America notes that this wouldn't be the first time summit seating plans have been politicized. At a NATO Summit in Prague in 2002, NATO officials reportedly rewrote the seating arrangement in French to isolate then Ukrainian President Leonid Kuchma at the far end of the table.

Title: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to Meet with Russian President Putin Amid Syria Missile Concerns

Article:

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is scheduled to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin tomorrow, adding to the recent flurry of global diplomatic activity over the ongoing civil war in Syria. According to a Kremlin statement, the meeting will take place in Russia on Tuesday, with "major attention" to be paid to the current situation in the Middle East, particularly in Syria.

The statement did not provide further details, but Agence France-Presse reported on Sunday that Netanyahu's trip was "reportedly prompted by concerns that Russia was preparing to ship Syria S-300 surface-to-air missiles, which can defend against multiple aircraft and missiles."

Russia has been a close ally of President Bashar al-Assad's government in Syria throughout the civil war, a fact that has caused consternation in the West and most Middle Eastern nations. Russia has countered that the West is fueling regional instability by supporting the rebels, particularly by empowering Islamist elements.

The missiles, whose shipment came to light last week, are a source of concern for both Israel, which has staged two airstrikes against targets in Syria in recent weeks, and for the US. According to The ███, Secretary of State John Kerry stated, "I think we have made it crystal clear that we would prefer that Russia is not supplying assistance" to Syria.

"We have previously stated that [ these ] missiles are potentially destabilizing with respect to the state of Israel," Kerry added. The introduction of the S-300 into Syria's air defense arsenal could sharply limit the future options not only for Israel but for the US should it decide to intervene in the conflict.

While the US and Israel express their concerns over Russia's missile shipment to the Assad regime, there is cautious optimism in some Western capitals over a planned international conference on Syria that both Moscow and Washington are organizing. British Prime Minister David Cameron, who is visiting the White House today, is reportedly set to tell President Barack Obama that he believes Russia is prepared to adopt a more flexible approach to Syria, based on his meeting Friday with Putin in Sochi, Russia.

Speaking during his flight to Washington, Cameron described his talks with Putin as "extremely positive and good." He said, "I was very heartened that while it is no secret that Britain and Russia have taken a different approach to Syria, I was very struck in my conversations with President Putin that there is a recognition that it would be in all our interests to secure a safe and secure Syria with a democratic and pluralistic future and end the regional instability."

Cameron said he would use his meeting with Obama to "try to really put flesh on the bones of this plan for a peace conference and to think of all the things that would make it work and deliver a peaceful transition in Syria." A lot of progress has been made, and I want to push on on that," he added.

However, experts tell AFP that they doubt the progress will amount to anything concrete. Stephen Sestanovich, an expert in Russian and Eurasian studies at the Council on Foreign Relations in Washington, said this week's agreement on a peace conference "moves the Geneva [peace plan] formula one step further, but what is one step beyond complete meaninglessness?"

"The real issue is whether the Russians are prepared to tell Assad and his supporters that the jig is really up for their regime," he added. Salman Shaikh, director of the Brookings Doha Center, said he was not convinced that the different players' positions had "changed that much."

"The situation on the ground," rather than diplomatic efforts, "will continue to shape events," Shaikh stressed. Reuters notes that it is not yet clear whether the Syrian opposition will attend the US-Russia peace conference. The opposition coalition is set to meet on May 23 to determine whether it will attend, though the coalition itself remains split over the leadership of the group. Reuters writes that two factions, one backed by the Muslim Brotherhood, the other by Qatar, are vying for control of the coalition.

Title: Bipartisan Gang of Eight Senators Expect Immigration Overhaul Draft by End of the Week

Article:

Members of the bipartisan Gang of Eight senators working on immigration overhaul legislation expect to have a draft bill agreeable to their circle by the end of this week. However, Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Florida), a member of the group, has stated that it is too soon to consider the deal struck.

In a statement, Rubio wrote, "I'm encouraged by reports of an agreement between business groups and unions on the issue of guest workers. However, reports that the bipartisan group of eight senators have agreed on a legislative proposal are premature."

Shortly after Rubio's statement, Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-South Carolina) signaled on CNN's "State of the Union with Candy Crowley" that the deal will be reached within days. "It's got to be written up. We have not signed off," he said. "There are a few details yet, but conceptually - we have an agreement between business and labor, between ourselves. It has to be drafted. It will be rolled out next week."

Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-New York) concurred on the timeline and acknowledged a few issues remaining to be settled. "As Sen. Rubio correctly says, we have said we will not come to final agreement until we look at all of the legislative language, and he's correctly pointing out that that language has not been fully drafted," he said on NBC's "Meet the Press."

Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Arizona) also sounded optimistic a deal would be reached but said, "We've still got a ways to go with the language."

Both Schumer and Rubio are seen as particularly important in this process, with Schumer the Democratic deal-maker who is bringing the sides together and Rubio key to bringing on board conservative members of both the House and Senate.

Schumer said any difference between his view and Rubio's view of progress toward a deal is just "semantics." "I do not think he'll walk away," Schumer said when asked, adding, "He's had a lot of input into the bill. Obviously, his views are not the same as the other seven of us. Every one of us has different views... He is protecting some of the things that he thinks are very important in the bill, but I do not think that will stand in the way in any way of any agreement."

On Saturday, leaders of labor and business groups reached consensus on the outlines of a guest worker program, a sticking point in the area of immigration between influential lobbies including the AFL-CIO and Chamber of Commerce. The consent of business and labor groups is important not only because it means neither side will fight the bill, but also because a key goal of the Gang of Eight is to restructure the current system for allocating U.S. visas.

The Gang of Eight includes Sens. Michael Bennet (D-Colorado), Dick Durbin (D-Illinois), John McCain (R-Arizona), and Robert Menendez (D-New Jersey) in addition to Rubio, Graham, Schumer, and Flake.

President Barack Obama has described immigration as a top priority of his, but appears to have left the negotiating largely up to Capitol Hill, especially after a draft administration plan for immigration reform was reported publicly and drew criticism from Republicans, including Rubio. A White House official said Saturday the president "continues to be encouraged by progress being made by the bipartisan group of senators." "We look forward to seeing language once it is introduced, and expect legislation to move forward as soon as possible," the official said.

Title: Trump Presidency Puts Voting Rights in Jeopardy

Article:

With Donald Trump's presidency, the possibility of him appointing two conservative justices to the Supreme Court has raised concerns for voting rights advocates. The current right-wing efforts to restrict voting rights and the diminished likelihood of challenging and overturning these restrictions are major sources of worry.

Dale Ho, the director of the voting rights project at the American Civil Liberties Union, expressed caution, stating, "It's not the apocalypse yet, but on voting, we're obviously not in as good a position as we expected to be in, and we're going to have to wait and see."

The concern lies in the potential for many voter-suppression tactics to remain in place or even spread, as the addition of two conservative justices could make it difficult to gather the necessary five votes to strike down these types of restrictions. In the past five years, voting rights advocates have been largely in a defensive posture, with the Supreme Court's 2013 decision to weaken the Voting Rights Act being a significant setback.

Another issue for voting rights advocates under a Trump presidency is the difficulty in expanding the franchise. Existing restrictions on voting rights have already played a role in electing Trump, as my colleague Matthew Rozsa reported. In states like Wisconsin, voter ID laws disproportionately affected nonwhite voters and may have contributed to Trump's victory in the Electoral College.

Trump's campaign platform, which at least in part channeled and evoked white-nationalist sentiment, dovetails with restrictions on voting rights, which are often explicitly aimed at reducing the number of people of color who vote. Trump's initial staffing decisions, such as the appointment of Steve Bannon as his chief White House strategist, suggest a commitment to pursuing an agenda rooted in white-supremacist ideology.

Voter suppression is not only about winning elections, but also about racism. In North Carolina, a voter-suppression law was struck down by the Fourth Circuit Court in August, with the court stating that the law targeted "African Americans with almost surgical precision." With Trump at the helm and his well-documented enthusiasm for racism in play, gathering a fifth vote to further restrict voting rights in the future is much less likely to be a problem.

Title: Obama Family's Annual Christmas Weekly Address: Emphasizing Service, Unity, and Gratitude

In the spirit of the holiday season, President Barack Obama delivered the annual White House Christmas Weekly Address, joined by his wife, Michelle Obama, and their daughters, Malia and Sasha. The theme of this year's decorations is "The Gift of the Holidays," reflecting the nation's greatest gifts, such as military families and the impact of education.

The Obamas expressed gratitude for the honor of serving as the President and First Lady for the past eight years. They highlighted their achievements, including recovering from the worst recession in 80 years, reducing unemployment, securing health insurance for 20 million Americans, and taking on global leadership roles.

The First Lady emphasized the importance of service, quoting the Bible, "We are our brother's keeper and our sister's keeper." She encouraged the American people to embody love, compassion, and hope, caring for the sick, feeding the hungry, and welcoming the stranger, regardless of their background or faith.

President Obama acknowledged the service and sacrifice of military families, many of whom are away from home during the holiday season. He encouraged the public to support service members, veterans, and military families through the JoiningForces.gov website.

The Obamas concluded their address by expressing hope for the New Year and wishing the American people a merry Christmas and a happy and healthy 2017. They signed off with a collective message of unity, emphasizing the shared values that guide Americans of all faiths and backgrounds.

Title: Low Trust in Government: A Persistent Trend and Its Implications

Article:

According to Gallup and most other polling organizations, Americans have record or near-record low rates of confidence in government. In the second quarter of President Donald Trump's term, only 39% of Americans approved of his performance, a significant 25-point drop from the historical average. Trust in public schools stands at 36%, the criminal justice system at 26%, and Congress at a mere 12%. Trust in most major institutions is lower than it was a decade ago.

Libertarians and other skeptics of government view this trend as a sign that people are finally waking up to reality. However, there are good reasons to be concerned about persistently low levels of trust and confidence in government.

Researchers have found that people in countries with bad governments often desire more government intervention in all aspects of their lives, despite their lack of trust in the government's fairness or effectiveness. A 2010 study found that 82% of former East Germans and 92% of Russians, two famously "low-trust" populations, favored wage controls. Residents in Scandinavia and North America, which are "high-trust" regions, were far more trusting of market forces.

It appears that government may be growing not in spite of our lack of confidence in it, but because of our lack of confidence in it. This self-defeating spiral will only get worse if the United States fails to stem its slide toward being a low-trust country.

The solution does not have to be nihilism or anarchy. Instead, we need a government that does fewer things but does them better. Government spending is at an already swollen 21% of GDP and is predicted to climb to 30% over the next three decades. Libertarians rightly want a limited government, and we should fight to end cronyism, drug prohibition, and regulatory overreach that increases the cost of doing business. We need to keep pushing back against defense spending wasted on elective wars and national security measures that put us under surveillance without making us safer.
