However, we should also point to places where government action is both legitimate and effective and praise policies—like school choice, for instance—that deliver better results at cheaper costs. Ironically, if we can get more people to trust the government, it just might be easier to shrink the size, scope, and spending of the state.

This article was produced by Todd Krainin, written by Nick Gillespie, and cameras by Jim Epstein.

Title: Mnuchin's Senate Hearing: Five-Hour Testimony Marked by Tough Questions and Policy Cautiousness

Article:

Steven Mnuchin's Senate hearing concluded after a five-hour session, during which he faced a series of challenging questions primarily from Democratic senators regarding his business background, investment holdings, and financial disclosures. Compared to his two television interviews in November, Mnuchin provided fewer policy details in the hearing.

In an effort to soften some of Donald Trump's controversial statements on tariffs, the dollar, and the U.S. debt, Mnuchin adopted positions that resembled those of the outgoing Treasury secretary. He emphasized the need to promptly raise the debt limit when its current suspension expires in March and to increase staffing at the Internal Revenue Service.

In other policy areas, Mnuchin adopted moderate positions without fully departing from the Republican orthodoxy. For instance, on the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, he expressed support for maintaining the bureau but suggested altering its funding mechanism, a change that some Democrats have expressed concern could lead to the agency's significant constriction.

On the Volcker Rule, Mnuchin supported the rule's objective but also outlined changes that its proponents have argued would weaken it. Although he appeared to distance himself from past support for privatizing mortgage companies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, he acknowledged their importance to the mortgage market and their past valuable roles.

Democrats attempted to question Mnuchin over disclosures that he did not make to the committee until committee staffers pointed out the oversights. Mnuchin attributed these mistakes to paperwork errors. They also sought to probe potential conflicts of interest due to Donald Trump not placing his extensive real-estate holdings into a blind trust.

Republicans did not seem troubled by these issues, with the exception of Nevada Sen. Dean Heller, who raised concerns over Mnuchin's lack of response to earlier questions about his foreclosure record at OneWest Bank in his home state.

Title: Graham-Cassidy Bill: Latest Attempt to Repeal Affordable Care Act Faces Uncertain Future

Article:

The Graham-Cassidy bill, the latest attempt to repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA), is facing an uncertain future as it undergoes revisions to secure the support of key senators. Under the revised bill, states could potentially allow insurers to set higher premiums based on a person's health status, though not on the basis of sex or genetic information.

State officials, in applying for federal grants, would be required to describe how they would "maintain access to adequate and affordable health insurance coverage for individuals with pre-existing conditions." However, changes to the bill's funding formula to win over Senator Lisa Murkowski could cost it support from conservatives. The hasty revisions have also raised concerns that Congress may be moving forward on a bill that has not been thoroughly vetted.

The Congressional Budget Office is set to release a partial analysis of the bill's impact as soon as Monday, but this report may not include the latest changes. President Trump, speaking to reporters in New Jersey on Sunday, seemed to be looking ahead to the next legislative goal for Republicans—overhauling the tax code—while also discussing the Graham-Cassidy bill and applying pressure to resistant senators.

The architects of the latest repeal plan, Senators Lindsey Graham and Bill Cassidy, are not giving up. "We're moving forward, and we'll see what happens next week," said Senator Graham on ABC's "This Week." "I'm very excited about it. We finally found an alternative to Obamacare that makes sense."

White House Director of Legislative Affairs Marc Short stated on NBC's "Meet the Press" that a Senate vote was planned for this week. However, a spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell declined to confirm that timeline on Sunday. The Graham-Cassidy bill aims to repeal the expansion of Medicaid under the ACA, as well as the tax credits that help people buy insurance on the individual market. In their place, it would provide block grants to the states to use for healthcare. The bill's future remains uncertain as it faces opposition from both sides of the political spectrum.

Title: Senate to Approve Three Obama Nominees This Week, According to Reid

Article:

The United States Senate is expected to approve three more of President Barack Obama's nominees this week, as announced by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid on Wednesday. Reid anticipates the confirmation of Fred Hochberg to head the Export-Import Bank, Gina McCarthy to head the Environmental Protection Agency, and Tom Perez to lead the Labor Department by the end of business on Thursday.

According to a leadership aide, Hochberg is likely to be confirmed on Wednesday, with final approval for McCarthy and Perez potentially coming as early as Thursday, depending on the amount of debate time requested by Republicans. The Senate typically adjourns for the weekend on Thursday afternoons, making it likely that the three nominations will be completed before Friday morning.

The progress on the long-stalled nominations follows the approval of Richard Cordray to head the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Tuesday. The agreements to vote on these nominees, as well as three candidates for the National Labor Relations Board, are the result of a Tuesday deal between Reid and Republicans to avoid an unprecedented Senate rules change.

Reid had previously threatened to change the Senate's rules to move those nominations forward in the face of Republican filibusters. However, the "nuclear option" of a rules change on votes on executive nominees, which would have lowered the voting threshold on some of Obama's picks from 60 to 51, was averted. Instead, senators agreed to fill the NLRB and allow Hochberg, McCarthy, Perez, and Cordray to proceed without a change to the Senate rules.

Reid expressed hope that this agreement marks a new era of cooperation in the Senate, stating, "We have now started a new era, I hope a new normal in the Senate where senators talk to each other rather than past each other."

Title: Discussion on Leadership Change in Democratic Party Amid Georgia Election Loss

Article:

Following the loss of the Georgia special election and other congressional races this year, there has been a surge of discussions about whether House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi should step down from her Democratic leadership role. This conversation has extended to President Trump, who tweeted on Thursday, "I certainly hope the Democrats do not force Nancy P out. That would be very bad for the Republican Party - and please let Cryin' Chuck stay!"

In response, Pelosi stated later that morning that Trump's comments were a typical Republican line and that he likely received the script from members of his party. "He then added the Chuck Schumer bit," she said at a briefing.

Pelosi defended her position and asserted her status as a master legislator and politically astute leader. While she respects the opinions of her caucus members, she added, "My decision of how long I stay is not up to them."

Since Jon Ossoff's loss to Karen Handel on Tuesday night, a few congressional Democrats have expressed a desire for leadership change, including Reps. Kathleen Rice of New York and Rep. Seth Moulton of Massachusetts, according to CNN. Rice stated, "We need leadership change. It's time for Nancy Pelosi to go, and the entire leadership team."

Democratic Rep. Filemon Vela of Texas expressed similar sentiments, stating, "You'd have to be an idiot to think winning the House in 2018 was possible with Pelosi in charge." Vela added, "Nancy Pelosi is not the only reason that Ossoff lost, but she certainly is one of the reasons."

However, despite the Georgia special election loss, the head of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, Rep. Ben Ray Luján, expressed optimism about the possibility of Democrats winning enough seats for a House majority in 2018.

Title: "2016: A Year of Reflection and Restoration for the United States"

Article:

As the new year approaches, the focus of many Americans is on the challenges faced by the country over the past seven years. The article discusses the perceived failures of President Obama's administration and the need for a change in direction. The author emphasizes the importance of recognizing the resilience of the American people and the strength of the Founding Fathers' foundation for the nation.

The article criticizes the left for advocating for changes to the Constitution and the amendments, referring to them as "harpies and trolls." The author attributes the strength of the Constitution and the nation to the work of the original Founding Fathers, who established a foundation to prevent disturbed individuals and tyranny.

The author argues that the current state of the nation and the world is a result of the actions of career politicians, and that the establishment has facilitated this disaster by going along to get along. The article mentions several issues facing the nation, including the childish and incompetent destruction of the health insurance and health care system, leftist bullying on college campuses, open borders, Islamic State plots, urban riots, high numbers of Americans on food stamps, and a government campaign to disarm Americans while importing potential terrorists.

The author also discusses the rise of Republican candidates Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, and the establishment's perceived fear of their campaigns. The article mentions comments made by Republican operatives Rick Wilson and Pat Brady, who have suggested taking action against Trump and Cruz, respectively.

The author argues that the establishment's fear of the current political climate is unwarranted, and that the American people are not divided or fearful, but rather angry and concerned. The author suggests that replacing failed leadership is a restoration, not an abandonment, of the system established by the Founding Fathers. The author concludes by comparing the current political climate to historical events such as Yorktown and the beaches at Normandy, emphasizing the importance of getting it right in 2016.

Title: Easing the Path to Bankruptcy for Small Businesses: A Potential Solution Amidst the Economic Crisis

Article:

The ongoing coronavirus pandemic has led to an economic crisis in the United States, with small businesses being one of the most affected sectors. Small businesses, which account for more than 99 percent of all businesses in the U.S. and nearly 50 percent of all employment, are at a significant risk of failure as the virus spreads and people practice social distancing.

Currently, a $2 trillion economic relief package has been passed by the Senate and is moving to the House. This package includes a $367 billion loan program to help small businesses weather this difficult time. However, additional steps can be taken by the federal government to further support America's small-business owners.

In normal circumstances, small businesses have a high failure rate, with only about 50 percent surviving the first five years and only 30 percent surviving longer than 10 years. The U.S. bankruptcy system offers these failed entrepreneurs a "fresh start" by wiping out debts and pardoning failure. By filing under Chapter 7 of the federal bankruptcy laws, entrepreneurs can shield some or all of their assets from creditors and are released from any future obligation to repay debts.

However, there is a lack of consistent bankruptcy policy across the states, which creates an unintended barrier to small business owners who need relief. Since the Federal Bankruptcy Code of 1978 was enacted, bankruptcy exemption levels are set by the states and vary widely. For example, in seven states or regions, the homestead exemptions are unlimited, while in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, they are zero. All other states lie somewhere in between.

Other bankruptcy routes include Chapter 11 and Chapter 13, which are reorganization procedures. While Chapter 7 is the usual route for consumer filings, Chapter 13 is available to individuals with regular income and sole proprietors, and Chapter 11 is typically available to corporations or partnerships. The amount of debt discharged approaches that under Chapter 7, but both procedures require the debtor to establish a repayment plan paid for with future income.

In 2005, Congress passed the Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act (BAPCPA) with the primary intention of making it harder for individuals to file a Chapter 7 bankruptcy. The reform introduced a means test for Chapter 7, which essentially prevented individuals earning above-average income from wiping out their debt through filing under Chapter 7. Instead, such individuals would be able to file under Chapter 13, which allows debt discharge only after the individual has made some repayments.

BAPCPA also lowered exemptions for certain assets and debtors now need to undergo credit counseling before filing—a costly process and, for many business owners, not particularly useful. Research suggests a modest but unarguably negative impact from some of these changes on small-firm entry decisions. Others find a 50 percent reduction in Chapter 7 filings after the act's passage, and a 25 percent increase in insolvency, leading to worse outcomes for financially distressed borrowers.

While these provisions may work to reduce bankruptcy abuse in normal economic times, these are not normal economic times. It is in the taxpayers' interest to do everything reasonably possible to protect small businesses—responsible for creating millions of jobs—from going under. Allowing small businesses to have an easier path to a Chapter 7 bankruptcy could provide them a fresh start when the crisis is over. By easing the costs associated with a Chapter 7 filing, removing means-tested filing for a temporary period, and allowing more individuals and small businesses to file and claim unlimited homestead and personal property exemptions for a temporary period, we can provide greater protections to the assets of small business owners.

Aparna Mathur is a Resident Scholar in Economic Policy Studies at the American Enterprise Institute.

Title: US-North Korea Summit: Preparations Underway for Possible Trump-Kim Meeting

Article:

A US team is currently engaged in negotiations with North Korean officials in the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea, signaling a potential revival of the planned meeting between President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. The talks, held in the village of Panmunjom, are the latest indication that the summit could take place after President Trump called off the meeting, citing North Korea's "hostility" on Thursday.

On Saturday, North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in held an unannounced meeting, with Mr. Moon stating that Kim had "again made clear his commitment to a complete denuclearization of the Korean peninsula." Kim later expressed his "fixed will" for the summit to proceed, and Trump tweeted on Sunday that the meeting would help the North achieve its "brilliant potential."

The US team, led by Sung Kim, a former ambassador to South Korea, is reportedly holding talks with North Korean Vice-Foreign Minister Choe Son-hui. The aim of the talks is to set an agenda for the summit between the leaders.

While officials appear more optimistic about the meeting going ahead, recent weeks have shown that the relationship can change very quickly, according to the BBC's Chris Butler in Washington. There is still a lot of ground to be covered, and President Trump has shown that if he does not think a deal can be done, he will not go.

It is unclear whether Kim will agree to fully abandon his nuclear arsenal, as similar pledges in the past have not been upheld. Analysts say the US had wanted denuclearization first, followed by rewards in the form of lifted sanctions and economic aid. However, Kim has indicated he wants a phased approach, with his steps met by reciprocal ones from the US and the South, mainly on sanctions but also easing of the US military presence in South Korea.

North Korea has been subjected to numerous rounds of international sanctions since 2006, which has cut off most of its exports and capped its imports of oil. The North also wants assurances that its survival as a state would never be in question.

Getting this far has been a surprise given that North Korea had maintained its strident rhetoric and continued its nuclear and missile tests through 2016 and 2017. This brought a bitter war of words between President Trump and the North Korean leadership. However, a rapprochement began in January when Kim suggested he was "open to dialogue" with South Korea. The following month, the two countries marched under one flag at the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics, held in the South. Kim announced he was suspending nuclear tests and held his landmark summit with Mr. Moon last month. This week, North Korea said it had dismantled its Punggye-ri nuclear test site, although scientists believe it partially collapsed after the last test in September 2017.

Title: Clinton's Challenges in Mobilizing Voters Beyond Primary Election

Article:

The ongoing speculation regarding Hillary Clinton's ability to appeal to Bernie Sanders' supporters in the general election and the potential for Sanders to hinder Clinton's prospects is a topic of discussion among Democrats. History suggests that there is little reason for concern, as candidates typically fight hard until they stop fighting, and post-primary unity is crucial for capturing the Senate.

However, the real challenge for Clinton lies not in reaching Sanders' supporters but in mobilizing the larger universe of left-of-center voters who did not participate in the primary elections. In the 2008 presidential election, Barack Obama garnered 17,584,692 votes, and Clinton lost despite winning about 260,000 more votes. To win, Clinton needs to mobilize not just Sanders' supporters but the much larger group of left-of-center voters who did not vote in the primaries.

The Clinton-Sanders race is not as close as the 2008 primary, but it is a lower-turnout affair. Sanders has about 10 million votes, and Clinton has about 13 million. Both numbers will increase once California and New Jersey vote, but they will not reach the levels seen in 2008.

General election winners need way more votes than the combined Clinton-Sanders total. Obama got 66 million votes in 2012, George W. Bush got 62 million votes in 2004, and even in the low-turnout three-way race of 1992, when the population was lower, Bill Clinton got 45 million votes.

The people who voted for Sanders in the primary are some of the lowest-hanging fruit for Clinton, as they are already registered to vote and are taking an unusually high level of interest in politics. Their names and contact information will be on Sanders' campaign lists, and Sanders will be endorsing Clinton and campaigning for her.

The real problem for Clinton is reaching the legions of people with left-of-center political views who are less attached to the political process than actual Bernie Sanders voters. Younger people and nonwhites, in particular, seem less connected to the political process and more willing to stay home from the polls.

Clinton's weakness with young voters was evident in both the 2008 and 2016 primaries. To win, she needs to reach a lot of young people who have not stirred themselves to vote for Sanders, which is a harder challenge.

Democrats' current hope is that fear of Donald Trump will be an excellent motivator to drive turnout among the Obama coalition of minority groups and young people. However, it is far from clear that this sort of negative focus is a successful voter turnout strategy.

Voting is not a very rational course of action, and the odds that one's decision to vote or stay home will actually be the difference between Donald Trump ending up in or out of the White House are incredibly small. People vote for the same kinds of reasons that they attend political rallies—we are communal beings, and it's nice to sometimes take part in larger activities.

Clinton, who would be the first woman president if elected, certainly has the potential to play a role in people's thinking. However, her generally low approval ratings, the fact that she is getting fewer votes than she did eight years ago, and her weak performance in the primary with young women are all signs that she is struggling in practice to do it.

The best news for Clinton is that Trump is viewed even less favorably by the public and will face his own massive challenges in securing Republican turnout. However, the basic dynamics of a race to the bottom in terms of voter enthusiasm are not all that favorable to Democrats—as we've seen in the past two midterm elections. The map we see every presidential election is pretty much useless.

Title: Proposed Amendment to Title VII of the Civil Rights Act to Protect Against Viewpoint Discrimination

Article:

A call for an amendment to Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, aimed at protecting employees from workplace discrimination based on their political views, is gaining traction in the United States. The current law does not cover political views, leaving employees vulnerable to termination or denial of employment opportunities due to their political beliefs.

The issue, often referred to as "cancel culture," has been criticized for its impact on free speech and the ability of individuals to express their opinions on important public matters without fear of economic and social repercussions. The proposed amendment would add "viewpoints or beliefs" to the list of prohibited discriminations, which currently includes race, color, religion, sex, and national origin.

The amendment would give employees legal recourse against viewpoint discrimination, potentially deterring employers from bowing to pressure from activist groups or public opinion. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and, in extreme cases, the Justice Department could also take enforcement actions for such instances of surrendering to public pressure.

Currently, four states and the District of Columbia have some form of viewpoint-discrimination protections in their laws, but 46 states do not. Additionally, people employed by the government, who are protected by the First Amendment, have free-speech protections, subject to certain limits. The proponents of the amendment argue that it is unfair for those in the private economy to be left without such protections.

The effects of this legal gap are not limited to employment decisions. Across the country, the ability of activist groups to block or ruin the careers of their opponents has created a climate of fear and repression, particularly among young people.

The proposed amendment is gaining support from various political perspectives, with the exception of the extreme left and the libertarian fringe. Supporters argue that the amendment is necessary to protect the foundational right to freedom of speech, which they believe is essential for a functioning democracy.

Michael Schwartz, of counsel at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, has expressed his support for the amendment. The views expressed are his own.

Title: Michael Oren: Boston Bombing Aimed to Instill Fear and Inflict Trauma, but Communities Refuse to Submit

Article:

Israeli Ambassador to the United States, Michael Oren, has stated that the bombing in Boston was an act intended to instill fear and inflict trauma, with the purpose of forcing communities to forfeit their freedom. Oren, speaking in the aftermath of the horrendous attack on the Boston Marathon, emphasized that both the American and Israeli societies, which value their freedom, must refuse to succumb to fear.

Oren highlighted the resilience of the people of Boston, who were celebrating liberty's birthday on the day of the bombing. He pointed out that communities, caregivers, police, security forces, elected leaders, and volunteers can unite during such times to block terrorists from achieving their objectives. While taking all possible measures to prevent further loss of life, the ambassador stressed the importance of refusing to forfeit one's way of life.

Oren acknowledged the emotional damage inflicted on countless citizens by the attack, but also emphasized the healing process that begins when first responders rush to assist the fallen. He noted the acts of selflessness displayed by the heroic first responders, athletes, and countless others in the aftermath of the attack, which serve as a reminder of the American spirit and its capacity to overcome terror and emerge stronger.

The ambassador concluded by expressing solidarity with the bereaved and the injured, and reiterating the importance of remembering the victims while refusing to be victimized. Oren's remarks underscored the shared experiences of the United States and Israel in dealing with terrorism, and the determination of both nations to defend their democratic liberties and remain vigilant and resolute in the face of such attacks.

Title: Mexican President Responds to U.S. Tariff Threat, Sends Foreign Minister to Washington

Article:

Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, commonly referred to as AMLO, has expressed his desire to avoid a confrontation with the United States but has criticized President Donald Trump's plan to impose tariffs on Mexican goods as a "fallacy." In a public letter released on Thursday, López Obrador announced that he is sending his foreign minister to Washington, D.C., on Friday to negotiate with U.S. officials ahead of a June 10 deadline set by Trump.

In a Thursday tweet, Trump stated that on June 10, the United States will impose a 5% tariff on all goods coming into the country from Mexico until the illegal migration issue is resolved. Trump's tweet also stated that the tariff will escalate by 5 percentage points each month, reaching 25% by October 1, if the illegal immigration problem is not remedied.

In response to Trump's statements, AMLO said, "With all due respect, although you have the right to express it, 'America First' is a fallacy because, until the end of times, even beyond national borders, justice and universal fraternity will prevail."

Trump defended his proposal in Friday morning tweets, blaming Mexico and congressional Democrats for the migrant problems on the border. "Mexico has taken advantage of the United States for decades," Trump tweeted, claiming that "Mexico makes a FORTUNE from the U.S." and "they can easily fix this problem."

In another tweet, Trump claimed that companies would leave Mexico to avoid the tariffs, but it should not come to that. "Mexico must take back their country from the drug lords and cartels," he said in a tweet. "The Tariff is about stopping drugs as well as illegals!"

Trump did not define what a sufficient solution would be to stop the wave after wave of Central American migrants journeying through Mexico to reach the U.S. southern border. According to Border Patrol data, U.S. Border Patrol agents have apprehended more than 280,000 migrants entering the country illegally who are minors or members of family units during the first seven months of the 2019 fiscal year. Of those, 97% are from El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras, and only 3% are from Mexico.

In his written statement, Trump also said, "Workers who come to our country through the legal admissions process, including those working on farms, ranches, and in other businesses, will be allowed easy passage."

In his public letter responding to Trump, López Obrador said Mexico is already doing what it can to stop the migration, and added that "social problems are not solved with duties or coercive measures." He also told Trump, "Please, remember that I do not lack valor, that I am not a coward nor timorous but rather act according to principles."

Citing the United States' history as a nation of immigrants, López Obrador also told Trump, "The Statue of Liberty is not an empty symbol."

Title: President Trump Announces Winners of Self-Proclaimed 'Fake News' Awards

Article:

President Donald Trump unveiled the winners of his self-proclaimed 'Fake News' awards on Wednesday via Twitter, with The New York Times and CNN leading the list of alleged inaccurate news reports. The list, published on GOP.com, cited studies indicating that over 90 percent of the media's coverage of President Trump is negative.

The list, titled "The 2017 Fake News Awards," placed The New York Times' Paul Krugman in first place for his prediction that the stock markets would never recover from Trump's election. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed above 26,000 for the first time on Wednesday, marking a significant increase since Trump's inauguration.

ABC News' Brian Ross came in second place for his botched report that Trump advised former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn to make contact with Russian officials during the 2016 campaign. The list also highlighted four instances of alleged inaccurate reporting by CNN, including a false report that Trump had early access to "hacked documents" from WikiLeaks, a video suggesting Trump overfed fish during a visit with the Japanese prime minister, and a report that former FBI Director James Comey would deny saying Trump was told he was not under investigation.

The Times appeared on the list again for a false report that the Trump administration hid a report on climate change. Newsweek also received an award for a report that Polish First Lady Agata Kornhauser-Duda did not shake Trump's hand. CNN's report that former FBI Director James Comey would dispute President Trump's claim he was told he was not under investigation was also on the list.

The Times, CNN, and Newsweek all acknowledged their "awards" via Twitter. The final "winner" on the list, as Trump described it, was "RUSSIA COLLUSION!," with the president stating, "Russian collusion is perhaps the greatest hoax perpetrated on the American people. THERE IS NO COLLUSION!"

The website carrying the results of the "Fake News Awards" crashed due to high traffic after Trump tweeted out the link. Trump also tweeted his praise for "many great reporters" and acknowledged that there is "despite some very corrupt and dishonest media coverage, there are many great reporters I respect and lots of GOOD NEWS for the American people to be proud of!"

Below is the full list of winners of the 2017 Fake News Awards:

1. The New York Times' Paul Krugman claiming markets would 'never' recover from a Trump presidency
2. ABC News' Brian Ross' bungled report on former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn
3. CNN's false reporting of the Trump campaign having early access to hacked documents from WikiLeaks
4. TIME's report that Trump removed a bust of Martin Luther King, Jr. from the Oval Office
5. The Washington Post's Dave Weigel tweeting that Trump's December rally in Pensacola, Fla., wasn't packed with supporters
6. CNN's video suggesting Trump overfed fish during a visit with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe
7. CNN's report that Polish First Lady Agata Kornhauser-Duda did not shake Trump's hand
8. CNN's report that former FBI Director James Comey would dispute President Trump's claim he was told he was not under investigation
9. The New York Times' report that the Trump administration had hidden a climate-change study
10. In Trump's words, "RUSSIA COLLUSION! Russian collusion is perhaps the greatest hoax perpetrated on the American people. THERE IS NO COLLUSION!"

Title: Iowa Senate Race Remains Tight as Ernst and Braley Battle for Undecided Voters

Article:

The latest poll in the Iowa Senate race indicates that the contest remains close, with a margin of two points separating Republican Joni Ernst and Democrat Bruce Braley. According to a Quinnipiac University poll released Wednesday, Ernst leads Braley 45-43, a lead that falls within the poll's margin of error.

The race between Ernst and Braley could potentially shift the balance of power in Washington, as Republicans are favored to take back the Senate in the upcoming midterm elections. The results from the survey of 967 likely voters in Iowa echo two other nonpartisan polls this month, which also showed Ernst with a narrow one- to two-point edge.

As the election day approaches on November 4, both candidates will focus on winning over undecided voters and the 10 percent of likely voters who stated they could still change their minds. The poll reveals a significant shift in independent support, with Braley converting a seven-point deficit in Quinnipiac's September poll into a five-point lead among independents. Braley now leads independents 48% to Ernst's 43%.

Braley also continues to gain support among women, leading his female GOP opponent by a 13-point margin. Ernst, on the other hand, maintains her lead among men at 56% to Braley's 39%.

"Voters are choosing partisanship over gender when it comes to making their ballot choice," Quinnipiac University Polling Director Peter Brown said in a release.

Ernst may also benefit from the expected strong performance of Republican Governor Terry Branstad, who has a 15-point lead according to the Quinnipiac poll.

Title: NBC's Portrayal of Obama's ISIS Interview as "Very Candid" Sparks Controversy

Article:

In a recent interview with 60 Minutes, President Barack Obama discussed the U.S.'s handling of the Islamic State (ISIS) threat in the Middle East. On Monday, NBC's Today show presented the interview as a "very candid" admission by the President, but the portrayal has sparked controversy due to the President's apparent attempts to distance himself from blame.

Co-host Matt Lauer opened the show by stating, "Underestimated. The President admits his administration and U.S. intelligence officials misjudged the threat of ISIS." However, a soundbite of the President later in the show showed him distancing himself from blame, saying, "I think they underestimated what had been taking place in Syria."

Later in the show, Lauer introduced the story, stating, "President Obama acknowledging in a new interview that U.S. officials underestimated ISIS and overestimated the ability of the Iraqi army to take on the terror group." NBC's chief foreign correspondent Richard Engel reported that the President blamed the former U.S.-backed Iraqi government for allowing ISIS to flourish and said American intelligence did not fully appreciate the threat.

However, The Daily Beast's Eli Lake criticized Obama's attempt to blame the intelligence community for dropping the ball on ISIS. In an interview with The Daily Beast after Obama's interview aired, a former senior Pentagon official who worked closely on the threat posed by Sunni jihadists in Syria and Iraq was reportedly flabbergasted, saying, "Either the president does not read the intelligence he's getting or he's bullshitting."

NBC's chief foreign affairs correspondent Andrea Mitchell also dismantled the President's claims of being in the dark about ISIS on August 10 on Meet the Press. On September 3, Engel himself appeared on Mitchell's MSNBC show and explained that the President's claim of having no strategy for Syria was "quite ridiculous" given the buildup of ISIS had been well-documented for over three years.

Given NBC's own reporting on how Obama knew about the ISIS build-up all along, the network's description of the President passing the blame as "very candid" has been met with criticism. On ABC's Good Morning America on Monday, co-host George Stephanopoulos tried to push similar spin regarding Obama's remarks to 60 Minutes, but White House correspondent Jon Karl called out the presidential blame game.

CBS This Morning led with a clip of Obama's exchange with 60 Minutes correspondent Steve Kroft, then at the top of the 8 a.m. ET hour brought on Wisconsin Congressman Paul Ryan to offer criticism of the President's handling of ISIS. After Ryan pointed out "colossal mistakes in our Iraq and Syria policy that led to this emergence of ISIS," co-host Charlie Rose pinned the blame on the President.

Here is a full transcript of Engel's September 29 report on Today:

[Transcript not provided]

The controversy surrounding NBC's portrayal of Obama's interview highlights the ongoing debate over the U.S.'s role in the Middle East and the handling of the ISIS threat.
